description:
I've always had my eye on a visit here for a very long time, but I never really did so until very recently. I went in with a friend one day because we were feeling curry that day. It was pretty cramped when we came in, and it seems to be more of a takeout place since there weren't more than a dozen seats if I remember correctly. 

Since we got there near closing time, they ran out of the pork katsu curry, and we got the chicken katsu curry over rice instead. I ordered mine with the maximum spice level, since I like my curry spicy in general. One thing to note is that my friend ordered the same dish and we got it to eat inside, and I got my order on a plate while he got his in a to-go container, which is probably attributable to them not having enough people to wash dishes and it piling up. I don't fault them for that, but I did think that this is a very fast paced place. I thought the chicken curry was pretty good, and I'm not a huge fan of chicken in general. 

I came back another time because I was intrigued by their noodle dishes, and I got the spicy udon, which is the spicy ground beef curry udon, which had a more thicker base. I always thought that thicker curry and udon went well together, and I was very pleased with spicy noodle. The portion were a bit small for the spicy noodle, but still filling if you take your time to eat. Slightly prefer the chicken curry over the spicy noodle because of the chicken katsu.

I haven't had a chance to taste the croquettes yet, and I could see myself coming back here to try their other curry noodle dishes. Overall, a solid four for FiDi, and I look forward to coming back here. Highly recommended since there's not really another place like this nearby.
author: Nelson X.

description:
So my first review was a little unfair and I gave this place 2 stars? 

I'm stepping off my high horse and actually appreciate this place for what it is.  This place is quaint, the pork katsu is delicious, and I haven't had a problem with their service. Like I said in my previous review,  this place is small.  Order take out and go to a nearby park and enjoy your outdoor lunch!

There aren't that many Japanese curry place downtown (this might be the only one...but correct me if I'm wrong).
author: Benjamin B.

description:
Muracci's has been on my list of places to try, so when I was in the area for work, I decided to stop by for lunch. Muracci's can probably fit less than 5 people comfortably combined with the customers waiting for their takeout orders. I ordered the chicken katsu curry, which comes with a heaping portion of rice, curry, chicken katsu, and a small portion of their house pickles. I opted for the mild curry and the spiciness level was great! You can choose between mild, medium, or hot. The chicken katsu curry is almost $13, which is expensive in my opinion and somewhat slightly off-putting.

Honestly, it was just okay! The chicken katsu was slightly dry, not seasoned very well and the curry tasted slightly off; I can't really pinpoint what it was. Maybe it was burnt? I had leftovers, but I didn't finish them.

If you want a good plate of chicken katsu curry, go to Bhugay's in Oakland! They are always consistent and never disappoint
author: Joyce E.

description:
Instant fan. Had my first meal here on a Monday afternoon, around 1:10 pm. The line wasn't out the door as many people have experienced at lunch time, but a number of people had already ordered and were waiting for their food. But the line moves fast here and the food comes fast, too.

I went with the karaage curry, hot, with white rice ($12.45) and extra rice ($3.00). I also got the curry pan ($3.50) and learned from the cashier that the type of curry pan on offer changes daily. The Monday special was chicken. I bought a piece of the strawberry roll cake, as well ($2.45). My boyfriend got the katsu don ($11.20).

Seating here is extremely limited, so everything is served in to-go packaging in case you more than likely need to take your food elsewhere because there's nowhere to sit. Luckily my boyfriend and I grabbed the tiny table for two around the corner from the cashwrap and got to eat in peace, out of the way of waiting guests.

I was surprised how big my plate of food was; this doesn't happen to me very often, but I actually ended up getting two meals out of this plate. Admittedly, I felt that there could've been a few mores pieces of karaage, but getting lunch and dinner out of one meal made up for that in my mind. I appreciated that the curry sauce was in its own separate container and I could add it to the plate according to my own preference. The curry was delicious and spicy, but wasn't overwhelmingly hot. The chicken was cooked well and juicy on the inside.

My boyfriend felt his katsu don was solid all around and a hefty amount of food for the price, though his only complaint was that the bowl is served with a lid. That causes the contents of the bowl to steam a bit, so the katsu isn't as crispy as it could be, which might be a bigger issue if you're taking your food to-go.

I wish we'd ordered two of the curry pan because that was so good. The bread was a little crisp, golden, and the chicken curry on the inside was well flavored. I ate the cake for dessert with dinner and thought it was a good amount of sweet without being sickeningly so, and the cake was soft and spongy.

All in all, a very impressive first impression from Muracci's for me. I really can't wait to go back and get more curry, and definitely order more than one curry pan. If you can, show up after noon to avoid the line-out-the-door lunch rush, though it seems like there's going to be a number of people here no matter what time you show up. With good reason! Fantastic meal.
author: Angela M.

description: Came here to order to go during lunch rush hour. The line came be pretty long and the wait for the food was around 15 minutes. I ordered the katsu curry and honestly, it was just meh... The meat was thinly sliced and there was too much rice. However, the curry itself was pretty good. Lot's of flavor.
author: Jenna W.

description:
OH MY GOD!!! Guys this place!!! Small little shop, be prepared to take your food and go somewhere else to sit. But it's totally worth it. Once you walk in you can smell the spices and your mouth will start to salivate. 

I was in Japan last year and had their curry and fell in love. Ever since I've been looking for a place that has, and have had no lunch. Today I check this place out while in Cali for work and it made my day!!! 

I got the Katsu Curry (pork cutlet) and it was DELICIOUS! The curry sauce was sooo goood. The perfect amount of spice for me. They even give you the radishes on the side just like Japan. Don't skip out on this place!
author: Nancy M.

description:
Came here for lunch while I was in San Francisco for work. It was a cold day and I was craving something warm and filling. When I got to the place, there was a pretty big line. Overall it moved relatively fast, but would not recommend if you're in a time crunch. 

For a first time, I probably just should've tried the katsu that they're known for. I went with the chicken karaage curry. Also tried one of the curry pans with beef while I was waiting. 

The curry pan was pretty good but could've have something a bit more substantive inside. 

For the actual meal, the pickled veggies that came inside were very good. The rice was a bit on the soft side. The chicken was over fried and a bit burnt and the curry was far too salty. Prices were not bad for SF given the portion size. Would maybe come back to try the katsu but was not over the moon for the curry.
author: Ashtar B.

description:
After eating multiple meals of curry throughout Japan I had a major curry craving. Thankfully I was at an event near Union Square with some friends so we stopped by for dinner and OH MY GOD I forgot how good this place is. I've been super bummed since Charley Noodles wanted their lease back and Muraccis closed their Los Altos location. 

Portions are large and generous and the katsu is cooked perfectly and the pieces they give are gigantic. Homemade tsukemono was amazing to pair with it. 

Must visit. Every. Single. Time. I. Am. In. Union. Square.
author: Vicky L.

description:
Absolutely delicious Japanese curry and gyudon!

The beef curry is some of the best in The City. 

Very very small restaurant in the financial district with seating for 4-6 people. A little bit dingy on the inside but the food is incredible. Be prepared it's not fast food - it typically takes about 10 minutes to get your order during the lunch rush and there's usually a line out the door. But the wait is absolutely worth it.
author: Dave K.

description:
Small restaurant with very few seats. 

Chicken curry was good - chicken was crispy and the curry sauce was well made. The gyudon was also delicious, and the serving sizes were adequate as well.

With that said, it is a bit pricey for a curry place. But given that the other good option, Volcano Curry, is rather far away, this is a good choice if you're near the FiDi/Chinatown area. Just don't expect to get a seat and be prepared to eat somewhere else.
author: John L.

description: Decent curry spot but my pork cutlet was a bit dry. The breading is nicely done. I added potatoes (good) and vegetables (a bit raw / underdone) and egg (overpriced). I'm sure it's one of SF's top shops but NYC has it beat.
author: Tiffany T.

description:
Sadly did not live up to the hype :(
I got the chicken katsu curry which at most places that serve Japanese curry should be standard to make. The panko layer was very thin where it was falling off (picture included). Additionally the chicken was pretty dry, maybe I should of tried the pork. The curry itself was good, not as sweet in comparison to other places I've tried but still good. It's probably one of the top places to get Japanese curry in FiDi, but if you are to venture to other parts of the city there definitely better. Also considering during the lunch rush you wait 20+ minutes and this is what you get, it's overall not worth it.
author: Victoria C.

description:
I finally gave this place a try and wish I didi't! This is possibly the worst Japanese curry I've had in a while. It should be a crime to call this Japanese curry!

We ordered delivery through Caviar. 
1) Beef Curry ($10.95): Just take a look at my photo! Yeah, I know! Where is the beef? And what is this pathetic diluted watery curry sauce? It also came with gingers for sushi. Why? Beats me! And you can't just add chili powder and call it "spicy." Really stingy on the amount of curry sauce they give you as well. 

2) Karaage Lunch Set ($11.75): Burnt and unappetizing. The chicken was bitter and tough. The only thing we could eat was lettuce and tomato, which no cooking was involved. The salad dressing was good and that's about it. I didn't even want to try the potato salad or the miso soup. 

The food was cold and felt like they were left outside for a long time. We took couple bites and threw them away. It was so gross and disgusting. 

I grew up in Japan and was really looking forward to this place. It was supposed to be comfort food for me. What a huge disappointment! Honestly, the curry in a pouch that you can buy at an Asian supermarket tastes better than this! 

I'm honestly surprised by all the good reviews. Perhaps they were good in the olden days?! In any case, I will never order food from here again. What a waste of money!

We are going to look for real good now :(
author: Alice L.

description:
Probably one of my favorite casual places to eat in the city, especially with its central location. Muracci's curry is super flavorful without being overpowering and the spices give you just the right amount of kick. Their curry plates are my go-to, particularly the pork or chicken katsu! 

Would definitely come here multiple times a week if I could!
author: Lydia S.

description:
Based on two visits, both to-go orders, I give Muracci's a 4-star rating. I grew up on Japanese curry, so that's always my go to.
The funny thing is, the first time I was here I ordered Katsudon instead of curry. I've definitely had better Katsudon before, but I would still say it's slightly above average in this area.
My last visit I ordered the Mild Katsu Curry. I was expecting it to be on the sweeter side, but it actually was not. They give you a pretty generous amount of curry to pour on top of your tonkatsu and rice.  Again, I've definitely had much better curry before, but it was pretty good. It's better than the Korean/Japanese restaurant's curry inside the international food court across the street.
Both visits were during the lunchtime rush, so it's super packed inside the restaurant. You definitely do not want to eat inside as you'll be squished to death.
At about $12-$13 per meal, I probably wouldn't come back super often, but maybe once in a while when I need my curry fixing.
author: Mike O.

description:
Came here on a Wednesday right before they opened at 11am, which was a good idea since this place got busy quickly.

$13 for chicken katsu curry (medium spicy) on white rice. Comes with cabbage and pickled radish. They have cups for water if you plan to dine in. The curry was not very spicy at medium, and tasted just okay. This is the first Ive had chicken breast used in my chicken katsu, usually restaurants use thigh meat and the meat is tender. The chicken breast inside the unusually thick breading was thin and dry. 

They do have a lot of options on their menu and a variety of pastries in their display case next to the register but I do not recommend their chicken katsu curry here.

P.s. we wanted to try the Curry Pan but the lady who makes it decided not to come in today.
author: Amy T.

description:
An update review just to show my photo for the Katsu Curry $12-$13... but my favorite for Katsu Curry goes to Volcano

Still 4 stars because Beef Udon here is bomb and it'll be my to-go item when I visit here
author: Yeanne L.

description:
Came here on a weekday during lunch hours and the line was pretty long. One of the workers talks to each of us while we're in line to get our order so when we get to the cashier, all we have to do is give them the order sheet and pay. Waiting for the food to get cooked took about 10-15 minutes.

I ordered the Chicken Katsu Curry and was expecting crispy batter on the outside and tender juicy chicken on the inside. However, the chicken meat was pretty tough and rubbery. It was like chewing on a rubber band. I've ordered from here last year and I remember it being good, so I have no idea what happened in this instance. I rarely come here for lunch, but now I probably won't come back here anymore after this experience.
author: Wesley S.

description:
I finally ended up coming to this restaurant due to my craving for udon. There didn't seem to be any other udon place close by, so decided to try this place. I'm so happy I did! The food was delicious!

Curry udon-It was very tasty and nicely fulfilled my udon craving. There were thin beef slices inside, which were yummy. It was a pretty large bowl and left me really full.

The whole restaurant is very small, with only seating for around 6 people. The cashier was super nice and helpful, offering suggestions when customers were unsure of their orders. I came by for dinner, so it wasn't crazy busy, though I'll assume that the lunch time rush would be crazier.
author: Elaine Z.

description:
This is one of the places in the Fidi that I've been meaning to try and have walked/ran by a million times but just never tried for some reason.

Finally...finally the line wasn't that bad and I got in a "shorter" line and I was impressed.

I got the :
Chicken Katsu Curry

The breaded Katsu was delcious but what makes the meal is  the savory/tasty curry which they give you a hearty/generous portion of in a plastic container. It was so good and you can liberally pour it over your Katsu/rice as your darn well please.

I'm not a Japanese Chicken Katsu fan per say but like any good venue this place has made me a fan of their version despite my previous attitude towards the food.  

Get there early since the line at this place gets long quickly.
author: Rod M.

description:
Muracci's, you're like my best frenemy. 

I love you because your curry is actually very delicious, but I hate you because all your delicious foods are fried. 

I usually get the chicken katsu over white rice (because let's face it, brown rice is hard to adjust to when you've been eating white your entire life). You can adjust the level of spiciness as well. The katsu is crisply breaded and yet stilll tender and juicy. The little red pickles they throw in, those things are so yummy. 

The place would be described as "hole in the wall" and there are 3 or 4 bar stools at the front that you could sit on to eat your food.
author: Nicole H.

description:
I know I'm late to the party.  Better late than never though, because I loved the food I had from Muracci's.  Since this was my first time there, I kind of went all out and ordered two items.

Karaage Curry -- http://bit.ly/2BybPWh
Huge well fried chicken karaage pieces and the curry had a good thickness to it.

Gyu-Don  -- http://bit.ly/2BChJpq
A very beefy bowl.  As it should be.  No complaints here, this was really good!  Next time I hope to add a runny fried egg to it.

Unfortunately, I came in during peak lunch time so all the seats were taken so I had to order my food to-go and reheat them when I got home.  They were both still delicious even after reheating, but I would've loved to have experienced eating the hot food straight out of the kitchen.  Maybe next time I'll arrive earlier to grab a seat.

One thing that was awkward was that I had to repeat my order to the cashier 3 times.  She was probably new but the fact that she didn't know what Karaage Curry was or couldn't understand me made the customer service experience a little awkward for me.

Best Japanese Curry?  That's still up for debate for me.  I still like the curry from Kaz and Usagi from San Mateo and On The Bridge as my top 3 favorites.  But I'd say Muracci's is slightly better than JapaCurry which is still a high compliment from me.  I would still come by again in a heartbeat if I was in the area and they were open.
author: Rodney H.

description:
Pretty good Japanese curry. My chicken katsu curry came with a large chicken breast that was perfect breaded, white rice (option to pick brown), and pickled veggies. I got mine to go and they did a great and separating the curry in a container. 

I know now why there are so many reviews. 4 stars because it's a bit pricey $14 for my order without a drink.
author: R T.

description:
Came here for lunch on a Friday around 1:30PM. I've been wanting to try it for a while because of the lines and great Yelp reviews! 

Service: Awesome service here! I got helped quickly and the food was ready in only a few minutes. When I ordered the tofu and veggie curry- the cashier offered two broths one was with meat broth and one vegetable- so obviously being vegetarian I got the veggie broth option. So happy they have a completely vegetarian meal! I always worry that places lie about it being veggie broth though... 

Food: I got the tofu and veggie curry with brown rice, medium spice, and vegetarian broth. I'm usually not the biggest fan of huge tofu hunks- but the tofu here is really good and soaks up the curry sauce perfectly. Medium spice was perfectly spicy for me! 

Overall they give big portions, average price (for SF), and tasty curry!! I want to come back and try the sushi rolls too.
author: Hayley D.

description:
Would recommend and would come back again.
I tried and recommend the Tofu and Vegetable Curry.
Service was good and quick enough.
Limited Seating.

The Curry is the star here...so I'll start there.  I ordered it Medium Spicy.  Very flavorful and the consistency was spot on.  I didn't want to go with anything too heavy (i.e. Katsu) so I got the Tofu with Vegetable in the Regular Curry (chicken stock based?).  They do have a Vegetarian based Curry.  Tofu and Vegetables were cooked perfectly (not soggy, fresh and crisp).  Loved the Pickled Vegetables that came with it.

Look forward to dining here again; maybe try one of the Katsus.  Would definitely recommend it if you have a hankering for Japanese Curry.
author: Brandon S.

description: This is a small place with really good Japanese Curry. It might be a good take-out places for lunch. But we went there for quick dinner and the dinning experience is just alright because the tables and seats were both so tiny. And there's a trash can right next to one of the seat. Overall a good place I will buy food from.
author: Yanzhong L.

description: Food was great but experience was less than stellar. Came here many years ago and wanted to bring kids. However, service was slow, space was tight, and spiciness level not as advertised. I like my food spicy so not a big deal to me personally, but my kids are sensitive so when something is labeled "mild, not spicy" it shouldn't have any heat at all.  Seems like all their food leans on the spicier side. Great food overall but everything else is a bit lacking.
author: George W.

description: Some of the best Japanese curry (and curry pan - !!) I've had in the city.
author: Joshua D.

description:
The Japanese Curries here are okay. At around $12 each, they are a little bit on the pricy side, but given that they are in the Financial District/Chinatown area, I guess the price and quality makes a lot of sense.

I'm used to the delicious curries from SoCal, so having the curry here made me realize how much better they are down there. I had the spicy curry, and it really wasn't all that spicy, so if you like any heat, I'd go straight to the spicy. 

The curry itself was kind of boring, it tasted like a slightly nicer version of the curry you could get from an instant Japanese curry block packet. I had the Tonkatsu one, and the tonkatsu was a little dry and overcooked, which was disappointing. 

The amount of rice you get is also a little lacking, wish there was more control over the options.

Overall, it can hit the spot if you have a big craving, but I'd rather eat at home for this quality.
author: Tyler T.

description:
I was really excited to eat here because I love Japanese curry and this had 4 stars on Yelp with 1500 reviews. Really promising, right?

Well, I'm sad to say that I was extremely disappointed with the curry here. The curry croquet we got was good, but the katsu curry was awful. The actual curry itself was thin, watery, flavorless, and had a "burnt" smell to it. I don't think I've ever tasted worse curry. The katsu itself was fine, no complaints, but nothing to write home about either.

This place doesn't really have much service or atmosphere so all the focus for the dining experience is on the food, and Muracci's didn't deliver on that front. We went on Saturday for lunch however, so I'm not sure if they have a different chef during the weekdays, when it's most popular. 

Might be willing to try this again during a weekday, but for now I can't recommend this place when there are decent Japanese curry options available in the Bay Area.
author: Jacob Y.

description: Hole in the wall close to where I used to work. Was a regular stop despite the long lines. The curry and the chicken katsu are great.
author: Sunil R.

description:
I was visting SF again recently. Just wanted to mention the Chicken Katsu Curry is still as amazing as I remembered it and this time I got to eat it with a view! YUM! 

Alas, still on a hunt in NYC to find a place that makes chicken katsu curry as delicious as Muracci's does.
author: Sargam B.

description:
Came at around 11:30 and I think I barely missed the crazy lunch time. There was already a line when I came, but it was super long after I left with my food at around 12. 

It's really small and crammed inside and there's not really a place to stand and wait for your food. I did notice that some people ordered the food in advance, so maybe I'll try that service next time to save myself 30 minutes. 

I got the beef curry and I thought it was pretty good. The curry was nice and thick, but the spice level was too spicy for me. I only asked for mild spiciness, but it still had a pretty big kick to it. I also paid $2.25 extra for a hard boiled egg. Yeah....that wasn't really the best bang for the buck. So don't do that unless you really want the egg.

The pricing is right around the standard for lunch in SF downtown. I uploaded a picture of the menu, but I know you can see the most recent menu on their website. 

The staff was super positive despite the restaurant being super hot inside and the it being so packed. So kudos to them!
author: Victor L.

description:
Wow! Japan curry in SF!
Locals & Japanese visitors eat here & the meals are all very addicting!! Not much room or seating but the Katsu, Curry & Udon is why we are here!
Maybe some Day they will expand but for now our Muracci's is a golden heart string of deliciousness!
Thank you for such great authentic Japanese curry like I had in Niseko Japan!
author: Rachel C.

description: What a gem. We got the chicken katsu curry (white meat) and the grilled salmon. It was nice to see someone offering grilled salmon curry for those who are trying to be a bit more healthy. Very generous portions for under $13/person and delicious curry sauce. The place only has a few seats and one small table so it is best suited for takeaway.
author: Eric W.

description:
I got the Pork Katsu Curry. It was really yummy, only wish was that they give you a little more pork  but it was perfectly cooked, nice and crunchy! Medium spice was a bit spicier than I thought it would be, if you're not sure I would err on the side on caution and order one spice level down. 
Not much space inside to eat, plan to take it to go.
author: Sonya G.

description:
4.5 star curry with 5 star service!

The food here is solid. The curry is super flavorful and delicious. It's less sweet than the curry your would get at Curry House, and it's a bit spicier as well. I had the Pork Katsu which was cooked perfectly- the meat was not overly done and was super tender. Even the rice at Muracci's is really good. 

The restaurant is a total hole in the wall joint and easy to overlook. It can get crowded and there aren't a lot of seats. The service is quick and friendly, and the owner knows how to take care of his customers. 

I'll definitely be back next time I'm in SF!
author: Emily C.

description: One word: legit! Reminds me of Tani's Kitchen in Daly City. The curry is just a little chunky. Rich flavors. The medium has a good kick, just enough to tickle the throat. The chicken katsu was perfectly fried, not dried up inside. And they offer brown rice as a base!
author: Stephen Y.

description:
Very pricey for below average food - overt dry chicken katsu - less in quantity and quality!
Sad looking plate for $12-13
author: Geena N.

description:
Muracci is much better than most options in the financial district but is not as good compared to other curry places in the bay area.  A lot of it for me is due to personal preference as I find the curry thin and lacking in flavor.

The prices are reasonable for what you get but the location is small and lines around lunch-time run long.  There's not a lot of curry places in FiDi or Chinatown so if you're looking for japanese curry that's slightly more health conscious, this is your best bet.
author: Mark C.

description:
I get a biweekly craving for curry, so I tried really hard to love Muracci's, hoping it to be my go to place near work.

Pork Katsu Curry: I ordered this dish multiple times here as this is one of my favorite dish in general.. However, each time it disappointed my cravings. First time I ordered it, the pork was super dry and the katsu itself was not too tasty. I thought I came on an off day and was willing to give another try. And another try. And another try. Ordered it 3 more times, and it confirmed that I will not be ordering it again as they were consistently super dry and tough and chewy. The reason I gave it multiple tries is because the katsu was crunchy, which I like, and the curry that came in a separate container was delicious.

Chicken Katsu Curry: it was actually a little better than the pork katsu because the chicken meat was not dry in the middle. 

Spicy Noodle: I finally found a winner here. This spicy curry deliciousness was finally able to satisfy my cravings! I slurped all the udon coated in curry and ground meat in less than 10 minutes.

I will not be ordering any of the katsu dishes again, but might be back to try other dishes and update my review because some of them do look really delish.
author: Solongo B.

description:
I thought this place was just okay. Nothing too special in my opinion.

I got the Chicken Katsu over Brown Rice with Mild Curry for lunch to-go. I ordered via Yelp with their Eat24 service and was able to apply a coupon so that was nice. Around $11 after taxes even with the coupon. When we got there around 12:10pm on a Friday, there was already a huge line from the lunch rush, but luckily since we had already ordered online, we were able to just go in and pick up our food. There's a shelf in the very back where all the online and phone orders were. You just look for your name, sign on the paper, leave the paper behind, and leave with your food. There's not much seating here so if you come here, expect to get your food to-go.

Back at the office, the Katsu wasn't as crunchy. I'm sure it's a little bit crunchier if you eat it right away. The mild curry did have a kick, but nothing too bad. My coworkers were suffering from their medium curry so I'm sure the medium curry is no joke. The chicken was a bit bland and even with the curry, it wasn't too outstanding. There weren't a lot of pieces of chicken and very little cabbage. There was however a LOT of rice. Just wish they had more meat or veggies compared to the substantial amounts of rice.

Overall this place was decent. Depending if you can eat a lot, this place may not fill you up. I wasn't full afterwards, but content. I wouldn't come out of my way to eat here, but I'd come if all my friends or coworkers wanted to come.
author: Alvin Y.

description:
Outstanding Katsu!  Fried to perfection with a super juicy center.  The curry is pretty good too.  Takes a bit to get your food but that's probably cause things are made to order which is always appreciated.  The service was friendly over the counter style.  Would definitely return for a nice bowl of curry udon with pork katsu. 

Food 4.5
Service 4
Overall 4
author: Patrick C.

description:
This is the best Japanese curry located outside of Japan. Hands down. Best.

It's a hole in the wall place with limited seating, but the food is worth the wait.
author: Mr. B.

description:
Hearty, satisfying, and ridiculously good. If you like spicy, you can't go wrong with their katsu + spicy curry for $12. 

The place is tiny and always packed. I was lucky enough to arrive right when they opened at 11 on a Thursday. By the time I left at 11:30, there was already a line out the door.
author: Kristen S.

description: The cashier dude is super friendly. And I got my order within a minute. But the katsu curry wasn't as good as I remembered. Maybe it's because I came over at 3pm. The katsu wasn't crispy at all. The temperature was pretty lukewarm too so I'm guessing it was because it was left over from lunch hour.
author: Iris H.

description:
Delicious! No wonder there are lines out the door. The line goes by fast!

I order the pork donburi and it's delicious! The meat is so juicy and everything has so much flavor. 

There isn't much room to sit down so I suggest picking up and eating elsewhere. Enjoy!
author: Carina M.

description:
The curry here was pretty solid, but I didn't find anything special about it. I ordered the katsu over white rice. What's nice about this place is that you have the option to pick between brown or white rice. I asked for a medium spiciness level, however it wasn't spicy at all. Instead I found the curry to be heavily seasoned, which kind of made it hard to enjoy my food. For that reason, I found myself barely drowning my katsu and rice in the curry. I wish I received more pickled vegetables because there was only a spoonful amount of it on my dish. I could barely taste the chicken from my katsu because it was practically 1/3 chicken 2/3 breading. 

For $13 though it will stuff you up. I shared this dish and I felt pretty content. The people here were very friendly. Very few seating if you plan on dining in.
author: Lisa T.

description:
Almost every Friday, I drop by at this small business in the midst of the colossal buildings in the financial district of SF. What's so special about this place that it is really an awdsome japanese curry spot. The curry is rich in flavor, and has a slow burn spiciness that doesn't overwhelm you right away but melts you in the inside like lava. 
The place is really small so it gets really cramped at times if you decide to eat there. The front workers are mostly Japanese and it's awesome to interact with them. I recommend the usual Katsu Curry to start things off.
author: Cy C.

description:
Came here for a quick bite before whiteboard-ing for UX! Figured this would be my second time with Japanese Curry (with Go Go being the first), and Muracci's happened to be around the corner.

At first, I was going to go with the special because you get soup and salad and lots of extras. But since it was a curry place, I was convinced to get the (non-special) curry instead. Alright!

The place itself is super small; with seating for maybe 8. This is a better place to-go if you have a nearby office as it gets crowded very quickly.

The food came, and the chicken was very crispy! The interior is juicy, though a bit plain for those who are really into their marinades. The curry itself was pretty decent, but lacks a punch that one might find at other places. I suppose this could be a personal preference, but I really like strong flavors.

It also came with rice and a tiny pickled salad; both were fine.

Overall, Muracci's is not a bad place for a lunch spot in the city, but not the best place to go if you're looking for authentic or trying to wow your friends (haha).
author: Greg G.

description:
Fast and solid comfort food in the downtown area. The restaurant only has a few tables so seating is limited however, service is prompt. 

I always get the pork katsu curry and am never disappointed. Japanese curry perfectly hits the spot on cold SF days (which tends to be often). The katsu is cooked perfectly and to a nice crisp without being too oily. I also recommend the medium level of spicy to get a good kick from the curry.
author: Kevin T.

description:
A great find in downtown SF! Super small hole in the wall, if you're  not looking carefully, you might even miss it.  I came here with a friend on a cold day and this really hit the spot.  We got the katsu curry and the karaage curry.  I had the karaage curry and it was a generous pile of deep fried chicken on a bed of brown rice (you can get white too!) and a side of curry.  I inhaled that plate because it was so delicious.  You can choose how spicy you want your curry.  I got medium and I thought it had just enough kick.  The kaarage was so juicy in the inside and crunchy on the outside and they REALLY don't skimp out.  

This restaurant is usually for pick-ups since it's nestled in the perfect area around a ton of businesses so if you're planning to eat here, be sure to come a little earlier/later to beat the lunch time rush.  There are about 7 seats in total.
author: Michelle B.

description:
Omg!! My colleagues always come here... So FridayI decided to come here with them. I ordered brown rice with curry... I ate it when I got home.OMGGGGG this was hellllllla good!!! I ate 1/2 Friday night, and I just finished it for lunch.. omg this was sooo great!! I'm in love y'all

Minus one star because the white rice was super sticky, and the brown rice was just weird....I ithink they should have basmati rice, or thai schented jasmine rice
author: Nickey H.

description:
Decent curry option for the area but the wait is always too long.

The curry is very watered down FYI, and not thick.

Maybe only 5 seats inside. A definite grab and go place.

Prices are fair for what you get. Wish they had Omurice.

It's kind of a cluster when you step in. If you go here once, you will get the system. But otherwise it may be too daunting to draw in new crowds because of its clustered line and ordering system.
author: Kay H.

description:
We saw a long line at this place and had to see what the fuss was about. The order line was pretty quick and Japanese lady was friendly. We ordered the mild beef curry, mild chicken curry, and mild chicken Katsu curry. The curry was delicious and agree with other reviews about this place. The only issue was that my order was wrong- I didn't have any chicken on my curry and the curry sauce for the katsu was spicy not mild like the other curry. I had it the order to go so I was not able to figure these issues out until I afterwards on my way to Sacramento. I was pretty bummed! 

I wouldn't mind trying this place out again though and give it a chance to redeem itself.
author: Holly A.

description: Chicken was on the dry side, curry was watery, overall it was very okay. People saying this is the best have for sure never stepped foot anywhere else. Starting to think SF yelpers have never ate anywhere else other than the bay. Only plus is that it's close to my office so maybe I'll come back if starving.
author: Nicholas W.

description: Good deals and selection of very flavorful japanese curries. I had a chicken karaage curry which is bit more heavily deep fried then their katsu chicken. Its over rice in a spicy brown gravy even the mildest medium has good kick to it. Lots of big chunks of crispy juicy dark meat chicken made for a filling dish. The spices they use are aromatic several of my jealous coworkers wanted to know what carry out I was eating. Service is very friendly and if you dine in they use good presentation for date nights vs the togo box.
author: Sean G.

description:
The restaurant is super small and tight,  I felt like I was cramming in a little bento box!  They have a restroom but it's really small and can get pretty rank during busy times, I would avoid it if you can. They do have hand sanitizer / soap

The food and service however is what stands out here. The curry bread (that comes in spicy or mild) , katsu curry with rice (on my list to try next time) and many soups. They give you 3 types of noodles (ramen, soba, udon) to choose as well and you can choose the spice level as well or add extra toppings, very customizable menu overall so props for that!  The owner is very down to earth, taking orders so you can get checked out at the cashier quickly and helping them if they need help. My friend had a difficult card to scan and the cashier tried a few times and the owner came to help. We had some mild kakuni curry ramen with boiled egg and cheese. It was delicious and one portion was huge and I enough to fill the both of us for the rest of the day! I went back to buy some curry bread and I hope to visit again soon to try some kasu curry chicken with rice. 

To success and nothing less,
Marilyn N.
author: Marilyn N.

description:
4 star because it's on the expensive side but totally understandable because of its location.

I got the chicken katsu curry with brown rice (hot). The chicken was perfectly cooked. It is moist and juicy on the inside, crunchy on the outside. The curry sauce is surprisingly hot but did not overpower the flavor. I hoped that the potatoes and carrots were included, and notadded for an additional charge.

The place is quite small, but we went an hour before closing on a Saturday so it wasn't packed.
author: Angelica P.

description:
Muracci's is a special little place in the heart of Chinatown and I make it a point to grab lunch from here every 2 weeks or so. 

The restaurant is super small and tight, and you always feel like you're cramming but they somehow make it work. They've also recently improved the ordering process where they take your order at the door and your food is ready by the time it's your turn to pay. This means that you don't have to spend a lot of time inside the store and that is a big win IMO. That being said, even if you have to stand in line for some time, it will be totally worthwhile. 

I usually get the Chicken Karaage or Katsu Curry 3X spicy with brown rice and extra curry (Japacurry fans beware; Muracci's is not on the same spice level scale. It's much much spicier!). Honestly, I'd suggest you start with the medium spice level if you can't handle red chili powder. It is this spicy since they add the raw powder on top of the curry which makes your tongue and throat burn since the curry hasn't been cooked with the chili (Trust me, it's totally worth it!!).

If you're in the area and reading this review, walk in the door right now. If you're not in the area and are reading this review, get an Uber and walk in the door right now.

PS - Special tip: Get the curry sandwiches they keep near the payment counter!
author: Gaurav K.

description:
I ordered the Chicken Katsu Curry ($11.95).

I was given about eight pieces of chicken strips. Each were about 1" in width and 2.5" in length. They were crunchy and tasted pretty good. 

Since I ordered to-go, I was given a separate curry container. I received so much curry! It covered half of the container (container was 3" in height with a diameter of about 4.5"). Even though I asked for mild, I found the curry to be a little spicy. The curry was more on the plainer side.

I was hoping for some vegetables in the dish (I do not include the pickled cabbage that made up the tiny corner of the container as a real vegetable). I did get a lot of rice though and was able to split the meal in half.

I have had better katsu places in the past. The chicken was good but I would not come back for the curry part.
author: Kristina M.

description: TASTE OF JAPAN !! Dragged around SanFran knowing the amount of Japanese food available but unable to find a phenomenal katsu kare was breaking my heart. But wondering around aimlessly i stumbled upon a gem. A wonderfully spiced curry not to thin and not to thick, with a succlent and freshly fried pork cutlet this katsu kare atop rice was perfection for me. Wanted a little more pickled items but it was fabulous. Although the young lady packaged mines up (was eating in house) i was content. Small space so do not always count on having a place to eat.
author: Brittanie W.

description: I went during lunch from work and got the chicken curry mild. It was very good, but it was a very small amount of meat in the actual curry sauce. While I went mild cause I thought I was afraid of it being to spicy, I would suggest doing the middle option cause the mild was a little bland for my liking. Other than that friend staff and fast service.
author: Shelby L.

description: I've visited this place numerous times and ordered delivery, and on 4 separate occasions, they forgot to put the katsu meat in to-go box. As a result, you open the box and it's just rice..At this point, I question if they are just careless or intentionally omitting the meat hoping customers don't notice until they get back to their desk. And if you're lucky enough to get actual food, it's mediocre and overpriced.
author: Chan K.

description: My favorite curry place in San Francisco. The size is almost decent for the price. It's on the pricier side around $10-13 but I think the curry is worth it. The food is prepared after you order so it's always fresh! The seating is very minimal so expect to order to go especially during lunch hours or if you're with a group.
author: Angelina W.

description:
Met my craving of Japanese curry. Their curry was so yum with chicken katsu and also fried chicken curry ban was so crunchy and soft. You can order level of the spiciness and rice. They also offer some mochi and rolls which look really cool but i haven't tried it yet. 

Next curry craving, i definitely come back to this place even the resto is so pack and few seats provided
author: Tiratiwan L.

description: A piece of glove in cabbage pickle. It was one of my favorite lunch place, but I won't go back this place.
author: Colet C.

description:
I decided to try Muracci's Japanese Curry & Grill for lunch a couple of days ago. It is located in the FiDi so as expected it is a small to-go place (there are like 3-4 chairs but good luck finding a seat during lunch hour). At the peak lunch hour there was a line that extended to the entrance of the restaurant next to it. I dutifully got in line and waited for my turn which came up in about 10-12 minutes.

The ordering process here is a little strange as you step into the restaurant there is a host at the door that takes your order, screams it to the people behind the counter and hands you a paper with the selections that you hand over to the person behind the counter, pay and try to find an empty spot to wait for your food.

I decided to get the Chicken Katsu Curry Rice ($11.45) and went with the normal steamed rice and hot level for the curry. After a cramped 10 minute wait I was finally on my way. The first thing I noticed was that they had packaged the curry separately which was a good start. The chicken katsu was a decent lunch sized portion. I felt that it had been in the fryer a tad bit too long making it a little crispier that what I'm normally used to. The meat was not dry but at the same time it was not juicy either. The rice was not sushi grade but was of a decent quality. The hot curry had a taste of raw spices. It felt like they had taken the base curry and just mixed in a lot of spices and sent it on its way as opposed to having prepared a separate hot curry (I may be wrong but that's just how it tasted). Overall I felt that this was an average dish, definitely not bad but not very good either.

Pricewise it was about 15% more expensive than L&L Hawaiian Barbecue and the Japanese restaurant in the Internation Food Court both of which are just across the road. Looking at the overall package of wait time (greater than 20 mins), quality of food (average) and price (high) the best I can rate this place would be A-OK. I may be back once in a while to mix things up.
author: Ahmad J.

description: Tried this places out because of all the yelp reviews and it's not as I suspected... the curry spicy and full of flavor for 12.55 I was hoping to be knocked off my feet with flavor, rice was soggy and weird. I got the beef curry and only had a few pieces of meat and a lot of sauce... I wanted to like this place and heard nothing but honestly I don't see what all the hype is about...
author: Sydney G.

description:
Muracci's is really a gem. Their curries are truly special and only around $12 a pop.  I got the Chicken Katsu Curry with white rice - probably the best Japanese curry I've ever had state-side. Note that they don't kid with the spice - I got medium and would rank it more like pretty spicy. If you like a kick, I'd recommend the mild. If you don't like spice, I'd recommend asking for no spice at all. 

I I also got a dorayaki, which was good but not as good as what you can get in Japantown. Unfortunately, the curry balls are usually out by late afternoon.
author: Judy S.

description:
Very good spot! Right next to Plentea, too, so dessert is covered!!

I had the katsudon. It was very good but the egg was a little on the salty side. The curry pan was tasty!! 
My dad got the curry udon which seemed good. I mean he ate all of it ‍

This place is more of a grab-and-go type! There's some seating but don't expect to fit your three siblings, five cousins, aunts, uncles, Grandma, and dog. There's probably about 12 seats. 

The service is efficient and the flavors are pretty spot-on! Give it a try!
author: Dom B.

description:
I like this place a lot but its small, very small. The staff here is very friendly and liked their attitude. Tried the curry and it was good but i would of preferred it to be more thicker. It was good nonetheless. Very flavorful. The place gets busy at lunch time and I arrived just after.  During this time, they ran out of the curry noodle :( but its okay. Overall, great food! Definitely, recommend it.
Pros: Food, staff
Cons: Small, busy
Stars: 4
author: Sunny L.

description:
Best Things: Katsu Curry (fried pork cutlet) w/ Rice, Chicken Katsu, Oyakodon (chicken + egg combo over rice)
Ambiance: Bustling hole in the wall, no room to sit, get to go
Price: $13, decent price for great lunch in the area
Additional Notes: Long line if you come during the rush

Katsu curry, a delicious Japanese comfort food in the business center of the city, is great for lunch, and in a delightful hole in the wall.

Muracci's is located in an unassuming hallway of a restaurant, shaped for a long line with little to no space for dining, and has quite the wait during rush hour. However the wait is a testament to the quality of their food. Their namesake, the curry, is great, and they also offer a wide variety of other Japanese dishes, such as oyakodon, which is also delicious. However, the Katsu curry is my dish of choice, a perfectly fried pork cutlet with tasty curry, and fluffy brown rice to go with it. It's a simple dish executed extremely well.

Most of the reasonably priced daily lunch places in the area are boring, stripped of character, and generally unremarkable, making Muracci's a step above most places in the area. Not the cheapest lunch place at around $13 a dish, and if you're looking for a sit down kind of place, look elsewhere. But Muracci's maintains flavor, taste, and style that feels consistent with the type of food it serves. As a whole, it's a flavorful, filling, and all around great place for lunch.
author: James H.

description:
Curry: 3.75/5
Katsu: 3.5/5
Amount: 2.5/5
Service: 2/5
Interior: 2.75/5

Curry was good, but nothing special. Wasn't hot though, as if it was just sitting out in the open for 20+ minutes waiting to be served.
Pork katsu was good, overall good blend of spices used, but had the same left problem with the curry: it wasn't hot.
Portion surprised me. The amount of pork katsu given was small.
Service... I said for here and they gave it to me to go. Smiles were nonexistent. No welcomes or thank you. 

Overall, this place is at a max 4.25/5 and that's under the conditions that you order to go & order at a time they make everything fresh.

Otherwise, my experience is gonna give them a 3/5.
author: Alvin D.

description:
A chicken schnitty on rice with some hot curry poured on top. Bloody fantastic. Who knew I was missing out on the wonders of the Chicken Katsu for so long.

Make sure to grab a Curry Pan while paying to gobble down while waiting for your number to be called. Basically a fried curry hot pocket version of your lunch!

Expect a bit of a wait during prime time although it isn't too bad. Also a little pricey if you start customizing with a boiled egg or veggies, but I can never stop myself.
author: Tristan L.

description: The chicken katsu curry was good. They give a generous amount of curry. I felt like the chicken katsu was lacking in taste, but with the curry and vegetables it was still good.
author: Kevin T.

description:
Love the spirit of this place and the curry. I'll go out of my way to come here. There's a wide variety of meats but I like the pork katsu and fried chicken curry. I got the pork belly once and there was too much fat and the meat was slightly dry. The place is tight so don't expect to necessarily eat there but there is bar stool type seating. 

How to best describe the curry. It's simple and liquidy.  They can increase the spicy-ness if needed. It's delicious. They also provided a few pickled vegetables which is nice. 

I saw ramen on the menu, but haven't tried that yet despite having eaten here like 10 times. One day.
author: Young Y.

description:
Compared to Volcano:

On the heartier side with the gravy.
The Hot one is actually spicy with the spices.
No potatoes and carrots.
For the Katsu: the breading has seasoning which makes the katsu very salty in comparison. 

Overall it's good, I like it. 3-4 stars. 

I think in a sense, it shouldn't be compared to Volcano because different places have their own things. But, if you like something heartier: go here. 

I'd recommend getting the Medium level of spicy though. The heat from the Hot doesn't kick in until later and then you just want water.
author: Lilian L.

description: Delicious curry if you're on the go! This place encourages take-out though there is some limited spots to eat there. I came here with a friend at around 12:30pm on a Wednesday and there was already a line to order/waiting for their orders. We were picking up food to meet up with another friend nearby, so like many others in line, we were ordering to-go, especially since the venue is small. I got the chicken katsu curry with mild spiciness. The curry was delicious and had a tinge of spiciness, but not too overwhelming. The chicken katsu, however, was a little burnt and dry, so it didn't really enhance the meal at all. Overall, this is a great place if you're craving curry!
author: Lisa C.

description:
I came here 3 times and my favorite item is spicy karaage chicken Ramen
Great taste, the curry is flavorful and the chicken is crispy and moist 
The eel fish is also delicious 
I will keep coming whenever I get a chance to
author: Mohamed B.

description:
Very crowded when going during the lunch hour! So plan accordingly.

Pricing isn't too bad for the quantity of food you get. If you do not like spicy food, be sure to specify NO spice or you will burn up! 

The food itself is delicious regardless! Definitely try something that you haven't had before, and I guarantee you will like it!
author: Michael T.

description: Very good Japanese katsu curry, with three levels of spice. Recommend the classic order, or the katsu ramen. Gets very busy during normal lunch hours (12-1) but can order online for pickup, or hit it up later.
author: Trett J.

description:
This long line confuses me.

Because why would you wait so long for curry that tastes worse than the instant kind you eat out of a bag?  The spiciness and depth of flavor that comes with a good curry was pretty lacking for me, I really felt like I could make something better at home from S&B.  It was also a lot runnier than I would've liked for the meager amount of curry you get.

Chicken katsu was thin to the point of dryness, the breaded portion was made up more of the katsu than the chicken!  Maybe I've been spoiled by years of Coco Ichibanya.

Tips and Tricks
-Go before or at noon, the FiDi lunch lines get long
author: Jessica L.

description: Decided to give this place a try after a couple of co-workers recommended it. I'm not a huge fan of Japanese Curry...so I was a little worried about what I would order. But as soon as I saw the Oyako-don on their menu, I was set! I went around noon-ish on a weekday, so the line was pretty long. I waited about 20 min total before I got my food. Not terrible...but you can definitely avoid the wait if you just go a little earlier. The oyako-don was delicious! The chicken was tender and flavorful. Good amount of it too. The eggs/onions were cooked together perfectly. Loved the texture. And portions/prices were decent. If you're in the area, definitely give this place a try!
author: Ashley Y.

description: Curry is good, donburi ok. The restaurant has a very limited seating and we have to sit very close to each other, not very comfortable. But it is what it is.
author: Maria S.

description: Small, unassuming hole-in-the-wall that serves delicious food. Other than their curry dishes, I've tried their teriyaki salmon and chicken lunch sets, and they are on point every time. I've needed to ask them to put the teriyaki sauce on the side, since when, by default, they pour it on everything, the rice etc. gets quite salty. Nevertheless, this place satisfies when I need something to go.
author: V C.

description:
3-stars for the friendly guy working there who seemed to be holding down the fort (maybe a manager). 

Otherwise, disappointed with the food especially for the price. 

Got the katsu (pork cutlet) curry medium. The katsu was actually ok- fried nicely and not too fatty. The curry really was a bummer. Rather than incorporating some spice flavors and melding it into the curry, it just seems they add a ton of red pepper flakes to make it spicy. I saw a ton of red pepper flakes just there in my curry. It was very one note sour spicy and all I tasted was red pepper. You can get more nuanced curry spice from packaged curry from Vermont or House brands in your Japanese market.

My meal plus a drink was $18 which is too much even if you factor in downtown pricing premiums.
author: Ryan L.

description: Small hole in the wall. Quick service. Got the katsu curry (hot with brown rice). Rice was perfectly cooked and Katsu crunchy. The curry was hot but not overly that you can't taste anything. A little expensive in my opinion but a great meal. Would return but not with a large group - there is limited seating (no tables - only stools lined up against the wall).
author: Jeanna S.

description:
Muracci's is the best Japanese curry I've had in the city. But it's not quite perfect. I can't put my finger on it, but something's missing. Ah well, I'll continue to eat it and be satisfied all the same. Rice has a good flavor and is the perfect amount of sticky, chicken is good, and the curry itself is good with a great mix of savory and spicy flavors.

Order ahead! The place gets packed during lunch, and they accept orders an hour in advance through Yelp (and like every other food pickup service).
author: Shawn W.

description:
Not as impressed as I thought I would be. I've heard many rave about the curry here so felt the need to put it on my for sure need to try list. Ordered to go (since seating is minimal and it gets crowded inside with others waiting for their to go orders).

Got the chicken curry and the chicken katsu curry. The chicken curry was meh- they both had the same sauce (med spice) which had good heat, but still slightly mild, but the chicken still had some skin and grissle on it. THe chicken katsu was solid with the curry. Recommend that one over the regular chicken curry.

Overall ok curry (I prefer the one I make) but a bit pricy for what you get.
author: Alison L.

description:
Definitely my go-to dinner place during weeknights. I seriously cannot get tired of coming here. I always crave their chicken katsu or tonkatsu curry with rice. It's crispy, flavorful, and filling.

There's the option to get cheese as well, but often times the original is the best version of the dish. Simple is key.

I've ordered in as well as to-go. They tend to give you a lot more if you order in, so try to do that! Or if you'd rather get a quick bite, to-go is just as good. Remember to get the sauce on the side if you end up doing to-go to maintain the crispness of the katsu.
author: Jenny H.

description: Great curry, but a "hole in the wall" interior. The seating can be really tight. I'll definitely go again.
author: Jeremy E.

description:
Great place to satisfy your curry craving! The place itself is suuuper tiny with few seats inside (so basically non-existent). Come 15-30 mins before the lunch rush because if you come any later you'll hit the lunch rush and it can take about 15-20 mins to get your food. If you catch the rush you'll usually have to wait outside before they call you since it gets packed inside and the caviar orders shelf is near the back. 

*If you don't want to wait in line, just caviar ahead of time

I always get the beef curry (medium) with potatoes over brown rice. When they take your order someone comes by and fills out a paper and then that's what you hand to the cashier. THEY GIVE YOU A TON of curry sauce too.

The beef is so tender and the curry sauce so flavorful. It's just the right amount of heat without being too overpowering. You can adjust how spicy you want it so if you don't want it spicy at all you can totally do that. If you want it spicy x4 you can do that too since i've definitely seen people do that.
author: Keizzel C.

description:
If you love Japanese curry, this is the place to go in Financial District.  Even though there are questionable health ratings (around an 80, I think...) the line is consistently out the door for the lunch time rush.

If they have the curry pan (curry filled fried pastries), definitely grab a few.  Even if you can't eat them immediately, throw them in the toaster later in the day and you'll be in heaven!

The chicken katsu curry is standard and delish.  Comes with rice, chicken katsu, and a bowl of curry.  Pretty much exactly what you'd get in Japan!  It's nearly impossible to eat inside this place, so I would recommend taking it to-go.  Medium heat is perfect and not too spicy.  The curry and rice save well if you can't finish it all - but the chicken should be eaten on the spot!
author: Kenna H.

description:
A cozy place with practically no seating. During lunch, the line will always be out the door. A smart thing to do is call ahead and pick up your order! They have bento boxes, katsu curries, karaage, donburis, and some japanese snacks and sweets on the side. Their main competitor is Japacurry, and they're pretty similar. Not too hard to mess up chicken katsu and curry, but tastes great and overall seems pretty legitly Japanese style. They do a good job of making the katsu crispy with minimal oil drippings, and it stays crispy in the container for a while!
Customizable level of spicy, and you can either get no rice (sub with lettuce) or add extra vegetables for $2 ish. 
Rent price of the location drives the price up to ~$11 for chicken katsu curry, which is silly, but SF is silly, so what are we gonna do
author: Grace P.

description:
I had a few people tell me how good this place was so I decided to try it one day for lunch. It's a super small place so it's more of a to-go place if you want something quick. I got the chicken katsu curry with brown rice. The curry was really good, but the chicken katsu was so dry and flavorless. It almost relied on the curry for flavor. The brown rice was ok. The small amount of pickled vegetables they are really good though.

Overall, the curry is good, but avoid the chicken katsu.
author: Sophia Y.

description: I decided to check this place out because they have super long lines and great reviews. I tried the acclaimed katsu curry. It had a nice crunchy breading with tender pork inside. Their curry had good flavor and spice. To eat this dish, you gotta eat a little of everything in a bite. You get a little katsu soaked in curry with a scoop of rice. The pickles cut through the richness and add nice freshness. Though this dish was good, it didn't live up to the expectation I had of it. I honestly would not wait in a long line for this again.
author: Cute Dine R.

description:
I love Japanese curry!! You get large portions and the curry is amazing. Definitely a heavier meal, so be ready to take a nap later/get a coffee later. I like the chicken katsu as well as the curry ramen options:) Definitely try it, especially if you haven't had Japanese curry in the past. 

*Tip - order online! Especially during lunch time the line can get quite long. But you can place an order online and just come grab it*
author: Caley Z.

description: I ordered the Katsu Curry (Pork Cutlet, white rice, cabbage, ginger, and medium spicy sauce) so spicy
author: Ryan L.

description:
Muracci's is authentic Japanese curry.

Most of the people who work here are Japanese so they know what they are doing. The gentleman who took my order spoke Japanese so I hesitantly attempted to place it with the rough Japanese that I still remember. He spoke back in Japanese and we eventually made it through my order. 

I got hot katsu curry on white rice and a Calpis. Orders are taken as you make it through the door. Don't be surprised if the line is going out the door and down the street. Your order is taken and then you are handed your order on a slip of paper. This information is verbalized to workers behind the counter in the kitchen and then you patiently wait. There is only enough space here to walk in and get your order. There is some space against the front, maybe 4 stools or so, to sit and eat your food if you so choose. Everything comes in a to go container.

My order was placed, I took my ticket to the checkout and paid.

Once I got my food I unwrapped it and began eating by one of the window seats. It was like I was back in Japan. I could eat curry for every meal.
author: Rawlins R.

description: Grab and go curry shop. Perfect for lunch time.  The food is worth jumping in line. The line may be long but it moves fast.
author: Andrew B.

description:
Love the deep peppery taste of the curry. While it's not at the same level of the curry back in Japan, it's the closest I found.
The pickled veggie is a nice touch. Katsu curry is my favorite. The batter, partly crispy and partly soggy from the curry, with the juicy meat and supple rice...happiness.
The place is very small so I always have it to go.
author: Jenny T.

description:
Best curry flavor I've tasted. 
Really small space . Very small space . Did I say the space was small? you'll be lucky to find seats so order to go. 
The main thing is their good down to earth hospitable service and the food is worth coming .
author: Phil L.

description:
Quick, decent Japanese curry dishes at reasonable portions and prices. Although I found the curry sauces to be slightly salty, and the katsu dishes just a bit overdone on the breading, they are nevertheless fairly authentic, and as an added bonus this place is open fairly late for FiDi on weekdays.

Good for a takeout meal, or for a quick in-house bite if you can find a seat in the small venue.
author: Vincent L.

description:
My girlfriend had been bugging to come here for the longest time (childhood favorite) and we were finally in the area, and hungry so we dropped in. 

I have always heard great things from her and friends, but never went in because I am not a big fan of curry. I won't say this place changed me completely but I think I found a spot where I can actually enjoy the curry. The things to order here are the Katsu Curry (breaded pork) or Chicken Katsu Curry (breaded chicken). 

We ordered two Katsu Curry with white rice, but they do have brown available if you'd prefer. The pork was breaded perfectly, cut perfect sizes and the rice was cooked just right. There weren't any overcooked pieces, burnt or soft. It was pretty bomb. I got the curry medium, which wasn't spicy at all, tasted like mild. It had a great aroma to it, nice flavor and tasted great with Katsu and drizzled over rice.
author: John M.

description: The best Japanese curry dedicated place I've been to in the U.S. Seeing the line out the door right around noon every day should tell you this hole in the wall is the place to be. Truly believe these specialty curry and katsu spots are probably going to be popping up more and more, if you're in SF and love a Japanese curry rice or udon dish, hit Muracci's.
author: Riki N.

description:
The only thing I've EVER ordered here is the Chicken Katsu Curry.

Why mess with greatness?

However, we are eating "healthy." 

So instead, we tried the Salmon Teriyaki and the Grilled Chicken Curry. The Salmon was a bit dry and the Grilled Chicken was good but not Katsu Curry Good (obvs). Still liking the brown rice option but needed way more pickles. I wish it could be like banchan where you can have as much pickled stuff as you want. Banchan all the things!

Also, I'm a fan of the Order Ahead online option. On my way home, I placed the order and got it stupid fast 10 minutes later. 

Dinner is served.
author: Amy C.

description:
Food here is very very tasty. I got a Katsu Don and the seasoning was perfect. It's not that expensive here either, approximately $11 for my meal and it was very filling. Although I haven't tried it myself, I've heard tons of good things about the curry here. One thing to note is that the listed prices on Yelp are actually cheaper than the prices at the store. On average, each dish is about $1-$2 more expensive than what it says.

The problem is the line here, especially around lunch time, is INSANELY long. It took me essentially 35 minutes to get my food. Either come here a bit earlier or a bit later than the usual lunch rush. Another option is to order online and then go pick up your food. Don't expect to find a place to sit and eat here either. There's approximately 10 seats but 20-30 people standing around waiting for their food.
author: Cassie Z.

description:
Great spot for lunch in downtown. Came here for lunch around noon on a weekday and line was out the door. Thankfully, it moves quickly and someone actually takes your order before you pay to get the cooking going.

There isn't much space inside, but most people take the food to go so there shouldn't be trouble finding seating. We ordered the chicken katsu curry and curry ramen. The chicken katsu was tender and breaded nicely, served with brown rice (optional) and pickled veggies. The curry ramen was a nice surprise, very flavorful and the noodles and toppings coming together perfectly.

Definitely a must-do for anyone who enjoys curry and works downtown.
author: Tim X.

description:
This hole in the wall restaurant is located within walking distance of Union Square. It's on Kearny St across from L&L. You will recognize it with the line of people out the door. It's usually a good sign anytime there is a line of people at a place. The restaurant is cozy but they did manage to fit in a restroom. Due to the size of the restaurant, most people order takeout. You can dine in but there is little room and not much seating. 

We didn't have to wait too long. The employees there are fast, friendly and efficient. The person who takes orders surprised us when she spoke fluent Japanese to the kitchen. After she calls out your order to the kitchen, you take your order sheet to pay at the cashier. Beverages are also available for purchase at the cashier section. They accept cash and credit here. The cashier gives you a number after you pay and you find any available spot to wait. 

Is the wait worth it? I think it is if you have the time. The curry is very flavorful and the portions are generous. I ordered the Tonkatsu and Mink got the Chicken Katsu. We both got it spicy (it was not spicy) but I got mine with cheese. You can choose from white or brown rice. The Katsu was a little dry but still good. All the orders come out in takeout containers. The curry is separated from the meat and rice which is great for takeout. Glad we got to try this local favorite and take this off my bookmark list.
author: Daniel C.

description:
Staying the weekend in SF for the national pharmacy conference. Although I live in the bay area, I do not often visit SF. I am glad that one of my friends told me about this place. I love curry as a general food and Japanese curry is amongst my favorites.

This restaurant has a very pick-me-up to-go sort of feel. It is small and has little room for sitting but are well equipped to handle many togo orders. The curry itself was excellent. The consistency was good and the taste was not overpowering. The mild spice did not challenge my taste buds but instead warmed me up. Although the meat in my udon could have been better, I definitely think this place is a curry treasure.
author: Joshua L.

description:
The hype is real y'all. This place serves authentic Japanese curry. The spicy curry is seriously spicy and the chicken katsu is crispy. Prices are affordable. 

The location is very small (like a small hallway) and it's more of a order your food and take it to go type of place. There's very little seating to eat and barely enough room to stand while waiting for your food.  

I recommend looking at the menu online ahead of time because once you get there you'll stand in line, once the menu comes into view you'll be expected to order (very rushed). I guess it makes the line go fast but you better be prepared.
author: Ming Y.

description:
Muracci's has so many Japanese comfort dishes to choose from - lots of curry options, tonkatsu, teriyaki, donburi, udon, ramen, & soba dishes. They also sell Japanese sweets, like mochi and roll cakes. Muracci's sure packs quite a selection in their tiny kitchen. There are just a few stool seats against the window, so it is mainly a takeout spot. There is typically a long line at lunch, but it moves quickly, so it helps to know what to order ahead of time.

$10.75 Tonkatsu Lunch Set - pork cutlet with tonkatsu sauce over steamed rice, w/ salad, miso soup, mini appetizer:
The pork cutlet was very crunchy on the outside, and stayed pretty crunchy on top of the hot rice. It was a generous, meaty portion. I didn't care too much for the sides, but I'm not usually fond of the sides that come with these sets. The salad didn't come with dressing, but I don't like iceberg lettuce anyway. I also didn't really care for the mini appetizer, which was a ball of cold mashed potatoes with corn and broccoli.

$2.99 Curry Pan - chicken baked curry bread:
The bread was fluffy with air pockets and had a crisp outer coating. However, I would have liked more curry filling.

Overall, I would give my lunch options a 7/10. I do appreciate that they make their food to order. I think I need to come back and try their curry to give a more complete review, and to satisfy my own curiosity.
author: Joy W.

description:
Me and my co-workers go to lunch take away place. Hella long line especially during lunch rush, but man, the food is so good. 

Everything here is good, but my favorite is Tonkatsu and Kaarage with Mild Curry.

When you're downtown, try this place and you won't be disappointed.
author: Em B.

description: This place was pretty good but it was a little watery for my liking. The thing I liked about it is that it was filling and affordable for being in the city, however I don't know if I would go out of my way to go back. The place is also very small too so if I were to go back or someone else wanted it I would suggest taking it out to go or getting take out.
author: Katrina D.

description: For how long the line gets during the lunch hour I was really impressed at how quickly and efficiently they are. I was out in under 10 minutes which considering the line was to the door is pretty quick. So don't let the line intimidate you because it goes really quickly. I had the chicken katsu with the mild curry and it was delicious. The curry was super flavorful and pairs great with the crispy crunch of the katsu. The price was super affordable at $13 and plenty filling. I do wish I had gotten a little side salad just to balance the fried chicken so it wouldn't seem as unhealthy but life is short. I would highly recommend this place. I can not wait to try it again and really explore the menu.
author: David P.

description:
Small spot downtown. Pretty tasty food. I tied the chicken katsu curry and the fried prawns. Both were good. The medium spicy curry was delicious. 
If you're planning on eating at the Restraunt, it is very small/limited seating. Overall, this place did not disappoint. I'd recommend it for a quick bite to eat.
author: Kevin S.

description:
Pretty darn good. I find the mild is still decently spicy and the flavor is great. The only reason I deducted a star is because during lunch time it's tough to get in there and order, even if you order ahead (which is a nice option). It's such a small place it's hard to know where the line is and where you should cram yourself when waiting for the order.

I like the chicken katsu with curry on the side, and have also tried the 'chicken and veggie' soup, which is basically noodles, vegetables and sauce, so not a true soup but very yummy!
author: Rose R.

description: Although not much to look at, and easily missed from the outside, this little gem delivers great Japanese curry. At lunch there may be a line out the door, but don't feat, they move quickly. Their curry is flavorful and also spicy! I opted for medium spicy and was surprised how spicy that was. Maybe I'm losing my tolerance... I digress. The menu is straightforward and focused on their delicious curry. It's affordable at just around $10 for a katsu curry at lunch. There is little seating inside, and it's crowded, so plan to take your food and find an open space in the city to eat. I need to remember to come back here more often. It is really great Japanese curry.
author: John W.

description:
Good curry, friendly staff. They tend to run out of stuff at the end of the day, so don't go too late.

My favorite here is the Spicy Beef Pan-Pan - a fried bread pocket filled with beef curry in a paper bag.
author: David T.

description:
It's been raining in SF for about 10 days straight, so we've been seeking out warm, comfort food and thank goodness we discovered Muracci's Japanese Curry & Grill. This is a true hole-in-the-wall. I think there about 8 stools in the whole joint. 

We stopped by for lunch on a Saturday and were so satisfied with our meals. I went for the spicy noodle with the ground beef curry sauce and udon noodles. The flavor in this sauce is to die for. You get the crazy curry punch, the beef itself is so delicious -- most of it is find ground meat, but you can tell the larger chunks were seasoned really well. The portion is the perfect size. It's hot and steaming and heart warming. Also, your nose will probably drip through the process so make sure you've got sufficient amount of napkins.

My partner loved the other beef curry which he also made super spicy. Overall, a great meal.

I find the dishes to be a little bit pricy, but no complaints as you're in downtown Union Square in San Francisco. Such is life. Ambiance is super casual. You're in and out for a quick heart meal. Would definitely come back again!
author: Priti K.

description: I mean, the curried take 20 hours to stew and cook...what more do I need to say? The Katsu is always fresh, hot, crunchy and totally not greasy
author: Claire C.

description:
I have been wanting to try this place.  But there is always a LONG line every time I passed by it, so i never gotten a chance to.  But today changed all that.  I really wanna try this place because my coworker kept saying it and kept making fun of me for not trying their food.  I kept telling him, there's always a line. .but today, the line was shorter so I decided to go in and ordered.  OMG BEST DECISION EVER!!! My coworker came with too and man I will come back for sure. 

I got the Katsu with curry, mild, with brown rice and added vegetables.  The curry was very tasty.  I really like it. the meat was very meaty, and the breading is just right.  not super heavy.  I really like it.  I will try on different meat next time so i can compare. 

service: fairy fast. the line was shorter, wasn't out the door just yet, I think there are at least 4-5 people in front of me but it move quickly and they are such a team players where they get everything ready like have the To Go box all ready just in case.
