atmosphere: very tight, not enough room to stand between the counter and the door, so when people are leaving or waiting for take out, they are having hard time getting out.  so just be prepare to say "excuse me" and bumping at people. AHHAHAHHA 

I guess the best time to go would be before 12pm or after 1pm  then I think it should be good.
author: Candice Y.

description:
This place has been on my radar for about a year now and I'm so sad that I'm just now trying it - it was so bomb. I came for lunch and ordered the katsu curry to go - they have a separate container for the curry, for you to pour onto your meal yourself which is really thoughtful! 

The katsu was perfectly cooked and the curry added a really good kick! I definitely want to come back and try their lunch combo though.
author: Carrie L.

description: I really enjoyed the curry and katsu at Muracci's so the main reason I'm giving them three stars is because they forgot the katsu in my to-go order. My boyfriend ordered katsu + curry and I ordered just katsu. When we walked back to his office to have lunch, there was only rice in my to-go box. We shared his katsu + curry (which was delicious) and walked back to Muracci's. They were nice and gave the correct order but overall it was an unsuccessful lunch and extremely upsetting because we wasted quite a bit of time. I'll definitely go back and hope this doesn't happen again. I get they are busy but forgetting the main part of the dish is very sad.
author: Radhika G.

description:
My coworker loves this place, and I may have too if they had not completely forgotten to make the food I walked 25 minutes to pick up on my lunch break. 

When I got there, they told me the wait would be another 20 minutes because they did not make my food (ordered through OrderAhead) - some issue with the system, they said. 

I didn't have that kind of time so they gave me a free chicken Katsu (not very tasty, I wanted curry). 

Not the best experience for a first-time customer, but I have to give it to them for at least trying to make it right.
author: Jessica D.

description:
Muracci's is a hole in the wall curry spot in FiDi, with a line regularly out the door. Do not be deterred - the line moves fairly fast;  just keep in mind this is a mostly carry-out eatery because there are few tables which hold about 2 people only.

* Katsu Curry - 4 STARS: Light and crispy, battered and fried, super juicy pork chop. Ordered spicy (go for medium, hot is super hot!). I would highly recommend the katsu curry over the donburi.

* Curry Puff - 3.5 STARS: This was a great snack - light and crispy fried on the outside like the katsu, and filled with a bit of curry paste. I wish it was served hotter, it came luke warm.

* Oyako Donburi - 3 STARS: I've had much better oyakodon's, this one was lacking in flavor and just very boring. On the upside, it was a fairly large portion. Stick with the curries!
author: Jess C.

description: For a first timer here. I wasn't impress. Got Salmon Teriyaki. Gave me a small portion of salmon and they had my rice swimming in the teriyaki. It would've been better if it wasn't close to being covered in sauce. Everything else was slightly ok.
author: Shirley A.

description:
My favorite Japanese curry in the States! its a small place with limited seating but I love it. People are nice and they are quick. Always a line but never too bad of a wait. The food is always good and hot. 

For the rice plate I love the Tonkatsu Curry and my favorite is their SPICY NOODLE with udon. Both medium spicy. Medium spicy is perfect. The flavor and spices are just amazing. The best comfort food ever. I almost go once a week and I look forward to it each time.
author: Sandy B.

description:
I finally got to try this because it was the Tues after Christmas so the FiDi lunch scene was vacant as f**k. Ordered that sexy little number (34) that I've had my eye on for a while - the spicy beef noodles. The employee asked me "mild medium or hot" and I said medium cuz I was feeling hella wild. The lady quickly put me in my white girl place and told me to order mild so I was like ya ur right thx boo. 

Ok so mild will destroy your mouth. 

I remember when I had taste buds, back B.S.N. (before spicy noodles). 

Ok so spiciness is in the mouth of the noodle beholder - I get that, but if you grew up on pot roast and casseroles or if you own something from LL Bean, this isn't your dish. It was bomb though. I ate a few bites, got a face transplant and then ate it cold with like 14 drinks and enjoyed the golly gosh out of it. I'll definitely order again.
author: Emma H.

description:
$11.36 for white meat chicken teriyaki w/brown rice, a little salad, and potato salad. 

Small restaurant with little seating (alone window only). Line moves quickly, food is pretty decent - though nothing out of the ordinary. 

This place reminds me a lot of YoYo's, but this place accepts credit card, order ahead and door dash :) 


TLDR: decent japanese food relatively cheap. for the most part, this is take away lunch restaurant.
author: Kristie C.

description:
Pretty damn good curry. I didn't even know such a thing existed in the realm of Japanese food. First time and I was happy I tried it! Got the katsu curry (deep fried pork cutlet) with rice. $11 its apparently the favourite and I dont deny it!

Quick service, always a short line and you get your food in about 10min. Not much space to eat, so you'd want to take it out to the park or somewhere so you can truly appreciate the food.

They come in legit containers so if you're a pack rat, you might what to keep them for yknow... to help pack for future lunches. This may be the asian in me speaking right now. 

I'd definitely come back to eat this when visiting San Fran! Oh and make sure to try this curry empanada thing at the front of the cash, not sure what it's called... but it's good!
author: Jacqui L.

description:
Good taste curry and you won't disappointed most of time especially during lunch hour. It's always fresh made and I love their Katzu Curry ( Pork). It's deep fried and very juicy.
I had once had experience from them since the pork was not cooked well done but they exchanged a fresh one right away. I will give them 4 stars for that!!!

Recommend: call for Togo order first so you can avoid the line.
author: Kimmy M.

description: This is my go to lunch place when I'm not an a Keto diet. I love the deep fried chicken cutlets that you pour tasty, delicious, molten curry sauce on top of. These guys have never done me wrong after 3 months of going here. If I had a complaint, it's that the space is cramped and you can't do sit down. No problem, I'll take it to go and eat along the water front.
author: Jim B.

description:
Is worth the hype? I think so. Came here on a busy Tuesday lunch rush hour, the line was out the door! The owner (I'm assuming) greeted us with a friendly smile and suggested to order the katsu or the chicken curry. Decided to get the chicken curry and it was definitely a good choice. The busy kitchen pushed out order extremely quickly and I was able to get my food about 15 minutes after I ordered.

If you're expecting something something exotic or fancy, then this is not it. Japanese curry is usually known as street food that's quick but yet hardy. Muracci's chicken curry came with some white rice, pickled daikons, and curry of course. It's nicely seasoned and had a little kick even though was opted for the mild. I would say it's a little pricey for what it is, but can't knock on that curry hustle.
author: Sunny W.

description:
"Hurry up wit da CURRY" is what always goes thru my mind when I'm sitting waiting for that plate of spicy steaming yumminess. Japanese curry is one of my loves n I first fell in love eating it in its point of origin, Japan. my favorite specialty curry shop in the Bay Area was in Los Gatos. surprise! it was Muracci's Japanese Curry & Grill. yep, it was their second shop. it was such a sad sad day when I found out they were closing that shop down. : / a great Japanese restaurant that only does curries  isn't easy to find. 

I've never come to this SF location before so I was overly enthusiastic n brimming to the top with high hopes for eating a plate of Muracci's curry again. we turned down Kearny so we were expecting to c a sign on the wall soon, but we had walked almost to the end of the block n still no Muracci's! so we doubled back n walked slowly making sure we didn't miss it again. (now that I think about it, we should've used Google Maps. duh!) so the shop is located 3 stores down from the hair salon. the name of the shop is way above the door n hidden behind a protruding shelf so it's easy to miss. this tiny shop is literally a hole in the wall.

the shop is so tiny there's no tables; only some stools by the windows which makes it really cramped for ppl going to the restroom. (yep, there is a bathroom in this teeny tiny space.) u order at the cash register, pay, then u wait for your order to b called. it's a buy n leave kinda place. if u want to sit n eat there, u better get there early to grab one of the seats at the windows which is good for ppl watching also. thank god we got there early. there was a long line forming out the door after we finished n left. 

my wait for their curry seemed forever, but lo n behold, there it was steaming hot in front of me n I was in heaven! omg, it was so DE-LICIOUS. it reminded me of the Katsu n Chicken Curry dishes I had at the Los Gatos location. the chicken was crispy from the panko on the surface n juicy on the inside. they give u a container with the curry separately so u have to empty it onto the meat n rice yourself. I ordered mine medium spicy so that was perfect for me. mild is always good too, but I like it with a bit of spice. : ) 

it's too bad their only shop exists only in SF now. I hope they have plans for other shops in the future! I can only wish n pray.
author: Julie W.

description:
When you talk about the best curry in town, Muracci's name is guaranteed to come up. In recent years, however, coffee shops have been debating whether Muracci still deserves the lone recognition of being the best.

"Of course it does," offers one curry connoisseur. "Legitimate Japanese folks cook that flavorful curry every morning, fresh as can be!"

"Be that as it may," a naysayer retorts. "Muracci's curry is not as thick as traditional Japanese curry. I prefer mine to be a little more heavy."

Just as the discussion begins to escalate, the barista calls the debaters for their coffee. 

"William? William with a light roast?"

"Oh gosh, it's just Will," complains Will the curry connoisseur. "I absolutely detest it when they call out your full name. How do they know I'm not Willheim, or Willbur or something?"

"Don't mind it too much, buddy," says the naysayer. "Judging by your choice of coffee, I can see why you may prefer the lighter side of curry. But don't you just crave that thick texture when it's mixed in with the fluffy Nishiki rice?"

"Actually, I don't," counters Will. "The ridiculously crispy layer of that katsu pork is more than enough to satisfy my cravings for texture. Besides, I feel that a more fluid curry can seep through the rice better. Should we walk over to Murraci's and confirm this?"

The naysayer nods and the two debaters soon find themselves in line for the famous curry.

"You can just smell why Muracci's is so good!" exclaims Will. "And look, the little Beef Curry Pan is perfect for a bite-sized snack."

"I must say that their curry noodle soup also look very hearty and delicious," the naysayer admits while he browses around the store with his bright green eyes.

Will's eyes light up and exclaims, "So Murraci's is the best curry in to--"

"Pork Katsu Curry for Stephanie!" interrupts the server. "Is there a Stephanie here!?"

The naysayer approaches the server with a smile and notes, "Thank you, but it's just Steph."

Steph bites into a spoonful of the rice topped with a slice crispy pork katsu, all drowned in curry.

"This is good, this is damn good," admits Steph the naysayer, to Will the curry connoisseur's delight.

"But..." adds Steph while wiping his mouth with a perfectly rolled up tissue ball.

As Will eagerly waits for the verdict, Steph shoots the tissue ball 26 feet across the store. The tissue rainbows into the bottom of the rubbish bin, touching only enough of the trash bag to make a slight sound. A sound that can only be described to be a..... 'splash'. Will's jaws drops to the floor as Steph breaks a smile.

"I am the best Curry in town." Steph Curry proclaims.
author: Ringo M.

description: A really small place with limited seating but it's worth it. The medium spicy curry really hit the spot. I got the cheese omelette curry and my friend got the kaarage curry. Both really good. My only complaint is that there wasn't enough of the red pickles, but that's more of a personal problem. I could and have eaten an entire container of those pickles. Get the curry pan though!! I was pleasantly surprised.
author: Deanna L.

description: The portions are very small and the curry is overhyped. The curry is a bit bland and more along the lines of a boxed curry. In addition, the price is more along the lines of a sit down restaurant instead of a place that is mainly takeout.
author: Ernest M.

description: Hands down THE BEST KATSU CURRY in SF. I'm pissed off though.... pissed at the fact I didn't discover this place sooner. The sauce is out of this world.... not the same in every sushi restaurant where the use the generic packaging. EVERYTHING IVE NOTICE IS FRESHLY MADE. So that mean the food will take a little time to make and get to your hands. I can't say enough how much of a difference this place is compared to every place in the city that offers this on their menus. They should be embarrass.... and that maybe an understatement. I love I love this place.... btw the average cost of this item at sushi restaurants is about $8.99-$9.99, here it's $13 after tax, WELL WORTH EVERY BIT. Thank you guys for the food and good service.
author: Dang D.

description:
If you have been exploring most of the day and you are starving...you have to come to Muracci's!
I know with such good reviews (and with so many), I needed to make a visit.This place definitely is a take out kinda joint as they had only high tables along the wall and window areas- not many but enough for a quick bite. We got our meals in take out containers so it is quite convenient if you cannot finish.The portions might I say are huge for what I expected. If I was back home, I could probably split the rice up for 3 meals. The protein and curry sauce is quite generous. I ordered the the chicken katsu curry, which comes with a bed of rice. My fiancee ordered the beef curry udon special. We both got medium spicy level. Medium was just right, it was a kick of spice that made you want more!
We were satisfied with the yummy meal:)

In addition, I liked how the rice dishes, you could choose either regular rice or brown rice.The rice dishes came with pickled radish and cabbage- this complemented with the curry nicely. I also want to add that I loved how environmentally friendly this place is. They separated the recycled waste from the compost waste. I am not sure if California in general has more of a green thumb...but definitely a positive note to mention. 

Keep up the awesome work with the Japanese curry!
author: Daphne W.

description: So many reviews, which meant I had to try it when I was in the neighborhood. Ordered the katsu curry to go. It's great how they package the curry separately so nothing gets soggy. Overall, the meal was good. I ordered the hot curry and it was a good kick of spice. Although I liked it, definitely wouldn't go out of my way for this curry. Probably would order the ramen next time if I were to try this place again.
author: Annie H.

description: This is my go to place for pork tonkatsu curry. I always crave this when I pass by. They're quick and fast. I take it back to work and it's still fresh/hot. Prices are reasonable.
author: Jenna L.

description: 5 stars for food and service, less stars for venue/seating/ambiance. Great quality Japanese curry place. They have a lot of the usual options, including chicken/pork katsu/cutlet with mild/medium/spicy options. Be forewarned that even their 'mild' option is fairly hot/spicy. They also do a couple of ramen options; my favorite is the chicken karaage ramen, but it seems to take extra time to make. Overall, line flow is decent, but it's really, really crowded during peak times because there's minimal, cramped seating, and there's a lot of staff shouting orders/instructions, and the line is very long. Best thing is to try this place during off-peak hours, like 11:30am or 5pm. They are also on various food takeout/delivery apps, so you can order in advance!
author: Jimmy H.

description: There's only one regret I have after eating the most delicious meal for lunch - why did I not try this place earlier? The breaded chicken or whatever coating they put on top of the moist chicken is perfectly crisp and each bite packs a punch. I put the sauce on the rice instead of the chicken because I didn't want to lose out on the flavor of the fried chicken by itself. I'll definitely visit this place again and really want to try the chicken karage ramen. Excellent food!
author: Akshat G.

description:
I came here on a Monday after work and I thought the curry was pretty decent. My friend got the Karaage Chicken Curry medium spicy and I got the Chicken Katsu Curry mild spicy. I would definitely say that the Karaage Chicken Curry is the go to dish when you come here because the chicken was prepared very well while the Chicken Katsu could be a little more on the dry side. The only reason why I say this is a 4 four star is because although I think that the chicken is superb, the actual curry itself tasted a little basic.. something you could've easily done at home. 

Service was good, seating is limited, prices are average for SF ($11), and the portion was just right for me.
author: Amy L.

description:
I've come to Muracci's twice for dinner after loving the one in Berkeley a lot and having heard a lot about this location from my college roommate.

This location is nice and small, being moreso suited for take out as opposed to eating in. They also close fairly early if you're coming here for dinner. I got to try both the beef curry and the pork katsu curry dishes here. The curry is very unique and is unlike any other curry I've ever had. It has a smooth texture with a nice kick to it if you get it spicy. I recommend the katsu curry the most as it has a nice ratio of meat, rice, and curry. The katsu is also fried to perfection for a nice coat of crispiness on the meat. Overall, I really enjoy eating at Muracci's but have to say that the one in Berkeley has an edge over this one since I feel that the flavors are all slightly milder here.
author: Joshua M.

description:
ordered spicy breaded chicken ramen. chicken had bite ans broth is just perfectly spicy!!! sat people watching on a beautiful day eating this amazing food. so happy with the fast service and good eats.

wish we has this in NY.
author: Catherine P.

description:
Been here a few times now. 

Get a beef curry pan while you wait. It'll help ease the hunger.

The line is almost always super long, then there's no easy place to wait for your food. There's very little seating inside too... despite that, I've eaten there twice. Most people buy to go. 

I generally go with the curry katsu. Only issue with this is the lack of veggies in meal. Or else everything is delicious.

They accept credit card.
author: Kaje Y.

description: This place is a must for locals and tourists. Admittedly this is the first and only place I've had katsu curry, but it's spot on the lunch rotation is quite secure. It's always packed, always fresh and always worth it.
author: Jason D.

description:
My friend was visiting from out of town and Muracci's was on her list to try. We came on a late Saturday afternoon when it was pouring rain out...what better food is there for a rainy day than curry?! Our thoughts exactly.

Since we were doing a little food tour of SF, three of us split a Chicken Katsu Curry, medium spice. Well, damn. This was so delicious!!! Katsu was crispy and the curry was on point. The rice and pickled veggies went well with it. Highly recommend!
author: Noelle H.

description:
This was my go to place for Japanese curry.  Early on, the beef curry was a proper helping of beef in the curry.  Now it's simply beef flavored curry.

The Katsudon used to be a proper serving of what you'd find in Japan.  I would count the days until I was going to get another bowl.  Now it's really hit or miss and feels like either the staff doesn't care, or they are starting to skimp just like the curry as described above. :(

Bring back the quality!
author: Bryan D.

description:
I'm a sucker for their Salmon Fry Curry. Excellent flavour, generous portions of fish and curry. The pickle they give is a perfect accompaniment for the meal. The curry is perfectly blended; great aroma!

The queue can get quite long during the lunch hour so pre-ordering online might be a good idea, though be mindful that it's probably a dollar more.
author: Sundaram R.

description: Beef curry was OK, not the best but not the worst. The curry flavor was a little too tangy/sour for my taste and some of the beef had fat on it which I don't think any beef curry should have. Decent amount for the price. Can be busy in there but the line goes by quick.
author: E. R.

description:
If I was going to run for president, my one and only campaign promise would be to put a Muracci's in every home in America. 

Everything about this place is incredible.

The food is, of course, the star of the show. If you've never had Japanese curry, this is the perfect place for an introduction. Start with the Katsu curry, and don't be afraid to ask for it as spicy as you're comfortable. The pork is perfectly fried: crispy and tasty, but not heavy. The curry is phenomenal. If there's a line, grab a curry pan while you're waiting -- you won't be disappointed by this hand-held, fried pocket of curry and meat. My personal favorite is the chicken katsu lunch set, a good alternative if you're not feeling the curry for one reason or another. If you're a regular, try mixing it up with one of the variety of additions they can add to your curry!

Beyond the food, the experience is also pretty great. Muracci's has definitely got a "hole in the wall" vibe, and while there's some seating inside, I wouldn't count on being able to eat in during the lunch rush. That's just fine, though; there's plenty of great parks and rooftops that are open to the public nearby that make for a great place to eat. When the line starts forming, they'll often take your order while you wait, helping you get your food faster. You also get to experience the almost effortless way that the people taking your order yell it back to the kitchen, seemingly to nobody, in a way that leaves you wondering "how could this ever work?"; yet, somehow they never get it wrong. Even with the long lunch lines, I've never had to wait very long for my food once I've paid.

Long live Muracci's!
author: Fred H.

description: Extremely tight space. Great fast food. Good service. Sometimes the line can be really long and the wait time can be up to 45 min. Call ahead. I'm not sure if it's worth the wait if you ever find yourself waiting that long. But overall, good place to stop by every now and then.
author: Nit A.

description: Tiny little shop, BOMB FOOD. There is very little space in this restaurant (like literally 5 chairs) and it's very crowded so plan on taking your food to go. But don't let the lack of seating stop you from eating here! Amazing tonkatsu, probably the best I've had. Highly recommend!
author: Elaine D.

description:
Been a big fan of Muracci's ever since going to the one in Berkeley. When I realized there was a branch in SF downtown, I figured I needed to give this place a try as well, so I stopped by for dinner with a friend.

They have a fantastic selection of Japanese curries. I ordered their mild pork katsu curry. The pork katsu was great - juicy, tender pork with a crispy outside breading. The curry was decent but seemed lacking a bit of flavor, compared to the curries I had at Berkeley.

The place is pretty dirty and small - we had to tightly fit in at some counter seats.
author: Alvin W.

description:
Muracci's is like a hole in the wall. It was a little hidden, but quite noticeable due to the long line at lunch time.

I got the Karaage Curry with a 'hot' spice level. If you don't have a good tolerance for spicy, do not go for 'hot'. The curry was amazing! The food portion is a little on the heavy side. Also, I think the curry to rice ratio is leaning towards too much curry.

All in all, Muracci's deserves a five star for the quality of their food and I definitely would recommend it for everyone.
author: Alton L.

description: Suchhhhh good curry and rice! They ran out of pork tonkatsu when I got there, but the chicken katsu was amazing. Probably the best katsu I've ever had honestly!
author: Jessica L.

description:
$11.36 for a standard katsu curry with brown rice.

I found the dish OK, but not worthy of a ditty, or some wiggling of any part of body-- especially toes.

Came after a cut at AVEDA. Don't know if I would patronize the long-standing Berkeley outpost.
author: Jana C.

description:
I got the chicken katsu here with medium spicy curry - it was really good! I would say, though, they definitely give a lot of curry for the amount of rice you get. I wish they would give more rice, because I had to end up buying two bread rolls at the Metreon to utilize all the curry (which is really good!) The medium level definitely has a kick to it.

The chicken katsu was fantastic. Nothing too special to call out about it, except it was really delicious.

The wait time here is maybe 10-15 minutes to get your food, because I guess it's pretty popular. I do remember standing for a while after I ordered before we finally had our numbers called.
author: Brian W.

description: This place is small but the food is amazing! It was my first time having Katsu Curry and I loved it! I would definitely come here again when I'm in the city.
author: Ayana H.

description:
It's human nature to compare, but I'm trying to review Muracci on its own merits. After trying Go Go Curry in NY I had a craving for Japanese curry back home. Muracci is good. No doubts about it.  The Katsu is cooked perfectly. I will need to try some other entrees next time besides the curry.  

During the lunch rush my suggestion is to order for pick up. There is not enough space to wait and order your food. If you do order on site just wait outside. You can still hear them call out your number. 

With all that said my favorite Japanese curry place is GO GO Curry, but while out here I'll still go Muracci and JapaCurry...... just less often.
author: G M.

description: I've only gotten the curry here and it is always solid. Consistently good and the service is nice and quick.
author: Rahman S.

description: Pork katsu curry was savory, quick, and delicious. Definitely a to-go spot, place your order while in line and then walk out with your container when it's ready. If you're looking for a neighborhood lunch, this one's super.
author: Kitt H.

description:
What time is it? CURRRRY time!
How do we like it? HOT, HOT, HOT!

I swear, their curry here is hotter than Steph Curry. Owww. 

This tiny sorta hole in the wall spot in Financial District. You probably won't go out of your way here since parking WILL be a huge pain in the butt. There's also no way you would want to come during a weekday lunch because you'll be stuck in a line along with the Financial District workers. If anything, come after work hours or on a weekend. 

There's two counters which seat like 4 people each. On a 5pm Monday, there was no line, but the order took quite a while. They take phone calls which comprised of half their orders at that time. One tofu & vegetable curry udon, hot level please! It was about 15 minutes give or take. For a 4 star place with over 1k reviews, I'll wait any day. 
 
This is my FAVORITE. The taste actually had taste and it wasn't just salty or spicy. It was a wonderful bowl of different aromas that made it very hard to stop eating regardless of how much I was sweating. For those spicy loving foodies, try the hot. Although you'll be begging for some milk tea, it was ridiculously satisfying. There was a good amount of tofu & vegetable that actually made me feel like I got my moneys worth. I finished the bowl with not a drop left. With tax, it came out to be ~$10. Somewhat of an average price, but it's nothing compared to having the curry of your life. 

You're in for a treat if you're able to snag an order of their curry pan. They usually sell out fast, so consider yourself lucky if you can get one.
author: Fiona L.

description:
Old order:
Pork Katsu with cheese and beef - 5/5

Current order:
Karaage curry (x2 spicy, +cheese)
(Option) make the Karaage a side order, swap in pork belly

Overall, Japanese curry is "as good as it gets" and muraccis is the best around.
author: Mark O.

description:
Great food. tried it twice, once at restaurant and once from their food truck. Curry is tasty and chicken is also good.
I ordered medium spicy and it was good for me. Some of my colleagues got 3x and even 10x spicy level. (wow) 
Lines for lunch are long but its not too slow. Their to-go boxes are also decent quality.
Price is fair for the amount of food.
author: Arjan N.

description: Just found this little spot in the city for lunch and everything was really flavorful! The pork katsu wasn't greasy or overly breaded and the curry, I got it mild, was spiced but also kind of sweet which was a nice change! We also got katsu udon. Prices were reasonable and portions were sufficient! Shout out to the super friendly staff too
author: Samer K.

description:
I love their curry. I like how good it smells when I come into the restaurant. It seems that whenever I go, it's always really crowded and busy. I'm beginning to wonder if they even have a eat-in option with a plate, instead of a to-go box. They do have a couple seats at the place but it's probably difficult with everyone waiting for their food. Recently we've been ordering for our office, which eat during the typical noon time when everyone else eats, so when we went to pick up our food, we had to squeeze through the sea of people waiting for their food. 

I've tried their tender beef curry, which had like three pieces of beef, so if you eat a lot of meat (like me), I would get the extra meat... I also freaked out when I got my order because I expected the meat to be in the rice box but of course, the tender beef is marinating in the curry container. 

I have also had their chicken katsu curry, which was delicious. Kinda craving some right now.
author: Sara T.

description: Awesome place to stop by for a quick meal. I decided to get the katsu with curry (spiciest) and i was not disappointed. The lines go fairly fast although it can get super packed. The establishment is pretty small with probably around 8 seats total and no tables outside so prepare to stand or choose to hover over people who are about to leave. I did want my food a tad bit spicier and was hoping to find siracha but found none :(. The only thing i wish that they would change is putting everything in a to-go container made of all plastic even if you are choosing to dine in. It would def save then environment (just being real here) Overall, GREAT place to satisfy your curry & katsu cravings :)
author: Samee M.

description:
Japanese curry curry curry! This is an awesome hole in the wall place that you'd just walk by without noticing. They have a good assortment of curries, all with good flavor and authenticity. My favorite is the katsu curry. 

Good quick service, with quick in and out. Place closes early (b/c its near the FiDi area), so hurry over when you are hungry!
author: James S.

description:
I heard great things about Muracci's from people at work. So,I called in my order right before I left work for lunch. They said it would take 10 minutes and the walk was about the same. The order was ready when I got there, which is prob why it wasn't very hot by the time I got back to work. 

The chicken was perfectly breaded. A little different from other curry restaurants. I got the medium curry, but it didn't seem spicy at all. I also added extra chicken, thinking it was extra katsu, but they just add chicken in the sauce. If you want extra chicken katsu, it's an extra $9. Would have liked it if they clarified when I ordered since no one is going to pay for an extra katsu cutlet if it costs almost the same as ordered two meals. I'm sticking with Volcano
author: Lisa X.

description:
Pretty decent Japanese Curry in a really small spot. The line moves pretty fast and they have a lot of different options. I grabbed grilled chicken curry with brown rice with a friend and took it a nearby place to eat. 

Cheap and nothing negative to say. I was on a diet at the time so I was trying to avoid fried foods and carbs, else I would have tried their curry with katsu.
author: Kenny N.

description:
I'm amazed by how much curry they give you. So much more in excess than how much katsu I got that I even used a spoon to slurp up some of the remaining. I came during an off-lunch time so there was no wait at all. The place is pretty small, so seating for large groups isn't that great.

Katsu Curry - quick default to get. I like that they separate the curry so that it doesn't soften the katsu. Dunking those crispy, pork strips into the curry was very satisfying.
author: James N.

description:
The spicy noodle dish uses the same gravy from the katsu curry rice dish.  It's quite thick, but still good.  I ordered it medium spicy, but could've def gone hotter.  

No doubt the food here is good and quite popular given the long line during lunch.  But what stood out to me was the service.  There was a gentleman there that was taking orders from ppl in line to move things along.  He saw that my friend had two small girls with her, and saved some seats for us.  This is key given that there was very limited seating available.  

Cheap asian restaurants with good service are pretty rare.  I can't wait to bring others here.  It's like showing them a unicorn.
author: Lan N.

description: Used to be really good but now I can taste the difference. I believe the sauce is being dilluted now with water.
author: Quelle O.

description:
Food:
-Chicken and Vegetable Hot Curry Soup: I really enjoyed this dish. I ordered it with ramen and got it with medium heat. To give you a gauge, I'm the type to enjoy some sriracha in my pho (a squirt or two), but not much more than that. The medium heat was great. My nose was running (sorry if tmi), but I was able to finish the bowl. 

-Chicken Teriyaki Lunch Set: A good deal and it was healthy. I probably wouldn't order it again though, just because I want to try the other curry options. The chicken was cooked nicely and had a light teriyaki sauce on it. It came with miso soup, salad (really just a few leaves of lettuce pieces with a wedge of tomato), and the "appetizer" was a mashed potato with corn and broccoli. 

Atmosphere: It is SMALL in here. Be prepared to take it to-go unless you're eating alone. That being said, they package it to-go really nicely. They left the curry separate from the noodles and the miso was in a large container so that it wouldn't spill. 

Service: The only bummer was that they were out of beef and didn't indicate it on the menu. Given that they are so busy, when you get to the front, you feel a lot of pressure to order quickly and I was suddenly informed I needed to make another choice. Have a backup in mind.
author: Susan G.

description: This place is a small; very cute place. There's not much seating so my friends had to split up to sit. The food was really good, had the right amount of spice (I got medium spicy). But I agree with some other reviews that it wasn't TOO special. I feel like I could've made similar sauce at home. Overall, would recommend!
author: Erin J.

description:
A must try Japanese place. One of my friends took me to this speakeasy style place and in the span of 2 months I must have been there around 6-7 times. 
Their Chicken Katsu Kari is absolutely delightful to eat.
author: Saket K.

description:
I don't often go the downtown area in the weekdays for lunch. But whenever you dine in San Francisco's financial district, you are definitely paying a downtown worker's high-finance price. The food from many of restaurants can be fluky as well.

But Muracci has been one of my radar businesses for a while. And this tiny restaurant is open on Saturday, in which I came for lunch. 

On my debut, I ordered the Chicken Tonkatsu rice plate. For $10.45, I get a chicken breast battered in panko bread crumbs in a curry sauce and a choice of rice. On the curry sauce, you can choose the level of the spiciness ranging from mild to extra spicy. Also with the rice, you can order white or brown rice. I thought the chicken piece was a bit too thin with over-excessive amount of the panko batter. The Medium spicy was tolerable for wimps. But I do like the brown rice offering. 

As I was eating my rice plate, I did peek at what other people were ordering. The Donburi rice bowls and Spicy noodle soups are also popular dishes too. Other people also like the eel and salmon. But many of you know that I hate seafood. 

Weekdays are crowded. But Saturdays are least crowded. I might come back and try the other poplar items. 

My anticipated wait for this tiny restaurant has turned median!
author: Matt G.

description:
I love Japanese curry and this place definitely hit the spot. I went at 5PM and there wasn't a line. I was able to get my food in about 10 minutes. There isn't a lot of seating inside so I recommend getting the food to go. Also, try to come before 3PM because when I got there they had already ran out of some items.

Come hungry because the portions are huge! I ordered the Katsu Curry with hot curry sauce. The curry is simply amazing and the pork cutlet was really thick and crispy. I have a very high spice tolerance so I didn't expect much spice, but the curry has a nice slow burn that really starts to hit towards the end of the meal. I will definitely come back the next time I'm craving Japanese curry.
author: Jason B.

description:
Can't believe I haven't reviewed this place considering it's one of my favorite work lunches ever, probably since my first job in SF years ago. I try to get this at least 1-2x a month. 

I always opt for chicken katsu, brown rice, and extra curry, and if I know I'll still be hungry later, one of their chicken curry pans, which is basically like a deep fried bun with your choice of chicken, beef or pork inside. 

FYI, their website states there is an online delivery option but that has since been discontinued, so you'll need to order takeout or eat-in, although it's such a tiny place that unless you're meeting up for a nooner with someone who has a major love jones for Japanese style curry, it's best to just take it to go and eat at one of the cool public outdoor spots that SF has plenty of. 

My husband makes a pretty mean version of this dish at home, which I love, but sometimes the leftovers aren't very conducive to take on BART. It's nice knowing I have an option to walk less than 10 minutes for some of the best Japanese curry of my life.
author: Aivy C.

description:
I have only had Muracci's catered, but it was so good that it merited a second visit. My personal favorite is the beef curry, and though it has the disadvantage of now being deep fried like its katsu counterparts, the tenderness of the meat really makes up the difference. 

They also have brown rice for free! For those who are being a little more healthy conscious, this is always a plus. Another thing to note though, is that this Muracci's location has very limited seating so if you're coming here with a party larger than 2 definitely look for alternative seating options.
author: Tiffany K.

description:
I've been here for lunch 3 or 4 times and I probably won't be coming again. 

Taste - the food itself deserves at least a 4 star. Every item I got here was tasty and I highly enjoyed it. 

Quantity - one order is not filling enough for me. I'm like maybe 60% full. That's at least a star penalty. 

Cost - prices start at $11, considering the quantity, value here for me is very poor. Down another star. 

Two other things here I'm not a fan of - long lines during lunch (I'm the hangry type) and the inside is really cramped. 

I'd consider coming here again if it was during non peak hours and my meal was expensed. Even then I'd be sure to get at least 2 items here.
author: Jeff C.

description:
the food is consistent 

shop is a little too small

nice hole in the wall for good Japanese food
author: Stephen C.

description:
Muracci's is owned by husband and wife team from Osaka, and named after a nickname for their son. How cute! Even before I looked up the history on their website for this Yelp review, based on taste alone I noticed the unusually fresh and homemade element--either there is a blatantly obvious difference compared to your typical katsu curry, or I'm finally developing some serious food critic skills.

[TL;DR] Homemade style with skilled use of herbs and spices. Would recommend for anyone with a marginal liking for katsu curry.

[THE BACKGROUND]

So the boo had a katsu craving a few months ago, which prompted me to investigate katsu places in SF. Volcano turned out to be underwhelming (watered-down, and Americanized), Kare-Ken is in the Tenderloin (no we are not sheltered and naïve as to think we'll get mugged eating katsu in the Tenderloin... it's just out of the way), and Muracci's remained on the radar. I therefore made the executive decision to give it a try when we were foraging for lunch around the much-touristy-and-overpriced Union Square area.

[THE AMBIANCE]

Because it's small and the interior décor doesn't go all-out, Muracci's could be classified as a hole-in-the-wall. Granted you could snag a seat, the dining experience is not bad--the bar stools add a modern touch, and we enjoyed the sunlight and people-watching at the storefront window (or perhaps more like people watching us inhaling the delish curry).

[THE NOMS]

I got the TOFU AND VEGETABLES CURRY ($9) because I felt in dire need of veggies. It's not as sad as it sounds though; the fried tofu, veggies, and brown rice blended into the curry really well. It could have used more assorted/pickled veggies, but I was very impressed with the curry. According to their website, the wife owner "lovingly prepares" the curry sauce over 2 days. You could definitely taste the superior quality over those box curries (which I'm sure are manufactured with no love at all). 

I stole some pieces of the bf's CHICKEN KATSU CURRY ($9) and I honestly do not know if I've ever had such good katsu. The chicken was tender and juicy, surrounded by a delightful thin panko coating. Dip into the magical curry, devour while the katsu is still crunchy, and you'll be as happy as the grinning Muracci icon.

[OTHER NOTES]

- Prices are not cheap, but for SF it is rather inexpensive at ~$10 or a little more for a filling entrée
- Props to the brown rice option at no extra cost!
- They have weekly specials but it's not available on weekends
- There's a small selection of enticing desserts, including roll cakes and dorayaki
- They serve most food in to-go containers so overall it feels quite street-foody
- Trash can says "regular trash only".... seriously wondering what irregular trash consists of
author: Edna C.

description: Pretty decent lunch for the price. A bit salty and not as good a deal as the Katsu place I frequent in Oakland but then again this is FiDi. Overall even with the million food options out here katsu Curry is not super prevalent,  I would definitely come here again for a quick cheap(er) work lunch tho
author: Alexander Z.

description: This place is pretty good depending on when you arrive. Most of the time the food is cooked fresh to order. Being a huge Katsu Curry fanatic, this place is very on-point with their curry and Katsu. The only reason this place doesn't get five-stars is that sometimes the Katsu isn't great, and by great I mean that it's not freshly fried upon ordering. I'm pretty sure that behavior has been corrected since a few weeks ago. This place swarms with office workers during the 11:30am-1:00pm rush, so don't expect to sit down anytime then. Definitely order the Katsu Curry (medium) or the Chicken Katsu (medium) for an authentic experience.
author: Nick C.

description: Probably one of the best curry beef udon I have ever had in my life... Soooo goooooood!!! Wish it was closer to my work though!
author: Siian X.

description: Tried their katsu curry during lunch hour. It was really crowded. They only have seating capacity for 8. Almost everyone buys it to go. The brown rice was cooked just right and the pork katsu was crispy on the outside and moist on the inside. Curry was flavorful. I can see why long lines from outside the shop!
author: Gary L.

description:
Who, me??!! Yes, you!! I've been here a couple of times. I tried their curry udon the first time, and the katsu curry on the second time. I was impressed and graciously satisfied by their generous portions on both occasions. I would recommend anyone who is down to get some Japanese-curry gobbles to this place. They do it right. The curry in my veins votes them 5 stars.

Definitively a hole-in-the-wall place.
author: Jason W.

description: It's a small hole in the wall place so order To Go. It's not a place to dine in or take a date to (don't even think about it!), but this is exactly what I was craving for and I'm so very happy to have found this place! It's exactly what I want, a lot of curry sauce (which they put in a separate cup) and perfectly cooked katsu on rice. It was tender and crunchy where it needed to be, and most of all, it was tasty and delicious! Oh, so good it makes my mouth water. It's like a warm gentle hug for my belly. As for the spicy level, medium was not spicy at all for me, but it was still very good. I'm still glad it was the way it was, because I could savor everything without it being too spicy and masking all of the delicious taste. Next time though, I definitely will be trying more than medium. Bring on the spice!
author: Liz E.

description: Delicious Japanese curry! The katsu curry is my favorite. The lunch line here can get pretty long though, so I usually place an order in advance with the Yelp/Eat24 app.. so when I arrive, I can skip the line and pickup my food : )
author: Tak K.

description:
I heard about this hole-in-the-wall from my uncle. This is likely his FAVORITE restaurant in the city, and that's something because he eats out a LOT (not to mention - at $$$ restaurants too) and he's quite the picky eater. So I finally had the opportunity to try it for lunch today.

So it sounds like the Chicken Katsu is the thing to get here according to the reviews, and the fact that they ran out around 2:30PM on a Saturday is some testimony. So I got the regular Chicken Curry instead with brown rice. Since they didn't have to fry it or anything, it was way quicker than some other orders. I waited at the side for about 3 minutes tops for them to call my number.

I don't think they expect anyone to eat there at all because they don't ask if you're eating in or taking out. They DO ask if you'll need a bag though - be smart, take the bag OR bring your own bag. I didn't because the whole waste of plastic thing, but I was worrying that I'd drop all my food if I didn't hold it with both hands all the way back to the office. They give you one thin takeout box, one container for the curry, and utensils wrapped in some napkins. Don't be alarmed when you open your box to see just rice and some pickled veggies (?) in the corner. The meat is IN your curry container!

I think I understand why it's my uncle's favorite though - the spicy. I ordered a mild and I feel it was slightly more medium. But it was still edible-spicy and yummy. I feel like the rice and chicken were slightly swimming in curry but the amount of rice and meat were just enough so that I'm full and happy now.

So I will be returning to try the Chicken Katsu and their noodles some other time.
author: Athena C.

description:
Tasty, homey curry at a super popular hole-in-the-wall lunch spot.  Bar seating for ~10 ppl.  Order at the counter, or be a pro, and order online for pick-up on their website.  Dishes are ~$10-12.

They've been popularized through a number of news/magazine articles, and their quality/flavor hasn't wavered (though their prices have of course increased).  The line typically goes out the door and down the sidewalk during the lunch rush, so be sure to either go early (before 11:30) or order ahead so you can grab and go.  Or, get boba at nearby i-Tea to hold you over during your wait in line.  Granted the line moves fairly quickly considering how many customers they serve, but why wait if you don't have to?

The curry sauce is their signature, and is included in mostly every dish--it's so tasty, it makes anything you get (chicken katsu, curry pan, noodles, plain rice) super flavorful.  As others have mentioned, the curry is already spicy, so if you say you want it "medium" or "spicy", they'll make it even MORE spicy.  For you newbies, just order mild--it's equivalent to spicy at other places.

Chicken Katsu--great crispiness and tenderness, and ample portion of rice (your choice of white or brown).
Spicy Noodles--ground beef and your choice of noodles (ramen, udon, or soba)
Curry Pan--curry inside panko-breaded deep-fried bread, with a similar outer texture to katsu--they'll alternate their varieties (so sometimes they'll have chicken curry inside, or beef curry).

Overall great no-frills Japanese curry spot.
author: Vanessa O.

description: Their curry is great, but the real pleasant surprise for me is their non-curry dishes, like their gyu don, unatama don, and udon. They do these items better than any other Japanese place I know in Fidi. I only wish they included more meat and less rice; but no complaint about the flavors!
author: Carl W.

description:
Really good Japanese curry! No frills; the food speaks for itself.

The boyfriend and I stopped by here for a quick dinner, and we tried the katsu curry and the hamburger curry. Both were good, and the curry sauce was amazing. The pickled vegetables helped cut the richness of the sauce, and the service was nice! They let us stay a little over after closing time to finish our food.

This place is super small, so expect to sit right next to the bathroom or the bussing bin. The place is clean, so no real complaints about the space.
author: Lea L.

description:
If you're looking for good Japanese curry, look no further than Muracci's. There are two Muracci's locations in the Bay Area: this one in San Francisco's Financial District and another in Berkeley. The SF FiDi location is a tiny hole in the wall. The food is both affordable and delicious.

I was confused by the name Muracci's. While the name doesn't look Japanese, the food is quite authentic. Muracci is the name of the owners' son. The owners are from Osaka, Japan. According to the menu, the restaurant's curry sauce takes two days to prepare. It comes from a special recipe from Muracci's mom, Tamiko Murata.

Mainly open for lunch and early dinner six days a week (closed on Sunday), Muracci's specializes in Japanese curry (almost 10 different varieties), donburi rice bowls, curry noodles, simple sushi rolls (e.g. California rolls), and various Japanese snacks and side dishes such as fried ebi (shrimp), agedashi tofu (deep-fried tofu), and karaage (fried chicken). Filling curry entrees run about $10-11 each and most snacks under $8-9 each.

There's seating inside the narrow space, but not much. Total seating capacity is about 10. There are two four-person counters, one against the window facing the street and one against a side wall facing a mirror. There's a small table by the kitchen with seating for two. I saw many folks getting their orders to-go in Styrofoam containers. If you order in, trays are brought out to you and the food is served on actual plateware. Water and tea are complimentary and available self-serve in the back. There is a single clean restroom.

If you want to get the good stuff, go early! We visited around 4pm on a Thursday, after the weekday lunch rush. Unfortunately, the restaurant had run out of our first two choices, the Katsu Curry (fried pork cutlet with curry sauce) and Curry Pan (baked curry bread pouch). Normally, you can find the Curry Pans sitting right next to the cash register underneath a heat lamp. They'd already been completely wiped clean during our visit. I next thought about ordering the Beef Curry, but the lady behind the counter warned us the beef might be unusually tough and chewy. I didn't fully understand her reasoning, but it had to do with the cooking and prep time.

We ended up trying the Chicken Katsu Curry (#4 on menu, $10.45) and the Spicy Noodle ($9.95, #34 on menu). I was quite pleased with both dishes, particularly the former. The Chicken Katsu Curry was essentially like the Katsu Curry, but made with chicken instead of pork (tonkatsu). The breaded meat was still crispy and savory. There was a generous portion of rich, creamy, brown curry sauce. I was impressed with it. It had great flavor. It was so good, I couldn't stop eating it. Even after finishing the chicken, I kept eating spoonfuls curry with rice. By the way, you have the choice of both white rice and brown rice.

The curry entree came with a couple different pickled vegetables: red fukujinzuke (which can be made from a variety of vegetables, not sure specifically which one I tried here) and pickled cabbage. They were appetizingly crisp and tart.

The Spicy Noodle bowl was interesting. You have the choice of udon (thick white noodles) or ramen (thinner yellow noodles). We went with udon. Udon and ramen noodles are typically served in a soup broth. At Muracci's, these noodles are served smothered in curry sauce. The Spicy Noodle bowl contained ground beef topped with freshly chopped green onion. It was indeed spicy and every bit as flavorful as the curry used in the Katsu dish we tried. I'm pretty sure it was the exact same sauce.

I think it's hard to go wrong with the curry dishes here, especially the Katsu.

There's a display case next to the checkout counter selling pre-packaged containers of Japanese pickles, salads, and plastic-wrapped slices of roll (swirl) cakes (green tea, strawberry, cocoa, tora) and three different kinds of mochi (Japanese rice cakes - white, red bean, green tea).

Service is good. It took a few minutes for our orders to come out, but I think that's because the staff were freshly preparing several of the ingredients. The staff was friendly and helpful. Credit cards are accepted.
author: Daniel B.

description:
When you're visiting and you notice the store hours, I just knew had to fit in this place in somehow during my trip. Made it just in time before closing and took it back to the room. 

Muracci's specializes in Japanese curry of all sorts,  donburi rice bowls,  some rolls, curry noodles, and various Japanese side dishes and snacks. Of course, got the Katsu Curry, just shy of $11. The curry sauce was amazing, ordered it in hot and found it was enough sauce to pour over more than just the pork  cutletand rice, but perhaps over fries, karaage, shoot Anything. It was that flavorful and rich and I had plenty leftover. 

It probably has a max capacity of 8 seats. IT'S SMALL and narrow. Good luck trying to get a seat. 

Initially, I wanted the curry pan. But just like anywhere else you go, curry pan runs out fast. So be sure to come early for that and the pork curry, as they told me they run out of that fast too. Sigh, I will come back for you next time.
author: Danica D.

description:
THIS is the spot to go to for legit Japanese curry! 

I love their salmon curry with white rice with mild or medium spiciness! 

They give you a pretty big portion of curry and pickled vegetables to go with your rice and meat selection.

I'll definitely go here again and highly recommend this spot to others!
author: Alice X.

description: Really enjoyed our food! We love Thai food, and was looking for a place to grab a quick bite for dinner. Just happened upon this place, but noticed it only had 3 stars on Yelp. I usually am a stickler for at least 4, but I was starving, and my husband was okay with anything. We got two pad thais (3 of us), (cause that's our favorite) and Tom Kha soup. Both were phenomenal and the service was great, even though they were busy on a Friday night.
author: Serena M.

description:
If you're craving for something spicy, delicious and hearty, I recommend Muracci's! Beware that after your meal, you'll be in a major food coma. It is a heavy meal, so be prepared!

Their spicy noodle is my favorite! The medium was very, very spicy when I got it... but I do love spicy food. It was so spicy I was tearing up!! I also had the chicken katsu here and it's pretty good as well. It didn't feel greasy and the outside is crispy.
author: Janet H.

description:
I had been to this place a couple of times before and enjoyed the food. It's a small, crowded, chaotic place with orders and numbers being shouted out, and usually a line out the door. However it is all worh it. At my previous visits I had just tried the chicken katsu which was great but didn't stand out too much. However, today I went back and got the spicy noodles. WOW! It was incredible! I already want to go back, and cant see my self getting anything else from now on. 

I got the spicy noodles with udon noodles ( you cna choose between udon and ramen) I also got them extra spicy and it was delicious. It even got me sweating a little bit! but absolutely worth it!! 

and to THINK I was considering getting a salad instead.... I woulnd't have had this epiphany at my first bit of those spicy noodles! The moral of the story is you shouldn't let the crazy lines and cramped space deter you. This is San Francisco after all.
author: Thielson D.

description: Wonderful and tasty food.  Their Chicken Curry is delicious and although busy it's worth the modest wait for this grub.
author: Gary B.

description: Yass please! I got the classic chicken curry with I think medium heat. It was quite a treat. It's a small spot in inside, so plan on getting takeout and enjoying your meal somewhere out and about.
author: Justin W.

description: Fabulous curry. The medium was a good level of hotness without ruining the flavor. The serving size is bigger than what I expected. I ordered the chicken karrage and it had juicy meat and tender flavor. Just love this place. I'm a snob when it comes to Japanese curry places. This one is great! Only drawback is the small area- if you are willing to wait, you can snag a seat to sit down and eat, other than - try to plan to order take out. Love the food.
author: Trisha H.

description:
Originally wanted to try the beef curry and Inari sushi. Paid for both but was told later on Inari sushi was out. They could've told me at the time of the order. I substituted the Inari with avocado which is average at the best. 

Now on to the actual curry experience. The beef portion was small. I counted about 3-4 small pieces of beef. So I mostly filled up with rice. I ordered medium spicy which is decent. Not too mild and with a kick. The brown rice option is also a nice touch. 

I recommend to try pork cutlet since the portion size is better. I will probably try it next time. 

Overall, average experience.
author: Xing M.

description: Best Katsu in the city . I've been here multiple times in the afternoon and they deliver each time. The lines aren't too long and I've waited only 10 mins or so if I turn up at 1 PM
author: S A.

description: I ordered the spicy ground beef noodle - it was quite tasty and pretty spicy (mild). Prices for their menu are decent, not really cheap or expensive. I do wish their portions could be a little more generous. Despite waiting in line with a crowd of hungry people, service was fast! Staff was friendly. There is a slight possibility of another visit, just to try the katsu chicken with curry over rice.
author: Diana L.

description: Nice little shop in San Francisco for takeout Japanese curry or rice bowl Items. I had Katsura-don with roasted cold green tea. Both of which I was delighted to find. The staff was friendly but the shop is very small and I would think might get crowded during busy lunchtime. Overall no issues with the food - obviously not as good as Japan but it's a nice little find in the area.
author: Robert C.

description:
Katsu curry and chicken curry.
Where is my chicken? I thought maybe that's why chicken curry is the cheapest curry, wait! That should be called curry over rice! It tastes as same as instant curry in every Japanese store, they r way cheaper!
鸡肉咖喱饭木有鸡肉，怒怒怒不管你们谁要点餐，请一定要确认你是否拿齐了！！！看到好多评论都缺东少西的。。。味道也就那么一回事儿，还不如去日本超市买个咖喱自己热着吃，更便宜，而且绝不会少东西！！！
author: Welcome Z.

description: Excellent Katsu Curry here. Wow! I got it Spicy, but I'm going to get it extra spicy next time. I also want to come back to try their Curry Udon, their Gyudon, their Ramen...I wanna try everything here!
author: Michael K.

description:
First, let me say that the katsu curry is good. I really like the medium hot flavor because it gives a bit of a kick to the katsu. The katsu is pretty big in size and they are very generous with the amount of curry they give. Secondly, I did also have their fried bread stuffed with curry, which is basically a coroque. This one was definitely worth the money. I could have had 4 of these instead of the actual curry dish - but apparently these sell out really quickly so grab one when you see them! 

 I knocked of a star because while their food is good, especially the curry, it's just not good enough to justify the $10.something price tag on it. Coroque was expensive too but justified because it's so darn good.
author: Sarah K.

description:
Two words: Food Poisoning.

My friend and I both ordered the Katsu Curry and we both ended up with a really bad case of food poisoning. I actually really liked the Katsu Curry, but I just can't take the risk to go here.
author: Kevin S.

description:
I've come to realize that I'm not really a person who likes to get Japanese curry when I go out to get food with friends, but after hearing some hype about this place I decided to give it a try with another one of my foodie friends.I got the chicken curry medium spicy with white rice, and he got the chicken katsu curry mild spicy with white rice. All their curry dishes are around $8-$10 and come in a take-out box since I guess they assume everyone who visits works in FiDi wants to take it back to their office and the shop itself is VERY small; only two spots for seating in front of the mirror and by the window. 

I thought portions of the food were a good size, considering how food is expensive in FiDi and there isn't much, but this was enough to get me full without any leftovers. Foodie friend and I had the same opinion that the curry here is very mild; not too salty, but not too rich. We THINK that no meat is used to flavor the curry itself, but I would ask in case this was a concern. Otherwise, chicken was super tender and had a piece of the katsu; can't go wrong with it as well. They separate the curry sauce (if you get meat, it's already in the curry. If fried meat, comes in the box) from the rice which is nice, so it doesn't get soggy.

I'd come back if I was having lunch with a friend in FiDi, but I wouldn't go out of my way. Highly recommend if you're on a lunch budget. Also, they have lunch specials that run out pretty quickly, so come here early or order ahead to claim yours!
author: Kathleen S.

description:
Unfortunately, the special 20 hour simmered curry they are famous for has always been the item I like the least on their menu.  Fortunately, you can always ask for it to be served in a separate container on the side.

Today, I had a really tasty dish the Gyudon Beef Bowl for $11.25.  It has paper thin slices of beef, onions, pickled ginger, rice, and a really nice tasting broth.  You can add an egg for $1 more.

For me, the Gyudon is best thing on the menu, and it doesn't come with the curry sauce unless you pay $1 extra for it.

Now I'll just have to visit when the lines are short!
author: Roy C.

description:
Having had Muracci's on my radar for so long, I'm glad I finally got the chance to try it the other day! I always figured that this place was a little overrated but I'm happy to say that the food wasn't bad at all. :)

The lunch crowd seems daunting but they do a pretty good job keeping the line moving and the ordering process organized. I had the curry pan and spicy katsu curry, and was impressed by how the pan and katsu stayed crispy after a 5-10 minute walk back to the office! The portion sizes seemed small but I was full and enjoyed everything.

So why only 3 stars if I enjoyed everything? Even for Japanese curry, I thought that Muracci's rendition leaned a little too much on the sweeter side and lacked depth compared to my fave places in the Bay Area, so I have to rank it lower.
author: Steve L.

description:
I ordered from yelp and specifically noted that I will pick up my order at 1 PM.  I got there around 12:55 PM.  The food was already on the shelf.

1. The food was not hot. Less than so-called warm.
2. the pork was over fried and hard.
3. I order mid-hot curry.  The curry I got today did not even taste like a mid-hot curry.

I know they are busy.  But they should not sell a over-fried meat. And the level of heat in curry is not consistent. Sometimes mid-hot is too hot and sometimes mid-hot is not hot at all.

Don't recommend order thru yelp or over the phone with them.  They make it when they get notification and let your order sit on the shelf. 

Yelp provides pick up time option, but it seems to me they do not use this function and do not care about your note.
author: Louise T.

description: Yummy curries!! Even the vegetarian one is delicious. And you can select your spice level to make it perfect. I also love their curry pans that they sell next to the register. It is delicious!
author: Sharmi D.

description:
I wanted to love this place, but it fell short.

First of all, this isn't your eat and dine type of place. It's your get your food, go eat somewhere else type of place. It's very small, and you're looking at bar seating with people waiting in line watching you eat if you want to stay.

Second, I would suggest anyone who wants to try the curry here to get at least medium. Having an extensive two days of drinking, I didn't think spice would work well with my stomach so I went with mild. While safe, the curry lacked flavor and just felt watered down.

Third, the Katsu Don needs to be more sweet. The broth was just salty and there was no dimension of sweet & savory which to me is what makes the dish. The more I ate it, the more I cried that I wasted my money.
author: Jason F.

description:
Yum! The hype is real!!

I was walking down Kearny one day and saw this place packed with people. Of course, the illogical side of me automatically associates long lines with delicious food. I got in line and opted for the pork katsu with medium-spicy curry over brown rice. As others have mentioned, the storefront is extremely small and cramped, with people everywhere. You get in line where one employee asks what you want, shouts out your order to the kitchen, and tells you to stay in line to pay up front. To be honest, I felt a little rushed and pressured to place an order ASAP. I realized while waiting to pay that there were a lot of different non-curry options that I could have picked from. No regrets though because my curry ended up being delicious. The medium spiciness level turned out to be extremely mild, so I'll suggest getting the spicy or EXTRA spicy if you're looking for that extra kick. Can't wait to come again, but definitely not during weekday lunch hours when the wait can get a bit long.
author: Tammie K.

description:
I have a huge soft spot for Japanese curry; it's definitely up there on my list of favorite meals. I wanted to try Muracci's after hearing great things & realized it was only a block away from my work.

I ordered the Chicken Katsu Curry with medium spicy & added vegetables (+$2). The medium had my nose running, but if you can handle and love really spicy foods, I would consider one upping the spicy level. The chicken katsu was a little on the dry side and fried a little too long. I also wished that my carrots were a bit more on the soft side. PERSONALLY, I like Volcano on Geary better; their curry sauce is a tad bit thicker than Muracci's.

Overall, I enjoyed my meal, hence the 4/5 stars, but I have had better! Plus, now I'm in a huge food coma and can't think straight at work!
author: Elizabeth W.

description: There is some good curry going on here.  While this place really seems more for the weekday work crowd, there was still a decent crowd coming in on the weekend.  There are only about 10 seats or so in this place so takeout is probably a better option if you can.  Another thing to note is that their curry bread must be popular.  It had sold out by the time I was there, but a few people came in asking about it!  Anyways I just had some pork katsu with the spicy level curry.  It was hot, fresh, and super tasty.  One thing to note is that the spicy level curry does have some distinctive differences in taste compared to the mild.  Basically, you're missing out if you can't handle the spicy because there was a small but significant depth of flavor added.  This spot really does amazing curry katsu and is much better than what you'll find at sit-down restaurants in SF.
author: Bryson L.

description: I ordered a chicken curry for take out today. When I open the curry bowl, guess what!?!? There is NO CHICKEN in my curry!!!!! I would never go back to this place. Bad services! Check your food before you leave!
author: Joanna H.

description: Sooooo good. Spicy curry with cheese omelette was the bomb. Best curry for sure ! Planning to visit again with my friends soon. But there is no enough seat :( can onlt.5 people can seat and eat. others kinda have to take it Togo
author: Reina Y.

description:
Came her during lunch time with a coworker during Thanksgiving week. When we got in line, we were right outside the door. It took maybe 15 minutes or so to get our food? I heard during a normal week, there's a lot more people and the wait can be really long. I saw that some people ordered ahead and can just come and pick them up.  I suggest calling and ordering ahead if you decide to come during the workday. 

The food itself was okay. The chicken katsu curry and rice was okay and the spicy was just a okay spice level. I know you can get a level higher then the spiciness they suggest. 
The price is a little pricy for what it is. 

Overall, nice to have once in awhile but it's a little expensive. The wait can be long so make sure to order ahead if you're coming during lunch time.
author: Paul U.

description:
Quick and affordable eats! Great lunch spot featuring katsus, udon soup, and their famous curry that's been simmering for 2 days. Their chicken katsu was moist and flavorful even for being white chicken breast. Their curry is definitely amazing. Try them both in their chicken katsu curry combo :) Portions are generous and filling.

Tiny space, with very few seats to eat in. Most people grab and go. The line is ridiculously long between the time of noon to 1pm during lunch rush. I came in at 11:45 with no problem.
author: Minh N.

description:
Japanese currryyyyy!!! I have a secret love for claustrophobia-inducing small restaurant spaces to begin with, but the food here really sold me. Muracci's offers a variety of Japanese curry foods (and non-curry foods, if your heart desires) including soups, rice dishes, and as I came to discovery yesterday, donburi.

I ordered the udon tofu & veg curry soup because I was feeling a sore throat coming on. Medium spice did the trick for me! The veggies were fresh, the broth flavorful, and the noodles plentiful. You are served in plastic containers with plastic forks/spoons like to-go food, and I liked that they separated garbage disposal into compost, recyclables, and bottles. My friends who ordered katsu curry got a huge portion that came with sides. Stealing a few pieces I can confirm that it is a great choice!

Very quick service, very delicious ($8-12 range) food! Recommended for curry lovers.
author: Vicky N.

description: This is a very authentic japanese curry restaurant. We got the pork katsu curry and the pork was very tender.
author: Kevin C.

description:
It is a cheap fast food Japanese curry place close to some of the European consulates in SF. The line is long during lunch time. They don't have much seating inside - guess their primary customers are the nearby office people.

The spicy Beef Curry Ramen was the best I've ever had and it was my first time trying Ramen. It was really spicy in a good way, even though I ordered medium spicy. Fried chicken with rice was mediocre.
author: Mia C.

description: I haven't been here in a long while and my work decided to order takeout. I ordered the Katsu Curry and it was satisfying. The portions they give are a lot. I always end up having left overs.
author: Stephanie Y.

description:
Busy, busy store. The lineup was through the door onto the street just to order, not to mention a lineup to actually pick up the food. The good news is, on your receipt it shows you the estimated time you can pickup your order next to your order number, and mine was correct down to the minute. I'm not sure if this was always here, as last time I came was in 2014.

I went in and tried to get the Ebi Fry, but it was sold out. And the last karage was sold to my coworker just ahead of me. But that's alright, because the 2x hot chicken katsu curry was delicious. My only wish is that I had ordered extra veggies, as I'm not the biggest fan of just meat and rice. If you do want either of the first two dishes mentioned, you should probably try to get there early to avoid the lunch rush.
author: Rajeev S.

description:
This was my second time at Muracci's and I wasn't too impressed. I ordered the curry katsu(mild) the first time and it was too overcooked and dry. Though the curry itself was fairly good, it was somewhat lacking in flavor and was a bit too salty.

Since first time impressions aren't everything, I decided to try Muracci's again the following week. I ordered the beef curry(mild) this time and was completely devastated because as I fished for my tender beef chunks in my to-go curry container, I only found four and yes I said FOUR pieces of beef in there. My coworker who had got the chicken curry had at least a full grown man-sized handful of chicken chunks in his. 

Next time, I'm going to test my curry luck elsewhere.
author: Jen F.

description:
Mmmm curry. This place is really near my office so we sometimes end up here to grab a quick lunch. This place basically sells super yummy Japanese curry! I got the pork katsu with white rice and milk curry and the curry bread. The curry bread is actually really good--they have it on display so it's a nice snack to have when you're waiting for your curry. Basically just bread with pockets of delicious curry flavoring on the inside.

The actual curry itself was also pretty good. I didn't love the pork katsu--it was drier than I would have preferred mostly because it was such a thick cut, but the curry was absolutely delicious. This place is a grab and go mostly (makes sense since it's FiDi) but they have counters that you can sit at. They'll give you the curry in a separate container which is awesome and very convenient. Curry flavor is great. Portions are very fulling--it is a giant box of rice basically. 

tldr; yummy Japanese curry to go--lines can get long!
author: Jasmine X.

description: I had the katsu curry. Both the curry and the chicken was delicious, and the servings were generous. The business is quite cramped but I think it just adds to the atmosphere. Good for a quick meal.
author: Victor Z.

description:
It's good, fast and cheap. If you wanna grab something quick and yummy for lunch, it's a good option definitely.
I ordered curry udon and I like it very much.
author: Meng Q.

description:
Worth. It. 

AMBIANCE- Tiny little space where customers are packed like sardines. Hard to distinguish the people eating vs. people paying vs. people waiting. 

FOOD- But so good! I got #5 Ebi Fry Curry ($11.25), which is fried prawns served with curry sauce. Love that the fried prawns came with a huge lemon wedge. I ordered my curry hot and my rice brown - both good choices. Also loved the plentiful special house pickles (seemed like fukujinzuke and gari). I also got the Inari Sushi (5 pieces for $3.95). Such a solid choice because it comes with so much rice and it is so filling! Also comes with gari (pickled ginger). More than enough food for me but I ate it all! And, to vouch for its goodness, both these dishes were still delicious after a 10+ minute trek home in the rain!
author: Phoebe C.

description:
Umami: 3 Quality: 4 Price: 3 Wait: 2 I booked marked this place cuz I love the depth and flavor of curry. Came here during lunch and ordered the spicy tonkatsu curry +  extra cheese ($2.75). The line was out the door during lunch hours, so expect to wait. 

The curry was not served pipping hot as I expected. It's understandable since they have to serve numerous customers in the most efficient amount of time. Overall, it was more warm than hot and the flavor wasn't there. The tonkatsu also lost its crunch because of the moisture in the takeout box. My stomach was greatly disappointed by all the positive reviews.
author: Alex Z.

description:
Japanese curry is one of the most popular dishes to eat in Japan. They have curry over rice, curry over noodles, or curry bread. My favorite? Definitely the curry over rice. The chicken katsu over rice was served on a large plate with some pickled vegetables. You can pick between white or brown rice, or you can even do half half. You can also pick the level of spiciness. 

There are a lot of other things I want to try on their menu, and I'm hoping they're as appetizing as the pictures look! Besides rice and noodle dishes, they also have small snacks and desserts. They don't have a lot of seating, which is why people usually take food to go. If you want to grab dinner here, make sure you go early because they close at 7pm!
author: Christine S.

description:
We were looking forward to eating here since their other location closed a year or so ago.  We were really dissapointed.
The curry sauce was very bland, the rice was not cooked correctly, but the katsu was good.  That was the only bright spot.

A really small place with counter seating for about 8 and one miniature table for two.  Looked and felt dirty.   The cook dropped his rice scooper on the floor on the customer side, rinsed it in his canister of water and did not wash or replace it!
