Won't be returning and recommend that they clean the place top to bottom and train their staff on basic cleanliness.
author: Ken K.

description:
Decent food but definitely over hyped IMO and not too cheap depending on what you get. I ordered the veggie curry udon, which came with plenty of tofu, broccoli, carrots, and bell peppers. It was tasty, but nothing special. 

My bf ordered the salmon curry. Please don't order this - it was no good and not worth it. It was a tiny piece of salmon and super fishy tasting. Worse of all, it cost the same as the katsu curry where you get WAY more meat. It cost more than my udon as well, I think $13 + tax. 

My sister and I also shared the fried curry bread. It was disappointing for me. The curry was lukewarm and most of it was fried breaded crust, so nothing spectacular. 

Overall, I probably wouldn't go out of my way to come back. If you want a quick lunch, then maybe stop by. Otherwise I think there are much better places to eat at in the area.
author: Sophia H.

description:
The Good:
* service was on point, fast, organized

The Bad:
* i am not a fan of this style curry. i am from hawaii and used to many different styles of curry, japanese curry - and i thought the chicken katsu curry came out very dry
* the portion was a bit small for me, i mean for $12

The Weird:
*sigh* when people order things like Japanese curry with brown rice. unless you have a medical problem where you can't eat white rice, some dishes you should only eat with white rice. but hey, eat what you like!
author: Juliann C.

description: I had the chicken karagee and pork Katsu. Both were pretty good and it's a very good to grab your lunch and go to some nice open air place nearby to enjoy the food.
author: Ash M.

description:
Comparing curry is basically like comparing fried chicken. Various cultures will have their own interpretations of fried chicken: all of them are very good but very different from one another. You wouldn't compare Japanese fried chicken to Korean fried chicken right? So it would be unfair to do the same comparison for curry. However, unlike fried chicken, there really aren't enough places in SF that serves Japanese curry which means if I said this place was 2nd best curry in SF that wouldn't mean much if there were only two Japanese curry shops in the city (I've only found two so far). 

As far as Japanese curry goes, this place is certainly worlds better than the garbage House curry packages you can find in the Japanese grocery chain. Rather than a bland taste of curry and sweetness which seems to be the general consensus of Japanese curry, the flavors are a pretty good blend of spicy, sweet, and salty. The curry is just the right amount of richness so you can get all of the flavors which is made even better by the red pickles that come with your order. My personal go-to is the pork katsu curry plate since the pork katsu is tender on the inside and crisp on the outside which works well with the curry. It's not quite the flavor mom has for her homemade curry, but it certainly isn't far off.
author: Ray L.

description:
must try if you're ever in the area. I love their chicken katsu curry. sometimes if they're not busy they'll let you replace rice with noodles but you'll just have to pay a little more. 

their katsu is crispy, with juicy meat on the inside. their ramen/udon curries have a more soup like consistency, but their spicy beef ramen is a bit more thick. 

only thing I would like them to change is to have a chicken katsu ramen/udon option on the menu.
author: Ava F.

description:
For $10, it was a shamefully meagre amount of food.

Chicken Curry: 2.5 stars
Just rice and curry with a little meat and pickles. Mild was slightly spicy for me.

Better flavour than the average Japanese curry in America, but still nothing to write home about.

I might try the Katsu curry at some point, but was not impressed this time.
author: Letitia L.

description: It was a cold and rainy day - a perfect recipe for some Japanese curry lovin' to soothe the soul. They ran out of chicken katsu and karaage, so I settled for the katsu (pork cutlet) over brown rice, with medium spicy curry. The breeding on the pork strips was excellent, not too heavy! Small joint but great grub and friendly people behind the counter. Come hungry!
author: Andy L.

description: I've looked forward to tasting their japanese curry for a while,  and I just had my delicious Ebi Curry Though the curry sauce is perfect,  the Ebi seems to be over fried which makes the appearance look dark.
author: Amy C.

description:
OMG, where has Muracci's been all my life? Nothing will ever be the same since I tried Muracci's for the first time three days ago. Since then, I can't stop thinking about curry tonkatsu.  At night, I lie in bed thinking about curry tonkatsu, and my first thought upon waking up, is curry tonkatsu. I've had curry tonkatsu twice in three days, and although I had one for lunch a few hours ago, I'm thinking about getting it again for dinner.

Muracci's is amazing, it's hard to imagine anything more delicious than their tonkatsu and curry.  Their tonkatsu is perfect. It cannot be done any better. It's crispy on the outside, and moist and juicy on the inside, with perfect texture and porky flavor. And the curry, what the hell is in that? It must be crack. I think I'm addicted, I can't stop thinking about it. I want to drink the curry.
author: Allen T.

description:
I found Muracci's on the SF.Eater's best meals under $10 list and since I work in FiDi I decided to give it a whirl.  

I grabbed a coworker that grew up in Tokyo and walked to Muracci's.  He had been there before and verified that their Japanese curry is indeed authentic.  

 This place is very tiny and has very minimal seating.  Expect to order and take your dish to-go

We ordered the Katsu curry chicken and tufu & veggie soba noodle bowl for takeout.  Our orders came very quickly with minimal wait time.  Both dishes were ordered with medium spice heat.  The curry sauce accompanying the katsu was complex and flavorful.  The curry broth in the soba noodle bowl was similar, but thinner and more broth-like.  It was also complex, flavorful, and not too salty.  Both the dishes had just right amount of heat.
author: Andrea H.

description:
I was in need of some comfort. Some comfort food that is! After getting a little carried away with the wine at dinner the previous night, I needed something for lunch that was warm and comforting. Enter Muracci's!

Curry pan ($2.75) - I wasn't planning on getting anything other than my curry noodle soup. But these looked so good while I was standing in line, I had to have one! The bread was fried perfectly and the curry just made it that much more comforting. 

Curry hot noodle soup bowl with ramen: beef and vegetable ($9.45) - Warm soupy, saucy, spicy goodness in a bowl! Just what I needed to sop up that extra alcohol still in my system!

The gentleman who took my order was super nice. He found me a seat and brought me my curry. The place is very modest in size, but clean and comfortable. Next time I want curry, I'm coming here!
author: Elena N.

description: From the moment I started working at my office, my team members were raving about this place. Finally after about an year and a half on my last day we made it there. And I was not impressed with the food. I felt it was way too much flavor bursting in my mouth than I can handle. I had the vegetarian curry along with white rice , I don't think this restaurant works for my taste.
author: Sailaja B.

description:
I love this Japanese curry place!

My favorite is the katsu curry (pork cutlet). You can choose to get white or brown rice, and mild, medium or hot curry. I usually get half and half rice (half brown rice, half white) and the mild. Today I tried the medium just to be adventurous - and it was a bit spicy! I usually don't take spicy foods very well, so if you love spicy foods, medium is probably very doable.

There is usually a line out the door for lunch. And very few places to sit inside - maybe 5 chairs or so - so most people just buy it to go. You have the option to call in, and I've seen people do that, but I've never tried it. Usually the line isn't too bad if you can get in before 12:15pm.

I haven't fried the other items in the menu so I can't speak to those - but if you're craving Japanese curry, this is the place to go in downtown SF!
author: Ena Y.

description:
3.5/5 solid stars
IMHO, this place is a bit pricey, but given its location, I will let it slide. 

The food is good, fresh, and made to order. However, good place for a small party--very difficult to accommodate large parties. There is not much sitting room. Counter tables with about 6 or less seats in the restaurant. I noticed a lot of folks ordered take out. 

Ordered: 
1) Spicy Beef Curry Udon Soup: 4/5 this was my favorite; great portion and good size. My soup came out piping hot.

2) Beef Curry over brown rice: 3/5 eh, this was OK. It would've been nice if there was more beef in this dish.
author: Jen H.

description:
I ordered the weekly special, pork belly curry, and chose the "hot" option.

I got a mild curry with curly ramen noodles, three pieces of crisp Chinese greens, three pieces of whitish, unseasoned pork belly, a hard boiled egg that was cooked too long, resulting in greenish discoloring, and a garnish of chopped scallion.  All this for $13.32.  Bags are 11c a piece extra.

Plus:  the greens are fresh and the curry flavor is very good.

Minus: none of the items picked up the flavor of the curry, resulting in a bland experience.  I ended up pushing aside the noodles and slurping up the broth.  I had some extra curry left over and poured it over the noodles, hoping that if it sat for about a half hour, the noodles would be infused with the curry flavor.  Nope.

The next time I'll try the curry puff - it's a deep fried pocket filled with curry.  Maybe that will pick up the curry flavor.
author: Sondra H.

description: Great spot for Japanese curry!  Friendly staff, quick service, and delicious food.  The line can get backed up at the lunch hour, but that comes with the territory of serving up goodness.  I only wish it were a couple blocks closer to my office.  Chicken katsu or chicken karaage curry are my go to choices, and why not order up extra curry sauce while you are at it! Portions can be very inconsistent, check your bag before leaving.
author: Colin S.

description:
I don't know how I've lived in SF for 4 years and never had Murracci's. & I don't know how I even went to Japan and never had Japanese curry. So when I recently got a new job close to Murracci's, I finally had a chance to try it. I love that you can choose from white or brown rice, & that you can choose the spiciness level. Katsu curry, brown rice and spicy will always be a favorite, but I tried my friend's chicken karaage ramen recently and that was surprisingly good as well. 

Long lines during the lunch hour, so if you're in a hurry, you can order ahead!
author: Elizabeth B.

description:
Came here on a Monday evening after some shopping with a friend, since it was MLK day, it wasn't as busy as the other reviewers had mentioned. Anyways, like everyone else said, this place is tiny, I was lucky to snag two seats right when we got our orders. The curry is great here, got my freshly made chicken kaarage curry fix and the right amount of medium spiciness (in my opinion, I've got a fairly good tolerance of spicy). Not recommended if a good kick ain't your thing. 

What really got me here was the service, the man running the place was super duper nice! He not only cleaned up and wiped down the table as we sat down, he also got us and everyone dining there some napkins and water without us having to ask. Agh too sweet!

Hope to try the curry pan and curry udon next time around!

Also to whoever was playing Hyukoh in the background while we were there, you got great taste! Sincerely, a piece of kpop trash. 

Japanese Curry in The City checked off the list: 
-Volcano 
-Muracci's
author: Olivia C.

description:
Forget chicken soup for the soul--Japanese curry is where it's at. Since I was feeling a little under the weather, I wanted some spicy curry to gulp down.

Their location on Kearny St is a bit smaller than their location in Los Altos (RIP), with two rows of counters on the wall. Surprisingly crowded for 3pm, but we received our food rather quickly and the staff wasn't overwhelmed--rather, they were quite pleasant!

If you're craving curry, it helps to get there early; by the time we got there, they were out of about a quarter of the menu toppings (popular items seem to be ebi fry, cheese, and pork katsu).

Portion sizes are generous and worth the price (~$10 per plate), IMO. The plate is split pretty evenly down the middle in terms of rice to curry roux. There are also sweet pickles on the side to cleanse your palate. The curry has the consistency of thick gravy (not too watery) and you can tell it's better than the instant stuff. It's not too salty or full of MSG and has a more complex flavor, with tones of tomato, herbs, and spices. Their "hot" spicy curry won't burn your tongue off, but it helped decongest me a bit. You can also choose from brown or white rice, with no extra charge for the brown rice!

From the limited options available, we went for the chicken katsu and the tofu&veggie toppings. The chicken katsu was top notch, crispy crunchy, and the breading was actually adhesive (instead of falling off). The chicken was juicy and tender, too. The tofu was lightly fried so it was crispy on the outside and the vegetables were soft but not overdone.

With that, Muracci's has leapt to first place in terms of my favorite Japanese curry in SF.

I'll have to come back to try the curry noodle soups.
author: Jade V.

description: Chicken Katsu Curry done right! I usually struggle finding a place that can get the breading right (not soggy) and the curry (not too salty), this place nails it. Also liked the little pickled garnish too.
author: Briget P.

description: Went here for lunch and the food was fantastic. During lunch time it is hard to find a spot to eat in the restaurant so be prepared to take your food out. The Chicken Katsu Curry was amazing!
author: Wayne C.

description: Love japanese curry... this place used to be a block away from my old office in the city. I used to love going here. Every time we are in the mood for katsu and curry I try to make it out of my way to stop by this place.
author: Dave Z.

description: Too small to have space for in-house eating. But the staff is friendly and nice. Chicken katsu curry with spinach is good.
author: Zoe L.

description:
This place was good! It's a bit small but the food was fantastic. I got the spicy beef ramen noodle and those little curry chicken hot pocket thingies... I"m not sure what they are anymore but it was REALLY good. This place is literally a hole in the wall, and it's probably small then my bed room. I swear to god, people were rubbing elbows in line and breathing down each other's neck because it's so cramped. The tables and booth are really condense, it's really hard to eat there. I recommend getting take out because if you sneeze you might actually knock someone over... jk. no really that might happen. 

pros: foodddddddd *get the chicken hot pocket thingies
cons:spaceeeee
author: Lalaine T.

description:
I stopped in SF to visit some friends and we walked from their place to Muracci's. 

It's tiny, it's loud, it's awesome. 

Everything tastes really great, and it feels like some serious Japanese comfort food. given a different environment, I could sit and spend a few hours with friends, just sipping tea and miso.

At $15, it's an inexpensive hot meal in SF, and doesn't disappoint in any way.
author: Jacob S.

description:
Came here for lunch the other day. Pretty busy hole-in the wall type of place with lines out the door.

I ordered the Katsu Curry with Mild Curry. The curry was a little runny for curry and didn't pack a lot of flavor. I felt like each bit of curry, katsu and rice was a tad bland for Japanese Curry. 

The portions were a bit meager. I only got 6 slices of Katsu atop the rice. The Katsu was made perfectly. Cripsy on the outside and tender on the inside. The rice though was a bit soft and a touch soggy.
author: Cyrus H.

description: I made an order online through Yelp and stopped here to pick it up to avoid all the lunch madness on a weekday. The place is really small and has very few seatings. The people who work there are constantly dealing with all the people coming and going so you really have to get their attention to ask for your takeout order or you can just try to find it yourself in the front. There was an older gentleman who works here who was extremely nice and attentive if you could find a seat to sit down and eat your curry. I ordered the katsu curry and asked for extra spicy. The price was decent, not super cheap for lunch but not too expensive. They gave me a lot of pork and the curry sauce was tasty and had quite a kick in it. I went back to work full and satiated. I would certainly come back here again for lunch!
author: Catherine T.

description: I tried their salmon shioyaki set with green salad, potato salad and miso soup.  It was all so tasty, filling and refreshing, and they give a generous amount of food.  I love their potato salad with broccoli pieces mixed in!
author: Maile N.

description:
I arrived 10 minutes before they closed, when asked if I was eating in or taking away, I said 'well you're closing in 10 minutes so I'll take away'. The guy behind the counter (who I think may have been the owner) said 'Oh no no, you have plenty of time'. Wonderful. The same gentleman poured me a glass of water, from the water fountain that I could have helped myself from - very nice of him.

I took a seat and they served my meal up about 10 minutes later. I'd hate to find out what the hot curry is like as I had the mild (the lowest heat) with udon and it had my rose running. It was pretty tasty.

At 7.10pm (10 minutes after they closed) the gentleman came over and filled up my glass again. Such amazing and friendly customer service.
author: Laura D.

description:
In spirit of the Warriors (mostly Steph), my cravings for curry has made it to the top of the list.
Muraccis always has a long line streaming out the door... Even on parade day.
This compact Japanese joint makes me feel claustrophobic yet happy at the same time. The exposed kitchen and staff are working hard at getting everyone's orders out.

I have decided to try the Tonkatsu curry. The katsu was breaded nicely with a thin crisp around my juicy pork. The curry itself was solid - not too watery, not too spicy, not an explosion of flavoring, just a solid delicious curry. The brown rice itself I felt was a little hard but mushed well after being drowned in curry. 

I know their seats are limited but eating in is an experience in it of itself! Also, I feel they give more when you dine in only for the large plate they serve it on. Overall I am super satisfied!!
author: Linda K.

description:
I ended up with the beef curry with plain rice. I always try to have saucy foods with white rice. At medium spiciness, it provided the perfect amount of kick and didn't overpower the other flavors of the sauce. The beef was very tender and overall, it was a pretty good and filling meal.

I hear that the hot spiciness level is pretty spicy so be prepared to sweat.

This place is pretty small so be prepared to wait in a line during lunch times and it might take a while if you bring a group of friends.
author: Marco C.

description: Great katsu curry at this place! I ordered a spicy tonkatsu curry and it was great. The portions were good and as someone who enjoys curry as their favorite food the curry itself was great as well. It's a nice small shop that u myt not even notice but totally worth the search for. I have been to Japan and tried authentic katsu curry, and I have to say that this place is right there with it. Hot, crunchy panko crust with juicy, tender meat inside, great place
author: Adrian E.

description:
This place is a first Japanese Curry restaurant I had been to. A friend took me there to celebrate on my most memorable night. I was so happy so everything tasted nice and delicious.
I came back two days later, finding the flavor of Chicken Katsu Curry stays the same. So delicious. I wish they could have more side salads. The price isn't cheap to student. Could go only once a week -.-  wish they could lower the price a bit.... (Love the grilled Salmon btw!)
author: Bao V.

description: Love the spicy Chicken Katsu Curry. I order it once a week and have learned to either order it online or to call in the order. There's always a line out the door for people ready to order.  I wouldn't mind trying other items but I love the chicken too much to bother. Staff is quick and friendly, space is a bit tight, but it's perfect for pick-up.
author: Combiz S.

description:
**Disclaimer** 

I'm NOT a Japanese Curry connoisseur

I ordered the chicken curry with ramen noodles, medium spicy. This meal was perfect, given the brisk fall weather we've been experiencing lately. I like how they give you a to-go bowl and not some tupperware thing like what you'll receive from Vietnamese establishments for pho.

I dig spicy food, and I'd say their medium spicy was accurately labeled. Had quite a bit of kick, but not enough to say it was "spicy."

The bummer was that the prices had gone up from whenever the prices on their page were posted. Some more noodles would've been nice, or ingredients as a whole. Tend to like my veggies a little softer too when they're in a soup.

All in all, it's good, but a little pricey for the amount received. But that's to be expected when dining out in the Financial District. Perfect for cold weather though!
author: Aaron C.

description:
My co-worker and I had the craving for some chicken Katsu, and since it was a late lunch we had to scramble over to Muracchi's to satisfy out cravings. Stood in line and placed my order and while waiting, happened to ask how hot they will make the spicy curry sauce? 

The gentleman running the counter told me they can and will make it up x 20 spicy!!!  I immediately felt the challenge was on. I ended up asking x 15 spicy... I've tried x 10 spicy at other places and I haven't been phased in the past, and that's where they tap out so I figured I had to go big or go home this time around.

When I placed my order, I heard a slight gasp from a few regulars inside, knowing they thought I was being excessive. When my order was ready, I was told by the gentleman behind the counter to enjoy and "try not to pass out"... That added more fuel to the fire!

After adding about half of the curry sauce on my order, I realized that this was serious business! Caught that tingle in my throat and I was in love ! Copped a cup of water and proceeded to finish up and was on my way my co-worker. He said since he lives close by he will be here multiple times per week. Glad he was willing to venture up the block to enjoy this gem of a place with me...

Already anticipating my next visit... See you all soon!
author: Josh H.

description:
Best Japanese curry spot in SF!  Got the Pork Katsu with extra spicy curry and the curry here definitely has a kick to it! Love it! 

However the pork katsu was too thick for me, I like it a little bit thinner. However it was still really good. Fried really well! 

Cheap and good!
author: Janet K.

description:
While I was walking around in SF, I was craving some good Japanese curry and found this place on Yelp!

It's a small hole-in-the wall, but there was a line coming from the front door. You can smell the curry cooking as you walk in.

You can tell that this place is authentic because it's run by Japanese workers who speak Japanese.

Based off of people's reviews, I ordered the Chicken Katsu Curry and it was delicious! The katsu was perfectly breaded. And the flavor of the curry was spot-on. Definitely a hidden gem in SF!

There are not too many seats available, so I would recommend getting it to-go (if you're in a hurry).
author: Lily Y.

description: Came here with some co-workers during lunch and yes the place is extremely packed and busy during the lunch hours. Claustrophobic people may want to stay clear because there's barely enough room in here to even stand while waiting for your food! Past all of that the line moves quick, the prices are basic Fidi prices and the food is quite good! I ordered the chicken katsu with the smallest of spice for the sauce. It came with some veggies and also some rice. I waited maybe ten minutes for everything and it came out to me. I actually enjoyed the katsu, but looking at my fellow co-workers (check my picture for it) I felt like I got jipped on the amout of chicken! Anywho, it was crispy and the rice went well with it. I wasn't a huge fan of the peppers and in all honesty I should have gotten at least medium spicy for the sauce. I was very full after regardless of my complaints about the amount of chicken and I would definitely come back here again!
author: James R.

description:
I didn't get a chance to try their curry dish yet but I heard great things from coworkers. This is a tiny shop so be prepared to wait a bit or order online in advance for pick up. I personally love spicy food so I ordered their Spicy Noodles and hope for the best. 

It was the bomb!!!! I absolutely love the dish. I actually ordered SPICY on the degree of spiciness and you can choose between udon or ramen. It comes in minced beef sauce so it is not exactly noodle soup. 

I really love it and I can eat that almost everyday, I will return for their famous curry for sure.
author: Athena C.

description: Not the best Japanese curry in SF but decent. I'd recommend Volcano Curry of Japan in the Richmond District.
author: Curtis L.

description:
I'm not a huge fan of curry at all. Really, I don't fancy the taste at all. I work in the area and have noticed that this place always has a line out the door. So I decided to be a little adventurous and try this spot out.

I ordered the chicken katsu with curry and extra tofu. I was very impressed actually- I loved the pickled cabbage pairing that my meal came with! It was a good balance of flavor with the curry. I just wish they provided more rice- I'm Asian- I can't help it, gotta have my rice! The curry was impressively pretty tasty and I like how they serve it on the side as opposed to serving it over your food and every inch tastes like curry. 

Honestly, I would've given this spot 5 stars but after my meal I started feeling a bit different and a little light headed. Maybe there was too much grease in the food? I'll give it another shot though, maybe it was an off day?
author: Dara S.

description:
Sad face.. My Paypal wasn't working/connecting... So beware. About 4-5 people in line when I got there after 1pm. Wait time for food was about 5 minutes? Really cramped in there. Bar like seating.

Had the mild Katsu curry. Seriously. That pork was AMAZING. Fried perfectly and the meat was sooooo tender and delicious. Haven't tasted anything like it. The curry however, not enough flavor. It's like Japacurry but I think Japa has a little bit more flavor. Honestly, I'd come back just for the pork.
author: Benita M.

description: Check it out new place and it's delicious curry that I haven't try it before. I ordered #3 Katsu curry. The store is kinda small but luckily we come at the right time so not really busy. The chicken is very crispy and curry taste good but. Will come back next time to try different food.
author: Travis N.

description:
So listen, I make Japanese curry at home.  It costs $$$ and lasts for a long time.  So as I've searched the Financial District for the curry I don't HAVE to make, Muracci's was a pleasant surprise.  What I don't understand is why everyone in the city seems to feel the need to blend their curry; probably to make it last longer.  And Muracci's is no different, don't expect chunks of vegetables.  But the curry is rich in flavor and they offer Mild, Medium and Spicy.  Medium has a kick.  Forewarned is forearmed.  Just be sure to get there at 11am or the line is out the door around lunch.

IT IS VERY SMALL.  Plan on getting it to go if you are doing lunch.  

They have curry hot pockets!  Delish!  

They also have traditional japanese teas and drinks like Calpico.  No Pocari Sweat, however.

The staff is friendly, courteous and respond well to compliments and encouragement in Japanese (because unlike many places, they are actually Japanese!) ;)

Healthy portion sizes; you definitely get your $11 worth for curry.
author: Mark B.

description:
Love the curry tonkatsu here. I opted for the "spicy" which barely registerd any spice in my book. Still the curry was flavorful and delcious.
The Tonkatsu was juicy and crispy,

Muracci's has very limited seating so just keep that in mind.
Most customers take the meals to go.
author: Geordie E.

description:
Tonkatsu curry was awesome! 

You'll probably be in a crazy cluster of a line inside...but its worth the crowded wait!
author: Katie 2.

description:
Absolute deliciousness! I've had a few lunch meals here, and every time it has been really good. I get the chicken katsu curry, which is fried chicken curry.

My only complaint is the space constraint. I always use orderahead for pickup, but trying to squeeze into this place to get food is a nightmare.
author: Dylan R.

description:
Not too much to say about this place. It's kind of a hole in the wall with little seating, but they make a mean Japanese tonkatsu curry. The spice level is also solid, though if you are a big spice fan, I would suggest underestimating how spicy it will be and kicking it up a notch.

Debatable whether this or the Japacurry truck is better - I'll leave it up to you to decide that for yourself.
author: Ananya M.

description: I had grilled salmon with mild spicy curry. The curry was just ok, not anything special. They also have this funky pickled stuff which is just not my cup of tea. Anyway the reason for the low rating was that I had food poisoning after eating this.. I had not eaten anything all day and then had this for dinner with disastrous consequences
author: Joseph H.

description: Curry was my goto meal when I lived in Japan and I'm always on the lookout for an authentic experience at a good price when I'm back. This is one such place. Good curry sauce, good katsu, good rice at a good price.
author: Mike H.

description: Got the Chicken Katsu Curry. It was already busy at 11:15 am. It was alright. It was filling. We still go back but will get another dish.
author: Melinda B.

description: Disappointed. Feels like overpriced. And I choose the chicken katsu, it is not crispy. The meat taste too hard.  "gogocurry" in NYC is much better than this one. Don't know why the review got so many stars. Though the service is very good.
author: Peng G.

description:
Katsu curry, yum!

I have to admit that I'm not really a fan of Japanese curry. There's something about the texture that just doesn't do it for me. However, I kept hearing about Muracci's and figured that I should give it a try, just to be fair.

The space inside Muracci's is so small so do not get stuck there during an emergency or you will not be able to get out. Although it's crowded, the kitchen staff clearly knows how to churn out food quickly.

We took our curry elsewhere to eat and I was pleasantly surprised by the rich flavor. I asked for it to be spicy and I completely expected to get "Japanese spicy," aka mild but it was spicy enough to almost make me cry (in a good way). Too bad Muracci's is too far for me to go for lunch regularly.
author: Yi Z.

description: I used to live in Japan and this hole in the wall is as authentic as it gets when it comes to Japanese curry. Generous portions.
author: Andy N.

description: The curry ramen is so yummy! It was super easy ordering online on yelp and picking it up at lunch. There was a huge line during lunch so we totally did the smart thing by ordering ahead and picking up. I got the chicken with vegetables soup, mild with ramen noodles and I would definitely recommend it.
author: Stephanie Z.

description: This was a great experience! The food tasted good. It is a pretty small and cramped space, which gives you the feel of an actual restaurant in Japan. I live far, but I would make my way back to SF to eat here again.
author: Marcus J.

description: OMG SO DELICIOUS! Small hole in the wall location and not mug seating when you go in! But the staff was extremely nice and the lady who took our order was super helpful! When we received our food it was nice and hot! I highly recommend this place when you are in San Fran! I ordered the number 4 chicken, medium spice which was not hot at all! Check this place out!
author: J.C. F.

description:
So underwhelming and unimpressive.
The curry was... Pretty bland. We got the spicy but it actually wasn't that spicy and there was so much rice with the chicken katsu. The curry noodles were also... Kind of like a "the heck am I eating" kind of feeling? The servers were also pretty unhelpful. We asked them a lot of questions to try to get a better understanding of the spice levels or the items on the menu they recommended but they were more interested in talking to each other. At the end, we asked for our check several times and ended up just having to go to the counter ourselves to pay. I don't think I'll be returning any time soon.
author: Michelle K.

description:
2.5 Stars, would not go back but not a regretful try.

The Chicken Katsu Curry and Tonkatsu Lunch Set were both okay.  First off, spicy isn't really spicy here in my opinion.  Second off, the Avocado Roll is hella stingy on the avocado.  I don't think that's my opinion at all and that anyone in their right mind would agree with that assessment.  Third off, the curry sauce was just okay but the meat was pretty good.

Lunch is crowded after 11:30 am, so best to go earlier if possible.  I seriously don't get the hype.  Don't expect a seat, there's only a handful of seats in the place.  Good thing we went early.
author: Phillip N.

description:
After finding out about this place, I have been going back to try new things for lunch. Yes, the line is extremely long and the restaurant is crazy small and crowded. Thing is, they don't "hurry" their food to match the people, in a good way. The food comes out nicely cooked and they are all very flavorful. 

I have tried the Katsu Don, Katsu with Curry (medium) and Spicy Noodle (between medium and spicy). I first when their to get their katsu don and soon realize that literally everyone is there to get their curry. So I went back and get their katsu with curry. I didn't know their spice level so I went for the medium. For my Thai tongue, the medium was nothing, it was just nicely cooked curry with no spice (I'm not saying it's bad, I'm just saying it's not spicy ;P) -- I like the curry flavor though, which means I will definitely make another trip there for a hotter curry. And last but not least, the spicy noodle. I chose the recommended ramen noodle with medium-hot spiciness, since the guy said that the medium in the spicy noodle is equal to the hot in the curry. I liked the flavor of this a lot, definitely worked with my spicy crave :) I would probably get hot the next time I go though. I love spicy food, if you can't tell.
author: Rapas C.

description: This place was hard to spot as it visually doesn't stand out on kearny. The location is cramped and seating is insanely limited. I decided to try this place out since it was highly recommended by my friends and i was greatly disappointed. I ordered the medium grilled chicken curry and the curry itself was overcomplicated with the heavy amount of spices used and the chicken itself was very bland. I tried the pork katsu which was alot better but i expected each menu item to have the same degree of satisfaction and effort. I also noticed a cockroach running along the picture frames which begs the question: how often is sanitation maintained in this restaurant? Overall, i would not highly recommend this as the best curry place but only when i am around the area.
author: Bernard W.

description:
Still 5 star all the time! This time I tried their dine-in service with their pork belly ramen! It was super awesome! Usually it is always out during lunch time! 
They are famous for chicken katsu curry, but other items are also tastey! It is worth of waiting and trying!
author: Nina H.

description:
I like curry. All curry. Chinese, Thai, Indian, etc. etc. etc. Japanese. All good and all different. I've had my fair share. This here is good curry.

I like that they make it from scratch and that it's started the previous day. I like the meat (chicken). It falls apart, it packed with flavor, and there's a decent amount of it. There could definitely be more of that red ginger and some vegetables would be awesome. Brown rice for nothing extra is nice to see.

I like those things a lot, yet somehow, Japanese curry is always, always just a little better than those dried blocks of curry from the market. Unquestionably better at a restaurant, but somehow only slightly so. I don't get it. Maybe those blocks are just high quality.

That won't stop me from having it out though. Oh no no no.
author: Andrew R.

description: Went here last night with a friend to try out Japanese curry. I got the katsu and am a fan. The breading was perfect and they let you swap out white for brown rice if you want. Great take out food, although you can dine in (although this can be tricky during peak meal hours :p).
author: Helen F.

description: Japanese curry was new to me but I'll definitely eat again. It was delicious. I got mine with tofu on ramen noodles. It's a tiny place, only one table and some counter seats by the window. I was lucky to get the table. Bathroom was clean too!
author: Shannon H.

description: Muracci's offers some tremendous Japanese curry. The medium curry is sweet and spicy - it doesn't taste too spicy but the spice builds as you eat it. The staff is very friendly, and the food is reasonably priced. If you're planning to eat in the restaurant, be aware that it's very small and seats are not usually available - takeout is probably the best option.
author: David V.

description: Their chicken karage curry is the best. I visit SF location at least couple of times a month and the food quality is always consistent. Usually ~5 minutes wait.
author: Umer M.

description:
Food 5  I tried only Grilled Salmon with brown rice a couple of times. always good.
Ambience 2 Tiny, uncomfortable space to eat in, so togo is a better choice.
Service 4 Fast, organized well
Price 5++ Grilled Salmon with Miso Soup and Brown Rice costs just $11. Love it!
author: Tory T.

description:
A small grab-n-go place, probably can seat no more than 8 customers.  Came in late afternoon just to avoid the dinner rush.

Ordered #3, which is the Tonkatsu (pork) Curry hot with brown rice.  It was also served with Daikon garnishes on the side.

Surprisingly, the tonkatsu was prepared very well and not overcooked. The hot curry was creamy & spicy, but not overwhelming to put your tastebuds into shock! The curry/pork combination paired very well together and the serving portion was generous.

For a small place, the food here packs a punch and I can understand it's popularity!! There are a variety of selections and keep an eye out for the weekly specials.

I'll be back most definitely and can't wait to try out the other meals!!
author: Dalmacio C.

description: Eeh?? I do not get the hype. Got the katsu curry. The breading on the meat was poor. I also ordered an unagi don that had maybe like 7 pieces of unagi total and the rice was oversaturated with soy sauce. Was not impressed.
author: Leslie C.

description:
Tried the chicken katsu curry -- it was alright, definitely not worth the $11. Curry sauce tasted a little bland; I'd say the Japanese curry sauce mix in a box taste even better. Rice was undercooked. 

I did, however, try the chicken curry pan and it tasted pretty good!
author: Shela D.

description:
Been hearing a lot about this place, so my girlfriend and I decided to try it out.  It's a VERY small restaurant, with ~4 seats in line against the wall, and another maybe 6-8 seats in line along the front window.  Note that they typically do not do sushi on weekends.  The staff is friendly and responsive.  I had the Katsu Curry (pork cutlets with curry).  It comes with a side of white rice or brown and some pickled vegetables.  You can have your curry mild, medium, or hot.  The curry is naturally spicy already, so just keep that in mind - you are just adding more spice.  I thought they made it pretty fast, less than 10 min wait.  The katsu was very crispy and cooked well.  The curry sauce itself was OK, the flavor was very common for me.  Medium spicy had the right amount of heat, but most people not accustomed to this kind of cuisine or other cultural foods will find that mild is probably too much to handle (you know who you are =P).  The portion size is good, it will fill you up!  I could have eaten more, but I was still satisfied.

My girlfriend had the spicy noodle.  You get a choice of ramen or udon, she had udon with hot spicy level.  It was really spicy, scorching, but she likes it that way.  Portion size was deceiving, it looked like a small dinky bowl of noodles, but she was stuffed after it.  Watchout guys =)!  The sauce is very thick with ground beef and green onions, it's like japanese spaghetti, don't think of it as like a noodle soup dish, but instead, a thick noodle curry dish.  

We also had the curry pan - hot, which was not that spicy.  The filling size is decent and the crispy dough/pastry was delicious.  It's like a japanese empanada - must try!  Overall, we'd rate this $$ instead of $, it's kind of expensive for a "fast food" style place.  We'd come back though, it's definitely worth trying!
author: Kevin N.

description:
I always see a crowd and line here around 5-6 p.m. I checked the grill out during their slower hours to see what all the fuss is about without having to elbow my way through. I really wanted to like this place but it fell short of my expectations. 

It is pretty small inside so I wouldn't recommend bringing a crowd with you during their busy dinner hours. There was bar style seating with wooden stools. You can get cold water from the container located towards the back. I don't recall seeing a bathroom available. Service was ok, not rude but not memorable either.

The curry pan was very popular and had already sold out by the time I arrived. Before I visited this place, I looked up the menu on their website and had picked out the tofu and vegetable curry with rice. The picture on the site showed the dish had a nice, even ratio of how much rice you get versus curry and veggies. I ordered it and chose the mild heat option. 

My total was almost ten dollars, so I was shocked to see the amount of tofu and vegetables I got on my plate. Good thing I ordered brown rice because I pretty much ended up eating mostly curry flavored carbs. Somewhere on the wall, they announced increases in prices after a certain date. I understand San Francisco's rent prices are insane but is it too much to ask for a few extra carrots and peppers so my glucose levels don't overload? Well technically, you can but you have to shell out some extra $1.50 for it. 

The curry had a soupy consistency. It wasn't necessarily a negative point for me but maybe some people would like their curry more thicker. If there were more vegetables provided, it would have balanced it out more because I just ended up with mostly soaked rice to eat. A couple positives: The curry had a nice savory taste and the few vegetables I got were hot and cooked fine (not over/under cooked). I did enjoy the red and white pickles that came with the plate. They were crisp and packed a punch flavor wise. I wish I had more of those to mix in with my rice. 

Due to all the rave reviews, I want to give them the benefit of a doubt and the possibility that they were having an "off day". However, I am very hesitant to come back and give them a second chance because I really don't want to experience feeling ripped off again.
author: S A.

description: So Muracci's is strictly inferior to Japacurry. No question. I know i'll regret revealing this, for it will surely make Japacurry's line even longer, but I think chicken katsu is much better with thigh than breast. I also don't like Muracci's curry. I've had Japanese curry throughout the city, from Inner Richmond to Japantown to Downtown and I like Muracci's curry the least. It's not thick enough and I find it bland. Maybe it needs more starch. Maybe it needs to be sweeter or something? I dunno, but I love katsu & curry and Muracci's just doesn't hit the spot for me :(
author: Andrew D.

description:
I was a little underwhelmed by Muracci's. The service is awesome, since it's a cute mom-and-pop shop. And they move very quickly, despite the line out the door.

We had the Katsu Curry ($10.45) and Chicken and Vegetable Curry Noodle Soup ($9.75). The Katsu breading was nice and crispy, but the pork was really dry. Once the curry is poured over it, the breading gets soggy and you're just left with dry pork. The portion sizes are very filling though, and the pickled cabbage salad side is delicious. The curry here is a little different from the standard Japanese curry you would usually get. There's a lot more flavor packed in with veggies, spices, and ginger.

I liked the curry noodle soup. It's udon in curry soup (pretty much the same consistency as their katsu curry, but as a soup) and packed full of veggies and meat.

They also have some cute Japanese drinks and snacks (mochis).

Really small restaurant with a counter with 4-5 seats (it's a little bit in the way of the line to pay) and three small tables that sit maybe 1-2 people each.
author: Alice T.

description: Super tasty Japa curry made in a tiny hole in the wall by a friendly and capable wait staff. It's now on my list of trusty lunch spots!
author: Tyler D.

description:
Oishi-desu ne! Best Japanese curry in town.
Long line during lunch, but moves fast.
author: Nate A.

description:
Omgoodness... THIS PLACE WAS BOMB!!!!

I went to Muracci on a Monday night with my coworker before our Star Trek preview and I suggested Japanese Curry (one of my fav dishes) for dinner. We stumbled across Muracci on Yelp and decided to check the joint out. 

The inside is very small with only a few tables and seats. To order, you go to the front and order your meal, then wait about 5-7mins for your food. The aroma of the curry smelt so good that my mouth was salivating as I sat patiently waiting for my food. 

When my order came out I finished the whole thing within 10 mins, LOL! My Pork-Katsu curry had a great balance of sweet, spice, and was very savory. *drooools*

I will definitely come back!
author: Annie D.

description: Had the beef curry and it was fantastic! Came here to make sure we weren't drinking on an empty stomach and it was a very nice surprise. Stop in and try it!
author: Ed K.

description:
Hello All,

Today was my first time eating here and MAN o MAN what an experience. A lot of people kept mentioning how great their food was and I must agree for the most part. Especially with their curry entrees. Their salmon was alright, nothing special. The firm wanted to have a luncheon and so we decided to try this place. WHAT a mistake that was! DO NOT ORDER bulk orders from here! I would not recommend. They will rush your order out due to the amount of traffic they get. I completely understand because we ordered 22 things, but we ended up leaving with only 21. Without knowing of course. On top of that some of the orders were wrong. I'm not going to give them a bad rating because of those mistakes, because the food tasted awesome regardless! The staff was also very nice.

Food:4/5
Staff:4.5/5
Area:CROWDED during lunch.
author: Pj A.

description:
Delicious! During my trip to SF, I stayed in the financial district and this place was only a few blocks away from the hotel. I was thoroughly impressed.

I got there at about 1130, and there was no line!! It definitely filled up fast and by noon there was a line out the door.

I ordered the chicken Katsu curry, and there was absolutely nothing wrong with it. The chicken wasn't at all oily, fried til perfectly crispy, and really juicy. The curry was flavorful and paired perfectly. The whole meal was so simple, but so well done! At around ~$10 a meal, you really can't go wrong!
author: Ken T.

description: Great place to try super tasty food! If you are around the financial district or Chinatown you shouldn't miss this small Japanese restaurant! Food is on your hands in 10' and full of flavor! Totally recommended
author: Nacho C.

description:
Hole in the wall goodness. The cutlets were a bit overcooked and so the end pieces weren't edible. However, it's hard to find good Japanese curry, so when in town, this is where I'm eating guaranteed. 

A bit pricey, $25 for two meals and no drinks, but maybe not seeing how this is SF. Definitely saving this place for future visits.

I had pork cutlet and my wife had chicken cutlet (both curry).
author: Jason Q.

description:
Simple, specialized concept - curry!  

It's a very small, narrow place that is generally designed for people who work in Financial District to just order up a good meal of curry rice plate or noodle bowls and take it to go to eat for lunch or dinner!  They have limited seats to dine in so I recommend ordering it packed to go!  

The line during peak lunch hours move actually pretty fast!  Service is on point with getting your meals down and served out quickly. 

They offer pork katsu, chicken or beef and brown or white rice.  I got their beef curry with brown rice and it was amazing!  They provide these pickled veggies that complimented well with the meat and curry.  It was delish!

It's a good meal to a point that my plate was cleaned with no sauce, no grain of rice and no pickled veggies left!
author: Tiffany D.

description: 99% of the time I go, they're out of the curry-pan. Either they sold out or the guy that makes 'em called in sick. But what's a girl to do? The only thing she can: keep trying and remain curry-pan optimistic!
author: Yad L.

description:
The curry here is pretty good for the area, not the best I've had, but definitely good. In hindsight, spicy was not spicy, but you actually need to 5x or more the spicy for it to be considered hot. Ordering during lunch hour was a breeze, in and out in 10 minutes. The guy taking your order in line expedites this so much better than you'd think. 

If I were to go back, cough. I mean when I go back, I'd order the tori katsu, with white rice (people, do you know that there is better nutrition in white rice than brown? ugh), extra sauce, and 5x spicy. If there are croquettes, you know I'll be ordering them. 

The croquette was great, btw. You should get one if they have them.
author: Eric A.

description: Good food, decent price, but extremely slow service. Don't come here if you're on a time crunch. I came around 6 and I received my order in 30 min. I could tell other customers weren't really happy about it either. This wasn't my first visit, but I felt compelled to write this review now because I've noticed that they're only fast during their rushes. I'm probably going to come back, but management please look at my review.
author: Jeanne C.

description:
The line was wrapped around the outside of the store so we knew (hoped!) it would be good. We stood in line and waited for about 15 to 20 minutes before being served. 

Once we got to order we chose the chicken katsu curry with white rice and milk sauce. It only took about 5 minutes for our order to be called. 

Even though the line was out the door it was all office worker grabbing take out. We grabbed a seat in the window and dug in. The sauce is served in a small tub so you can add your own and not let it get soggy.

It was delicious! Crispy and crunchy coating and not a bit dry. The sauce was the perfect level of spice with all the taste that you want in a Japanese curry. It also comes with pickle on the side which cuts through all the heaviness. 

It's not and everyday meal but it is certainly delicious!
author: Jess U.

description: Asked my coworkers where I could find flavorful curry within walking distance of Union square and they pointed me in Muracci's direction. I called in an order for tofu curry noodle soup around 12:15 on a Saturday and it was ready when I arrived at 12:35. At medium heat, the spices were just right and there was a good ratio of veggies/noodles/tofu. Very small space, so plan on taking your order with you. Overall filling and full of flavor, would definitely come back!
author: Mary S.

description:
I've tried their salmon curry and their ebi fry lunch set. Both were delicious! But the curry was my favourite. Get the spicy option because it's honestly not that spicy.

Definitely coming back for more of that glorious curry!
author: Cindy Z.

description: I could eat their katsu curry every day. And I actually did for a couple weeks before I came to my senses and realized that I was paying A LOT for lunch. Anyway, I couldn't recommend this place more. It's amazing. Just go there, alright.
author: Rob C.

description: I would normally rate Murracci's much higher but the last 2 times I ordered the chicken and vegetable ramen I found a piece of medal in my curry and today there was a strand of hair! The quality of the food is always great but please make sure you guys aren't losing your attention to detail and being careless!!!!!
author: Leeni L.

description:
Soooooooooo good!!!  One of my favorite places for lunch!! Sometimes I even pick up a bowl for dinner and take it to go.

The curry lunches are very good, but I always get the oyako don. They are generous with the chicken and egg, unlike the place across the street. And the sauce is perfect. Note that this is mostly a to-go place. They have a few seats, but it's cramped in there, especially since the line is always running through the entire restaurant and out the door. No exaggeration.

TIP: Call in your order ahead of time. They'll tell you it will take 15-20 minutes, but it's usually done in 10 minutes. Then you get to cut to the front of the line, pick up your order, pay, and leave. It's brilliant!
author: Jaching H.

description: I got the beef curry which was satisfying, but I expected more - both in quantity and quality. The portion size left me wanting more, and I just felt something was "missing", although I can't quite describe what.
author: Michael S.

description:
This place used to be my go-to place for lunch when I worked a block away. Nowadays, it's a bit of a walk, but still worth it. I normally get the chicken katsu curry. I love how they use chicken breast for the katsu and it is not as greasy as the katsu i am used to. 

One time, I accidentally ordered the chicken katsu rice plate (no curry) instead, but it was still good! Don't know if I was just hungry, but even the katsu sauce tasted so much better than other places. I also tried the curry udon, which was delicious as well.

The only downside to this place is that the place is super tiny (size of a hallway) and the line can get ridiculously long during the lunch rush.
author: Annie X.

description: Place gets packed with people, it's really awkward but totally worth it for the curry.
author: Mario L.

description: Sweet nectar of the gods I would move to SF just for this place alone. I love Japanese curry and have been having it for a few years now. I was visiting SF when I stumbled on this amazing place. When I walked it I got super claustrophobic. This place is small but definitely worth the lack of space. I ordered the pork belly curry with a curry pan on the side. The curry pan was so savory and hot it made an excellent appetizer. But that pork belly curry, oh my jesus, that was a orgasmic experience. At first glance my eyes went straight for that huge layer of fat. I know pork belly is fatty but this one was extra fatty. I hate fat OR SO I THOUGH. I poured my hot curry all over it and took a bite. The fat just melted in your mouth in the best possible way. It was like drinking bacon which is probably what it was. I had to NOM NOM NOM as fast as I could because I couldn't get enough. I even forgot to breath at one point. Even the pickled veggies that came with it made a perfect accompaniment to cut through the heavenly pork belly fat. YOU NEED TO GO HERE. It is a must. I have nothing bad to say about this place besides the space but I understand the struggle for real-estate in SF. 20+ Stars
author: Billy K.

description:
Everyone raves about how great this place is, but I don't this place lived up to the hype. I got her just before the lunch rush and was able to grab a table. I got the katsu curry and my boyfriend got the chicken and vegetable udon curry. I also decided to try the hot chicken curry pan, which is basically Muracci's version of an empanada. 

The katsu curry was good, but I felt like I could make this at home. The chicken and vegetable udon curry was interesting, but again I think I could make it at home. The hot chicken curry pan was not good. I think Muracci's is overhyped and won't be back.
author: Melanie H.

description:
Muracci's has been on my bucket list for years, ever since I heard it described as "the kind of curry your mom would make". A ringing endorsement, if I ever heard one! Unfortunately, my mom doesn't make curry (she makes a mean egg salad, though) and my S&B curry leaves something to be desired. So, finding myself in San Francisco one afternoon, I made my way down Kearney, in search of Muracci's mythical homestyle curry. 

In a city booming and busting with food trends, it seems that Muracci's popularity has in no way declined since opening. Locating this hole-in-the-wall was easy; I scanned Kearney for a line of hungry lunchers spilling out onto the sidewalk, and made my way in toward the counter. Ordering was also easy- as everyone was ordering the chicken katsu curry, I saw no reason to buck the trend.

10 minutes later, I was sitting in front of a bento packed with warm, fluffy rice, chicken katsu, and bright, pickled veggies. The katsu --thick, tender slices of chicken breast beneath a crisp, golden crust-- was particularly well-prepared, and stayed crisp even after a 10 minute walk to my next destination. The curry sauce lent a warming shichimi kick to the entire dish, and paired well with the spicy, tangy cabbage and daikon radish slices, which (alongside the katsu) were the bright stars of the dish. I was surprised to find that I wasn't floored by the curry itself, but grant that it did its job in pulling the bento together. 

What's really amazing (but also infuriating to me, as an out-of-towner) is how accessible and easy it is to enjoy an inexpensive, good --and I mean good-- lunch in downtown SF. If you have 20 minutes to spare, you too, can have hot and fresh Japanese comfort food.

FiDi'ers have got it good...
author: Tianyi S.

description:
Good curry!

I went during lunch on a weekday so the line was super long. Fortunately the wait wasn't too long (around 10-15 minutes to wait in line, order, and get my food).

The food is a little overpriced and there isn't much seating inside.

I can't handle food that is too spicy so the medium was a good amount of spicy. I got the chicken curry, so the chicken pieces came in the curry bowl. With the fried chicken curry, they lay out the breaded chicken over your rice.
author: Rica Z.

description: Disappointing is the word that comes to mind. I ordered the chicken katsu curry, and the curry was bland and too runny. I get better curry at the Japanese market.  I get that this is more of a take-out place, but the restaurant itself kinda reminds me of a restroom stall because it's tiny. Sorry Muracci's.
author: R Q.

description:
Went here twice during my stay at SF. First time for lunch then for dinner the next day to try out different menu items. Chicken katsu curry and pork katsu curry were delicious and katsudon was very good as well. 

The line during lunch was crazy and because the place is so small, it does get very crowded. I appreciated efficiency of their ordering system where the guy marks your order on a sheet and all you do is just hand that paper off to the cashier. Food does take awhile to come though. Service was very good and I will come back!
author: M K.

description: Got the spicy noodle with ground beef and pork katsu with curry. Was delicious and luckily got a place to sit but I wouldn't count on finding a place to sit in the future since there's maybe about 10 chairs in there and most of the seating is bar style seating.
author: Saachi G.

description:
This place always has a line out the door.

Food is lit. I've tried most of their curries with Chicken Katsu or Chicken curries being my favorite.

Spicy is always a must as it can get quite hot. They give you picked daikon and brown rice is an option.

Its just cheap, delicious fast food.  Can't beat that.

Only thing is that it will come out the same way it came in.

Will come back...
author: Jeff H.

description:
Honestly this place is just alright.  I expected something amazing but here's what I got:

1)  Located in tourist haven, between Union Square and Financial district* (I refuse to say "fiDi as I'm a native and I think it sounds pretentious and stupid).  Suffice to say parking is a real pain in the rear.

2)  Flimsy and lukewarm curry pan (those hash brown looking nuggets)...had to ask 3 different people to warm it up and they simply tossed it in the microwave...and yes it tasted microwaved.  Who wants a floppy and chewy nugget covered in previously-fried panko?  Not I.

3)  Ordered the beef and veggie curry over udon.  Medium spicy.  My nose ran the entire time and my stomach felt like it was a nuclear reactor ready to blow.  No bueno.

I gave it one extra star because of the nice older Japanese gentleman who insisted on throwing away my bowl and utensils for me.  Everyone else seemed grumpy and disinterested in giving any sort of customer service.  The younger kids were talking amongst themselves and really could give a youknowwhat about paying customers walking in.  Is this really a Japanese restaurant??
author: Cin P.

description:
The short: Ok Katsu place

It was only 11:20 and my friend and I were already waiting right at the door! The menu is on the glass wall, and after a couple minutes, a guy with a pad asks what we want. I decide on the katsu curry with brown rice and medium hot.

After waiting about 10 minutes, my order arrives! Luckily my friend and I score a spot at the counter opposite the kitchen. Mild privacy, though we would prefer a spot looking the street. 

Interesting story... right after the cashier took my order, the iPad register crashed so... it had to restart and reboot, which meant that the line just continued to extend and wondered why the line wasn't moving. (It's not our fault!)

She ordered the Katsu curry too with the mildest curry and a side of the curry pan. The katsu curry was not worth it, the curry pan (which I had a bite of) was. I would love to try other things on their menu, just not the katsu curry.

We tried stopping by around 5 and they were sold out of their curry pan! :o Order it while you can!
author: Catherine W.

description: Overpriced and dirty tourist trap that will have you running for a toilet within the hour.  Asked for gyudon which was on special, they didn't have any. Asked for omelette curry and chef got mad because she didn't want to make it.  Went with regular beef curry rather than arguing and literally sat next to a toilet to eat it (which the cook then used and the smell from the door blew over me). Curry was nothing special and I was sick an hour later.  Asked for a box to take it out and it was as if I was speaking a foreign language - took a while to explain what a carry out box is.  Left it with the homeless man outside.
author: Richard O.

description: Found this place on yelp because I've always wanted to try katsu curry. Soo good! This Japanese joint is pretty small and can be easy to pass by if you don't pay attention. I get this is a passing-through kind of eatery, but the place is just too closed in for my liking. Other than that, customer service was great as well as their katsu curry! Definitely check this place out in the city!!
author: Jordan L.

description:
I've had Japanese curry.

I've had chicken katsu.

But I've never had them together before.

Is this the epitome of a perfect union?

My working friend and I visited on a Wednesday noon and were lucky to only encounter a 5 minute wait. This is a small, efficient operation up in here! To speed up the process, they have a waiter walking down the line to take your order before you get to the cashier to pay and wait 3 minutes for your food.

The famed item here is their CHICKEN KATSU CURRY (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/muraccis-japanese-curry-and-grill-san-francisco?select=XuHUWHSl3dT18caakYC9Vw#XuHUWHSl3dT18caakYC9Vw), $9.95, $10.82 after tax, and asking for brown rice is free of charge. For the express to-go orders, the curry comes in a separate container to keep the chicken from getting soggy. Thoughtful, amirite?

Juicy chicken with a crispy breading that soaks up the savory curry with ease. Healthy brown rice to satiate the stomach and the conscience. Delicious and filling. It really is a perfect union.
author: Adele F.

description: I had the chili curry with ramen. Most delicious meal ever! It was spicy and I did need to order a side with it to fill me up.
author: Adriana N.

description:
As much as I want to give this place 5 stars, I have to take one away due to the small space and the dirty bathrooms. :(

This place is literally a hole in the wall. 
It's small and Does not have a tables or chairs. If you get lucky, you might find a small area for yourself on the counter that's if you go during a down time. Otherwise, expect to order to-go.

Other than the tiny space, it doesn't change the fact that they have delicious curry dishes! We got the chicken Katsu curry. It was a chicken breast fried to perfection with just enough curry sauce. We ordered a side of brown rice! 

Love the pickled veggies they had in the side.
I would definitely come here again.
author: Benson T.

description: Ordered the Salmon Curry and got a TINY portion of salmon.  I compared my meal to my coworkers and their portion of meat (tonkatsu) was huge compared to my little cut of salmon.  VERY DISSAPOINTED especially when you are expecting to experience what is suppose to be 4-5stars of a meal.  TIP - DON'T ORDER THE SALMON!! I gave 2 stars because I can see the potential if I had order meat other than fish.
author: Paul John G.

description: Really good vegetable/tofu curry. More of a place for take out, as the seating isn't awesome. All the people working there are nice though!
author: Madeleine M.

description:
Muracci's curry is a favorite lunch go-to for many in my office. The location is cramped (similar to the way smaller spaces are the norm in Japan) but they make a small space work very efficiently. 

The curry is amazing. Kaarage curry is delicious (and why wouldn't it be, it's fried chicken!) and I recommend ordering it with vegetables for a larger meal, so you can save half for dinner as the portions are quite large.

I've tried some of their daily specials (unagi udon) and have never been disappointed. Thanks Muraccis!
author: S. B.

description:
I can eat Muracci's everyday and still not get tired of this place. I enjoy ordering the spicy chicken katsu curry with white rice and every now and then the pork katsu is tasty too!

There are 3 levels of spiciness: mild, medium, spicy. Spicy is not enough for me, but I'm asian :) 

If i'm extra hungry I'll also order their Japanese pan, which is their version of the empanada. It's a delicious fried gluttonous dough, with curry inside! Mhhhhmmmm. 

On my way to get lunch there now....
author: Kitty K.

description:
Eh... 

I really wish I liked this place because I like katsu & curry and because Muracci's is super close to where I work... but the food was mediocre and plain. Nothing extra special that I would crave or introduce to my friends visiting from out of town.

My friend and I ordered in advance (online through some website) and got to skip the line to just pick up our food wahoo! I recommend doing the same as well to avoid waiting in line.
author: Annie S.

description:
The Best Japanese Katsu and curry! Small restaurant with simple menus, kindly and efficiently working employees with clean kitchen. 
The food quality was great too! Totally recommend for togo lunch or dinner.
author: Ellen L.

description: Katsu curry, hot, brown rice, extra vegetables hits the spot every time. The pork is tender (and deep-fried, of course), the curry sauce is really tasty. If you're feeling extra hungry they have curry-pan and some desserts to tempt you while you're waiting in line. The line's usually out the door for lunch but it moves quickly; an old gentleman takes your order as you're waiting in line. It's a tiny place with a lot of people working behind the counter in the kitchen.
author: Wing Y.

description: Love the chicken katsu curry here the serving is massive enough for two people. The restaurant is tiny not enough room to sit if you come with friends you'll have more luck finding a seat on your own or just get it to go.
author: Rita A.

description:
I heard it is the best japanese curry shop in San Francisco. Not sure if it is true or not, the food is satisfying to me. 
The layout was narrow, we waited some time for seat at 2:00 pm. They did not have enough staffs to help cleaning instantly. That was a bit unusual for a japanese shop.
The quality of food, on the other hand made up for the environment. I ordered the hot curry, it tastes around the third spiciness of coco curry, and almost as flavorful as coco. The curry ramen was good, but I'm afraid the ramen was made from instant noodles.
author: Sherry C.

description:
I used to really hate Japanese curry.. for some reason I always imagined it to have a lot of cornstarch and be just too.. thick. 

But my friend finally convinced me to try Muraccis and I've been back many times since then. It's a decent price $10.. and usually I can spread it into 2 meals. They give you a lot of rice.. so if you portion it, it'll last you. The katsu is probably my favorite (pork). And I like the curry super spicy!
author: Angela L.

description: The grilled chicken curry is superb. Green mochi was a bit too sweet and heavy for me, but still very good. At any rate, this place isn't getting less than five stars from me. The curry easily made up for any other disappointments (e.g., not serving edamame on Saturdays). So freaking good. Even though there's not much in the way of dining space, tourists should not feel guilty about picking up some take-out from this place (and bringing back to the hotel). The food makes the experience, and this spot appears to be a favorite among locals.
author: Michael A.

description:
If you like Japanese curry, you need to try Muracci's! The line gets outrageous during lunch, but it is worth the wait, and you get your food pretty fast.

I ordered the katsu curry, which is most popular. The pork cutlet is thick, juicy, and delicious. It comes with a side of curry, rice, and a little bit of pickled vegetables. Everything is freshly made, and you can choose how spicy you want your curry. The price is reasonable for lunch in Fidi- around $10.

Would have given this place a solid 4 stars but the old man, I'm guessing who is the owner, is SO nice and happy.. totally made my day! He is friendly and greets all the customers. He even gave my friend and I a cup of water and napkins! This just goes to show that although this place is super popular and they KNOW they're good, they still appreciate their customers.
author: Jessica L.

description:
3.5 Stars

After hearing countless rave reviews about Muracci's Curry I decided it was due time I gave it a try and see for myself.

I decided to try the katsu don donburri bowl while my friend ordered the vegetable curry medium.

From an execution perspective, the donburri was done well. Pork was tender and flavorful while retaining a crisp coating. As for the sauce, it had a good balance of sweetness and savoriness. I was glad to find the eggs were still relatively cooked well but was closer to being overdone. 

I sampled my friends curry and found it to be quite concentrated in flavor which really packed a punch. I'll have to venture back and try the dish as a whole to get a better sense if it's going to be a like or love. 

I also decided to try the curry pan (beef) on a whim. The pastry exterior was decent but felt it was too soft and was missing the buttery, flaky goodness. As for the filling, the curry flavor was certainly present. I wasn't able to discern much else after the first few bites.

Order ahead and pick up is the best option if you want to avoid the long lines

Overall Thoughts

I can see myself venturing back in the near future to give their curry a real try
author: Eddie W.

description: Love the place I wanna go back. I did a level 7 spicy. A little too hot I heard HOT is enough no level. I'll come back for HOT. Place is a bit small, I love how you can get your own water.
author: Nino A.

description: Beef Curry was off the hook!! Definitely coming back here whenever I'm in town. Also the Miso even as basic as it typically is was better then most. Service was also good and pretty quick.
author: Wil J.

description: The restaurant location is easy to miss if you don't pay attention while searching for this place. This place is quite tiny with only roughly 10 seats. Some items on their menu will be sold out if you come after lunch hours. I got to try the curry (nikomi) hamburger patty with brown rice and green tea cake. The wait was about 5-10 minutes, but it wasn't so bad. My friend got the chicken katsu curry with white rice. We regret not trying the house made curry pan. The food was delicious and I'd like to return to try their ramen.
author: Kosmo Z.

description:
A bit pricy for what it is, but the quality is decent. If you like pork, try the Katsu Curry. It's a breaded and fried porkchop, cut into strips. You'll have your choice of white/brown rice and spicy level. The spiciest is still not very hot. I like that they serve the japanese curry on the side so the meat stays crispy until you're ready to indulge.

No room to sit...it's more catered toward the corporate crowd of the financial district who just grab and go. Line can get long at the lunch rush, so best to go a bit early or late.
author: Michael W.

description:
Please DO NOT drop napkins on the floor, pick them up and then let patrons use them. 

It was busy already during the opening at 11 on a Friday morning. My order was taken second as they opened and it was packed already. A worker was running around trying to finish all the preparations outside. She grabbed a bunch of napkins and opened the package only to drop half of it on the floor. As I'm picking up my food I continue watching to see what she does with the napkins and she proceeds to continue stocking the napkins including the ones she has now picked up off the floor for customer use like nothing happened... 

If that's how your napkins are treated, how is the food handled?
author: Wilson T.

description:
I went around 6pm and they were out of katsu (and pretty much everything else except chicken and beef). So go early if you want variety!

I ordered a chicken curry to go. You can choose your spicy level and brown or white rice. Mild was just perfect for me. 

The curry was tasty, but not really the comfort food curry I was hoping for. You can clearly taste the different spices in the curry - making it almost have some resemblance in taste more to an Indian curry. 

Also, they charge you 11cents for a plastic bag for your food... :(
author: Cynthia X.

description:
I was kind of surprised at how high of a rating this place had, given it's...cozy comforts (translation: it's almost a dump location-wise, but they make do of it).  But given that I've always said "food comes first," I was always going to give it a shot.  Plus Japanese curry doesn't really come around all that often, and when there's a good spot, you gotta take it.

Had the chicken katsu curry.  I was pleasantly surprised that they used white meat instead of dark meat, because I'm always used to getting dark meat for my katsu fry-ups.  I was doubly surprised that they had a brown rice option.  It's good because..well, if you're a health freak, honestly you'd never come here in the first place.  But at least if you're trying to watch yourself, you can mitigate the damage (supposedly).  Anyways, it was definitely a good lunch.

I do appreciate how they know the long line (and yes, it gets LONG) is coming and they have someone taking orders while you're line.  Then you just pay after that.  And they are VERY fast despite the line.  Bonus points for speed of food delivery.

Problem is, this isn't exactly a sitdown place.  Yeah, they DO have chairs...about a grand total of seven of them.  If you want to eat here for lunch, better get here early or else be ready to just take it to go.

Next time, pork cutlet for sure.  And must try the Curry Pan!  Didn't want to be too adventurous, I was pretty full after the katsu.
author: Alexander Y.

description: Good food. Katsu don and curry were great. Quite dirty though - dirty table, dirty chair. Would highly recommend to go.
author: Anya C.

description: This one is smaller than the original one in Los Altos, but still a good place to go if you crave for Japanese curry.
author: Yoshikage K.

description: Stopped in to get tonkatsu but they were out, so we got hot chicken katsu w brown rice & a gyudon to go. The curry gravy itself was yummy, but the chicken was not good. It was like it wasn't cooked all the way & either frozen before or just not pounded out enough. The gyudon was yummy. I wish I had liked the chicken more.
author: Ruth W.

description: The curry is amazing! I've tried the chicken Katsu curry with brown rice and it's amazing! Props for not having additional charge for brown rice either!
author: Stacy W.

description: Best chicken katsu curry in San Francisco hands down. I always get the chicken katsu curry - medium - with white rice. My go to spot in downtown SF.
author: Jonathan B.

description:
Came to Muracci for lunch on a Monday at around 1230pm and there was a line outside. There was a waiter who came out and took our orders while we were waiting, so the line moves pretty fast. The restaurant is pretty small, so you cant really have a large party eating in. Most people who come here order take out. 

I had the tonkatsu curry don which I really enjoyed. The pork was juicy and succulent, tasty, and not too oily. They also offer brown rice option which is great.

I like that the curry is not too thick and goes well with both the pork and the rice. 

Definitely coming back again!
author: Christina N.

description:
