Since there seems to be a lack of great Chinese food options in Chinatown, we found this place through Yelp. Granted, we had just come back from a trip to Japan so our standards for anything Japanese-related is pretty high. But this was a solid overall 3.5-4 star place considering all things.

Husband had the katsu curry and I had the beef curry. Husband's katsu was three times better than my beef curry - if I could put it simply. GET THE KATSU. The one piece I tasted was crispy (not to the point of greasy) and tasty. My beef curry was fine, nothing much to report. There was also only maybe 3-4 pieces of beef in mine with a very generous helping of the curry. The curry, overall, was well-seasoned and delicious. 

I would also call it pretty hole-in-the-wall, but being right between the Financial District and Chinatown, the price was pretty fair. I also appreciated that the bathroom was clean and that there was cold water (for the taking) available for those who were dining in. Granted, there isn't a ton of space to sit inside (can maybe fit 10-15 people?), but it was nice that they had seating. 

Overall, I wouldn't mind coming here again and getting my own katsu plate next time (instead of glaring at oblivious husband's plate with envy). 

PROS: Great location, yummy katsu and curry, good price, clean bathrooms
CONS: Beef curry is ok, not very much seating, would be nice to have a few more sides
author: Sarah C.

description:
I got the Katsu curry with medium spiciness. The food is really good, but the portion is not that big. They don't give you enough curry to brown up all your rice. 

I thought there would be tables or a nice seating area, but this place is mainly for people picking up and to-going food. There are high-tables to the sides of the walls, but the space just feels too tight, especially with the long line that usually goes outside the door during lunchtime.
author: Eric S.

description: It's with a heavy heart I give Muracci's only 3 stars and debated about going lower.  I've been coming here almost weekly since close to when they first opened.  Sadly over the past year, it's increasingly frustrating to step foot in the place.  The joint is tiny but due to the rise of the tech companies and army of tech bros, this place is nearly impossible to get in and out in a reasonable time.  First, the bros seem to constantly bring their entire offices here.  Bad enough you have to endure the constant chatter of their next lame startup idea that's just another rip off of something else but line is down the street often by 11:45.  Second, these tech (and admittedly other) companies place large pick up orders on a regular basis.  I'm glad Muracci's is doing well but they are forgetting the loyal fans that got them here in the first place.  See, they will prepare all the large orders as they come in before making any others which is often as the lunch rush is beginning.  If you unluckily order behind one of these, well, you're sh*t out of luck.  You get to wait 30 minutes for your order, at least.  I can't think of very many times this hasn't happened in recent months.  Sucks, sorry Muracci, but you're losing a lifelong customer.
author: Figaro D.

description:
FYI: Come here earlier in the day rather than later otherwise they run out of the good 'n' famous stuff like Curry Pan and pork Katsu Curry.

Got here at 7 PM and basically nothing was left. The consistently call out which dishes are unavailable so you can make an informed order. Only 'katsu' option left was for the salmon which I ordered with extra veggies. The fried cutlet was quite standard but the curry was piping hot, spicy, and comforting. Glad the curry stayed hot even though I ate it ~20-25 minutes after leaving. I definitely understand the hype. 

The place is super small and narrow, so you're probably going to opt for take-out. The uncle in charge is super nice and efficient. I almost felt stressed as I gave my order because there was so much hustle and bustle around me and in the kitchen (you can tell they are trying to work and deliver supremely fast).

Definitely coming back to try the pork katsu curry and also because I have an odd affinity for these kinds of chaotic Asian Mom and Pop shops ^.^
author: Arushi S.

description: I wanted traditional Japanese curry during my trip to San Francisco. I ordered the beef vegetable spicy udon. The restaurant was extremely busy (we went during lunch time) and cramped, but we were able to sit and eat. The udon was good but I feel like I could have ordered that anywhere.
author: Gee S.

description: Go to lunch once every other week. Perfectly breaded and fried chicken katsu... And the delicious spicy curry sauce! Love it... There is space to sit but most of us just do takeout and eat  at the office. Highly recommend it!
author: Raj S.

description:
Whoa. Can't believe I've been coming here for years for lunch and I haven't written a review. 

Solid lunch experience and they are definitely one of the Kearney favorites. 

I have only tried one thing. Chicken Katsu Spicy with Brown Rice. Have it a few times per month so that's saying something. 

I highly recommend ordering online or calling ahead with order. The lines can get pretty gnarly and it's a narrow joint.
author: Amy Z.

description: Went with a co-worker for lunch and the line was pretty long - which is standard for most places in the FiDi during lunchtime. We both had the chicken katsu with curry (medium spicy). We both commented that we could've gotten the hot but the heat comes as an aftertaste. Trust me on that one! Overall if you're looking for something quick, and moderately cheap I would check this place out! Note: there is not really seating available it's more grab and go!
author: Teresa C.

description:
I COULD make my grandmother's curry recipe at home...but muracci's is so delicious (and convenient, if you order ahead)...so why bother?

I keep hearing about other dishes, but I pretty much only order katsu curry. I'm also obsessed with the pickled cabbage that they include. I could eat that by the bucket and I'm usually too lazy to make it at home.

Not the cheapest lunch in the land, but very satisfying and if you have self control this could be two portions.
author: Katies F.

description: although this place isn't crazy amazing, it still provided curry that reminded me of home! I always eat here, but the chicken is sometimes cooked weird as a katsu. but other than that yea. also they don't put potatoes and vegetables in the curry:/ that costs two dollars extra!!!:^(
author: Xavier L.

description: Got the katsu curry (I assume thats what its called) surprisingly spicier than what I thought it would be. It's pretty filling tbh, but quite limited in whats given in terms of "things" It's just the meat, curry, and some pickled veggies. Still good though.
author: Victor D.

description: Delicious Japanese curry! Not cheap but not outrageously priced, especially for SF Financial District. Portions are quite generous -- I usually have leftovers for a snack/second meal. Shop is quite small -- only about 5-7 bar spots to sit and eat, cramped in with everyone else waiting in line to order/get their food. Gets very crowded during lunch -- expect to wait in a line out the door for 20+ minutes just to order. A hole-in-the-wall place, very easy to walk right past.
author: Jackie Y.

description: I called at around 12pm to order, I wanted the katsu curry and curry pan but curry pans were ALL SOLD OUT! I ended up ordering the $10 katsu curry mild with brown rice. http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/muraccis-japanese-curry-and-grill-san-francisco?select=bHo9KCZ92mpLCORM_cL60g#bHo9KCZ92mpLCORM_cL60g Friend had the beef ramen. If you call-in your order, go straight to the cashier to pay and pick-up, it saves a TON of time instead of waiting in the long line and ordering there. The place is tiny, very hard to walk to the cashier with the amount of people in line. There is place to sit inside, but with the amount of people there, you do not want to sit there to eat. We ended up going to to Crocker Galleria to eat and we saw other people with Muracci's there too. Both items were delicious. I would come back to try the curry pan and another curry.
author: Kylie L.

description:
Here are my thoughts: 

(1) Healthy. The base does not appear to be coconut milk or to contain any dairy, for that matter.  I always get the salmon curry with brown rice.  If I'm wrong and this curry is dairy based, I do not want to know about it. That's my story and I'm sticking to it.  I love the brown rice option as well. 

(2) Timing. During the lunch hour, Muracci's goes ape, and it's unpleasant. It's a good plan to go earlier or later than noon (although that's pretty much the consensus with any lunch spot at noon), which brings me to my next point. 

(3) Tiny. Muracci's is the definition of tiny. No, you may not dine in. There's a long line going out the door usually, and someone walks through the line and takes your order. It's best to have your act together so you don't hold things up, especially if I am in line behind you. If you special order be prepared to wait.

(4) Potato Pancake. Of course you want one of those. So good. 

(5) Sriracha. You can order your curry mild, medium or hot. I like it hot, but Muracci's version of "hot" is only hot if you are a little beech. 

So I'm paying my tab and I asked if they had sriracha. The cashier looked at me as though I had suddenly caught on fire. I became instantly confused. Did I say sriracha incorrectly? Was this not Japanese curry? I became flummoxed. I said, "sriracha(?)" again, with pause. The cashier just looked at me like, "What the hell is sriracha?"  Completely confused, I looked to my friend for help. She's a lot mouthier than me (imagine that)--so she asked forthrightly, "Are you serious? You don't know sriracha?"  Indeed, I'm pretty sure it's the official hot sauce of San Francisco. I put that sh** on everything. The cashier turned to ask the cooks--sriracha? They said no, but at least they knew what it was. They gave me chili powder on the side, which is not an acceptable substitute, as you well know. But not a big deal--I just wanted to know if they had it, because if so, I'm down. I ended up having to wait a lot longer for my order because I made this (what I thought was a simple) request. Whoops. Lesson: Muracci's does not have sriracha. Just don't ask. 

Other than that, pretty good.
author: Sunny S.

description:
201. My roomie and I were on an adventure in the city and stumbled upon Muracci's.  Unfortunately, we got here right after it closed.

We were about to leave when the owner called us back and offered each of us curry katsu.  The katsu was understandably soggy by the end of the day.  But there's some real customer service right here!
author: Katherine C.

description:
This one is a tough one.. If I could, I would give this place a three and a half stars. Better than a three star but not quite a four lolol The curry here is as good as everyone says in their reviews; no doubt about that. The spicy option though was not quite spicy, disappointing but still the food was good enough without it being spicy. The quantity here.. Sucked... I was not satisfied by the amount of food they gave.. But of course this differs for everyone. 

I came here during lunch time and the place was packed! I mean the line went out the door.. Well, not really out the door but it got close.. If you are claustrophobic, I do not recommend this place. Not only is the line long but the spacing here is terrible. I bumped into multiple people just trying to find the exit. 

My advice here.. Get your food and get out as fast as possible before it gets even more crowded. Oh and make sure to buy the beef curry pan. That was delicious and since they don't give you much in quantity, you will want it to fill your stomach!
author: John L.

description:
I was super stoked to find a Japanese curry joint in SF that specialized in the stuff.  Unfortunately, it didn't live up to expectations.  

The place is definitely a hole in the wall which I absolutely love.  There are minimal seats and your food most likely will be devoured elsewhere.  I ordered the katsu curry and couldn't wait for my food.  Well, I was lucky enough to find a place to eat and couldn't wait!  I took one bite of the katsu and it was super dry and overcooked.  Le sigh.  Even pouring on the curry sauce didn't help much.  The curry sauce was also pretty bland.  

Such a sad experience...really wanted to like the place and have a local curry spot.  I'll just have to look elsewhere.
author: Jen W.

description:
Do not get me wrong, I love this place but 
May 9th, Saturday around 3pm
You guys gave me the Chicken Katsu, not pork Katsu !!! 

My boyfriend and I ordered 2 katsu curry (1 super spicy and 1 mild), 
and wow .. it as chicken katsu. :(
I HATE CHICKEN!!! 
I wanted to go back and complain, but before I left the place, I heard they were running out of pork katsu ... so I assume they just gave me the chicken (WITHOUT TELLING ME). It wouldve been nice if they let us know before we ordered.. 

other than this, this place is AMAZING. 
I will update my review after my next visit..
author: Yumi K.

description:
Decent Japanese curry that's conveniently located near Union Square.
The place is small, so I would recommend take out for the food.

Went around 2pm on a Tuesday and most of the good stuff was sold out--beef, ebi fry, etc.
author: Adorable T.

description:
One of my favorite spots in SF! It's a hole in the wall, but has the tastiest Japanese curry that one could ask for! There's usually a line out side between noon and 1 on a weekday. So, I recommend going a little after 1PM as the crowd dissipates. In the evenings, the kitchen usually runs out of stuff, so call in before if you were craving something in particular :) 

The kitchen is accommodating to your spice needs! Also, The food is usually packed to go with rice and curry in separate containers. 


My favorites are the chicken katsu curry and the spicy beef with ramen.
author: Meghan K.

description:
Don't be alarmed by the line that practically wraps around the block. The service is incredibly fast. 

You can't miss Muracci's because there is basically always a line. (You can also smell the distinct smell of curry.) I had never had Japanese curry before, so my friend and I got in line and hoped for the best.

I ordered the pork katsu and admired the little spiral cakes in the display but didn't order one. Next time!

Our currys arrives smelling positively divine. We drooled the whole walk back to the office.

My katsu was perfect, and my curry wasn't super thick, which made it more like a curry-flavored sauce for my katsu, which I liked a lot. A coworker mentioned that adding cheese to the top makes it even more tasty; I'll make sure to try that next time! 

Welcome to my go-to lunch places list, Muracci's!
author: Christina S.

description:
One of the best lunch places in FiDi. 

- Long line on week days. So reach early.
- Accepts credit card.
- Super tiny space. Mostly its To-go. However there are 3-4 stools to have a quick bite. 
- Fast service.  
- MUST ORDER - Katsu curry over rice or spicy curry noodle soup
- The katsu gravy is rich and super delish.
author: Payal B.

description:
Financial district: where people with money over pays for mediocre food. It seems that the raging reviews for this place might be greatly influenced by the lunch bunch hunger more than the actual taste of the food. 

I recently started work in FiDi and was so excited to find all the great lunch spots. I find myself at this little shop on a nice Friday afternoon after scrolling through yelp. I'm a big Japanese curry fan. I've tried about every type of Japanese curry, made Japanese curry, heck I even went to Japan and ate their curry. After all that yelp hype, this place left me disappointed. 

The curry was plain, bland and greasy. It lacked depth in flavor and that special Japanese umami taste. The chicken katsu I got along the curry, however, gave me far better satisfaction. The katsu remained crispy despite the 5 minute walk back to my work. The meat was tender and juicy. 

Overall, this place is mediocre. Not the best curry. Good katsu. Okay curry pan (I got that also because I was hungry). The price is definitely not worth the taste. 12 dollar for katsu curry and 3 dollar for curry pan. 15 dollars for a mediocre lunch is just not my cup of tea.
author: Winne L.

description: Amazing food, amazing proprietor. It's one thing to knock what you do out of the park with absolute consistency. The katsu and chicken katsu are the best. The udon is perfection. This is the archetypal Japanese curry. But what makes me love this place even more than the noms is the proprietor, who is ever present, ever working, and ever sweet. This place rules.
author: James S.

description: This is a solid Japanese curry place right next to the Cal campus. I enjoyed my chicken curry cutlet, which was actually spicier than I had expected. I also tried a weird sparkling peach sake drink with jelly in it. It was...interesting, but not for everyone. My friend also had one, tried it and ordered a beer instead. If you have a Cal id you can get extra rice and curry for free, but my favorite part was adding a fried egg to my curry. This place is inexpensive and perfect for students, or those craving some homey Japanese food.
author: caroline y.

description:
Japanese curry rice is an easy fix especially when you are pressed for time. With the availability of instant curry mixes from any Asian grocery store, it is easy to make even for someone like me with little cooking skills. So when I buy curry rice from a curry house like Muracci's, I would expect to get better quality and tastier curry rice. Unfortunately, this wasn't the case yesterday. Hopefully, it was an off day for Muracci.

I had 3 different takeout orders and all 3 left a lot to be desired.

Beef Curry Rice - My daughter had some dental work done in the morning and needed something soft. The beef was not slow boiled in the curry and the meat instead of being tender was tougher than my shoe! STRIKE ONE!

Katsu Curry Rice and Ebi Fry Rice - Both the Tonkatsu and the Ebi Fry were too heavily breaded in panko and left behind a thick and heavy crust. It was then over fried drying out the pork and the shrimp. STRIKE TWO!

Too much curry powder or mix was used leaving my mouth with a bitter aftertaste. It could also be the after effects of a MSG overload. STRIKE THREE! And I guess you know what 3 strikes mean...

Being located in the heart of FiDi and the proximity to Chinatown, they do attract a huge lunch crowd. Their rent must cost 1 arm + 1 leg and to remain viable in business, I hope it was just one bad day yesterday. Maybe the regularly scheduled cook took the day off!
author: Geoff G.

description:
My number one lunch place. I usually try to avoid going at noon because it can get very crowded, though, even in those instances, the line moves pretty quickly. The space is small, and definitely more suited for takeout rather than sit down.

I've only ever gotten the katsu curry with white rice here. The curry sauce is amazing, perfectly savory with a little bit of spiciness. And the pork katsu is crispy, and they give you the sauce in a separate container when you order to-go. Also, the curry pan (essentially curry flavored samosas) are tasty.

I'm getting hungry just thinking about it!
author: Lawrence W.

description: My homie of mine asked me to have lunch. He decided we go to Murracis. Haven't heard about, so you know what I had to do.. Yelp. Saw it had curry.. I'm a big fan of curry. So I was game to hit that spot. I ordered the chicken katsu curry plate.. While ordering a gentleman, another customer of the restaurant;told me, Good choice. && man it wasn't kidding. I had medium hot btw and it was delicious every bite til the very end.
author: Daryl M.

description:
so lets start with the bad- its a very small place with a hand full of seats. I get its something they cant really fix but it still makes an effect when you want to eat in.

ONTO the good!
   Personally I would have never thought of coming here again its a small little hole in the wall. My friend trusted yelp and it paid off!!! I got the Katsu Don and loved it. At first look it looked like it was going to be very greasy BUT that was not the case at all. The Katsu Don was very delicious something I would suggest to any Katsu lover.
author: Nina M.

description:
We were super excited to try Muracci's, since we love LOVE Japanese curry.  My idea of a perfect curry is Hotaru's cury in San Mateo, and I was expecting Muracci's to become the new favorite based on the fabulous reviews.

But Muracci's didn't live up to my expectations.  I ordered the spicy curry with chicken cutlet, and it was spicy hot, but lacked a certain depth of flavor.  I'm not sure how to explain it, but it was just missing something.

Now that I don't live in SF anymore, there is no need to go to Muracci's for my curry fix.  Hello Hotaru!
author: Nadeem A.

description:
I love me some dense, saucy food... *_______*  

This place is tiny and it's probably better you do take out than try to cram yourself into one of the small dining spaces along the wall.  Do take out!  It's fairly quick for lunch time (maybe about 15 minutes throughout all the waiting... if the line isn't out the door by the time you line up that is).  Super filling when you're hungry and perfect when you're wanting something nice and heavy.  I love the curry sauce and relished pickles and pickled cabbage on the side!  I usually get the Hot spicy level, which to me, isn't really spicy at all, so I recommend it if you can eat spicy food!  I'd also recommend adding some veggies in with your meal as well since it tends to be a lot of carbs (brown / white rice) and meat if without.  Any of the katsu curries are all tasty!
author: Carena N.

description: must order anything with curry.  the medium spice is a little inconsistent but you can wash it down with extra rice/water or just add more hot sauce.  lunch lines to order and the wait after ordering can be long so plan accordingly!
author: Amy J.

description:
Another way way overrated place. Really cannot understand all the five star reviews. Have people not tried real authentic curry Katsu??? 

Location is convenient for the work lunch crowd so I can understand giving them a good review for that but taste wise...C'mon! Curry is bland and tasteless. The katsu dry and hard. 

People got to demand better and have higher standards.
author: John R.

description: Chicken katsu, medium spicy sauce with brown rice. I love how they give the sauce in a separate container (I don't need that much). Was tasty and fresh and served with a smile. The place itself is tiny. I sat in a rickety stool but it held up through my lunch lol. I'd come back for take out!! I went before noon (thankfully) because it was packed w the lunch crowd by noon. Next time I'll get some veggies w my katsu.
author: Dina E.

description:
Pros: good favour, 
Has a good kick in terms of spiciness 


Cons: I got a chicken curry, with 4 pieces of chicken for 10 bucks. 

The food was not as hot as I would like it and half way thought finishing my dish, my dish was cold.
author: Fran C.

description:
The highlights:
- The pork cutlet (Katsu) was pretty tender and somehow chewy
- The curry (I ordered the medium hot) tasted like the curry I had in Tokyo. I would say it's pretty authentic
- The waiting time was decent, even there was a long line, but the staffs were very efficient and helpful
- Very friendly staff

The lowlights:
- Space... it's a tiny place that has less than 10 chairs. This is not a place to go with a big group, but for take-out or eat alone
- The price... I found it a bit pricy for the eating experience. A Katsu Curry sets you back 10 bucks, no misu soup or sides, eating while people walking and standing closely next to you. I think $8 would be more fair just for the food.
author: Shaz L.

description:
This small store would be easy to miss if it wasn't for the long line out the door. It's always packed but they have their system down so well that you're wait will never be too long. 

I have been eating Japanese curry all my life -- in fact, it's my comfort food -- and these guys make it well. Sometimes the katsu is a little dry.

My go-to dish is the chicken curry (about $8), not to be confused with the chicken katsu curry. The chicken curry just has chunks of un-fried chicken in it. 

Also, don't forget to pick up a curry pan ($2.50) when you go. They are deep fried curry pockets that will make you incredibly happy when you bite into them.
author: Mariko F.

description: Well worth the wait! The beef curry was awesome. I love spicy food so I asked for it as spicy as they can get it and they made it 2X hot. I didn't think it was going to be spicy at all but it definitely gave me a nice kick in my mouth, and I want more! I also had an order of the karaage which was still crispy, and delicious, after a 10 minute walk as I ordered it to go. For the cherry on top, the service was excellent. I made contact with 3 different members of the staff and they were all very nice. My order took a little longer than expected, but they kept me informed so there was no frustration on my part at all. I was also given a a free fried bun (not sure what is was exactly) stuffed with curry for the extra wait, which wasn't that much longer than expected. This place is great, come eat here!
author: Will C.

description:
I loved their Ebi Fry Curry (Medium) and curry pan!! 
Tasted great! Savory.  
Ebi fry was crunchy and crispy and hot!! 
Came with pickles as well.

Wish there was a bigger eating area... 

Went there at 11:45AM on a weekday. 
Waited for our food for 20 minutes.

Well worth it! 

Probably best to call ahead for pick up.
author: Sunny S.

description:
Curry is definitely good. Spice is on point and the meat is tender. I finished all the rice and sauce and pickled veggies, with a sense of satisfaction! 
Line can be long during lunch hours, but
author: Teresa T.

description:
Been meaning to try this place since they always have a long line and I have along history of enjoying Japanese curry (plus, pretty inexpensive for the neighborhood). Immediately had issues with service/communication. Apparently they have both a chicken-stock based curry and a veggie one. When I asked I was told it was all chicken-based, then when I started to leave they called back and asked the kitchen, who said they had veggie-based as well. It's worth mentioning they were out of brown rice when I got there, as it was their off day and they didn't have a lot of customers.

Anyway, this wouldn't be so bad if the food was good - and it wasn't:
Curry - Watery and flavorless, I also ordered my curry hot and it had absolutely no kick to it. The veggies were super-inconsistently cut, some carrot slices were about die sized and another was so big it did not fit in my mouth.
Rice - very dry, it tasted like it had just been sitting out for hours. Maybe they were scraping the bottom of a rice cooker?

The pickled ginger was fine, I assume they purchase that as is. There was some cabbage, too. Traditionally that would be fresh shaved cabbage, in this case it was extra funky, like they tried to pickled it and something went off in the fermentation process. It's in a tiny container on its own, so not a huge deal.
author: Daniel S.

description:
Talk about a line! Man this place has a line that goes out the door, wraps around the corner... block.. ( of course an exaggeration ). I would definitely recommend ordering ahead through the application they use to avoid the long line. The food service is relatively quick and the food is good. I've had the pleasure of eating in the restaurant before and it feels like everyone is starring at you while you eat, likes eagles to a baby chick. They package the food really well, for those of you that like to take the food back to the office to torture your fellow colleagues! 

RECOMMENDATIONS: 

I would definitely try the chicken curry and the katsu curry!
author: Andersen Y.

description:
Muracci's is my fallback when I'm craving Pork Katsu Curry and my first choice isn't operating at the time.

Muracci's curry just isn't spicy, rich, or flavorsome enough when you compare it to other popular katsu curry eateries in the Bay Area or NYC. Their Pork Katsu Curry is less dry and a little less bland than their Chicken Katsu Curry so I tend to go for the pork. However, I really like their red pickles and always ask for extra.

Parking can be difficult and the lines can be long during lunch, so I tend to order ahead and get my food to-go.
author: Asha S.

description:
I was hanging out with a good friend of mine and we wanted to get curry. I took him here. 

It was later in the day (4?) so there was no line. I told him to get the chicken katsu curry. I got the tonkatsu curry (pork cutlet) with brown rice. 

There is more seating in this place than I thought, but still quite a small place! Presentation of our food was wonderful. It looked great and of course it was just as good.

Tonkatsu and chicken katsu looked and tasted essentially the same. But chicken has a more mild taste because it's chicken. Both were delicious. The curry really added that kick.

I quite like this place.
author: Sofia R.

description: The curry and the chicken even the rice make me sick. And it's not cheap at all comparing to other lunch places nearby. I literally cannot have chicken meat after I eat here. Usually the Japanese food should not be this bad. I don't get it.
author: Ting Z.

description:
This place is the shizzz when it comes to Japanese curry!!! 

It's a little hole in the wall (literally). There's not a lot of sitting room. I think it's more of a to-go kind of place, but the food is oh so good :)

I got the mild curry katsu. Let me tell you right now, the curry angels were singing in my ear when my food arrived. It was like they were preparing me for a holy feast. I scarfed my food down so fast, that I sat there a little sad wondering why I didn't treasure it more. 

The service is friendly and fast! The food is for sure nomz worthy. I would come back here all the time if I could :D 

The bad part is that it's located away from union square in a some-what sketch area, and it's really really tiny. If you have a big party, you won't be very comfortable eating here.
author: Thuy T.

description:
Been here a few times for lunch and have not been dissapointed. Katsu Curry is definitely the way to go! It's lightly breaded and the pork is super juicy.

I've also tried the chicken curry and while it was good, I couldnt help but stare at my coworkers' fried piece of pork goodness.

The owners are quite smart and sell curry pan (bread) at the front. It's a decent wait time for your food, so my mouth and stomach forces me to cave in and buy one.
author: Jeff M.

description:
I've had a hankering for Japanese curry ever since I left New York. Too bad Muracci's is only open for lunch during the week, so it's taken two years for me to hit it up.

The curry was pretty good. Spicy and flavorful. But I think I prefer the thicker sauce at Go Go Curry. The katsu was very done and no complaints about the portion.
author: Sherry L.

description: Chicken katsu curry is so good! Large portion, more than enough curry to pour on top of chicken and rice, and a reasonable price. 10/10 would definitely come back.
author: C K.

description: My aunt and I dropped by before noon to grab a quick lunch.  I ordered the Katsu curry ($9.95) while she got the beef curry ($8.95).  My katsu was crispy and tender, but a bit bland.  The curry sauce was mildly spicy as I requested.  Since the sauce was served separately, I was able to control the amount of curry to put in my katsu and rice.  My aunt liked her beef curry, but she said the meat was a bit tough to chew.  We split a green tea roll cake for dessert.  Service was relatively fast.  The place became too cramped when the lunch crowd started arriving.
author: Janice T.

description: Had the chicken katsu curry over white rice. First time I had a Japanese curry ever, spice level was perfect with great flavors!
author: Navjeet S.

description: Amazing curry. Ordered the Chicken Katsu Curry (medium). Line was out the door on a Friday lunch hour, took about 30 minutes to receive order, but wait was worth it. You can also order/call ahead online or on the phone. Definitely try to do that.
author: Jason D.

description:
Since this place had the same yelp rating as my absolute favorite katsu in the city - Kare Ken, I had to try it. And no,  there is no competition. Sure Muracci's menu is longer, their service is faster, they are in a better location and their food is fine- good even. This place does not compare to the "delis-e-osity" that is Kare Ken.

They offer "to stay" but really there is no space for that...so get it to go.
author: Amy W.

description: This place is good...but not like AMAZING (compared to NY or other places in SF who serve the same thing). I think it is very solid and they make the line move at a decent pace. I think the food isn't necessarily that cheap based on what they are serving you? I would come here again but don't really think it's a must go place and don't really understand the hype either.
author: Lily P.

description:
I ordered the Salmon Fry curry with brown rice and ended up getting 3 tiny pieces. 

The curry was good, but didn't have anything really stand out.
author: Enoch L.

description:
Hmm.. somehow, I've forgotten to review this place. A lunchtime favorite of mine, with excellent curry. Also, their curry pan (deep fried bread stuffed with curry) is my favorite -- I used to love that stuff as a kid.

A bit pricey for curry, but then again, what isn't pricey in the FiDi?
author: Kazu O.

description: I get pork katsu or chicken katsu... with extra spicy (2x) curry sauce.... it is THE BEST. Get it with brown rice, because the white rice tends to get a little mushy when mixed with the curry sauce... unless you like mush..
author: Betty T.

description: I got the chicken katsu curry with brown rice and my friend got some kind of beef dish. They were both good. It wasn't anything amazing, but it was good. I would try it again.
author: Renée E.

description:
The place is super small - only 4 counter seats along one wall, 5 counter seats along another wall & 1 table for 2. 

Menu is pretty simple. Curry items include Beef, Chicken, Katsu, Chicken Katsu, Ebi, Salmon and Tofu over your choice of white or brown rice. You pick the spice level.  
Other menu items include Green or Potato Salad, Donburi, Curry Noodle Soup and a few sushi items (California Roll, Cucumber Roll, Avoocado Roll & Inari).

The curry plates only come with pickled veggies.  I wasn't aware that you have to add potatoes to the curry.  You can also add eggs or spinach.  I was missing the potatoes but the picked veggies were pretty good.

My Chicken Katsu was lightly breaded, crispy and moist.  My husband had the Chicken Curry and loved it.

Service was fast and with a smile.  = )

We plan on being return customers.
author: Rose A.

description:
Yes Beyonce, time for an upgrade.  Muracci's is all about the amazing Japanese katsu curry served in a tiny and immensely popular hole-in-the-wall in the middle of dirty Kearny.  

If you work in the FiDi, chances are that I'm preaching to the choir.  Muracci's fans have understandably been forgiving of the longer wait necessary for freshly prepared, non pre-cooked katsu, karaage, ebi fry, etc.  Management made minor but effective adjustments that minimize the wait time.  The charming elderly owner, Yasuyuki Murata, now takes orders while you stand in line, so the staff prepares your curry while you stand in line to pay.  They also came up with an express curry line to go along with phone ordering system.  Such simple adjustments isolates the wait to the prep time, not the time to take orders and payments.  Nicely done.

The katsu curry continues to amaze.  The pork cutlet pieces are fried just right, perfectly crispy outside, juicy and tender inside, and hot all over.  It helps that they serve the curry on the side, pretty clever if you ask me.  Awesome curry as well, perhaps to be expected as it takes two days to prepare, and even the red special pickles on the side are delicious, breaking up monotonous flavor.  I still think the spice level could kick up up a notch, but the curry has good flavor with an extra kick. Delish!
author: Angel S.

description: Definitely not as good as JapanCurry's Curry. I got to say I don't like this restaurant curry sauce. I had a pork katsu and karage curry and both time, the curry sauce a strong overwhelming sour salty taste for me. The pork katsu and the fried karage was good though, just not the curry sauce itself. I prefer the the curry sauce from JapanCurry food truck
author: Hui Y.

description:
I'm all about curry. Spicy, creamy, and downright hearty is my favorite type. I was a military brat and while my dad was stationed in Japan, I lived in a small town called Sasebo on the island of Kyushu. All through middle and high school,  I spent majority of my youth there and from my earliest memory, it was there that I was first exposed to curry. 

Growing up in Japan, curry was my favorite dish. Beef, tonkatsu (pork cutlet), or chicken; I loved em all. I love the side of red Fukujinzuke (relished pickle; had to look that one up) and how it added a certain sourness and crunchy texture to the creamy delight. This is my version of "soul food". It had been 13+ yrs since I had authentic Japanese curry, so you can imagine how ecstatic I was when Jason S. had found this gem (thanks Yelp) and suggested that I pay a visit.  

I work in the FiDi, so one random afternoon, I coordinate a meetup with Jason S. to try the infamous Muracci's. First impression: cramped. With the lunch line of 10 people, it was already spilling over into the sidewalk. There was a "small" (and I use that term loosely), sitting area that sat less than 5 people. As I get to the front of the line, I'm distracted by the tempting display of korokke (potato croquette). "Do you want to add korokke?" says the cashier. "Uhhh sure let's do it!" I reply. After all, you can never, really, go wrong with fried carbs.

That day, we ordered pork katsu (tonkatsu) and beef curry and opted to sit above the Crocker Galleria to enjoy our lunch. When I opened up the plastic lid, I noticed that it smelled and looked like Japanese curry, but the taste was not. It tasted like the same basic ingredients: onions, garlic, peppers, S&B curry cube, but so much greasier than I had anticipated. Look, I enjoy grease in my food, but to add more fat to an, already rich, food and that's just obscene.  Sure, the tonkatsu was perfectly fried and white rice was as fluffy as clouds, but the sauce! Oh the sauce. Needless to say, I'm not a huge fan of greasy curry. The ironic thing is that I wanna love Muracci's, I really do!  But sadly, Muracci's take on Japan's "national dish" was a flop. The only saving grace was the amazingly crunch-on-the-outside-but-so-fluffy-on-the-inside croquette. That was an A+ in my book.

The closest thing I've had to to the Japanese curry I had in Japan has been at Ringer Hut (Saratoga, CA). It's been nearly 13+ yrs since I've had authentic Japanese but until I am able to go back to Japan, I'm still on my search for my favorite Japanese dish.
author: Carloalexi M.

description: Great food at an excellent price. You could easily walk past this place and miss it as it's inconspicuously tucked away. I'd never had Japanese style curry before, and ever since Muracci's I've been craving it again!
author: Tanya H.

description: Was on a mini vacation with my family and the day we had to leave we wanted to have lunch. We, of course, looked on yelp to see the local popular places and came across this restaurant! YUM I'm so glad we came here. It's small and crowded, like most places we saw around here, and being from Orange County we're used to our space lol but we were able to snag the seats by the window so we could eat here. Best decision! I loved having the food FRESH. My boyfriend and sister got the fried pork cutlet and it was so juicy! My (picky) niece had the chicken teriyaki and she loved it. The side potatoe salad was a nice touch too. I had the grilled chicken curry with brown rice. I got the spicy curry because I love my spice. The chicken was so moist and tender! OMG I cannot explain how delicous all these plates were. We got there around lunch rush but service was still good and quick. When I come back to this great city I'll definitely be coming back here!
author: Solmayra M.

description:
Sauce was much more "wow" this time!  I'm convinced they don't use the boxed powder curry or if they do, they put a lot of their own spices into it.  The medium has a nice heat throughout the sauce.  

I can't believe the prices have jumped up $2 in the 2 years that I've been.  It is definitely worth the quality though... they fry your ish right when you order it!

I remember not having enough curry the first time around so I forked out the $1.75 for extra curry and now I have extra curry sitting on my desk.  

I can't believe I ate the whole thing.  Small Asian girl compared to big white guys eating the same portion.  I should be proud but I feel like I'm going to explode.
author: Shannon L.

description:
Great food and awesome curry!!! Only issue is you don't get ur food sometimes. I tried this place 5 times and they forgot my order 2 out of 5 times. (I use order ahead by the way, and they don't care about these orders either) 

I had to cancel the order and find somewhere else. 

Great food but it's a question if you actually will get any food.
author: Kaiye C.

description:
FINALLLY FINALLYYY got my hands on this katsu curry and though my favorite place is in Japan (hah) this place is bombbb! You can tell its super fresh- moist and juicy and perfectly fried piece of meat!
I like how they serve you the sauce on the side and you can ask for more sauce if you want. Service was fast and efficient - glad I beat the lunch rush by getting there before 12.
You won't be disappointed coming here, just make sure to go to the gym after work. Haha.
author: Angela D.

description:
Have gotten the chicken curry and the chicken katsu curry. Both were very good.
Tends to have a long wait during lunch time on weekdays.
Highly recommend the curry.
author: Nakul J.

description:
Speaking only for the teriyaki chicken.... Average. Wanted the salmon but they were out.

Tiny piece of chicken dry and pretty tasteless, not enough of the (admittedly decent) teriyaki sauce to cover this fact up. Miso soup 7/10. Crowded and noisy, would endure this if the food was awesome, but it's not. For $11 with tax I expected much more from a restaurant, much less a hole in the wall charging this much for one item.

A couple stars for friendly honey service and real plates.
author: T J.

description: Love the food here!! The katsu is perfect. What puts it over the top are the pickled veggies and that sauce. Get all that in your mouth in one bite with some brown rice and BOOM.  #peaceoutDiet
author: Ramon L.

description: I need Muracci's right now!!! I've had a LOT of curry in my life so I know when I've had good curry. On my first try, I thought the food was OK... and today, I find myself craving this place over and over again. The spiciness is on point. The consistency is full of flavor. I am salivating just thinking about it and writing this review. Definitely give this place a try if you like curry!
author: Jonathan L.

description:
Great experience! I'm born and raised in Japan and I absolutely loved it. Great quality for the value. I must also add that they serve you a lot for the price! We ordered Pork Katsu Curry and it came on a huge plate. My bf was able to finish the whole thing however, I was unable to finish the rice. I finished all the meat though ;) 

The employees there were very nice, fun and welcoming. I will definitely be coming back and also will consider their delivery service! 

A very casual restaurant so I recommend to pick up or go for a VERY quick eat.

They also have Curry-Pan! Mmm!
author: M. N.

description: Some of the best take out katsu I've ever had. The katsu was still nice and crispy half an hour after I got it and the portion size was really good for the price. The katsu wasn't too oily or overcooked. You wouldn't really expect that at first glance, but you can't really go wrong here. Don't come here expecting to sit down and eat though. It gets really busy at lunch and there are only seating for like 6.
author: Ephie T.

description:
As with any well-known place around FiDi, expect to wait if you come during lunch time. Coming at noon on a Friday resulted in about a half hour wait. I got the very standard katsu curry just to try the most basic thing for my first time.

The curry was good but wasn't head and shoulders over other Japanese curries I've had, like I hoped it would be. I got the medium curry, and it wasn't very spicy but I do eat a lot of spicy food. The pork was pretty satisfactory so no complaints there. The curry pan was also solid.

It was more a 3.5 but not many places do just Japanese curry and I haven't tried some of the other menu items. Worth checking out if you can go there during off-peak hours.
author: Kevin T.

description:
3.5 Stars. I'm roundin' up because the green tea sponge roll did make me quite elated. 

So it's a bright, beautiful sunny day in San Francisco. The sprightly weather inspired me to give this one guy a second chance. And while he may have brought me to this currylicious haven, yet again, he fails to meet me on time let alone even offer to pay for my meal, AGAIN. PSH. Now I ain't a gold digger and I would have refused regardless, but come on man. Come on. Take notes P.C, cause I'm callin' you out! There's a reason why you've been single for so long. Way to be a gentleman. WORD. 

ANY WHO, Muracci's is supposedly one of the bay area's best places for Japanese curry. I've been waiting to try it out for quite some time now, and thank goodness for my lunch date's only redeeming quality of being a S.F know-it-all, I finally got my chance to. 

Like the majority have mentioned, this place isn't exactly an ideal dine in. There is a counter here and there and a tiny (but adorable) table that you can enjoy your to-go packed meal. I ordered the katsu curry in medium with brown rice(!) and a green tea sponge roll. 

In comparison to several places, the curry here is definitely on the soupy side. It was well seasoned and had a decent kick of spice for a medium level (next time I'd go with hot though), but the curry was not as thick as I would have liked. The Katsu pork was decent -  admittedly a little dry, but saved by the curry nonetheless. Still, the medley of the katsu, curry, pickled veggies and rice in a spoonful was nonetheless satisfying and good. 

Green tea sponge roll was nice. :D That is all. 

Overall, it's a nice affordable spot for lunch if you're craving good Japanese curry. Not the best I've had, but it definitely ranks up high.
author: Kero D.

description:
The tonkatsu is FREAKING amazing. It's a small place, which sort of sucks - I wouldn't suggest to dine in here. However, I would definitely suggest for you to get take-out and enjoy the deliciousness that is Muracci's at home. The meal is surprisingly HUGE.

They also make everything fresh when you get in -- so expect to wait a bit longer when orderring.
author: Joanne W.

description:
One block away, while standing on Kearny and Bush.

Where did Muracci's go?

Oh!  There it is, I guess I didn't recognize it because there's no line outside...

I walk a block and 20 seconds later...WTF, where did all these people come from?  The lunch crowd just walked in,   That is how fast and furious a lunch crowd in FiDi is.  One second they are not there, another 20 second, ka-boom!  there's a line out the door.  We move fast for an opportunity to avoid a line.  And this time, I didn't move fast enough.

I've been here many times and typically, I would order the mild beef curry over rice.  The curry is pretty darn awsome.  But I try not to come too often since there are other places that serve curry for less $, which is different but good in its own way.  This last time, I poured through numerous photos on YELP and the chicken Katsu called me over.

First time having chicken Katsu...EVER!  it disapponinted me.  It was crunchy and tasty on the outside but the inside was super dry.  And even dosing it with curry, you can still taste how dry the chicken was.  The curry, which is served to the side, was still good though.

Even at this, I imagine I'll still be back to give it a second try.  Other Yelpers raved over this dish, so, I'm chucking this as a bad day for Muracci's.  Yep.
author: Jenny T.

description:
This place is very small and quite cramped so I suggest getting your food to go. Lunch time is super busy so there's often a line but you can call ahead of time and simply pick up your order to bypass the wait! 

The food is amazing.  My favorite by far is the spicy noodle with udon.  The curry is authentic and not too spicy (you can ask to make it spicer- I do and it's fantastic). The udon is always perfectly cooked.  

If you're looking for a quick, delicious, lunch spot in FiDi I highly suggest checking this place out!
author: Ashley A.

description: Hands down the best best best Japanese curry in the Bay Area. So sad they shut down the South Bay branch in Los Altos. Please open more stores !!
author: Ronak S.

description: I ate here yesterday during the busy lunch hours and ordered chicken curry, only to walk back to my office and see they forgot to include the chicken :( This was especially disappointing considering the food is a bit pricey to begin with and the wait can sometimes take a while. The curry itself is delicious so I may go back, but next time I'll be sure to check that I received what I ordered.
author: Christine C.

description:
Excellent joint in FiDi for lunch. I didn't want to walk (my office is further down in SoMa) so I ordered delivery for beef curry noodles with ramen, spice level medium.

There is a hefty delivery fee of $6, but if your office is far, and/or you're ordering as a group, I think it's worth it! My order was placed shortly before 11 (when they open), and it arrived at 11:21, even before their estimated of time of 11:29-11:45.

The noodles were great in texture and the curry broth was amazing. Really spicy--next time, I think I'll opt for a mild spice level, because medium definitely has a kick to it (and I absolutely love hot foods). My order was $10.25 pre-tip and pre-tax.

Would definitely order again from them in the future!
author: Chrystal Z.

description: I was fooled by high marks this joint got. The place is super tiny and is able to seat about 11-12 people. Definitely not good for groups. Expect to order to take-out. I had the chicken katsu curry and it was pretty unimpressive given the four stars this place has. I've had better curry in the South Bay. I won't be coming back here again.
author: Jack U.

description:
Above average curry.
I love spicy but I feel like the `medium spicy` this place is more spicy than other places.
author: Pai-Wei L.

description:
What could be better than some yummy delicious curry? True the wait is long, but it does move really fast! 

The curry itself is packaged separately in another container (so you can take it to go without getting your food soggy, since seating is limited), and you just pour it over your rice/Katsu whenever you're ready.

Katsu is well cooked, tender and crunchy, super delicious.
Curry is very flavorful, spicy (I ordered it extra hot), and taste heavenly. 
Your taste buds will be jumping and running around in excitement while you're eating it. Comes with radishes and pickled cabbage that complements the curry well.

P.S: Use Orderahead to place an order beforehands, so when you get there, you can just pick it up!
author: Xin W.

description: I love it. I moved away from the Bay Area and it's one of the handful of restaurants I miss the most. That sauce is magical.
author: Jerome T.

description:
Small joint with not much seating. Curry was okay, but I Japacurry wins over this place hands down. 

Super fast service. They offer both brown and white rice, for all the healthies out there. 

Also, beware, if you say hot for your spiciness level, expect HOT. I only got a medium/mild and the spiciness already overtook the regular sweetness of Japanese curry. There's nothing in the curry either. No remnants of potato or carrots, which I would definitely like to see.
author: Annie S.

description:
I got the beef curry and vegetable ramen while my friend got the pork Katsu curry. The Katsu was definitely better! It was so crunchy and perfectly breaded! I will definitely order that next time. I was totally experiencing food jealousy! 

The doracci (red bean either cheese pancake) also looked super delicious, but sadly they sold out even though it was only 1145 when we went!
author: Karmen K.

description:
Excited to try this out. 

VEGETARIANS, I have confirmed they use vegetable stock for the veggie options.

Will update my review after trying the food :)
author: Annie J.

description: Ordered online karaage chicken curry.  Check your plates before you leave.  Got to my office and no curry :(
author: Manalani S.

description:
This place was really close to my internship and I always passed by this place when it had a huge line shooting out the door. You can go ahead and call ahead and pass the entire line which is what I did. Seating is very limited and I think only 6 people will have actual seats, so you might have to bring it back to your cube.

I got the chicken curry katsu, and honestly it was just ok. I have had chicken katsu before and it is just chicken breast fried to a crisp. Crispy food is always delicious but I expected the meat to be more flavorful. If it wasnt for the fried part, the chicken would be really plain. The curry added flavor to the dish but this was just regular Japanese curry that I could make at home. The dish was good but overall I was not very impressed by it.

**TIPS**
1) Call ahead to skip the huge line!
2) The curry and fried chicken are warm and taste good on those cold SF days.
3) Enjoy!
author: Amy H.

description:
Probably one of the best Japanese curry spots I know of in SF.  Having living in Tokyo for 15 years, I get a craving for Japanese curry time to time.  Sometimes I'm thrown off by Japanese curry spots being opened by folks who only visited Japan.  Muracchi is actually owned by a Japanese guy making all the recipes and you see him time to time taking orders when the line is long for such a small spot.

I can almost eat there every week and vouch for its authenticity.  Plus, this is the only place I now in SF that I can get a "curry pan" (Deep fried bread stuffed with Japanese curry) that I have loved since childhood.
author: William Y.

description:
LIQUID GOLD. 

This curry is more like a spicy gravy, which should equate to a hearty beverage. If they sold it by the mug, I would be dead.
author: Eduardo R.

description:
We went there around 3:30 on Saturday craving for some legit curry after reading positive Yelp reviews. When we walked in, all the chairs were up on the table and obviously they were ready to close. Not a welcoming environment to eat in at all. We were told by the cashier lady there was only chicken curry or beef curry to choose from as they shut off the fryer due to closing. 

It's very misleading that they say they are open until 4 if they start closing after 3:30 and have only TWO items available! We had to walk out. It is very unfortunate as we always wanted to try their chicken katsu. The casher lady was not apologetic at all and rude. Probably won't go back.
author: Chris L.

description: So good. I know it's hard to mess up curry but the chicken katsu curry was so delicious. Ordered it medium hot but I definitely think I could have handled the hot. Pretty fast service considering the huge line on a Saturday afternoon. They have pickled cabbage with it as well, which was a nice addition.
author: Emily K.

description: The food was off the chain!! We ordered the Katsu Curry, Chicken Teriyaki, Chicken Curry, and Chicken Karaagi Ramen all very flavorful!! I opted for the medium curry and it was really spicy for me ( but I still digged it ) The only downside is that this location is really cramped, such so that you get the feeling that you gotta rush to eat so that other people can fit in to order their food. I guess this place is geared towards take out. Place gets really busy.
author: Cha S.

description:
Their service is amazing!! If you've ever gone to Japan, imagine taking a sample of Japanese service and placing it in America. Ya, it's that good.

So I, in a demonstration of my utter stupidity, left my debit card on the table before leaving. The lady from the restaurant chased me for more than 3 whole blocks to give me the card. Next time I go, the tips is going to be more than the meal itself.
author: Ken K.

description:
Finally found a good Japanese curry spot! 

I ordered the chicken katsu curry over brown rice, medium spice. The chicken katsu was still crispy after the walk back into the office, since they put the curry in a separate tub The medium spice curry was perfectly spicy for my taste, though the curry itself was a little tart for my liking. 

My co-worker ordered the same as me, and also got the curry pan. She said she actually liked it more than the chicken katsu. (She thought the katsu breading was a little much).

I would still definitely recommend to anyone that's craving Japanese curry!
author: Camille A.

description: I ordered salmon teriyaki lunch set. It is big potion, with potato salad, vegetables. It tastes very good. Real Japanese. I saw everybody here order curry dishes. I definitely come back to try curry!!!!!
author: Emma C.

description:
Literally a 'hole in the wall' in SF, my cousin and I ended up stumbling upon this place and thank goodness we did! (=

I got the pork katsu curry, and IT WAS SO DELICIOUS! Basically inhaled it in a couple of minutes *O* Pork was crispy, mixed with just the right amount of curry, rice was on point with the pickled radish too = PERFECT! The portion is just right too.
My cousin said the curry soup was good too~ You can also increase the spicyness if you want. 
The owner (?) was also very nice and helped us order :)

The place is sooooo small, and there's like no where to sit. Also, when you first walk in you can totally smell the pungent curry. But we were able to get the window seat! Pretty cool too, see everyone looking in and reading the menu from outside while you're stuffing your face (x
author: Christine T.

description: Doesn't wroth the hype. Too expensive for a simple curry rice. Ordered chicken cutlets curry and the chicken cutlet was too dry.
author: Tina H.

description:
lunch

food: pork katsu curry. i like how they asked to put the curry sauce on the side. most places slather that stuff all over and it makes the patty all soggy. like fries i prefer dipping my food. it was crispy and tender. most importantly thick enough that it's not dry. ***4/5 

service: the place can get cramped because it's so small. while i was there, many people ordered to go. the place is muggy since it's so close tot kitchen. it doesnt help that it was a hot day. the server was nice and i get to see my food being cooked since i got front row seats. ***3/5

value: the portion is great. perhaps too much for a starter dish on my food adventure. plenty of food and the food was good. ***4/5
author: Andy Z.

description:
Maybe I can't tell the difference between good curry and great curry, but Muracci's tasted like every other japanese curry place for me. It is also too expensive to be worthwhile, at $10 each order, with lots of rice and like 5 pieces of stewed chicken in the curry. 

Also, realized that chicken curry is not the same as chicken katsu curry-- gah get that one instead!!
author: Y W.

description:
athentic japanese curry! 
i usuaally order the chicken curry with brown rice,
the portion is okay but i hoped they could add some vege inside the curry.
its basically just chicken + curry sauce + brown rice.
author: Miffy L.

description: good japanese curry in SF! I order Katsu curryand curry is good, Katsu is big enough but nedd a little bit more flavor for the pork. Anyway I like it :D especially the cabbage pickle that come with the curry in the small containner!
author: Orange S.

description: Really enjoyed getting their Katsu Curry. I enjoy spicy food a lot and most places aren't very spicy but Muracci's 10x spicy was very enjoyable. However, I would not recommend getting their Chicken Curry since it was way less meat than their Katsu Curry.
author: Guorui W.

description:
The owner is very nice and friendly and i enjoy good teste of curry 
I reccomence to everyone
author: Miyabi K.

description:
Came here with my coworkers for lunch. I would suggest you start trending over to the location around 1130 since the restaurant is located near the financial district. I had the spicy noodle with udon and the curry pan. Love love love ! The place is small but my to go order didn't take that long and I the food was superb. The spicy noodle was a good amount of spicy but be worn it can get messy. The curry pan is a lightly battered fried bread with a curry filling. This was delicious and for only $2.50 it is definitely worth it. 

The prices are affordable especially for SF downtown standards. I would definitely recommend is place for smaller groups since the seatings are limited but take out isn't that bad either.
author: Amy T.

description: Quick Japanese food for a reasonable price. Good portion size and friendly staff.
author: Josh H.

description: It was very good and a large portion. However way too pricey for a curry plate. Starts around $8. After a vegetable here and a tofu there, you're looking at $12+ meal.
author: David N.

description:
Wow. I got this through Caviar. I figured Caviar only delivers the BEST. But no. Not here. I placed an order for Chicken Curry and get a call saying they're out of chicken, would I like beef instead. I say yes reluctantly and take the order.

This is not beef. It's like those rawhide dog toys. The curry sauce was amazing. Maybe a little too sweet, but the thing that ruined this meal is the beef. Just to make sure I'm not missing out on some sort of "Foodie" moment where I'm supposed to see some kind of brilliance in this curry dish, I went and looked at the menu and it said 'TENDER' pieces of beef. What a lie.

I'd avoid this place. Too much hype to even bother to check the quality of their meat.
author: Stephen H.

description:
The line looks long, but your food comes super quick so don't stray away from this place just because of the line. 

I ordered the Japanese curry with vegetables and tofu with brown rice and I asked them to make it spicy. A lot of the reviews on Yelp recommended doing this but I wouldn't recommend it. I didn't particularly like the extra flavor the spices added and it make the curry taste a little powdery. Besides that, I had never tried Japanese curry so it was an interesting dish that wasn't particularly one of my favorites. It just didn't have very many flavors, it was just OK. Just a tip, if you're vegetarian, make sure to ask for veggie broth for the curry.
author: Malika R.

description:
I have been wanting to try this place ever since I started working on the 7x7's Big Eat 2010 scavenger hunt. Perhaps my expectation was unrealistically high. I wanted to fall in love so desperately but I left feeling underwhelmed alone. 

The curry was tasty but not rich. I was looking for the complexity of blended vegetable flavors but there weren't too much there besides the spiciness. The tonkatsu was crunchy and fresh but the meat wasn't tender enough. I like it but it wasn't the great katsu curry I was hoping for. It might be a good place for a quick and cheap lunch but there are much better Japanese curry places elsewhere.

I like their croquette better than the curry. The chicken and vegetable ramen was a bit strange to me though. If I work in this area I would probably be a regular but I won't make a trip just for this.
author: Mona W.

description: HEAVEN. I wish I could pick this place up and take it back with me to NYC. Usually I find japanese curry to be sweet but the medium level Chicken katsu curry had a slight kick! The sauce was BOMB and I cleared out my plate. The chicken katsu was PERFECT. Moist and crunchy.
author: Lily L.

description:
We were late. It was 19:15 and they were already closing. We were disappointed and showed it. The owner wanted to recommend us another Japanese restaurant. But we said: "no, we wanted to eat in your restaurant". So he said, wait here. We waited a few minutes. He came out with a brown bag full of food and gave it to us. It was a very nice beef curry.  We wanted to pay him, but he insisted not to be paid. If you read it , dear owner - thank you so much!

So this review is not only about food quality, it is about human kindness and generosity.
author: Sagiv S.

description: Incredible Japanese curry...after living in Japan I became obsessed and addicted to curry. I found this small friendly location today and had a great experience. Friendly service and perfectly prepared pork cutlets. If you go for lunch, get it to go or prepare to squeeze into a corner, like I did. It was worth the squeeze!
author: Carl R.

description:
Ever since I got really bad food from Tokyo Express, I tried to find another permanent place for my Japanese food fix.  I came here today and the line was out the door.  I sort of debated about whether I should stay in line or jump for subpar Japanese at the food court.  Before I can make up my mind, the owner came out and took our orders In N Out Burger style.  This helped a lot because he called in our orders while we waited and it cut down the wait time.  

When we got to the counter, I just handed my order sheet to the girl.  I waited less than 5 minutes before they called my number.

I got the chicken katsu with brown rice lunch set.  The chicken was pretty good.  Not pounded to the ground thin.  They gave a lot of brown rice.  The rice was sort of dry so I didn't finish it.  Miso soup was good - not overly salted.  I actually ate the potato salad this time and it was good - and I'm not a PS fan either!  Salad came with dressing on the side.  The dressing was delicious.

I'm stuffed.  No croquette.  :(  I understand it's a pain to make.  Bring it back and you'll get that last star!
author: Wendy H.

description:
Most delicious  japanese curry you'll find on this side of downtown!! I always go for their pork katsu curry- it never disappoints. 

The place is always SUPER packed and limited seating - you're better off taking it to-go and enjoying it in the comfort of your own place.
author: Tiffany S.

description: I'm not sure if they are under a new chef or management, but the taste and quality seems to have gone down the last few times I've been here.  One time I had ordered chicken curry and there was no pieces of chicken in it.  The taste almost seems like it's watered down a little...it just got a lot blander.  It's still good, but just not the amazing good that it used to be.
author: C A.

description:
Pros: Delicious Japanese curry dishes, great service, priced fairly for the quality of food, dishes are made to order and fresh, the curry sauce is packaged separately so your food does not get soggy!

Cons: Long line at lunch time (but it moves fairly quickly and there's usually someone taking orders to get your food started before you reach the register), limited seating.

So happy I was introduced to this restaurant a few months ago. Now I go here on a weekly basis. Katsu curry, beef and veggie curry over ramen, and the curry pan are my favorites. I wish I could fill a pool and swim in that delicious curry.
author: Tammi H.

description: Lied to me about wait time during busy lunch period. Said 10 min and it took closer to 30. I would not have waited that long. Food was small and almost cold. Also one employee was scratching their head and touching their pants and then picking up food and putting it into soup. Disgusting.
author: Pete S.

description: The curry is really flavorful!!! It meets my expectation for Japanese Curry! Highly recommended for people to try. It could be up to 30-40 mins wait during lunch hours.
author: Wen Hsia C.

description: Made it in time before they closed. I was so sad to hear when I first walked into the door thr owner said "no more ebi or any katsu" one look at me he said hold on let me check. Came back and whisper to me just for you we still have katsu left. I was so happy made my day for a first timer trying their curry. Anything curry this is the way to go. Happy belly!
author: Linh D.

description: Finding a cheap spot with good food is rare in the city so I'm a fan of this spot. I got the katsu curry, perfectly breaded and well cooked. I've had many experiences with overbreaded and chewy katsu, so I was impressed with this one. I've never had Japanese curry before so this is a first. No complaints. I would definitely come back again. The place got pretty packed right after we got there so we lucked out and managed to get a seat!
author: Vivian S.

description: Yummy, seemingly authentic (I don't think someone who grew up in Oregon gets to qualify japanese food as Authentic) quick serve fare. I ordered the Katsu Don and found the cutlet just a bit chewy for my liking. Excellent egg prep though, very tasty.
author: Sean M.

description: Got one of the traditional Japanese dishes - chicken katsu curry - very good. Definitely going to come back to this place to try something else. If you are planning on going there for a lunch do not expect to get a table or something, take out would be your option. Kudos to staff for being pretty fast even during busy lunch hours!
author: Svetlanko I.

description:
Came here on a trip to SF and had my first taste of katsu curry.  We don't have places like this that serve katsu anywhere in Tampa so it was a good experience.  Got it to go because the space was teeny tiny and the wife and I were in a hurry anyway.  

The gravy on the pork katsu is so flavorful and the rice does a good job of soaking up any excess.  The pork cutlet was moist and perfectly fried.  Great intro to the cuisine.
author: Bob B.

description:
Really tasty curry dishes!

Let's start with the line. I went at 12:30ish for lunch and my total wait from entering line to leaving store was 30minutes. The line was pretty long but once my order was in, the wait was pretty short. 

The food. I had the Katsu Curry dish, spicy curry with vegetables on white rice. It's commended by many people so I had to try it, and it was delicious! The spicy was just fine for a Japanese curry dish and the Katsu was done so well. 

10/10 would return.
author: Andrew Y.

description: I had a chicken katsu curry which was spiced to my likings. The flavors were great with an adequate serving size. I will be coming back before I go back to Australia!
author: Thangy S.

description: We got the chicken curry pan to go because they ran out of beef. It was lukewarm and tasted like it had been sitting out for most of the morning. Doesn't mean it wasn't good though; it was delicious. Still, I don't understand how they can run out of beef curry pan at 1pm on a Saturday, or why it was so cold.
author: D L.

description:
after 4 years i finally went back to try their ramen!

ordered the spicy noodles ramen with extra tofu, beef & vegetables ramen, and a croquette. When you order the spicy noodles they ask you the level of spiciness and i asked for regular holy shit it was so spicy! but in a good way. the tofu was bomb! croquette was bomb! bf got the beef & vegetables ramen and that was also bomb! overall muracci's is awesome and i would def come back if im ever in the area.
author: Rily S.

description: Fast service great food and affordably priced. Must try katsu curry and of course beef curry. Nice tender meat pieces married with curry sauce that can be mild to 10xhot.
author: Karl S.

description:
As good as Japanese curry gets! You can customize your curry order quite a bit - curry over white rice/brown rice, noodles, or bread, spice level, etc.

Always made fresh. My favorite is the chicken katsu - I appreciate that the chicken katsu stays crispy. Every time I pass by this place, I can smell the aroma that permeates from within.

Another big plus is their pickled veggies! Really complements the curry.
author: Jamie Y.

description: Decided to grab a quick dinner after some Plentea boba down the street. Found this hole in the wall (literally a hole in the wall) on my handy dandy yelp app. Good Lordt it was pretty empty around 4/5pm cus I hear it gets rly packed for lunch. Since I love noodles, I went with the Spicy Noodles. It consists of ramen cooked perfectly & drained, topped with a spicy japanese curry sauce w/ ground beef. It looked like a pretty filling portion when I first got it. Mixed the sauze & noodles & oh my goodness was it justtt sooo goooooood. I started to feel full when I was about 3/4ths done, but couldn't stop picking at it because it was so good. I finished it and knew I would regret it later. .. it's ok tho cus yolo. lol. I def would love to come here again. I never really even crave japanese curry, but after having their spicy noodles, I can already feel an itch to go back. Their sauce is already spicy, hence the name, and I usually can handle spicy but it came with the perfect kick when I asked for mild. If you're a first timer, I would say stick to mild & u can always make it spicier. Since it's such a teensy spot, seating is limited. There was a bar table with 4 seats behind the cashier, and around the other side is about 2 tiny tables.
author: Elise T.

description:
Pretty good

Definitely hits the spot if your looking for Japanese Curry. Agree with others that it's on the sweet side and spicy was not spicy at all. I like my Katsura curry with some veggies carrots potatoes etc but theirs is just gravy. Pickles were good. Everything kind of on the luke warm side and the tonkatsu was a bit tough.
author: Michael B.

description:
My favorite Japanese curry places are in San Francisco's Japantown or in the Sawtelle area of Santa Monica, LA.  However, Maracci's is a wonderful gem in the FiDi area of San Francisco.  Lucky for me, I work a few blocks away.

I usually get the katsu curry.  Great portion of food, you can ask for a level of spice, and they cook it to your choice.  However, my 4-stars is for their curry pan!  

The curry pan is cooked to a perfect crisp and the sizes are enough to hold you down as a snack or even a mini meal.  Honestly, I would get 2nds if my body could handle it in one sitting. 

Tips:

Don't expect fast service during the busy hours of 11:30-1:00pm.  If anything place an order ahead of time and pick it up.

Don't eat in.  Order, pick up, and perhaps eat your wonderful curry pan at the rooftop garden of the Crocker Galleria.  There are also a bunch of other rooftop gardens in the FiDi area worth checking out.  The point is, its not the kind of place where you eat in, because there isn't much room and it could get stuffy in their.

If you want something lighter than the lunch plates, they have side dishes, and rolls.  Check them out!
author: AJ T.

description:
Came here late in the day so some of their curry choices had already sold out. However, I ended up getting a chicken katsu curry and a tofu/veggie ramen to share with my mom. The katsu curry was excellent. Chicken was still moist and there was just enough curry for everything on the plate. Ramen was just alright, it really didn't come close to the rice plate.

We ended up ordering two plates to go for my dad and brother. Got the beef curry and another order of the chicken katsu. Unfortunately...they forgot the beef. Literally. We ended up with two boxes of rice. Two containers of curry. And one order of katsu. We called back just before closing and the guy, though in disbelief, was ready to accommodate us. He promised either a dish on the house or a full refund...went back today and sure enough he recognized me and apologized profusely. I took my refund and went on my merry way.
author: Elaine Y.

description: This tiny hole in the wall restaurant has got to be one of the best place I've ever had Chicken katsu Curry.  Chicken was amazingly tender!  Thin batter so it was very crispy on the outside.  Curry sauce was flavorful.  I asked for spicy and it had enough kick to it.  There were only a few seats (stools) though.  Just grab a quick lunch/dinner and go type restaurant.
author: Kim S.

description:
Like a care package of cookies and candy delivered in the nick of time during a bleak college winter away from home, Muracci's provides an oasis of comfort food during a harsh and hectic FiDi workday. 

The seemingly daunting line that stretches out the tiny door during peak lunch hour is deceivingly quick as the efficient, mustached man takes and relays orders back to the kitchen before customers arrive at the register. Upon stepping into the narrow confines that place you shoulder to shoulder with those awaiting their finished orders, the waft of heavy, salty air from the work of the flurry of cooks causes uncontrollable salivation.

Muracci's pork katsu is evenly breaded, coated just enough to provide a crispy jacket for the juicy meat, while the ebi fry is plump and fulfilling, despite being 3 pieces per order. Both display an admirable resistance to the temptation to over coat with breading, which inevitably leads to an unnecessarily heavier and oilier experience. The pork katsu is definitely more plentiful than the ebi fry, which can be taken under consideration based on appetite.

The copious curry is flavorful and rich, triumphantly uniting the meat and rice into nearly a stew-like state. The pickled red radish is a welcome crunch that could actually use additional reinforcements so that each bite can be uniformly blessed by it.
author: Andrew M.

description: In the City for business and had a little break for lunch. Decided on Marruchi for a Japanese curry dish, which I have not enjoyed for quite some time now. Full disclaimer here ... I'm not a Japanese curry connoisseur, but I do enjoy a good one when it comes along. I ordered the tonkatsu curry over white rice. Everything was fresh to order including the curry sauce. I selected the medium spiced curry, which delivered just the prefect amount of heat. The tonkatsu was moist and meaty. I liked the dish but was not bowled over with the flavor of the curry. It had a slight bitter flavor that was strange with the first bite. It got better with each bite afterwards. Overall, I enjoyed it but not so sure that I'll return again.
author: Alvin G.

description: Ordered Chicken Katsu Curry both times I've been here. Chicken is fried well and chicken stays juicy.  Tried the medium and spicy curry.  Spicy is very spicy its hard to enjoy the flavor of the curry for me.
