Wish they would add the vegetables as a traditional curry dish has (potatoes, carrots, etc) as this would bulk up the meal a bit and make me feel less hungry after eating.  Still good flavor though.  Will be back whenever I'm in the mood for it.
author: Jennifer G.

description: Good customer service and food. Messed up my order but was addressed quickly when i came back plus a free curry pan was given to make up for the mistake.
author: Alex S.

description:
Muracci's is the place to go on a nice chilly day in the city. It's worth making the 15 minute walk to the FiDi for their Japanese curry. The place can get very busy during the lunch hours on the weekdays, so try and make it out there before noon.

I would recommend getting the curry katsu (pork) and getting it spicy! At least that's what I always get. There's something incredibly satisfying about fried pork cutlet smothered in a delicious curry sauce. The meal comes with rice (white or even brown at no extra charge) and some pickled veggies. It's pretty typical to have the sweet/sour to help cut into the richness of the curry.

I'm not sure what it is about their curry that makes it different from other places, but the sauce from Muracci's handily beats those from other Japanese food joints in the city.
author: Vivian L.

description:
'09-'10 7x7 Big Eat List: #16 katsu curry

Mmm Japanese curry. My foodie-in-crime got one order for us to share. The box opened, and inside was a ginormous piece of golden brown tonkatsu laying on top of a mountain of rice. Curry on the side to avoid sogginess, so smart!

The tonkatsu was crunchy, juicy and hot! I gobbled up the thick long strips of meat within seconds. The curry was not spicy, but it added so much flavor to the dish. Wish it was a bit thicker!

Ahh another outdoor lunch success! Thanks FIC! =D
author: Marti L.

description: Loooove Japanese curry and this place does it well. The line can be wrong but the orders can come out quick as long as people pick up their items quicker. I know the place is a small shop but there are always people who don't pay attention to the orders being called out and when then complain about the wait. Did it never occur to these people to stand within ears range of the place? Overall the food is great. Fills you up and you can't go wrong.
author: edward k.

description:
Asked the order-taking head-set dude for extra-spicy curry sauce for my C-Katsu...
("the hottest you got...except if it's made from bhut jolokia")
...I received a puzzled, but smiling stare.

It was hot, but I thought it would be much more so.
Sorta like that date from hell, after she makes you earn that first-date and then it's like a facepalm event.

Four-stars today for being really crunchy and hot (the chicken, not her).
author: Derek N.

description:
I've never had curry cravings until I tried Muracci's. The curry is seasoned just right - not bland or overly greasy, and the katsu has the perfect ratio of breading to meat. Oh, and YOU MUST ADD CHEESE. The cheese addition is LIFE CHANGING. 

[+] Get the chicken katsu curry if it's your first time. Sometimes it can be a bit dry, but the curry helps with that
[+] The grilled chicken curry is consistently moist if you're afraid of getting dry chicken
[+] CALL YOUR ORDER IN! There is always a huge line around lunchtime, so unless you like waiting, call ahead!
[+] Brown rice option
[+] Their udon, croquettes, and curry pan are also really good
author: Janice W.

description:
Must try:
a) $2.25 Curry pan!
b) their katsu curry, choose your own level of spice.

That's all I'm going to say!

Don't expect to eat there is always crowded.
author: David L.

description: Get ready for mega flavor burps the rest of the day!!!
author: Amy C.

description:
PROS: LOVE THEIR CHICKEN CURRY!!! I add cheese to the curry and its just so delish! I havent tried anything else in their menu, but thats ok because I'm already satisfied wit their curry. 

CONS: Don't go there on busiest hours which is from around 1130AM-1PM. It's like a hole in the wall type place so their lines are pretty long between those hours and it can get crowded. I usually call for take-out so I can't complain.

I usually order this once every 2 weeks so yes I consider myself a regular :)
author: Sharmaine M.

description:
Curry is pretty consistent most of the time.

Pickled veggies compliment the curry really well.  My fave.

My only complaint is that there isn't enough meat in their curries.
author: TM O.

description: Love love that this place exists! Legit japanese curry!! I heard they're are long lines for lunch, but theres not much of a price difference between lunch and after that. I went around 5:30, it closes at 7. There wasn't many people, or a line, and I got to sit down and eat. I got the Chicken katsu which was breaded perfectly from the panko. The sauce I got "Mild" but it still had a bit of a kick in the flavor! I got it with white rice, and nothing beats japanese white rice made in a japanese rice cooker! My only problem was the Chicken Katsu was only a few pieces. Probably 10 at most.  I never finish my food, let alone the meat, and at this place there was so little chicken that I finished it... /: I'd go again once more to try the Pork Katsu and their Curry Pan. But I won't get the Chicken katsu since it wasn't filling.
author: Stephanie T.

description:
Japanese curry is amazing and this place has it! Now open on Saturdays, we stopped by for curry and left so full.

The price is really good for the amount of food you get. I ordered a mild curry with tofu and the guy taking my order asked if I needed it vegetarian, thus giving me the impression that there's something else in the food (aside from your choice of chicken, beef, fish, etc) that isn't veg*an friendly, so asking me was *much* appreciated!

I did order mild but wow, it was still spicy. Not sure if mine wasn't mild or if their version of it is a bit spicier than I expected. Regardless, it was full of mixed veggies and chunks of tofu and lots of delicious curry sauce.

Two thumbs up, would happily come here for lunch again!
author: Cassandra J.

description:
I used to live in the Bay Area but in the last few days when I traveled to SF, I realized that the standard of Japanese food in SF is quite low compared to places like LA and Vegas. Those people who are raving about this curry has obviously had not had real good japanese curry.  

First of all, this curry sauce is pitifully thin and devoid of any umami.  There is such thing as "soup curry" which was made popular in Sapporo in the last few years in Japan, but this is not it.  This is just a poorly made curry.  

Secondly, there was hardly any rice compared to amount of curry sauce it came with.  

All in all, $12 for a lunch box of oyster fry curry.  My only reason for given 2 stars was because the kaki fry (oyster fry) was actually decent.  However, if this is a so called "curry-ya" and if the level of their curry is this low....it only deserves 1 or 2 stars.  If this place was in Japan, it would be out of business in one month.  That's how bad it is and it is an insult to Japanese curry culture.
author: Alex S.

description:
i was really excited to try this place but i left a little disappointed :(

i got the ebi curry and the ebi (shriiiimp) was fried well but the curry bored me after a while. also had some of the katsu curry which was a better because of it's crunchiness and the fact that it had a better meat to rice ratio than the shrimp curry

i still don't understand why curry in the states is always just the liquid, without any veggies (unless you pay more of course). hope to one day find curry reminiscent of my childhood school lunches in japan :') 

giving them three stars because i should probably come back and try something with more variety (like their curry udon or the veggie curry)
author: Hana S.

description: I've been here multiple times, and oh my goodness - I can never talk about how good they always are! They are pretty fast - things I've tried: katsu (pork) curry and the karage (fried chicken) curry. Both were pretty good. They offer brown rice for free in place of white rice, which I really appreciate. My brother got the fried ebi (shrimp), and he only got 3 pieces (which I thought was not that much given that it was $12.95). Regardless, great place for delicious curry. They don't have a lot of seating, so it can easily be a grab and go place too.
author: Sophie D.

description:
Pluses - Quick and fast place to pick up lunch - large portions as well

Minuses - rice to toppings ratio is not great, there's a lot of rice in those bowls!
author: Grace Y.

description:
I give this 4 solid stars. 

With a line that wraps out the block, the line goes by extremely fast. I got the Mediusm Chicken Katsu with brown rice. The curry was not spicy, but there is a kick. Some folks do get extra spicy, so that is an option if you enjoy spicy food. The chicken is crispy but moist. They do give you a good portion of it too, so you are not left with a hefty plate of brown rice. Definitely place to check out. For me, I would only get it only if I am craving curry. I am not a superfan, but it is definitely a good lunch option if you work in fidi. Less than 10 bucks!
author: Phuong V.

description:
The katsu is good... but not enough curry. I usually order to-go and the curry comes in half of a clear container only. I don't know about you but I LOVE curry with my rice as well as the meat. The curry was barely enough for my meat alone. For almost $10 a plate... a lil more curry is all I ask for. If you've been to Tani's Kitchen in Daly City, they drown their curry onto your plate! 

They messed up on my phone-in to-go order once. I had to walk all the way back to exchange it. They gave me a complimentary dessert pastry. Thanks.
author: Nancy N.

description:
I came here to pick up some take out for lunch while working.
I ordered the salmon and it was pretty decent. The portion was good but it don't think it was anything to write home about.
author: Noa R.

description:
The food was ok and the service was terrible. The kid at the front didn't notice us and we had to go to him twice to get seated. 
No one checked on us and once again we had to go up to the front counter and place our order. It took 35 minutes to get our food. Ridiculous for the fast in and out place this is supposed to be.
author: Heidi N.

description:
ive been craving katsu curry with cheese ever since I first discovered it on inebriated evening in shibuya at curry time. when I first heard about muraccis, ive been jonesing for a taste. i finally had the opportunity when I got out of a tableau conference just a 15 min walk away.

after a short brisk walk, i found myself sweaty in a small hole in the wall that didn't seat more than 10. they were already sold out of all curry pan and katsu curry. i was pretty bummed i had to settle for chicken katsu.

the taste was reminiscent but the medium spicy was a little sweet. not a fan of three curry. additionally, this place is wayyy overpriced for what you get. my chicken katsu curry with cheese ran me a little over $15! granted i always tip well wherever I eat, but c'mon! pretty sure there's just a large vat of curry they just ladle onto a little bit of fried chicken. cheese was an additional $2.50! 

double ewe, tee, efffff? glad i didn't drag my brother here, curry is his favorite. he would have probably beat me like when we were kids for wasting this epic fail.

2 stars cause i got my fix, at the very least. beggars can't be choosers.
author: Jimmy C.

description:
Yummy curry from a tiny hole in the wall (emphasis on the TINY!)

Customer service was nice and friendly.

Freshly cooked chicken katsu - hot, juicy and moist with a crispy panko crust.

Spiciness level for the curry is custom - make it as mild or spicy as you want.

PERFECT white rice!  Not too wet and not too dry.  Sometimes you just need some good, Japanese rice, and this place gives it to you.

The tsukemono (picked cabbage) was sweeter than most that I've had.  It was different, but in a good way.
author: Kristy S.

description:
I really think I am addicted to the Katsu Curry!  Ever since I first went a month ago I've been back every week.  I get it extra spicey with extra sauce and pickled vegetables.  Deliciousness.

An article says that the curry is made in a 2 day process and you can tell.  The flavors are complex and well distributed, and just thinking about it makes my mouth water!

I had it once with the beef on a friends suggestion.  It was good, but nothing beats the Katsu.  I stood on the side once watching them prepare the Katsu.  Expertly done.  

Line can get a bit long during lunch, but it moves fast.  The wait is a bit long for a take out spot, but I wouldn't rush them one bit because the quality shows when you get your food.

Highly recommended, as this is usually one of the first places I suggest visiting friends to go.
author: Veasna H.

description:
A little hole in the wall place - almost missed it. It's right next to the corner Thai restaurant.
Got chicken katsu curry (hot) with brown rice and boiled egg (extra). Perfect portion for lunch and great pickled veggies.
A long line right at noon so come early - especially if you wanna grab a seat to eat there.
A little noisy when it gets busy as there is a man that takes order of the folks in line and yells the order out loud. I'm sure this is efficient but very loud!
author: Linda K.

description:
We went to Akiko's trying to get a table for dinner, however they were all full. Seeing this place was really close by with good reviews we decided to stop by. No line at all 30 minutes to closing so that was a plus!

I ended up ordering the Katsu curry at medium spice while the fiancé ordered the spicy noodles. The curry was much better in my opinion than the noodles. Nice flavor and it really hit the spot! The curry is the best I've ever had but that doesn't say much as there's no good Japanese curry place in Houston. Overall, it was a great find for dinner!
author: Wendy L.

description: My go-to curry joint when I'm in town. Fast, cheap, hearty.
author: Alexis L.

description:
Muracci's - This place is a diamond in the rough.  It is located in an understated, as referenced in some of the posts, hole in the wall spot with enough table space along the inside parameters of the tiny space for about 10 people to sit bar stool style.

Why is it good???  Well let me tell you!!  I always order the CHICKEN CURRY.  It is always on point delicious.  The sauce is perfectly seasoned with just the right hint of flavor and spices.  I asked for medium spicy and it was exactly as ordered.

One minor complaint though - why is the cashier charging $1.75 for an extra tiny little container of the cabbage?  That is seriously over the top ridiculous for literally getting half a leaf of chopped cabbage.  Seriously??! C'mon.

However, I will still go over and over again.  I'll just SKIP the extra cabbage that I do crave!!
author: Ana W.

description:
Highlights
- Literally a hole in the wall with limited seating and more of a place where you place your order, grab your food To Go. 
- The best Katsu Curry in SF so far. Pork cutlet served with curry sauce over white rice. The rice is cooked perfectly and curry sauce mild has enough spice to make it taste delicious over the crispy fried pork cutlets. It comes with a side of pickled ginger. 
- Another one of my favorites is their Tofu and Vegetable Curry Udon. The perfect portion of vegetables and udon noodles. I think I like this dish more than the katsu curry, but alternating between both does the trick to spice things up a bit. 

Improvements
- The lunch crowds are unavoidable and there really isn't much space to sit and eat comfortably in this restaurant. 

Tip
- Call in your order and pick up for quickest turnaround.
author: Tracy T.

description:
Omnomonomonomonomonom

That's what I sound like when I'm eating Muraccis. It disappears in about 5-10 minutes after I order it, and I am left completely satisfied, every time.

I've ordered the salmon, chicken, chicken katsu, and veggie/tofu curry w/ brown rice. Medium is a good spice level if you want some kick to it. There's usually a line for lunch but it's worth it.
author: Natasha N.

description: The curry here is average. Nothing spectacular. Prices are moderate. We just stopped here for lunch while in the financial district. The place is tiny. Needs more flavor in the sauce.
author: Ali S.

description:
#16 on the 2011 7x7 List: Katsu Curry
#16 on the 2009 7x7 List: Katsu Curry

Muracci's a small little shop in the FiDi.  The line is out the door so they must be doing something right.

One thing to note is their Express Curry - ready made and can be handed to you if you want Mild Beef or Chicken curry with white or brown rice to go.  The working stiffs in FiDi can enjoy a nice curry without having to wait upwards of 10 minutes for something that they'll take back to the office anyway.

I had no one to report to, so stuck around for the made-to-order Katsu Curry.  My last attempt to try-something-on-the-2009-List before the new one rolls out February.

-Tasty? My spicy-hot Katsu Curry was worth every bite.  What's great is that they use durable plastic containers that don't leak and are reusable.  I hope everyone gives these containers a chance

-Service:  The line moves pretty quickly.  The food is handled by two people. Although there's a wait, you know they're on it to get it to you asap

-Ambiance: hole-in-a-wall with limited counter seating

-Worth the trip/try?  If you're on this part of the peninsula, definitely grab some take-away from here
author: Winnie L.

description: I don't usually crave Curry, because it's usually too heavy. But when I do crave curry, this is my go to spot. Go for the Pork Katsu Curry. The pork is perfectly crispy and the meat is juicy and tender. You can choose the spiciness of the curry sauce as well as the option of white rice or brown rice. The curry also comes with pickled vegetables. Mix it all up and eat to your heart's content. Get ready for some food coma at work...
author: Tim L.

description:
I cannot stress enough how much I adorrrrrrrrrrrrrrrrrrrrre (yes its necessary to put so many R's because it is that amazing) this place! I miss working literally right around the corner from it, but I would walk the 10 blocks just to get my hands on some delicious, slow-cooked Japanese curry. I remember a few months ago the staff informed me they would not sell the currypan bread for a few weeks and I was devastated! But their food takes time, and it shows. 

Don't get put off by the settings, it is the very definition of a "hole-in-wall" restaurant but it's a total diamond in the ruff.

Thank you Muracci's for bringing your amazing food to San Francisco!
author: Mariko M.

description:
I don't quite remember how good this place was, but I do remember that I never came back afterwards so it wasn't good enough for me to get another item. 

Price was consistent with what everyone else has said. 

I got the chicken curry over brown rice and though I remember it was decent, it wasn't  changing my prior views that Japanese curry was on the low tier of all curries in life. So, come here if you are just craving japanese curry or you have just an entirely different view on what counts as good curry because Japanese curries just don't cut it for me
author: Andrew C.

description:
I'm not a whore.

But whenever I dine in here I sweat like a whore in church....
Cheap, fast and oh so delicious. One of the greatest things about working downtown is Muraccis. I met up with a friend here for lunch, the area is small few tables I want to say ionno ONE, but it's worth it. If you can get here have the pork katsu curry be fat be happy!
author: Cristelle J.

description:
I've had a good amount of curry in my life and although there are subtle differences with each try, it's more or less the same. However, there was something very different about Muracci's! Maybe it was the extreme hunger factor or maybe it was that the owner was super helpful but I fell in love with this place.

It's definitely a hole-in-the-wall with seating for 14 people max, but the owner made sure we had comfortable seating and didn't process our orders until we were seated so our food wouldn't get cold. We were a group of four and unfortunately had to separate by 2's but didn't mind it as we all had one thing on our mind: fulfill hunger. 

I shared the Katsu Curry with brown rice with my friend as it was 3pm and we wanted to be hungry again for dinner. It was the perfect portion for us girls. The katsu was perfectly crisp on the outside and tender on the inside and the curry had a certain kind of ZING that I liked. The side of house special pickles also proved to be crucial to this dish and I devoured all of it. Regardless to say, our plate was licked clean and our tummies happy.
author: Jaimie L.

description:
If you haven't been eating Japanese curry for lunch, you are missing out. Period. Aloha Eats in Chicago tipped me off to the joys of the food. The wondrous Emi H in Honolulu advised me on how best to fit 11 servings into my big belly. Muracci's sealed the deal. Oh, Muracci's. I understand why your small storefront is forever lined to the gills with people. This isht is delicious!!

Know before you go: the place is small. You are the last person in SF to have heard about Muracci's, ergo there will be a line. A long one. But, because the Muracci's folks know what they're doing, they've devised an order/pay/receipt system that's nearly flawless. Step in line. Observe. Imitate. Don't f it up. Simple, right?

Also know: get the chicken katsu curry. Yes. This. If a place has 'curry' in its name and you don't order 'curry'... what am I doing even finishing that sentence? Get the curry. "But, Johnny T," you plead, "Chicken katsu is my jam." Of course it is. It's delicious. "Whatever do I do?" Get the curry *and* the katsu. See? See that? But, wait. I'm not done. Get the white rice, not the brown. You aren't eating a kale salad with sprouts for lunch, so don't act brand new when it comes to rice. Throw the pickles over everything and ask for the hot curry. Yes, the hot one. Medium has a nice flavor profile, but no real heat. Hot will add some serious depth to your food but it's not so hot that you'll be in pain.

Also also know: all this amazing food will be yours for less than $10. It's true. Seating is limited, but you're in SF. Odds are the weather will be decent enough for you to eat outside. Head over to YB, plop down on the ground, yell at some hippies to get a job & cut their hair, and settle in for a huge amount (your food bag will be heavy) of delicious delicious food.

Know this.
author: Johnny T.

description:
Get the hot curry. Don't be scared. You have to believe! It adds so much flavor.

Also get the extra cabbage! You'll be happy you did at the end when you have a pile of rice an curry to shovel in your mouth. Texture upgrade.
author: Eric D.

description:
Delicious!

Small hole in the wall curry house.  Best to order take out and eat somewhere else.  

Pork cutlets served crispy on the outside, tender on the inside, and hot all over. Curry sauce is thick and tasty, with your choice of spice level. 

Reasonably priced. Long lunch lines. Will definitely be back!
author: Diana M.

description:
I love being in SF this week!  So today, as it was wet and I've been walking a lot (stupid contacts ripped in my eye yeah!  I know!  Weird! So I had to go home and so much BART traveling), I decided it was a perfect time to try out the Katsu Curry at Muracci's since it was just a block away from our training center.

Located on the corner of Kearny and Bush, this place is tiny!  Don't expect to eat here with a big group.  Also if you do have a big group, order ahead of time and come in to pick it up.  The kitchen seemed a bit cramped but they made it work.  Everything is made to order so nothing is pre-made.  When I heard, "1 katsu kare, onegaishimasu"  I knew this would be a winner.  It took maybe 10 minutes before I got my order and I hopped skipped away to eat it.  There were other different curries as well as lunch specials and sandwiches.  They sold Japanese drinks too, so you get the full quick service Japanese food experience in SF.

~ Katsu Curry ~
You get a choice of the spiciness - Mild, Medium, Hot.  I opted for hot since I figured it was a Japanese restaurant and not Korean.  I would be very wary of Hot at a Korean Place or Thai for that matter.  Anyway, I digress.  Then a choice of white or brown rice.  SCORE.  I love brown rice.  They separate the container of curry and katsu with rice and pickled veggies.  I've never had just Katsu Curry so I was expecting a little more than just meat in the curry sauce like veggies etc, but I guess that's not authentic.  The pork cutlet is definitely sizeable.  So crispy and juicy.  I opted to dunk my cutlet in the curry sauce and mmmm.  Hot was perfect.  So much kick but I wanted it to be.  It didn't distract from the taste of the pork, just enhanced it.

I would say this place is a definite hole-in-the-wall, but a fancy one with authentic Japanese quick meals.  A bit on the pricey side, but I think it's definitely worth it for the quality.  I will definitely be back to try the katsu with cheese and the rest of the menu!
author: Carolen M.

description:
Holy cow batman! The line is ridic during the lunch rush. I probably waited about 20 mins from order to pick up. 

I ordered the chicken katsu curry. Honestly, the curry portion was meek. They charged me extra for the pickles (which was fine). Nothing about it stood out though. 

I like Volcano Curry on Geary Street better. Hands down way better.
author: Katie Anne N.

description:
Quick service. Small place - only bar tables.  
Place Lunch rush. Fresh ramen noodles- still al dente and chewy. Thick curry sauce. Beef a little dry and the veggies undercooked.
author: Adrienne L.

description: I am not an experienced person when it comes to Japanese cuisine, but I did enjoy the food here. I yelped some restaurants close to the hotel I was staying at, and this was the first place I chose to eat at after first arriving in San Francisco. If you happen to be around the Union Square area give this place a try! The place was a little too small for my preference so I took the food to go. If that does not bother you then you will have no problem. :) I ordered the Chicken Katsu curry and I ordered the curry mild, although I regret it because it was a little too mild so I recommend getting a little more spice on your curry. :)
author: Lucia M.

description:
Four years later and this place is still in my opinion one of the best if not the best lunch spot in FiDi/Downtown.  The food is always served up hot and fresh, the people are friendly, and it is good quality food without being pretentious.

One improvement I have noticed they made in the past year or two is that during the lunch rush hour, someone goes through the line and takes orders, which makes a BIG difference in how fast the line goes.  Now you can get your food in a reasonabile amount of time even if the line goes to the door.

While their katsu curry is the best, it's a good idea to check their weekly special, because often they will have something interesting and good to eat.  Their "spicy noodle" dish is also amazing - it's like spaghetti with meat sauce except made with ramen, curry, ground beef, and a lot of heat.

They also happen to open until 7 during the week, which is awesome for dinner if you're going to work late.
author: Jon N.

description: Went here tonight to grab a quick dinner and bring it back to the hotel. I have never had Japanese curry so I have nothing to compare it to. That being said, I ordered the chicken curry and thought it was okay. The brown rice was the best part of the meal, which is good because there was very little meat. Granted it was only nine dollars, but there were only about 4 or 5 chunks of chicken which I thought was disappointing. Not a bad meal at all, but don't know how it rated 5 stars!
author: Linda M.

description: Sadly-our Muracci's in Los altos closed down due to leasing issues-we desperately miss it!  But it is definitely worth the trip to The SF or Berkeley locations. Family run and they could not be more kind and hard working!!!  Our family loves this curry!!!!
author: Elizabeth L.

description:
I'm a regular customer here. I'm a beef curry fan. I'm so disappointed that the last two time I ordered beef curry and the beef is not tender at all!! The prices are slightly raised and beef is no longer tender. ME SAD :,(

Anyway the curry is still the best.
author: Rujii Y.

description: Got the chicken curry. I think it was ok, certainly nothing to write home about. The place was a little dingy but that's what you'd expect from a place when searching for "cheap eats" so I wasn't offended... The staff was young and upbeat but it seemed more like them just partying with each other. It was ok but I wouldn't go back.
author: Clark L.

description:
My go-to place for Japanese Curry in the FiDi (Does this still count as the FiDi?

This is an office favorite and where I take every single new employee. It's an office tradition!

We usually order Curry Pan and Chicken Katsu Curry. The Medium is pretty spicy so beware of the spice!
author: Enoch L.

description:
I love a lot of Japanese food, but I don't totally get this style.  It is kind of grungy, street food style I guess.  The curry I got was kinda thin and just not my style.  I can't really fault it totally because I don't know what the upper limits of Japanese curry are, but there just isn't something right with this place.  

It seems to work for a lot of people so take my review with a grain of salt, but them's my two cents.
author: Adam T.

description: First time eating Japanese curry. It's very different from Indian or Thai curry. There's no richness to it so it takes some getting used to. And they are kind of stingy with their pickled cabbage. Overall it's a quick lunch option for work days.
author: Yasmin M.

description:
Muracci's has been on my list of SF curry shops for some time, but given its FiDi location and my Peninsula employers, I have never had a good opportunity to try it out.

That all changed when I recently (and temporarily) became funemployed during a break between jobs. Time to try out some downtown eats!

I ordered a katsu curry on white rice, with an extra order of pickles. It was (as expected from other Yelp reviews) quite good! The breading was well within deliciously acceptable limits, albeit on the low end. Unfortunately, the pork was a tad over cooked and chewy.

Is it the best curry shop in SF? I'm going to have to say no. But it's pretty good, and I would nom again. If you're fortunate enough to work near this gem, you can kiss your waistline goodbye.
author: Cameron W.

description:
I always order the chicken katsu curry here. Big portion of rice and probably half a breast so it's a little pricey for the amount of food you'll get - about $10+. Don't come here for lunch if you've skipped dinner the previous night!

But I am a fan of the curry - and there are not many safe curry spots to choose from. I like that the chicken is breast meat too 'cause I'm not into that mystery stuff.

The place gets busy - lines out the door. Small seating area either so you gotta watch the tables like a hawk to dine in.
author: Cookie M.

description: New favorite local place just down the street. When a former co-worker used to do a lunch run he'd go there and bring back lunch but I never knew where he went. I saw him the other day and I asked him...glad I did. I stopped by Muracci's the next day for take out and it was better than I remember! So glad I re-connected with this amazing little FiDi spot.
author: Rob Z.

description:
Overall, this place is okay.

I was a little disturbed at the cashier's staring problem - okay, I'm being modest; all of the employees staring problem.  It led me to turn around to the large mirror that hangs against the wall to check if I had anything on my face - and I didn't.  Then again, what do you expect walking into a tiny fast food restaurant.  

I ordered the California roll and one of the donburi bowls.

It was okay; just okay.
author: Natasha R.

description:
On a weekday, tiny little Muracci's is often bustling with men in fine suits, women in cute business casual clothing, and engineers in their t-shirt and jeans. Needlessly to say, this is a fairly poppin' spot for the workers of FiDi. And it makes sense.

I've only gotten the Chicken Katsu with brown rice. I'm typically not much of a carb person, but okay, I'll break my semi-strict regulation as long as the rice is covered with Muracci's curry. The chicken was crisply fried - yum yum - though I have to admit, a little bit dry. I simply compensated by dousing the chicken into the curry. 

The Katsu is the most recommended thing on the menu, I definitely recommend trying it out for first timers. And do take out! There's a nice gallery place in the Bank of America building nearby if you don't know where to sit :)
author: Mandy C.

description: AMAZING spicy veggie curry ramen. Perfection. Super crowded during lunch since it's a very tiny spot, but it's worth the wait!
author: Ryann B.

description:
Since this place isn't really a sit down place I never really got a chance to come here. Usually I am with friends I want to catch up with and actually sitting down helps with that. 

This time I was with a friend who I have seen a lot so no need to catch up. We had 90 minutes before our movie at the Meteron so we decided to come here. Also it was 11ish so we knew there won't be the lunch crowd yet. 

Mild Katsu Curry for the both us - to go. We actually got the only table here and decided to eat here comfortably instead of at the park on a bench. The curry was good. The Katsu in my opinion was alright but I am not a huge pork fan.  I do like the pickled veggies. My friend did too. We wished there was more of that. We also like how they give you a lot of food. I was thoroughly full. 

There is a bathroom by the dinning table. 

It is tasty and hearty but we probably won't be going out of our way to come here to eat but if we are ever in the area this is a good solid place to eat at. 

7x7 The Big Eat 2011 - Katsu Curry
author: Sarah C.

description:
Order ahead and early - no line when I get there at 11:20am

Curry is always good - very authentic.

Always my #1 Japanese Curry place in FiDi
author: JC C.

description: I have been searching for a good japanese curry restaurant in SF for an entire year.  I finally found it.  This is definitely the best japanese curry I have had in SF.  So far I have tried the chicken katsu curry (spiciness level = medium), pork katsu curry (spiciness level = mild), and the beef curry pan.  I liked the beef curry pan and the chicken katsu curry, but my favorite was the pork katsu curry.  I will definitely be back again soon.
author: Cici A.

description:
I can't describe how much I miss having a good Muracci's for lunch, no matter what day of the week it is.

I won't describe the food as plenty of others already have, but I'll just end up telling you this: Once you taste the wonders of a chicken curry katsu, you'll be drawn to Muracci's for lunch for random reasons. Just when you thought you wanted to try that place on the corner.. nope, Muracci's it is!

The line is not that bad, and is even better if you try to avoid going there at 12pm. I recommend going there later between 1-2pm to solve that problem.
author: Thibaud R.

description: Rubbish. Although I can agree that their curry is above average, on balance their food would embarrass any honest Japanese restaurant. I had an oyako-don today that no self-respecting Japanese restauranteur would serve. And their curry-pan is hopelessly bad. Believe what you will, but this place survives on the ignorance of its clientele, and the fact that it's the only one of its type in the area. Shame on them..
author: John H.

description:
Muracci's is like a blast to the past. While sitting at the small stools by the window in this tiny store on Kearny, I felt as if I was part of a Japanese anime.

1. The setting. 

It doesn't help that Muracci is located on the brink of Chinatown. Walking along this area of downtown is literally like travelling through time, or at least entering a portal to another country. You look to one side and you see shiny high rises and bankers in suits; you look to the other and you see shady red buildings and unsanitary fat pidgeons. (Actually, I guess the fat pidgeons are all over SF.)

2. The crowd.

The crowds of people walking into this store to order curry range from all sorts of ethnicities -  Asian to American, brunettes to blondes. Now choose any anime. You will notice that although the setting is in some part of Japan, there is always one main character who isn't actually Japanese! (ex. Light from Death Note, Lelouche from Code Geass, Kawachi from Yakitate!! Japan. Unless they are all Japanese but dyed their hair...?) 

3. The protagonist.

The Katsu Curry is probably the reason most people even come over to this place. Breaded and fried to a golden crisp yet perfectly juicy and not at all too oily. Topped with deliciously thick and spicy curry sauce. (except I do wish it were more spicy). 

4. The archnemesis.

JapaCurry Truck, located only several blocks away. They must be at war, battling to see who can dominate the market share of katsu-curry craving customers. They even have the same to-go boxes! But I guess JapaCurry one-ups Muracci's with its Frequent Buyer's Card deal (get a free curry with every 12th stamp!), but Muracci's has a secret weapon -- their brown rice option at no extra charge1 (I think Japacurry is an extra $0.50). So really, you make up that free curry option with all that brown rice you're getting. 

So who do you think will win the battle?
author: Jeanette S.

description:
Placed an order for pick up. They have me the wrong order. Refused to fix the problem or give me refund when I discovered it at home.
When I called them to get it fixed they were very rude.
author: Tom B.

description:
A voice of dissent here....after years of wanting to try this place, I did so at lunch today. Unfortunately, this was one of the more disappointing meals! 

I came at lunch (12:20) on a Thurs afternoon. There was only one person ahead of me. A few more people showed up after, and a lady took their orders while they were in line (I ordered at the register). 

Ordered a katsu curry (hot). Expectations were high, but what I got was a lukewarm (but generous) helping of brown rice (can choose between white or brown) topped with a lukewarm helping of sliced katsu (thought things out of the deep fryer should be pretty warm???) along with a small side of pickled cabbage (the best part of the dish). The hot curry was not spicy at all, the fried katsu quickly withered into a soggy blob under the curry sauce, and the brown rice tasted like it had been sitting around for a while. 

Service was very friendly, but the food was lackluster. My friend ordered the teriyaki chicken, and it was one of the most flavorless dishes I've ever tried. The "teriyaki sauce" tasted like soy sauce poured over the rice - not even over the chicken, which barely had any sauce or flavor. 

I liked the katsu at Kare-ken better....maybe it depends on the time you go? Lunch was definitely a failure. Guess I should have tried this place a couple of years ago.
author: Carolyn F.

description:
It's a travesty that I hadn't been to Muracci's sooner, seeing as my hands-down favorite food on Earth is Japanese curry. I finally decided to take myself on a date here today for lunch and I did not regret it. Definitely not a place I'd go if I was in a rush, as there seems to be a constant line out the door. However, keep in mind that if you get the beef or chicken curry you'll get it with almost no wait!

I myself went with the chicken katsu curry with brown rice. I liked that they put the curry in a separate container so that the katsu was still crispy by the time I found the perfect spot in the park to enjoy my meal. The curry itself was also delish, though the medium was a little spicier than the mediums I'm typically used to... all good though. I need to up my spicy tolerance anyway! It also came with a small but delightful bit of pickles. 

The place itself is super cramped and tiny, so don't bother trying to eat in, as you'll probably be squashed by the huge line that's always there at lunchtime. A cute older Japanese man comes by taking your orders and they really seem to have their system down because I think I waited less than 5 minutes at the height of lunchtime rush hour. 

Definitely feel a little heavy in the tummy after this rich (yet satisfying) meal, but next time a curry craving hits me I'm glad I know where to go!
author: Christina P.

description:
This is one of the best kept secrets in San Francisco! Everything is amazing here, especially the curry Katsu. I always ask for ramen instead of rice, which isn't on the menu, but they let me do it everytime. I give them points for always being so flexible and kind.

Seriously the curry is some of the best I've ever had. It has so much depth of flavor with the perfect amount of spiciness. I love all the little pickled vegetables that also come with many of the dishes. They just do such a great job. Its one of my favorite places in the entire city.
author: Dexter H.

description: Visited here on my last trip to San Fran.  Long line but worth the wait. The katsu curry was perfectly cooked and full of flavor. I got the spicy and it was just right.  Only negative was the limited seating, but that is a minor point.
author: Mike W.

description:
There was a line when I came in, but the wait isn't actually too bad for a Friday lunch. You'll be hard pressed to find seating in this tiny place though! It's quite alright though, since I think most people order to go anyways. 

I ordered a mild chicken curry with brown rice and it came out super speedy! It was quite filling. My friend ordered a hot chicken katsu curry with white rice, and it took a little bit longer to come out. I'm assuming it's because their chicken is freshly fried. He also tried a curry pan, and it was so-so. 

If I ever happen to be in the neighborhood again, I'll probably try the udon or ramen curry!
author: Shirley V.

description:
I've been dying to try Muracci's and I finally am working in SoMa/FiDi! 
I called ahead and ordered the chicken katsu medium curry and a krokke to pick up. 
I liked that I skipped the line and my food was ready to go when I got there. 

It took me about 10 minutes to walk, finally sit down and eat my food, so granted it was a little cold. 

The katsu was OK, but I really enjoyed the curry. It was flavorful and had the right amount of spice. I could definitely just eat the curry and rice! I want to try the chicken katsu when its fresh, maybe it will change my mind about it. The krokke (croquette) was pretty good and I liked the amount of breading it had. I would order one again! 

Overall, the food was pretty good! I want to go back and try the curry bread and maybe the katsu fresh.
author: Leah F.

description:
I came here for lunch once, during a visit to the Bay two winters ago, before I'd moved to the city. Unfortunately, I haven't had occasion to go back since my move, much of which is due to the fact that Muracci's is up two steps, and thus, not wheelchair accessible.

That said, I came with a friend last time, who was kind enough to go wait in line and order curry to-go. Yes, even at 230pm, the place was still crowded, the lines were still long, and it still took nearly half an hour to get our food. From what I've heard though, you can call in your order ahead of time, which, perhaps, is sage advice.

Having ordered their spicy chicken katsu curry, my conclusion was that it was enjoyable, but not amazingly so. While their curry is pretty darn tasty, and their chicken katsu is good, I've experienced better-fried katsu before (unfortunately, I'm not aware of an English equivalent for the Chinese adjective I'm thinking of here). 

Overall though, pretty solid Japanese curry that clocks in at 3.5 stars for me. If you're nearby, and won't be hindered by the steps, be sure to drop by - and call in your order before you do!
author: Johnny W.

description:
I always find myself wanting "more-acci" after eating here, and not because the portions are too small.  The curry sauce is the main draw - it is fantastic.  Ordering is simple: you pick a rice (white or brown), a spiciness level, and a meat.  There's also a bunch of extra options like hard boiled egg that you can add on for a little bit extra.  A guy goes up and down the lunch line taking orders to speed things up, but unfortunately you should still expect a medium to long wait during lunch.  

As always, I'm going to give a shout out to my vegetarian friends and say that the vegetable curry is just fine.  In fact, it's what I usually get when I go there.  If you're really strict about things, you can request vegetarian curry sauce and go full veggie.  

Arbitrary power rankings:

Lunch wait: 3/10
author: Allen C.

description:
Went to Muracci last night, because Yelpers seem to love this place. 

Yes I know it's small before I made the trip.
Yes I know it's sticky everywhere before I made the trip.

But come'on, I am visiting Muracci to eat the food, not to review its decor and perform a Health Department inspection. Surely the majority of the Yelpers here can't be wrong!!

Sigh...  I was wrong.

Perhaps I got spoiled with all the wonderful Japanese curry joints in Southern California... But Muracci really failed to impress me. The curry sauce was really watery, and the flavors were mediocre at best. The curry filled bread that everyone craved? Come'on, I have had better ones from Mitsuwa's frozen food isle.

Overall, it is NOT a terrible place, but it definitely does not deserve all of the amazing reviews I read here. I will give it 3 stars because 2 seems to be just mean.
author: James W.

description: That's my first day in San Francisco and the public transportation almost tortured me in a whole day, I'm so depressed by the fees and complication. But this curry restaurant warms me and I feel I'm getting love with it!
author: Van H.

description:
Pros: 
- Reasonably Priced
- Damn Good Cookin'
- Friendly, though busy, staff.

Cons: 
- extremely limited seating.  The stools they have a rather unsteady.  I recommend getting carry out.
- Hot curry has a kick but isn't that hot

I should note that I'm Cajun, so my definition of hot is probably a bit hotter than most.  It definitely has a good kick.  Some of y'all may find yourselves beggin' for mercy.  

That said, the food is DAMN GOOD.  If you're worried about da heat, get the baby spices (mild and med).
author: Rick B.

description: The best katsu chicken curry I have ever had! The katsu chicken is everything you can dream of - crunchy on the outside (but not overly hard) and juicy soft chicken inside - it was so good. The taste of the curry was also just right. The price is reasonable. I love it!
author: Snowdrops C.

description: friggin delicious! the line kind of sucks so get there early but curry that packs a punch of flavor and a lot of food for 10$ plates. not really a place to sit and eat, but if you want a lot of delicious eats for a good price downtown, go here.
author: Jonathan Q.

description:
I love that they have an order ahead capability. Makes getting food so much easier during the lunch rush!

I ordered their mild beef curry over white rice to go. The beef was pretty tender -- I didn't have to chew forever in order to eat it. And the curry was pretty flavorful! They give you a decent amount for what you pay. I wish they had given me a bit more rice though. Other than the meat and curry sauce though, there's really nothing else to it. I wish I had thought to add vegetables or something to my meal to give it more dimension.

Overall, a good lunch spot when you're hankering for a tasty lunch. The walk (for me, from the Embarcadero Centers) is a little far, but it's not too bad if you order ahead and just go to pick it up.

I really want to try their oyako don and katsu don next! Pictures make it look very good!
author: Anna W.

description:
[2.5] Review purely for the curry noodle soup. Ordered medium spice  

Not what I was craving. I was craving creamy spicy curry. So far they delivered the spice but the curry didn't feel creamy enough for me. I got the udon noodles with beef and vegetables. The beef was tough and chewy and not how I expected the beef in a noodle based soup should taste and feel. Beef should be soft and tender.  The curry soup base felt too watery and not the creamy base the restaurant had boasted.

It's a very small establishment and can get very crowded as the lunch hour passes on. Service seemed kind of messy. I noticed a few customers complaining about numbers being skipped. Definitely a hole in the wall. Come early if you want seating. But it did look like they knew how to get people in and out quickly if needed.

Next time I'll stick with what the restaurant is known for. The katsu.
author: Alice G.

description:
Japanese Curry ftw! This little place is always extremely busy. That definitely means something. 

1. They're only open on weekdays for lunch
and 
2. They serve pretty good curry. 

Unfortunately for out of towners, this place wil pretty inconvenient to get to but if you happen to be town for business or decide to play sick for a day come eat japanese curry in the city. =P
author: Annie Z.

description: Used to like this place until they increased prices AND cut the portions down on the amount of food they give you. I'd rather go to the Japa Curry food truck.
author: Andre O.

description: This place is legit. Ordered the chicken curry with brown rice and it was downed within seconds lol. The curry reminds me of Indian and to make this meal perfect I would add a garlic naan!
author: Mark M.

description:
VEGETARIANS BEWARE.  THIS PLACE IS NOT VEGETARIAN...AT ALL.

Despite selling "VEGETARIAN" curry, the curry they use for just about everything (including the veg. & tofu curry, etc.) uses a variety of meat in its stock.

Extremely disappointing but just goes to show that even today, in a place like San Francisco, some people just don't get it...
author: Sagar G.

description:
This is a review for take out Muracci's.

I got a potato croquette and an Ebi Fry meal to- go. The potato croquette was decently portioned with pieces of corn and peas, it was balanced in sweetness and was savory at the same time with a good crust around it. The Ebi Fry consisted of a salad with a sesame dressing, miso soup, brocolli potato salad, rice and 3 large pieces of ebi fry. 

I particularly liked the portions of every thing, but found the Ebi Fry containing too much batter. Other than that and the potato salad, I found the meal enjoyable. The portions here are also generous, so if you're looking for a big meal this is a good place!

The service was friendly and relatively quick.
author: Janet N.

description:
I have a redneck friend Bubba in Texas who has a phobia of anything not meat and potatoes.  Bonus points for anything fried though.  I got a call from Bubba shortly after I had stumbled into Muracci's and pointed to the Katsu Curry photo as my form of ordering.  

"Hey, how's San Fran?"
"Just checking out Chinatown right now."
"Tourists and weird food?"
"Pretty much.  I'm at this Japanese place.  Just ordered, uh, hang on...katsu curry."
"Cat what???"
"Kat-SOOO curry, f'ing racist."
"Curry?  Isn't that Indian?"
"Yeah, I don't know.  I gotta go."

My order came out a short time later.  At first glance, it looked pretty plain.  I was already thinking about how I would explain it to my semi-racist friend back in the Lone Star State.  Chicken fried pork with Japanese-Indian brown gravy?  

Actually, that's not an entirely misleading description.  But the light and crispy breading gave way to a deliciously tasty bite of pork.  And the brown gravy, errr, curry, was awesomely flavorful, thick, and spicy.  I felt I needed something else to sop up all the curry after the pork was gone, like you do with pita and hummus.  Alas, I had to let some curry go to waste.  

The katsu curry was a seemingly simple combination perhaps, but this was very good . . . and at a good price too. Stop by late afternoon or call ahead if you don't want to deal with the lines.  If you can't do that, it's still worth the wait.  Maybe I'll even convince Bubba to try it sometime.  It is meat.  It is fried.  I just shudder at the thought of him trying to order it.
author: Corey C.

description: You can't go wrong with comfort food :3 rarely anyway. Japanese curry always warm my heart and soul and makes me melt with happiness. I got the chicken katsu curry with traditional white rice. I shared it with another person because portion was quite big. But I really should have gotten my own... Hehe
author: Sabrina D.

description: Decent curry, though I didn't think it was anything spectacular. Only thing special was that they had curry pan, which many other Japanese curries don't always carry.
author: Amy W.

description: One of my favorite places in the south bay, but now I get to try to SF version.  I'm so used to the sit down restaurant atmosphere of the Los Altos location that I was totally thrown off here.  But hey, the food is still legit.
author: Tiffany C.

description:
I went here once with a friend a few months back, and enjoyed the Curry. I would have given it 3 stars. I realize this place gets rave reviews, and has a line out the door. However, it's not "that good" as there are many comparable lunchtime venues nearby.

I'm knocking them down to 1 star this time because they forgot part of my order today. I waited in line and ordered Chicken Curry and a California Roll. I was feeling extra hungry. I got back to my office to discover they had not put my California Roll in the bag. I checked the receipt, and sure enough I paid for it. I simply don't have time to call them back or walk back to the restaurant during the work day. On top of that, the amount of chicken with my meal was skimpy at best. It was a half-breast of chicken at the most.

Next time I'll skip the line and take my $13.38 elsewhere. There's too many options downtown to settle for this experience. Hard to believe so many people rave about this place.
author: Jason W.

description:
Muracci's has become a favorite lunch stop whenever I'm in the downtown area on a late weekday afternoon.  Around 3 PM on most days the lunch crowd is gone, and I can actually sit inside the little restaurant and enjoy Muracci's amazing curry dishes.  On some days some of the selections might be sold out, but that hasn't bothered me since I'm willing to try something new with each visit.

I love the taste and consistency of Muracci's curry sauce.  The portion is excellent as there is plenty of sauce to mix into the rice.  One of my favorite yelpers once wrote about his desire to lick the plate clean at Muracci's.  If I were not in a public restaurant I too would lick my plate clean each time.  The entire staff at Muracci's is nice and friendly where I'm always greeted by a smile and thanked before departing.

Muracci's curry sauce is a brown colored sauce with tiny specks of chili visible to the eye.  It has a subtle sweetness to it.  I don't take very spicy foods too well and the one time I ordered my curry "hot" from Muracci's I didn't look too good when I left the restaurant with my eyes watering and my nose running.  I order my curry "medium" all the time now.  It's the perfect degree of spicyness for me because while the sauce still creates a sensation on my tongue, it's a more gentle sensation that will warm my entire mouth and stop just before it reaches my nose.  No runny nose.  No teary eyes.

My usual order consists of brown rice.  I've had the curry with ramen also, and that was outstanding.  I'm eager to try it with the udon noodles hopefully on my next visit.  The rice dishes come with crunchy pickled cabbage and sweet pickles.  I love combining everything into the rice and then smothering everything with the sauce.  Here are some of the selections I've tried so far:

Chicken Curry (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/7qK2Gwu0afQMtYFSJvvCqQ?select=chh-Ec2DVbLJhhGJnhK1vA) - Very good with big tender pieces of skinless, boneless dark meat chicken.

Chicken Katsu Curry (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/7qK2Gwu0afQMtYFSJvvCqQ?select=Gu66z3HwgDZbp8Vabe0B3Q) - Excellent with a big piece of chicken breast breaded and deep fried.  The chicken was juicy and the breading was nice and crunchy without being oily.

Salmon Curry (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/7qK2Gwu0afQMtYFSJvvCqQ?select=CJ4l4K_QSvNQr5j3oQX4kg) - Excellent as the salmon was grilled to perfection moist and flaky.  The salmon skin had very nice crispy edges and they even added an extra piece of salmon into the sauce.

Vegetarian Curry (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/7qK2Gwu0afQMtYFSJvvCqQ?select=5x7bGOIexkzXs8CVIrpFhA) - I ordered this one "hot" and still loved the taste the most even though the curry drove my senses crazy.  The fried tofu really absorbed the flavor of the curry sauce.  The vegetables in this selection are firm (but not hard) carrots and firm (but not crunchy) broccoli.  There are yellow and red bell peppers in there too.  The tofu was of a medium firmness.

Chicken and Vegetable Curry over Ramen (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/7qK2Gwu0afQMtYFSJvvCqQ?select=Qew_2CR0JUPtk8OQ7Kqd5w) - You have the option between udon and ramen noodles.  This was outstanding as the curry sauce takes the place of the broth.  Lots of dark meat chicken with firm broccoli and carrots.  Lots of scallion and green onion too.  As close to licking a bowl clean without actually doing so as I'll ever go in public.

I've also had the Beef Curry with nice tender chunks of beef and the Ebi Fry Curry with breaded and deep fried shrimp (no photos).  Both were delicious as well.

It seems you can't go wrong with anything on their menu.  Muracci's is outstanding!
author: Wilhelm Y.

description:
Solid Japanese curry. The sauce is slightly sweet, perfectly smooth, and very well balanced. The spicy level has decent but not overwhelming kick. 

This place is one or two dollars more expensive than your joints in suburbia but that's the Financial District markup for you. 

If you go during the lunch rush, expect a long wait (15 min if not more if you want the Katsu!), so make a mobile meeting out of it!
author: Lan T.

description: Tonkatsu was overfried, somewhat juicy. Rice was whatever and curry was pretty good. I'm really disappointed since this place had great reviews. Volcano on Geary is much better, especially for the price.
author: Ruobin W.

description:
Muracci's is just A-OK.

I ordered the chicken katsu curry. I think the curry lacks taste compare to JapaCurry's, but the portion is bigger. My chicken was kind-of dry. I think they re-fry the chicken to heat it up and it was over done.
author: Terry C.

description:
YUMMmmkfmalkejmxfaenfkljahefa!

A hole in the wall joint, walking distance from my work in the Financial District.  I'll even come here solo when I'm craving kastu curry! I've tried the pork & chicken katsu, but I cant decide which one I like more, they are both SO good. I love the fact that they offer brown rice as an option.  Haven't tried their ramens yet, so I will definitely be coming back on a cold blistery day to try em. 

They give youa good portion of food. The old me was able to finish the plate in one sitting if i was REALLY hungry, but now a days, half will leave me full and satisfied & I'll even have left over for dinner ;)

Plates are about $9-10 including tax, but that's a normal lunch DTSF. Also, they are only open during lunch hours.
author: Olga F.

description:
Ask and you shall receive! 

Extra spicy = blowing your nose YUMMY

Beef & veggie UDON + extra spicy = heaven (if you like things hawt)

Perfect for cold, rainy days like today :)

WARNING: REALLY FREAKING SPICY
author: Kat C.

description: Got the pork katsu curry -- really good portion of rice and homemade curry (like it probably did not come from a box mix that they got from the Asian grocery), along with a pretty big, perfectly crunchy but tender pork cutlet.  It's around 10 bucks for the dish but any add-ons seem to be pricey given the place isn't really a sit-down restaurant with service -- it's cramped and there's not much seating for eating in.  But for the area in SF I'm not all that surprised about the space or price.
author: Anita T.

description:
It's been a year since Muracci's first opened, and they're still one of my favorites for a weekday lunch (or early dinner - since they normally close at 6pm, & 5pm on Fridays). I usually order the katsu curry or the grilled salmon with either white or brown (sometimes they ran out) rice, unless the daily special looks yummy.

It's possible to avoid a long line by coming in a little after the lunch hour. You will still have to wait (but not as long as those in the lunch crowd) because all the grilling and frying is made to order, only the curry sauce has been made in advance.

In case u still have a copy of their original menu, please note that the rib eye steak teriyaki and the green tea ice cream are no longer in their regular menu. They also discontinued the shredded cheese topping. Now occasionally, they offer the rib eye as a lunch special. The tasty (and fatty) meat is cooked medium rare, it's served with Japanese shishito peppers, which I love.
http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/7qK2Gwu0afQMtYFSJvvCqQ?select=nzh2YMp4UxYSUyt5T-bSZQ

Their potato croquette ($1.95) is good too.
http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/7qK2Gwu0afQMtYFSJvvCqQ?select=CuYmPqbly6JTyQW6vH0acQ

It's a vegetarian curry flavor inside.
http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/7qK2Gwu0afQMtYFSJvvCqQ?select=1m4zffLmb6tJq99eVc6ztA
author: Luis C.

description:
It's homestyle Japanese food served out of a hole in the wall downtown. Incredible how many people they fit behind the counter in this tiny shop! The line can go out the door but if you choose to get in it, it does move pretty fast. 

One of the few Japanese places I've seen where the entire staff actually seems to be Japanese (or at least Asian). That should speak for itself!

Very popular are the Katsu curries (a coworker of mine calls this place the japa curry truck that doesn't move) and I recently tried the oyako don... Muraccis inari and other sushi rolls are nothing too special but they are very cheap.
author: Stephanie T.

description:
Great taste, great value, great find!

It was a horrid Tuesday evening. It was pouring rain and I had to get from the office to Muracci's before it closed at 6PM.     I made the mistake of leaving too late the night before so I made sure to make it there on time.

I ordered the pork Katsu with extra spicy sauce. Eagerly waiting, I interviewed a local who was also waiting for her order. She said this was the best Japanese curry in town. The pork is thinly sliced and tender. It's fried to a light crisp and served with this awesome tasting sauce.

She wasn't kidding!

The meal was really good! It was simple and the pork wasn't over seasoned. The best part for me was pouring the sauce over the pork and the rice. Wow! What a gem of a place with meals served at a great price point. The Katsu, for example, cost $10.25 including tax. It was delightfully filling.

The place is really small and the people are very friendly. What a great find!
author: Roehl A.

description: Although this restaurant is not large, but the food is very delicious.I eat curry chicken Riga the pepper, eating the body is very warm.
author: Gavin L.

description:
Excellent katsu curry.  4.5 stars.

The chicken katsu is perfectly breaded and crispy all the while keeping the meat very moist.  In my opinion the chicken katsu here is second to none!  I do prefer the curry from JapaCurry over Muracci's however, just preference, but it's still very good.  The side of pickled veggies that come along with the katsu curry are also very vinegary good.  Best for take out as the only seating is counter seating save for one small table for two.
author: Erich D.

description:
Real japanese homemade curry.
Cheap, fast and oh so delicious. One of my favorite restaurant in town.
author: Momo G.

description: The best Japanese curry place in San Francisco. Period. Just come in 45 minutes before they close so you don't have to wait in line. It's a great dinner food if you are done working for the day and want to crave for the perfect Japanese curry.
author: Silin N.

description:
This is my second time trying to write this review, so hopefully this one will stick.

My partner was craving Donburi.  We saw that this place had it and checked the Yelp reviews on it.  We saw a lot of mixed reviews, but decided to try it anyways.  Big mistake.

We looked at their dinner menu and ordered a couple of the Curry Pan's, Tonkatsu Donburi, Miso Soup and Chicken Katsu Curry for delivery.  They said they don't have any Curry Pan and that they "NEVER" have it for dinner because it sells out after lunch.  I thought to myself, "Then why still have it on your dinner menu?" So, we ordered 2 orders of the Korroke instead.

Not only did the order take a long time to get delivered, but when it arrived the driver called me to come down to get my food because he was double-parked.  For real?  Ok, I was really hungry... so whatever.  When I got the food and unpacked it, the sauce for Korroke was not sealed completely, so it spilled inside the container and leaked into the bag as well.  It was all over the place.  Not to mention the food was cold and not very good.

Moral of the story is, if there are mixed reviews, that's probably a sign right there that the place is more bad than good.  I'm definitely "NEVER" going to order from here again that's for sure.
author: Fernando R.

description:
Tons of reviews already, so I'll just add that you should order online or via phone so that you don't have to stand in line!

And, if you get non-breaded meats, they'll be IN the curry - it's not just a box of rice :)
author: Alex T.

description:
One time my car got towed because I want their curry so bad .

Been here 50+ times  ever since they open. 
Their curry sauce unlike the others , other like japa curry , kare ken they just using curry ru (sauce mix) which you can buy at any Asian supermarket.
author: Sushi K.

description:
I have been seriously OBSESSED with chicken katsu curry ever since I discovered JapaCurry's version about four weeks ago.  Since then, I crave it...weekly, and maybe even daily.

Since it was a beautiful Monday afternoon, I decided to venture outside of my little half a block radius and head to Muracci's for lunch.  I decided that I was going to do a live assessment and comparison of Muracci's chicken katsu curry with Japacurry's plate.

On to the food! The pros/cons of my experience:

PROS:
-This place has a wonderful variety of options for people who are interested in curry, and those who aren't.  Not only were there chicken and pork katsu options, but there was also shrimp.
-Brown rice is an option without needing to charge you extra for it.
-Everything is made to order
-Two types of pickled cabbage is provided with your lunch
-Curry sauce has a lot of flavor, and there's good breading on the chicken katsu that I had

CONS:
-So, for starter's, Muracci's little shop is TINY.  On a nice warm day, the tiny shop turns into a sweltering shoe box, cramped with people who are waiting for their food and people picking up their orders via phone order. 
-The ordering system here is totally disorganized.  There are people who called in orders, and people like myself who showed up at the door.  Since there's only one register, it's a huge cluster of people cutting in line to pick up their phone order.  It'd be helpful if they had a separate area of people who were phone orders, but since this place is so small, it's probably not possible.
-Muracci's portions are deceivingly small.  They spread out a layer of rice on the bottom of a regular sized take out box to make it seem like you're getting a lot for your money.  The truth is, it's really not that much.  Relative to what you get at Japacurry, it's maybe even a little less.
-The chicken katsu I had was slightly overcooked and dry.  It looked like someone had left it in the pan for too long since the breading on one side was crispier/drier than the other.
-The curry sauce I had was flavorful, but was sort of thin and more like soupy in consistency.  
-Lunch was $10.25, compared to Japacurry where with brown rice, your total is $9.00 and you get more food.

So, based on my experience, Muracci's is overrated.  Perhaps I'm biased because I "found" curry through Japacurry and hold them on a pedestal for converting a non-believer like myself into an avid fan.  However, from my experience, I just couldn't get around the letdown feeling I had after starting my meal.  If you need to find me, I'll be standing in line at Japacurry for my curry fix from now on.
author: Lisa I.

description:
I kind of hyped this place up for myself, but the food here still wasn't too far from my expectations; 

I got the medium spicy katsu curry with brown rice amidst yelp suggestions that spicy/extra spicy overpowers the flavor of curry -- probably a wise choice, but next time I'd probably go with white rice instead.

One thing I'd probably change about Muracci's: the curry here would be a lot better if they also served the yellow (saffron) rice that most "traditional" Japanese curry places serve up. 

Other than that, I guess I will be ordering "Curry Beef/Chicken" from Chinese restaurants no more.
author: Scott S.

description:
I don't think I ever tried Japanese curry before going to Muracci's for lunch with coworkers. Being a rather conservative person when it comes to food I started out with the Beef Curry and mild spicy curry. It was life altering-ly delicious and I've keep nudging people at work to go back often.

I've gone on to try the Katsu Curry and Vegetable Curry, both with the hot spicy curry. They are consistently good and always a treat. Consider getting one of the Daifuku Mochi too. I've tried the red and white bean cakes and am looking forward to finally getting the green one (gotta try them all!).
author: Chapman S.

description: Not gonna lie - the curry here is pretty delicious. It's definitely not something I would want to scarf down every day, but when I'm craving some really amazing chicken curry, I go here for lunch. Great stuff.
author: James H.

description:
I hate when I have a craving for Japanese food during the work week, because there are so few and far good Japanese restaurants in the FiDi. Ever since I've discovered Muracci's I've been saved. I have only tried the chicken katsu curry, so I can't speak to the rest of the menu. It's as if someone decided to fly it from Japan especially made for me. 

It is on the pricey side at ~$10, but its well worth it when you're trying to satisfy your craving. They also make your curry when you order, so it's piping hot and fresh. The lines can be long during lunch hour, so go before 12 or after 1 unless you like waiting 45 minutes for your food. Highly recommend!
author: Kim C.

description:
My colleagues raved about this place when I worked in the FiDi.  We all went as a group once and took the food back to our office.  

I would have to say that it was just okay.  Nothing memorable and I was never determined to go back although I worked around there for 5 years.
author: Kay R.

description: Awesome Japanese place! Amazing Curry Katsu, maybe the best! Tight space, so may be a line.
author: Peter K.

description: I don't like here, food is fine, but the shopkeeper is not honest. I ask one extra rice , he ask me to pay price as the steamed rice. That's not about $1.00, that's the attitude for business.
author: Dou C.

description:
I was sooo disappointed when they said they sold our pork Katsu ( Tonkatsu) at 11:05am. Really? How can you sell all your pork in 5 mins?  Okay. I tried to stay calm and ordered chicken ( overcooked) Katsu. Second huge disappointment knocked me down. Please don't deceive Americans! 
Have you ever tried coco Ichihara curry in Japan?  http://www.ichibanya.co.jp/english/index.html.  Their curry represents Japanese curry. Honestly. Muracci's curry is not Japanese curry, their curry is more Indian curry side and I  firmly believe that all Japanese agree with me. They misled many people here saying their curry is Japanese curry. No No No ! If you have a Japanese friend, please bring him/her here.  You will know I'm right. Oh maybe you can go to curry house in Cupertino. Their curry is not the best but you can see how different between Muracci's curry and curry of curry house. Curry house IS Japanese curry. We don't use Indian spices on Japanese curry! We don't like strong spice, you know.  I'm sorry to say but if you say Muracci's curry is the best, Japanese think you don't know Japanese food at all. Their curry wouldn't sell well in Japan especially Osaka as their curry is not Japanese one. Honest is the best policy to me!  I want to eat the real Japanese curry! If you want to enjoy Indian curry, plz go to Amber at Santana Row or Mountain View! ( I personally love Mountain View one) if you want to know what real Japanese curry is like please go to curry house.
author: Maki N.

description:
Friday at lunch: came here to try the famous Katsu curry medium spicy on white rice. I barely stepped into this tiny joint when the nice server took my order and sent me on my way to pay. There's very little room to maneuver in this place and it gets hot up in there! Anyway, we sat on the stools on the street side to wait for our food. I witnessed deep fried chicken coming out of the fryer and then immediately sliced to be placed into to-go boxes. The katsu is very fresh. 

After waiting 5 minutes or so, my friend and I got our food and took it elsewhere to eat. Just pour all of the curry onto the katsu, would ja? You will not be disappointed. The rice and the meat get all soaked up by the curry that you won't notice that the katsu wasn't extremely crispy to begin with. And medium spicy was perfect. That is some solid good food, my friends. Definitely worth trying if you're in the Financial District on a weekday.
author: Diana C.

description:
Delicious Japanese cuisine.   I enjoyed the chicken curry with white rice.  I didn't find it particularly spicy, but the chicken and rice were both cooked perfectly, the curry was really savory, and the portion sizes were perfect.  Waiting in the cramped dining area was actually fun and a nice change of pace.

If you're really looking to cut out the wait problem just order ahead!
author: Bill H.

description:
This hole-in-the-wall food hub hides delicious curry in a humble setting.

Each curry dish is served with your choice of seasoning: mild, medium or hot, white or brown rice, a tiny salad and special house pickles.  OMG, the piiiiicccckkkless are amaze.  Depending on which curry you get it could be grilled or fried to perfection.

They take orders quickly and the wait isn't that long.  Well, it could take up to 10 minutes depending on how far down the menu you go, but normally the wait isn't for than 5.

For a Japanese curry first-timer I would suggest the hot chicken curry with white rice, but my favorites are the katsu curry and the ebi-fry curry, both seasoned hot, with brown rice.

I only wish there were more seats.

Still, it's very fast and very delicious...
author: Randy M.

description:
Ok I have been coming here for more than 3 years now. It's my favorite thing on a cold day. For some reason it's just hearty enough to make me feel warm and comfortable again. Muraccis is much better than the other japanese curries options and a lot of their dishes are made to order.  So you don't end up with re-heated food like you would from the food trucks. Tonkatsu is really good, breading is just right and the curry is flavorful but not overpowering. I am a sucker for the curry-pan things at the front of the line. They are tasty and perfect for a short snack while you wait for your lunch. 

this place is popular (and small) and while I know this, I never learn so I show up and there is always a line out the door. You can call your order in ahead if you are smart ... I'm not smart, but I enjoy the rush I guess. Anyways this place is the go to lunch spot when you are sick, feeling in need of comfort food or just want to warm up a bit.
author: Greg G.

description:
Maybe I'm missing something, but Muracci's just didn't do it for me in the way I thought it would.  It wasn't bad, just not up to the hype some Muracci's evangelists  created.

I headed out for lunch to this hole in the wall curry joint for lunch and I was immediately struck by the line that was well out the door.  Luckily the line moved relatively quickly and I got my tonkatsu in a reasonable amount of time.

Once I dug into my lunch I found it to be decidedly okay.  The breading on the pork was perfectly crispy and made for a great texture, but I was let down by the curry and rice. The curry was plenty flavorful, it just wasn't particularly memorable in any way.  The rice was underdone and left me wanting a lot more.

Overall my experience at Muracci's was decidedly okay.  The price, line, and average food make it the type of place I won't shy away from visiting in the future, but don't expect me to become a regular here for lunch.
author: Jonathan M.

description:
CURRY CURRY CURRY!!!!
I eaten a lot of curry in my day, and this one has to be one of the best by far. Unlike most japanese curry that i've had, here you can pick your level of spiciness! SPICY CURRY??!? UMM..HELL YAHHH!!! 

picked veggies & salad (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/7qK2Gwu0afQMtYFSJvvCqQ?select=RxJwpOxxtq9BAY0lLDdrFA)
katsu curry (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/7qK2Gwu0afQMtYFSJvvCqQ?select=2gHNWSmj8uT8UGlE907Fig)
spinach & eggplant doria (only @ los gatos location) (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/7qK2Gwu0afQMtYFSJvvCqQ?select=epNmVGVuBYAyJbuJv3v8Eg)
beef curry pan (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/7qK2Gwu0afQMtYFSJvvCqQ?select=1QLnKrox-hNJM33EZD8-TQ)

My favorite thing about Murracci's is that I was there the other day and saw that 100% of their sales for the entire day were going towards Japan Relief efforts. WAY TO GO MURACCI'S!!!
http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/7qK2Gwu0afQMtYFSJvvCqQ?select=4gGBHqhQxs1T8y1Tdha3cA

TIP: be sure to check out their daily specials!! and if you want beef or chicken curry, there's no wait for it since they have those already set to go!
author: Kristen C.

description:
This place was definitely a let down.

I discovered this place through yelp, hoping to find a new lunch spot around the financial district. Honestly, with all the great reviews that people are writing about this place, you'd think it would AT LEAST get a 3 star review right?

NAAAAAAAAA. 2 stars for me.

I came here around 11:30ish and the line was already almost to the door. Seems to be pretty popular eh? It's barely lunch time and it's already close to the door.
Anyways, the Caucasian girl that works there came and spoke to me with a Japanese accent. Okay.....
