You basically tell the girl what you want and she'll hand you a piece of paper to give to the cashier in the front. I ordered the Curry Katsu.

Then the wait begins....

About 20-25 minutes later, I get my food. By this time, the line is already out the door. 
Seeing the line, it definitely built hype for me for the food and thought I was definitely in for a treat. I walked back to work as quick as I can so that I can start GRUBBING.

As soon as I opened the box, I was already disappointed. For about $10, I get 1 thin chicken breast, about a scoop of rice, and some veggies.

What?? Did they recently raise the market price of chicken or something? I paid $10 for something I could've got for $5 at any Hawaiian BBQ spot.

Their curry wasn't even all that great! I got more curry than chicken and rice combined. Finished my food and was still hungry. 

For the time and money spent, this place is definitely not worth it. I would much rather go to a Hawaiian BBQ spot (L&L across the street) for Curry Katsu for ALOT cheaper and wait half the time.

Will probably not be back unless they lower the market price of chicken. You can call me fat but spending $10 and not even being remotely close to full is not where I want to be.
author: Johnny G.

description: Wow!  What a delicious meal!  Had a Chicken Katsu with the Hot Curry.  Man oh man!  The rice was great, the Katsu was fried perfectly and the curry was very tasty!  The line was out the door, but moved fairly quickly.  Yay!  I just found myself a new lunch spot!
author: Raj G.

description: The food is really good, fast and consistent! It's amazing how organized and fast they are set up to serve the hordes of lunch office starved customers.
author: Sandra M.

description: Let me first start off by saying the food is good but while I was waiting for my food I saw a roach on the wall. Where there's smoke there's fire I won't be going back to the spot again.
author: johnny W.

description: Didn't like that chicken piece was too small and they don't sell extra pieces of their katsu.
author: Omid A.

description:
They serve the absolute best Katsu Curry I've had in the mainland US!  My authentic-Japanese loving taste buds were delighted with the flavor and spiciness in every bite.  I've lived and worked across the Pacific and Asia and all I have to say is:   Good Japanese food how I've missed you!

The owner is a pretty cool guy too.  He was having his lunch and overheard me joking around with the folks behind the counter.  It turns out he's from Osaka and knew the area around my former company very well (near New Hankyu).  Rather than finish his meal, he chatted with me for a while.

It was after 3 and they were out of the two items my girlfriend and I wanted (shrimp tempura and gyu-don).  I "settled" on the katsu curry and was not disappointed.  I was rewarded with a crispy piece of ton katsu with yummy curry drizzled over it.  Our other dish was crispy, hot karaage.  The owner felt bad they were out of certain items and threw in some steak in the curry and tossed a croquette in the bag as well.

Great food! Great service! Definitely going back next time I'm in the Bay Area!
author: Rich T.

description:
I love this Japanese curry. Food is consistent, simple and delicious. Absolutely love their special but they never have them in stock passed 12:30. Good value. Brown rice options is great!
Authentic and true San Francisco find.
author: Xela H.

description:
I really wanted to love Muracci's.  Really.  It sounded so great!  Homemade curry that simmers for 2 days.  Menu, price, location -- all the makings of a winner.

I thought Muracci was just okay.

I had the Chicken Katsu with medium curry for $9.  You can choose white or brown rice to go with it.  It was made to order and still piping hot by the time I walked 3 blocks back to work.  The curry sauce was in a separate container so you pour it in as you're eating.  With the hot curry sauce separate, the katsu with loads of panko crumbs stays crispy.  Katsu was good but would have liked more seasoning on the chicken.  There was a little red/pink pickled daikon (long white radish) as well as pickled white cabbage.  I would have liked more veggies!

I'd like to give it another try.  I might try the Veggie Curry or the Chicken Karaage next time.

In the mean time, if you're craving Japanese curry, make it at home.  Instant curry doens't have the depth like Muracci's but still tastes darn good!  Buy S&B Golden Curry at Safeway/Berkeley Bowl/Ranch 99/some Asian grocery store.  Boil some water and put in a couple of cubes of instant curry.  Add veggies (onions, potatoes, zuchinni, carrots, etc).  A box of instant curry will only cost about $5.  Now for the katsu, you're on your own.  I don't know how to fry like that!
author: Susan C.

description: I used to love this place, until I ordered Katsu curry with noodles, only to get back to the office to discover that they had given me rice... and NO Katsu!
author: Jake B.

description: Good seems good but the process to get the food and the rude Russian speaking woman at the register made the experience bad. Don't expect a smile with your meal.
author: Joseah R.

description:
Solid Japanese curry spot in the Financial District. I ordered the chicken katsu curry, HOT, and unfortunately, the spice level didn't do it for me. Definitely could've thrown some Siracha on there. 

I'd recommend showing up at least half an hour before 12 to avoid the lunch rush. Grab take-out, and head to one of San Francisco's roof-top POPOS. Perfect day!
author: Chanel F.

description:
Wow!

Had no idea this place even existed. They have a very robust curry menu. Katsu curry, tofu curry, seafood curry, you name it. 

Their katsu is wonderfully crispy. The meat however was hit or miss, mine came extremely dark and fatty while the bf's was lean and white. You can really taste the different spices in the curry sauce. Of course, when I dipped in for my first bite, the curry that I poured in the to-go box slooped out like a drinking fountain and landed right on my leg. :( Be careful. Seating is barely existent between the counter and a couple small tables. 

They also have curry pan and cake if you want a quicker bite to go.
author: Torie Y.

description:
Hey, what the...Muracci ain't no Japanese name. I got me a Japanese name and ain't no bruddas with that name. Hmmm, sounds Italian to me. Hey paisan!...Do you put pesto in your sushi? What?....Only four types of sushi and none of them with marinara? No wonder we both lost the Big One...World War II that is.

Ethnic stereotypes aside, it does look and sound like bruddas run the place. Genki desuka, dude? I was a kid in a frickin' candy store for lunch today. What to get, what to get. Curry plates. Tonkatsu. Donburi bowls. Ramen bowls. Gee, I miss my mom (...my eye is getting moist). I went for the $7.95 Chicken Karaage Lunch Special (see my photo). Several pieces of fried chicken chunks, very tender and moist, over a bed of brown rice with a salad and a scoop of genuinely awesome potato salad with corn kernels and cucumbers. It comes with a steaming serving of miso with big tofu cubes.

You can be brave and sit at the teeny-weeny counter (see my photos) or just take it to go like any normal, anti-social worker drone in the FiDi. The wait isn't horrible...you have to understand that each order is made individually. No slabs of chicken are drying up on that grill. Looks like I'll be a regular here...better bone up on my Japanese. Maybe I can get one of those cake roll slices for free. How do you say "Buongiorno, Paisan!" in Japanese?

FOOD - 4 stars...karaage just like my mom made it (...getting teary-eyed again)
AMBIANCE- 3.5 stars...like a closet in there, but hey I ain't picky...they've only been open for six weeks, took over Kearny Pies, a place I was meaning to try...but my thighs wouldn't let me
SERVICE - 4 stars...super-friendly...maybe blood is thicker than shoyu?
TOTAL - 4 stars...can't wait to try the other stuff in the coming weeks
author: Ed U.

description: My first couple times here I really wasn't understanding what the hype was all about. Fast forward a year later & 7 months pregnant it's like OMG , where has this place been all my life?  The tonkatsu curry was so tender you could basically gum it. I got the medium spicy curry which caused the baby to somersault in my belly... Whoaaaa!  Will go for mild next time.  Service could be better, way better but who cares? I don't know if anyone actually eats in here, there's like 4 chairs n it's always crowded.
author: Lauren S.

description:
Well, we have Muracci's Monday for the team I'm on, if that says anything.

Muracci's is a pretty good lunch spot. It's very popular, so if you go at around noon, be prepared to wait quite a bit. The shop is pretty small (essentially enough to fit the kitchen), so the line usually snakes out the door.

The first time around, I ordered the chicken katsu. The second time, I ordered the katsu (pork). For people like me, initially, who didn't know what katsu meant, put short, the meat is breaded and fried. The chicken and pork are both placed on a bed of rice, and a container of curry is kept separate (so that your chicken/pork doesn't get all soggy by the time you get back to the office). Both of these items were pretty damn good.

Before I came to Muracci's, I never knew that there was this thing called Japanese curry. Now, I know that Japanese curry is fantastically awesome.

Some hints: it takes a bit of time to prepare the katsu, so I recommend also getting that fried treat that they have by the cash register. It's not too filling, and it'll keep you occupied while waiting for your food. Also, as I keep forgetting this, you can add toppings, like an egg or some vegetables.
author: Daniel G.

description:
Curry pan. Katsu Curry. These are the items that soothed my hunger, that pacified my tears of anguish, that fueled me for the long trek back.

Why did I walk here from SoMa? 

My poor feet.
author: Ben T.

description:
This place is great!! 

If you like curry, you should check out this place! The lines can get a bit long at lunch time, but it's totally worth it! :D
author: Rylee R.

description:
I woke up at 6:30 this morning and had to take a quick shower and sprint to catch the 7 AM ferry.   Sure enough, I got stuck with the shitty MV Vallejo and the vessel was fully packed since I got on board at 6:58.   Sure enough I had to sit outside and pretty much froze my ass all the way to the Ferry building.   I got to work and was complaining to Tom, my coworker, when he said that when he's cold, there's nothing better than Katsu-Don to warm him up.

Kazuwhat?

Katsu-Don, he corrects me.  It's a bowl of rice with a breaded pork chop and an egg on top.   It's so good especially when you're cold in Wintertime.  He goes on to recount with deep nostalgia all the wonderful Katsu-Don he's eaten back when he was in Tokyo and how amazingly cheap it is back there and so on and so forth...   I decided to ignore him then since I almost got to go to Tokyo earlier this year for a bank implementation project and the trip fell through at the last minute, which totally pissed me off.   The bastard got to go about a month later instead...  

Anyway, I decided to yelp Katsu-Don, narrowed the choices down to the FiDi since that's where I make my bread and butter, and I came across some pretty stellar reviews of Muracci's.   I was standing at the cash register at 12:00 sharp ordering a Miso soup and Katsu Don.

It was pretty damn good, I must say...  I think I'd probably try one of their curries next time I'm here, but the Katsu Don at Muracci's was certainly hearty and it most definitely warmed me up.   At $7.50, you get a lot of food, so much so that I couldn't even finish it all.   The breaded pork chop, while certainly not the best I've ever had, was nevertheless quite juicy and tender.   All in all, I'm happy I finally got to try Katsu Don and Muracci's introduction to the dish certainly left me pleased.   For $11 and change, I also got myself a soft drink and way too much good food for a tasty lunch.  Sayonara!
author: David O.

description:
I had the Chicken Teriyaki. The chicken is cooked fresh on the grill and the teriyaki sauce tasted great. I only had one issue: they didn't give me enough of the sauce. It was the perfect amount for the chicken, however there was none left for the rice (so i didn't end up eating much of it).

This is now one of my go-to spots for lunch.
author: Zac A.

description:
I learned how to save a life that day but all I could remember was how good the curry was at Muracci's!  

Six of us pharmacy students stopped by Muracci's BEFORE a CPR training downtown.  That was a mistake.  We were in a hurry so I had no time to finish my delicious katsu curry with brown rice.  I had to eat half and take the other half with me to the CPR class.

While I was doing chest compressions and breaths, I couldn't help but smell the delicious scent of chicken katsu from my fingers as I held down the face mask.

Then as a gust of wind blew through the window, I caught a whiff of the curry since I left my bento box on a table near the window.

When we were doing the babies section, as I did my finger compressions, I was actually thinking about when I could go home and re-heat my curry and eat it.

Delicious curry! I usually don't even like katsu chicken because I don't like some places fry it so that the chicken is too tough and chewy (yuck!) .  It was perfect at Muracci's!  PLUS the owner was so nice!  My friend and I both ordered coquettes and while he was handing her some free peppers to take home and try, she accidentally dropped her coquette on the floor!  He was SO NICE about it and gave her another one for free.

And he gave the rest of us free pickled veges to take home.  ^_^  hooray!
author: Gloria C.

description: Easy service, I ordered online. Pick up was 30 minutes later. I got beef ramen curry. This is a great dish for cold days and especially if you are one who enjoys spicy food
author: Jae L.

description:
Tiny little place in the Financial District but pretty daymn good Japanese curry in SF.   Expect a long line during lunch hour and any katsu curry dish would be a great choice!   Super generous portion for the Katsu curry plate and all under 10 bucks!  

Seating: It's first come first serve and there's only about 10 seats in this restaurant.  

Parking: not easy but there are a few parking garages within two blocks near Chinatown. 

Overall experience:  Awesome cheap eats!
author: Ying F.

description:
Great place for lunch! Wait was not bad, but in case I learned that you can call in ahead of time!

Only tried their Katsu curry so far and I definitely would want to go back to try their other stuff. They make the katsu when you order and give you a side of pickled lettuce. They give you a generous amount of food. Not sure if they do the same for dine in orders but I got a separate container for my  delicious curry, so I got to choose how drenched I wanted my katsu and rice to be. 

The katsu was crispy and I like how they give you the option of white or brown rice.
author: Katie M.

description: Katsu Curry is the way to go! Yummy and filling.  Order ahead of time online to skip the wait in line.
author: John B.

description: Ordered the Chicken Katsu curry on brown rice medium spicy. It comes with pickled cabbage? I think it was. The dish was pretty yummy except I think I should have gotten a hot spicy level instead, the medium did not have any kick. Perfect lunch place.
author: Kathy N.

description: It's a good place to go for a quick, comforting meal. The food is good and service is fairly quick.  If I worked in the area, I'd probably hit it up more often for lunch, but I don't... and wouldn't necessarily make a special trip just to eat it.  But if you're in the area, definitely try this spot!  Get the pork or chicken katsu!  The crispiness is a next balance to the curry!
author: Jae W.

description: Definitely the best Japanese curry in the area, albeit not a difficult dish to serve / low bar to pass. The beef curry sucks (small portions, nothing special) but the chicken/pork katsu are very generous and delicious. Often times, I find breaded fried cutlets to have a weird bitter taste to it, often the result of over frying and stale bread crumbs. Muracci does not suffer from this problem, the katsu is legitimately good. However, the ridiculously long lines and slow prep time makes it a hard spot to recommend often. It is good though, indeed.
author: Ben H.

description:
They have curry udon!!!!! it's surprisingly hard to find despite being so easy to make. Sadly I didn't think it was particularly good, once again, despite being so easy to make.

Still, I'll be back for some katsu curry and I'll for sure update this review after.
author: Misha T.

description: Delicious tonkatsu lunch spot.  They were relatively fast despite the long line and well priced.  The curry was second to the tonkatsu, and have to agree... not very spicy.  But extremely filling and I'd be back all the time if I worked nearby.
author: Lisa P.

description: Talking about a tiny packed place. Lunch time was very crowded. I got the chicken katsu curry. It was pretty good, but it wasn't top notch. The chicken breast was nicely breaded and the curry came in a separate container. You eat it from a to go box. There was barely any place to sit, so perhaps, plan to eat it somewhere else.
author: Fraya S.

description:
The food is great but the wait is horrible. 

I came here for lunch after 1:15 on a weekday. After ordering, the wait was 25+ minutes. I won't be back although the Beef Curry is good.

The food is 4 3/4 stars the disorganization kills it for me.
author: Justin S.

description: Oh my gosh, I am on a curry high.  The vegetable curry is making me so very happy right now.
author: Jooly H.

description:
I came here at 1 pm and there was still a line. That's because the food quality here is solid.  If you like Japanese curry, you have to come and try Muracci's.  I've had the Katsu (Pork Cutlet) Curry (Hot) and it was delicious.  

You wondered what makes Muracci's special?  Let me break this down:
+ The katsu has the soft breading, so it doesn't hurt your gum when you chew on it.
+ The curry are so delicious that you want to lick every last drop.
- okay, way too much rice.

In reality, there was too much food for lunch.  Come hungry or just don't eat all of it.  It's a hard call considered it taste so good, its hard to control yourself. 

Prepare to order take out, the store is very small.  They package it nicely for you.  Separate container for your curry.  So your take out order won't be soggy before you get to eat it.
author: Steven M.

description:
Really really small shop but it fills up quick during FiDi lunchtime. I get the katsu curry every time and it never disappoints. 

You'd think katsu curry is an easy dish to make, but some places leave the curry watered down or chicken pounded too thin. This place is perfect and the flavor profile is spot on.
author: Calvin W.

description:
I have been on a good luck with restaurants these last few weeks, as I am giving out a lot of 5 stars!  

Muracci's serves the best Japanese style curry in the City, period.  Let me justify it for you with 10 reasons:

1) Their curry tastes like the way it is made in Tokyo;
2) They are clean - VERY.
3) Their portions are generous.
4) Their katsus are cooked perfectly: still tender on the inside.
5) You can order vegetables such as spinach to be added to the curry without changing the taste too much - and they cooked the spinach just right even then.
6) They make each order one order at a time: NO, they didn't just kill your chicken, it just tastes good.
7) You can get it with brown rice.
8) You can walk out full, happy, satisfied, and warm, for $10.
9) They serve each dish to you with clear pride on their face - what else do you want to know?
10) They can even do curry right on ramen.  They are the only ones that do this right in this City.  Can you say SKILLZ?

Only criticism: I hate how they use soooo much plastic for the to go orders.  Yes, I want to be clean too!  But if you are a tree hugger (can I get a WHOOT from the fellow Cal. Bears???), eat in or go die from guilt!
author: Mark M.

description:
The line during lunch time is around 15-30 mins.  Had to point that out since i believe that food experience include the entire life cycle from wait time to rest room cleanliness.
This place has its perks which is the large portion to price ratio.  The taste however is mediocre.
I had the fried pork cutlet with curry sauce on a bed of rice(dont remember what it's called on menu).  It was a decent lunch before a meeting.  I had left overs for 3pm reheat snack.
Not a bad place for something different and satisfying.
author: Jason L.

description:
JAPAN in a SPOON...ful of curry!

Definitely the go place during lunch for Japanese Curry. Came here several times already and each time the curry was amazing.

I tried the medium chicken curry which was flavorful, and rich. The curry is made well and not heavy at all. I also ordered the vegetarian curry before as well which was just as amazing. It comes with all sorts of vegetables such as tofu, carrots, peas, and broccoli.

The line can definitely be long at lunch time (half an hour) so definitely come early.
author: Stephen C.

description:
I really like their chicken katsu curry here! It's spiced how you want it (you can get it different spice levels) and it's a good portion. I like Japanese curry. I feel like it's sometimes overshadowed by the more popular curries (i.e. Indian and Thai) but Japanese curry is definitely a more lighter-tasting curry. 

The curry here goes really well with the crisp of the chicken katsu! I also like the ginger they serve with it. They get pretty busy at lunch time, but not too crazy to pass on the delicious curry. My only issue would probably be that it's slightly overpriced. But then again, it's in downtown San Francisco!
author: Junel S.

description: The food was good. It is not a meal that will stick out in your mind. The servers were really nice, the food was at a good price point. It's just not something I would go out my way to get. But a solid 3 star rating is good.
author: ayanna K.

description: For the 1st time, I found the Chicken & Vegetable curry pretty tasty & the portion size was filling. I did a take out as the place is primarily a take out place... The people there were kind (pretty rare). The food was excellent! It was an actual curry unlike the make belief ones by many restaurants. Highly recommend it!
author: Indraneil G.

description: I got the beef curry with vegetables over ramen. It was $10.82 after tax. There was so much ramen and it was very thick ramen. It was only ok. I thought it was too expensive for the amount you're getting: mostly ramen, some beef. I also thought the taste was very mediocre. I could make something just as good at home. Because of the high price and the lack of taste, I doubt I will come back.
author: Wendy L.

description:
I tried Muracci's Japanese Curry & Grill and thought it was just ok.  It's a tiny shop in the FiDi and almost walked right by it, but saw the sign on the window.

I had to wait since it was still their lunch rush.  Maybe 5 people in front of me.  All the seats were taken, but it soon opened up after I got my food.  I choice to eat elsewhere.

I got chicken curry - I asked for "hot".  6.95 + tax .59 = $7.54.  It comes w/ a compostable container filled with rice, some red pickles & some other small container was it veggie or more pickles?  Anyways the chicken curry comes in a small container.  I poured the chicken curry over the rice.  Lots of the rice didn't get covered up.  So if you want more curry you have to pay more for it.  It's barely spicy, no nose running, but a small amount of heat.

I'm in no rush to go back.

They take Credit Cards.
author: Ann L.

description:
Saw the rave reviews about this place and honestly, this place is nothing fabulous, just your normal Japanese curry place. For those of you who have never thought that curry could be associated with Japanese food, this must have blown your mind, as it did with some of my out-of-town co-workers who have thought curry was reserved only for the Indians. 

Anyway, I tried the chicken katsu curry over rice ($9.95!!) since that is what the boss (I guess Muracci-san himself) told me what they were known for while I was in line. $10 bucks is whack for this type of super casual Japanese food. First of all, they gave me a thin layer of rice that was packed flat at the bottom of the to-go box (NEVER EVER FLATTEN ANYONE'S RICE IF YOU KNOW WHAT'S GOOD FOR YOU). The chicken katsu was okay, it was fried just right. The curry came in a separate bowl. This tastes like the same packaged Vermont curry that I can buy from the supermarket and make myself. I was not full nor was I content.

The line goes out the door during lunch time but it moves fast. It's small inside so I suggest taking it somewhere else. I wouldn't consider coming back.
author: Cheri S.

description: This place is tiny so get ready to pack in. Tried the beef curry over ramen noodles, Katsu Don (pork cutlet and egg over rice), and the curry pan (a snack sized fried bread stuffed with curry). The beef curry was good but nothing to go crazy about. I would recommend the Katsu Don over the beef curry. The star of the show for me was actually the curry pan which was really tasty.
author: Hillary R.

description: Got to keep an eye out for this little shop it can be really easy to miss. The Katsu chicken curry was o-m-g good! The katsu chicken was the perfect about of crispy and the curry to rice ration was spot on, the portions were very nice as well.  I would say (could just be me) the curry hotness is about one step down. I would normally get hot and here I would possibly get extra-hot next time. Defiantly would recommend to try this place out or to get someone to try Japanese curry for the first time!
author: John C.

description:
Yums.... hits the spot for curry! About $9ish after tax.
I always get the beef curry, spicy. I wish it came with potatoes and stuff though [I feel like potatoes are a MUST in curry].. but the rice is always cooked well and the curry is always on point. I always take bites out of my friend's katsu and that is ALWAYS hella bomb.
They have an option for brown rice which is nice but WHITE RICE FTW
I don't eat that red (ginger(?)) stuff it comes with.

The cashier ladies are nice and my coworkers love the curry-pan.. which I have yet to try but it always stares me in the face.. one day! There is usually a line but the wait is never long.

Sometimes I sit in with my friend at the bar on the side when there's a seat. Iono.. I love sitting in high chairs with counters.
author: Emily C.

description:
It's been a while since I had Muracci's curry, but it's still awesome as before. Their katsu chicken goes a long way compared to other curries out there. The katsu is fried really well so that the chicken isn't dried out on the inside while the outside remains crispy. The curry is good, but it could be better. Their "hot" spicy isn't that spicy. Japanese spicy is mild compared to any cultures.

Their curry pan is a bit expensive, but they're great! Crunchy on the outside, but soft and moist on the inside. There's nothing like this! If you haven't tried this, something's wrong. Try it!
author: Steven B.

description: Back for the katsu curry! Just as good and oh so comforting on a dreary winter day (and yes, I realize that in SF that's said only semi-seriously). Line moves pretty fast now with the guy taking orders and checking on seating. Feels very Japanese :-).
author: Jean K.

description:
I HATE you Muracci's! This place introduced me to Japanese curry, and I've forever craved, but unable to find ANYTHING similar outside of the bay. It's just so good!

So I'm sure most of you have read all the other reviews about katsu and tonkatsu curry, but the secret? TELL THEM TO ADD CHEESE!!!! It'll take away from the authentic taste, but wow it CHANGED MY LIFE! SO GOOD. I just wish I could have some now...

Perfect lunch spot when working DT. Just wow.
author: Robert H.

description:
Iron Chef Muracci what happened?  You now take orders instead of being at the stove?

Usually it would take at least 10 mins to get my food.  I knew something was up when my order only took 5 mins or less.  Chicken Katsu tastes frozen and the regular Katsu is not the same crispy made to order taste as before.  The medium curry sauce is still on point.  

I guess this is what happens when you make it to 7x7 and become a hipster spot.  There are more people in the kitchen and is best an organized chaos.  The only option they have is take-out.  A box with a thin layer of cold white or brown rice.   I miss the days when the lady behind the counter will have those heavy plates with the smoking hot curry and a good size of rice. 

At $9.45 per order, the prices went up and the quality is lacking.  They did expand to their second location in the South Bay:

http://www.yelp.com/biz/muraccis-2-japanese-curry-and-grill-los-altos

I will probably go check out their new spot since there are actually tables and chairs.  Also I see they use plates instead of to go boxes.  You can compare with old pictures to the most recent ones.  

I miss the old mom & pop shop whole-in-a-wall place atmosphere.  They use to give out free samples of hash-browns and drinks while you waited.  Not a thumb's up for me anymore Muracci-san.  *sigh*
author: Elliot Y.

description: Excellent Japanese curry, which I didn't even know was a thing before I sat down. It's really good stuff.
author: Marcus F.

description: I love Japanese curry, and Muracci's is definitely one of the better places in SF. I think the meat Muracci provides is top notch, but I think there curry isn't "the best" in SF. The curry is still awesome though. I'd recommend the Chicken Katsu Curry with Veggies.
author: Zain M.

description:
I haven't ventured for Japanese curry much since my days at Cal buying lunch from a truck serving curry noodles and such.  When my co-worker suggested coming here last week for lunch while working in the area, it was a welcome change for me.  The curry was flavorful and most (if not all) curry plates run for $10 before tax.  The seating is limited but we are lucky to be able to grab a couple of seats by the window counter since we arrived before noon.

The staff is nice.  My one disappointment, however, is that they did not serve soup with the curry plates, but on the menu it says they're included in other items.
author: H K.

description:
Croquettes are out of this world and compared to empanadas which costs $4.75, these little babies are only $1.75. They have four flavors - Vegetable, Vegetable Hot, Beef & Vegetable, and Beef & Vegetable Hot. I usually always get the Hot, sometimes veggie and sometimes beef & veg. Both are really good and somehow I think the curry sauce they use in these croquettes are more flavorful than the ones in their usual dishes.

Their katsu curries are huge portions, but their noodles are just right for me. I also like that there are more curry sauce in the noodles. I wish that their rice curries have that much sauce as well without paying extra. You can get the curries, mild, medium, or hot. You can also add toppings such as veggies, spinach, eggs, etc. For the health conscious, there is also brown rice option. 

If you are really early/late or by yourself, you probably can eat in here. There are counter seats for maybe about 8 people and one table for two. It gets really hot in there though. 

If you dont want to wait, get their express curry meal. Only difference is that no deep fried stuff, just stewed meat and veggies - which is good too actually.

They also have a weekly specials that's limited to only 15 servings everyday. This week, it is spicy beeef noodle - very spicy!
author: July N.

description: Tonkatsu curry is really tasty.   The fried croquet is good too.   Very crunch and soft gushy mashed potatoes inside.  Will define ly come back to try other fried crispy goodness
author: Danny C.

description:
Great lunch spot.  Got the beef curry over white rice - very good (under $9.)  The beef was very tender and the curry was tasty.  Their spicy isn't too spicy.  They also give you a small side of pickled cabbage which was a nice compliment.

The line can get long, but it moves fairly quickly, esp. considering they cook your meal when you order it.

It's a hole in the wall with very limited seating.  It might be able to fit around 8-10 people at most inside, so plan to take your food togo if you get there during the lunchtime rush.
author: Julia C.

description:
AM I CRAZY OR DID I JUST PAY $12 FOR RICE AND GRAVY?  WHOA.
If you prefer actual protein with your beef curry do not order this dish.  This makes me feels crazy.  Maybe they thought they could get away with it since it was a delivery?  BOO.
author: Brenda B.

description: Very fresh, crisp Katsu. The only complaint I would have is the meat was a tiny bit dry - if they had kept it more moist this would of been perfect. Great lunch spot for those that work close by!
author: Samson T.

description:
Best Japanese curry in San Francisco! Their katsu curry is the best in the Bay Area. 

It gets super crowded at lunch so go early or call ahead. I always want to try the other dishes but I always gravitate back to the katsu curry.

I just wish they were open later and on weekends as well.
author: David N.

description:
[Update] I take my 4* ratings back. I recently learn from their own staff that Vegetarian is not Vegetarian, they use beef broth in it.
I wish they told me the first time around.

Not for Vegetarians.
author: Chinmaya S.

description:
Was crazy busy for lunch but still fast.

I got the Chicken Katsu and it was very good and plenty filling. Definitely a great lunch spot.
author: Ian F.

description: Pretty good curry.  Portions are healthy and prices are decent - considering that there is essentially no seating.  They roll up the sidewalk at around 6:00, so you can't get it for dinner.   Too bad.
author: Lewis C.

description:
Muracci's had only 2 diners inside when i was there 11:30ish so i ate in. gave my order and it was ready in about 10 minutes. cashier very helpful in directing my  order . (ya. i'm a virgin here).

menu: ramen, curries, lunch sets, udon, entries.
music: commercial orchestra music
decor: murals on wall,  little bigger than a bento box

sampling: tonkatsu curry. medium spicy on white rice (8.95)
-tonkatsu was palm sized, very tender but not juicy
-curry was medium but it didn't seem spicy enough. (curry boxed separately)-nice touch.
-sides of pickled veggies tasty
*order pretty hefty for lunch, still finished it.


temaki:
-free water, self service
-lunch sets(entree, soup, salad) available (8.50), no curries
-wooden chairs and counter by wall and windows (10ish)
-definite repeat: ramen?
author: Victor G.

description:
Now that I'm well into my 7x7 challenge of going to all of the places on that list before this year is over, I knew it was a matter of time before I got to this place. So with #16 on the list being the Katsu Curry, I was on my way. What's left to say that hasn't already been said here. This dish is made to perfection. I'm glad I went before peak lunch hours because the moment I was leaving, a huge influx of people arrived desperately hoping that they had some left (and with good reason). 

Even on a rainy day, I would gladly make the trek over to here again. And if it was somehow possible for it to be raining curry, then I would totally want this curry to be pouring down on me as I stand outside with my mouth open. One can dream, right?!  =P
author: Gajan K.

description: Overpriced. I swear every time I go I get less curry, less rice, less meat and the price just seems to keep going up. Stick with the Jap-a-curry food truck.
author: David L.

description:
If you want Japanese curry anything in the city, this is the place to go!  There is a reason why people line up for this small hole in the wall with a few seats and take their meals elsewhere to eat.  It's still piping hot by the time you find a place to sit down and enjoy the sweet, rich curries.

Service is fast and friendly.  Parking is tough on the streets.
author: Jenny L.

description:
Beautiful day to tick mark another restaurant off the old 7x7 list @lunch. I am about 50% complete..... yessss!

Location: located on Kearny/Bush in the FIDI & about an 11-minute walk in flip-flops (google mapped the path & time) from my office. 

Ambiance: Amarillo....that's what I remember~ yellow walls. Small & veeeeery cozy (which means there's ample space to park your rear & enjoy your meal). If you get there early enough you can probably snag one of their bar stool spots.

Food: we tried the chicken & beef katsu curry w/ medium spice and brown rice. Very deliciouso!! The katsu is golden brown & crispy...tender chicken breast and beef, served w/ a small side of pickled cabbage. The curry comes in a separate container to prevent sogginess. It's warm and plentiful...been marinated in herbs and spices for TWO days so it's thick & packed w/ ultimate flavor. Unlike other curry sauces, it's not as creamy or buttery... it's a healthier approach but by all means does not compromise taste. It's still delish!

Service: Well well well Muracci Cucurachi, your food does impress. Per Yelp reviews, it's suggests a phone call in to place your order. I tried dialing you from 11-11:30am but I guess you didn't want to pick up your phone. No matter, placing the order in-store worked just fine...as long as you arrive before the lunch crowd arrives.

Tips:
-Order the beef katsu over the chicken. The beef seems to packs more flavor.
-Order chopped potatoes in your curry sauce...you won't regret it!
-Ask for extra pickled cabbage and more spice in your curry sauce!

Bottom line: Great lunch joint...just be sure to get there earlier to avoid the lunch rush!
author: Joy A.

description:
DELICIOUS!!! :)

It's definitely a battle between Muracci's and JapaCurry... I might be leaning towards Muracci's (not sure why, based on instincts I guess), but JapaCurry is a close second for sure.   

Muracci's has a really small store front, so there are limited seats available (I would say 10 or less). Most people just get take-out from here. If you get here around noon, don't be alarmed by the line. It may seem long, but it really doesn't take a long time, maybe 15 mins total from lining up to picking up your order. To expedite the process, a guy goes around the line to take your order, so you just have to pay when you get to the front of the line. After that, it takes about 2 minutes for them to have your order ready. 

I ordered the Tonkatsu Curry, and it was amazing! First of all, the portion is just right - I left feeling satisfied, but not stuffed. The pork cutlet was perfect fried to its golden brown complexion. It was crispy and tender. Best part is that the breading never separated from the meat, thumbs up! As for the curry itself, it had a nice balance of saltiness, sweetness, and spiciness. I got mild hot, and that was spicy enough for me (although I can handle and enjoy eating spicy food). Putting the pork, curry, and rice together, it made for a perfect lunch, especially on a cold day as the curry does warm you up! 

Would definitely be coming back more often! :)
author: Michelle L.

description:
Definitely one of the better places to get Katsu Curry in the city. It is a really small place, and good news is majority of the people get it to go anyways. Be aware of the long line that goes out the door and then some during lunch. 

I did like the curry lots, did feel like it was stewed for hours. I like how the curry is placed in a separate container, so your rice and katsu won't get all soggy. The katsu was quite yummy, nice and tender, and uber juicy. The right amount of panko flakes. My fav part is to ask for extra pickled radishes! I like to take a bite with rice, curry, katsu and radish. That's the best combo! hmmmmm *drools*
author: Vanessa K.

description:
I come here when I'm feeling a little Japanese curry.

Katsu chicken curry is the only thing I've ever liked here and mainly what they are famous for. 

I've tried their pan fried curry they leave next to the registers and for some reason even with the heat lamps the ones I ate came out still cold. Not as good as it looks because it's all the lighting and photoshopping (jk)

It's quite small so expect to get it to go
author: Dorris W.

description:
This is the review I left for their delivery service ORDER AHEAD, which does not impact the quality of food/service from Muracci's. Wanted to warn those who might consider ordering through ORDER AHEAD for delivery--don't bother, not worth it!

**********************
ORDER AHEAD: 1 Star
This delivery service is laughable at best. Customer service is NON-EXISTENT and they do the restaurants who utilize their "service" a huge disservice.

I placed a large order for lunch delivery to my office from Muracci's. Given the size of the order, they should have alerted the pick-up biker (yes biker) that there is no way he would be able to pick up and deliver lunch for 14. Add on to that the first of the two deliveries was 30 minutes late (super fun when you have 14 hungry people). I called, left a voice mail, sent an email through their survey they sent. No response at all.

If I would have known it would have been this much of a hassle, I would not have even bothered.

Their mark-up and automatic 15% gratuity is unconscionable. If you a restaurant considering this, don't bother. It only clouds your own reputation and is not worth it.
author: Mrs P.

description:
Delicious! Bit of a wait if you come during prime lunch times, but well worth it. It was more expensive than the $ listed on Yelp's price range - I paid a little under $10 for my chicken katsu mild curry. Seems a little high for curry, but that's my only complaint honestly. 

I loved loved the chicken katsu! It had that perfect combination of juicy tender chicken and light crispiness that is so easy to screw up. The curry had a great flavor to it as well, and spice-averse me appreciated the tiny kick the mild version had. Next time I definitely want to try the Curry Pan!
author: Kristie C.

description:
This is a little hole in the wall downtown that is suited more for the daytime lunch crush than seated dining, but the Katsu curry was very good and reasonably priced for the quality you get, especially downtown.  I believe that it might've been the owner who took my order and then brought it out, but he was very gracious and nice to boot. 

Be aware that this place is so small that there are mainly stools and a shelf along a couple walls to dine semi-standing.  There is a small 2 person table too, but most people get the food to-go.  If you come here with a group of people and want to sit, you will not be able to.
author: Dave N.

description:
The katsu curry is #16 on the 7x7 Top 100 list and I am still slowly working on it! I got to Muracci's and placed my order.. there was a pause as the lady I ordered from asked the chef if they had any left... I held my breath... YES! One portion left! I scurried home with my bag, poured myself a cold beer and dug in. I was shocked at the quality of the pork cutlet. I imagined it being thin, but it was really thick! As I cut it with my knife I could "feel" the quality, if that makes any sense. I poured the sauce on and it was fantastic. The breading was so crunchy and tasty smothered in the sauce. 

I have ony had Katsu Curry from one other place and I did  not care for it at all. Muracci's made me realize that that other place was doing it all wrong.
author: Liz M.

description:
Definitely a place to stop-by if you happen to be in the area for lunch on weekdays. They don't have a lot of seating, but from what I saw most people get their food to go anyway.

The katsu is very tender, juicy and they serve thick pieces, unlike most other places. The curry is thick and flavourful too. Best part - their homemade cabbage pickles you get for free!

If only other places can do curry as well..!
author: Alice C.

description:
The chicken katsu does live up to its hype! Everything is made to order so you have to wait a bit but definitely fresh. 
The place is really tiny so don't expect to always get a seat
author: Shawarma K.

description: Just like Japan, tsukemono and everything. Just what needed today. Thanks for an awesome meal folks!
author: Cori A.

description:
Check this, as far as quick lunch options in the FiDi it doesn't get much better than Muracci's!

The fondness in my heart for a beautifully fried piece of pork was fulfilled. I've been here twice once ordering the Katsu Curry the other time going with the chicken katsu curry. It's no mystery as stated in the beginning of this paragraph that I preferred the pork. The efficiency of the establishment is off the charts. A nice Japanese gentlemen greets you and takes down your order while in line. By the time you get to the register and pay the meal is practically bagged and in your hands. A bunch of Japanese words are thrown around in the kitchen = LEGITimacy. 

Now on to the most important part of any review: food description
Katsu Curry (medium hot)- Simplicity is key, nicely fried pork cutlets on a bed of white rice (or brown if you prefer) with pickled cabbage and ginger. I added an boiled egg for 75 cents. Reminds me of a taiwanese fried pork chop dish I hold near and dear to my heart (flavor profile completely different, but ya know). The curry not surprisingly is the star of the show. The delicious flavor is subtle in its excellence. Medium hot was an adequate amount of kick. I was expecting more due to hype, but as I ate my appreciation grew. I wouldn't say best curry ever, but top 3. I'm sure If I went to Japan my mind would be BLOWN. 

Chicken Katsu Curry- Respectable fried chicken, but imo the pork was better. Curry was consistent in goodness the second time around. 

Udon (chicken and veggie curry)- My friend ordered this dish. She had asked if the curry base was thick and the nice man said it wasn't. After finishing all the noodles a decent sized pool of curry was left. It was curry overload for her. As she threw away the rest I cringed because I could have easily cooked a batch of white rice and dumped that curry over. Instant delicious meal. Her slobber was all in it, I restrained myself. 

The place is small and compact. There is some cramped seating along 2 sides of the restaurant, about 8 seats total. Next time I come back and it's only a matter of time I'll snag an assortment of Korokke to try. They looked pretty good bathing in the heat ray machine next to the cashier.
author: Jack C.

description: I've only recently started eating Japanese curry, so I am not a connoisseur or whatever. But, This place is pretty good. I came here for take-out during lunch. It was around 11ish and there wasn't a line. I ordered the curry katsu and also grabbed a curry pan. I didn't know there were different spice levels for the curry pan and I accidentally grabbed a HOT one and it wasn't too spicy. The curry katsu was pretty good, but kinda small. The rice and katsu was pretty much half the box and the other half was empty. They should use smaller boxes so the food is more presentable. Anyway, over all, it was a good experience.
author: Lina C.

description: Yummy japanese curry, but go with beef/pork/chicken, not the salmon. I think I got 5 or 6 fried salmon nuggets, but they were not very flavorful and not as tender as I would've liked. Should've stuck with the tried and true!
author: Linus W.

description:
Muracci's is not only a must for the 9-5 worker, it's a refuge.

Although I had a hard time understanding the gal on the other end of the line when I called in my to go order, I crossed my fingers that she got it right.  There are only 4 stools where you can sit so it's a lot better to take it to go.

We were in and out in 5 mins. and soon enjoying our delicious lunch. For $8.95 you get a huge serving of chicken katsu or tonkatsu with white or brown rice and pickled veggies. I requested my curry medium spicy (with extra spinach) but it wasn't spicy at all.  If you really want some heat, order yours spicy.

My tonkatsu curry landed a spot on the Big Eat Sf list at #16. It's lightly breaded, fried golden brown and pre-sliced for you.  This was super moist and tender, I just used my spoon to free up the pieces. Make sure you drown the whole thing with curry sauce, it's the only way to fully enjoy it. 

A magnificent meal on the go.  Muracci's, you break the monotony of the work day simply by serving a tasty meal. Dare I say this? you actually make me want to work in the Fidi.
author: Janice C.

description:
Definitely still my favorite place to eat Japanese curry. It's been a couple years since I had it, but everything was just the way I remembered it. The lunch lines are always out the door. They continue to make everything to order which ensures that their katsu or other fried options don't get soggy and their curries remain hot. Knowing all of this, I was prepared and called in my order ahead of time. Doing so allows you to skip the entire line, leaving you to pay at the register and pick out which order is yours. 

I always get the CHICKEN KATSU CURRY because it never fails me!
___
Lifetime Health Score - 100!!
author: Dennis L.

description:
After reading a bunch of reviews, I knew I had to try Muracci's since I love Japanese curry and it's so close to where I'm working this summer! This place definitely didn't disappoint - we went earlier, at around 11-11:30 to beat the lunch rush, so there was barely a line. It's actually really small inside, with a table that seats two and some counters and bar stools along the wall and window, so most people get it to go. We ended up snagging two seats at the counter by the window facing the street. 

I ordered to chicken katsu curry with medium sauce and brown rice. I really like that they offer brown rice at no extra charge. We ordered it to go and they put the curry sauce in a container on the side, which I think is smart so it doesn't make the katsu soggy and we can control how much sauce to put on. I didn't know how spicy it would be, so I went with medium, but afterwards I realized I probably would have liked it spicier. Overall, it was really yummy and well portioned; it was a generous amount of chicken, perfectly fried, and the sauce was so flavorful and delicious. My friend also got the curry pan, which we split as we waited for our food - it was super good as well!
author: Jessica S.

description:
Way overrated--not worth going to. Had the weekly special spicy noodle, not great. I know my standards are high now that I had Momofuku, but this was not good. Would never order again.

Also tasted the Katsu curry--nothing special. What I did love though was the family aspect, it was very homey and intimate. Unfortunately the food was not great, would not go back again.
author: Chrissy H.

description:
Fried chicken is something that (as far as I can tell) is universally considered amazing.  I would argue that it is securely in the top 100 of God's gifts to man kind.   

The Chicken Katsu at Muracci's is something unique that really stands out from all the other fried chicken dishes I have ever had.

Why does this place stand out?

...maybe it was that having called in our order to this tiny hole-in-the-wall, we got our food in a few short minutes.  (Plan for take out, there is virtually no seating)  

...maybe it was the low price of $8.95 I had enough food to last 2 very filling meals.

...maybe it was that rather than traditional katsu sauce, it was served with ample tasty curry and pickled veggies that complement the dish perfectly!

...maybe it was the brown rice option that fooled my brain into thinking that my meal of hot/moist chicken on the inside; perfectly crunchy and salty panko crumbs on the outside, then smothered in curry was somehow healthy. 

Ultimately this experience was everything a fried chicken loving girl could hope for.
author: Susan C.

description:
Got there at noon and there was a long line outside. Good sign for a first timer. The line moved kinda slow and I got to the tiny counter in the tiny hole in the wall restaurant after waiting about 10 minutes.I got the veg and tofu ramen Togo. Asked for spicy and it was boiling hot to touch...another good sign. I love hot, steaming food on cold and windy days.

Got to the office and was looking forward to stuffing my face. The ramen was perfect but the curry lacking:(

Hardly any flavor, very flat with only one layer of flavor, if you know what I mean. Zero spice even though I asked for spicy.Was hungry so are the whole thing anyways.

Next time I am craving Japanese curry, HRD it will be!!
author: linda g.

description:
The curry udon here has been a disappointment for the past 2 visits. At first I thought it's close enough to what I can have in New York. Now the curry udon is just watered down so much that the nijiya market sold curry udon - half price, is able to beat. A place like this getting four stars shows how pathetic the food scene here is in San Francisco. Ask why there's nothing like New York magazine here.
What a disappointment!
Do not come.
author: Angelina Y.

description:
I came here today with half our office, on a field trip to find pigs. For to eat.  Got here around 12:00pm, stood in line at Muracci's for about 10 minutes, and ordered my chicken katsu curry, over brown rice, mild.  We waited around for another 10 minutes, then walked back to our office, ready to get our curry eatlove ON.

I was SO EXCITED to eat this stuff because I heart Japanese curries. 

The verdict?  Well, while I was eating, I kept thinking that I could walk myself over to my local Asian supermarket, buy a block of packaged Golden Curry for $2.99, and cook myself several bowlfuls of good Japanese curry instead of spending $10 on an order of this. 

The chicken katsu wasn't very crispy, it was just a very mediocre piece of chicken, an unexceptional deep-frying job.  And I know it was fresh because we were waiting for a bit, and they were making that stuff fresh. So I guess it was just a bad fry job. The curry was flavorful, but not anything more special than the blocks of Golden Curry you can cook yourself.  At $10, it was also a pricey lunch (but that's to be expected, this is the Financial District).

Maybe they were having an off day?  Though, I'm not inclined to go back because I don't really want to eat it again, especially not for $10.  

On the bright side, the lady who took our orders was very nice!

Oh, and their potato croquette is bomb.  Do get that.
author: Vivian C.

description: I like to get the curry udon. Calling ahead is a good idea as the line can get long. The place itself is super tiny so squeezing in to pick up your food can be a little difficult, but worth it when you emerge victorious.
author: Christine H.

description: Grabbed lunch on a random Wednesday around 12:30pm. There were about 4 seats open out of 7ish seats. There wasn't much of a wait and we got our food quickly. I ordered the pork katsu curry - hot and my friend ordered the chicken katsu curry - medium. The hot wasn't too spicy and the medium was pretty much a mild for me (I love and can handle really spicy food). The pork and chicken were both a little dry. The portions were good. I eat a lot and couldn't finish my lunch. I wish they gave more pickled veggies though! Wish I worked in the city more often, this place is a great and affordable lunch option.
author: Dorothy L.

description: Best idea ever! Curry bread!!! Great on the go. Make sure you buy more than one!
author: Claire M.

description: I thought my Tonkatsu Don was directly served from Japan. The taste was so good and original. If you wanna eat original tonkatsu don, this is the best Japanese restaurant owned by Japanese in San Francisco! p.s. The restaurant has only 8-9 seats, most people usually ordered for to-go.
author: Maythee C.

description: A super small spot in downtown SF, but the curry is what keeps you coming back! The line can be long, but it's worth it when you order tonkatsu curry. Perfectly fried, and the sauce is the best that i've had so far. You have a choice of white or brown rice and the curry is served in a separate container so you can add as much as you like.
author: Andrew S.

description:
Japanese curry. Now this is something I've never tried. And glad I did.

I came here with a co-worker on a Friday afternoon, hoping to nurse a hangover. Space is small, so I'd rec calling in your order, or getting it to go and enjoy at a nearby park - as we did. Based on my friend's regular order, we both opted for the fried salmon with brown rice. Hearty, heavy, it hit the hangova spot. 

Service is fast, friendly but with no-frills ... I'm a fan.
author: Farrah A.

description: Called to order pickup, phone line just kept ringing for over 5 min. Tried to order online and the online menu was incorrect so they couldn't process my order. Tried calling again and then was told that they were out of my order... this was 2 min after they opened. Tried to order and alternative and they were ALSO out of that... such a let down... it's a small business, I get it. Just very unreliable.
author: Justine L.

description: The first time I had Muracci's was one of the happiest in my life. I had the beef curry mild. The wait in line is really cool. One of the guys there walks up to you and asks you what you want, hands the paper to the kitchen. It was really efficient because it definitely helped with the long line. I was like the 7/8th person in line but I didn't wait too long like 15 minutes the most ? I love how they separate the curry and beef from the rice. I had Katsu curry the next time and I loved how they put the rice and Katsu separate from the curry. Makes life easier, especially when you want to save that Katsu curry for later. I bring tons of friends here and my office mates and they fell in love with it. One of the best Japanese curries I've had in SF. Do yourself a favor and go. Be in mind of the small space. Seating may not always be available, so getting it to-go might be one of the best ideas.
author: Cynthia D.

description: Haven't came here in a while, knowing how it is usually busy I used the OrderAhead app on my phone to place an order during lunch. I was super excited to start munching but much to my surprise when I opened my box of salmon curry, I found a tiny piece of salmon and no toppings in my curry. I discovered that they stopped serving potatoes and carrots with every order, instead it costs extra to add them. My meal was not worth the $11, not at all. Disappointed and will not be ordering from here anymore.
author: Kawai N.

description: I had a late lunch today. There was no line around 2. I tried the Katsu curry with brown rice, it was soooo good.  It would be better if I ate there instead of carry out. Overall, really satisfied! One thing is, I think they don't change the oil often for fried stuffs.  My Katsu seemed overcooked with the brownish color, but it was not.  I think that is the reason...
author: Josey T.

description:
Heard lots of great things for Muracci's so decided to give it a try. I was craving curry that day, so was definitely up for some hot curry! It's a very small space with a homey ambiance. The workers definitely were helpful, helping me choose a dish/level of spice. They also have little goodies that they make for sale. The food is cooked quick and fresh.

1) Chicken curry: They give a lot of rice and sauce, but only a little handful of meat. I think we only got 5 small pieces. It is accompanied with some radishes and a little bit of pickled cabbage.
2) Pork katsu: A lot of rice and sauce, with a decent sized pork. This one good.

The curry is very flavorful and a cure for a hot curry craving. I got the medium spice and it was still pretty spicy. To my taste, I was still craving for the Thai type of curry and therefore, I didn't enjoy it AS much. It was still good, but didn't satisfy my cravings for curry. 1) Not the type of curry I like 2) A little too spicy that it took over my tastebuds. 

Also, I paid .75 more for a boiled egg and spinach. The boiled egg I would have liked as a fried egg on top of my curry better. The spinach, they only gave a small handful once again and it wasn't much of an addition.

All in all, good curry for those who enjoy this type and a satisfying meal.

(Can't think of anything creative to end it off :))
author: Jennifer C.

description: Great lunch place when I work a block away.  They have another location in Los Altos both very good.
author: Ronald L.

description:
Let me disclaim from the beginning that I don't like curry. Whew, now that that's off my chest...

I came here at lunch, around 1PM, which was probably my first mistake. I assumed my 1PM arrival time would mean that I would miss the lunch hour, but alas, I was wrong. The line still swarmed far out the door. There was a lady who went down the line to preemptively take your order though...she would yell your order to the guys behind the counter. I'm not convinced that the guys behind the counter are able to make use of this information because the whole atmosphere is hectic. There are some seats inside, but the whole inside is small and crowded.

Plus: they take credit cards! I guess they have to since they are located in FiDi, but for a hole-in-the-wall type establishment I was surprised that they do.

The curry was mediocre...I don't even like curry and I know I've had better. The rice tasted like basmati rice, and there were some interesting pickled vegetables too. The highlight is probably the katsu, which was delicious.
author: Melody L.

description:
If the 4-Stars rating is based on their Katsu Curry dish, that would be a serious stretch...

The curry sauce was way too thin (liquidy) and the flavor is off. It's got this hint of sour-like taste which is very unusual to me.  One redeeming fact is that the port cutlets are done well (good flavor; not dried). It wasn't even cheap, still cost $9.95.

Overall, a 3-stars at best. I would have given a 2-stars if it wasn't for the port cutlets.
author: Cheung L.

description:
It's hard for me to write this one. I wanted to love it. I really did. But, alas, I didn't. I didn't like how thick the cuts were. If it's authentic that way, I don't like authentic, and I'm entitled not to. The sauce was slightly watery and I wanted more flavour. And the mild was spicy. Took a while to get my order and felt cramped in there. 
Others seemed very happy.
The people there were nice, but overall the place just didn't do it for me! I probably will never return.
author: Andrew K.

description:
Came down here for lunch to try their Katsu Curry. It's a fairly easy place to find, but the restaurant itself is a bit small so make sure not to go on a busy day or you might find yourself waiting in line.

They prepared their meals pretty quick because I didn't have to wait long for my order. It looked and smelled great, and I couldn't wait to chow down. I should have ordered it with more spice to it because it wasn't as spicy to me. It was still good, but I'd like to point out their rice tasting a bit chewy.

Overall, the meal was pretty good but you might want to consider getting yourself another order of it or you won't be filled. Maybe it's just me but I was still hungry after eating it. If I ever get the chance to come back here and have lunch I'd get two orders while trying out their "Homemade Curry Pan". The people seemed nice and you'll receive your order pretty quick so give this place a go if you're hungry and around the area.

They also were donating the money they made that day to the victims in Japan during that Tsunami so I thought that was pretty cool.
author: Richard C.

description: A hole-in-the-wall lunch or dinner spot with limited seating and bare-bones service, but great food. Their rice is beautifully sticky and moist, and the curry is the epitome of hot comfort food. If you work or live in the area, I would get the food to-go.
author: Jenny Z.

description: YOU BURN ME SO GOOD! Omg, got the spicy beef curry noodles (w/ ramen) and it was the BOMB (literally, as in it was spicy) but so satiating! And that aroma that comes off of it wherever you go is indescribable! I'll be back for the koroke next time!!!
author: Diana L.

description:
I'm not a japanese curry expert by any means, but I was not impressed by the curry here. Ordered the veggie+tofu curry plate with brown rice. Everything was fine, but I found the curry to be too... tomato-ey tasting? I can't quite put my finger on it. 

Personally I prefer the curry from JapaCurry, it's a little bit thicker due to a higher proportion of whatever onions etc. that are blended and cooked into the curry. I will give Muracci's points for no up-charge on brown rice.
author: Michelle Y.

description: I was in the city and decided to try this place again since Katsu Curry is not terribly common even in the Bay Area.  Since my first review back in 2010, a lot has changed.  First of all, I've now been to Japan 3 times and have had many a Katsu Curry and so, I now  have a better idea what Katsu Curry should taste and look like.  Anyway, when I first went to Muracci's, they used to serve you on a real plate.  Now, everything's in a styro box.  Also, the sauce used to be much thicker and the cutlet much crispier and juicier.  Now, the sauce is a little thinner and the cutlet was a little dry.  In Japan (or Korea for that matter), not once have I ever had a dry cutlet.  In America, dry cutlet seems to be the norm.  If you really want to experience great Katsu Curry, unfortunately, you'll have to go to CocoCurry or Saboten (neither of which exists in the Bay Area unfortunately - but for those who have been to these restaurants, you will know what I am talking about).
author: d h.

description:
Yummm! I'm loving Japanese curry more and more. I was prepared for the long line after reading the Yelp reviews. There was a really courteous waitress who took orders while you were in line, so you only had to pay when you got to the cashier. (By the way Muracci's accepts the mobile payment app Level Up as well! You get $2 credit from using the mobile app, so I'm going to definitely use that app next time I come here!) I ordered a chicken katsu with medium spicy curry and spinach over brown rice. While I was ordering, there were small versions of chicken katsu bread that looked so delectable that I made an impulsive move and purchased that along with a strawberry cake! 

There wasn't too much seating available inside, so my friend and I went elsewhere to eat our lunch. The chicken katsu curry was definitely delicious! However, compared to Japacurry, I think it's about the same quality for a slightly higher price. I'll definitely come back though. Use the mobile app and receive credit!
author: Jeannie W.

description:
Katsu Curry (#3) (pork)

The place is small, and I went during lunch hour, BUT the wait really wasn't as bad as I expected it to be! 15 min I think? There was a friendly old man taking our orders as we stood in line, and even though it gets crowded around the water fountain while people are waiting for their orders, it's nothing I'm not used to. I like how the place feels very family-oriented. The older man reminded me of my grandpa so much, I bowed out of reflex when he gave me my order slip. =)

You kinda have to get the food to-go. There's barely any room to eat it there. But luckily there are places to sit, like near the batter bakery kiosk at California and Kearny where the big flag is. We sat there on a sunny day so it was a nice lunch atmosphere. 

Food is fresh and hot: 
I picked medium for my curry because I wasn't sure how spicy it'd be, but now that I've had it, I'm gonna go HOT! lol. They keep it in a separate container. I liked pouring the curry on myself because I got to control how much I wanted...and the curry was good!
The katsu was crispy, thick, and delicious...one of the best I've had in a long time! You know how some places' katsu is almost all breading and barely any actual meat? Well, not here. They give thick cuts that came with some pickled veggies that I wish I had more of, and I got it on top of brown rice (which tasted like the frozen brown rice at TJs). I don't mind the mediocre rice as the katsu was the main attraction and rice was secondary to me...

Expensive ($8.95) but a good amount of yummy food. Definitely my kind of comfort food.
author: Hana K.

description:
Ever since I had the veggie & tofu curry dish for lunch on Friday, I have been craving it! I wish I could eat it right now!  The weird thing is that I don't typically even like curry but this place does it right!  Yum!  At lunch, we had to wait 15-20 minutes in a line wrapped around outside but it was all worth it and the line moved quickly, given the number of people waiting.  

Note: I would encourage you to find an alternate place to eat your meal as this place is teeny tiny and with the lunch crowd, it may be hard to snag a seat.
author: Vanessa L.

description:
I love Muracci! It's definitely a tough decision if I have to choose Muracci or Tani's, but shoot, they're both great! They definitely have different taste for the curry. Tani's curry is a little bit thicker and stronger in flavor, while Muracci is feels a bit lighter and not too thick/watery. 

I got the chicken katsu curry, I think I got it spicy, and I really liked it. 

The place is, indeed, very much like a whole in the wall and it's always crowded. The wait doesn't feel too long even though it looks like it would take forever to get your food. It's actually pretty quick!

OH! and a must try is their curry beef croquette thingys! Haha, super good and it's the perfect snack!
author: Verdina P.

description:
First off... the place is super small. There are like 8 stools in total at the place. I ended up ordering the katsu curry over rice as a take out to find seating elsewhere to eat. 

Side story: During my wait, I needed to use the restroom. I walk over and attempt to turn on the light... and what happens? the light doesn't even work. I had to use the restroom with the lights off.. how awkward is that!

I hope I didn't ruin your appetite, but after receiving my food, I gave it a try a few blocks down. The pork covered the rice with the curry inside a little container to keep everything from getting soggy. Overall, I thought the food was only mediocre. It had a small spice to it and the flavor was decent. It didn't blow my mind and there wasn't anything special about the curry, meat, or rice.

Not sure if the curry is worth $10 since I wasn't even full after eating my order. In the end, I don't think I would recommend the place, but it was worth the try.
author: Kevin G.

description: Reasonably priced with generous portions, an authentic Japanese curry in a quaint location(not much sitting room-recommend ordering to go). Yum.
author: David B.

description:
I really do love this spot.  I love it's hole in the wall feel, I love that they take lots of care into the preparation of their food, I love that they continue to give great service and haven't compromised their quality despite their growing fan-base.

This is my GO TO when I have cravings for Japanese curry for LUNCH.  I was downtown with the boyfriend yesterday and when deciding where to go, MURACCI'S came to mind!  We know that over the year's the lines have become more and more ridiculous so we knew to CALL AHEAD OF TIME and PUT IN OUR ORDER prior to arriving.  And it was exactly as we expected.  They said 15 minutes and after a quick stop at H&M from Union Square, we were at the front of Muracci's within 15 minutes and the line was out the door and partial into the next store front!

We squeezed our way into the tiny restaurant to the front cashier area, paid and walked out with our "TO-GO" package ready to eat!  This isn't a place where you'll stay and eat...they have very limited seating!

We found some benches and consumed EVERYTHING!  Hot prepared rice, crispy chicken katsu with their special curry sauce.  O-M-G... i really do love their curry sauce more than any other japanese curry truck/restaurant i've been to in SF.  Creamy, just the right amount of spicy, and bits and pieces of all their veggies.  If you wait too long you'll miss the crispiness of the chicken, but their breading is very good!  I haven't had an experience where they overcooked the chicken and I always find it very juicy and perfectly fried on the outside.

CALL IN!  GO TRY!
author: Sandy L.

description:
Update: So I have perfected my order at Muracci's, allowing me to bump up my previous 3 star rating!

The best I've ordered was the pork katsu with the hottest sauce you can get... and make sure you ADD CHEESE! Holy crap that cheese addition makes it a gooey awesome delicious mess. I will never order anything else here without CHEESE.

Yeah, and so the chicken katsu is still sort of dry imo, but the pork katsu is always flavorful and tender. Damn pigs for tasting so good.
author: Melody S.

description: This place had really good Chicken Katsu. The line wasn't too bad either, although we went pretty late into lunch (1:15pm) so that may have helped a lot.
author: Coltin C.

description:
The service was quick, once you get past the line. The prices were also reasonable for the amount they give you. 

Ordered: 
Curry pan - deliciously crispy on the outside. Yummy curry goodness inside. 
Curry katsu - the curry was well spiced and the katsu was crispy and the meat was juicy. 

This place is small and therefore seating is not always available.
author: Jess H.

description: I've been here on many occasions, and the curry and food was always delicious, so I'm hoping today was just a fluke.  I ordered the tofu and vegetable curry, which I've had at least 4 times prior.  Today the curry was disappointing to say the least.  It tasted watered down, and weak.  I almost thought to return it, since it was that mediocre. Again, hoping it was just a fluke day.
author: short t.

description: Walking around Chinatown looking for a quick and yummy bite to eat we found this little "hole in the wall" as people walked out with these savory pastries in hand (Curry Pan). There was an older gentleman taking orders while people were in line and he recommended the Katsu Pork w/Hot Curry Sauce, so we shared one with a couple of Curry Pans. Very good, great taste and friendly staff. Little to no dining area, but that did not seem to be a problem. Place was busy, then again we did stop by during weekday lunch hour, but still speedy service.
author: Pat R.

description:
I'd give it 3.5 stars actually.
I had the Chicken Katsu which was good but the real star of the show is their curry sauce. I made the mistake of ordering a lunch set and then realized that it didn't come with curry so luckily I bought a side of curry sauce before leaving. There is no reason to go with a lunch set unless you really like miso soup, iceberg lettuce and flavorless potato salad.
author: Mark S.

description:
Yum, yum, and happily stuffed yum. I was going to L&L across the street, but felt like i should try this place since it was 2:30 w/ no line. I ordered the chicken katsu curry. My only gripe is the wait, and when you have your one hour break, time makes for more hunger and wait. Next time, I will phone my order in. When I opened my box, it contained fluffy, soft rice and the curry initially did not taste too spicy (medium spice), but once the flavors sunk into my tastebuds, yeah.. kinda spicy, but a good spicy. I LOVE the tsukemono (the picked vegetables) they added as a side. 

I will come back to sample the other dishes.
author: Thomas L.

description:
Came here finally! It's been on my list for the longest time. 

Line was long (as all the reviews say). I chose to ignore the fact that you can call in your order, and pick up (doh!). But it wasn't so bad. Wait in line, give your order to the lady writing down orders, pay, get your food within a minute. Easy peasy! 

I got the HOT tonkatsu. It really hit the spot. It wasn't insanely spicy, but it had heat and I loved it. But I do like my food spicy, so be warned! Brown rice was cooked perfectly along with the tonkatsu. The breading looked a little dark, but it was still moist and delicious! So I can't/won't complain. 

I'll make a repeat trek here for lunch. Yum!
author: Jeannie L.

description: Best katsu curry i've ever had. The curry sauce had a nice spice (you can specify mild/medium/hot) and richness. The katsu was juicy and tender on the inside and had a crispness on the outside that withstood the dowsing of curry sauce. Portion size is decent sized for the price. They do offer brown rice.
author: Eugene C.

description:
I tried out the beef curry and have to say it's pretty heavy so be prepared to gobble down some delicious meal that I think might be better for dinner. And even I like spicy food the medium spicy is not for the amateurs. It's the quiet spicy.

Also had the Lupicia tea which was good.

I had to take 1 star off because I found out they charged me as the Tonkatsu curry (probably because the girl who worked there was brand new and did not know how to put the orders into the cashier.)
author: T L.

description: Good food in general.  2 stars off for screwing up my order during off peak hours too.  Didn't get 1 item and the other items weren't made to order as requested.  Funny because when it's super busy, they get it right.
author: Paul G.

description:
HURRY HURRY GET ME SOME MURACCI'S JAPANESE CURRY!!!

This small, hole-in-the-wall place is TOTEMO OISHIII!! ^_^ hMMmmmM!!
It's REALLY small, but it seemed like most people were just getting their orders to go anyway, so my friend and I sat at the bar-style tables. It wasn't too busy (I can imagine it can get crazy with all the business people on their lunch break). We waited about 10 minutes.
The workers are awesome because they call out orders in Japanese! I studied it for 4 years in high school, so sometimes I could catch simple phrases! 

Anyway, I got the weekly special: Chicken Curry Nanban with shimeji mushrooms! It has buckwheat noodles, the shimeji mushrooms, green onions, bonito stock, and Muracci's curry sauce broth! It's only available until January 7 so I HAD to get it! I'm so glad I did too! :)  If I didn't, I'd probably think about it  regret it for the rest of my life! haha
I'm a wimp when it comes to spicy, so I got mine mild spicy and it was PERFECT! I've gotten Japanese curry at other places and it's either been a) too spicy or b) not even spicy. Muracci's got it down!
It's definitely filling, but not that ug-I'm-gonna-die full. 

Afterwards, my friend and I decided to split a curry bread ("curry pan").  That was really good as well! It was like a dumpling shaped croquette and inside was beef & chopped up veggies in a curry sauce! Yummy! 

I was torn between the weekly special and the salmon curry, so next time I'm going to try the latter! I was reading one of the signs that talked about the Japanese people like to put cheese on their curry, so I'll have to remember that! FREE WATER is available too!
author: Kei H.

description:
