My favorite lunch spots in the Financial District! Without hesitation, if someone asks me for a recommendation for lunch downtown, I'll tell them, try Muracci's! Their KATSU CURRY (not chicken) is one of the best katsu's I've ever had. Always fresh out of the fryer and consistently tender and moist, this is my go to order. The katsu lays on a bed of rice in a biodegradable container, with a small side of pickled cabbage and ginger, and a whole separate container for the curry (choose mild/medium/hot), always an appetizing sight! Servings are large and will fill you right up for lunch, watch out for that afternoon food coma at your desk! 

The few times I've tried other items here, I've always come away thinking I should have just ordered the katsu curry. The one biggest disappointment has been the beef curry. The beef was overdone and dry, lacking that same tender and moist character of the katsu. The ebi fry is good, but just not as filling, or for that matter, fulfilling of a portion as the katsu. I've ventured to try a few of their weekly specials, which too, have been good, but the katsu curry keeps me coming back! You can also substitute brown rice for white rice (no additional charge!) if you're into that.

The curry is fantastic. Apparently cooked overnight, it has robust flavors and is a great accompaniment to the meats (and non-meats) they have on offer. You can choose the spicyness from mild/medium/hot (and with that, you'll see the amount of chili in your curry rise). They don't skimp on the amount of curry you get with your entree, plenty to go around on your rice and katsu. 

A good appetizer while you wait for your mean is one of their Curry Pan's. Sitting on the counter next to the register, under the heat lamp, these little guys are fried pockets of goodness. Bread, fried with various curries inside (vege hot/regular, beef hot/regular, chicken hot/regular). Selection varies based on day/time of day. When they're fresh, they're amazing. but when they've been sitting for a while, they can be a little dry.

They have very limited seating inside, one table for 2, 4-5 seats at the front counter and another 4 seats at the side counter. This place is SMALL. If you're coming around peak lunch time, 11:45-1PM, typically plan to take out (BofA building's plaza is a short block away, as is St. Mary's Plaza if you're not toting back to your office). However, if you do eat in, you'll be treated to service on a large plate and silverware, with the rice/meat/curry spread out across it. 

If you're in a hurry and know what you want, call ahead and place your order for pickup. It typically takes them 10-20 minutes, depending on how busy it is. The wait in line can be daunting but it's well worth it. All of the people working here are very friendly, although can seem a bit less so when it's busy and the line is out the door. Somehow they manage to fit 5 people behind that counter...

CLIFFS: Delightful Katsu Curry, choose your curry's spicyness and kind of rice, small place (take out!), Peak lunch time = line
author: Justin S.

description:
WOW!  This place is so good!  We had the Curry pan while we waited for our food.....  this little treat is a delight!  Fried bread with curry inside -- delish!  We both ordered the Curry Katsu!  A friends recommended it as the best item!  So freaking good!  Cripsy pork cutlet wth curry sauce over brown rice!  Absolute heaven...  I am sitting in my cubicle savoring every bite!  I will most certainly go here again!  I am just sad I had not found it earlier.  

Tip: Order before you arrive so you can pick it up, it gets suuuuper busy during lunch in the financial district.
author: Jessica J.

description:
Tiny place in FiDi that is only open during lunch on weekdays.

There's no complicated reviews here. They make authentic, Japanese-styled curry. The owners are nice, and I chatted with them in Japanese, and they gave me a currypan (bread) to go on the house! While I make my own curry at home now and then, their unique kick of curry is not to be easily imitated. It's as good as it gets for a mid-day lunch!
author: Rui R.

description: The curry is thick and earthy with a lot of veggie pulp. It is the main course in the meal and the rice and chicken katsu is just for garnishing. They didn't do a good job cutting the chicken katsu, but I didn't mind picking up half the chicken portion and using it to scoop up more curry.
author: Lea M.

description:
Walked by this place during lunch time, line was not out the door but a good showing enough to catch my interest. The man takes your order, so be ready with what you want. I got the chicken katsu to go ($10.50). The chicken was lean and had a light fried touch to it. The pickled radishes are always a must with curry. 

All in all, I have a problem paying so much for something I can make at home myself.  I would come back to try other things on the menu but chicken and rice over curry for $10, I'll pass next time.
author: Andrew C.

description:
I love curry rice and it's relatively easy to make non-katsu versions at home. That being said, I wish the beef curry came with a little more stuff (veggies). Okay, okay, I get it. I order beef curry with rice and that's simply what I got. But a few baby carrots and onions wouldn't hurt...

Tastes great, love the brown rice option, a bit pricey. I'd recommend calling in your order to avoid waiting in the teeny restaurant. There's not much seating, so if you don't have an office to go back to.. maybe you can eat at the St. Mary's square nearby.
author: C. Z.

description:
Super delicious food and SUPER friendly owners and staff - SO fabulous!! I wish I could take this place back home with me to DC! I typically order the tender beef curry, spicy, with brown rice and potato salad (the potato salad is crazy delicious; it has broccoli and other totally unexpected vegetables - sounds crazy, but trust me, you'll love it).  I've also had the salmon teriyaki - that was also yummy, but I can't seem to deny myself the beef when I smell the curry as I walk in their door!

Call ahead so your order will be ready if you're trying to eat right after work (b/w 5:30-6:30pm) or expect to wait - this place is justifiably one of the most popular places on the border of the financial district and chinatown! 

If only they'd open a second location on the east coast, I'd be 20 lbs heavier, but SO thrilled!
author: Shalin C.

description:
I've been here twice and each time I thoroughly enjoyed the food. Definitely the best katsu curry I've ever got.

Why 3 stars then? Well I got the katsu curry to go today. And it was good as usual. However, as I had the last bite of the pork, I realized that the pork was raw :(. I understand that when you cook a ton of food, some of it is hard to get right. So hopefully the chef will see this and be careful with the orders next time!!
author: Ngan B.

description:
curry katsu chicken over rice.
tasty curry but bland chicken katsu. a little salt goes a long way, people!
i ordered the hot curry but it was only a  little bit spicier than normal japanese curry. the hot version of japanese curry at volcano on geary is more spicy.  when i get down to this part of the FIDI i will try it again. but for now, it's just an a-ok.
author: Jeff W.

description: This little hole in the wall was two blocks from my work.  I use to come here often when I worked nearby and miss it!  The curry is a one of a kind!  I love their Katsu curry, as well as,  their curry noodle soup.  They are always crowded everyday single day with a line out he door (especially during lunchtime), but the wait is not long compared to some places I have gone.  The line and wait seems to go by pretty fast!  There is only a few bar stool seating but most people order to go.  I can no longer go here as I work out or the city, but this place is a gem and who can beat freshly made curry daily?
author: FG L.

description: Came in super early right when they opened to try their vegetarian curry pan but left super disappointed because they did not have any. Hope to come back so I could try it!
author: Nancy L.

description:
Came here at around 11:30 and to my surprise, there wasn't a line! Lucky. And there were two empty seats for me and my friend. Even more lucky!

Since I'm not really a curry eater, I decided to get myself an oyakodon while my friend got the katsudon. We both enjoyed our dish; the rice was flavorful with the sauce and it meshed well with the egg and meat. I like how the store keeps cups and water pitchers on the bar table, so for anyone eating in can help themselves to water.

During our meal, the line just kept on getting longer and longer. By the time we headed out, the line was wellllllllll out of the door. As long as it's not prime time of lunch hour,  I wouldn't mind coming back! 

I sat near the cash register, so I kept on hearing people order the chicken katsu with curry. Despite not being a curry eater, I really want to order the star dish and give it a try!
author: Kirsten H.

description:
This is the BEST chicken katsu curry I have ever had! And it comes with a lot too! The chicken katsu is perfectly breaded and crunchy. The curry, when requested medium spicy, was actually spicy! Quick and great for lunch. I also love that you have the option to get brown rice too. And they take credit card!

This location is a bit small to dine in, so I recommend getting your order to go. No worries, it'll still be good.
author: Caroline C.

description:
Of all the things I ate, and I had a lot to eat on my recent vacation, this was one of my favorites. I've been to Japan several times and the curry here, as good or better than anything I've had in Japan and the price is definitely right. I split the chicken katsu curry with a friend and one gets a good deal of food for the price. If it was large enough to sit down and chat with someone and drink some hot green tea or a beer, it would be five starts but for the price and the quality (they simmer the curry sauce for 20 hours and it is delicious) it is worth a visit. I would have happily traded one or or two of my expensive meals for another meal from this place. 

If you are on vacation, like I was, go at an off time so you can sit there and enjoy it.
author: George L.

description:
I was craving some curry on a cold foggy SF day and yelped this place and decided to give it a shot.  I was left rather disappointed.

I think as others have pointed out, it's incredibly expensive for lunch given what you get. Rice is flattened down in a box (WTF) and wasn't cooked that great or interestingly. The curry sauce was tasty enough--I've had better but was still good. Meat was tender but there wasn't a lot of it. Overall the portions were a little small given the cost ($10+) although was filling enough as a lunch. 

I went around 11:30 and didn't experience any of the lines that people talked about but I couldn't see myself waiting in line for this. Go for it if money is no object--it's good (not amazing) curry. I'd give it 2.5 if I could, but I'll round up since most of the alternatives are worse. All things considered, I don't see myself going back.
author: Kyle P.

description: Ordering was a little hectic with the lunch rush, but the chicken katsu was awesome. The meat was really high quality, the breading was done well, and the curry was flavorful. Prices were fair. The rice was disappointing, but everything else was great!
author: Erika R.

description:
M y go-to lunch spot when I'm craving Japanese curry...
U nless the JapaCurry truck is around the area, that is
R ecommend the chicken katsu -- nicely breaded and meaty
A nd it's even good on its own, without the curry
C urry is well-flavored and has a nice consistency
C hicken donburi could be better -- it's a bit bland
I nstead ask for Chicken Katsu Donburi (not on the menu), they'll make it for you!
author: Anthony N.

description:
When your name states your specialty, it better be good.  In this case, they did not disappoint.  Because I bounce between two neighborhoods, my schedule doesn't normally allow me to come here since they are primarily open for lunch.  I was fortunate to have a friend surprise me with an order of their famed Curry Katsu, mild curry as a take-home dinner.  When I opened the bag, I was happy that there were two containers: one with a bed of rice with some red pickled vegetables topped with carefully placed and still-warm, crispy pork cutlet slices and the other cylindrical box with the warm curry sauce; almost forgot to mention the small tiny paper cup of pickled cabbage.  Was it the best I ever had?  Close, but no cigar (see Menchanko Tei - Honolulu).  The sauce is what makes this experience different.  The menu explains that the sauce is prepared a day in advance, allowing the veggies and other ingredients to permeate.  I hope to try their medium next time to test my spiciness tolerance.
If you told me that this quality food was available for less than $10.00 in the Financial District, I'd call you a liar.... boy, was I wrong about this.  If you are a curry fan and work in the area, this is THE spot.
author: Mike C.

description:
I can't really choose between this and Japacurry. To me each of them have their distinct flavors so it's really just a matter of preference. While I find Japacurry to be richer in flavor, I like the curry texture and slightly bigger portions of Muracci's. Also, there are more offerings to be had over here if you don't feel like eating curry.

Some pointers to remember:
- Call ahead of time for your order (lunch) as it gets insanely packed during peak lunch hours.
- There is only one line for ordering and paying. Do not let the line discourage you, it is worth it!
- They have a mini-deli of sorts on the counter where you can order their cakes or potato croquette with your meal.
- The place is very SMALL with some seating areas.

Oishi desu-ne!
author: Rachelle Q.

description:
Katsu Curry Hot is the only thing I get

Tonkatsu is fried crispy but the interior is nice and moist. 
Curry sauce is excellent.

Its hard for me not to go here every week
author: Greg M.

description:
Came here one day for lunch when the line had 4 people in it. I was amazed since the line is usually out the door by noon. I've heard plenty of good things about this place and wanted to try it for quite some time, but the line was always too long.

The place is tiny, and it seems like more kitchen then seating area. One line from the register to out the door, and a ton of people standing inside waiting for their to-go order. There are a few bar seats in the front, but I suggest taking food out.

They take orders while you stand in line and then give you a slip to give to the cashier. I got the chicken katsu with extra vegetables, spicy. It was quick to order, but a lot longer to wait.

The chicken is crispier compared to other curry places, and I love how the vegetables are put into the curry, which makes them tastier. It's a decent amount of food, a breaded chicken cutlet, rice, and vegetables. I really enjoyed it, but I didn't notice a difference in the taste of the curry compared to other places.

I like this place, and I'd come back if the line wasn't so dang long all the time!
author: Andrew T.

description: i came in probably an hour before closing. i gave it 3 stars because of the taste. the curry is pretty good, decent serving. mochi they sell there is not very good, skip that one. paid almost $20 for my meal. way to pricey or they over charged me.
author: Karen V.

description:
This place is great.

Katsu and Curry.  Simple and just gets it right.  Big thick piece of katsu, big container of curry.  Everything is convenient to-go containers.

There is a little wait because they are frying all the katsu meats to order.

It get super crowded at lunch so if you come here plan on ordering to-go.
author: Steven F.

description:
One of my favorite places in SF. Seriously, once you've been here, there will be days where you'll get a hankering for Japanese curry that only Muracci's can satiate. Folks, today's that day. It's about a mile walk from my office, but it's totally worth it. Got there a little past 12nn -- about 15 people in line ahead of me. Albeit the long line, my friend and I were able to get a table right away. Waited about 10-15 minutes to get my order, and when I finally did, what do I do? I KNOCK THE WHOLE THING OVER, FACE DOWN. Perfect fried pork cutlets and white rice struck down in the prime of life. I was speechless. When I finally got myself together from this horrific incident, I told the kitchen what happened and they gladly replaced my order for free in just a matter of seconds. So amazing. Got the 'hot' option instead of my usual 'mild' and it delivered. There's definitely an extra kick. Whoever said their curry sauce is bland must be really old and have only 50/10000 working taste buds (I'm looking at you, Jen W.) 

The only "complain" I have is the tiny space -- I always think that with all the curry money they're making, I'm sure they're able to expand. But then again, there's something about it being a hole-in-the-wall. So I take back what I said and have no complaints! Looking forward to coming back here soon.
author: Trixy S.

description:
I really like this place!

It's a quick walk from work and you can always call in first.  The wait time is around 15 minutes.

I've eaten here twice and had the ton katsu curry both times.  Because it was just so good.  The katsu is very well made.  Definitely not the usual dry/rough piece of meat with oil oozing out from the breaded part. No.  The katsu was tender and well fried.  The curry, just makes everything else more amazing.  You can choose how you like your curry.  I love how their mild is mild, medium is medium.  For a lot of other places I've been to (not only curry ones), their medium is like.. mild.  I think Muracci definitely does a good job at fulfilling every demand.

There is not much seating inside, just a few seats along the wall in a very compact space.  People usually just get take-out from this place.  

Definitely recommending this place!
author: Emily W.

description:
Best pork katsu curry around town at a reasonable price ($9) AND large portions. You can't go wrong with spicy katsu curry over white rice. The pork is thick and juicy and the curry is flavorful. 

JUST GO.
author: Julie C.

description:
Best Japanese Curry Place in the bay area. 

I always get the Chicken Katsu Curry with rice :-)

Muracci's never disappoints. I always recommend my friends here and they love it as much as I do after they try it.
author: Monica T.

description:
After being bookmarked for a while, I finally got the chance to try Muracci's.  Knowing that getting to the FiDi from China Basin during lunch hour can eat up a good amount of time, my coworker and I planned ahead and left early enough to beat most of the lunch traffic.  Good thing we did too:  get to Muracci's in 10 minutes or less?  Check.  Get parking right in front?  Check.  No line, no lunch crowd?  Barely checked.  I'd say 2 minutes after we got there, the line started to form and it formed pretty fast.  (Btw, there isn't really any place to eat inside and it was always our intention to go back to work and eat, so parking right out front in the metered truck loading area was ok.  Err...not legal, but okay for a few minutes I guess.)

Anyways, on to the food.  I went with the chicken katsu curry with vegetables as an extra topping.  Overall, it was just okay.  The chicken and the flavoring were there, but nothing really stood out.  I may have had my expectations high after reading some other reviews, but really, the curry sauce was too thin for me.  I like it thick, and I've read some people say that it is thick at Muracci's.  Maybe I caught them on an off day?  Either way, I felt let down since I had been waiting to try this place for a few months.  Like having a long day at work and getting a watered-down rum and coke at happy hour.  Although, I must say that I did inhale the entire plate and I was sufficiently sleepy for the rest of the afternoon.  So it wasn't bad....it just didn't meet my expectations.  I still hold JapaCurry as the standard, but Muracci's will do in a pinch.
author: Joe M.

description:
A big group of us headed out into FiDi to grab the katsu curry for lunch on a sunny day.  Because we had so many orders, we were able to compare/contract between the quality.  Apparently, it's either hit or miss.

Thankfully, mine was a hit.  The katsu was battered/breaded and then fried to perfection.  My brown rice was fantastic.  My curry was hot, though not as spicy as I'd like.

This is much too long of a trek to make it a regular lunch stop, but it stays in the rotation!
author: Jenny L.

description: I've heard many raving reviews of Muracci's from friends and coworkers. I finally had a chance to go as I was at Topsy's across the street. I got the Chicken Katsu with Curry. I think the curry was awesome, it had the perfect amount of spice. However, you don't get as many pieces of chicken katsu as I would like, but at least the breading ratio to chicken is appropriate. You're not just eating fried junk.  The people working there are fairly nice and attentive. Overall, it was an alright experience.
author: Kelvin N.

description: Really really miss this place. I now work in SoMa and it's just too far to go for lunch. My favorite is the katsu donburi. Don't expect to be able to eat it for about ten minutes--it's that hot.
author: Brian H.

description: Had the curry pan,  it was cold and didn't taste as good as what the reviews say. Might come back and try something else on their menu.
author: Eatdrink L.

description:
It's really small and was jam-packed! There are a total of 10 stool seats and 1 small table for 2. You really have to beat the rush during lunch time - it's quite popular! Operated and cooked by real Japanese people (except the guy in charge of the frying) is comforting to know.

I didn't start liking Japanese-style curry until 2 years ago and even then I never really craved it; growing up, I always preferred Indian, Afghan, Chinese or Thai-styles. But now I'm turning into a fan of Japanese curry, or at least for Muracci's Japanese curry I am!

For curries, you get to choose the level of spicy-ness and what kind of rice (brown or white) you want. On my first viist I got the grilled salmon with hot curry sauce and brown rice. The curry wasn't really spicy, but it was very flavourful and not too thick or paste-like. The salmon was grilled just well, so it was moist on the inside and crispy on the outside - very nice. I thought the portions and prizes were pretty reasonable compared to other FiDi options. 

They have other items such as udon/ramen, donburi's, katsu plates, side dishes and a la carte items. Ordering is really simple, you can even fax or phone in to avoid the wait! There's an express line for mild curry with beef or chicken orders, I believe.

My second visit I their almost-monthly special for December, which was the "spicy noodles". It consisted of ramen/egg noodles with ground beef, green onions, onions, hot chili pepper and seasoning. They claimed that they only made 15 orders of these a day.

It was not bad, though not really spicy (though I already expected that.) The noodles were the best part - very soft and al dente and were packed with egg flavour. The sauce was very appetizing and could go well with many other carb-enriched items. 

I also had their curry with beef; the sauce was good like before and the beef was very tender, though too little in quantity. 

Muracci's is definitely worth the try because it's not like your average Japanese curry. But the seating really sucks, even if you find a seat. I recommend going before 12 or after 1 if your time is flexible!
author: Grace C.

description: The food here is not consistent. Sometimes is too spicy and sometimes is not. The last time I tried is too spicy that I have to keep drinking water and still couldn't finish the meal.
author: Stacy T.

description:
Relatively speaking, I'd put this place at the top of (Japanese) curry offerings in the city.

I don't stray too far from the fundamentals -- i.e. beef curry with rice.  Though I'll make it brown rice sometimes just because I like the texture change.

Curry pan is fantastic too.

The katsu is pretty good too, both pork and chicken, but for some reason I get too distracted by it and always end up wanting the simple beef.

Yes, it is way too crowded here during rush hour, which is why I try to go during the slow periods.  End up walking home and eating it there.

I wish they were also open on the weekends, but the FiDi is just too dead during that time I suppose.
author: Chris E.

description: Cool mom and pop joint that serves some damn good chicken katsu curry over rice. The curry sauce just makes this dish pop! The only request I have is that the temperature of the food needs to be higher. Remember to come before noon or call and place an order for pick up to avoid the lines.
author: T L.

description: Lines can get long during lunch but you can order ahead and pick up. They spices in the curry is to die for! Get it 3 times hot! Some people get it 10 times hot but that's too damn spicy. Wish they gave more katsu with each order. Extra katsu is 9.95. Pricy but the curry is worth it
author: Allen L.

description:
Decent, fast lunch! I got the chicken ramen at a medium spicyness level. I probably would've been okay with the mild level, but the heat was definitely tolerable, and I don't consider myself a spice person. I was skeptical at ordering noodle soup in a to-go form, but they nicely package the soup and noodles separately so that you simply pour the curry over the noodles when you're ready to eat, and the flavor immediately infuses the carbs. At first, I thought that the small-looking clump of noodles wouldn't be enough, but my eyes prove time and time again to be bigger than my stomach and I became pleasantly full after consuming everything. They serve a strong, dark brown curry soup that I tasted in my mouth for the rest of the day, but not in an entirely bad way. There was a fair amount of chicken, but I could've used more veggies.   

I have to say that I am really impressed at the way they have streamlined service to best serve a maximum amount of customers out of their tiny space. When I went, there was an older gentleman walking in front to take orders while taking phone orders on a headset--ultimate multitasking skills--and he'd shout the menu items to the kitchen area, who would assemble the entrees lightning fast so that one's food is ready shortly after one pays at the cashier, further down the line. The service is actually pretty great for the very casual setting: when the man asked "to-go" or "for-here" our facial expressions showed that we wanted to eat in but doubted that there would be room and he quickly assured us that we could eat "to-go" food in house if there was space, and we did indeed manage to get two chairs. Second, he found the time amidst the restaurant hullabaloo to bring me water while I was eating, which was unexpected but showed that the workers are extremely attentive.

Difficult to snag a seat during the lunch rush, but if you have a dining partner you can tag team it and enjoy a cute Japanese meal. A tad pricey for what you get, though it's definitely enough to satiate and I probably just have to get used to prices in the city.
author: Amy G.

description:
The trick is to call in your order for to-go and bypass the massive lines during peak hours. :) 

Katsu curry, medium hot, was delicious! The katsu was crispy but not dried. And the curry came in a cup so you can drizzle as much / as little as you want. Medium hot curry was not too spicy for me, but definitely has a kick to it. 

I would return
author: Judy L.

description:
Chicken curry was deeeeeeelish! You have a choice of mild, medium or spicy and the medium has the perfect amount of spice (if you're like me and can handle a tiny kick.) I don't know what the pickled veggies are (cabbage and bell pepper maybe?) but I'd like to try more. 

Yum.
author: Lesley Amor G.

description:
I ordered "weekly special curry" that was 2 slices of deep fried tilapia and brown rice($13.50) 

Food was ok, crispy fried tilapia was delicious. but place was small, so you may not sit and stay there long time. Roughly 10 seats available.
author: Tammy M.

description:
4 stars, just cause not ALL their stuff is 5-star. But the katsu curry is awesome.

Not a huge fan of katsu curry in general, but I get the one here because its fried just right, sauce is awesome. Great if you want a cheap bite near FiDi, or if youre lurkin around Chinatown and want some Japanese grub.

Super crowded during lunch time, no place to sit. Great for taking it togo and eating in the office though!
author: Ryan C.

description: Tiny hold in the wall place with little to no seating. Great pork katsu curry with pickled cabbage/radish. My only suggestion is that I wish they would add a vegetable. Quick, tasty, a definite must.
author: Doris K.

description: This is the place if you like katsu curry. Their curry is so flavorful I don't think you can't find a better one anywhere in the city. I do like it mild, so I can't judge on the spiciness.
author: Davide D.

description: It gets the job done but pricey. It's not the best nor the worst curry. Got the chicken curry, will come back and try other items such as the curry bun.
author: jasmin t.

description: I have gone to Muracci's at least 50 times over the last few years I've worked nearby. I have almost always ordered the chicken katsu curry medium. I have always been pretty happy with the product (bland chicken but delicious sauce makes it all better). But today... TODAY... I have absolutely no idea what happened today. I opened it up and the piece of chicken was half the size of what it normally is, the katsu batter was not stuck on the chicken AT ALL (when i cut the chicken, the batter fell right off), the chicken was super tough and rubbery as if it wasn't even real chicken, and the curry sauce smelled and tasted smokey. I have no idea what happened, but it was so disgusting, I threw it out because it wasn't edible and I feared it would make me sick. This is the first time I had to throw my Muracci's curry out. And it's so unacceptable, I tried to email them, but the email came back invalid. Then I tried to call, but the line's been busy for 25 minutes straight. So I'm now writing this post. I really hope this was a one-time thing, but I'm almost afraid to spend $13 again just in case it's not.
author: Darryl Y.

description: They have a long azzz line for a reason!!!  Ebi fry curry is perfect!  Kids love chicken karaage!!
author: Marie I.

description: Worth the wait during the lunch rush. When I get the pork katsu curry, the amount of meat doesn't seem consistent, but it's still good to me! Prepare for a food coma afterward.
author: Samantha H.

description:
The Japanese are known for compact, efficient things. Take the Honda Civic, for example, or any number of buildings around Tokyo. Muracci's Japanese Curry & Grill is certainly compact, but they are a little less than efficient.

I had seen the lines in this place before, so I made sure to call my order in ahead of time. I thought this would insulate me from the wait, but I was mistaken. Although I showed up 15 minutes after the order had been taken over the phone I still had to wait awhile, and that sucked. It defeated the purpose of ordering for take out.

Aside from that, this place would certainly be *5* star worthy. This was probably some of the best chicken katsu Ive ever had. Seriously. My socks were knocked off. I honestly contemplated going back to the shop and proposing to the punk rock Japanese girl that took my order (she had a bad-ass Black Flag knuckle tattoo -- hard core) just because it was so good. Someday, I suppose.
author: Wes T.

description:
Although Muracci's is always busy during lunch hours, it moves fast despite the long lines. When I order the katsu or chicken curry, I'm usually in and out in 10-15 minutes. I recommend ordering take out because this location isn't really sitdown. It's too small for groups and you will be crammed. 

I usually prefer thicker curry, but Muracci's curry is really good. Their curry is a little light in flavor and not as thick. Which is great for lunch because it doesn't sit as heavy. It's also a plus that they have brown rice as an option. 

IMO, it's a bit over-priced for what you get (even have to pay extra for the pickled radish). But considering you spend approx $7-$10 for lunch in the area anyways, it's reasonable.
author: Chris Y.

description: Only been here once, had the ton katsu curry, mild. Definitely yummy, but my only suggestion would be to add more potatoes/carrots/onions in the curry! Aside from that, I'll probably come here tomorrow.
author: David P.

description: Popular lunch spot. The line may look long but it goes fast. Got the grilled chicken curry and it was just spicy enough for me. The portion was a little small but I guess you get what you pay for since it was one of the cheaper dishes. Will definitely go again.
author: XiaoChuan Y.

description:
So simple, yet so delish! 

Food: This has to be one of my favorite Japanese curry places! I always order the vegetable/tofu curry, spicy, with white rice, add an egg. It hits the spot every time I come here.  The consistency is just right, the portion is a good size (kind of big, but never a bad thing!), and the food is always fresh and made to order. They also give you a little container of pickled cabbage and some pickled raddish served on top of your rice.  They also give you your rice/meat separate from your curry, so you can decide how much curry to put on your rice. LOVE IT! 

Ambiance: the place is VERY small, which is part of where it gets its charm :) The line is usually out the door by 11:45.. so it is always good to get here a little early, probably around 11:30 (especially if you want to get a seat).  They have one table and about six-eight bar stools.  The place is rather crowded, especially when people are waiting in line or waiting to get there food, so if you can't get a table seat, I would suggest taking the food to go and finding a nice spot outside somewhere.  

Service: The works are always friendly and are super quick! The old man who maintains the people in line and takes their orders, is always fast and watches out for seating if you request you want to eat there.  

Price: Great price for what you get! 

Always a great spot to hit up during lunch time. I want to try and come here for catering sometime soon.
author: Ashley M.

description:
The line is so annoying. Always out the door and down the sidewalk. The people who call in advance and cut the line to pay are extra irritating. 

The food is good though, so worth the wait.
author: breana c.

description: Is Japanese Curry a common food item? I had never heard of it until Muracci's. Clearly I've been missing out! Breaded meat with rice and some ridiculously good curry sauce makes for a delicious, filling meal with a nice crunch to it. They have lunch sets that come with a salad, appetizer, rice, miso soup, and entree, but they're sadly not curry dishes. So I ordered the Chicken Katsu Curry and I'm so glad I did! That curry sauce is AWESOME. It comes on the side so don't forget to drench your meat and rice in it!
author: Talia G.

description:
There's always a line. Deal with it.

My go-to item here is the chicken katsu, medium curry with spinach, brown rice. SO tasty, and it's PLENTY of food.

The salmon fry is a little short on the portion, to be honest. It was like, three small pieces of salmon.

People at work always eye my take-out container with blatant envy as I pour the delicious curry over the breaded chicken. Maybe they should have stood in line with me, then!

Eating at the restaurant during the lunch rush is like, "Yes, I want to be packed tighter than sardines while attempting to enjoy my food." Not recommended; just get it to go.

And try the Curry Pan if you're extra-hungry or there's a long-ish wait. Totally worth the price, and it's quite satisfying.
author: Cody K.

description:
TWO days to prepare their curry.  need to say more?  20+ hours or simmering curry....

i like to have my chicken curry a bit spicy.  With their famous radish and brown rice option, this is the place for Japanese Curry.  Seating is limited so don't expect to bring a group of 4 to enjoy this meal.  It's only meant to eat by yourself or with a friend...even that, the space might be too tight...

if anything takes TWO days to make, it's worth a try.  You won't be disappointed in their curry.  It's so sad that I destroyed this dish in 2min.  
It's like a relationship.  It takes forever to build but only few seconds to just destroy it.  Wonderful.
author: Jang David K.

description:
When you want comfort food, think Japanese.  What can be more comforting than deep fried food immersed in a fragrant Japanese curry?  This is probably the only joint in the FiDi that consisently serves high quality curry.  Delica has it sometimes, but no where near as good!

Korokke: Some korokkes are pretty bland, but this one is awesome because it has curry mixed into the potato base.  It also wins on filling to deep fried surface area ratio with the size being like a thick hash brown.

Spicy Curry: The center piece of any respectable meal at Muracci's.  I suspect it is homemade because it is way better than those curry cubes obtained from Japantown.  Spicy (the highest level) has a good kick, but is not insanity.  I like that they give the curry in a separate container so you can choose how much to allocate to each food item.

Katsu: What can make deep fried meat taste even better?  Curry!  Mostly  a good cut of pork (found a small gristle piece).  Crispy outside without too much batter.

Cheese Topping: Pre-mixed in the curry bucket.  Makes the curry milky/creamy, not so much cheesy.  Not recommended.

Potato Topping: One of the only things not fried!  A few chunks of boiled potatoes thrown in your curry bucket.  Good way to add an extra bit of heartiness to your curry, but no culinary innovation with boiled potatoes.

Boiled Egg Topping: Sliced (as it should be for Japanese food).  Love how the yolk absorbs a bit of the curry for a blast of pasty goodness.

Pickled Cabbage: Bland and vinegary.  Perhaps the Koreans have cornered the market on good pickled cabbage.

Japanese Pickle: It's red and salty and not too vinegary.  Can't really say it has a distinct taste aside from that.
author: Adam B.

description: Love Muracci's! Never had a bad meal here. Prepare to wait a long time in line at lunch but if you swing by at the end of the day its worth it. Fantastic curry stocks, great addons, brilliant katsu. Don't miss Muracci if you want good curry. Reminds me of when we lived in Tokyo :)
author: Jim S.

description:
I'm not one of those "Oh, I taught English in Japan/lived in Japan for __ years so I know Japanese food" kind of people, but I know Japanese curry really well. I used to live in West LA and frequent Orange County for a few years (these areas have excellent Japanese restaurants), and I used to eat Japanese curry at least once a week. 

After moving home to SF, I had the intense craving for Japanese curry and read about Muracci's on yelp. I showed up before the lunch crowd and was prepared to be blown away by the curry here.

Hmm, I wasn't blown away, it was more of a light breeze. Maybe my expectations were too high. I thought the chicken breaded cutlet was a bit dry and overcooked, and the curry was standard. The price was really expensive for the amount of food I received and I was annoyed that that I had to pay extra for pickled radishes. I'm used to Japanese restaurants having that available to patrons in a jar on the table. I'll chalk up the added expense of a meal here due to being in the FiDI. 

I wouldn't make a special trip out here to Japanese curry, but Muracci's is a good option if you're in the area.
author: Monelle A.

description: Muracci's curry is deep and complex. Thick and rich. Perfectly seasoned. Just hot enough. I can tell it was slow cooked for at least 2 days. No lack of love went into their roux. The owner was speaking a friendly Japanese dailect - Osakaben I think.  I ordered in Japanese and he put a little reserved sign on the counter for me. Medium hotness curry with big Ebi fried shrimp. Tasted like home.
author: Grayson K.

description:
We had lunch delivered to us for a business meeting. I love Japanese curry, esp Coco Ichiban curry house in Hawaii, but I thought Muracci was just OK. Definitely not anything like coco Ichiban. 
The katsu was dry and not very flavorful. 
The curry was good but not great. 

The delivery was right on time (actually they were early) which is much appreciated for a business lunch (as opposed to the useless Osha delivery ppl)
author: Jocelyn L.

description:
New favorite lunch spot! But that's what I say about almost everyplace...and then I get bored of it. lol but this place is really great.

Their curry reminds me of my mom's Japanese curry. Anything that reminds you of mom's cooking is good right?
Filled with savory love and goodness.

Unless your mom was a horrible cook like someone I know (haha hit or miss)

Recommend getting take out, the place isn't for eating in.

I've tried the Chicken Curry ($7.50) so far and added vegetables for an extra $0.75. So goooooood. I can't wait to try all their other dishes. I think I'll go for the Fried Tofu & Vegatable Curry next ;)

They have a lot of good side dishes like Agedashi Tofu, Edamame, Karaage and Ebi Fry.

Just go there!
author: Teresa W.

description: Boo. Not a fan. I got the mild chicken curry. There was a major lack of chicken. I only got about three mediocre (in taste and size) pieces. The curry was too sweet for my taste so I would recommend getting the spicer versions. The brown rice was this dish's saving grace. It was cooked perfectly. Not going back here.
author: Ryann M.

description:
Awesome Japanese Curry to satisfy my cravings during the work week. 
What I've had so far:
1. Pork Katsu Curry with Brown Rice - typically what I order. I usually get medium spicy which adds just enough heat without overpowering the curry flavor. The Pork is breaded perfectly and it's not super oily. I usually order it as is  it plain but once added spinach...it's nice to have the vegetables but the extra cost doesn't make it worth it.

2. Tofu and Veggie Curry with Brown Rice - I tried this once. It was good, as always came with their flavorful curry. The tofu was lightly fried and the vegetables consisted of 3 vegetables: broccoli, carrots and another one that has slipped my mind. The one thing that I didn't like was that there is less curry given to you in the to-go container because the tofu and veggies are in curry instead of being on top of the rice.

3. Spicy beef noodle - very tasty but beware of the greasy and upset stomach you may get after. I got the "normal" spicy which was pretty spicy for me. Each bite I took was delicious but the aftermath didn't feel so nice. If you've ever had boiling crab...that is what it felt like after. Too much grease and spice. 

Overall, a great Japanese curry place. It doesn't get 5 stars because I feel that it is a bit overpriced for what it has to offer. Also, it's a small place that doesn't provide much room to sit down and enjoy your curry. Japanese curry isn't super smelly...but you can def smell it in the office.
author: Karis L.

description:
Best Japanese curry I've had since I first had it as a boy in Tokyo. They serve it at an actual edible temperature as opposed to burning hot, and just the right amount if you're feeling hungry. And get the curry pan, which is a Japanese fry bread filled to the brim with delicious curry. At $2.95 they're a great grab and go snack that has veggies, carbs and protein. Just be sure to get them early while they're fresh and before I've bought all of them ; )
This place has got the goods. Be prepared to stand in line if you're coming in at lunch time-it'll be worth the wait (surprisingly, you'll be waiting longer in line than you will be for your food when you order; the place runs like a well-oiled machine). I'd make a daily habit of coming here if it wasn't half an hour away and I could afford to eat 2-3 meals out every day.
author: Brian W.

description:
Been here plenty of times for lunch. A very solid Fidi lunch choice- not too expensive, pretty quick, and very tasty. 

During lunch hours, it's usually packed, so call ahead and you can skip the line. Everybody raves about the katsu curry and if you are a first timer, you should go for it. But, if like me, you are on a non-fried food diet, the chicken curry is super tender and flavorful as well. They offer brown rice at no extra charge, which is also very clutch. Usually a curry dish will run you about 8-9$. 

I wouldn't advise eating here as it's really small, though it really reminds of Japan! It's tiny and you can hear the workers yelling orders in Japanese, which makes the food taste even better. 

Bottom line: Good authentic Japanese curry for a reasonable price. Call in and avoid the wait!
author: Michael I.

description:
Today I decided to give Muracci a try.

Boy, am I glad.

The food is impeccable. Delicious food with decent portions.

Only downfall, not the fault of the restaurant is, that it's TOO popular! At certain busy times, the line can get quite long. However the ladies are quick workers, and you should get your stuff in no time.

DELICIOUS FOOD. CANT GO WRONG!!
author: Jessica D.

description:
Muracci's is the best Japanese Curry place in the bay. They have another location in Los Altos that is a sit down restaurant. This one is more for fast dining.   

I normally eat vegetarian food and found their vegetarian curry to be much better than any other that I have had. Normally, restaurants just give vegetarians the same normal curry minus the proteins like pork or chicken. This means that the vegetables are usually limited to onions, carrot and potatoes. Muracci's also puts tofu, broccoli and bell peppers in their curry.  

The only thing I wish is that they were open on weekends.
author: Arun V.

description: Great spot to pop into for a weekday lunch if you're craving something warm and comforting. The curry is pretty tasty, but I wouldn't say it's extraordinary.  The restaurant itself is tiny and has limited seating, so take out is a good option.
author: Tiffany W.

description:
Mmmmmmmmmmm........ SO AUTHENTIC and TASTY!  This place reminded me of my Japanese mom's curry.  Thick and hearty... mild is just spicy enough... incredibly flavorful and you can tell fresh ingredients are used.

Basic pluses that help the cause:
-Good portion!  Not too much, not too little... all of us finished quite satisfied.
-Perfect amount of curry to spread among your rice and katsu.  At first I thought it might not be enough... but it was ppeeerrfect.
-Great option to get brown rice instead of white!
-VERY flavorful and tender katsu (if only it were thicker like in Japan!)

After I finished my bottle of tea (a PET bottle), I asked if they recycled (since you always recycle PET bottles in Japan) and the lady was like "uhh yeah..." but then threw it in a random bin.  So I guess they don't??  Sad.

Gets quite crowded so come early!
Place only seats about 10 people...

I wish there was a Muracci's down in the south bay...
author: Ruth C.

description: The curry here is delicious and filling. They are really generous with the meat and sauce. Not much seating room so be prepared to take out if you can't get a seat. Totally worth it though! The staff are very nice too. Even if you're not normally a fan of curry, you will probably enjoy their Japanese curry. It's so yummy!
author: Lauren T.

description:
Whoa, really! This stuff is incredible. I got the Katsu Curry and it was the tastiest meals I've had for lunch in a long time. Delicious pork over a bed of rice and a bowl of hot curry... you betcha.

Only come here if you want to be completely satisfied for lunch. If you are in the mood for mediocre food this is not your spot. For how small of a place it is / how busy it is, they sure have figured out how to pump that stuff out at an incredible speed.

I've never had Japanese Curry before but this is the beginning of an era. Nom... nom.... nom.
author: Jason M.

description: First time and loved the curry!  No wonder this place gets packed at lunch!  Went before NOON and was able to grab the only little table!
author: Daphnie A.

description:
Popular "mom & pop" shop during lunch. Line usually is out the door. The food here is great and decently priced for being in the financial district. The place is small and dining inside is pretty tight. Coming here for the first time, I missed the place and had to backtrack -- didn't see the small sign by the door.

I had the chicken katsu with curry .... delicious.
author: Robb J.

description: Best Japanese curry place around the area - love their pork katsu with extra spicy curry yummm!!!
author: Lulu L.

description:
I have come to the realization that I am not the biggest fan of Japanese curry. Don't get me wrong I pretty much love all things Japanese; high on that list of favorites are Japanese raw denim, Japanese hair wax, and Uniqlo. But Japanese curry just doesn't do it for me.

Muracci's is the Japanese take on a hole-in-the-wall grab-and-go type of lunch place. This place is tiny, but clean! 

If you want a quick grab-and-go lunch that is cheap, fried, and substantial, this is a great option. The Japanese curry is good and tastes like, well, curry. If you like spicy, be warned that the "hot" version is pretty mild. No need to call 911 because shawty was definitely not burning it up on the dance floor in the pit of my stomach oh whoaaa oh. 

Curry, C-atsu, and Clean. Muracci's in a nutshell.
author: Allan Y.

description:
This place is nestled in the heart of the city, in walking distance from Montgomery BART and Union Square. It's more of a take-out place, but has ~5 seats at the window bars.

I love Japanese curry, and was delighted to find Muracci's in SF after worrying that I would have to wait until my next visit to LA to enjoy some .

Come here and stick to the basics; I love the katsu curry and the ebi (shrimp) curry. The portions are generous, and the curry is available in mild, normal, and spicy. Avoid the lunch time crowd and you should be fine!
author: Hanui C.

description:
Okay, I just had to read a few reviews, and heed Euge's review to try this place...

Totally teeny-tiny spot.

Tonkatsu curry (hot) = delicious (but you will want lots of it, and now I know why people said order extra sauce lol)!!!!  Oh, and they keep the sauce in a separate container (so no soggy katsu/rice!)   Tonkatsu, moist inside, crispy outside.  Flavorful too.  I also love the pickled veggies with the food...XD I wanted to eat all of it for lunch, but I saved it for dinner.  Drool.  

Do yourself a favor and call the order in....as it really lives up to all of the hype!!! The lines can get long but they don't take too long.  

Prices = reasonable.  They take plastic too!! XD



I think I finally found a good place for lunch!!! XD 
*doing the peanut-butta-jelly-time dance*  
*hiding her wallet, so I bring in brown bag lunch instead of getting this*
author: Fannie S.

description:
An authentic Japanese Curry place. Ran by Japanese expats, and selling some interesting Japanese items like fried potato curry croquets, japanese teas, and Japanese Rail Tickets. Yes i said Japanese Rail Tickets.


Ebi Fry (3 big fried prawns, on brown or white rice, and a container of curry sauce) Curry (#5) at a fair $9.25 (before tax), was tasty and well portioned.  Murracci's is tiny and the line was out the door, the wait was a bit long. The food was great, and worth the money and the wait, however i dont see myself going out of my way, or standing in that line again for it.

So you could say these guys are a experiencing a downside of their own success. A good problem to have :)
author: Oleg H.

description:
I've tried making Japanese curry at home with various powders and mixes (e.g., Golden Curry) and Muracci's curry is SO much better.  It's got this rich, slightly sweet, deep flavor that you can't get from a box.  It's dark brown with flecks of carrots and chili flakes. 

I placed my order at the counter (salmon curry, spicy, with brown rice, $8.95) and then waited while they cooked my order (the sign says they don't cook it till you order it).  The counter has a taped menu and they crossed out sold out items - looks like katsu curry items are the most popular.  The prices are quite reasonable, lunch sets that come with rice, salad and miso soup start at $7.50 and donburi dishes are $6.95. They sell Lupicia tea, salads, bottled drinks and 6 types of roll cake ($1.75 each). 

To speed things along, they also offer the Express Curry special - mild beef or chicken curry with rice.  

The curry comes in a separate container.  I never expect hot/spicy to be spicy when it comes to Japanese food but the curry actually had a good spicy kick to it.  The grilled salmon was delicious even without curry - a good quality piece of salmon, grilled properly with pretty grill marks.  Even the salmon skin was tasty.  The housemade pickles (fukujinzuke) and pickled cabbage were nice crunchy complements to the salmon and brown rice.  

The vanilla roll cake was soft and dense with a buttery, creamy filling.  It was good but I like my cake lighter and spongier and my filling less buttery.

Mr. Muracci was there that day overseeing the kitchen.  It's a tiny place with seats for 10 people - reminds me of GoGo Curry in NYC only not as crazy and Japanese.  At Go Go Curry, I heard people speaking Japanese and they had Japanese programming on TV.  At Muracci, I heard people speaking Chinese and English and they were listening to the radio - in English.  Though Go Go feels more Japanese, Muracci's has better curry.  Too bad you can't add natto to the curry (Go Go has that option).
author: Lolia S.

description:
When I want some kick-ass Japanese curry, Muracci's is where I go.  The beef curry udon noodle soup (extra hot!!!) with carrots and broccoli rocks my world.

THEY AREN'T KIDDING WHEN THEY SAY EXTRA HOT! Wash it down with some Japanese green tea.  Waddle back to office.  Burp up curry for the rest of the afternoon.
author: Sherry C.

description: Really good Japanese style curry, had the grilled salmon with brown rice, simple but well done. The potato croquette is unlike any other I've tried in sf, the best so far!
author: joan l.

description: A quintessential hole in the wall with superb food! A diverse menu, but dishes sell out daily. I had the tofu vegetable ramen bowl, medium spice, and it was fabulous. My friend had the beef curry with brown rice, and the curry sauce smelled great and reportedly was also delicious. I'll definitely be back!
author: Lara S.

description:
I loved the katsu curry here! It was crispy, spiced just right and the curry was just delicious. It's a small space but service was efficient and friendly.

I think I would put it on the same level Japacurry but one less star as I don't think I was as impressed with it as I was with the food truck. Also the hours bum me out as its hours cater to the business hour crowds of the financial district and it's usually closed by the time I can get out there and it doesn't open on weekends.

Big portion and not expensive, if you want a solid katsu or are trying it for the first time definitely try Muracci's.
author: Sam H.

description:
Murraci's has fast become one of my favorite little lunch spots, but i'm not alone... Call ahead and you'll have a much shorter wait ahead of you. Real Japanese speakers is always a good sign of authenticity.

Flavorful, not dry, and not overly greasy chicken katsu is delicious. Spicy curry makes my nose run, mild still has a bit of spice and works best for me. I also like to switch it up and get the vegetarian curry with tofu and broccoli. Another favorite is the fried pumpkin. yum!

Thanks for having brown rice!
author: Nikki M.

description: Hmm, I hate to say it, but this place makes me miss LA. Seriously some good Japanese curry houses in Southern Cali, kinda makes this one seem a little sad. It's a great little tiny shop for business workers to take their lunch- to go. It's far too tiny to sit comfortably and not worth stopping at unless you're already out in downtown for something else. It's authentic and very tasty. It's fairly big portions and for $9 a plate I guess you expect it. They have a few select teas that are very nice. Again, this is more of a to-go joint, not a place to hang out in.
author: Naomi K.

description: Thick, delicious curry, crispy katsu chicken. Satisfying and cheap!
author: Cary Elizabeth L.

description:
The food isn't bad but I've definitely had better Japanese Katsu curry before. The spiciness fit well with their curry though. I wish they had a bigger store. It would be much easier if I was able to sit down and eat there. Their service was quick and the food is also pretty pricey compared to what you actually get in the box.

I would rate this place higher if they actually had more in the curry other than just the sauce. I felt like it was a bit too plain for me. I also didn't want to pay for extra potatoes or ingredients especially since my Katsu Curry was already almost $10.
author: Ingrid C.

description: Whenever I try Japanese curry at a restaurant, I'm always disappointed. This place does it right! I love their curry. It's not watered down and very flavorful. Their curry pan is also delicious and very cheap.
author: John D.

description:
Mmmm...crispy, tender meat (I got the katsu) and really flavorful curry over brown rice. The line is intimidating, but they're super efficient so don't be deterred by that.

The heat level is what you'd expect - I got hot, and it's certainly hot, but not mouth-numbing.
author: Lisa W.

description:
I LOVE MURACCI'S. except so does everyone else so they're always busy during lunch hour :(. The last time i was there I arrived a little bit late and the line was already out the door. I ended up ditching for another place down the street because I didn't have time to wait. 

I usually get chicken katsu lunch set. Because I love katsu and tonkatsu sauce and I cant get it anywhere else.
author: Kiersten B.

description:
Best. chicken katsu curry. ever.

~$9 for a huge, thick, juicy, perfectly fried chicken breast. Your choice of mild, medium, or spicy curry sauce - a perfect consistency with rich flavor. Then your choice of brown or white rice. I always eat every last bite.

I crave Muracci's all the time. When I Interned in the city, I would eat there all the time. 

Tip: If you're short on time, call in and you can skip the wait. The line usually goes out the door during lunch hour and there aren't many seats inside.
author: Anita C.

description: I've only been here once with my BFF but holy shit we're hooked... We both love curry and were starving after a long monday.  We stopped in here for a quick bite before happy hour and destroyed a katsu curry in less than 10 minutes.  the curry had so much flavor and the katsu was crispy but not greasy at all. definitely coming back here every chance i get!!!!!
author: Jen D.

description:
Awesome chicken curry katsu! 

I love how they give you such a big serving and also offer brown rice for free (most places charge extra for that, right?). I got the medium spicy, which was not too bad, but I definitely felt the spiciness afterwards (and I am someone that loves spicy). My friend got the curry ramen, which also looked delicious, so I think I'm going to try that next time, if I'm ever back in SF! 

There is not a lot of room to sit inside, so I'd recommend getting food to go.
author: Jenny M.

description:
I ordered over the phone to skip the wait and hustle of fighting for a place in line when I got there. Didn't work. 

Once I found someone to help me I was instructed to go to the front of the line where someone would assist me. I went to the front but it was like I was a ghost. Out of 3 people circling around the cash register not a single one helped me before I finally said "can I please pay for this" holding up my lunch.

I had the Oyako Don [chicken/egg] minus rice plus extra veggies and it was so-so. I figured asking for no rice and some veggies they'd compensate some of the space in the bowl with some garden goodness. Not exactly. Definitely not very filling. My wife had the Chicken Katsu. It was really dry and tasted like cardboard. It came with two sauces that we seriously could not identify. My wife's lunch box came with some seaweed soup which wasn't half bad.

Sadly, it might be a while before I repeat.
author: Jase O.

description:
One of my favorite lunch place.

Price is very good for the amount of food you get.
Line may get somewhat crazy, but it's lunch time in financial district, everywhere is crazy.

I have a friend who is very picky about the food he eats and he enjoyed his curry udon.

I always get hot katsu.
author: Mike K.

description: long lines but luv their curry and usually order a lot for our office.  tip: call ahead - the wait is usually a lot better though there still is a wait as the cashier sometimes has trouble managing between the walk ups and the order aheads.
author: Daniel Y.

description:
I met up with my friend who is also working in the FiDi and we decided to try one of the many restaurants near Kearny and Bush. (Of course, I already Yelped several of the restaurants beforehand so I had an idea of what was good. I do not go anywhere without having Yelped!)

We decided to try Muracci's since it had good ratings and curry sounded delish. The place is pretty nondescript from the outside but it was packed inside.

SEATING: Bar style seating along one wall (4 seats) and the windows (4 seats). I saw one stand-alone table for two. There's not much seating here, but surprisingly, seats do open up. My friend and I were able to grab two bar stools and the two next to me were open for awhile.

ORDERING: Pretty hectic as there is a line and lots of people are just standing around waiting to get their food. The nice, Japanese man was taking orders in line to make it go faster.

MENU: A bit expensive, but I guess it's decent for the FiDi. Most dishes like curry and noodles around $9/$10 with other side options.

FOOD: I got spicy ramen noodles that had ground beef, spicy pepper sauce, scallions and other yummyness in it. It was a pretty small portion though. My friend got the katsu curry with half brown, half white rice. Everything was yummy and filling. You could choose how spicy you wanted your dishes.

Overall, it was a good experience because it was fast and the food was really good. Also, the nice Japanese man brought over some water for us even though it was self-serve. Maybe he thought we were having trouble with the spicy food (:

TIPS:
-Go around 12:30/1- The line is shorter
author: Katherine K.

description:
I've always wanted to try this place since I notice a long line during lunch hour outside its tiny door....after finding out it being # 16 in Big Eat SF list, the more I gotta try!

Passed the rush hour by going there at around 2pm, glad no wait was required...

Ordered Chicken Katsu Curry and my friend got Beef Curry, both in medium hot level.  First of all, it's made to order...so the food is steamy and fresh. 
-The tonkatsu (fried chicken cutlets) are really fresh and crunchy while not being too dry! 
-The curry wasn't too spicy so if you expect more, order hot. Also love the consistency of the sauce not being too watery/thick.
-The brown rice that we ordered was really really chewy...and the food came in such big portion that made me full throughout the day..

Overall, I would give 4 stars...due to its limited seating space, this would be a great take out spot to fill your stomach :)
author: Shirley H.

description:
Hmmmmm, great place. Still have their curry on my lips but can't wait to go back there already. The place is amazing, the food is even better.

So far I had only their Pork Katsu (No.3 I believe) with spicy curry. Absolutely MUST!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!

Great hole in a wall place that makes SF so unique and awesome.
author: Andrei S.

description: Had the katsu curry. The curry sauce was delicious,perfectly spicy and just the right amount to coat the katsu and rice. The rice was also really good and chewy (I got the brown rice). The pork was good, but not the best I've had. It was a little dry. But still, I'd probably go back because the curry is so delicious!!
author: Christina L.

description:
We were at the Omni. We were hungry. We wanted something local.

YAY CURRY!

This place is the tiniest restaurant I've been in. I've seen closets bigger than this place. That being said, it gives credit to the saying, "Dynamite comes in small packages." 

This tiny place has a big kick. The food was awesome and reasonably priced.

AN ENTIRE STAR simply because we ate curry and it didn't jack up our stomachs at all. I have to admit - I thought I'd pay for it, but I didn't. 

Go. Hurry! Don't get stuck in the doorway.
author: Ashley H.

description:
Simple. Great flavors. Spicy. Cheap. Fast.

Really, what else would you want?
author: X O.

description:
A friend who works at Yelp brought me to Muracci's. Great pork katsu curry, but the medium hot isn't all that hot, next time I would get it "hot". It was a good sized serving, at least for me, so I saved the leftovers for later.

There's a wait and there's hardly any space here to sit down, you need to find your own place somewhere to eat nearby.
author: Emily M.

description:
Muracci's is my favorite lunch spot in San Francisco to get my Japanese curry fix. I try to avoid peak hours since the line can get pretty long and there's not much room to wait inside.

I recommend the Katsu Curry over rice...you get curry options of mild, medium, and hot. Go for the spicy hot!

While you're waiting in line for your order, grab one of their curry pan's to munch on. It's curry, wrapped in dough, covered in panko, and then deep fried. YUM!
author: Lester W.

description: I've realized the best way to tell if Japanese food is authentic is if you charge the bill to a credit card and they hand it back to you with both hands and bow. Muracci does that!
author: Victor W.

description:
I wandered in here jet-lagged and starving from a 13-hour flight on Sunday followed by a couple hours of sleep and work bright and early on Monday. Encouraged by the crowdedness of the place at around 1:30pm, I decided to try my luck. 
I ordered the tofu and vegetable curry to-go (medium, white rice), and was more than happy with what I got. The vegetables were indescribably  yummily-cooked and I loved the little container of pickled cabbage and carrots(?) that came with it. Portions are also pretty generous, and will definitely keep you full for the rest of the afternoon. This was my first time trying Japanese curry, and I will definitely be going back for more.
Wait was around twenty minutes...not too bad considering all I had to look forward to was going back to work. Only downside - this place only seems to be open for lunch!
author: Wendy L.

description:
This is one of my go-to places near my office when I can't quite figure out what I want for lunch, it never disappoints.

Let me state outright, I only ever get Katsu curry (they have pork or chicken, both are delicious) with mild curry, so I can't speak to the full menu, but judging by the fact that the line is regularly out the door I assume it's all good.

The service there is always fairly quick, even when they're pretty busy.  The folks working the counter are always smiling and friendly and never once have I received the wrong order (which is wont to happen in the FiDi during the lunch rush).

I think they make the curry in the morning to use for the full days service, if you go later in the day the sauce is a little spicier than if you go early in the lunch service.  Even the mild has a nice little zing to it by late in the day.  Also, they offer brown rice if you want it, which is a total plus in my book!

If you are in a hurry call your order in ahead so you can skip the line and go right up to the register to pay and grab your order.
author: Shelley M.

description:
Our lunch at Muracci's today was a result of an executive decision I had to make due to plan A failing miserably. Thank you Muracci. You have redeemed me!

A couple of tips: come at 11 or 1:30 to avoid the lunch rush or call in for pick up. Today we waited for almost half an hour for our food. 
That wait was well worth it though. I got the beef curry extra hot over white rice. It also came with pickled cabbage which I loved. I finished every last bite. It was soo good!

I am going to try their chicken katsu next time...
author: Cindy W.

description:
Decided to try Muracci's based upon these great reviews and I have to say I was super satisfied with everything!  You have to eat here and see for yourself!

This is not on the menu, but I ordered the Chicken Karaage Curry plate with Potatoes and Mixed Veggies as my sides.  The portions were hearty and the taste was tried and true good old homemade Japanese curry!  Their Karaage batter was awesome as well! 

I also tried the Tonkatsu and I was happily surprised to see it was cooked perfectly and the portions were again huge!  You are not going to feel like eating seconds after you finish this plate!

Being a bit Japanese I've had my share of curry, and these guys pull through generously!  Check it!
author: John M.

description:
Long lines, tiny space, efficient sweet man in the front that keeps the line moving, and super tasty katsu curry. It makes for a delicious lunch experience and makes me wish I was in SF instead of Oakland during the day. 

I got the hot chicken katsu curry and it is a ton of food for lunch. You have to be pretty hungry to finish it all in one sitting. Pair with their breaded (curried) pan. So so good. The entire order came out to about $13. A little on the pricier side for lunch, but well worth it since you can save up half of it for dinner as well. And of course worth it, because it tastes so great. 

They also have a pretty nice collection of asian drinks. The best part is that for a small space with the kind of foot traffic they get, they keep the line moving at all times. For the most efficient use of time however, call ahead and get it for pick up. Otherwise it will take around 10-15 minutes to get your order.
author: Aditi R.

description:
I've recently become a big fan of Japanese curry and when I found out that Muracci's is only a couple blocks from my workplace, I had to try it out. 

Unsurprisingly, when my coworkers and I arrived at around 12:30, the line was out the door. However, they had an employee take our order as we stood in line, to expedite the process. All four of us had our food within 15 minutes which isn't bad for such a hoppin' place. I imagine if we had the foresight to call in our order ahead of time, gratification would have been more instant. 

Seating is limited but as most people seem to take their orders to-go, it wasn't impossible to procure seats along the counter.  

The food is great! I ordered the chicken katsu curry over brown rice. The chicken was breaded lightly and not too greasy. The curry was flavorful and even managed to make the brown rice enjoyable. (I am a strong proponent for white rice but I was feeling healthy that day.) The portions were huge and I left the restaurant ready to suffer the rest of the day from an excruciating case of food coma.
author: Courtney C.

description: Twice in two weeks I've hit Muracci's for some light and healthy vegetable curry over brown rice.  It's been consistently tasty good and at the level of spiciness I can tolerate.  Perked up with their homemade pickles makes for a good quick lunch, just be sure to call your order in ahead of time to avoid any kind of wait!
author: Peg S.

description: Best katsu curry in the Bay Area. It was delicious and they adjust the spice level as per your preference. Sadly, they dont have seating.
author: Sunn M.

description:
Ok clearly my mistake here was NOT ordering the ton katsu. If you notice all the pics fellow yelpers have put up of the food- Its ALL the KATSU. 

I just ordered the beef curry. And while it does have a nice flavor I am utterly horrified at the little amount of food I was just given! This sad little container is barely half full with about 3 pieces of beef floating in there. At first I thought there was a mistake. To make matters worse, my coworker opens his box of chicken katsu that has (I swear) a half chicken in it!!!! He paid about $1 more than I. I'm seriously in shock! whats going on Muracci's??? Is everyone so in love with the katsu that you've completely neglected your other menu items? 

Word to the wise- If you want your monies worth only order the katsu here, Or get ready to be severely disappointed and worse still STARVING.
author: maria K.

description: Chicken karaage was awesome. There's always a long line during lunch so call ahead.
author: justin c.

description:
Well, the place is consistent - at least based on the identical pictures posted.  I had the the spicy vegetarian curry with white  rice.  It was fine.  The portion seemed small - i thought others got bigger portions of curry sauce.

The spicy was pretty good.  not too spicy.  The fried tofu was ok.  Came with red pickles and a cabbage salad, very crisp and nice.  The price was good.  It was a light meal that did not weigh me down.
author: Jaime O.

description: I come here every time I visit San Francisco. The curry katsu don is my favorite and usually have it extra spicy for my liking. And the beef pan (beef curry puff) is really good too.
author: Jason T.

description: Cheap. quick. Yummy vegetarian curry. They have BROWN rice :) Score!
author: Akshaya M.

description:
Finally! I've eaten curry at Murraci's.. although technically it was takeout and I never actually stepped foot in the establishment.. but I ate it and it was delicious!

Kat C. saved the day and avoided the crazy lunch rush by ordering ahead for everyone AND picking it up!  I had extra spicy curry with beef over brown rice.  The curry was really spicy and had that nice thick consistency.  I definitely want to try the katsu curry next time.

I'm with Cristofer P. on this one.  Although brown rice is healthier for you, it just doesn't go with Japanese curry....

Friendly on the wallet, will be back!
author: Kim-van T.

description: This place is terrible. The food is not worth its price they serve. Its just less then 10 pieces of meat. To me for 10$ just a little bit of meat is not worth it and the curry isnt that great. In my opion they couldve given more. Once you mix everything its no more  one small bowl. I do not reccomend this place.
author: Jenny L.

description:
Super long wait--whether you are dining in or taking out...the curry is pretty good but the portions are fairly small. You'd have to pay extra for more curry sauce.

We ordered the chicken curry ramen today and walked back to the office to find that we both got beef instead...$@#%!&%!
author: Mimi T.

description:
I really love me some curry... Thai curry, Indian curry, Japanese curry.  My dad introduced me to Japanese curry many years ago, when all I knew about Japanese food was sushi and sashimi, and I've been a fan ever since.  There weren't really too many places to get Japanese curry, let alone GOOD Japanese curry, in college and law school, so I was excited when I heard about this Muracci's place that wasn't too far from work.  

I've gotten the HOT curry everytime, which isn't actually that spicy, but had a great level of heat.  I've had the chicken, chicken katsu, and regular katsu curries, and I've loved them all.  I've never had any of their non-curry dishes, and I don't think I ever will, because the place is JUST far enough from work that I don't want to walk there and the wait is JUST long enough that it makes going there hard.  I usually also get extra curry, so I can just eat it with rice!  I really like the different croquettes they have all the time.  They sit there on the counter right next to the cash register, saying "get me... eat me" and I can never say no, especially since the curry isn't too expensive.

I've tried a couple other Japanese curry places in the city, but none have been as good as Muracci's so far.  Big thumbs up from me!
author: Pilan C.

description:
In a nutshell:

Food: 4.5 stars
P/C: 4.5 stars
Service: 4 stars

My co-workers and I have been talking about doing the katsu curry for a long time and it was time that we executed on our usual food-related musings.

The restaurant is tucked right in the middle of the downtown Los Altos and is fairly easy to find.  It can seat about 20~25 people at the most, so if you're going during the prime lunch or dinner times, you might have to brave a wait outside.  Luckily, it was a late lunch for us so the restaurant was pretty empty - yay.

All of us got some combinations of the katsu curry (pork cutlet with curry sauce over rice) and the beef curry.  The servers bring out 3 different types of pickles to go with your curry.  

The curry - awesome.  The katsu was cooked perfectly, crunchy crust and the meat was very juicy and still maintained some texture.  The curry was a little soupier than I'd personally liked it but the flavor was deep and nicely seasoned.  by the way, you can get your curry in different heat-levels (mild, medium and hot).  You can also ask for brown rice instead of white rice.

The next time I am going there - I might have to try other things on their menu.  I think that they are known for their curry dishes, but they offer other japanese goodies - oyakodons, teriyaki platters, omurice, etc.  

Will definitely return for a kick-ass curry and other concoctions at such reasonable prices ($8~$10 on average before tax and tip) and good service.
author: Mike P.

description: Tasty lunch in the Financial District. I like the spicy curry, chicken or pork katsu. A good value for a yummy lunch!
author: Adrienne G.

description:
there are ALWAYS lines.  Being impatient, it took me a year to brave the lines, and, as expected, great Japanese curry.  Tiny seating area, so take out is better.

Simple menu, decent value, tasty food.  Solid 4 stars.
author: Java Z.

description: Just had a beef curry patty on the go as we just finished lunch but wanted to try the place out. The curry was very very good but it wasn't nearly hot enough (but I guess that's what you get for an on-the-go item)
author: Crystal W.

description:
YUM. I got the katsu curry with a medium spice curry for lunch and was surprised that it was almost $10 (Asian food is generally very cheap), but I definitely was not let down.  The pork was tasty and fried just right and it comes on a nice big bed of rice. The curry was delicious! The sauce was flavorful and delicious- it didnt just  taste like some gooey curry sauce. 

Even though I thought it was kind of pricey, there was a ton of food and easily lasted for two meals.
author: Lisa C.
