description: One of my favorite places for Japanese curry. I always get their tonkatsu curry. The curry itself has a slight sweeter taste than other places, but it's very light and flavorful. The tonkatsu was just amazing. Juicy, delicious, crispy.
author: Thomas T.

description: Very underwhelmed by their chicken & vegetable curry udon, which was overly spicy. It was so spicy that the taste of the curry was completely lost! The only vegetables present were carrots and a piece of broccoli.
author: Baviera K.

description:
Small venue, but the katsu curry was very good, and the simplicity to it gave it a very home-cooked charm. I made sure not a single drop of curry was wasted! You can also request how spicy you wanted it; I recommend mild.

It's very accessible by BART, a walkable distance from Union Square. If you're working around the area, it's definitely worth a bite during your lunch break! Just writing this review makes me want to go back and get it again real soon!
author: Emmanuel C.

description: If I were an ambassador trying to explain comfort food to a delegation of Martians, I'd just take them to Muracci's. I've eaten here for lunch three days straight and would have gone longer if I could have. It's a hole in the wall that gets super busy and chaotic during lunchtime, so I've only ever taken out (beyond a bit of counter seating, there's hardly room to stand while waiting for your order). The crisp, light and moist pork katsu bathed in that punchy curry and served with rice and pickles is a paragon of the dish, and the beef curry is great too. The hidden gem of the menu is the spicy noodles (ramen or udon) smothered in a fiery, beefy gravy. Even medium level is blazing.
author: Cecilia L.

description:
All you need to really get is the chicken katsu curry. Or the pork. SOMETHING KATSU.

TAKE AWAYS: 
- This is very much a to-go place. It's very small. 
- They accept AMEX, like a true FiDi spot boss. 
- They make about 70 curries for the day, so try to beat the traffic and go early! 

Can't think of a place better for Japanese curry.
author: Abel L.

description:
To say the Japanese culture is weird is a ridiculous understatement, but amongst all the weird things that have emerged from Japan, we did get Anime, Samurais, Sushi, and Katsu curry!

Muracci's is definitely a hidden gem. I was working in the city one week and we just happened to be across the street so we decided to give it a shot. The place is beyond small, maybe comfortably fitting 8 individuals to dine in, so expect to take out during the lunch hour. 

To be honest, I've only eaten here once and the ONLY thing I've tried was the Chicken katsu Curry rice plate. Will I need to try anything else? HELL NO! This dish was the best creation since Popsicles. I was beyond impressed at the portion size, the quality of the box they put the food in, and the amazingly spicy curry. I kid you not when I say that I literally had a orgasm in my mouth.. and I can't wait to go back when I'm in the city!
author: Phuoc L.

description:
the BESTTT chicken katus ive had in the bay area!! and adding spinach with it just makes it SOO MUCH BETTER!!

i recommend calling in your order cause it gets BUSY!
author: Katherine C.

description:
I hella love this place. I go whenever im in the area. 
They make the best pork katsu curry ever. 

It's a must try if and when your in the downtown area.
author: Blake R.

description:
One of my comfort foods is Japanese curry rice. Muracci's is famous for their katsu curry so I just had to try it. The portion was big and the pork cutlet was delicious. The pork was juicy, tender, and fried perfectly - crispy but not with too much batter. The curry was tasty and not too salty. 

The seating is very limited with only a short bar with stools and a few small tables. My sister and I went 20min before closing time and ate at the bar. The owner (I'm assuming) was very kind and brought us cups of water. When it was closing time, he notified us that the restaurant would be closing soon but that we could take our time and stay until we were finished. 

This is a good place if you're craving Japanese curry rice but it's more of a to-go place so buy it then hurry home so you can eat it all!!!
author: Wanda K.

description:
Tiny immaculate place. Order your food to go because you will feel claustrophobic eating there.  Arrived at 11:30 to beat the rush. It seems like everyone was ordering the chicken katsu curry.  
 This is what I ordered, medium hot for the sauce. Wish I had ordered hot because it wasn't that spicy. The chicken katsu was perfectly cooked with the white breast meat remaining juicy. The breading had just the right crispness.  In all honesty, it wasn't my thing and I probably would not order it again but it was not flawed in any way. Love the accompanying cabbage. You have your choice of white or brown rice. The people working there are super efficient and nice.
author: Bleep S.

description: I used to love this place so much. Delish curry and love the pickles. Today I had a sad experience. I used the restroom and left my curry on my table I was sitting out and the guy cleaning up threw out my curry. I was very sad because he did not offer to make me another batch or anything.
author: Melissa M.

description:
Chicken Katsu Curry with brown rice!  Super tasty (slightly healthy with brown rice?)!   Can get crowded at lunch, but they're pretty efficient.

Today they had some curry bread ... It was like a bread roll filled with curry, breaded and fried ... Bought it for $2.25 because I was hungry.  If you plan on finishing your actual order, try not to impulsively purchase the goodies by the cash register.  The curry bread was filling and I only ate a quarter of my chicken katsu curry!  

Writing this had made me hungry ... might have to hike all the up to Kearney again for lunch tomorrow!
author: Dina H.

description:
Meh.
Everyone goes crazy for this place. It was just ok, chewy beef if a decent curry sauce. Wasn't worth writing about, good or bad. I'll skip the bashing and take my lunch money elsewhere.
author: Chris M.

description: Absolutely loved this place! I am actually going to Japan next month and was a little nervous because I don't like sushi. Now, I am so excited. I had the beef curry with brown rice - medium spicy. It was so amazing. I loved the flavors and it was really well organized. They managed the lines well. Next time I will try the katsu!
author: Anna M.

description: This lil hole in the wall is a great find for lunch in the city. Although it's small, I always manage to find a seat with my boyfriend on the counters. I like the feel of it being small and cozy. The staff are all Japanese. Apparently this is really authentic although i cannot tell the difference since this is my first and only experience with Japanese curry. But it is very good anyhow! I always get hot curry which is enough spiciness for me and I usually get the pork or chicken katsu which is cooked well and crisp on the outside. Brown rice is a must too! Such a simple dish seems like homecooked food and really soothes my soul on a cold, rainy day. I suggest coming before 2pm because it seems they run out of the good meats by then and to get the food quicker, try calling in beforehand.
author: Stephanie H.

description:
We got a mild and medium pork and chicken katsu curry.
It was delicious but didn't go far enough beyond the golden curry like taste. That is a good thing as there isn't anything wrong with the golden curry taste except the price difference!

The croquettes were piping hot and up there in terms of croquettes I've ever eaten.

However, their katsu and brown rice are excellent - perfectly crispy to the bite and very moorish.
Always good find a good place to grab lunch.
author: Nick L.

description:
I'm beginning to think I'm just *slightly* biased with Asian cuisine....

I guess it's inevitable with the fact that most people are biased towards food that they're familiar with, right?

Anyway, the Japanese at my work had been hyping about Muracci's for about a week at the office, so yesterday I finally decided to go check out Muracci's to see what all the fuss was about. 

This is one of those places that can be easily missed if you walk by too fast--Muracci's is housed in the same building as Bangkok Best and the Cinta Aveda Institute. The whole building is painted a weird beige colour and the three shops barely stand out from one another other than the plain, black lettering above their front doors. 

Muracci's itself is a small place, similar to the ramen/udon shops found in Japan. The people who own/work at Muracci's are Japanese: they even greeted me with "Irrashaimase" (welcome). There are daily/weekly specials, and apparently they're popular, since I attempted to order the special spicy noodle and the cashier told me they were sold out. Aw man!

The menu has plenty of yummy Japanese offerings, including several different kinds of curry (salmon, ebi fry, etc.), donburi, and some small sushi orders. Prices range under $10, which is average/not bad for lunchtime prices, and a sweet deal for dinner (unfortunately, they do close at 6, so you'd have to go eat an early dinner around 4:30 like I did). 

I ordered the salmon curry, extra hot; sat at one of the front counter seats and immediately felt like I was in Japan. It's tight yet cozy; the shop was pretty empty at 4pm, considering most people hadn't left work yet. It took them a little bit to bring my order to me, but no worries, since I wasn't in a rush to get anywhere else.

When my curry did arrive, I was surprised to see how huge the plate/portion was! Really good deal for the price I paid! The plate was as large as the rectangular serving tray, and...mm, plenty of curry sauce with a generous portion of salmon on top. I also liked that they gave me the option of choosing brown or white rice--knowing how I am these days, I tend to lean towards brown rice since it's healthier.

The entree itself was filling; curry wasn't as spicy as I thought it'd be, but that's okay, I figured the "spicy" was mild in comparison to, say, Thai food. I completed the meal with dorayaki...felt like the dorayaki was a little overpriced, but hell, I guess they gotta make money somehow.

I can see how people would say the place isn't good in terms of the lunch rush--Muracci's does cook everything to-order, so the food is always fresh, but that means it takes a little more time to prepare than most people would prefer. Catering to the Financial District area is a smart move, but it's also kind of a weird spot for the restaurant to be in.

Will be back again to try the other entrees. My friend bought the katsu donburi from Muracci's and it also looked very appetizing.

In short: Muracci's serves up delicious Japanese "comfort foods" in American portions. =)
author: Helene K.

description:
If you know Japanese Curry, you'll know this place is great. Don't expect to eat there, don't expect a peaceful lunch run, just order, wait and leave and enjoy the Japanese Curry that is better than probably 90% of the places I've been to in California. I have never been to Japan and can only imagine the size of the shop and the crazy vibe you get while in it, is similar to what you experience in Japan. Big portions, small place.

If you want to eat someplace, grab your curry and walk a block over to Trinity Plaza ally and grab a table outside there.

Wait a minute, I just realized what I wrote. I know Japanese Curry as best as it can be in the US. I don't know what it's like in Japan. So I guess I don't really know Japanese Curry. I just like it. Love it.
author: Lorrie N.

description: Had their Katsu Curry and a Croquette for lunch the other day, and it was pretty good. The Katsu Curry portions were very generous  for the price, and the katsu itself was very tender as well. I'm a big fan of the taste of the Croquette, which was fried just long enough to have a nice light crisp going for it, although I'm not sure it's worth it for the price (1.75 for one the size of a hash brown patty). The restaurant is very small, and generally has a lot of customers, so be sure to call them and order before going if you don't want to wait.
author: Nevin L.

description:
Came here for the chicken katsu curry. I was kinda bummed that the curry didn't come in a lunch set (that includes miso soup and salad). It did, however, come with white rice or brown rice, and 2 kinds of pickled veggies (cabbage and daikon i believe). I've had pickled veggies at other Japanese restaurants, and the veggies here didn't taste that great.

Waited about 10 minutes for my food around noon. Quick tip: phone in your order to avoid the line! 

PROS: 
-they separate the curry sauce and katsu on to go orders
-they don't skimp on the curry sauce
-the HOT spiciness level is actually spicy! yummy!

CONS:
-not cheap. my chicken katsu curry lunch w/ white rice and a small side of pickled veggies cost me $9.80. T_T
-crowded little place if you're waiting there
-pickled veggies aren't very good
-curry dishes aren't available in lunch sets (soup & salad)


Overall, this place isn't too bad. I'll probably come back to try the Tonkatsu curry sometime.
author: Jennifer C.

description:
Probably some of the best Japanese curry you'll find downtown in San Francisco. There's often a line out here and the food takes a bit, but it's well worth it. 

I typically order the chicken katsu and it's comes out piping hot which adds to it's deliciousness. The chicken is laid over rice and the curry is served in a plastic container when you get it to go (which almost everyone does since seating is so limited). 

The staff is friendly and handles the lunchtime crowd well.

They have curry pans, which are essentially curry pockets. They're great if you've got a craving but won't be able to down a whole meal.

Coming back often for sure!
author: Tammy C.

description:
Omg, yummy!  Places like this make me lament the lack of some real good Japanese food in San Diego where we live.  My husband and I were here on a weekend trip and found Muracci's on Yelp...even with all the cautions of a long line, the wait wasn't too bad when we were there around 12:30 on a Monday.  My hubby and I have a pretty good team setup of one of us hawkishly targeting a table at small crowded restaurants while the other one orders and gets the drinks and stuff to the table, so we got seats at the counter no problem.

We had the pork katsu curry, extra spicy and the katsu don (pork katsu and onions with eggs).  The pork katsu was crispy and delicious...fried to perfection!  The accompanying curry was to my surprise actually, spicy!  You don't really get a lot of spice in Japanese food so I was impressed at the depth of flavor and spice in this curry...made my nose run a little and but my stomach was very happy!  My husband undoubtedly will order katsu don at Japanese restaurants because it's his comfort food...I think he's usually left with a feeling of longing/disappointment after eating katsu don but not here!...best one he's had (other than his mom's of course!)
author: Susan W.

description:
Never having Japanese curry before, I ordered the chicken katsu curry (medium spicy) with brown rice. The chicken was nice and crispy on the outside, and juicy on the inside. The curry was flavorful, but not as spicy as I thought. I will definitely get spicy spicy next time. The pickled veggies on the side paired well with the curry.

Do not be discouraged by the line out the door, it moves pretty fast. And the older man taking orders close to the door is really friendly. 

Prices are also reasonable my lunch order came to around $10, and I was given a good amount of food (not enough to have leftovers though).

Definitely recommend to put on anyone's lunch rotation!
author: Kerina J.

description:
mmmmmmmm.  The chicken katsu curry is A-MA-ZING!

Unlike other katsus, this dish is NOT oily, the meat is not fatty, and the curry sauce is vibrant- extra spicy REALLY is extra spicy.  Also, it doesn't taste like the box curry you can buy from china town (which most other restaurants probably use).  This curry has a certain spice in it- can't put my finger on it, but it is friggin amazing.
author: Clarissa P.

description:
Down on my end of Market, $9.00 gets you a very organic, very locally-sourced, very small biodegradable bowl of smug served to you out of shiny trucks and brightly-logoed kiosks by slender, clear-skinned hipsters backed by a shadowy consortium of private investors. 

At Muracci's, that $9.00 will get you a delicious big-ass slab of deep-fried pig, laid out on a bed of more rice than any reasonable human being can eat, with a murky bowl of curry, in which some perfunctory vegetables roil, sluggishly, like harbor seals on a humid day. It is the perfect thing to eat during your workday, before your return to your office to sit and arrange fat cells in an attractive pattern around your rapidly expanding thighs. 

Somehow, they manage to squeeze a team of eight or so bodies behind a narrow counter in the tiny restaurant, cranking out plates of curry and many fried things, rapidly barking out order numbers in an incomprehensible shriek. 

You can get an order to go, or eat your delicious fried lunch at the bar, peoplewatching in the big mirror that runs along the wall or, hypothetically, staring creepily at a tall, perfectly-formed man waiting for his order at the far wall, all the while spinning insane vignettes in your head featuring you, him, a deserted beach, a soft tropical breeze ruffling his hair and a marine sunset reflecting brilliant striations in his eyes. 

Hypothetically.
author: Laura T.

description:
Muracci's rocks.  Authentic Japanese curry is f'n delish.  Their chicken curry is tasty and veggie is too.  And the price is oh so nice!  Don't sleep on the lotus root chips - also tasty...  Y'all know how I complain all the time about the expensive, crappy lunchtime eats downtown.  Pay attention, 'cause this time I'm singing praises.

Get there early, as in 11:30-11:45, or call-in first.  Only a few seats, but you'll probably get one if you'd like.  Most worker bees take theirs back to the hive. 

Their kitchen is so clean it kinda freaks me out!  I almost kick them up to 5 stars because it is that exceptional.  I've never seen a grill in the middle of a lunch rush that was as sparkly clean as first thing in the morning.  Yeah, the health department gave them a perfect 100.  

So the cute folks workin' the grill are super neat and precise and don't rush your grub out as fast as Mc Sandwich place down the street.  Count all the Issei and Nisei in the cue and get a clue.  It's worth the wait!
author: Ted R.

description:
I've been meaning to try this but it's not open for dinner or on the weekends. I was finally in that area at lunchtime so I decided to give it a go. It's full of people during lunch but service is fast and the boss is very friendly. I wish I could rate it higher, but based on the food, I think maybe it might even be worth only 1 star. Sorry!

The only good thing is that they offer brown rice. And they make the curry from scratch. But it doesn't taste anything like japanese curry. It tastes more like indian curry. I had the spicy and it was watery (!). Maybe it's healthier than the regular thick ones but I value taste over health benefits :-(

Pork katsu was ok but not really better than what you can make at home yourself using panko. I won't be back. I prefer On the Bridge in Japantown for curry.
author: pj n.

description:
Helpful hints, tips and observations:
- Long wait
- Come here before 11:30a
- Phone in your order before 11:15a or else they won't pick up the phones once the lines are out the door
- 13 stools/seats total (I think)

Katsu Curry? HELL YEAH. 
Chicken Katsu Curry? SURE THING.

I tried both of them but I prefer the katsu (pork) over the chicken since the chicken came off a bit dry, but nonetheless it was still tasty. It's definitely meatier as my special friend described it. You can pick the spiciness of your curry ranging from MILD MED to HOT? Or something like that. Not sure if that's the correct wording but MED was good enough for me. Woo wee! I finished EVERYTHING. All the rice, all the meat, and all the curry. 

Their cake rolls are tasty too. I tried their tora, green tea, and plain cake rolls all in one day. Felt like a fatty but it was definitely worth it since I loooove sweet Asian cakes. But the only drawback is that it was pretty pricey -- $1.75 each for a one inch thick slice of cake. Oh well.

(Photos uploaded)
author: Heidi C.

description:
I just started working in the finance district and there aren't too many choices for reasonable asian food (unless you hike all the way to Chinatown), but I read all the reviews here and it seemed pretty reasonable. Until.....I arrived there at noon, there was a line out the door! So expect a 25-35 min wait till you get your order. 

Food
I got the simple curry chicken over rice and it was just ok. I had the spicy selection and it wasn't brutally hot. I didn't appreciate how there was only 3-4 small pieces of chicken and a splash of curry. The taste of the curry was good though overall. 

Price
For 8ish, easily 10 if you get the fried selection, just OK in my books.

Atmosphere
Don't plan on sitting inside at this place! Might only fit 6-8 MAX.
author: Derek L.

description: Forgot to review but I finally got to try katsu curry and it was AMAZING! Go there early as it does sell out!
author: Natassia S.

description:
This place rocks. It feels like a bit of Japan in SF w/out the gratuitous architecture of Japantown. 

This place is REALLY popular for lunch, but it's not impossible to find a seat to sit and eat your curry at. The line moves fairly fast and the wait isn't too long. 

Their curry pan is impossibly tasty cold so I can almost imagine how blissful it must taste when it's fresh. It wasn't particularly oily either. I'd definitely come back and get a croquette too. Oh, and to try their weekly specials! wah, so good!

Brown rice doesn't cost more than white. 

Credit/Debit is accepted.

portions are large and prices are reasonable.

I wished that my katsu was a little crunchier but really, Muracci is pretty much perfect.
author: Andrea L.

description:
My buddy and I came here right at the opening for lunch so we can check out Muracci's curry special of the week, which was beef tendon curry. The special of the week was limited to only 20 orders per day.

Sorry, the lady at the counter says to us. We are out of the special. I do the awkward Ben Stiller look around of the restaurant. Hmm besides that one lone guy who has already ordered, we are the only other people here.

So, I ended up ordering the pork katsu curry with a croquette. The katsu and croquette were fried up to a nice golden brown. The croquette tasted ok. The filling reminds me of a less chunky samosa.

The curry which I had high hopes for was a let down for me. I had some great Japanese curry the last time I was in Hawaii so I was expecting to sit down and devour the entire plate of food.

I'm not saying the curry is bad at Muracci. It's not to my taste and not to how I remember the curry in Hawaii. If the curry is tasty... you can give me a tub of rice and I'd be set.

Oh well. My buddy and I left with full tummies but not satisfied ones.
author: Sam T.

description:
Muracci's has the most authentic and delicious tasting Japanese style curry I've had outside of Japan.  The staff is very friendly despite always being rushed by the number of people in line waiting for some curry.  Not only does everyone greet you, but they also remember my order.

I always order Katsu Curry - Geki Karai style.  It means "SUPER HOT", and while it's not really that spicy compared to other more traditionally spicy foods, but it does kick it up a notch beyond regular Japanese style dishes.  

The only downside to this spot is the line.  The food is always made to order so it takes time to prepare.  But they allow you to call ahead to order and you can move directly to the head of the line to pay for food and be on your way.

The wait while long won't detract from my star rating as there are ways around it, and the wait is not due to sloth so much as the spots incredible popularity during the lunch hour.
author: B J.

description:
JUST had the katsu curry (not my first time) and as always, hits the spot.  The spices are so aromatic and the katsu perfectly breaded/fried, crunchy even after dousing in amazing curry.

On a "lighter" day, can never go wrong with a donburi!!
author: Judy L.

description:
YAY! I finally went and tried their curry pan! It's really good!! :D

I am tempted to just buy five of those things for lunch sometime. It's fried bread with curry inside. The one I had was room temperature, but it was curry in a crispy fried bread husk.

Remember to order ahead of time so you don't have to wait in line. Now they have someone walk down the line and take your order before you get to the register to keep everything moving.

Now to eat my katsu curry leftovers.
author: Amy N.

description: I like curry. Muracci's curry, I love! I've tasted mainly Chinese and Indian curry dishes which I typically order to provide a contrast in flavors to the other family style dishes shared at a meal. Well, this Muracci version of Japanese curry I ain't sharing. I got a bountiful portion of medium spicy curry juxtaposed next to a nicely crisp serving of pork katsu. I originally ordered curry chicken katsu but they were all out. My disappointment was mitigated by the leanness and moistness of the pork. Brown rice a plus. Would be nice to have more vegetables on the menu. California rolls nondescript. Good and friendly service. Self serve water readily available Glad they were open till 7p so I could make this meal a delicious dinner.
author: Valerie F.

description:
After reading Wakako's review, I had planned for a week to come here yesterday since I had the day off and I was sooooooooo excited when yesterday finally came. 

Came in around 12:30pm. Head on into the lunch rush. This place is TI-NY, only seating 10 on bar stools at a bar against the wall, and 2 at the only table in the establishment. This is definitely more of a take-out place. The orders come quick, but don't let that fool you because nothing here is premade, except the curry of course, in a big pot on the stove. 

I ordered chicken katsucurry with a extra side of japanese pickles. The chicken cutlet was HUGE and cooked when I ordered it, so it came out nice and crispy. I had the curry medium and it was perfect. Next time I'm going to try it with veggies. I'm used to curry having at least potato and onion in it. This curry does not. It's still really good, but I prefer veggies in mine. 

I'm with Wakako on the fact that fukujinzuke would have made this meal perfect. That and maybe some takuwan.
author: Jen D.

description: Went with my mom, dad, and bf. And my family considers ourselves to be curry connoisseurs because my dad is full Japanese and it is one of his, as well as my own, favorite meals. Plus we make it at home from time to time. We came to the conclusion it was the best Japanese curry we have had in the US. Most places give you watered-down curry which in my opinion just defeats the purpose of curry. It should be thick and flavorful just like Muracci's. Seating is tight and it gets super busy at lunch. Overall very good, however, I wish they'd give you a little more curry.
author: Sarah S.

description:
Awesome & quick little lunch spot. Everything on the menu is good, but I usually go there for the curries. 

It's a little bit on the pricier side, but it's worth every penny. It's run by some very happy and welcoming people. 

If you have to choose between this and L & L across the street, why not try Muracci's out? You won't be disappointed.
author: Ed D.

description:
As far as lunchtime NON-sandwich dining options in the SF Financial District, Muracci's is my #1. I eat here once a week, for years, and I've tried EVERYTHING in the FiDi. Nothing is as consistently high quality, flavorful, and efficient as Muracci's.

You're going to spend less than $10 here, you will be in line less than 10 minutes, and you will rave about your chicken curry the rest of the day. Their daily special is great if you're a regular, but for a first timer, go with chicken curry or chicken katsu (fried) curry. Their chicken katsu is better than their pork katsu.

Oh, and 'spicy' is actually spicy here, points for that! The only downside-- no seating besides some very uncomfortable positions between people in line. Just take it to one of the public spaces and chow down.
author: A B.

description:
this place is meh... Maybe i eat curry too much at home! Home always have the better food!

Anyways, Heard about this place from 7x7 and came down here for lunch one day with a friend. we got here and ordered the Katsu Curry over rice. (Medium spiciness) The inside was small, with not much sitting area, maybe because its in the financial Dist. so it is more like a grab and go lunch spot. Luckily, there was some seats left and we ate there. 

the food wasn't that great, the curry was not even spicy at all! I should have gotten HOT! the curry was meh.. it didn't have that great smell, and it was pretty bland to me. However the curry goes really well with the pork katsu, that is  the only good thing about it. The rice was kind of chewy to me.This t was below average to me. I wouldn't come back here again.
author: Daniel L.

description: Just plain amazing. Yummy and affordable. No frills, but best, most flavorful Japanese curry I've ever had. Must visit whenever in SF!
author: jenn t.

description:
So yummy! Katsudon & grilled salmon curry!
Always a tremendously long line, but it's definitely worth it. 

There are practically no seats and they're highly coveted, so don't count on it. There are pretty much no places to sit outside either! I don't care. I'd stand outside and eat this curry if I have to!

Things I wished for: more seating space, and longer hours.
author: Jessica F.

description:
I really wanted to love this place. Chicken Katsu Curry is just one of those dishes I constantly crave.. constantly. 

Pros:  The curry is very flavorful. The portions are large, and even after being drenched in curry, the panko crust is still crunchy! The chicken is white and juicy.

Cons:  It took me 20mins to get my lunch. Ok, I came in at 12:15pm.. yea. lunch time. When I ordered, they had just called out order #19, I was order #23. I noticed the orders before me were only one or two things.. not like gigantic group orders.. WHY did it take 20mins to get through four orders? I had originally ordered my lunch for here, but after waiting 20mins, my meter only had 5mins left. UGH. Also, the cuts of chicken was super thick, which just isn't my preference. Also, I'm more used to there being actual veggie chunks in my curry. 

Overall, the flavor was good enough that I'd come back, during a non-lunch time when I'm not in a "hurry" and only if I happen to be in the area.
author: Tammy S.

description:
I am hooked on Muracci's. I finally got to sit in and have lunch here today since I was in the area. I ordered the Chicken Katsu with japanese curry and every bite lived up to everyone's good word. I was satisfied and my belly full. I had the medium spicy curry and it was so delicious. I savored every spoonful and now, I know where to go. 

This place is small, by any means but I managed to sit and enjoyed my lunch by myself.
author: Mika D.

description:
Man, do I feel this place.  I order the tonkatsu curry, extra spicy, and extra veggies every time.  

I have my obessions.  One of which is Muracci's curry.  I've tried duplicating this dish at home and needless to say, it was a culinary fail.  Their sauce is savory and spicy without the viscous texture.  Ah, sooo good.   

FYI, they take plastic but have limited seating.  No one is perfect.
author: Uyen N.

description:
Went here for lunch today, got the Nasa curry (eggplant curry) since it was their special and well, I always love trying specials for the first time. I was a little nervous about it since it said "spicy" but I figured I had a decent spice tolerance and could suffer through it.

It had a really good flavor, I have to say, I think they know how to do curries. It was spicy, but not burn your mouth spicy, you could tell they cooked the spice in properly so it had spice without being overpowering.  I was pleasantly surprised with my curry.  They gave me a pretty generous portion, so I only finished half the curry since I ran out of rice. They were smart and packed it in a to-go container for me, so all I had to do was throw the lid back on so I could take it home. 

There is extremely limited seating (I think 10 seats overall) so I would plan on grabbing your lunch and eating it somewhere outside. 

I want to go back again soon and get the katsu curry like I had originally plan. Who knows, maybe they'll have a new special and I just might have to try it.
author: Analisa S.

description:
I shocked myself today in realizing that I have never written a review for Muracci's and I have been there at least a couple of dozen times. I was referred by a fellow yelper and sadly I can not give him/her credit since I can't find the original referral. This is definitely as good as it gets in San Francisco as far as Curry goes. I cannot speak to the other dishes as I have never gotten anything but Curry....oops, I forgot about the Croquette that was great too. The must cycle out their oil frequently because it always tastes fresh and light and never too heavy. Lunchtime is crazy so be warned...call/fax ahead and save yourself the time. 

The last warning....Japanese Curry is not for everyone and varies greatly from other ethnic curries.
author: John D.

description: Tried only their Curry Pan and Korokke/Croquette so far and I thought it was pretty authentic to what you could find in Japan.  Although I ate them more than a half hour later, it was still good after briefly reheating them.  My only suggestion is that their Curry Pan be a little bit wider in size - the curry pan that I remember getting from Japan years back tended to be so, but other than that, it was fried right and the overall flavor and consistency of it and their croquette which I believe was a yasai (vegetable) and potato combo, were a thumbs up.  If I stop by here next time, I will definitely try their curry.
author: Kahanalei M.

description: I think my new favorite item is the chicken curry with ramen. They separate the noodles and curry so the noodles don't get soggy. The ramen is a nice slightly chewy consistency and the curry is just delicious! Big chunks of dark meat chicken and big cuts of carrots and broccoli.
author: Linda C.

description:
Finally!!!!

After bookmarking this place for over 2 years, I got to try Muracci's!!!Yes..............It is as good as it gets!!!

I'm a huge fan of Japanese curry and this place didn't disappoint.  I had the tonkatsu curry and it was fried to perfection.  You ever get batter that you have to discard because it was either too doughy, over battered, or mushy???  You won't get that here.  The pork was moist and juicy on the inside, crispy and light on the outside.  They actually separate the curry from the rice and tonkatsu which I think is a fantastic idea to keep it from getting soggy.   It shows that they care about how it should be eaten.

For curry, in the bay area, this place rawks!!!! For you guys in the Fidi.........you guys are very fortunate to have a place like this.  For 10 dollars a plate.........a little pricey for take out but it's well worth it.
author: jason g.

description:
Delicious, delicious curry with a nice kick to it. The tonkatsu curry came out piping hot (the katsu burned my mouth when I first bit into it) and they offer both white AND brown rice for your enjoyment.

The curry is thick and if you look closely you can see the spices running throughout the brown, liquid gold that's on your plate. It's quick, convenient, and cheap. Call ahead and talk to the ojiisan and you'll have your order ready when you get there.

Also, try one of the Curry Pans that's sitting in front of the register. The bread itself is crispy at first bite but very chewy once you get to the center. It's also not overly oily compared to other places I've had it. All in all, a quality experience at an affordable price.

Cheers!
author: Andrew B.

description:
Having walked past this place a myriad of times, either not hungry or after it was closed; I finally made it in for lunch and had the katsu donburi and sampled the katsu pork curry.

There was a line out the door when we got there, but they took our order as we waited in line.  By the time we made it to the register our orders were basically ready.  The line didn't take longer than 10 minutes.  The restaurant is quite intimate (microsized), with enough bar-level seating for about no more than 10 or such people.  Very cute, reminded me of Tokyo.

The katsu donburi was quite yummy and totally hit the spot.  I thought it was much more flavorful and homestyle than some of the other donburi I've had around SF.  It had plenty of egg and onions with a well-balanced amount of soy.  I thought it was a pretty hefty serving, and felt a little bummed that I couldn't manage to force it all in.  I will definitely be coming back for more.

The curry was pretty good, if a little watery.  Very well spiced and strong vegetal flavors, though I didn't think the hot was really all that hot.  The pork was a bit overcooked but combined with enough curry sauce, it didn't matter much.  My friend ordered this and I asked more than once for a taste.

There's a bunch of items on the menu that I'd like to try.  I'll be back!
author: Mary P.

description:
Stopped by this place after work and have to say it is incredibly tasty and even more, easy on the wallet.

I ordered 2 Chicken Katsu and one vegetable curry pan all for $22 and well portioned. The chicken was white, moist with the right layer of crunch for katsu that isn't overly burnt or drenched in oil. The curry pan was a nice treat, a flaky airy dough embedded with a tasty vegetable curry.

Most importantly, the curry sauce for the katsu was not too pungent like Indian curry with an amazing blend of flavors and even perfect just over rice.

Be aware they close at 6pm and seems to be a happening lunch option but nonetheless, get to go!
author: Ash T.

description:
I used to loveeeeeeeeeee muracci's! 

Until I got food poisoning this afternoon from their salmon curry.

Now my heart is filled with fear. Why Muracci? Whyyy! I thought "Better to be loved than feared?" Guess thats not their creed. Wah!

I had lunch with 4 other people who had chicken katsu and fried shrimp and the same curry. So the culprit must be the fish. 

 I had lunch until 1:30 and by 2pm I was in my cube, feeling stabbing pains and sweating, chewing on pepto pills and praying for relief! Then a trip to the bathroom....could have done a bad infomercial, 
forget the master cleanse diet--just have contaminated fish!!!!!!!!!!

 I am suddenly very worrisome and afraid of fish since no one else had a problem so it must have been the salmon. I've eaten here before without this happening so I will be back after my stomach is confident again, it could be awhile. Poor estomago!

Well I am still giving it 3 stars, you know the currys good when you get food poisoning and only knock off 2 stars.

Pros: I probably lost 5 lbs eating this meal. 
Cons: I probably lost 5 lbs eating this meal.
author: Amy S.

description:
Favorite Japanese curry place downtown!! Beats JapaCurry truck by a landslide, for me. Why? I like my curry with chicken breast, not breaded chicken (katsu).

Simple, rich flavors will do the trick for me. They lead a pretty efficient shop with plenty of staff. One who takes your order while in line, the cashier, to the people behind cooking and prepping each meal. 

There's not a lot of space to eat, so get there early if you want to sit down. Most people order as carry out, so it's fine. It's about $9-10 for a meal here. 

I was left licking my plate and wanting more. I'll be back.... the 15 minute walk is worth it!
author: Jeanne C.

description:
One of my favorite spots in town for lunch. Too bad I work in the Embarcadero Centers and can't take too much off for lunch.

I would absolutely recommend their Katsu curry, which is curry over rice with tonkatsu (breaded and fried pork). It's delicious and the most authentic katsu curry I've tasted in SF so far. Bit on the pricy side (9.70 + tax), but nothing crazy given it's SF. It gets packed during lunch, so they will take orders from people in the line which makes the process a lot faster. The curry pan (breaded fried bread with curry inside) is delicious too.
author: Sean L.

description:
This place has the BEST curry!!! I came here with my boyfriend for first time, and I've gotta tell you, he nearly cried because their katsu curry was so good. Curry comes with little picked cabbage and you can adjust the level of spicyness according to your taste (which I like, because I love spicy spicy spicy!!!). 
Quick advice: Seating is very very limited.
author: Hana K.

description:
I love this place for a quick lunch to-go. Have had their curry multiple times. It's not the best curry in the world, but for the price, quickness of service, and location, you can't beat Muracci's. The chicken or pork katsu is always very crispy and the sauce is a great thick texture. They are also very accurate on spicyness level. Make sure you choose what you can handle as it does get spicy! Even the radish here is delicious. 

Not a very large location though so hard to find spots to sit. come prepared!

tip: you can also call ahead for take-out to avoid the long lines!
author: Yue Z.

description:
Oh so tasty. Especially if you can beat the line.

The curry bread is so delicious and to date I've only had their curries, but they are so good. Especially if you get them spicy hot -- delicious.
author: Shauna S.

description:
This is it, guys. THIS is Japanese curry.

I've had: tonkatsu, chicken katsu, and the spicy noodles.

Their tonkatsu and chicken katsu are so crispy and perfect, I can't even tell you.

The spicy noodles are HOT. If you normally get hot curry, get mild noodles.

Thanks Muracci's. I can't eat Japanese curry anywhere else now.
author: Shawn C.

description:
Seriously tasty japanese joint. But really, the katsu curry is on the 100 things to eat before you die? Am I wrong or isn't it a fried piece of meat? I had it, and had the curry and the curries tasty but i wasn't like blown away w/ the meal. Their ramen, rice and other noodle dishes are all really really good though. Very flavorful and their menu's simple and easy to order from (read not super foreign so you don't feel like you need a translator w/ you while ordering). 
Will go back many times as it's close to work and really good, but not for the fried meat, i'll stick to my spicy noodles!
author: Audrey V.

description:
You can definitely taste the love in this dish.

I can't even remember what I got because I ate here so long ago and forgot to write a review. But it was definitely one of the curry ramen dishes. And mmmm, was it ever so good. I can tell you my mouth is watering writing this review.

I only hope that in the upcoming year I can hop on the MUNI to get to this place once again... mmmmmmmmm.

Don't click useful on this review. Trust me, I know no amount of "mmmm"s will ever be very useful. We can be real, brothas.
author: Rusty S.

description: I had the katsu curry spicy today.  It is the best katsu I had outside of Japan.  You might want to have the curry mild since the spicy curry kicked my ass:-) I also observed the way they make each and every order that comes in fresh, which really surprised me since they must have enormous volume and the lady makes each and every one!  They also have a perfect 100 on their health dept score.  They are not cheap, I just don't know how they could have such excellence in their products.  I think the care they take in making each one fresh explains partly why many yelpers complain about the wait.  It was extremely busy even at 11:15am, 15 mins after they open.
author: Jim J.

description:
Just went here last friday; again excellent service, excellent Curry.
This time I enjoyed the tofu curry; always yummy. I went on a colder San Francisco day and the place had only one customer there. The cashier said to me :  " you know on a cool weather day like today, you'd think more people would want curry"    I agree. Curry on a cooler weather day is like putting Racing Gas in your Sports Car. Vroom Vroom. !

I do favor this dark,almost smoky curry , I can say Japanese curry , seems to me, is more earthy than Indian curry or Thai curry. 
Hard to qualify, but the curry here is the shiznit.
author: Bert K.

description:
Woohoo! Finally a japanese curry place! I missed going to Curry House when I was back home in Hawaii and I haven't ate authentic japanese curry since then. Coming here was an accident, me and my bf were hungry after school, and were on our way to L&L instead, but I saw Muracci from across the street, and decided to try it out (sorry L&L!).

I ordered the katsu curry, but unfortunately they were out (I guess since it's that good!) The guy suggested chicken curry, so I asked if it was the fried chicken, he said no.. I noticed there wasn't a curry menu item for the karaage (fried chicken), but the guy said they could make it. I ended up ordering avocado sushi for the boyfriend, and a fried chicken spicy curry with white rice. 

My portion was huge. The lady serving me even included a piece of katsu in my curry, she said it was the last one. The curry was delicious, right amount of spiciness, and the fried karaage was not drowning in the sauce, so it wasn't soggy, but crunchy. It was accompanied by pickled cabbage and radishes which was a nice complement to the dish.

When we were leaving, the guy gave us free curry bread for us to try to take with us, he said it was their new dish, and OMG,those were delicious also! 

Good curry, and even better curry bread! Definitely coming back.
author: J R.

description:
Stumbled upon this today while looking for inspiration on what to eat for lunch. 

The line says it all - yummy, convenient, fresh!
author: Lisette P.

description:
I have been here more than two times. Each time I come here, the curry is just delicious! I ordered curry with tonkatsu and salmon over brown rice and tofu and vegetable over ramen. There's three different spice you can order from, I always order medium spice.The meal portion is more than enough, but I always end up finishing because I love their curry!! My friend and I tried the Curry Pan and we thought it tasted so good. However, I wished it was warm or hot like a hot pocket. :P

The workers there are so nice. They always make sure you get your order by calling your order number out quite a few times, which is awesome! I am definitely coming back. 

Note: I think around 12-2 or 3pm it can get pretty packed in there because it is located in the financial district with a lot of business people.
author: Ange G.

description: Muracci's is the best japa-curry in the area. It is tiny tho, so expect to be cramped in a closet-like room if you go during peak lunch times. They have these curry pan breads that are awesome, but they tend to run out if you go too late. I usually get the chicken katsu curry or the chicken karaage curry. They also offer brown rice for you healthy people. Check this one out.
author: J S.

description:
After weeks of staking this place out after hearing rave reviews from a coworker, I decided to go here to preempt Rickhouse. 

I am an absolute fan of Japanese Curry. Its less spicy than Indian curry and it doesn't give me the BG's haha (but I still eat Indian Curry anyway because its good).

I tried the Katsu Curry, because I wanted to compare it to Sagami's in Irvine and Cafe Hiro in Cypress. Honestly, I now have a 3 way tie for my favorite Japanese curry stateside. The price point is actually pretty good considering the location and probably split a serving in half and eat the rest later (but I didn't because it was really good).

The curry sauce had a nice consistency to it and it paired well with the katsu cutlet, which was fried perfectly (juicy and meaty). Surprisingly, the cutlet was not fatty, and I was afraid that would take away from the flavor of the pork, but the curry sauce had a good amount of flavor, yet was not overpowering at all. They don't give too much rice nor pickled veggies, which sucks, but the piece of pork they give you is huge, so maybe that dwarfs the rice and veggies...

I wussed out and got mild because the spicy ramen at Ramen Dojo torched me, so next time I will at least try medium heat and throw some cheese on it, the next time I'm in the FIDI prior to tossing a few back at Rickhouse.
author: Marc T.

description:
Wow, great stuff. I like the addition of spinach to the curry sauce. I was a little sketched when I saw the big tins of S&B curry powder in the kitchen but it's just a base. The katsu-kare I got was way beyond anything I could have put together with a box of Golden Curry in my kitchen. Also, the actual tonkatsu was very well prepared, VERY juicy and tasty.

I began eating it and fell into this kind of stupor that I didn't break out of until I had finished eating. It was Good.

Spicy was actually spicier than I've ever had in Japanese curry (even in Japan); that still doesn't mean it was spicy at all! Disappointing, but that's the status quo, so that's okay with me.

I also had a korokke (croquet) and they are mighty good. Unlike normal korokke (well maybe, I haven't had that many korokke in my life) there are pickles inside! It's like eating katsu-kare .. in a bun.

5 stars!!!
author: Josh K.

description: This place need some serious training on customer service. One star for the food being decent but it is not worth the time. My co-workers and I used the OrderAhead app to place our order. Ready time: 12:40, got there at 12:40 and waited another 20 minutes for the food. When asked when the food will be ready, this lady responded: If you don't see your food it's not ready. WTF!! We walked 4 blocks to get there (8 blocks total to get back) with one of us on crutches just to get back to the office to find out one of our order contain ONLY rice and without the Chicken Katsu Curry that was ordered (ofcourse it's the order for the one on crutches). WTF #2!! Called the place to let them know and their response: Well, you need to come back and get then. We have to walk back there (now a total 16 blocks back and forth...still on CRUTCHES) and they did not even apologize (still the same lady)! WTF #3 Food is decent like I said but at this time of age we also need good customer service. Good food is what makes us come and try but it's good CUSTOMER SERVICE that will keep us coming back and I am definitely NOT coming back!
author: Jenny L.

description:
Great place for lunch in the FiDi! It's a small shop, but wait time was not bad at all.

They have a option of white or brown rice. So far, I have tried their Katsu Curry and Oyako-don. Both dishes have hit my cravings spot on. They give you a side of picked cabbage and also a separate container for the curry, so you can choose how 'saucy' you want your Katsu rice to be. I think I chose medium spicy for my curry and the spice level was just right for me. I don't like my food to be overpowered by spice to the point where I can't taste what I'm eating and sweating unattractively. 

The Oyako-don was also tasty. The sweet flavor of the chicken and the moistness of the rice did not disappoint.
author: Jenny M.

description: curry noodle soup!!! spicy, yummy, slurp slurp!!!
author: Asiyat T.

description:
I always walk by this place but just tried it for the first time in 2 years the other day. I think I was always put off by the notions of 2 familiar things - Japanese food and curry- merged together in a way I was unfamiliar with. I didn't want to try to understand. 

But one day, I decided to bite the bullet.The tiny little place is very efficient. They take your order as you enter, they shout it to the cooks as you wait in line to get to the register and pay. I ordered chicken curry. I got my dish as soon as I got to the register.  It was pretty good, nice flavor - good quality meet. Cabbage pickles. The only thing is you have to specify if you want extras like veggies or (randomly) an egg. I wish I would have known that bc the chicken and rice alone was a bit boring. My friend had friend chicken and it was pretty bomb. I'll go back.
author: Hanan H.

description:
Tiny restaurant but there are a few seats (most people buy to go and eat at their office which I did when I worked in the Financial District) 

Curry explodes with flavor and you can choose your level of spicyness. 

I love curry and I love Muraccis!!!! Now if only they opened on the weekends too....
author: A. Z.

description:
Great curry.  My favorite is the katsu curry, thought I've had the beef curry which is ok.  They let you add things (hard boiled egg, spinach, etc.) which is nice.  Reasonably priced (par for the course in SF for lunch, a bit pricey compared to anywhere else) and the lines are insane.

If you can, fax or call in your order first.  Saves you a ton of time.
author: Ken L.

description: Very small place. The curry was katsu was yummy, but comes with no veges. I got the chicken karrage (no curry). It was crispy and tender. So yummy. Comes with miso soup, salad, and potato. Not bad at all.
author: Karen H.

description:
I love this place and when I don't know what to eat for lunch, this is always my safety place.  It's really close to work and since all I want is the mild chicken curry with white rice, the wait is only about 2 minutes.  Even if the Express meals are pre-cooked, it's still very warm by the time you start eating it in your office and it still tastes pretty awesome.

I'm not the biggest fan of curry but I really enjoy this place.  Still pretty pricey though but that's the Financial District for you.

The place is really really small so most people order take out.
author: Alyssa S.

description: Went here once and wasn't impressed. Yes, curry is simple and how can you mess it up...but oh yes you can. I got the tonkatsu (pork) curry. The Katsu was ok  but the rice was overcooked with too much water henceforth a bit mushy. It might have been an off day so I'll give them the benefit. Finally, the curry was just ok, not memorable. Overall, the curry didn't have that "it" factor for me but just ok. Small place so I think of this place for more of take out. Check out Japa curry food truck instead but in a pinch this place will do since Japanese curry is a bit sparse in the city.
author: Tim S.

description:
This was my first time to try Muracci's Japanese Curry.....Yup, I did not type wrong.  It was hard to believe that I have worked in the financial district for many years and I never have a chance to try their curry.  

My co-worker and I were there around 12:15pm and the line was already outside the door.  But don't worry, the line moved pretty fast.  I ordered the Katsu Curry (mild) with brown rice.  It was about $10.  $10 was OK in the financial district but little pricy for take out.  Anyway, the food was made to order...so it was steamy and fresh.  The pork was crunchy while not being dried.  The curry was tasty and wasn't too spicy at all , so if you expect more, order medium or hot.  The brown rice was really chewy and perfect combination with the curry.

This place can get SUPER busy during lunch, so ordering ahead of time for pick up is a must (I saw a lot of people were doing this)!  I waited about 20 minutes to get my order (10 minutes wait in line and 10 minutes wait for food).  Also, it is hard to eat over there because there are only two small tables and 5-6 stools.
author: Liza T.

description:
I'm biased.  I have a soft spot for Japanese curry.  But, that also means that I've tried a lot of it -- both in Japan and in the U.S.  
This is some of the best I've had on this side of the Pacific.  Katsu is always crispy -- if you don't let it sit a long time -- and the breading is just right. I think the extra spicy is a bit much, but the medium spicy is perfect!
Wish I went more often, but I just have to eat it all, and I go into a sleepy coma at work afterwards.
author: Ryan T.

description:
I'm a Curry Freak. I luv all things Curry, with Japanese style Curry being one of my favorites.

I got the Katsu Curry hot, white rice. 

http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/7qK2Gwu0afQMtYFSJvvCqQ?select=v2ZodxUYz2W3GY7AsiEmIw

Good portions. Tasty fukujinzuke on the side. very fresh.

Hit the spot at 1pm on a Monday and it was slammed full of people, no way I could have eaten at the place, too bad. Wish I could have. 

Muracci's is located on Kearney St, along the "Restaurant Block of Death" as I like to call it. I say this because most restaurant's open up here and then slowly die (or very quickly {One I remember only staying open for 6 days}). I've seen dozens of places go in and out of business on this row over the last 6 years. I'm happy to say I don't think Muracci's will join them.
author: Paul V.

description: pork katsu curry was really good! definitely will be back to check everything else out!
author: Wilson K.

description:
This is definitely my favorite place in the Financial District for Japanese food that isn't sushi.  The big thing here is obviously...the curry.  The Katsu Curry might be the most popular, but I like to get the chicken curry over rice.

They give you really a ton of food... plenty of crispy fried meat of whatever type you choose, and a seriously big thing of curry sauce to pour over it and your rice.

You do not want to try to eat here though.  It's crowded and with minimal seating.  Take it to go -- if it's sunny you can even eat in the plaza in front of the Bank of America building.  (C'mon, where's our sunshine?!? Aaah!)
author: David W.

description: Delicious Japanese curry - even the medium spicy curry was very hot to me, and I dig food! Had the salmon and brown rice and added veggies to the deal, and it was a tasty AND healthy lunch. Score.
author: Marla W.

description:
Portions = modest
Taste = unimpressive
Prices = OK

For a place that "specializes" in curry they serve the most unimpressive curry. Not only is the texture of the gravy weird, it tastes stale and the vegetables are not cooked in the sauce. The portions weren't terribly huge so it's not llike this was a bargain, and all the desserts and other crap they sell seemed to have been prepared elsewhere and retailed here.

Got some katsu and croquettes... hard to fuck up fried food, but again, unremarkable.

I am bored.
author: Y K.

description: Came here to catch up with a few friends over lunch. We knew the place was tiny and were planning to take our food to a nearby area and enjoy, but we ended up just grubbing in the place. We came at an odd time (after lunch rush), so it was fairly empty. Their food is definitely good quality stuff and tastes really authentic. We all ended up getting the chicken katsu curry because they had run out of tonkatsu :( Next time I'm in the area I'm going for the tonkatsu. They give you the option of brown rice which is always a plus for me. Making it easy for me to be healthier? Yes, please! The people behind the counter were suuuper nice and welcoming and even brought water over to us (mind you, this is definitely not a sit-down kinda place). Definitely worth a trip, but you probably want to avoid lunch time because it'll be crowded with all the suits!
author: Sannie L.

description:
Wow - this place is awesome. So much better than the stupid pie shop that was here and the flavorless Japanese stuff across the road.

I got the Angus beef teriyaki lunch meal on brown rice for $9.73. The beef is buttery, so soft and delicious, I even took a photo of it! Everything else was nice, the rice, lettuce salad and miso soup. Well worth the price. Next time, I'll try their curries - definitely look good.

Not too crowded on a Tuesday around 1pm, straight in and out. Service was prompt, and they had a bunch of cooks working in a very tight section, let's hope they can find something bigger in the area.
author: Joseph T.

description:
I don't know why it took me so long to write a review, but ta-da.. . Finally.

This place has really good Japanese curry. I ordered the Ebi Fry Curry, with brown rice. I really love that you have the option of white or brown rice. Not a lot of places offer brown rice. What I ordered was pretty good, but I wish it came with more prawns. :/

Other than that, this is definitely my go-to place for Japanese curry. Oh, here's a tip: Call ahead and pre-order, 'cause the wait is pretty long. But at least you know you're waiting for something good. :]
author: Valerie N.

description:
Curry: 4.5 Star
Radish: +1 star
Overall: 5 star

After all the rave I hear from my friends and see online from 7x7, I finally got a chance today to try out their Chicken Katsu Curry. The overall experience was amazing: the breading on the chicken was perfect, not too thick and still very crispy, the curry spiciness was just about right, but becareful if you aren't use to japanese curry though, make sure you choose the spicness level you can handle cause it can get pretty hot, lastly, the sweetness and sourness of the radish side was just perfect to top off the curry. However, I do wish the curry included a bit of veggies, not sure if that would be authentic japanese style though.
author: Tony L.

description: I decided to try this place because of the reviews on yelp. I order curry with fried pork to go and was disappointed. Since, I don't find anything special about this place. I definitely wouldn't go out of my way for their curry, since I live far.
author: Aniko N.

description: Definitely the best Japanese curry place in SF. I really liked the hole in the wall feel to it: it is a very small establishment but the food is great! I got the Katsu Curry, the pork cutlet was crispy and tender, and the curry sauce was creamy and delicious. The pickled vegetables balance it out with its tartness. Definitely going back to try other things!
author: Joy C.

description:
This is not Curry House (http://www.yelp.com/biz/coco-ichiban-curry-house-honolulu)... in case you're from Hawaii, craving chicken katsu curry with cheese, and crossing your fingers that it turns up in the Yelp SF search. But this isn't bad either. This just isn't Curry freakin' amazing' House.

I like my chicken pounded thinly and my panko dusted heavily, but here it is the opposite case.  I also didn't like how the cheese was blended into the curry instead of melted on the chicken katsu. I guess you like what you grow up with. The curry had a great flavor and kick, though.

Because it took 20 minutes for the food, I also got the korokke (croquette). I loved that this was instant, hot, curry-infused, and only $1.75! This is a good snack to have in waiting for the faint of tummy.

Order beforehand--it's over-flooded with business.
author: Liz T.

description: I was staying near Chinatown for a work trip and found Muracci's before they closed on a week night.  I tried the Katsu over brown rice.  The pork was delicious and well prepared.  I ordered the Medium spice for the curry and it has a fair amount of heat.  I loved the pickles that they add on the side.  Delicious, simple and comforting food.
author: Amanda F.

description: The katsu is cooked pretty close to perfection. It is a nice slice of meat that is crisp on the outside and tender and full of flavor. The mild curry has a nice kick to it, not too spicy. The portion size is pretty nice for the price but still on the pricey side.  The curry bread was good but more on the salty side. It was cold when I ate it; I think it would be better warm and crispy. The service was kinda of slow for a restaurant that was less than half full and all those people had their food.
author: Eve C.

description:
This curry is serious business.

It has a thicker consistency than most others, and the cut of meat (I can speak for the chicken and pork at least) is full and lean.  Both of these factors make for a very hearty meal.

It's one of those popular lunchtime places lacking a seating area, so definitely call in ahead.  Bonus points for putting the curry in a tub of its own, so you can apply it as you please when you sit down to eat.

Last I went, $9.80 for a chicken katsu curry (includes the fat bed of rice and two small, pickled veggie sides).
author: Alex C.

description: Amazing curry that can be quite hot if you ask for it. Unlike the Los Altos location, which has plenty of seating, the one in SF is all about getting the FiDi lunch crowd in and out. It's not uncommon to see a line out the door. Still, for the volume it handles, the meals here are reliably good. The tonkatsu is always crunchy on the outside, tender and moist on the inside.
author: M S.

description:
My favorite Japanese Curry place in the city, it's cheap and good

make sure to call in your order, this place can get very busy during lunch
author: Eric A.

description: This is my go to lunch spot with my coworkers and friends when I am working in this area of SF (near Chinatown). Sometimes I find myself craving the curry lunch sets. They give you the curry separate so it can be poured over your meat and rice and the lunch set also comes with salad and another side dish. Yum!
author: Jenny Z.

description: A real find in the city for lunch if you are a Katsu and curry fan. Not a lot of sitting room, so try to arrive before the lunch rush.
author: Andrew S.

description:
This place is good, no doubt.  So why only the 4 star review when you only give reviews to 5 star places?  Well everything besides the food is subpar.  The curry is great!  Got a good spicy to it and it tastes delicious.  I go here regularly as I work like 2 blocks away.  Anyway I think the more useful part of the review is the bad.

Place takes forever to make your food.  Call ahead or order the express curry if you want ur food fast.  Here's a menu to help with that: http://dineries.com/ca/sanfrancisco/muraccisjapanesecurryandgrill/307kearnyst

The fried croquette and curry bun in line is generally cold.  If you don't mind, then go for it, but I like my food hot!!!

The place is tiny, and you probably don't wanna eat here.

The price, i guess i standard FD pricing, but I feel like it's pretty expensive for what it is.  

All in all, it's probably still the best japanese curry i've had in the city.
author: Andrew Y.

description:
Meal: Lunch
Date: March 2, 2009

Despite the fact that I walked in unprepared and ordered a dish with a sweet (instead of spicy) sauce I was happy with my overall experience at Muracci's. I ordered the Katsu Chicken Meal (#17) which came with miso and salad. Part of the fun of being was watching the staff working like crazy to get everyone's order right. They weren't always successful on that count or at least in one case that I witnessed they forgot to give a customer her order until she asked about it. This was after she saw a people who had come in after her get served before her. They also goofed and gave her the wrong kind of rice, brown instead of white.

The meal I got was very tasty. I poured both sauces over the chicken and did my best to polish off the meal. In the end I left some of the prodigious amount of brown rice they gave me but finished everything else off.

On the down side this isn't the sort of place you can be in and out of in a hurry, unless you call in advance. Also this is a lunch box so there isn't much in the way of places to sit, just a few stools and a couple counters; room for no more than 8-10 people to sit and eat at a time.
author: Dave L.

description: Tastes pretty authentic, like the kind you get in Japan. I had a chicken katsu curry. The chicken was cooked just right with a crispy panko casing. Just wished they gave more fukujinzuke.
author: Kenson K.

description:
I got the #3, Katsu Curry with a side of boiled veggies.

The food was yummy! After awhile I felt like it was too much for me! It's definitely a share-able size. :)

Loved the packaging and all.. would definitely be back to try their other items!
author: C C.

description:
Muracci's...oh how you hurt me with your delicious curry.

This is owned and ran by the people in the shop you see, Japanese folks that are polite and nice. The curry was awesomely delicious (I recommend getting it with vegatables). The bad thing about this place is that my first time going there...I had to wait 45 minutes for pre-made curry. They had gotten the order wrong and wasted a lot of my time. That was my first visit...and it was their first day open so I can't blame them for long wait and errors. 

I decided to go again this time calling in...ordered my food...and picked it  up with no hitch.

This place is awesome but small...and I recommend going there at least once a week...to stay regular :D.
author: Michael L.

description:
I really like murracci's. They use the right kind of brown rice (well, the kind I like) and their ingredients seem fresh, clean, and straightforward. Japanese curry is very good - on the milder side and not as fatty as some curries. 

My only complaint is the interface. This is a tiny place and it is mobbed every day. I got there early yesterday and I still waited 20 minutes for my food due to all the to go orders ahead of me. 

So my rating is based on this:
- Not the most relaxing place to even get a takeout lunch, ordering there can eat up your lunch hour if you're schedule-minded
- Some of their curries are heavy on the sauce and sparse on the actual food. For almost ten dollars, I don't think all of their portions are entirely reasonable. The non-fried curries are especially scant. The fried items are more substantial because they fry filets and breasts. I don't really like to get fried food often though.
- 

Favorites:

- Chicken tonkatsu Curry on Brown Rice
- Salmon Curry on Brown Rice
author: Roxmarie M.

description:
I never know when I've got a craving for curry and I should know better to call ahead as Muracci's Japanese Curry & Grill almost always has a line out the door.  Each time from waiting in line to getting my order 20 minutes has past.  The food is good, portions fair - and priced right.

Today I was lucky in and out within 10 minutes - no place to sit to dine in - so I had to bring it back to the office.
author: Rich W.

description: Tie for top Japanese curry with Kare-ken.  I gave Kare-ken the edge because it is much more fun to eat there, but Muracci may have the edge in ingredients and variety.  Very crowded unfun lunchtime environment, so you're there just to eat (or maybe better just bring it back to the office).
author: Ric S.

description: It's super simple but yet so delicious. Love this place and I always will. Some loss of points for the non environmental friendly containers otherwise I am a fan for life.
author: Kim M.

description:
i don't understand the hype around this place. while this place is good, it's not mindblowing good. i wouldn't wait in that awkward line, with people squished in their 250 sq ft joint just to get some of this curry. muracci's is worth trying but i wouldn't hold such high expectations about this place. just decent, good curry.

be warned, however, if you're ordering take-out! my friends and i ordered three curries to go last week for lunch... brought it back to the office only to find out they forgot one of the curries. kinda ridiculous how we went to a curry joint specifically wanting curry, only to come back and be missing a curry. apparently this has happened in the past to my other friend as well.
author: Monica S.

description: Authentic, Japanese-style curry. This place is a hole in the wall with literally just a couple of stools so plan to take out. They get pretty busy too around lunch time, so just keep that in mind and be patient. I'm a big fan of Katsu, so overall I liked this place. I made a mistake of ordering brown rice though which honestly just doesn't do all that sauce any justice. You need to order it with white rice and let all that curry goodness soak the rice. I'm also a big fan of spicy food, so I ordered "hot" which was spicy but it didn't burn a hole on my tongue or anything. The guy behind the counter said it's spicy, but not Thai-spicy. Probably a good way of putting it.
author: Carita O.

description: Muracci's is a solid choice for lunch in the Financial District whenever you're in the mood for curry. The lines are long during lunch rush but in 10-15 minutes, your food will be ready to eat. Their curries are pretty good - you can choose from mild, medium, or hot. Very few seating areas, so search for some outdoor seating around the area or bring it back to your office. And of course, since it *is* curry, expect your co-workers to smell your delicious lunch from a few cubicles away!
author: Emily C.

description:
I mean, they give you brown rice without charging extra.  How nice!

The curry here is good - very flavorful.  I got the vegetarian one and they don't skimp on the veggies and tofu at all.  

Not much else to say other than I really wish I was in SF during the weekdays so I could come here more often!
author: Kristine B.

description: The katsu curry was delicious.  The katsu was crispy and tender. The medium curry was not too spicy and complimented the katsu very well.  The side of pickled vegetables were a nice contrast to the heaviness of the curry dish.
author: Kai C.

description:
Love this place. It's on my rotation for lunch during the week. 
I always get the noodles w/chicken & veggies with Medium Curry. YUM. YUM. YUM. Perfect for a cold day...or any day for that matter!

CALL AHEAD, place your order via phone then jump to the front of the line and pick it up.
author: Isabel M. L.

description:
I really liked the curry sauce and the cutlet was perfectly fried and breaded.

I thought it was a lot better than Kare Ken in the Tenderloin.
author: Irving P.

description: Yum yum yum! Katsu Curry was awesome! My coworkers say that they've been a little stingy with their curry sauce lately but I had enough left over to go with my rice the next day. I usually prefer not to eat pork chop but this one is super soft and not chewy and GOOD. Pickled vegetables are sooooo good! Will definitely ask for more next time. Call in to place an order if you don't want to be waiting in that tiny, tiny spot for 20 minutes for your food to be ready.
author: Amy Z.

description: it's a really small place and can get pretty crowded during the lunch hour on the weekdays. only go there with the thought of ordering to-go. wasn't overly impressed; i mean, it was good, not great. as far as i'm concerned, it's one of the few curry-oriented places in the area, so just for that reason alone, i'll be going back.
author: Mike C.

description: For vegetarians, it's not that great. The first time, they missed a small side that I ordered; the second time the order was fine, but the food was nothing special to me. It didn't taste much different than "golden curry" packs sold at Chinese food markets... If you like those, or eat meat, you'll probably be more impressed than me.
author: Gatoatigrado A.

description:
Everything here is delicious!!! Katsudon too!

I also like the new curry topping options...potato and cheese.
author: Wakako U.

description: This place is overrated and super underwhelming.  Japacurry truck is way better.  I got the chicken curry and the chicken was dry, stringy and there were only a few pieces.  The curry sauce had a lot of ginger flavoring in it (not my favorite flavor).  I don't know why this place has such a long line--go down the street to the curry truck.  This place is not worth it.
author: F S.

description:
This is partially my fault, but my order got screwed up today.  I thought I ordered a chicken katsu curry, but when I got back to the office to eat my lunch, I realized that I had been given a chicken curry.  I double checked my receipt and the woman who took my order must not have heard me say katsu, because all it said was chicken curry.  So no fried, breaded goodness for me today and that kind of bums me out..  The really bad part about today's experience is that the grilled chicken I was given tasted old.  It just didn't taste good enough to eat, so I ended up having curry rice for lunch.  SO not worth eight bucks and the 15 minute wait.

Also, according to their menu, the lupicia tea bags are supposed to be $1.40.  But when I checked my receipt, I was charged $1.90.  This was definitely not a good muracci's day for me.

I have had their katsu curry on previous occasions, and while I've had better, it does the trick when I'm craving katsu curry.  I'm sure I'll be back once this bummer experience has been forgotten.
author: Lisa C.

description:
A gleaming column of light in the Financial District. I am not trying to over-sell this but I really enjoyed my food. 

We came here on the recommendation of one of our co-workers. A little played out on the corporate burritos and Soup options, we needed a new choice. When he said "I know a Japanese curry place, I was intrigued. 

When you walk in this place it is a fast food format. The space is hardly enough to hold the lunch line. You will wait around 5 minutes to order. Then most of us waited 15 minutes for our food. I know that sounds like a lot but you are truly getting a quality meal. I feel the quality is above the range of this neighborhood.

I ordered the chicken Katsu, along with a mango Calpico and a piece of cake (don't judge me, they looked delicious). 

The chicken was not too oily but crispy and great quality. The brown rice was a nice complement along with the most important part... The curry. I asked for spicy and while I am sure there are places in the world who would have helped me to "feel the burn" a bit more, this place gave me a mildly spicy and very flavorful curry. 

Looks like we have a new lunch standard.
author: Eric G.

description:
It took forever but was D*** Good! Why did itt ake forever? Because they make it fresh! Fresh food, in Fidi? Are they crazy! What are they trying to do, make sure I actually get a healthy and tasty lunch? For Shame!

Yea, I love this place. They don't mind that I speak to them in my white-boy broken Japanese. Hurrah!

They need a bigger space though, their food's too good for that closet.
author: Cory D.

description:
We went here today for lunch.  SUPER tasty!!! 

The only thing preventing them from getting 5 stars from me is that the curry is not cheap... $8.50 for a katsu curry but if you want veggies or spinach in your curry or a boiled egg it's all extra... It is easily a $10+ dollar lunch, which, just isn't my everyday work lunch fare.

Every once in a while I crave me a good katsu and this place will definitely be my go to when that craving hits!
author: Cindy C.

description:
I went here for lunch upon another great rec from Yelp.  The curry is fantastic and authentic!  The spot is quite small and seats no more than 10 people at a time.  I had a short wait for my katsu chicken curry.  I'm looking forward to the next visit. 

p.s. Get your curry medium spicy.  The heat is just right, even for my wimpy taste-buds.
author: Lisa R.

description:
Hole in the wall restaurant. Always packed during lunch time!
