Let me tell you, the curry is FTW! Straight proper!

I order the beef curry, extra meat and extra sauce. Why? MOAR SAUZ PLZ!

Plus if I don't eat breakfast I usually splurge for an extra curry croquette which is out of this world!

Bottom line: I don't have to wish to go to Japantown for lunch, when I have this diamond in the rough close to work!
author: Aaron P.

description:
Amazing that they turn out such good curry in such a tiny space. Feels like being in Japan.

Love it!!
author: Andrew L.

description: Love it love it love it!  This is my favorite curry spot in the city, and the husband-wife duo that runs it is super nice.
author: Jenna L.

description:
Yum, this place is good and always packed. I suggest going around 1.30 when the line dies down. But still worth the wait!

It's fast, its cheap and affordable, and you get what you pay for. This is one of my fave places to go in the Financial District.
author: Carissa E.

description:
This is a great concept as I love Japanese style curry and I was really optimistic given this was a shop whose betting its income stream on having the best curry out there. I'm not going to lie, I thoroughly enjoyed the curry. However, I felt like the ratio of curry to rice was a bit low and the curry had little ingredients in it. The flavor was great, though nothing that much better than that of the Golden Curry bars you can make yourself. 

Maybe this is as good as it gets for Japanese Curry. Certainly that wasn't my experience in Japan. Perhaps they need to diversify.
author: Andrew H.

description:
This reminds me of the curry houses in Japan. I was nice to close my eyes and remember all the good times I had there with just the first whiff as I walked into the Marucci's Japanese Curry and Grill. The Katsu curry is cooked to perfection with a light and flaky crunch. I recommend this!
-So Say We All
author: Joe L.

description: When i worked downtown I came to this place at least once a week.  I studied abroad in Japan and love curry.  This place definitely is as close as you can get to curry in Japan.  I love the katsu and tofu and veggies curry.  The pickles that come with the meal are amazing and really help cut the spice of the curry.
author: Nancy M.

description: The katsu curry here is all I ever get. I first came across this place from the 7x7 must eats list, and thought it definitely lived to up its expectations. While the place is small, and kind of hole-in-the-wall, the food is amazing, and everything seems to be clean. Will definitely be back for more when I'm craving something Japanese that's not sushi.
author: Victor C.

description:
I was thoroughly impressed. Craving some delicious Katsu, all the reviews here seemed great, so I took the plunge. I didn't wait but maybe 10 minutes, (although apparently you can call ahead) and it was SO worth it. You can choose white or brown rice, and they keep the sauce on the side when you order to go, which is crucial. The incredibly crispy, and perfectly cooked pork then does not get soggy. I got medium spicy, just because I wasn't sure how hardcore they were - next time I'm going hot. If you like spicy foods, I'd go hot, medium didn't quite cut it for me.

They were very friendly, and the lines were long by about 12:30, so it was cramped in there. As far as I'm concerned, that's just testament to good food, so it doesn't bother me. They had a few places to sit, also. I'll definitely be back, as it cured my Katsu cravings PERFECTLY.
author: Nick B.

description:
I'd been dying to try this place as soon as I had heard about it. Tonkatsu is one of my favorite foods, and every once and awhile I get a craving for katsu-kare. It seemed like a pain that this place was only open during the week, but since my friend and I wanted to do something spontaneous with our Friday, we decided to brave the rain and take the train up to the city to try this place out!

This place was easy to miss, but we found a full house when we finally found it. We placed our orders, and I got to munch on my korokke (curry-flavored croquette) while we waited for our food. Like I said, it was crowded, and this place is dinky, but we were able to snag two seats at a bar by the front door.

After a little (understandable) wait, our food was ready. While the katsu-kare was perfect on a cold, rainy day like today, I wasn't too crazy about it. I know I've had better curry elsewhere here in San Jose. I had more of a sensation of heat than actual flavor. The whole meal made for a nice lunch, and it was a neat experience to stare out at the city in the rain as I munched on my curry, but I wasn't blown away.

Overall, I liked this place. Probably wouldn't go back, but I didn't regret the choice. I kinda left feeling that if my favorite hole-in-the-wall sushi joint in San Jose (Shiki Japanese Restaurant off Santa Teresa and Cottle!) was plopped in San Francisco's Financial District, it'd be the talk of the town, too.
author: Chris C.

description: Decent. Their curry's on the more flavorful side of your regular Japanese curry. The line was long and the store crowded so it may be worthwhile to come early. The curry comes separately which is nice - so that your tonkatsu doesn't get all soggy on the trip back to the office.
author: Gee H.

description:
$9 for a chicken katsu curry dish.

The curry is definitely authentic Japanese and the chicken katsu wasn't bad. However, I felt that the dish was still lacking in number of things that were in it. I needs more veggies or something for $9. 

No complaints on the flavor but it didn't blow my mind.
author: Shawn T.

description:
If you want to know what is good quality Japanese food, ask a native. They seem to have some incredible ability to know what places are acceptable...even if they've never been there. As it is, one of my friends from overseas who has never even been to SF recommended Muracci's to me after we discussed curry, udon, their combination; and my friend did a quick bit of Google-work to find me a place to enjoy it.

I've had plenty of udon before, but never Japanese curry. I'm normally accustomed to Indian style curries, but for someone who doesn't care much for rich, heavy foods, they aren't something I can or want to eat regularly, so the thought of making a whole soup out of my favorite noodles and curry made me cautious, but optimistic; especially considering the mystical clairvoyance of my foreign friends who had yet to steer me wrong. Learning that the curries I've always known are quite different from the Japanese variety also made the prospect more palatable.

It turns out I've been missing out in a big way... I love it! It's hard to know if it's the dish or the restaurant preparing it, but that's sort of irrelevant. Muracci's hooked me. The couple running the place are adorably sweet and it's interesting to watch them interact as you order, wait and then eat.

The food itself, which I've had twice now, is quite good. The curries they make from scratch and involves a long, home-cooked process, which is probably why they only have X number of servings per day for some of their menu items. They make/cook each dish as it's ordered, so you get the freshest possible servings. I'm a huge fan of spicy foods, and was delighted that they allowed me to specify exactly how dangerous I wanted to live; they totally delivered on my request too... not enough to make my forehead sweat, but enough to force the pouring of a second glass of water down my food hole.

Bottom line: Obviously, I've gone back twice in about one week; the place is excellent. Tiny--maybe a dozen bar stools total--but worth eating in or taking things out. It's also easy to miss if you're not careful...it's right next door to the Cinta Aveda institute! Now, if they could open a location more convenient to my East Bay apartment, I could award an elusive six stars.

PS...don't insult the place by stopping in for a single korokke (croquette); I saw a few of these customers in just two visits. Get some damn curry!
author: Aaron H.

description:
It's hard to find faults with this place. 

Good J-curry (by Japanese metropolitan standards)
Good cutlet (nice portion, cooked in high temperature-Japanese way)
Family owned (same person makes their curry everyday using the same exact recipe) 

I would easily give them 5 stars if I found them in the middle of an Arabian desert. However, they run business in SF Bay Area and it's 2011. You need to be better than the curry places in Japan to deserve the ultimate status. I would rate this restaurant 3.5 (7/10).

If you want to try J-curry and you happen to be in the Bay Area, skip other options and come here. This is what you can truly call J-curry by our standards. If you don't like their curry, then forget the fuck about J-curry. 

One beef I had with their great tasting curry was the portion of the curry sauce. I previously wrote "nice portion" but that was referring to the cutlet, not the curry sauce. Rule of Thumb: J-curry is satisfactory when they give you the curry sauce a little more than you want to finish the rice with. Not a whole lot more, but should be more than "just enough". You know what the fuck I'm talking about? 

The Muracci family is originally from Osaka, Japan where locals are known for being severely tight-ass. They know how to make things  and they know how to make money out of it, but unless they're converted Christians, they will try to do anything to keep their operation and products cost-effective. They will not give you any mercy by allowing you to have a few extra bites. I could rate them 4.2 in the category of "Osaka cheapass Curry". 



Edit: I just read that somebody wrote this: "I remember not having enough curry the first time around so I forked out the $1.75 for extra curry and now I have extra curry sittin  g on my desk." 

This is a pretty good option as I'm sure many non-Osakan Japanese people will feel the same.  1.75 sounds just right.
author: yota L.

description: I love this place. The service is very quick, and the food is delicious. I usually get the spicy katsu chicken and am yet to be disappointed.  If you're looking for a quick grab and go lunch this place is gueranteed to be great.
author: Daniel G.

description:
What can be better than a take-out box full of Japanese curry over katsu (breaded pork) and rice ($8.95) on a cold, gloomy day in San Francisco? Came a little past 12:30pm on a Friday afternoon and the place was packed with people waiting for their take-outs. Luckily, only 3 people were ahead of me in line. Ordered the medium spicy katsu curry and waited at one of their 9 seats for about 10 minutes.

When I finally got my paws on the curry - YUM! The medium wasn't too spicy. The curry, which came in a separate container was thick and flavorful, not at all watered down, like some places. They gave a good amount of curry so I initially drenched my katsu and rice in curry, then dipped my katsu in leftover curry from the container. I should be ashamed because I even started to sip the curry sauce directly from the container with my plastic spoon in the end. And yes! I ALSO combined my friend's leftover curry with my own and took it home. ::cries::

My only gripe is that my pork katsu was a bit chewy. The chicken katsu was juicier so I'll be ordering that next time. Loved the pickled cabbage and radish.

Some tips:
- When you order curry, choose the protein, your level of spiciness (mild, medium, hot), and type of rice (white or brown) 
- There is an express line for beef / chicken curry, mild spiciness only. Order and leave. No wait.
- Order anything else and the wait is about 10 minutes
- Only about 9 seats available in the place so you can't always bet on a seat in this tiny joint
author: Tina T.

description:
The food here is really good. The Chicken Katsu is freshly deep fried so it comes out nice and crispy. I like how everything is made to order. Nice and fresh.

The lines are long during lunch, the wait for the food is much longer. What do you expect if you want made to order foods right? The restaurant is so tiny, the line is usually out the door. If only they got a bigger place. 

I don't suggest dining in there, there are only a handful of stools. Its best to sit there, wait for your food and depart.
author: Nance H.

description:
Another item to check off the 7x7 Big Eat List: Katsu Curry.

I am so happy I trekked over this way from SOMA. For such a small venue, I expected the lines to be out the door but the people behind the counter are fantastically efficient. I've been here twice now--first time, having the Katsu Curry, the following, having the beef curry.

I don't like bland food so I ordered a medium spicy curry. It was so delicious and flavorful. Just the right amount of hot intensity where I know they added spice but not too much where I can't taste my food anymore. 

I have to say that the Katsu curry is much better than the beef. The pork was much juicier and was a better complement for the curry. The beef was okay but not tender enough. Plus, they didn't give too much meat.

The brown rice option is a big plus for me. Plus, it's way healthier than its white counterpart. 

Highly recommend this place if you're ever craving Japanese curry. Service is great and functions like a well-oiled machine.

4 stars.
author: Jonathan L.

description: Come here for the famous curry pork cutlet.  Nothing special.  Neither the pork nor the curry.  The price is very attractable.  They should put some vege on the plate.
author: Morris M.

description:
This is little hole-in-the-wall place.  I think there were about 4-5 stools to sit so you definitely want to do take-out.  We ate our lunches at the Galleria.  
My brother and I ordered the chicken katsu curry (medium spicy).  Our friend ordered the chicken katsu (hot).  I like how they had the curry in another container so the curry doesn't get the katsu and rice all mushy.  It was delicious.  My brother recommended that we get cheese added to the curry for $1.  That was a cool addition.  
We walked in just a few minutes after noon and we had to wait about 5-10 minutes for food.  
This was great food and I was stuffed.  I would definitely recommend this place and I'll be back!
My brother, by the way, looks like the Muracci's logo.
author: Brent T.

description: It's way overpriced and I wasn't very impressed. I ordered curry at the bento place on the same street and they tasted similar and it was $4 cheaper.
author: Yoko S.

description:
So I was directed to this place after seeing it on the SF 7x7 top 100 food places 3 years in a row and since it combines one of my favorite kinds of food, (katsu fried chicken) my favorite food activity, (pouring a delicious gravy or sauce over rice) and finally, one of my favorite sauces (curry) I had to check it out for myself.

Open for lunch til 5 or 6 PM on the weekdays this location is basically a walk in and order from the counter place so get in, take your order, wait in line then grab your food and get out! There may be some tables in here somewhere but i have yet to see them. There is a long counter opposite of the kitchen and ordering area but I dont recommend sitting here to eat unless its empty.

Onto the food...ordered the Chicken Katsu curry and grilled chicken curry for a friend, both with the medium heat curry and drove home to enjoy the goods. 

Even after a 45 minute drive home was happy to say the katsu chicken was still crispy and hot. The grilled chicken plate seemed to be lacking in portion size however in comparison to the Katsu cutlet so not sure if that is the usual or what. Also I am a BIG stickler on rice consistency and prefer to have rice on the dry side so I have to say it was a bit more mushy for my taste. I tend not to like my rice when it clumps together in big balls and not separate. Again not sure if this is the norm but both plates were the same. 

Poured the curry sauce over the plate and that is when I realize these guys are on top  for a reason and that is simply this: their currey sauce here is simply amazing. In my experience there are two kinds of curry sauces I enjoy: the thinner milk/yogurt and/or coconut based sauces from indian and Thai cuisines and the thicker non dairy based ones that I see with chinese/japanese curries and as you can imagine the curry here is the latter variety.

This curry sauce is magic. I am pretty sure if I poured it over anything it would immediately turn it into the best curry-whatever it is I just poured over it dish of all time. It just has the perfect balance of flavors and a deep rich curry flavor that any curry dish or sauce should strive for. 

 So in spite of the mushy rice and just so-so chicken katsu the dish immediately becomes top tier once you add the curry. I would just go ahead and order another another to-go bowl of curry as that one helping they give you will not satiate your craving for the curry and you will inevitably end up with leftover rice or chicken with no sauce left.

Also the main reason for the 5 stars? You would think it would be the curry sauce and while it is special I have to say the thing that keeps me going back to SF in the middle of the ridiculous lunch rush even though I work nowhere near SF is the freakin CURRY PAN. These little deep fried, panko bread rolled, dough hot pockets filled with tasty curry love are simply....i have no words. The outer crust is fried to perfection and does not taste oily at all and has just the perfect salty and chewy exterior before you bite down and hit the curry gold inside. Fillings come in chicken, hot chicken, beef, hot beef, beef and veggie and just veggie. The filling is the perfect level of moistness not runny and not to dry or crumbly and they have the perfect ratio of filling to bread. Dip in curry sauce and say goodnight to any number of top 5 foods you have on your list.

So in summary: Go to Muraccis. Buy Curry Pan. Buy Curry sauce. Dip. NOM.
author: Donnie W.

description:
Among the best katsu with curry I've ever had.  The pork was moist, tender, flavorful, and featured perfectly crunchy exterior. Unlike a lot of Japanese curry I've had, Muracci's curry is nuanced and satisfying. The hot curry was spicy enough without being overpowering. 

Service is friendly, but understandably frazzled by the swarm of lunchers; after telling me they were out of chicken katsu, they told me they still had it, only to tell me once more that they did not have it. This led to a longer wait for my food.  

As others have mentioned, getting the food to go is preferable to hunting for one of the few seats in Muracci's cramped interior. The katsu remained impressively crunchy despite my taking a five or ten minute trek to find a suitable lunch spot.
author: Chris T.

description: Best chicken katsu and best curry = best chicken katsu curry I've ever had. Don't worry about the crowded space and lack of seating...it's all about the food here. If you want to be served at a table, eat at the Olive Garden.
author: Joshua H.

description: Best chicken katsu curry over rice I ever had! I always get the curry spicy and its the right amount of kick without feeling like burning your mouth. The chicken katsu is made fresh and juicy, not dry like in other places I usually get it at. Highly recommend this place.
author: Tony Y.

description:
When it was decided that I was going to get Japanese Curry from a place in Downtown, I had an image in my head that it would be a pretty big to a medium sized restaurant that served Japanese food and some good curry. Little did I know that it was a hole in the wall curry joint with barely any room to stand. Apparently, its a popular place since there was a huge line out the door for it, and yet, I have never heard of the place. 

You could smell the curry oozing from this place. I ordered the Tofu and Veggie + Beef curry w/ brown rice and my bf ordered the Chicken Katsu. I was pretty darn shocked that they served brown rice. My jaw almost hit the ground. I was excited cuz that meant that I didn't have to worry too much about how much rice I'd consume with the curry. 

We also tried the croquettes which weren't bad. It was definitely tasty. When the order came, I was glad that they used eco-friendly packaging for pretty much everything. 

I'd have to say that the katsu was really good. There was a lot of meat, it wasn't dry and just so tasty! The beef that I had with my tofu and veggie curry was NOT good. It was so tough I had to chew it for about 5 mins before I could swallow it. (well I don't really know how long cuz after about 15 chews I gave up and just swallowed it like a pill -_- ) I didn't touch the meat after that. 

Overall, the curry wasn't bad. However, the curry tasted different from other places I've been to. I would say that I'd come back, however, I would go to other places before I'd go back there - like the Japanese restaurant in Japantown next to Sophie's crepes. 

Having curry at Curry House in Hawai'i spoiled me a little bit. Nothing can compare to that curry place. Wish they'd hurry up and open one in San Francisco already.
author: Eliza B.

description:
I had the beef ramen, the beef was grilled and really really good, noodles were nice and al dente, the broth was just ok.  Probably true to form, but just not for me.  I was a skeptic of Japanese curry in general until this trip.  The broth in the ramen epitomized what doesn't move me about it, but their regular curry sauce on the Tonkatsu was phenomenal. 

What blew me away was their Karaage, best I've ever had... so mouth watering.  I'm going back to find out if they'll sell me Karaage with curry on rice... that would be amazing.

What's up with the Italian name though??
author: j s.

description:
I have no frame of reference for this- no visits to Japan, I've only driven past Japantown, and I've never eaten Japanese curry anywhere else. However, if this is what Japanese curry tastes like, thank you! I had the curry beef. To me, it was the perfect meal- meat, rice, spicy curry and no pesky vegetables getting in the way.
I was there at 11:01. When I left five minutes later, the line was already out the door (not that that is hard to do at this tiny little spot).
author: Johanna S.

description: Muracci's is a super awesome cheap and tasty authentic Osakan curry hole in the wall. Curries come with two types of tsukemono! They're friendly, thought not always fast. Then again the speed didn't bother me. The chef was happy to listen to my terrible Osaka-ben, and he's very friendly and cares about his customers. There are NO OUTLETS. It's not a good place for a friend who's afraid of their phone dying.
author: Sterling D.

description:
On this fourth consecutive day of rain, I climbed into my kayak and decided to go down to Muracci's for some Katsu curry. Even though I miss seeing the Sun, I am comforted by the fact that Hetch Hetchy and the Sierra Snowpack have fared well with the recent weather. 

Muracci's is small so don't take 5 office mates and hope to get a seated lunch. 

The Katsu, if not had before, is definitely worth trying. As countless people have already mentioned - its #16 on the The Big Eat SF List. I ordered mine medium spicy with white rice (brown rice is also available). In hindsight, I would order it hot and with extra curry for a $1.75. This was enjoyed with a cup of Green Tea. Total damage $10.35. Great value. 

Also helped that the very competent women behind the counter were both friendly and very easy on the eyes. 

I do have to take 2 stars off. Primarily, this is because of excessive use of plastic and poor recycling. I ordered my Katsu Curry to eat there but was still served it in a box (not sure of material of box - but it could have been Styrofoam) with a plastic bowl for the curry, a plastic fork and spoon. While actual cutlery and plates might be too much to ask for, compostable forks and spoons and actual composting would go a long way. The curry in a plastic bowl is also unnecessary. There was a bin to recycle glass and metal (cans) - but not plastic and the sign on top of it seems mostly ignored by patrons. Disappointing on this front - this is San Franciso after all. Throw a stone and you will hit a resident here who can wax ad nauseum about the benefits of recycling and composting.
author: Abhi S.

description:
Excellent Korokke - better than many I had in Japan! Very good Katsu and rice but the curry was extremely watery - way thinner than I've ever had before. That said, it did have good flavor and Medium spice is enough to make the average person sweat.
Great, friendly service rounds it out to a solid 4 stars!
author: Robert B.

description:
#1 Katsu Curry of my life!  Eating at Muracci's has prompted a year-long search for the ultimate curry recipe because unfortunately I live out of town.  I still haven't found a recipe that stacks up.

I ate at a strange time--3 pm--and there was no wait and plenty of places to sit.
author: emily e.

description: Salmon curry lunch was underwhelming... Salmon was DESTROYED during grilling process. :(
author: John E.

description:
Very delicious and the price is quite reasonable. I got a chicken katsu curry at the medium-spiciness level. I like my food spicy, so I should have gotten the hot. 

The chicken katsu was not dry, and the portion is quite large. This place definitely has a spot in my lunch rotation.
author: Anne M.

description:
Nom nom nom!!!

This place is definitely a "hole in the wall" (since it's a very small resto that can fit 10-15 people?). It's located in the financial district so it's perfect for lunch/dinner to go for all my work friends out there!

I ordered the chicken katzu curry and it was a good portion (had left overs), decently priced, and deeelicious. Plus, they give you the option of doing half brown and half white rice!!
author: Christina C.

description: The food tasted fine but the portions are made for a 90lb man.... for 10.50 I would expect alot more food......
author: Faruk M.

description:
I don't understand the rave about this place... I am a curry lover & have tried many different curry places & I think Muracci's is just ok.  It's not out of this world so  I am really unsure what the rave is all about.

I ordered the Grilled salmon curry ($10.95), added extra curry sauce ($2.25) & added a potato croquette ($2.20), add them all up with taxes and everything came out to be $15.99.  I would say this is a pretty expensive lunch, so I really expect the portion to fill me up and it didn't.

Well, turns out the rice is flatten out, thin layer, not good.  On top of it was a tini-tiny piece of salmon.  I've never had such a small piece of salmon for a lunch that cost almost $11 alone.  The extra curry sauce I paid $2.25 for wasn't much extra, probably gave me 25% more, totally, not worth it.  I expected a lot of extra sauce for that price.  

The croquetter was good so no complaint there.

Overally, the portion is relatively small compared to the price.  They seem to be very cheap with the sauce.  I guess it must be very expensive to make the sauce.  The overall taste of the curry is ok.  For $16, I would rather go spend it at a regular japanese restaurant that comes with soup & salad & california roll & will probably get change back.  Won't be coming back again.
author: Sasa L.

description: i don't know what the fuss is all about! i had such high hopes for this place only to be disappointed. i'm glad they serve brown rice here, but the curry was not the best in the world. i felt that the curry sauce was avg. i tasted better curry even at the places in J-Town. the place is super small, but you can still get a table because most of the customers order their food back to the office.
author: Belinda C.

description: Excellent chicken katsu and brown rice at no extra charge.  Fresh and they don't cook until you order.  I ate the whole thing!!  NOM! Chicken was tender, well breaded and didn't taste oily like other places I've tried.  The curry is SOOOOOO good.  Got the medium curry for a slight (but not too much of a) kick.  The really cool thing about this mom&pop shop is that they have Level Up set up and also take credit cards. Can't wait to go back and try their ramen!
author: Dee H.

description: Since I was down in the fidi wanted to try the katsu curry here. Very quick service, option of white or brown rice. The curry was tasty, got the medium spice. Good dish and nice location. Not many options to eat there one counter and two small tables but easy to take back somewhere.
author: Nicole S.

description:
This place serves halfway decent street food at a price that reflects their target audience's relative affluence. 

Their curries are all pretty good and a definite cut above what you'd get out of those partially hydrogenated roux bricks full of MSG. There's not a whole lot of heat to them, though, and you can do a lot better at home if you just get a Japanese friend to translate the recipe on the back of a can of S&B brand curry powder. 

The meat's pretty sub-par. Greasy, loosely attached breading, tons of connective tissue, and not a lot of flavor. Again, you can do much better at home with a kurobuta loin chop marinated in a little cold sake with some sea salt and fresh pepper thrown on top before breading and frying. 

The roll cakes are chemically enhanced and nowhere near what you'd get at a real bakery like Yasukochi's. 

But still, it's perfectly edible, and if the South Park startup nerds want to line up to pay $10/plate for it, why not take it?
author: Nicholas J.

description:
Muracci's wasn't on my radar until I read about them on 7x7's 100 Things to Eat Before You Die list. Even then I wasn't sure when I'd get to try it since I don't work anywhere near downtown and they aren't open on the weekends. But driving home from the airport yesterday it hit me that I could grab some chicken katsu curry on my way home and knock another item off my list - score.

The chicken was perfectly cooked, nice and crispy on the outside yet still juicy on the inside. The curry sauce was good but really heavy - this $9 plate of lunch kept me full through dinner! I did appreciated the fact that they curry came in a separate container as to not make the chicken soggy during transport.

Part of me is sad that I don't work closer to Muracci's but another big part of me (my muffin top) is actually kinda glad.
author: phil h.

description:
Here's how I eat katsu curry:
1. Sprinkle pickled radish over rice.
2. Dip katsu piece in curry.
3. Eat.
4. Pour a spoon of curry over rice.
5. Eat.
6. Repeat steps 2-5.

Sure my way is OCD but at least it ensures every bite of katsu is crispy!

Muracci's is a tiny hole in the wall but since most people take their order to go, I've never had trouble grabbing a seat.  They've got excellent katsu curry for about $9.  Crispy panko crust and juicy tender meat.  I usually get the pork but chicken is good too.  You can choose your level of heat as well.  I get it extra spicy.  And of course since this is a health conscious city... you may choose between brown rice or white.  Like the pickled radish?  You can get a small side for 75 cents or a container for $2.50.

Oh and they have other cheap Japanese goodies as well like sushi rolls, croquettes and green tea cake rolls.  Try it!
author: Justine L.

description: Chicken Katsu Curry, medium, with white rice is usually my order. Always hits the spot. One of the best chicken katsu I ever had. Love this place!
author: Bron G.

description:
I really like this place.  Everyone raves about the katsu curry but I've never been a fan of curry in general.  Imagine my surprise when I discovered one of the best katsu donburis. I love how the egg is not just a fried egg on top of my dish but is instead a soft scrambled deliciousness! I can honestly have it every day.

The drawbacks are the excessively long wait during lunch hours but that's to be expected considering how good the food is.  The prices are a little high for portion size. I'm still a sucker though and will continue to show up an wait in line.
author: Chanthi L.

description:
I love Japanese Curry, and Muracci's definitely does it the best! 

The pork katsu curry (and heck, everything) is so delicious! The pork katsu itself is breaded perfectly with a great crisp that even survives being drenched in curry, but it still keeps the pork moist and tender. The curry itself is full of flavor and is available in varying levels of spicy. I also like to add extra spinach to my order just to add some green to the plate. 

Of note: they run out of the pork katsu usually before the end of the day, so hurry on down to get a taste of it. They also close early, so go for lunch or make it an early dinner. Trust me - it'll be worth it! It is really delicious.
author: Jessica R.

description:
Holy Batcave! I am stuffffffffffffffffed. 

I just got back from this place and can't imagine eating another morsel until dinner tomorrow night. I met my roomie for lunch (he has to work this week while I get it off.... sucka!) and he suggested this "Japanese Curry place that's on my 7x7 checklist." Strangely enough, I was really craving some Japanese and carbalicious on the way over so it worked out perfectly. 

The place is small. Emphasis on S-M-A-L-L. We were lucky to grab one of the 6 seats available (and the only table). You have two main choices: do you want something gravied in curry, or do you want the lunch special? The curry menu has about 8-10 options and comes with your choice of white or brown rice. The lunch menu is not curry-oriented... but (!!!) the trick is order the lunch menu and then a side of curry. One of the employees explained this after we didn't get the soup we thought we had coming. Duly noted. 

I ordered the beef curry with brown rice and the roomie got chicken katsu with white rice and cheese in his curry sauce. The curry comes in a small container with the beef already mixed inside. I added it all on the rice and twirled it around until the whole container resembled one messy brown color. Although I wish there was more meat (only about 5 smallish pieces), I was fine with the rice and sauce as the majority of the meal. It was so filling and perfect for an overcast afternoon. 

If you're ever grabbing your stomach around 11:30am, aching for an extremely savory and hearty meal, come to Muracci's. And be prepared to be wheeled home.
author: Jared S.

description:
In my opinion, there's nothing better than a spine tinglingly, face meltingly hot curry on a cold day.  Being a fan of all types of curry, I and my coworker decided to go here for lunch. We were lucky to get there when we did, because the tiny 10x10 restaurant got packed right after we got our orders in.  It took about 5 minutes to get our food.

I ordered the Vegetable and Tofu curry and got "very hot" ($8.16), and he ordered a "mild" Beef Curry ($8.71).  The curry tasted really great, and the vegetables were fresh and not over cooked; the spicyness was at a good level too.  My face wasn't in danger of being melted, but it had a nice kick to it.  

The portions are pretty large, and the prices are fair.  I'd definitely recommend trying it, as there aren't really many good curry places in the financial district that i know of.
author: Eric W.

description:
Everyone loves their Katsu Curry, but I opt for the Katsu Donburi. (don't get me wrong, the Curry isn't bad, but the Katsu Don is better!!!) The pork is so tender and juicy, and the sauce is not too salty, the rice is light and fluffy, and the egg on top is cooked perfectly (not too done, but not runny). It is by far the best Katsu don I've ever had. 

This place gets super busy, so ordering ahead of time for pick up is a must! Trying to eat there is slightly impossible for there are only 5-6 stools.
author: jennifer h.

description:
I heard a lot about this place, so being a curry fan I headed over to check it out. I waited until around 3 when the lunch rush was over so I could get in there and check out what they had. Unfortunately for me the lunch rush left they cleaned out of most of their menu, leaving me with slim pickings on what I could order.

I ended up getting the fried salmon with rice and curry. I expected it to be in a bowl for some reason, with the fish on top of the rice and curry. I was kind of surprised to see it come on a plate with the plane white rice on one side, the curry on the other, and the salmon used to keep the two apart. I didn't quite understand what I was supposed to do, so I moved the fish and mixed the curry and rice. 

The fish was so-so, the rice was rice, and the curry was good. I am hoping the other dishes that I couldn't get were the good ones, since I wasn't that impressed with what I had.

The owners there were friendly, but the location is TINY. You'll be taking your order to go.

Maybe I'll go back and try this place again when I get more time, and when they get more food in stock. But for now, 3 stars is what they get.
author: Erik B.

description:
Poor Nobu, the people at Muracci's always give me a plate.

I have the urge to make this a longer, more flamboyant review, but it doesn't really need to be. Presentation is as simple as ever, yet so different. Hot, tender cutlets are used in the Katsu Curry, and the brown rice usually mixes perfectly with the savory curry. Throw in a bottle of Oi Ocha or can of Milk Coffee, and it's pretty hard to beat. Best Katsu Curry I've had in the states, one of the best Tonkatsus I've had overall.
author: Thomas J.

description: Food was good but they wouldn't let me order extra shrimp with ebi fry..... -__- it only comes with 3 pieces.....
author: Richard W.

description:
OMG I'm in love! And I'm sooo happpy that I've finally found a delicious Japanese curry place in the Bay!

Nothing could ever come close to Hurry Curry in LA but Muracci's come close! BOMB chicken katsu and they give you brown rice at no extra charge!!!! Gotta love that!

I would give it 5 stars if they had a little casual restaurant vibe. Wish it was bigger and had AC so I can sit there and enjoy my meal. They should really think about turning this into a little restaurant with dranks, happy hour and everything. I CANNOT WAIT TO GO BACK!!!!
author: Kathleen J.

description:
I have yet to try their katsu curry. The first time I ordered katsu curry but it's sold out so I went with chicken katsu curry. The curry was delish. A kicking spicy flavor would be great. I like my curry: hot... Nom2.... Second time, I didn't know why I ordered katsudon and thought it's the same thing as katsu curry. Only after the dish was almost ready that I realized I ordered the wrong thing. The katsudon was okay but quite salty, especially if you're expecting real Japanese food that's usually not salty.

Stick with their curry dishes and you won't be disappointed
author: Cliff T.

description: Consistently great tonkatsu curry, and even when there's a line it moves quickly.  The only thing I could ask for is more pickled onions.  Oh, and less packaging - what's up with the giant container for less than a cup of sauce?!?
author: M M.

description:
If you're not a fan of Japanese curry, you will be after eating here.

Chicken Katsu Curry at Muracci's can't be beat.  It's made to order, quite large, crispy and tender, and when you get it to go they'll slice it up and pack it with plenty of rice and a small serving of pickled sides in a compostable container.  The curry sauce comes in its own container, steaming hot and ready for you to spoon as little or as much of it over your meal as desired.  There's a wonderful aroma and intense flavor to the curry that stands out from other curry styles.  That's a huge plus.

I like how you can choose between white or brown rice too.  I'm a brown rice eater so that's what I went for.  Wasn't disappointed with the perfectly steamed nicely textured grains.

They give big portions here - another huge plus.  The plastic container for the curry sauce is sturdy and reusable, and I used it to pack my leftovers for later on.

On a previous visit I had the veggie curry with fried tofu.  The tofu was big and chunky and so were the vegetables.

Be prepared for a line and a wait because like I said they make everything to order and serve it up in turn.  It's a bit crowded inside for dining in and there are no outside seats.  Muracci's is more of a take out place than a dine in place.

A four star take out place, imho.
author: Eileen P.

description:
Summary: Muracci's has big portions and you should order ahead because the lunch rush makes the wait very very long. LImited seating and crowded, eat out near the rooftop of the mall nearby.

Muracci has a good selection of food with big big portions. I recommend the Katsu or the Chicken curry if you want some regular staples. They also have a limited weekly special that varies in quality from week to week. 

Drinks wise, don't drink the mango juice. Its 1% juice and terrible tasting.
author: Rohan D.

description:
Went here for lunch during work. Tried the katsu curry medium and the spicy ramen

Pro: the service is very fast, tonkatsu is fresh and crispy, curry has good flavor

Con: portions are a little small for the price, nothing comes on the side, spicy ramen consisted of undercooked ramen ad chili paste wayy toooo hot.

will be back for the katsu!
author: Adrienne C.

description: Small and cramped and crowded due to the long lines, so really only makes sense for takeout. I got the ramen with spicy meat sauce and it sure was spicy and delicious.
author: jeremy l.

description: Best curry in the Downtown area! My buddy from work tried the hot hot curry and within minutes he started sweating and leaking from his nostrils lol I in the other hand went for the medium curry which was perfect for me cause it was spicy enough and not over the top caliente. No bathrooms, No waiting area inside but really who cares call in pick up and go. Shouts out to the cute girl working the register always greeting peps with a nice smile.
author: Angelisimo G.

description:
Meh.  That about sums it up.  Today was my first time here.  I am paranoid of these little hole-in-the walls in the city for cleanliness reasons.  So I rely on Yelpers to clue me in.  I was happy to see the city rating gave them 100 and they had a fairly current posting from March 2012.  Although, like most shops, seemed a bit dirty.  A turnoff no matter what the city score (and it also doesn't instill confidence in the city's ratings.)  I just don't feel like there's anything to rave about.  Certainly not for the price.  I did get the beef curry HOT w/ brown rice $8.45 and added vegetables for $1.00.  I also wanted to try the California roll.  Not a bad price $3.50 for 6 pieces and the edamame $2.50.  Probably the best value was any 6-piece sushi.  But it was a lark and my paranoia probably won't let me order from a shop like this again.  It was fine, but fish is NOTHING to gamble with.  The edamame (I can eat a whole bag of steamed pods from Trader Joe's in one sitting most days) these tasted like they were steamed in what I can only describe as slightly fishy water. 

Service was pleasant enough.  I went at 11:00 a.m., so, no line.  Several people arrived 20 seconds after me though.  All in all, while probably many like their food, 
Sadly, I will not patronize them again.  I need to LOVE your food to shell out a minimum of $8-$10 for lunch.  Tasted like lunch truck food to me.  I actually spent a total of $16.76 to try everything I was curious about.  I'd rather pack my own and ensure I love it.  For that matter, Subway does a healthier, fresher, cleaner environment, for a much better value, $5 6-in turkey sub on herb cheese bread (CUSTOMIZED to your liking even).  Especially with this huge fiscal cliff, obamacare, and rising taxes looming.
author: Kelly T.

description: The service is fast and once you get a hang of ordering, it's a great lunch spot especially for katsu curry. It's not overwhelmingly amazing or anything, but I would come back for a quick lunch
author: Shang S.

description: LEVELUP was down. When I got to work the food was average and the chicken was tough. Come here if you have a curry fix.
author: Daniel K.

description:
Ordered the Katsu (Pork) Curry. It came with some pickled vegetables and rice.

Serving size was OK for a 10 dollar meal. Very unassuming place.

The dish was delicious and I would go back again.
author: John N.

description: the curry flavor is good, but the execution is not.  I asked for vegetables to be added to my curry, so I can get my veggie serving in for the day.  It was broccoli and carrots, the broccoli was cooked ok, but the carrots were almost rock hard, like they hadn't even taken the time to cook it... not even the time to microwave cook it...
author: Paul C.

description: I've never been a fan of any type of curry and in recent years started eating Thai curry. I thought I'd give Japanese Curry and chance since the Japanese do everything well, right? :)  Well, I'm glad that my first go at Japanese curry was at Muracci's.  I met a friend for lunch and we settled on this place. It's tiny and bustling. The lunch hour was busy and the long line didn't prove us wrong.  I tried the Katsu Curry. Although parts of the katsu were a touch fatty, the rest was really good. The curry wasn't too overbearing and tasty.  We also had the Korroke which was pretty flavorful with a light and flaky coating. I'd come back here again.
author: Anna R.

description:
It's 10:54am, 6min until the place opened and there's already 5 people waiting outside the restaurant.  By 11am there were 11 people in line to be exact, and if you looked inside the small restaurant, you could see 7 Take-out orders already done and waiting to be picked up.  Have you ever seen a restaurant with that kind of demand before it even opened for the day??  That's definitely got to say something about this restaurant.  We saw 2 people leave the line after waiting for 5 minutes... C'MAN people... you couldn't have waited another 2 minutes??  Such a shame... because the place is pretty damn good!  

The portions are fairly large at first glance, but once you start eating it, you'd wish you had more!  I got the medium spiced Chicken katsu curry, which was the perfect amount of spice for me.  The curry sauce was sooo delicious and definitely tasted better than the box kind.  Some restaurants' curries taste just like the Golden Curry brand, but this one was so much better! DELISH!!!! Even though we got our order to go, the chicken katsu was 15minutes later was still nice and crunchy, and  not too dry,  The chicken Donburi was also pretty good, but the sauce was a little salty and tasted too much like soy sauce.  I would definitely choose the katsu curry over it any day.  

The restaurant it self has about 3 seats, and seems to be more of a To-Go place.  The next time I come here, I'd definitely call in my order ahead of time and then come pick it up.  There's plenty of metered parking so you can easily come pick it up.  Chicken Donburi and Chicken Katsu curry = $17
author: Diane L.

description: I'm no connoisseur when it comes to authentic Japanese curry but I think I've tried enough places to know what I (personally) like. So far, the JapaCurry truck has taken first place in my book but Muracci's comes in at a close second. I ordered the pork katsu with spicy curry and was surprised that I could actually taste some heat - which I find strange for a Japanese place, but I won't complain. The boy ordered chicken katsu curry and said that he preferred the chicken here over JapaCurry. I wish this place was open over the weekend and outside of normal business hours but at least their hours aren't as limited as JapaCurry.
author: Novi M.

description:
I see why Randal L. gave high marks to this place.  It is indeed a bang for the buck with tons of food for about $10.  

My only nitpicky remark is about the curry and the flavors it needs.  Sure it tastes like curry, but it doesn't give that mMPH that I'm looking for in a specialized curry spot.  

But anyways, the place is great and the food is a nice hearty meal with plenty of rice, curry, and servings of TonKatsu (Pork).  My friend Terence S. got the salmon, and although it was nice of him to share it, I knew that when he saw his four little pieces, he'd be smart to share that and get some Ton Katsu from me.  All good.  But of course, even if the salmon wasn't dry and nicely breaded, the quantity cannot dare compare with that of the pork.  Once again, the pig wins.
author: Vincent K.

description:
Tasty! 

Although small and cramped, it was perfect for a summer or spring day.  You sit at a counter bar stool and slurp down the noodles before heading back to work.  It gets crowded but the lines do move pretty fast.  The kitchen is compact but there are at least 4 people taking orders and prepping the food for you.

I got the beef udon curry and the avocado sushi roll. It was $13.00.

Nice place to revisit if you are just in a mood for curry. You can choose Mild, Medium or Spicy!
author: Jboogie L.

description:
Came for: Mom-and-Pop (i think?) home-made japanese dishes
Will come back for: Oyako or Katsu Donburi over brown rice (brown rice!!)

What more can I say about this place that haven't been already noted and emphasized a few times over?
One reviewer already said it well, but I am a fan of their donburi (and mega bonus points for the brown rice option).  Personally, I have never ordered any other dish, but have stolen bites of their curry from friends and those seem pretty good too.  
But as for the donburi -- never have I tasted such moist and warm goodness over rice.  Yummmm!
It's perfect on those days when I need a more hearty and filling lunch.  The small space gets extremely crowded, so especially for those of you in need to grab a bite between conference calls/meetings, I suggest calling ahead to place an order and then go pick up.  Wait, did I just create extra line in front of my order??  Oh well...

Brownie points for efforts to expand dish offerings (croquet snacks, noodle dishes) and decent price points.
author: Carol K.

description:
Holy hole-in-the-wall Japanese curry joint! As spot on as any Tokyo back ally karei-ya. The owner clearly prides himself in j-curry perfection. If they gave out honors, he would be a karei-do black belt. 

Yes its cramped with maybe a total of 10-12 seats, a line out the door and service a bit slow but everything is freshly made as orders come in. Breaded pork, chicken or shrimp all cooked to order. Vegitables and tofu in the vegitarian curry are cooked together as ordered too.

Equally impressive is that their curry sauce is complex and distinctive as a variation on a theme without stuping to the grocery store, House Za Karei thick brown gupy standard.
author: David P.

description:
Went here with a friend during the lunch rush and we were really excited to go to this place since it was so highly reviewed. To be honest, nothing happened that was wrong, but nothing really stood out either about the food. My friend had the curry katsu and I had the regular curry. The chicken was soft and tender and the sauce flavor was also very tasty.

I still think that this dish could be duplicated elsewhere for less then $9 with more chicken with similar flavoring. The restaurant is small with minimal seating and during lunch time it is quite packed since there's nothing else like it nearby. 

All in all, I would go back there again, but not out of my way. As long as you go just expecting a good meal, not FANTASTIC or really something really really unique, then you'll come out satisfied. If I worked in this area, I would probably frequent it regularly. 

It was A-OK.
author: Katherine F.

description:
I've had Muracci's a few times, but I've never been into the restaurant until recently.  It's quite a trek from my office, so I usually had a friend pick it up for me.  Muracci's is famous for its curry dishes, specifically the katsu curry that was on the 77 list 2 years in a row.

The scene:

There's really only room for 4 people to sit in this restaurant. It's more of a order-to-go type of place.  I usually order the food and take it over to Crocker Galleria to eat.  Get here early because there can be a long wait during peak lunch time.

The food:

I've tried the salmon curry over rice and the curry ramen. Both are filling and rich, so pace yourself!

Grilled Salmon Curry w/brown rice - My gut would've ordered the katsu curry, but I had to watch out for my poor body that's been taking a toll on this food blog. So, I contently purchased the salmon curry for $9.25. Crazy expensive for Japanese curry. I have to admit the size of the fish looked pretty pathetic sitting on top of the rice. It was so small! I poured the container of curry over my meal and dug in. The curry was spicy, velvety and rich. I don't believe I had any chunks of carrots or beef in my curry, which is usually added at other Japanese curry spots. The curry was definitely delicious, but I think the curry at Hotei on Irving is very much comparable at a total cost of only $6.95.

Overall, I think Muracci's serves up great curry. I just don't think it's worth the price for what you get.
author: Sam L.

description: A longstanding favorite of mine. Simple, yet oh so delicious, and the chicken curry never fails to satisfy my need for curry.
author: Sandy Y.

description: Good Japanese curry. This place has a few seats for eating, but is mostly for take out. Muracci's 2 in Los Altos is where to go if you want to sit down and dine.
author: Thomas C.

description:
After reading all the review on Yelp, I decided to try out Muracci's for lunch. Before I went, I browsed the menu and decided on a Katsu Don.

I came at 1:00pm so the wait was not bad. My impressions of the place are it was very small, there's some seating against the windows and wall. While ordering, I spotted the potato croquettes with curry flavor on the counter. Since this placed is famed for their curry, I added it in and ate it while I was waiting for my order. And it was sooo good, still fresh and warm! The outside is light and crispy. Even though its fried, it doesn't have that greasy, heavy feeling. Inside is sorta like mashed potatoes in curry sauce with I think some peas and carrots. The curry was delicious, I'll definitely have to come back for that.

I sat and waited for about five minutes. I looked at other people eating and almost everyone is eating the curry dishes. My order came up and I took it to go and had it at the roof garden at Crocker Galleria which is very relaxing. (Sidenote - There's a farmer's market there with lots of goodies).

You would think a donburi, just pork katsu and egg over white rice, would be really boring but it was anything but. The egg was cooked all soft with green onion over the pork cutlet and the rice was all sweet and yummy. Very good, I could only finish half...will def. be back for the curry.
author: Joanna L.

description: Very small inside and its warm too. More of a takeout place altho you can eat inside. Medium spicy is pretty spicy!! Beef is tender.  When the order came out, the amount seemed small but it filled me up ok.
author: Sandy G.

description:
muracci's is the place to get japanese comfort food!  

they have a simple menu which includes curry rice, curry noodles, grilled items, an a few apps.  my standard order is katsu curry, medium spicy, with brown rice.  it comes with fukujinzuke (japanese pickles) and picked cabbage also.  the hot curry is a lil too spicy and overpowers the rest of the food, but if you can handle spicy def give it a try.  i used to get the hot, but switched over to the medium recently.  

make sure you call and order ahead, it turns into a madhouse during lunch time on any given week day.
author: Wendy S.

description: I started a lunch group w.in my office and we come here probably once a week.  Since day one I always got the same thing.  The Chicken Katsu w. Spicy Curry. and it never fails.  Ive gotten the cold noodles once and it was also very good.  But I always stick to my go to.  I figured that Katsu and curry would taste the same anywhere you went.. Boy was I wrong.  I tried to switch it up recently and there was a stark difference.. The chicken at Muracci's is solid chicken breast, where as the other place used more of the fatty thigh piece., not too bad but for katsu, breast is better.  Muracci's also wasn't as oily and the batter they used wasn't as thick.  The spicy which I always get was the perfect amt of spice.  Would definitely recommend this place, solid lunch spot.
author: Jason Y.

description:
Very disappointing. I was finally able to get here early enough to try the vegetable and tofu curry over (white) rice. The meal was interesting, spicy and pretty authentic as far as Japanese curry goes. The curry was not even close to what was advertised on the picture in the restaurant, however. I found nothing more than peppers, 2 pieces of broccoli and a few carrots thrown in with the tofu. I was expecting a few inoki mushrooms (as pictured), but no dice.

The service is slow, so lines are really long if you get here after 12:00. Plan accordingly. Do me a favor and try the tofu curry with udon bowl and let me know if it better meets expectations.
author: Milk and Cheese ..

description:
There's a reason this place always has a line out the door...it's damn good!

I've had a variety of their curry dishes (pork katsu, chicken, etc.) and have enjoyed all of them tremendously.

Just make sure you get the meal to go....the space is very limited inside.
author: Aalok P.

description: I would be impressed if I got this quality curry at a sit down dining establishment for dinner. Rather, after starting at the back of a somewhat ominous line, I had my order taken immediately after walking through the door, paid, and was leaving with my food in hand in literally 5 minutes. I got pork katsu with spicy curry, the pork came out perfectly breaded and crisp and the sauce despite the spice I found myself spooning it like a soup by the end. Will be back soon.
author: John K.

description:
If there's one savory food I could eat every day and not gain weight or get sick of, it's Japanese chicken curry. There's something about the simplicity of the presentation yet complexity of the flavors that make my tastebuds happy. I love having a bowl of spicy chicken curry to drench a large plate of rice. Oh, and let's not forget those pickled radishes that I have to include in every bite.

Muracci's does curry, and they do it well. The portions are perfect; not so big that I feel like I have a nine month food baby in my belly afterward. While I love Curry House in Cupertino, it often leaves me feeling uncomfortably bloated. 

They also have bento boxes, donburi, curry noodles and various appetizers and desserts, but I come here solely for the curry. Call in your order to save time -- the place is tiny so it gets crowded fast, and there's not much room, so it's definitely an eat and run type of place.

And if you're wondering what sweet food I'd eat every day if I could, it would be a red velvet cupcake, of course!
author: Connie C.

description:
So, I came in two days before Xmas, and it was their last day before the holidays. 

Tip. They normally prepare much less things before long holidays. 

They ran out of katsu, and white rice. Which was a big bummer for me. I ended up getting the Beef curry. But, of course, since they ran out of white rice, I had to get brown rice instead. The curry itself was really good. Beef was OK, but very tender. Which is good. The brown rice made it not as good though. It didn't soak the curry. I am giving it 3 stars right now, because i wasn't too impressed. But, I am pretty sure if I got the katsu curry with white rice, it will be a four or even (dare I say) a five star.
author: Jimmy H.

description:
This was my first time having Japanese Curry here in San Francisco and I was not disappointed.  Muracci's is a no-frills lunch spot in the Financial District.  I ordered the Vegatable and Tofu Curry Rice plate which was very tasty.  Ask for hot, it is properly spiced.  I even added more hot sauce to spice it up a bit more.  

This place is authentic.  The entire staff is Japanese.  Great place for a solid under-10-dollar lunch.
author: Moe J.

description:
I mad-dashed to this hole-in-the-wall (in heels) since they close at 6 and had super high Yelp ratings...

I got the chicken ramen curry (mild)...and it tasted like...regular ramen soaked in curry with pieces of chicken. Err, did I miss something? Should I have gotten chicken or pork katsu curry over rice instead?!

I went at 5:30pm and there was no line at all, but a crowd came in just as we were about to leave. (There were probably only 7 stools total...most people probably order to-go for lunch.)
author: Serena W.

description: Had the beef medium curry over brown rice. I thought it was good nothing spectacular. I'll have to try the chicken katsu next time and maybe extra spicy.
author: Larry L.

description:
Rice and Meat 10$ 1 scoop of Brown rice $2.75

Happy? Not quite. The wait is horrid specially around lunch time.

It's a tiny cramped little stall that's terrible to eat in. Always order to go.

They have this weird scam about having 15 specials per day. Most of the time you can get it. My hypothesis is that they are trying to get rid of old ingredients, but there's no price break.

They do have a nice tupperware ^^
author: Alistair W.

description: LevelUp paid for my lunch...I ordered the curry pan(it was gooood). Had the chicken katsu curry. It was good.
author: Shashidhar D.

description: The best Japanese curry I've ever had by far. They have the perfect amount of spice in it. This is a little hole in the wall kind of place. It's going towards the financial district in San francisco. A really really small place although it doesn't seem to be crowded whatsoever. I would recommend this place if you love Japanese curry or want to try it.
author: Irene O.

description:
This is a very small place, take out is awesome because they separate the curry sauce and the rice/meats to 2 separate containers. Their Katsu's are fried to perfection with a crunchy outside and tender inside. The meal is pretty heavy because they give you a lot of sauce and rice. 

My favorite thing to get is a pork or chicken katsu, spicy curry, and i even add cheese (yes it sounds weird but it compliments the curry sooooo well), oh and don't forget to try a kroket if they have it!
author: Chris C.

description:
This place is tiny, tiny, TINY and when packed, its like trying to push your way through a crowded hallway (apparently 2pm is when all the FiDi people take their lunch breaks). I have been dying to try this place for months though, so I stood my ground in their slow-ass line just so I could have a taste of their katsu curry.  

It took about 10 minutes to actually get to the front of the line to order and then another 15 or so to get our food, but we weren't in any hurry, and even nabbed two stools. Probably a bad spot to come to if you're on your lunch break and need something fast, but obviously everyone goes anyway because the food here is just that damn good.

My mild katsu curry was awesome. The fried pork cutlet was delicious, though a few cuts in the middle had some fat; I simply passed those pieces onto my boyfriend. ;) The curry sauce was flavourful, but I think I should have gotten it medium instead of mild, since I would have preferred a little kick. I tried my boyfriend's hot beef curry and though it made my mouth burn a bit, I think if you're a fan of spicy things, Muracci's is pretty light-weight in that department. 

I also got a tora cake roll for dessert. It was moist and sweet, but not too sweet. Priced decently at $1.75.

I would say the only drawbacks with the place are they skimp on the curry a little bit, and having to pay $1.50 for extra sauce is a little ridiculous. Also the beef curry doesn't have many hunks of beef, plus there are no potatoes or carrots either, which I find instantly annoying in any beef curry. My boyfriend was actually regretting not getting the katsu curry once he saw mine compared to his, haha.

If I ever want some Japanese curry, Murracci's is one of the best in SF (my other fav places are Tanpopo in Japan Town and Delica rf-1 in the Ferry Building). Mmm...
author: M S.

description:
The Japanese have this knack for taking things and improving on them exponentially, usually by streamlining design and function (e.g. cars, electronics*). When this principle is applied to curry, it's transformed from the spice-laden Indian version to a sweeter, smoother more homogeneous incarnation. In line with their track record, the stuff is damn good. 

I have cravings on the regular, and when I'm too lazy to dash over to Delica at the Ferry Building for the city's finest, it's Muracci's that fills my belly. Their spot is the size it would be in Tokyo, two narrow bars with seating, and a double wide aisle. You'd best be out with your box. 

If the line out the door deters, then call in with your order. From the curry, I've never strayed: medium spicy with flecks of lovely chili, chicken or veggie and tofu (fried), served up with the red radishes, pickled cabbage and your choice of white or brown rice for $8.72. Purists should won't have it any other way than with the donkatsu (fried pork cutlet). If you're all about the come and go, holler for a mild chicken or beef and you'll be on your merry way in a snap.

And if you don't know, now you know...

* = With the exception of language; Japanese is far more complex than Chinese, though perhaps not as poetic.
author: Ligaya T.

description: Good curry and ramen, but at least to me, not worth the extensive lunchtime wait. Whenever I come here I wait until 2-3 pm when the line isn't out the door.
author: Charlie F.

description:
I went here for lunch today and it was delicious - as usual, the Yelp reviews don't lie.  I had chicken curry (mild) with white rice and was stuffed after the meal.

If you're in the area it should definitely be in your regular lunch spot rotation.

I did remove one star for being slow, but that is a side effect of having great food and being crowded.

According to co-workers the spicy was apparently very spicy, consider yourself warned.
author: Ben B.

description:
I did not notice everyone talks about Curry.
so I ordered a Tonkatsu.
er.....the meat was dry.
next time, I will go again and order curry.
author: Clarya C.

description:
I had the beef curry. The curry was amazing in flavor and consistency. The beef was very good (tender but not very tender!). 

I also tried the Chicken and Vegetable Ramen. This was interesting. The flavor seems to be inspired a bit by their curry. Very tasty, but not very authentic. Also, The soup seemed to be thicker than normal Ramen soup should be. The chicken pieces were scrumptious though!

Finally, The Chocolate roll cake was an amazing end to an amazing meal
author: Sahir S.

description:
Got to be one of the best places to get Japanese style curry.

I went here with a friend on lunch break and got the Vegetable and Tofu Curry Ramen.

Sooo good.  Although what bothered me was they asked if it was for here or to go, and we both said for here, yet they still put it in a togo container for us.

My friend at the curry katsu which he said was also really good.  Only problem is the place is TINY!  You can only fit a max of about 10 people to sit down and eat.  Also, I suggest you come in before 12PM during the lunch hour rush, we came in around 11:30 and just beat the crowd and it got a bit cramped while we were trying to eat and all the people in line kept hitting us, as the line went out the door.  I saw a handful of veggie options as well.  I'd definately come back here again sometime.
author: Kameron K.

description:
The key is to get here early. I've walked in at 12:30 and waited half an hour, I've gone in at 11:30 and was in and out in 5 minutes!

I've had the Tonkatsu lunch special, but realized i wasn't a big katsu sauce fan. The meal itself is a good deal though, brown rice, katsu, a salad, miso with huge chunks of tofu--so good.

Today I opted for the medium curry with vegetables and tofu--just the right amount of food and spice. 

The space is tight, but they are always super friendly and seem to have a good system in the kitchen. I notice if you order to go ahead of time, they rarely make you wait. 

It's great belly warming food on cold summer days in SF.
author: Jessica P.

description:
The first time I had Japanese curry as a little girl, I was blown away--what was this magical brown spicy savory sauce that tasted so good with white rice? Since then I never had a mind-blowing experience when I ate curry. 

Until I found this place. 

It was like eating curry again for the first time again.

This place is PACKED during lunch hour--avoid at all costs! But it's definitely a good sign how packed it is!

I usually get their veggie and tofu curry with cheese. (Don't knock it till you've tried it.) I like to eat it the way the ~Japanese~ do. 

Muracci's curry is different from other curries because there's a certain richness and spiciness to it. I'm not a curry connoisseur in any way, but Muracci's curry is not like other Japanese curries.
author: K. E.

description:
Oh, my! I need a NAP! And there's only 1 reason why: Muracci's chicken curry lunch special. Absolutely delicious for under $8. 

3-stars instead of more, because my rice was a little off (is brown rice sometimes denser than white rice?), and there were no vegetables, which I was kind-of hoping for. But still a great meal!.. just could use some additions.

I'm excited to come back and try other items, especially the chicken katsu.
author: Andrew C.

description: it cost $8 for curry katsu and brown rice. So I was like uh ok.  Then i put it in my face. I can happily say this is the best katsu I've had in San Fran.. for 8 bucks WOW what a great deal. The curry was traditional, very good flavor, med is just enough spice for anyone to enjoy, i'm going hot next time. Though I with there was an option to get less rice and get veggies and junk with the curry, like how my aunt (1st gen from japan) made it... I will be back for more! :)
author: Sean MC E.

description: I really like their curry. I ordered the Katsu curry dish.  The Katsu was warm and moist on the inside.  It had the right amount of breading,  right amount of texture, and it was golden brown.  I received a large serving of rice. It was well made.  Not over cooked or undercooked.  It was delicious.  The curry sauce was fabulous. I ordered the extra spicy option.  It was sweeter than most curry sauces I tasted.  Moreover, it was very flavorful.  I think the curry here is better than Delica. At this place, you can customize the spiciness of your curry.  I am looking forward to trying out the other curry dishes.
author: Hiroshi K.

description:
I made a special day time trip here months ago even tho I don't work in FiDi. While the food satisfied and it was worth a trip, I just couldn't wrap my head around one thing:

I asked for my order "for here" and it still came out in a plastic box with curry ON THE SIDE in a separate disposable container. WTF? Does a little convenience really justify being wasteful? I came here with my friend and by the time we were done, we created this much trash:

2 boxes
2 lids
2 small canisters
2 forks
2 unused knives

The only thing we saved by not getting to-go was a measly plastic bag. Shame. shame. shame.
If businesses can wash trays, I think they can wash an extra dish.
author: Faffy L.

description:
The last time I had Japanese cheese curry was in Sydney, Australia and had been craving it ever since.

Thanks to yelp, I found my Holy Grail.

The Katsu was perfectly breaded and the cheese - perfectly stringy when mixed with the hot curry.

Guys - if you haven't had cheese curry - I suggest its time to switch over - a curry rice doesn't taste the same anymore without the cheese!

Now if only they had a Karaage cheese curry......
author: CK Y.

description:
Pitch-perfect Japanese curry.  In the old country, curry is right up there with ramen as a classic salaryman's dinner, coming home late from work or after-hours karaoke with the boss.  

Muracci's curry is as good as anything you'll have in Japan.  You won't do better in SF - or even NYC, for that matter.  Come for the curry (I like the chicken katsu), come back for more curry about a week later when you're hungry again.
author: Dan S.

description:
The good:
  * I had no idea what a Japanese curry was, but now I must have it all the time.
  * Veggie options that are delicious!  Brown rice available!
  * You can pick how spicy you like it.
  * Right by my work.

The not-so-good:
  * Wait times are long.  Really, really long.  I understand why, but it takes a certain commitment to eat here.
  * Lots of non-compostable extra packaging comes with your meal.  

Mmmmm...  curry.....
author: Andi T.

description: This is tiny hole in the wall, literally. There's barely any standing room to order, but there's just nothing like the curry here! Any of the curries is good, and so is the katsu...but the one thing you must try here is the spicy noodles. SO BOMB. They don't joke around with the spiciness levels here, so be careful ordering (I learned that the hard way). Def one of the best curry places I've had in SF!
author: Meesh N.

description:
I've been looking for Japanese comfort food ever since I left Osaka in 07. The times when I could roll up to a Yoshinoya at like 3am after the bar and get some curry rice or hit up the Royal Host famiresu and get the ebi fry curry plate has left a part of my stomach empty...UNTIL I WALKED INTO Muraccis!!! This place is small, so be forewarned but other than that, wake up and smell the curry. It tastes just like i remember, it smells just like i remember and they take orders in Japanese and yell it to the kitchen staff just like how i remember. 

I ordered the Chicken Katsu Curry WITH a side of karaage! pretty expensive (16.43) but I just had to get it my way. I got the curry hot and it was perfectly spicy with that tint of sweetness that i could remember. This combination was on hit with the brown rice and potato salad that came with the karaage. the Katsu was cooked to a perfect crunchy perfection and the karaage was the same as well.

I will try the other curry combos but for now, i got my J-Curry fix aka i found my crackstop.
author: Nick V.

description: Good - I enjoyed the curry chicken Katsu - per the other reviews it WAS cooked perfectly however the line was pretty long for lunch.  Oh well - worth it for good food right? Definitely will go again
author: Jennifer C.

description:
This is the real deal in Japanese curry...absolutely LOOOOVE it and thanks Jessica S. for bringing me here for the first time! It's a mom and pop establishment and is easy to get to from the FiDi or Chinatown. According to their website, they simmer the curry for over 20 hours to give it the amazing spice and flavor I enjoy so much. 

I haven't tried a lot of their items (ranges from katsu to salmon curry and sushi to teriyaki dishes) but I always get their chicken with veggies mild curry udon for $7.50. It's a perfect amount of food for lunch and is just spicy enough since I thought their medium was a bit too spicy for me. 
The curry soup isn't super thick but contains carrots, broccoli, and green onions...it tastes like heaven and is wonderful for cold or rainy days since it's steaming hot. The chicken is sooo tender and bursts with flavor in each bite too! Gosh, I'm craving it again just writing this review. =P

If you can handle spicy foods, be brave and try the ones with more kick but mild is good enough too! I have sampled the mild katsu curry...it wasn't as spicy as the noodle soup but still very tasty. I like how they have the option of ordering white or brown rice as well. I need to venture out and try some of their other dishes. 

Remember to call or fax in your order maybe 30 or 45 min before you want to pick it up especially during lunch rush hour so you don't have to stand in line. They make the orders as they come in so it takes a bit longer. Usually if you do that, you can just cut the line, pay for your food, and bounce.
author: Karen Y.

description:
I can't say enough how much I love this place. Their pork tonkatsu curry rice is the most delicious japanese curry I've had.

They have an option of adding cheese and it works surprisingly well.

Good for takeout, not so much for eating in. I wish they had a location that was open for dinner.
author: Franklin H.

description: I think one of the coolest things about a city is that you can find some of the tastiest food in nondescript storefronts that are squeezed into alleyways. Muracci's is one of those. I made my way there for lunch with some colleagues, and opted for the chicken curry done spicy. The portion would probably equate to two meals for most (not me) and was full of tender chicken, hearty hot curry. The side of pickled radishes offsets the spice nicely. The place was packed, but they'd set up a pretty efficient method for handling the crowd. One person jots your order on a ticket and submits it to the chefs, who whip up the dishes in order and then call out your number (just make sure you listen closely!). There's minimal seating indoors; but popping our cartons open while lounging on Yerba Buena gardens was one of the best moments I had while in SF last week.
author: Christina G.

description: Chicken Katsu curry here is authentic. Quick and delicious for a lunch in the city.
author: Hiroshi U.

description:
I heard about this place and have wanted to go for ages. Yummie Japanese curry. It is relatively inexpensive. I had the brown rice chicken curry for $6.95. The wait was long due to those sneaky phone orders, but well worth the wait. The interior is small and it is no frills. There are tons of people dutifully waiting, out the door in fact, for their curries.  I also sampled the vegetarian tofu curry and it was also delicious. 

(~) the medium isn't too spicy compared to other Asian food.
author: Natalie S.

description:
a solid 4.5 star!
The best Japanese Curry i had was in Japan, but Muracci is the best i can find at home.  i always order chicken or pork katsu curry over brown rice, and make it spciy for me!  the meat is always perfectly battered and fried; while white rice or brown rice is always cooked to perfection!
author: Sophia L.

description:
My friend been wanting to come here for the longest time, but we were never free on weekdays. Finally, we planned a day and head over here. We got there around 12:30 pm (lunch time), so the line was out the door.  The line went pretty quick and the food didn't take that long either.

I ordered Korokke and chicken katsu curry. I have to say I love the Croquette!! It was extremely delicious, really crispy and flaky.

Chicken Katsu Curry (Med) with White Rice was just okay for me. I thought there a bit of heat, but not enough for me. The chicken katsu was oh so satisfying. It was crispy, flaky, and unlike most places that use more breading than chicken; the chicken breast here was thick and juicy. 

I also love that the curry is a in a different container! :)

Overall I give this place a four because I never bought Japanese curry before. My friends would always make it, and I have to say its just slightly better than my friends. So I wasn't blown away with the deliciousness of the meal.
author: Tina T.
