description: Got the katsu curry. The pork is tender and juicy, and the skin is crispy. The only downside is that there isn't the pickled veggies on the side you can add on to your curry. I do like that they separate your curry and rest if your food, for those that might accidentally order too spicey. The hot isn't super spicey, so go for it if you want. Their curry pan isn't very good. I wouldn't recommend it.
author: Edison T.

description: Great curry this place is great for lunch, though it's really small I would recommend take out. And everything is priced reasonably with good portions.
author: Timothy K.

description:
dilemma faced for visit...open for lunch only on weekdays...no dinner...no weekend....quite the problem for non-fidi workers...monday morning office problems and free no-work pass for day....caltrain back to city...muni n-line to montgomery station...walk up, up and side few blocks...muracci's curry!...yosh!...

small curry joint...line to door...cramp wall barstool seating dining...patrons seated rubbing with patrons standing...take-out bagging popular...self order and wait...scoping out barstool to dine in...waiting for number nine calling...katsu curry taking longer than beef or chicken ready-made....roughly ten or fifteen wait...number nine calling....curry container seperate...brown rice choice with katsu on bow boxing....notice brown rice cooked bad for the day....dry, brittle and under-cooked rice....katsu cooked to fat juicy crispy golden brown perfection...dip to curry first...tasting buttery light curry saucing great....pour and drown of katsu and poor brown rice....a scoop and shovel into mouth....forking of pickled vegetables a good contrast to taste....roughly $ten weekday lunch meal satisfying....just small gripe over poor brown rice for the day....
author: Hen A.

description:
very creamy curry sauce. just a little too much MSG? need water the whole night. 
bargain bite.

chicken curry noodle

need to try pork curry rice next time.
author: Yelp Z.

description:
Certainly good, but the yelp rating is way out of whack. The tofu & veggies curry tasted fairly generic to me. The best thing about the meal was the pickles, which were phenomenal. I also think that their spiciness levels are calibrated a little high, my "medium" curry was pretty mild.

I'd come back, but I'd need to try something else on the menu.
author: Eric C.

description:
I've been trying to avoid katsu curry for the past year or so.  It's not that I don't like it.  I love it, in fact.  It's just that it is a part of my fruitless attempts to try to remain somewhat healthy (Emphasis on the word fruitless).  But alas, there are some times where katsu curry is exactly what you need to brighten your mood.   Why not enjoy it at a place that is known for the dish?  

The restaurant is tiny and, therefore, can get very crowded.  It's also extraordinarily difficult to find a spot to eat.  Somehow we did, but it was only because we were creepily stalking people and watching them eat while we waited for our food. 
 
 Anyway the katsu was perfectly fried.  Just the right amount of crispiness and none of that gross greasiness that generally comes with fried foods.  The curry was delicious.  I do feel like they skimped on the curry a little.  I got the spiciest curry.  It wasn't too spicy, but it was still great.  Loved the pickled cabbage too.  Also, the portions are HUGE.  Friend and I probably should have split, but I guess I have food for later.  

Also grabbed a croquette on the way out.  Delish.  

The food was great and the katsu curry was perfect.  Definitely worthy of the spot on the 7x7 list.  Wish the restaurant was more dine-in friendly.
author: Alea G.

description: Tiny Japanese curry restaurant slightly nicer than a hole in the wall with lines far out the door during lunch. Chicken curry tastes homemade which maybe is a good thing, only thing I've tried next to the vegetable curry. People also seem to like the chicken katsu which is fried chicken with rice. I wouldn't call it cheap but it also isn't expensive. I'm not too familiar with Japanese curry restaurants in the city but I imagine there is definitely better than this given this place isn't that great. In the financial district though, think this might be the only option and sometimes i'll just have a craving for this, not sure why. Feel like after the first time you go you randomly want it again
author: sasha h.

description:
Awesome Chicken Katsu curry! 

Seating is very limited though.
author: Priyanka G.

description: Decent Japanese food . Had better had worse so most people give them 4 stars and I would have to go with same mark. They are nice and quick, food is good, especially for fidi. I will order something more spicy next cause my teriyaki chicken was rather bland. Potato salad was really good so they deserve 4 stars for sure. Try it
author: Try E.

description:
I found my new 'healthy' favorite Japanese curry spot.  They offer brown (or white) rice, so I feel good eating it too.

An abundant variety of curries, traditional Japanese lunch sets (i.e. donburi, teriyaki, katsu...served with rice, miso soup, salad, and mini-appetizers), hot noodle soups, and delicate rolled cakes.

According to their website, their curry takes a couple days, so it's chock full of delicious flavors.

I miss my mom's curry, so it's a bit of a home away from home for me.
author: Cathy K.

description:
Totally yummos curry dishes here.  My favorite is the katsu curry.  Love the fact that there is a choice between brown rice and white rice and three heat levels for the curry.

Sometimes I wish the curry sauce was a tad bit thicker, but it's still great.  If you want to pick up for lunch, try to phone in your order or get here between 11-11:30 am to avoid the line.
author: T Y.

description: I went here for lunch, a bit later in the afternoon to avoid the crazy line that forms outside it. I got the vegetable and tofu curry. The curry sauce itself was alright, but nothing really jumped out at me. The whole dish seemed to be lacking. However, I've never really eaten a Japanese curry that I liked, so perhaps it's not Muracci's fault. In any case, I won't be going back.
author: Gary M.

description:
I walked by this place the other and said "yes! a Japanese curry house, finally!".  Let's get something straight though, Japanese people are not Korean or Thai or Mexican, so the choice of "hot" is not going to melt your face off.

All and all this is a very solid Japanese curry shop.  I got the chicken katsu curry and the fried chicken cutlet was expertly cooked.  I'm from the south and I am VERY picky about my fried chicken.

My only wish was that they have a little more variety in their pickles and that they had some veggies in their curry (instead of a just a sauce).
author: Chendo O.

description:
Yum, I have to point you all to Ed U and Nobu K's reviews for more detail as I agree with them both.  I'm half-Japanese, with my mom being the Japanese half and this place reminded me of her Japanese curry so man that's an impressive feat.  I never knew how good a cook my mom was until I ate other Japanese food elsewhere and found out what a great cook she was.  Of course my palate has been cultivated by her cooking and one of the things she wasn't able to leverage was the tasty, fresh ingredients we have out here so the restaurants get a leg up on her with that.

I love the all-Japanese staff and vibe even though it's super tiny to eat inside but the currys are super tasty and I loved it HOT and spicy!  Will need to try out more options but this place rocks.
author: Gene X.

description:
If you eat the curry here, you'll select 3 things:
--brown or white rice (plus a meager supplement of veggies to add color)
--a slab of meat: chicken, pork, beef, salmon (or veggies + tofu)
--mild, medium or hot curry

The rice was fine of course but the 4-5 bell pepper pieces sprinkled atop for appearances only taunts those craving actual vegetables.

A naked, withered cut of salmon fillet was lying exposed on the bed of rice, so I did my best to cover it up with the separate tub of spicy red hot curry, which was not spicy or hot but did have a reddish tint.

It helped but it wasn't enough to hide the salmon's shame. Maybe the other dishes are alright but this one was a lemon
author: Alan F.

description: Since moving away from Hawaii, I miss 3 things.  My family, my friends, and of course Curry House.  Thank you Muracci's for calming my cravings while away from Hawaii.  Anyone who loves Curry House but lives in the bay area should give this place a try.  Definately the best curry I've had in SF.
author: Michael K.

description:
Why should I put up with possibly waiting half an hour for my food after ordering!????

I had the chance to stop by for a late lunch after finishing up some stuff at work and had a conflictingly enjoyable meal here.  

It took well over 25 minutes for me to get my food.  Also, finding a place to eat is like finding parking at Costco on a Sunday.  You've got to kreep over people, looking out for the next empty seat!  Unless you've got a spot picked out for yourself to eat,  your order might as well be trapped in a time capsule! 

Waiting for food aside, the service is friendly and the katsu curry is pretty good.  I enjoyed the crispy layering of the moist, tender chicken katsu. The curry source was strong and flavorful.  It complimented the katsu very well--spicey and bold.

The battle to eat in seems justified.  The food is good, pricing is reasonable, and the service is personable.  If I'm ever in the mood for a "I've earned this tasty meal" feeling, Muracci's may be where I go.
author: Julian A.

description:
True to form, Alea G. and I, during our finals period, decided to scope out yet ANOTHER item off The List.  The 7x7 List, that is.  Muracci's is a little out of the way for us, since we live and play in the TL (or, at least, I live there-- Alea G. just comes by to play and study and keep me company :D) and Muracci's is in FiDi.  

But when finals roll around, of course we must find the best ways to procrastinate, no?  So after spending a few hours cramming in Union Square's Borders, Alea G. and I headed over.

Muracci's is awesome, authentic, and absolutely delicious.  The portions are huge, but it was hard not to keep greedily stuffing pieces of fried katsu in my mouth.  We ordered our food to-go, but seats opened up, so we grabbed them and sat down to enjoy our food.  I think there is a total of 6-7 seats at Muracci's-- they have definitely captured the squished-in feel of Japan within their ten square feet of space.  

Thankfully I ate at Muracci's before I started my current diet, because katsu curry is definitely NOT a health food.  Watching them drop HUGE slabs of nicely breaded katsu into large vats of hot oil isn't a recipe for healthiness.  But sometimes you just gotta let go and say SCREW IT, I WANT MY KATSU CURRY!  

And then you go to Muracci's, because there is nowhere else better in the city to go.
author: Jeanne Y.

description:
Had the chick katsu curry with rice.  Very tasty and would def go back again.
I would give it 5 stars if it came with veggies by default.  It is however easy and cheap to add more sides to your curry.
Order ahead of time by phone so you don't have to wait in line.
author: Rong H.

description:
Had the chicken katsu curry for lunch. it was literally only chicken katsu and curry with my brown rice. i thought it would come with miso soup too but it didn't. kind of disappointed there.

honestly speaking, the chicken katsu was just ok. however i guess a katsu is a katsu, it's hard to make it taste heavenly. the mild curry i had was just ok too, contrary to the positive reviews here. 

i guess next time i should just order a more popular curry dish to see what the hype is all about.
author: J P.

description: Muraccis is a little hole in the wall that I was introduced to when I began taking a class at the Academy building around the corner. They have it ready in minutes, and its a refreshing spicy lunch. I always get the vegetable curry over brown rice, and I sometimes wonder if there is any meat in the curry...haha. Questionable? I'm not sure. I still love it!
author: Cherish P.

description:
I was feening for some Japanese curry in a bad way...(like heroin addict bad).  So I sent S.B. to Muracci's to get me my fix for lunch, and boy did it satisfy the beast.

I ordered the mild veggie curry, he ordered the katsu curry.  The best part is the sauce, it tastes homemade and fresh - like real home cooking, not from a boxed mix.  I echo the sentiment from one of the reviews I read prior - it's so good, after all of the rice was gone, I drank the remaining curry like soup with my spoon.  

I love supporting really good local owned small businesses.

P.S. Definitely call your order in advance for pick up to avoid the hassle.
author: Burrito M.

description: I really want to know what people are eating here that they are in love with it. I've tried both the Chicken Katsu Curry and the regular Chicken curry, but the meat has very little flavor. Instead, I recommend the JapaCurry truck, which is amazing!
author: Aditi D.

description: Muracci's nailed it. If you're looking for Japanese curry downtown, this is your spot. The line moves considerably quickly, despite frequently stretching out the door. The food is excellent and the staff is very attentive / customer-focused. Space is a little tight but the food more than makes up for it.
author: Peter C.

description:
I had always been curious about the food at Muracci's since there seems to be a line out the door every day.  My friend also highly recommended it.  So despite it being surprisingly warm and sunny in the City today, I decided to stop in to pick up an order of vegetable curry with brown rice.  There was no line due to the fact that they had just opened 15 minutes prior.

When I got back to the office, I packed some aside in a small tuppy so I could eat it after my work out tonight.  I practically inhaled it! When I finished my lunch portion, I started working on my dinner portion and had to really tear myself away from it so I would have some left for later.  If I ate the whole thing, I'd be in food coma for the rest of the day!  Sooo good!  The curry was is very flavorful and isn't too heavy and they make the brown rice just right.  I'll definitely be coming back.  I want to try their ramen and udon, maybe I'll save those for a really cold and icky day.
author: Laura L.

description:
I had the Katsu and Curry. This was the best Tonkatsu that I've had outside of Japan. The crust was crisp and the meat was tender and moist. 

There's almost no place to sit except for benches along 2 narrow counter tops, but the Tonkatsu was so good, that I'd be happy to just stand and eat!
author: Albert S.

description: The curry udon chicken noddle soup will definitely hit the spot when your looking for a nice warm meal on a windy SF day.
author: Drew F.

description:
A Japanese owned place (Thank God) that serves up authentic Japanese fare.  Having moved here from Hawai'i I am a bit skeptical about Japanese food since I've had the best of the best back home.  Everytime I walk into this place I am greeted with a warmness that has always transported me back home to the land of "aloha" even for a minute.  It's this warmness that is missing from a lot of food haunts in the city.  I'm actually a person here not just revenue to pay the bills!  Fancy that!  

True, the place is small but most okazuya types are.  A few tables and counter space with stools make up for the tiny seating area.  Their menu is diverse and even though they specialize in Japanese curry they still have your regular Japanese items such as Karaage, Oyakodon, Teriyaki, etc.  I am always that much more happier with an eatery for their addition of brown rice.  Muraccis has such an option.  But, beware, SF is known for healthy eaters and the brown rice can be sold out at times.  Speaking of which, their popular items such as the infamous Katsu Curry become sold out as well.  This is a popular place especially during lunch time with the Downtown crowd.  Don't believe me?  Drive by Kearny during lunch time and I guarantee you will see a line out the door.  I usually call ahead and it always works in my favor.  

They are such sweet people to keep the curry and dry goods separate when doing take out.  They have a weekly special which is worth trying.  However, if I feel as if I can't seem to decide what to order I always go to my default - vegetable/tofu curry.  No I am NOT granola but I do love me some tofu from time to time and hello, I need my vegetables.  My Filipino ancestors would kick my beautiful butt if I go a day (or a plate) without it.
author: Heizel M.

description:
Like Japanese food? Like curry? Want to try them together? Come here.

Reading some other yelps, sounds like this place can get slammed in the heart of the lunch hour. Take my advice and go later - I stopped by around 2 today and I was the only person in the place. In all honesty, I could have used a line. I couldn't decide between the chicken, tofu or salmon curry. Everything sounded delicious.

Went with the chicken, and I was not disappointed. Chunks of grilled goodness soak in a tasty curry (your choice of mild, medium or hot), and earning them a fifth star, comes with your choice of white or brown rice. How often do you get that?

A few minutes after placing my order I had my eats, and a few minutes after that, I also had a very happy stomach.
author: Jason B.

description:
I really wanted to like Muracci's.  I knew immediately that it is owned and operated by Japanese Americans as soon as I walked in, and that's more than I can say about many places in the Bay Area that serve similar food.

However, Muracci's is OK at best.  There's nothing special here unless you've never had good curry before.  Anybody can make the same food (possibly better) with a little work.  Here's how:

Go to the supermarket and buy curry stock.  It'll be in the Asian section.  Buy some vegetables and meat (carrots, potatoes, onions, pork/chicken/beef).  Cook the meat and vegetables while you get a big ol' vat of water boiling.  Meanwhile, steam some California grown "Japanese" rice.  Once the water is boiling, add the curry and melt it and add your meats.  Let it simmer for a while--it tastes better that way.  If you have the patience to let it cool down and then heat it up again, do it--it tastes even better that way.  Pour the stuff on top of the rice. Viola~ Itadakimasu.  That's all they do at Muracci's.  It tastes like S&B instant curry and has very little "gu" (meat and veggies).
author: Jin D.

description:
This place is the real deal.  I had the Chicken Katsu Curry (medium).  I am used to a little thicker sauce but the flavor was perfect.  The medium had enough spice to it that it made my nose run a little but it wasn't too hot.  The chicken was a nice thick cut, fried to crisp perfection.

I ordered a Oyako Donburi to go.  I'm hardly ever in the Financial District during the weekday so I needed to make the most of my trip.  Heated the Donburi up for dinner and could not believe how good it tasted. It tasted just like my mother's and she made the best Donburi sauce.  

I can't wait to plot my next weekday trip downtown to taste more of the menu.  It is probably a good thing (for my waistline) that this joint is terribly inconvenient for me.
author: D J.

description:
I don't know what I'd do without Muracci's - my week would be empty.

Despite the long lines at peak lunch time, despite the crowding, despite the slight feeling that there could be more care over my curry, the quality of the product is also so great to warrant a 5 star rating.
author: John K.

description:
There are over 500 reviews for this place, so mine won't much matter, but I want the whole world to know how much I love this place.

This place isn't perfect. It's small, the wait can be long, and they sometimes run out of what I want to order. No matter, still definitely 5 stars.

All of those things are part of the charm of this place. Sure it's small, but it makes you feel you're in someone's kitchen and they're making a special meal for me. The wait can be long, but just call 15 ahead, and it'll be there waiting for you when you get there. And the fact that they run out of things, well everything else on the menu is amazing too, so no worries there either. 

When I'm waiting in line, its seems the most popular item is the Chicken Katsu, which I agree is wonderful, but my favorite is the tofu and veggie ramen. The curry is more of a soup that gets soaked into the chewy ramen noodles. So good, especially if its chilly outside. Oh man, after a long day of work, when the fog is starting to roll in, calling in an order right as I leave the office. Total win.
author: melissa c.

description: this curry is different and unique from all other japanese currys ive had. i dont know if its the spices or the way they cook it, but it looks nothing like the other ones. Its so flavorful but not overwhelming, i had the medium katsu curry, and it was delicious! =) i will be back here to satisfy my curry cravings again! =)
author: Stella J.

description: Go there often, just had the daily special "Tonkatsu Sandwich" it was fantastic, great portion fantastic bold flavors.
author: Tr M.

description: Crowded, but service is fast and friendly.  The curry was rich and sufficiently spicy, the katsu crispy and the pickles fresh.  Having a cute tattooed lady at the register helps, too.  ;)  Overall, quite good, and I will be returning.
author: Jason K.

description:
I can't believe it took me almost 2 years of working in SF to make it out to this place! A coworker and I were both starving and he recommended this place. I wasn't sure what to expect, but since I am not a curry lover, I was thinking this might not be the best place for me...

As usual, I was wrong. The wait was a little longer than your typical take out place, but it was because they make everything fresh. I tried the Tonkatsu, which are pork cutlets. It came with miso, your choice of steamed or brown rice and a small side salad. The pork was perfectly cooked and it was a rather large amount of food. For $8.50, it is definitely a bargain! Everything else was very good as well. The rice had the right sticky consistency and I was able to try the curry sauce, which surprisingly, I liked. It had the perfect kick to it. Maybe next time I will try a curry dish and who knows, maybe this place will covert me into a curry lover. Anyone who knows me can tell you this would be one hell of a feat!
author: Jason B.

description: So soooo delicious. I got the chicken curry and the flavor was incredible and bold. I will most definitely be back for it. It lost 1 star because I felt there were few pieces of chicken in the curry.
author: Frances S.

description: My friend and I visited this place on a Thursday at lunchtime, and the place was packed! There was barely enough room to shuffle around. Don't count on getting any places to sit during busy hours. We ended up bringing a the food to a nearby park to eat. I got the pork katsu curry, and it was everything I expected it to be. I was very satisfied!
author: Sean W.

description:
100% Japanese.
It is funny to say that.  
To a curry store, don't you think?
I like Japo-style curry very much.
I think Japo-style curry is the Best.
But, that does sound a bit strange because curry is originally Indian thing.
But I saw numbers of Indian lookin' people in the store too.
 
So, I understand that there is NOTHING WRONG to say "American style Sushi", right?
Is it?
But I say, "HELL NO!!!!"
I am saying GOOD and BAD.
I am saying that most "American style Sushi" are just SO Creepy BAD AS SHIT.
So, most "American style Sushi"= SUSHIT.

Enough for sushi, this is about the curry.
Anyway.

"Let's get this FXXXin' Curry Shit over with."
My lovely GF said.
So we went.
TonKatsu Curry  hot $8.50
Chicken Katsu Curry hot  $8.50
2 bottle of Iyemon Green tea $5.90
2 Dorayaki $3.50

Great tender pork Katsu.
I like the brown rice option, great idea.
But,
I wish I like eating curry from the paper box but I don't, I prefer plate.
Great Curry indeed but the presentation didn't attract me because I've never thought that curry is take out food in Japan, and if you call it Japanese style.

They don't need a dish washer.
Great idea for the place but making more trash.

I want my FXXXin' Japanese style curry on a FXXXin' plate!
4 star.

There was a NON Asian Girl sat next to me eating the curry with chopsticks!!!!  True!

Btw, Chie J. said, "Hey nobu! How are you!  I know the owners of Muracci and they are very nice!  FYI They have plates if you ask them."
author: Nobu K.

description: Simple and awesome. I got there beef bread which was so bomb. Also got there katsu curry with brown rice. Everything it should have been but with really good flavor. This is a must go to place for all locals.
author: Shawn K.

description: Muracci's has probably the best curry in San Francisco that I have tried, especially if you are looking to get it to go. I like the fact that you can choose your level of spice and add whatever you want to it (Katsu items, extra meat, tofu, etc). The only thing I wish they had more of is meat in the sauce. I only usually get 1 piece. Aside from that everything is excellent. I would also say that their curry pan is worth trying at least once!  Don't expect to find too much space to sit as it is really a to-go place. This review is strictly written for their food.
author: Justin Y.

description:
Brought the hubby here for lunch today. He's not a big fan of any type of curry but today, he wiped his plate clean.  

I'm leaving for vacation tomorrow and today's chicken katsu curry completely blew my swimsuit diet out of the water.  Must starve all day tomorrow! 

I seriously love this place!
author: kathi k.

description:
I was walking down this street when I noticed a huge line out of the door of this restaurant. Long lines usually mean good food, so I changed my lunch plans to stop and pick up some grub here.

Best curry katsu I've ever had! They use a large pork patty, all white meat, that is cut just the right thickness to remain tender after frying. The batter is light, tasty, and is freshly fried when you order it. The curry itself, is incredibly delicious! The spicy isn't overpowering and adds a great flavor. It's packed separately when you order it so that you don't get a soggy piece of pork when you eat it as take out. 

The korukke are also freshly fried. The filling is mashed up potato and meat that is curried, and almost as equally delicious as the katsu.

The beef curry soup with ramen noodles should probably be skipped. The flavor is good, but I think they need to give a lot more soup for the amount of noodles they use, and the beef is a little on the tough side.

The line was out the door for lunch, and a lot of people seem to phone in their orders for pick up to expedite the wait. The place is tiny and only wide enough  for 2 people to stand and way too cramped if you're trying to sit down at their bar to eat. 

I definitely recommend taking this food to go. The line is long because everything is freshly made to order, but the wait is well-worth it.
author: Elizabeth T.

description:
Had the chicken katsu spicy curry.. I like the curry..it was spicy.. but, I like the chicken katsu from JapaCurry truck more.. the place is a hole in the wall..very narrow.. it gets really busy during lunch time.. they do take orders over the phone and by fax..but, if you're in line, they do take down your orders..so, overall the service is fast.

On a separate time, I tried the beef curry udon noodle soup..the portion was small considering the price was $9..the noodles were good, but the beef was hard.. curry was yummy.. I don't think I'll get this again, but I will get the spicy curry that I had with the chicken katsu again.
author: Linda Y.

description: Definatley a fan , Mild curry veggie or tonkatsu is the say to go. And yes they have brown rice Yahh , perfect for lunch on a cold day will warm you and your bones upp. !!! a must !!! The meat is tender and never dry.
author: P C.

description:
I found this place on Yelp because I wanted to try Chicken Karaage. I tried it at Sawaii Sushi last week from a Yelp recommendation and it was nasty. 

Arrival time:      1:15 pm, Wed
To Order:           At the counter ,then wait for food
Space:                Very small, only counter space about 10 chairs.
Wait Time:        15min
Food Order:      Karaage and cal roll.
Food qual:        The chicken was tender and juicy with a good cruchy crust. Cal roll was average
Overall:              Very busy, lots of people packed in, but most to go
Price:                 Good price, large servings

I will go back to try the curries.

This place is directly across the street from L&L Hawaiian BBQ, yet I have never noticed it.
author: Monica H.

description: Perhaps the best oyako don I've had.  I've searched everywhere for the perfect bowl and this place is tops.  The egg was cooked perfectly, still a bit runny.  The sauce is out of the world.  Go try it!
author: Bruce M.

description: Delicious curry & at a price that doesn't hurt my wallet the way other restaurants in the city do. I'm pretty satisfied with this place. The curry has a nice flavor - not too strong. Goes great with the tonkatsu. I'd definitely come here again.
author: Shar M.

description: Third time there.  Ordered curry the first two times and very tasty.  Not the best but one of the better.  Been on a quest for a decent "fast food" oyakodon in downtown SF and had high hopes for Muracci's.  At first glance, had the right look and color (you'd be surprised how many places will stick teriyaki chicken in a bowl and call it oyakodon).  First three bites were good.  Chicken might've been a bit dry but fine with the egg and sauce.  After that, I was on a quest to find my next piece of chicken.  It was basically egg and rice.  If you go, stick with the curry.
author: David I.

description:
Short version: yep, it's Japanese curry.

Longer version: -1 for being stingy with the rice and the hot curry being a medium at best. Stick with the pork katsu. If you can, go at 1pm to avoid the massive lines; downside is that you'll miss the curry bread.

Long version: [see other reviews]
author: Steven L.

description:
I would have to say that the hype barely lived up to my expectations of this *crazy* busy lunch spot.

This play is a tiny, order-and-go curry shop with just a couple of bar seats available. I waited in line a long time figuring it must be some daaang amazing eats but was only mildly impressed overall.

I ordered a "medium" level spice curry ramen to go. The ramen noodles come packaged separately which meant they weren't hot were stuck together. Curry broth poured over the noodles were pretty good. Perfectly spicy and satisfying. 

I felt like I could get equally good soup elsewhere without the wait, and maybe wouldn't have to trek back to my office to eat it.
author: Rachel L.

description: Katsu curry all way! I've gotten a few other dishes here, but I always come back to this one. It's delicious, filling, and will definitely put you in a food coma for two hours afterward. Pro tip: call ahead with your order and skip the queue when you get there.
author: Adam D.

description:
I've never been to Japan, but I heard glowing reviews from people who visited multiple times that Muraccis makes the best katsu curry that tastes as though it were from the streets of Ni Hon itself instead of San Francisco.  

Although I had my doubts (after all, Katsu Curry is great and all but not my absolute favorite Japanese dish) I went for lunch one day and I was hooked.  The food is priced around $9 for the Katsu Curry, plus a little more if you want more curry - which I HIGHLY recommend.  There is nothing better than dipping the pork in the sauce as well as drenching the whole thing (rice included) and then shoveling it down.

I tried the chicken in an attempt to be "healthier" (but who am I kidding?) and it was pretty good as well - but I definitely recommend the pork for most people.  The chicken was tasty but slightly drier - though it didn't matter that much after I doused it with a hearty bath of Katsu Curry.

Definitely a lunchtime favorite, and something to look forward to in the work day - just make sure not to give yourself a food coma.
author: Shay F.

description:
On my continued quest to find some decent and decently priced foods in the FiDi San Francisco, I checked out this place based on other Yelp reviews.  

The food:

Katsu Curry (Pork Cutlet served with Curry Sauce) $8.95

First of all, the Pork Katsu was Delicious!!  Some of the best I've ever had.  It was hot, fresh, juicy and light & crispy on the outside.  

The curry was what I had a problem with.  It was thin.... much too thin for a curry.  It was just above the consistency of of vegetable soup.  I know Japanese curries aren't nearly as thick as some Indian curries, but this flowed right off of my katsu and through the rice.  Unacceptable.

The joint:

Very small, very busy, but cozy.  There was a line out the door with people waiting to order.  People standing, in every little nook and corner waiting for their food.  There's only one 2-top table and barstools for about 6 or 7.  Definitely not a place to hang out with a group of friends.  But the servers were very friendly and looked very busy behind the counter.

Thoughts:

I will go back and try this place again to give their curry another go.  Maybe it was a bad day.  I can't imagine it would be consistently like this with the number of good reviews this place has gotten.  And I will try some of the pastries and croquettes the next time I'm there.
author: Samuel L.

description: Tastes good, but a bit heavy for me. Probably a 3.75 stars, impo.
author: George L.

description:
I have mix feelings about this place. I did my research and was very excited to try it but was a little disappointed by the flavor of the curry. I ordered the SPICY chicken katsu curry but it was NOT spicy at all. My friend had their Donburi w/brown rice which was OK too. We both wished we had some kimchi.
I might try this place again if I'm in the neighborhood but not worth walking 10 blocks.
author: Deb C.

description:
Its a really small place and if your eating by yourself you might enjoy dining there otherwise take it to go. Lines are long so beware and I heard from people around me that you can order before hand and come pick it up. But you must keep in mind that there is a wait time because they fry your meat or what not right then and there..or if you want medium or Hot curry they also mix that up for you then and there.

I ordered a Katsu Curry...level of spicy being at medium. Medium is just about right..not too spicy but adds a little boost. Their katsu was very crunchy and tasty. And it wasnt dry which is a plus~. I added spinach to my curry...felt pretty good to me~

Overall they pack on a good amount of food, not too little but not too much. So you dont get overcome with food coma after heading back to the office for work. They also seperate the curry for you so you can add as much as you want when you eat. And they give you enough curry so that you wont have any naked rice with no curry.

Despite the wait time, I can see this place as another one of my favs for lunch time~
author: phillip w.

description:
I've solved the slow problem. You just need to order the express curry and make sure all parties in your group do the same, this is the most stressful part of going here. This is the only way you can get out of here in under 10 minutes with a group of 4-5. The first time we came it took about 45 minutes to wait for all our food. This isn't cool for a lunch time place when you need to get back to work.

The food quality here is high. I would suggest to the staff that they expand the selection for the express lunch to have more than just *mild* curries. I would also like more vegetables with my chicken, it's just kind of boring now when I only get a few dices of pickled something with my chicken.
author: Michael S.

description:
They will do Extra Spicy, no charge.  So good!  A boiled egg (highly recommended) is 50 cents.  

Next time, I will dare them to kill me with heat.
author: Jared L.

description:
Sounds interesting and there's a big lunch crowd but sadly the vegetable curry is really nothing special. Start with Panda Express and dump chili powder on it and wait around for 45 minutes, and you've got pretty much the same thing that you could get at Muracci's.

My co-workers rave about it so perhaps the meaty dishes are better. I think Muracci's is just not very veg-friendly.
author: Jamie F.

description:
Philly and I were talking about eating curry at Muracci for the longest time, but we were just all talk.  So I finally put this spot on my outlook calender for lunch with philly. 

Philly recommended chicken katsu.  I went for the katsu curry, he got chicken.  I make Japanese curry at home, so it wasn't ALL THAT exciting for me to check this spot out.  Since Philly and his wife don't cook too often, it's more exciting for him, and Muracci made it to his top lunch spot.

Wow.  To my surprise, the curry is flavor-packed.  Very spicy (as in the spices.)  The katsu was made just right.  Probably the best katsu I ever had. 

I got the medium spicy, and it's just the right hotness for me.  Cabbage that came with the curry were delicious!  The meal was hearty, perfect for a cold cold day.  The portion is HUGE.  I told Janie to split with me next time and we can go for dessert.

Overall, I love it.  Good recommendation Philly!
author: Gigi T.

description: This is a tiny restaurant on Kearny, always a long line outside the store during lunch hours, The curry noodle soups are good. Very flavory yet light. No MSG! I tried rice plates, they are OK, not match with the reviews on this site.
author: Emmy P.

description:
EDIT:

got the chicken katsu today with brown rice, potato salad, green salad and miso soup. 

SPECTACULAR katsu. the breast was tender and juicy, the panko crust was PERFECT and didn't need a bunch of tonkatsu sauce to make it taste better. 

************************************

i'm writing this review as i wolf down my tofu/veggie curry (hot) over brown rice, with a side of pickled cabbage and lotus root chips.

i haven't been able to taste much of anything for the past two weeks on account of the flu, but as the first thing i'm able to taste, this is probably the BEST curry i've had states-side since 1999 (and i was living in asia at the time). 

the veggies are lightly steamed, and retain a lot of crispness and crunch, but the real star is the curry sauce, thick and flavorful with multiple layers of spicy-ness. no milk or cream added to ensure full curry flavor.

i love that the little shop is super clean, and there are wonderful sides that really add to the meal, like sweet and sour pickled cabbage and fried lotus root chips. 

plus, you get your pick of white or brown rice. 

the serving size is LARGE and definitely big enough for 2 small lunches if you're not too hungry. curry keeps well in the fridge! 

i'll be going back to try their katsu curry and bento boxes. every option is under $10. 

tip: call in your order. the line is HELLA long and a normal wait takes around 10-15 minutes depending on what you order. (omg, did i just say HELLA?!)

tip for business owner: to expedite the bentos, you might want to forgo the first come first cook ticket method and group all of the similar orders together. say, if you have 3 tempura curries, do them all at once. just sayin.
author: May T.

description:
The night before we visited, we checked on Yelp for a good place to visit for lunch. What we didn't know was that the parking situation in the Financial District is hell! There was a lot across the street, but they were trying to charge us something crazy like $18 for 1 hour. OH HELL NO! We're from out of town, but we're not stupid. We drove around until we found parking on a hill 2 streets away. Lucky! 

When we got to the restaurant it wasn't full, but right after we ordered, a flood of people came in. It was almost as if the out-of-towners channeled in all of the regulars. So anyway, we managed to secure a table by the restroom, but that was a bad idea as it became super difficult to move when people wanted to go to the restroom. 

The Katsu Curry was juicy and perfectly crunchy and the curry was the right amount of spicy. I hate chunky curries and this place does not do chunky curry. LOVED IT!
author: Janny W.

description: I came here when it was the lunch rush on a weekday. I was surprised at how small it is on the inside, i imagined it to be bigger. I thought it was going to be a long wait because the line was out the door, but i only waited a few minutes. This one lady takes your order while in line and sends your order to the kitchen so people in line wouldn't feel like they needed to wait a long time. i ordered a mild chicken curry, which is an "express" order because i guess they make a whole pot before-hand. I had to quickly eat it because i was in a rush. But even if you're eating it quickly, it still tastes pretty good. I wish i had gotten the chicken katsu instead because just chicken is a little bland. But if i have time, i would definitely go back to try more menu items =)
author: Angela H.

description:
Technically, I would rate it 4 stars as food, but that extra is for under $10 in SF!

Must Go. I will go back if I am there on foot (can't drive to Japantown), and want a tasty curry (which is barely Medium on the Tacobell spice level, which is bland on the Thai spice level).

Food = 
[1] First time on 20080728 = 
[1a] Me ordered Pork Katsu Curry Hot on white rice. Hearty 10oz of pork breaded well and deep fried well. Along with the two small bowl worth of rice, 1 oz of picked red ginger, and another 1oz of picked cabbage, it was worth just under $9, and amazingly cheap to be in the middle of the financial district. My only complaint was the amount of curry was not enough with so much of everything else. 
[1b] Fellow foodie (lived abroad in japan) KO ordered the fried Ebi Curry Medium on white rice. I smelled the aroma and will order that next. KO tought the spice level was just right about mild Thai spice, which is good enough.
[1c] Fellow foodie (lived abroad in japan) LL ordered Chicken Katsu Curry Mild on brown rice. I tried a bite of the brown rice and was please to not have any graininess crunch, which meant this place spent the time to soak the rice for a day or two. LL liked the chicken well enough, but liked my pork and mixed curries to get from MILD to MEDIUM, but will order HOT next time. LL also said I should not complain about the amount of curry, because it is about the meat and watery rice sucks.
[1d] Tag-along Kentucky-raised white TW ordered Pork Katsu Curry Mild on white rice, and liked the taste of the curry, but was a bit hot for him and still would rather have American tonkatsu sauce and lettuce instead of all that rice. Since nothing like that is close by, then back TW will go if within 10 city blocks.

Speed = as fast as two cooks can make things. 
[1] My friend called in at 11:15am, was on hold until 11:20am, food was ready at 11:45am, paid at 11:55am, still hot! CALL AHEAD!

Setting = Authentic Japanese = small hole-in-wall with simple and friendly family staffing. Too small to handle a crowd, so always order to go. Layout looks like

|========================
|             |DD|................................ |
|             ------................................ |
|_               __............................... |
|  | O         |    | $........ __ ..............|
|  |             |    |............|    |..............|
|  | O         |    |.......C..|    |..............|
|  |             |    |............|    |..............|
|  | O         |    |..C.......|    |..............|
|  |             |    |_____|    |..............|
|_| O         |_________|______|
|                         W|_|W |               |
|              O  O                       BR   |
|           |--------| O  O  O |              |
|           |           |______|              |
|           |___________|______|
 Enter
------------------------------------------
                 Kearny Street
------------------------------------------

O = stools
W = wheelchair spots, with 1 foot high chairs in place
D = drinks in a fridge
$ = ca$hier (note only 1, which is why so slow for phone order)
C = cooks
... = employee area only

Each non-period ANSI character about 2 feet by 2 feet

[2]  went about 3 times in 2009 - consistently great! Curry Pan and and Croquette are just fried, has corn and is so very good! 

[3]  20110818 -  I was so happy to go back here after over a year out of state. If you know what japanese curry taste like, this is it. The meat may not be of Japanese quality, but hey, it is alot for under $10.

[4] 20120406 - Smells so good and was still a line of 5 people when I got there at 1pm. Curry Pan was sold out (boo!), but that curry was still so good!
author: Jim L.

description: I must say, they got some really good curry! The spice level of "spicy" is perfect! The right amount of heat and the flavor is just popping. Delish! What I like to get here is the katsu curry with brown rice =)
author: A L.

description: The Katsu is perfectly crispy on the outside and tender on the inside as is the curry, which is not too overpowering (how I like it). You can choose from mild to extra hot for the curry as well as a selection of vegetables to put with it too. They also have a good selection of side dishes. This is my go-to place for Japanese curry.
author: Z L.

description:
In the ideal world, my Obachan would live in San Francisco with me. My Ogichan would remain in Sacramento with my parents, but bachan would live here, cook me delicious food, go shopping with me, and spoil her only granddaughter in appropriate fashion.

Unfortunately, she lives in Sacramento and she and my grandfather come as a package deal. To get me through the time until trips back home, I fill the half-jap void in my chest with bad quality sushi and homemade terriyaki sauce (which never tastes as good as when someone else makes it, you know?)

But today I found Muracci's (courtesy of Matt J.) and finally tried it. I was waiting to brave the line (brought a book and everything) but I arrived at 2 and was in and out with my hot chicken curry with vegetables in less than 10 minutes. The curry is spicy and sweet at the same time, just like Obachan used to make. The carrots are cooked just perfectly, the broccoli is crisp, and it's served in generous proportions over white or brown rice (another thing like my grandmother-- generous proportions because she always thought I was hungry, even when she tried to pile on a 3rd serving). Their pickled cabbage side is crisp and perfect, but I still like my grandmother's sweet pickles better.

It's so good it makes me a little homesick. The only thing that would make this just like my grandmothers house  would be to sell onigiri the size of your fist with umebosh inside, manju with red bean paste, daikon kim chi, nato (this is not a good thing and i hate that her fridge always smells like it) and getting drunk on this fermented ume plum gin she makes that's supposedly "good for throat and nose". 

Yeah, that much alcohol would be good for that.

I digress. I don't like having to take my lunch hour at 2, but to get the curry from muracci's is totally worth it. Thank you for bringing me back to my childhood. Perhaps the chicken katsu-don next time.
author: Stephanie H.

description:
We hit the place at 11:30, after reading the Chronicle review and not wanting to wait in line.  I got the ebi fry curry (medium heat) over brown rice.  $8.95.  The shrimp was perfectly fried.  I also tried the potato ball and the strawberry roll.  Roy got the chicken curry (hot) and Cecilia got the pork katsu (medium).  Everybody ate all their food.  The place filled up quickly and when we left, there were about 7 people in line.

This is a good, cheap place to grab lunch, but you have to get there early lest you want to spend some time waiting for the food.
author: Lynnie P.

description:
I stopped by later in the day after getting out of work early.
So I bypassed the crazy lunch crowd.
The veggie curry with fried tofu and brown rice was everything I 
wanted, needed and desired at that moment served up for a 
reasonable price. . .
author: Kia B.

description:
Finally! Japanese curry in the FiDi! And this place is the real deal! Japanese food made by actual Japanese people (not that I don't appreciate you Mexicans). Great service. I ordered my food and they started cooking right away - got it in ten minutes tops.

I wish they had a bigger place so I can actually sit down there with a group of friends. Be prepared to spend about  $7- $9 for your order.

Delicious curry - mild, medium, or hot. And you get your choice of white rice or brown rice. They also have salads, donburi or bento boxes (w/ teriyaki whatever). Go for the curry!

JONASAPPROVED!
author: Jonas T.

description:
Although the name sounds almost Italian, it is true Japanese.

After reading reviews here, I ordered my medium spicy curry chicken w/ veggies and brown rice to go. It was waiting for me when I got there in 15 minutes as they promised. Very good curry and I will be going back. I'm not giving it 5 stars because I didn't feel that I had enough chicken. The chicken katsu, however, looked huge.

Since the menu isn't posted online, I thought I would share some of the items with you here in case you haven't been and want to order to go:

Lunch sets -- $7.50-8.95
Salads -- $3.50-5.95
Chicken curry -- $6.95 (curry is served mild, med or hot, over white or brown rice)
Chicken katsu curry -- $8.50
Beef curry -- $7.50
Katsu curry -- $8.50
Seafood (shrimp, scallop and fish) curry -- $8.95
Vegetarian (tofu and veggies) curry -- $6.95
Donburi -- $6.50-7.95
Hot Noodle soup (curry with udon, soba or ramen) -- $7.50-8.50
Sushi -- $2.50-3.50
Add on spinach or veggies to curry -- $0.50

Have a nice lunch!
author: Kat H.

description: Went with the recommendation of someone in line and ordered number 3 (chicken Katsura curry), chose it hot, and with brown rice. Like most of the reviews here, the food is very tasty, the service is fast considering the lines, and the endorphin rush of the hot curry is a nice finish.
author: Scott K.

description: They introduced curry pan, which is like a curry empanada.  it comes in beef, chicken and veggie - possibly other curry combos - I wasn't paying attention.  anyway, they are delicious and a great addition to the menu.  I got the veggie and tofu curry for lunch the other day and it hit the spot.
author: Bebe W.

description:
I love this place. 

First let me start with the people who work here. Everyone is so nice. I mean, super ultra nice. The guy behind he cash register kind of reminds me of Mr. Miyagi. I think it is the mustache. Today he was wearing a pura vida hat (a catch all phrase used by Costa Ricans meaning everything good). Anyway, I give them extra points for style.

But the food is the real star here. Sweet and spicy curry over all the standards. A little bit of perfect pickled cabbage on the side. They package the curry separate from the rice so you can control exactly how much you want to use (and they give you a lot). 

I get the curry over fried salmon spicy and brown rice. I like brown rice, it makes me feel like I'm healthy. It is easily the best curry I've had in the city. They actually can make the curry spicy (most places seem to have a serious problem with using enough chili pepper), but Muracci's delivers.

Extra points for the starch based containers.

The wait? Yes there is a wait. I'm sorry for all the people who get uptight about waiting in lines. Bring a book or a newspaper or go at go at 2:30. Or don't go at all. You just make the line longer for the rest of us!
author: Jordan M.

description:
I'll preface this review by saying that I am a Japanese(-American) and grew up eating curry.  I'd like to think I'm aware of what's good curry and what's not.

It's not that the curry isn't good, it's just that I can make it (better to my liking) at home.  I got the katsu curry because I love breaded deep-fried pork and I don't have a deep fryer in my kitchen.  

I was a bit surprised at first to get just curry sauce with the katsu and rice.  I'm used to vegetables and whatnot in my curry, granted you can get those for 50 cents extra, not a bad price.

I find their system rather inefficient which contributes to the wait time.  It can get frustrating to watch the nice lady prepare 1 order of curry at time when there's another open burner on the stove to use. and 15 people in line.  

Oh well.  Overall, it's not bad, not the best, but definitely not bad.  I likely will never come here for just curry.  If I have a craving for katsu, then i'll probably come again.  Otherwise, I'll just make curry at home.

Oh, and the side order of karaage is pretty good, but perhaps a little too salty.
author: Naoko M.

description:
The Chicken Katsu is simply amazing and has stopped me from trying almost anything else on the menu because the flavor of this curry is so good that I fiend for it. Seriously. 

Yes ... the wait is really long ... but ... it is really that good and that fresh. They take their time to make you're food, which you should really be thankful for. I suggest that you order ahead of time. 

Muracci....

Word.
author: Brandon L.

description:
You know those campbell chicken soup for the soul commercials they used to play on TV when we were younger? 

Well,

Muracci is the chicken soup for the soul. Instead of chicken soup, it's curry. 

Curry for the soul.

SO GOOD. SO GOOD. SO GOOD. SO GOOD. SO GOOD.
author: J T.

description:
This place is absolutely fantastic!  Owned and  operated by Japanese...quite refreshing from the typical non-Japanese owned Japanese restaurants.  I have only been here one time, so I can only talk about the chicken katsu curry (fried chicken to you and me)....but, if the rest of the menu is anything like the chicken curry...i will definitely be coming back again and again.  The chicken was all white meat battered in panko bread crumbs---very crispy and not greasy at all.  The curry was obviously cooked for a very long time (which is good) with a lot of vegtables which had been cooked down to blend into a smooth curry sauce.  Probably the best curry I've ever had...and believe me, i've had a lot.  I would go with the medium spicy curry, since even the medium was enough to get my mouth burning.  
I highly recommend this place, and can't wait to go back and try something else on the menu.
author: Connor H.

description:
Muracci's is a perfect example of the fact that Japan has so much more to offer in the way of culinary options besides raw fish. This is one of those places that you can tell just by walking by that the food is going to be excellent. They don't disappoint inside. 

Japanese Curry is a favorite of mine so finding a place that specializes in it was really great. 

I can't wait to move to SF and get a job downtown so I can hit this spot up all the time. 

RrL
author: Double L.

description:
The line truly is long and the wait seems unbearable at peak lunch time.  However, I called in my karaage lunch to go this afternoon and I was able to bypass that line.

The chicken was okay.  Stick with the curry here.
author: Eating Sleeping T.

description:
After reading the reviews about the long wait, my coworkers and I trekked over for an early lunch and were the first customers at 11 am. I realized this place used to be the Kearny Hand-Held Pie place (across from L&L), and yes, it's tiny. There are only about 6 stools along the walls, so call in your order since you'll just be picking it up to go anyway. Our food took about 10 minutes after we ordered.

The beef, katsu, and tofu/veggie curries all had the same curry base. The katsu was lean and tender, perfectly battered...I haven't had a good katsu in a while. The curries are between $7-$9. You can get brown rice and if you want spicy, get the hot since the medium was pretty mild to me. The stovetop behind the cashier is tiny, yet they manage to fit 4 people back there. They also have teriyaki, donburi, udon, ramen. Everything is made to order. I also picked up a green tea roll cake which they said was from Japan. Starting in May, they'll be closed on Saturdays.
author: Mimi L.

description:
Never even heard of Japanese curry before happening upon this spot. Completely found this place by accident, but now find myself here at least once per week. Muracci is easy to miss since the standing room is only about as wide as a doorway, but the team in the kitchen doesn't miss a step. 4 to 5 people working in a small but perfectly utilized kitchen gets my respect.

Curry is decent, but the real pros here are that when everything is ordered it's made fresh and that candied ginger is outstanding as a complement to the meals.
author: Nick V.

description: The katsudon was very good, juicy, and crispy. The curry was okay. I was craving curry from Katana-ya, but I made myself go try somewhere new. I was disappointed with the curry, but I would say the katsudon is better.
author: Joolie T.

description:
I left my desk at 11:35, walked the 2 blocks to Muracci's, waited, ordered, waited, received, walked back 2 blocks and arrived at my desk at 12:05. Whew, what a wait! 

It was really good, but only just barely worth the wait for takeout. Woefully, I have never been to Japan, so I cannot compare it to its Japanese original. 

Note: Their rice containers are made of starch, but you do end up throwing a lot of trash away when you're done eating.
author: Sahra H.

description:
With all the 4 and 5 star reviews here, I'll need to explain why I'm just giving it 3 stars. It probably deserves 3.5 but my expectations were a bit higher given what I've read. I ordered the tonkatsu and fried chicken curry. Both meats were well prepared, the pork was not overly lined with fat but not too lean and dry. The chicken is from chicken breast so it'll never be like dark meat but was still tender. So why 3 stars... the curry just didn't live up to the hype. Although very good, and had good depth I felt that Japacurry was a bit better. The spices and flavoring are slightly more intense and rich. I'm also going to rate Muracci's curry against Miki's in the outer Richmond district. Although Muracci's was a bit better tasting than Miki's, I really like the fact Miki adds in shredded/minced pork into their curry sauce. As others have mentioned, it's a nice touch that brown rice is available here which tasted good.

I wouldn't make a special trip just for Muracci's curry, but if you're in the financial district and need a quick bite to eat and not be disappointed by over paying for an expensive and bland lunch, hit this hole in the wall up.
author: Andrew L.

description: 7x7 made me do it and I am glad I did. Muracci's is quick, convenient and most importantly delicious. The Katsu pork curry with rice is one of the most comforting meals an Asian person can have. With the thick curry sauce, crispy pork and soft steamed rice, this is a great soul-warming dish. The sauce was not as delicious as I would preferred given I like a little bit more of a deep curry but the pork was extremely tender and hearty. Not a lot of sitting area inside but good for lunch if you work in the area.
author: Ed L.

description:
Reminds me of Japan, only complaint is the line, oh what a line...sigh..

But the food is cook to order, made by old Japanese couple.

Totally authentic Japanese curry over juicy pork chops. I would wait in line for the food, that's how good it is.
author: Phillip K.

description:
Authentic Japanese style curry at a decent price. Today I went with the tonkatsu seto (that's set in English) and it was seriously tasty. They make everything to order so it's always fresh and hot. The tonkatsu was really tender and juicy -- better than you'll find at most places outside of Japan. I love the Japanese staff because it makes me feel like I'm in Tokyo again. 

There's a long line at this place for reason -- if you work nearby you have to check out Muracci's.
author: Aaron V.

description:
Take a quick hint and order ahead, so that when you arrive to pay at the restauraunt you won't have to wait that much longer for your curry.  It's worth the effort to do so, trust me.

Other than that, I found my tonkatsu curry to be very pleasing, very fresh, and very delicious.  My only gripe is that it wasn't as spicy when I specified "spicy" for my order.  But I do admit to sweating a little bit.  The pickled cabbage is a reliever for the spices though.

I'll definitely come back.
author: Ren L.

description:
Just like my thing for Japanese girls I have a thing for Japanese Curry. CURRY!

This place is geared towards take out as the place is small.
1 table for two
3 people at the window counter
3 people at the wall counter (which would be cramped with people coming in to order)

This place is authentic as the workers begin to bust out in Japanese.  Just like my thing for Japanese girls I have a thing for Japanese Curry.  It definitely passes the test.  I wish they would carrots and potatoes in stead of having the carrot specks.  The curry has a nice spice if you ask for it spicy.  Also, they have the Seven Spices to sprinkle, I like to dump it on.  The brown rice was great with the meal at no added cost.  

Chicken Katsu Curry (spicy) & Brown Rice $9.xx - Curry = Great, Katsu Breading = Great, Spicy = Great

3 Stars as the food is good, but no place to really sit.
+1 Star because there aren't very many Japanese place with this quality in the area & authentic peps..
author: Po L.

description: Great chicken katsu curry. Loved the chicken hot pocket thing they had, not sure what its called. Only deducting a star for the chicken because it was a bit much breaded and made the chicken dry when curry was not on it. Will deff be returning though!
author: Benjamin K.

description:
Mm quite tasty.

This place is a cute, tiny little place with a few counter seats. I'd recommend calling in a to go order or at least come in for take out. It get super crowded at lunch time and even if you do score a counter seat, good luck because I'm sure the people in line will be bumping you all throughout your meal.

As for the food, yummy and reasonably priced! Their curry is quite flavorful and, esp since its in their name, I'd recommend getting that. The chicken katsu is good and goes very well with the curry. The pickled cabbage that comes with your meal tops it off. We also tried the fried chicken, which is deep fried chicken pieces, not like bone-in drumsticks or thighs. Pretty tasty, but got a little soggy by the time we ate it since we took it to go. The fried chicken meal was good tho, with salad, potato salad, and miso soup.

Overall, get curry and get it to go!
author: Christine L.

description:
Man, I just love the people here. 

I was actually on my way to Sushi Bay last week, and veered left into this storefront the moment I saw it. It's TINY, but oh-so-cute. There were three people working in there at the time, two men and a woman. After placing my order, I waited quite a bit of time to get my chicken curry udon. And waited. And watched a bunch of people get agitated by the wait. I know that this is the financial district, and people have limited amounts of time, so really, I can see why people are getting fidgety. 

But MAN, all that melts away once you get your food. I settled back down into my desk chair, and this glorious smell wafted up at me as I pried the lid off my curry noodle bowl. Holy cow - this is the REAL DEAL. I got the mild, and it was just right - goldilocks style. Just because it is the mild - it's not lacking in taste, and that makes it great. You can tell that everything is made to order - which is why things can take a rediculous amount of time if they get swamped during the lunch hour. 

The best plan? Know what you want and call ahead - it will be ready for you when you walk in. =)

This is going to be a "regular" on the "I'm too lazy to bring my lunch to work" rotation. I may have to drag my friends here as well.
author: Jessica S.

description:
Okay, I have to admit. I am a curry whore. I will do anything for a curry dinner. Having said that, I also had my share of bad curry. 

At first, when I found Muracci's I was iffy. I was working Downtown around Chinatown and took a walk to see what was available. It was very small but it was crowded - a good sign. Didn't feel I had anything to loose so I tried it. It was a good move. I started with their pork katsu curry over rice with those red pickles. I loved it! It was just as good as any of the curries I tried in fancier Japanese restaurants in SoCal. 

So with each successive visits I tried each thing on the menu and I loved all of them. I had my friend who worked a couple buildings over to meet me there and have lunch together and he started liking it too. I had many good meals there until I got another job in another part of the city. 

Hope I can make it back there one of these days.
author: David P.

description:
This place immediately drew a crowd after it first opened, but the lines seem to have subsided a bit, thank goodness. (Seems like people are flocking to Best-O-Burger at the moment.) I still call ahead, though, and pick my order up rather than waiting in line. Oops, secret's out.

I haven't had anything other than the chicken curry, simply because it completely and utterly meets my needs. I don't know anything about Japanese curry, what it should or shouldn't taste like, but all I can say is, I like this version. The sauce is thick and complex, not too spicy (even when ordered "hot" -- then again, I like food with a kick). Love that they offer brown rice, love the pickled vegetables on the side. Friendly people, too!
author: Tara M.

description:
I decided to join Yelp for a couple of reasons. 1) I just moved to San Francisco from Los Angeles and I've quickly learned that there are way too many good places to eat that I need to keep track of and 2) Muracci's Japanese Curry & Grill.

I work in the financial district and it's been difficult to find a place near my office that's quick, that I don't need a reservation for and isn't American Cuisine. I did a quick "search nearby" for Japanese Food and saw a fantastic rating for Muracci's that I just had to try it.

I ordered the #3 Katsu Curry with a hard-boiled egg and extra rice at an added cost.

I was in and out within 10 minutes, though the space was tight while waiting for my food! It's been really hard finding clean, good quality Asian food nearby and I'm sure there are many but this is the first I found. I'm sure there are probably better places to eat but it's exactly what I needed for the cold weather, to fix my craving for Asian food and when speed's an issue.

I wouldn't drive out of my way to eat here, but it's perfect if you work nearby and are looking for a good place to eat.
author: Derrick P.

description:
So a couple friends brought me some take-out from this joint a couple days ago. Apparently they told me that the line was out the door and the wait was literally forever. With all the hype and anticipation, I was pretty psyched to try it. 

I got the chicken curry over rice which I don't want to say was spectacular, but wasn't necessarily terrible either. I guess I'm a bit spoiled. My first experience with Japanese curry was at CoCo Ichibanya Curry House in Hawaii and if you haven't tried it yet, let me tell you it's to die for. On a scale of 1-10, its an easy 15. 

Getting back to Murracci's, I'd have to say it's a noble attempt at Japanese curry. The sweet, yet zesty sauce is pretty tasty and the only thing I would actually gripe about is the 4-5 niblets of chicken it came with. My friend, Tanley who apparently is quite the Japanese curry aficionado says this is probably closest thing to CoCo's he's ever tasted and wanted me to rate it at least a 4. Sorry Tan...can't do it man. It's a solid 3 which I wouldn't mind going back to.

FYI...a little birdie told me that CoCo Ichibanya is coming to the states pretty soon...watch out Muracci's...you've been warned...
author: jeff c.

description: Stumbled upon this little shop while walking down Kearny Street! When we went for lunch at around 11 on a weekday, it was pretty packed but the service was quick. We ended up waiting for only about 10 minutes in a line that went out the door. Because it's a small place, don't depend on getting a seat during lunch hour especially with a big group of people. The curry was excellent and very hot (temperature-wise). I ordered the vegetable curry udon and loved it! Overall, eating at this shop made me feel as though I was in a real Japanese lunch joint, with the eat-and-go bar-style seating and the quick service.
author: Allie K.

description: Tried the pork katsu curry, medium.  Good, but nothing special.  You can make curry like this or better with cubes bought from the supermarket. They do give you plenty of food though, so at least you'll be plenty full.
author: Lady V.

description:
Ahh, nothing like filling up the backroom at work with the smell of curry. 

I've been here a couple of times already to satisfy my love for Japanese curry since I can never make it right at home despite how EASY it is to make it. The first time I went here there was korokke sitting on the counter waiting to be bought... However the next few times I went there I saw none... Maybe I should just ask and see if they actually have anymore? :(

Anyway, my favorite was the medium spice, katsu curry. The curry is just the right flavor and consistency for me. The katsu is almost perfect: crispy outside and the pork isn't dried up. 

I am sad they're closed on the weekends but understandable since they're near the FiDi. 

I do suggest you call ahead during lunch time though. Unless you like waiting 20-30 minutes in line and waiting for your food. 

They do have the express curry takeout if you order a mild beef or chicken curry.
author: Jonathan A.

description: This place is normally packed around lunch time, but even though the line was out the door I was in and out of Muracci's in under 10 minutes. For the first time visitors, I would recommend looking at the menu online before hand so you know what you want. When I showed up there was someone at the door taking orders (hence the needing to know what you want to eat). A majority of the people order food to go since there are only a handful of seats available inside.
author: Jennifer W.

description: Not a lot of good curry in downtown/FiDi.  I like Muracci's but it's also overrated.  I prefer curry from Dojima Ann.  I'll get it when I crave ramen in a curry sauce (not much of a soup).
author: Erika C.

description:
I didn't even know this was a kind of food until my colleagues brought me by here during a lunch outing.

The katsu curry is a lunchtime revelation.  Slices of pork fried and sliced over a bed of rice in one container, and one of the tastier renditions of what they call curry in the other.  I'm just going to describe it here cuz it's novel to me.  Muracci's curry is I think sweeter than I'm used to, with hints of something like cinnamon.  It's somehow lighter than an indian curry.  I like to pour my curry over the food in sections, maybe 4 or 5 pours over the course of the meal, but some people like to go all at once.  It's really a personality thing.

Muracci's is a welcome neighborhood addition.

Repeat hit.
author: Oliver N.

description:
I should be ashamed of myself. I've worked blocks from Muracci's for like seven months and today was my FIRST visit. Yummy.

I got the express mild chicken curry. A little sweet, a little spicy. Place is packed during lunch, so it seems like ordering the express items (mild chicken or beef curry) is a smart move. Also, you can get white or brown rice, which I appreciate. Request: more tsukemono.

Definitely a lunch that I see myself craving in the future... I'll be back.
author: Stephanie P.

description:
Ittedakimasu!  The classic Japanese curry bar is raised with this welcoming new addition to the FiDi.  There's a few other local offerings of Japanese food (supervised) by Japanese people, but this joint is heads and shoulders above them in their quality.

Cost-benefit analysis: $8-$9 after tax for delicious, authentic curries, noodles, and lunch sets?  Consider me sold.  That being said, do consider the value of your time -- typical wait for food is about 30ish minutes during peak hours, 10-20 minutes off-peak.

Tip 1: Remember to eat your veggies... and order them!  They're 50 cents for some simple steamed greens, but they really help balance out the food.  Their brown rice is yummy too.

Tip 2: Do yourself a favor and call in 20-30 minutes before you arrive with your food order.  All upside, no downside. :)

Tip 3: Their spiciness level of "mild, medium, and hot" is kinda misleading.  My take: mild = sweet-ish curry; medium = lightly, lightly spicy; hot = mmmm, getting warmer, having a light kick, but can we kick it up a notch for the real spice monsters?
author: J C.

description:
I enjoy all curry, whether it's spicy Indian, coconut-y Thai, or milder and sweeter Japanese.  Even homemade wussy Chinese curry.   Muracci's curry is darn good.  I went with a friend there at 11 am to avoid the lunch rush and almost missed the place.  It's small, with no awning, but there is a giant picture of a smiling man/boy that's presumably Muracci, their son??  Not sure.  

Anyway, the place is slightly bigger than what I imagined.  Because from all the yelp reviews, I thought it was gonna be just a counter and standing room for 2.  But no, my friend and I, being the first to arrive, had literally 10 seats to choose from!  I sat on the tall stool next to the window for a second then decided to settle on the 2-person small table next to the bathroom.  I love having choices! 

Music is soothing, by the way.  Soft Brazilian bossa nova is somehow really Japanese and really fitting here.  The inconspicuous restaurant, the Italian-sounding name, the jazzy sound, it's all very Murakami to me.  

I had the veggie and tofu curry, a little over $7 after tax.  My friend had the chicken curry.  I had mine medium hot and was perfect.  My friend thought her mild sauce was not spicy enough.  I very much loved the pickles that come with the rice.  It's crunchy and pungent and compliments so well with the rich curry and white rice.  

By 11:30am, more people came but there were still a couple of seats available.  We left a little before 12 so I am not sure how crowded it gets after that.

Business-wise, I think this will work out really well.  Location on Kearny makes a lot of sense, the small space will save them money on rent, and curry and rice is such an attractive idea for busy downtown workers.  It's ideal for take outs.  You can eat it at your desk as long as you don't mind smelling like curry for the rest of the afternoon.
author: Candice B.

description:
Yum! Katsu Curry was great, and they even put the curry in a separate container so that the Katsu didn't  get all soggy. Don't miss the Roll Cakes, I'll be back for the snacking!

They now have delicious little Curry Pan, too!
author: Ashton E.

description: I was really surprised not to enjoy my experience here -- my hopes were high with all of the rave reviews. I got the spicy chicken curry and added vegetables. The flavor of the curry was all right, but it was not at all spicy. My main complaints were that the portion was very small (only a few pieces of chicken and veggies) and it was barely warm, even cold in some spots.
author: Olivia P.

description:
One of my asian facebutt friends updates his status every few days that he's going to Muraccis, looking forward to Muraccis, or so happy after eating Murracis.  

I think I understand the obsession.  It's cheap, fresh, friendly + big portions!
author: Melanie C.

description:
This is a deeply satisfying curry, my friends.
A rich, thick, decadent concoction that will tantalize your taste buds and haunt your dreams.

There is a madman named Muracci in San Francisco.
His evil genius is reflected in complex curry and delicate katsu creations.

Dont f*#ck with the curry man...
author: Gracie-C Y.

description:
Another hit on Kearny! I've been to Muracci's twice now and both times it's been excellent. YES, be prepared to wait in line for awhile, and be prepared to wait longer still for your food. You will be rewarded. 

I'm not a curry guy, so I've tried the chicken katsu and teri, and both were quite delicious and cooked perfectly--and to order. For less than 10 bones you get that, some not-salty miso soup, salad (ok, a few pieces of iceberg and tomato), and some other surprise side dish. (I'm not sure if the latter changes daily or depends on what you order.) 

The staff is very friendly, although I wonder a bit if they've become overwhelmed getting out so much food! Hope they can keep it up... this place is a find.
author: Aaron L.

description: more like 3.5 star. They are pretty good but it is a bit pricey. I like the pork katsu with their hot curry. The chicken katsu or chicken curry is not as good. The chicken curry is a bit disappointing as it is only consist little bit of chopped chicken in their curry sauce.
author: fenny g.

description: Best Tonkatsu I've had in the US. It's as good as anything I've had in Japan.
author: Ralph B.

description:
Heard great things about this place and I had to try it for myself. My co-worker goes to this place ALL the time and I had to go. I had the medium spicy curry with chicken katsu over brown rice (trying to be kinda healthy!) My first bite was AMAZING! Great flavor and consistency. We also got to try the Koroke for free (my co-worker is tight with the owner) It was this fried potato thing similar to a hashbrown (mc donalds style) it was delicious. 

You gotta eat here just once!
author: J-nine I.

description:
I work right across the street from this place and it's always packed. Be prepared to wait in line for 10-20 minutes if you go anywhere near the lunch hours. The staff here are friendly and they speak Japanese to each other and sometimes to you even if you're not Japanese.

I always order the ebi fry (deep-friend battered shrimp) medium spicy curry with white rice The shrimp is consistently crispy, hot, and fresh. The curry is good but not spectacular. This will put you back almost 10 bucks.  I think it's a good place for lunch but kind of pricey for simple food that you're getting.
author: Khoi N.

description:
This is a great lunch spot.  The curry is very flavorful, slightly sweet and not too spicy.  The meat always tastes fresh, and often times they will run out of certain dishes by 1pm, so come early!  The food is always served hot in a to-go box, by a really friendly staff.  

My dish: chicken katsu with medium curry and white rice. :)
author: Fotos C.

description: Muracci's is still very consistently GOOD. Chicken Katsu was hot, moist and delicious. The hot curry sauce is still really HOT! I love it. I came in around 1pm to find a small line and many more employees. A gal took my order before I got to the register to make for a faster transaction.
