I was very pleased that I was in and out in probably less than 15 minutes.
author: Julie F.

description:
Sauce cooks twenty hours
Deep, rich, reason for long lines
Katsu perfection
author: yutai l.

description:
I think they've gotta have one of the best Japanese curries in the downtown area of San Francisco; without having to travel to Japantown, of course.

My boyfriend personally loves the curry here and hates it when it's closed on weekends. There is a wide variety of japanese curry from us to choose from. I am quite a fan of their curry ramen while my boyfriend adores their traditional tonkatsu curry or ebi fry curry. I love it how its tucked in a small corner and it is usually not so packed except for the workers doing take-aways during lunch hour. The people that work there are always so happy and warm, it makes you smile. :)
author: Denise T.

description:
You know its legit when its made by a cute Japanese grandma.  She may be small but she's quick with her movements, ladling delicious curry onto perfectly cooked rice or pulling some perfectly fried Katsu out of it's oil bath.

Hmmm... moistness.  I ABHOR dry katsu.  But this place has got it down with super moist katsu and it's NOT GREASY so that's why it gets 5 stars.  

Yeah plan for take out because this place is teeny tiny --about 10 seats on a counter and no decor of whatsoever.  

But the curry..hmmm..slightly sweet, spicy and densely flavored with all those yummy spices.

The katsudon is eggy perfectness.

AND the homemade pickles...ah...I wish I had a Japanese grandma to make some for me all the time.
author: Jae H.

description:
Quality curry here, most definitely. If you come here at any time remotely near the lunch rush, be prepared to wait through the line for your order plus waiting for order to be pushed through the kitchen. But with the wait comes high quality curry. Japanese curry isn't super spicy (it shouldn't be) but they seem to get their spice choices (medium, mild, and spicy) pretty well done (there is an actual variety there). They even serve the curry and rice separately so you mix in a much (or as little) as you like.

The only small complaint I've had is that the ebi (shrimp) fry I had with my curry once wasn't all that great (a bit overdone), but really, I should stick with the standard chicken/pork katsu with curry anyway.
author: Roland C.

description:
Japanese curry is my favorite... unfortunately, it's not anything special here. Well it's not bad either... just needs onions/potatoes and other vegies in the curry itself. Is that a Korean thing? I don't know... it's how my mom used to make it.... jeez it sounds funny when I say that... probably because she hardly ever cooked... abandoning me all day and night... that bitch.... (just kidding i love my mommy.)

Nevertheless, I like coming here. VERY friendly shopkeepers -- always say hello, good bye, thank you, etc. Also, they offer brown rice!!! I can always appreciate a place that offers brown rice!!
author: Edward Y.

description:
I had my first Muracci's experience, and I really hate to say it, but I was a little disappointed. 

With the overwhelming enthusiasm of Yelpers in my mind, I wandered in eager anticipation around Walgreens to kill a few minutes before my call-ahead order would be ready. When the my watch hit 12:17 (or rather, my cell phone..really, who still wears watches?), I walked two blocks to the narrow restaurant, which was expectedly packed with people. I gave the cashier my name, and he said "Tonkatsu?" This was the first inauspicious sign. "No, I ordered chicken katsu," I replied, while recalling in my head how I had repeated it twice in case of confusion. He rather reluctantly offered to make me chicken katsu, but I realized that I was far too hungry to wait another twenty minutes. And if Muracci's was all that it was cracked up to be, surely pork would taste good too. 

I paid for my food and hurried back to the office, where I opened my box of rice and tonkatsu and the separate container of curry sauce while wondering if the smell would waft across the office and inspire from my coworkers either jealousy or annoyance. I poured the curry sauce over my rice and tonkatsu and eagerly bit in. Initial reaction: YUM. Thirty seconds later: Hm. Good, but not amazing. The sauce was just very unimpressive. It wasn't bad at all, but it tastes more or less like the S&B curry cubes you can acquire at any Asian (or even non-Asian) grocery. The katsu was appropriately crispy, though the meat didn't taste particularly flavorful. The portions are generous, but you certainly pay for it (my total was $9.xx with tax). 

Still, it's nice to have a Japanese curry option for FiDi lunches--
author: Ada T.

description:
mMmMm...

I tried the chicken curry over rice and my bf had the beef curry; they were both super delicious. The curry was very flavorful, gave life to my tongue the instant I tasted it. Though I wish I had gone with mild instead of medium, I thought the medium was a little too spicy for me to handle. Luckily it was somewhat empty when we arrived, we didn't have to wait long for our order. The lady behind the counter was nice too. If I'm ever in this area in downtown, I will come back again.
author: Cristal G.

description:
Today I found myself craving down-and-dirty get-'er-done curry, and I didn't find it here.  I paid an amount of money in keeping with such, in an area of town where I deserved no better, and yet I still walked out with a full belly genuinely enriched with quality cookery.

I ordered the salmon curry at "medium spicy" with brown rice.  My plate arrived with an embarrassment of rice and a great quantity of rich but not overly greasy or sweet curry, and at just the right spice level (says I).

The oyaku-don brought to my partner-at-large was nothing short of a artful landscape of chicken, egg, and green onion goodness.  He seemed to think it needed salt, but my taste of it was pretty agreeable.

We both agreed that the rice was lively, the sauces balanced, and our meats unexpectedly upscale.  No "down and dirty curry" here.

Confused?  Yes, I still am (yet thoroughly delighted).

What should I have expected from a hole-in-the-wall sauce kitchen with a couple of overgrown rice cookers?  Heck, they barely have room for their handful of stools and one lowly two-top table.  Great food has come from humbler places, I'm sure, but not in SF's shopping district.

So I'm sending a shout-out to my homies over at the Journal of Marketing Research, keeping it real with research on the influences of Expectation and Revelation on the total meal experience.

Next time, I'm coming back not for a bowl of greasy curry, but for an authentically pleasing and healthy sort of meal, and I'll leave feeling not confused-yet-happy, but happy-and-fulfilled.

Shouts also to the cool old Japanese gentleman who laughed generously when I told him I learned Japanese "guruma no naka de" (in my car).

ps. to my fellow reviewers: they're not skimping on curry, they're overdoing it on rice!  ^_^
author: Naomi M.

description: Come get your Japanese Curry fix here! Good lunchtime option if you're feeling hungry. Will leave you full and needing a nap! The spicy isn't that spicy, but maybe that's because i've got some f'd up tolerance for spices...
author: Anthony N.

description:
yeah its okay, but i am not so sure what the hype is about...  its okay...  i went once and i am not so sure i will go out of my way to go back, but if someone else suggested it, i wouldnt be opposed to it. 
i ordered the chicken katsu curry.  its just OKay... not sure what's so great about it, maybe i missed something?  its fast service- but not so sure whats so special about the katsu and the curry...?
i am always about trying the place at least twice to determine whether i really like it or not, so...  i will re-review if i happen to go back...
author: Katelyn M.

description: I love this place!!! Best Katsu Curry I have found in bay area and I try to get my fix once a week.  I noticed the best  batch of curry is after lunch hour rush.  They have more time to prepare it.  I love the hot beef/vege curry pan as well.
author: Yo Y.

description:
AHHHHHHHH!!!

I just had a very satisfying meal. It was 1:30pm and in this area, there's not much left open. 

I ordered the Tonkatsu lunch special. It comes with a side salad and miso soup. I also added a extra curry sauce (mild).

The curry was delish. Luckily I ordered mild - it was enough kick. In between bites, the potato/broccoli/corn salad helped calm the spiciness (and fulfilled my veggie quota for the day). The tonkatsu wasn't dry like other places and the breading was perfect.

One thing I would change would be the brown rice. I thought that it tasted a little uncooked.

Other than that, definitely would go back and order other items and recommend this place.

Now, I'm going to take a nap. ZZZzzzzz...
author: Alice C.

description:
They get 4 stars (formerly 3.5) b/c they added fukujindsuke!

Note: STICK TO THE CURRY. 

Also, call ahead of time.

My first visit was probably when they just opened b/c like everyone else, I waited 25 min. for my food to arrive. I returned today and was impressed to find that they had smoothed things out a bit, my lunch was ready in 5 min!

So far, I've tried:

Chicken Curry - the flavors were good, but I really wish there were some veggies in there and not just a pile of chicken

Chicken Karaage - well marinated. Could have had better breading/dough (for a crispy or fluffy outside). 

Vegetable & Tofu Curry - my fav so far. Has peppers, broccoli, carrots, and tofu. I'd say "spicy" is actually more like "medium spicy". It comes with renkon chips (lotus root), which are yummy.

Oyako donburi - by far, my least favorite dish. Egg was overcooked and didn't have enough seasonings. I can make it better at home...from now on, I will stick to their specialty: curry.

Chicken Katsu Curry - No wonder why all the guys get it! It's so filling, but yummy. Despite it being fried, it's not oily, and I love the combination of the crunchiness with the curry sauce.
author: lisa m.

description: Had the pork Katsu ... very filling and tasty with the curry.  Had it medium spicy.  Next time I think I will try it with "very" spicy.  I recommend Muracci's.  My co-worker's had the beef curry.  They liked it a lot.
author: Chris C.

description: Um, YUM? Got the last serving of the evening (before close) of their beef curry plate and it was piping hot delicious. The pieces of beef literally fell apart/melted in my mouth and the curry itself had just the right amount of spice. Portions are big and great for the prices. My ONLY gripe is the location for this place, you need to walk to it. They don't have many places to sit in here but you could always get your food to go. They even have curry pan :) (deep fried panko breading with curry inside) in individually wrapped portions. If you find yourself downtown in the cold weather, definitely drop by Muracci's for some hot curry.
author: Stephanie M.

description: An authentic hole-in-the-wall curry place. It's as authentic as it gets. I'm seriously jealous that there's a place like Muracci's in SF. Seatings are limited to bar stalls and it closes at 6pm on weekdays. I wish they would open till 7-8 for dinner!
author: Pete B.

description: Probably the best place to get lunch at a Japanese place in the Financial District. It tends to get crowded at times so you'll be waiting for an order you placed for at least 20 minutes. Let's just say my tolerance for spiciness in food has gone up ever since i had Korean food so even the hot curry at this restaurant really isn't hot to me. Still really good though. Plus the Hamberg Steak lunch special really hit the spot in terms of lunch. It's a little bit pricey to go everyday for lunch here, but sometimes it worth taking a hit on the wallet for some quality food.
author: Gerard Y.

description: I tried their Katsudon today!  (One of my favorite menu for lunch) Even though their specialty is Curry, I was not disappointed.  Freshly fried pork cutlets surrounded by soft cooked eggs with green onion over rice.  Served with Fukujinzuke (see below)
author: Chie J.

description:
All I know is that I sometimes wake up angling for their katsu curry. It's pretty inexpensive, is a big big portion, and is very delicious. You can get it with white or brown rice (although it's just not the same with brown rice.) And I like the people there. Nice polite Japanese people. 'Mild, medium or spicy?' 

Why are those crunchy red things on the curry so good? Why aren't you open on weeknights after work? Why aren't you open on weekends? Why isn't my life filled with more meaning and fulfillment?
author: D'arcy N.

description:
I really liked this place!  I read up on it before I went and ended up getting the #3.  It was dreamy, and fried and a total gut bomb...but the curry was amazing!  I ordered the side of veggies....two flowers a broccoli and a couple carrot slices does not constitute a 'side of veggies'!!  

That is my only compliant - other than that, this place is great!
author: Megan H.

description: The curry is exactly what you would expect.  The chicken of the chicken katsu fame was panko crispy on the outside, and decently moist on the inside.  Just that alone would give this place 3 stars, but it gets 1 extra star for the DELICIOUS crispy, chewy, fluffy, perfectly seasoned curry pan (curry bread, basically a curry hot pocket crusted in panko)..... and the cute japanese clientele.
author: eric w.

description:
Love the homemade curry! The curry is so fresh and, the quality of the ingredients are above average. You can definitely tell by the non-existent after taste.

Muracci's packages the curry in a separate to-go container. And when you get back to the office, you can reel in excitement of pouring just the right amount of curry on your brown or white rice and tonkatsu and then drinking down the rest by itself. I was just kidding about the last part.

They have various flavors of individually packaged roll cakes that look fairly tempting too. Next time.

If I worked closer to Kearny, this place would definitely be a weekly work lunch place.
author: Cathy H.

description: Man, the food at this place is really good! I'd never have Japanese curry before coming here, but damn did I enjoy it. The place is really small and get's super packed during the lunch hour, though. You can wait 10-15 min for your food after you order...so don't come here if you're in a hurry. But DO come here if you want a damn good lunch spot. I last had the chicken katsu curry (hot), and def recommend it.
author: Ian C.

description:
As a disclosure, I love Japanese curry.  Ok, now that I've gotten that out of the way, I must say this place is pretty awesome.  I had the medium spice katsu curry with white rice, and the curry had a pleasantly surprising spicy kick to it, and the amount of food was plentiful.  It had a home cooked meal side to it which made it all that much better.  

I also had couldn't resist but get a taro roll cake, and it was the best roll cakes I've had in the city.  I can't imagine it being very healthy, but the mix of buttery roll, mocha, and vanilla crème was uber delicious.

A couple cons were the lack of seats inside the restaurant (I would actually strongly advise planning taking it to go and eating it somewhere else, perhaps at St. Mark's Sq nearby) and the price which I thought was just a bit high.  I plan on being back and trying some of the other dishes.
author: Daniel L.

description: The place is usually packed..well, at least when I go to get lunch at around noon.  It's a small place that can seat maybe 15 or so.  The enviroment is very "to-go" only, but the food is worth the wait and the crowd.  They have brown rice with your curry choice, which is always a good option to have.  For lunch, I had beef curry over rice, which has a nice flavor to it.  The only down side is the lack of meat.  It seemed like curry sauce over rice than beef curry.  Perhaps I'll try the chicken next time, since it was their specialty.
author: Pace L.

description:
This is a really great japanese curry place for lunch downtown. The wait during lunch is Looongg, and the place has very few stools to sit on. But it's worth the wait when you're really craving curry.

Get the beef, salmon or katsu dishes. Their beef is very crisp on the outside and tender inside, from some frying after a slow stew. The salmon is well cooked and the curry, EXTREMELY flavorful. 

For ramen lovers, my staple is beef ramen with egg. The ramen can be hard to eat since the curry sauce is so thick and the ramen just soaks it all up. I usually ask them to prepare the ramen/curry seperately so I can eat it fresh at my desk. Oh they have a total of like two tables to eat, so don't plan on sitting down there.

They also have a dish of the day, of which they make 15 meals or so of. But you have to come in early to get them!
author: Marv G.

description:
Mmmm. Really yummy curry. We got our orders to go... and it was slightly difficult giving my order over the phone... and they were out of katsu chicken!!! 

Overall still really satisfying curry, loved that they give you picked vegetables on the side, the people who work there were super sweet, and all the to-go containers were so neatly packaged!!
author: Sandy K.

description: Came here on my first day of work in the city as I roamed the streets of the Financial District indecisive of what I wanted for lunch until I saw the sign for Japanese curry, something I'd never had apart from the mediocre boil in the bag stuff I picked up a few times in Japantown. This place though was quite tasty: crispy pork cutlet, rice (I chose brown) all bathed in curry sauce, which was a tad mild for me even though I requested hot, but perhaps I'm just used to the fiery nature of Thai and Indian curries. While it's not the cheapest place to grab lunch around, the portions are large enough to feed 2 unless you're ravenously hungry and asking for food coma later on.
author: Adrian W.

description:
This is my absolute favorite lunch spot in FiDi.  Katsu don with egg--YUM!  And the couple that runs the place is super cute and friendly.

Suggestion: Call in ahead of time because the lines and wait time are long.  I called in at 11:30AM and they answered right away.
author: Janice Y.

description:
Well, thanks to the other yelpers, we went prepared (i.e. early, and with our order phoned in). All three of us opted for the Katsu curry (med) with extra veggies and spinach. The curry was flavorful and pleasantly spicy (heat, but no pain--mebbe next time I'll opt for hot), and the katsu was crispy, and the pork was ok (not too dry, but not super flavorful). The pickles were fab (I do love my pickles) and the wait was very brief and painless. 

Definitely worth a return visit. Not cheap (with drinks and our extra veggies, we plunked down $12 each), but good splurgy lunch eats on a gorgeous Friday.
author: eliza w.

description:
Fabulous Japanese curry - worth the wait! Prices are very reasonable.  They have a fun website that shows their special as well as a cute blog.
Seating is tight; most clients get the food to go.
I prefer the curry tonkatsu (breaded pork) the most... and only the spiciest! Thankfully they give the curry sauce on the side.  I recommend the vegetable *and* cheese toppings.  Yes, cheese with the curry - it's really good, as well as whacky.
Yum.  Can't wait to return.
author: Michael S.

description:
I'd like to give negative 500 stars for this place.  My boss and I need a quick lunch the other day and so we've seen this place - decide to walk over.  This is what happens:

-we walk 10 mins to get there 
-we wait in line for 15 mins to order
-we wait another 15 mins to get the food
- we walk 10 mins to get back to the office

Outcome: I paid $7.54 for brown rice, two pieces of cabbage and curry - there was no tofu/veggies like I ordered.  My boss suffered the same fate. 

Advice: If you're going to have a lunch-heavy restaurant in the fi-di, get your standard operations right and THEN open.
author: Bhumika K.

description:
Had a lunch date with Mr. DJ who works in the FiDi area.  Him and his co-workers frequent this place and I've heard so much about it...I was excited to finally try it out.  We got there a bit before it opened to avoid the crowds.  I looked at the menu and wasn't really impressed initially.  I mean we've all had chicken katsu before...what's the big deal.  

The place opened and we ordered first.  As we waited for our meal, the place filled up in 2 secs.  No joke.  

The food was super yummy!  In a comfort food type of way.  I got the chicken katsu with the curry.  So simple yet so awesome.  I was really surprised.  

The food came quickly; staff is friendly  and efficient.  

The food was so good that I don't really care to visit any other place for awhile when it comes to a lunchdate in the FiDi with Mr. DJ.  Can't wait to try the other stuff on the menu.
author: Tina M.

description:
I was walking around the FiDi starving my ass off and kept finding that everything was closed, until I came upon this shop. I thought, "I am so hungry anything will taste amazing."

WRONG! I got the chicken teriyaki and received the most unappetizing plate of food I've set my eyes on. When I order chicken teriyaki, I expect grilled chicken with thick delicious teriyaki sauce. What I got instead was extremely pale, shriveled up, fake looking chicken with watery soy sauce on top. It came with rice, salad, and a chunk of mashed potato that was mixed corn and brocolli. 

I thought, "it may taste better than it looks!" WISHFUL THINKING. The chicken was so dry that it dried up my mouth as I ate it. The potato thing tasted gross and the salad had THE worst Asian sesame dressing ever. I couldn't even bring myself to finish half of it and threw the rest away. Save yourself ten dollars and disappointment and just keep walking away.

Tallulah's Verdict: HATE IT!
author: Tallulah J.

description: Great sauce! Great value for money! Too bad I missed out on the Beef Tongue Curry weekly special. This place needs more space.
author: Raymond V.

description:
I had Muracci's the other day. I shouldn't have. But I hadn't had for a while. And I missed the curry.

I didn't get the curry though. I got the Katsu Donburi. Which was awesome. But would've been more awesome with some curry. And the only reason why I didn't want to get curry was cus I didn't want the smell of curry to stick around in the office. Thought my coworkers would mind.

Forget them next time. I want the curry dammittttt.
author: Sandy L.

description:
I LOVE MURACCI's! The curry here is so good. Actually, Japanese curry is good. Period.

I ordered a Chicken Katsu and it was so good. The mix of curry and Chicken Katsu was delicious. The pickled cabbage on the side was also nice. I usually go after the lunch rush (thank god). I would hate standing in line that goes out the store!
author: Wilson Z.

description: I seriously questioned this place but finally tried it and wow, I really liked my katsu curry! The curry could've been thicker and had some vegetables...but the katsu! So juicy, lean, hot and fresh.
author: Nicole L.

description:
I like this curry better than Delica rf-1's and know where to go now when I need a curry fix by work. But, it was not the best, I've had.... 

I had the katsu curry and the pork chop was great! A lot of places deep fry their pork chops too long making it drier and tougher than leather, but they made it just right! It was juicy in the center! Hats off to fryer!

The curry came in a little cup, so your rice won't be all mushy which is a nice touch. It was a little bit weird though, I saw that they had plates, but they gave us our food in containers even when we said it was for here... odd... I'm NOT THAT down with eating outta tupperware/boxes if I don't have to... 

Oh and you get a choice of brown or white rice, how cool is that? Awesome, awesome, I say!!
author: Lester L.

description:
Yep, still dee-licious. 

I had the Chicken & Vegetable Curry Ramen today and it was so satisfying. Perfect ramen noodles in a puddle of medium spicy curry soup, with seasoned chicken, broccoli, & carrots. Mmmmm... My only complaint would be that I wish there had been slightly more soup because my ramen was so piping hot that I could not devour it the way I wanted to and by the time I had finished, most of the soup had been absorbed by the noodles. 

Also, the wait for the food here is still incredibly long because there are so many people ordering and 2 people cooking in their tiny kitchen...probably took something like 15-20 minutes for me to get my lunch, even after the lunch rush had passed. Definitely phone ahead and take your order to go.

Magically, my hangover from last night's Yelp Elite event was temporarily cured. :)
author: Felicia C.

description:
try it once and you develop an addiction that must be fed.  our office is nearby and at this point 1/3 of the office will do a group order - if they closed it would impact productivity and company morale.
Chicken curry and the katsu rock - if you have a group order or want to go with something other than the mild curry you should call in advance.
author: Eric G.

description:
Three words: Chicken katsu curry!!!!  

It was delicious...  They give you their homemade curry sauce in a separate plastic container, which I thought was great...  My katsu didn't get all soggy.  Get the Hot (spicy) curry, as it's only overwhelming if you pour all of it on your rice/chicken at once.  They also give you some of their pickled cabbage and pickled daikon, which were pretty good, and a healthy portion of rice.  I liked that you could taste the cloves in the cabbage...  And it was a nice contrast with the spicy curry.  $8.50.

I've also tried the korokke (croquette), which is a deep fried mashed potato/curry flavored mix, which was awesome.  (Not spicy)  For only $1.50.

They don't have very much seating here if you are planning to eat in (only about 8 stools) so, it's best to call in your order for pick up.  And when I went, there were about 7 other people waiting for/ordering their food...  So, I believe it's always busy around 2pm-ish...  

The wait staff is very friendly, too...  I was thanked about 3 times on my way out.  Super nice.  



LOVE!
author: nancy f.

description:
By far the best curry in SF, reminds me of home. The katsu is always cooked perfect, thick and juicy, and it's huge!  I like my curry spicy and they give it the right amount of heat without being overly spicy. 

It's a small place so if you plan to dine-in during the peak lunch hour, good luck.  I like to get there around 1:30 when it's not as busy and there's usually some seats.  I've also ordered take out a few times for my group and have had no problems getting it during the peak lunch time.
author: danny m.

description:
Yummmmmmmmmmmmmmm.  The fact that a Japanese curry restaurant is open in the FiDi is amazing.  They make good curry at a good price, but not in a hurry.  Prepare to wait and wait and wait and wait.   I'm not sure how long they will or can continue the we make your order fresh thing. 

*** Call ahead and plan to wait 10-15 minutes in line to get to the register to pay (at least during the 12PM rush). ***
author: Diana M.

description: Can't complain with a simple, yet, delicious lunch.  #16 on the 7x7 list, I got the spicy katsu curry.  The best things about this dish are the fact that the pork wasn't dry and the batter wasn't thick at all.  To top it off, when you order spicy, you get decently spicy!  You get some cabbage and pickled veggies along with it, but honestly, you don't really need anything else.
author: Jeff N.

description:
I've never had Japanese curry before, but this was great! I love regular curry and while it always tastes good over rice, I love noodles even more. I got the chicken and vegetable curry soup over Udon noodles. It was a thick broth, so not too much like soup, huge pieces of chicken and big fresh vegetables. I asked for it 'hot' but it still could have been even hotter so I'll try to push it next time.

I also got a croquette as they had just brought out a fresh batch. While good, I know this can't be good for you, so now that I've had it, I probably won't go for it again. I'll definitely be back to try some of their more traditional dishes as well.

Service is excellent, quickly take your order and even though food is made fresh to order, it comes out quickly. While not overly friendly, they're efficient and nice enough. I'll definitely add this to my monthly rotation.
author: Lauren M.

description: We came around 1:30 and waited in a short line. The curry it self is good but nothing spectacular about it. Their curry korokke is deffo worth trying!
author: Anna S.

description: Came here on a Tuesday at 12:10 and the line was right outside the door, not too bad. It took us about 15-20 mins from the time we arrived to when we got our food. I am not a Japanese curry lover or expert but compared to what I have had this was pretty good. My husband, who loves Japanese curry, thought it was very good. Not as great as his mom's but good for outside cooking. I got the chicken katsu and he got the pork katsu. Both were delicious but we both preferred the pork more. It was juicier and tastier than the chicken. I liked how there was an option of brown or white rice for no additional charge. We were able to grab two stools in the crowded restaurant and ate there. I will definitely be back.  ~$21 for our two meals.
author: Bling L.

description:
Went to this place today for lunch.  Finally an non-American influenced Japanese take out.  It's a hole in the wall, so easily missed, but oh my what a gem!  Their curries are so delicious and flavorful.  They simmer their curries for 2 days to bring in the flavor.  I tried the beef curry (hot spicy) and my friends tried the karage (fried chicken) and the deep fried mix curry (salmon, shrimp, katsu, beef).  

My favorite was the karage.  It was so juicy and the batter was perfect.  The beef curry was ok, a little on the tougher side, but my friend's deep fried mix was delicious and it was quite a lot of food.  

The curry comes in a separate tub in order to prevent the rice from being soggy.  Smart.  Wait is a little long, but worth it.  

I definitely will come back and try more variations of curry dishes.  Yay!
author: Yun W.

description:
Finally a good Japanese curry house in San Francisco and I'm lucky to work nearby~!

But now that the word is out and that everything remotely decent ends up in Yelp, it's packed with people and many people with weird obnoxious questions, requests, substitutions, etc. Welcome to the Financial District, Muracci~! 

I just hope that the folks from Japan's own Koko Ichibanya Curry House realize how much potential they'd have if they were to open a few locations in San Francisco. 

Yay for curry. oh~ and also, if you like spicy japanese curry they can take it pretty up there. love it~
author: Tomas V.

description:
A couple weeks ago a friend of mine mentioned Japanese Curry. I was like, "what are you talking about? There is no Japanese curry. There's Indian curry and Thai curry but I've never seen Japanese curry on the menu." I was told I was wrong and that I should try Muracci's. So, because I tend to go a little overboard with things, I asked some people in my office if they were interested in having Japanese curry for lunch on Friday. 23 people said yes and gave me their orders including brown or white rice, mild, hot, spicy and their entrée. The most poplar was #3, the Katsu Curry ($8.50). 

Muracci's is very small so I faxed a list of all of our orders and the recipient's name the night before. They called me five minutes later and asked for my credit card. The next day we showed up at the allotted time, grabbed our four bags of curry and brought them back to the office. Muracci's had actually taken a pen and written everyone's names on each of their meals.

The food was great.  Each entrée comes with rice and curry on the side that you get to put over your meal yourself. The #3 was definitely a hit and everyone loved it, including me. I can't wait to go back.  I just wish the restaurant was bigger so I could eat there instead of taking it to go.
author: Jackie G.

description: This is the Japanese Curry equivalent of Seinfeld's soup nazi.  Long line everyday lunch, for fantastic katsu curry!
author: Jeffrey H.

description: My favorite comfort food for lunch. Whenever i am feeling blue, I can count on their delicious secret curry sauce to pick me up! There cake rolls are pretty good too!
author: Angela J.

description: probably the best curry i've tried in the wonderful city of San Francisco. it's a bit far from where i live but i was able to avoid the lines by getting there around 11:40. my only complaint about this place is that they could really give out BIGGER portion for the price they charge. other than that, this place is great.
author: Louis O.

description: The food is good, but the portions are small.  Jappacurry is much better, cheaper and it has larger portions.
author: M O.

description:
I think they changed the meat that they use for Tonkatsu. The last 2 times, Tonkatsu was not as good as it used to be. I think they changed from "Hire" to something cheaper... Anyway, now I am getting Chicken Katsu instead of Tonkatsu.

I still like this place.
author: Wakaknee J.

description:
(+)
Great taste, cooked to order - I order their katsu extra spicy and they will give you extra curry if you ask for it. They do not disappoint on portion sizes.

(-)
Japanese-style space management (crowded) and the often lengthy wait can be excruciating only because you're being kept from your delicious lunch.
author: Brian D.

description:
Yum!! Used to work very close to here but not anymore. Too bad for me. Their curry is very good, but unfortunately I've been making this for years and it can definitely be better.

However, with that being said, it is one of the best I've had out at a restaurant. They don't use the cube that's for sure :) They have great selection, put the curry on the side, and fry meats to perfection. Add vegetables for sure, .75 is worth it. AND, there is a ton of rice. I usually would make two meals out of one order.

What else can I say? YOU CANNOT be in a rush, although the line moves pretty quick. Always busy, always tasy, and very consistent. YUM!!!
author: David M.

description:
Best Japanese Curry outside Japan!

This is one of the best places for curry hands down.  Ever since trying the Japanese chain restaurant, CoCo Ichibanya Curry House, I have been on a mission to find a good curry house in the States.  Muracci's definetly fits the bill.  

This afternoon, I had the traditional beef curry with white rice.  The menu states that the curry is prepared for 2 days to bring out the flavor.  Welcome to flavor country!  The curry was not too spicy and full of taste.  The only drawback was that there could have been more beef.

When going to a curry house, I don't expect much in terms of ambiance.  However, the line snaking past the door was a little annoying.  In addition, the wait after the order was like kicking a man while he's down.  Even so, the curry was worth the wait.  If you're in a hurry, I wouldn't recommend this restaurant.  Hopefully they'll find a way to control the crowds as more people eat there.
author: T Y.

description:
I had the pork donburi with brown rice and am slapping myself because it sounds like curry was the item to get. 

Pork was tender and nicely fried and the bowl overall was hearty enough to fill my substantial hunger. The eggs and green onions were tasty, but some of my egg white was a little bit runny. That's not a deal-breaker for me, but it's just a heads up if you are weary of uncooked eggs. The rice was scalding hot when the dish came out, a sign of prompt and perhaps overenthusiastic service. It took several minutes for the dish to cool down and in the meantime I was gulping water to compensate. 

This is a small place that definitely caters to the eat-on-the-go working crowd, so it gets cramped when all ten or so seats are filled and several more are waiting in line. The service is friendly as mentioned before. I just wish my food was just a bit more evenly cooked. Will have to try a curry dish next time.
author: Kevin L.

description: Delicious curry and katsudon. One of those places I could eat at every day. The people are really nice, friendly and slow (in a good way) despite the lunchtime crunch. They have two tiny tables so you can't really eat in but at work, we usually buy take-out and eat in Union Square park.
author: Abi R.

description:
This has become a lunchtime staple in my office though I don't go as often as my coworkers because the wait is a bit much and I've had my order messed up a couple of times. 

I think we've determined that the best thing to do is place an order via fax (we have the order forms regularly available) and then walk over a pick up about 40 minutes later. 

This place is tiny and not my favorite place to dine, but there is some counter seating available. 

In terms of food, my favorite is the Donburi (I get the chicken with egg bowl) and people fight for the daily special of which there are allegedly only 15 servings per day. And of course, the curry is great. I don't like my food super spicy so I like that you can indicate desired level of spiciness.
author: Alexis W.

description: Go after 1pm if you don't want to wait outside the door.  But make sure you do go b/c it is GOOD!  It is the quintessential japanese curry place, stocked w/ japanese soft drinks and the soft roll-cakes too. A total mom&pop in a tiny closet, they are sweet sweet people churning out FRESHLY fried pork cutlet - YUM!  Get the brown rice if you want to feel healthier.  You can call ahead too.
author: Barndi K.

description:
The best Japanese-style curry AND the best ton katsu I've ever had in my life!

Also highly recommend their donburi!

They get really busy around lunch time but it's worth the wait and then some. I actually walk 15-20 minutes from where I work just to eat at this joint. It's like a little piece of heaven on Kearny St.

What can I say, I absolutely love this place!
author: Brandon Y.

description:
WOW WOW WEEE WOW. 
seriously, the best japanese curry i've had. The whole time my friend and i were eating we had smiles on our faces cause it was THAT GOOD.
I decided to get the chicken & vegetable curry ramen...and let me just tell you they gave the right amount of ramen noodles, chicken, and veggies. The chicken was tender and perfectly cooked and so were the veggies (not too mushy or too hard). 

My friend got the katsu curry and it was so good! i'm definitely getting that dish next time. the pork was cooked perfectly with the the right amount of breading. ahhhhhh my mouth is watering just talking about it!

With the place being small, it's kind of a downside, but i actually didn't mind...it just wouldn't be great with a lot of people. I came after the lunch rush so i didn't have to wait long for my food...i wouldn't even want to see how busy this place gets during lunch...but i wouldn't blame them! it's uber delicious. 

AND! the owner was so cute! she gave us a letter opener with their name on it. it was a present for there one year anniversary. ISN'T THAT JUST THE CUTEST? 

yup yup..i'm definitely going back.
author: Suzan L.

description: I ordered the pork cutlet curry with a medium heat.  Wow, the curry was still able to make me sweat but in a good way.  The pickled vegetables were very tasty and the pork cutlet was delicious.  A great meal to have on a normal overcast and cold SF day.
author: David L.

description:
This place is just alright. I've had better, tastier curry.

It's a tiny tiny place, mostly take-out.
I got the veggie and tofu curry - medium spicy. It wasn't spicy at all.

You get a choice of white rice or brown rice. The portions are good. 
Decent place, not stellar.
author: Chili B.

description:
40 minute wait! Ridiculous! 

*Will update after I devour this food*

Ok, ok I'm done eating. Now how do I begin my review for Muracci's? Let's just say if today was not their first day of operations, I would have given this place just one measly star. A person with a 30 minute lunch, should not have to wait 45 minutes for PRE-MADE curry! But I will cut them some slack on their first day. 

Muracci's is a cute little whole in the wall - one table for two and a few stools along the wall. For the grand opening, seems like they had a lot of drop-ins from FiDi-ites looking for a good place to eat. Mr. Mike and I arrived at Muracci's and placed 2 orders of curry at 12:44pm. We waited, waited, and waited some more. We did not leave until 1:20pm. Every time they called out an order,  with bright and hopeful eyes we watched...thinking it would be ours. But no..it was not until we asked them how much longer for our curry that they finally noticed our lonely ignored order slip. 

As for the curry, not too shabby. I ordered the chicken katsu curry (medium spicy) with white rice. Not worth the 40 minute wait, but I am willing to go back and try more. The taste reminded me of packaged boil-it-yourself curry from the Korean supermarkets, but those taste pretty good so I'm NOT complaining. The only thing - for $8.50, they could have given more chicken katsu for the large amount of curry they give you.

Even though Muracci's made me wait a very, very long time, their friendly staff and yummy curry makes it hard for me to dislike this cute little hole in the wall. I wish them the best of  luck. Foodies are hard to please! =)

Recommendations: 
Chicken Katsu Curry 
Call in your order in advance, so you can pick up and GO!
author: Lisa T.

description: Japanese comfort food? For lunch in the Fidi??? Vegetable curry has been my go-to item on the menu. I don't like fried chicken (or anything else) so I haven't tried the famous katsu curry. I really should branch out a bit...go early or after 1, otherwise there will be a wait!
author: Sara P.

description: I love this place! The curry they have is always on point and the katsu or fried chicken breast is amazing. If you like Japanese curry, you will love this place. They also have a curry pan, which reminds me of a fried japanese taco pocket.
author: Elliot T.

description: I really do miss being able to get Japanese curry with the snap of a finger where I grew up. So, it's for that reason that, for me, the extra ingredient in Muracci's is yearning with a dash of nostalge. Nothing wildly amazing about this place, but such is the case with most Japanese curry. Generally, I'll get the chicken katsu curry with brown rice... although, now that I think of it, I'd just as soon get the pork katsu... the texture is about the same. The curry is nice and savory with as much heat as you like, although, JCurr has never been renowned for bringing the thunder. Call that bad boy in because that line will be out the door come lunch.
author: Roy M.

description: Trust me, if you are japanese and know about the japanese curry, you won't enjoy this place at all. Very nice owner though. It is too expensive and very poor taste & quality. I don't understand how they make it so bad. Such a easy dish to make.
author: Honey B.

description:
I guess I don't need to write much about this place and agree that they have really good curry katsu anything. Their brown rice option is great since it reminds me to be healthier and that there is another type of rice other than white haha...

I'll come back again on my next SF lunch visit.
author: Gerard L.

description: Pretty delicious curry. I ordered the chicken katsu curry (medium spicy). Big portions. One drawback is the seating. Wished there was more available and you weren't cramped up against a wall.
author: Lisa C.

description:
I usually do not like Japanese curry, but upon their being reviewed as Bargain Bite by the Chronicle, I decided to make an exception and give it a try.  Verdict: it does not disappoint.  I tried the tonkatsu curry on one visit and I tried the oyako donburi on a subsequent visit.

There's a bit of smokiness in the curry, but not overpowering.  The degree of spiciness definitely uses the Asian standard.  No offense to the white folks out there, but *your* spicy is bland to us...  So go ahead order the "medium", you will get a medium kick.  I have yet to try the ultra spicy.., but one of these days.

I like the option for brown rice.  Makes me feel better about myself and my digestion.  Although the spicy may loosen up the colon too anyway.  Uber long lines at lunch, but you can call ahead.  Honestly, it's not overrated.  It's downright good stuff.
author: Yohanna B.

description: This is my second time eating Katsu Curry over brown rice. It's good and well portioned which I could easily split it into two meals. I would get it again but would like to explore the rest of the menu sometime.
author: Jennifer D.

description: Katsu Curry: The Katsu isn't that great. Maybe because I expected to much from it from the glowing reviews on Yelp and also since it was on the SF 100 Big Eats list. The curry was really good though. I ordered extra spicy. The place was pretty quick with my order, but I think it's because I beat the huge crowd that came after me. The man taking the order was very nice and comical. This place really is owned by Japanese people, too.
author: Vera W.

description:
It's a convenient but pretty crowded lunch spot.  I ordered the pork katsu with vegetables on brown rice, to go; this meant the curry was in a separate container to be used as I liked it.  I typically don't drench my food in sauce, so I used the curry pretty sparingly (in the beginning).  

Here's the deal.  The pork was a bit over-fried for my tastes (and greasy), and was rather tough.  There was a gigantic fat pad running about halfway through my cutlet which I won't eat (but I do know people who love stuff like that).  The rice was dry and pretty darn flavorless for brown rice.  The veggies in my curry were simply limp broccoli and carrots.

However, the curry sauce itself was VERY good.  It took me about 3/4 the way through the meal to just dunk whatever bite I had in my curry sauce and then I actually enjoyed it.  But overall, not worth it.
author: Lisa T.

description:
Best curry inf SF!
Don't listen to the people that say that it's like the instant curry you can buy at asian markets. There's no comparison. Those people are just bitter that the wait time is too long during the lunch rush, that's all.
author: George M.

description: I read the reviews and have been here 3x already yes it's that good - chicken katsu and brown rice medium spicy curry !
author: lyn m.

description: Best tonkatsu in town! But the spicy levels aren't consistent, so it's a surprise every time. Also I would rather have a smaller rice portion and a bigger side of salad/veggies.
author: exploradare G.

description:
They do business right!  While waiting in line, a guy came to take our order, so that when we got to the register, all we had to do was pay and wait a few seconds because we ordered the Express curry to go!  Way to cater to the lunch rush!

And if you are super hungry, there are Curry Puffs right there just before the register, so if you don't get the Express curry and have to wait a few minutes, you can munch on that while waiting.  Best eat those curry puffs hot anyway.  :)

The Express curry was beef or chicken, white rice or brown rice.  I had the beef curry w/white rice ... Yummy!  It even had the red tsukemono (forgot the name of it) which I love too.

The guy who took the order was nice, the girl who rang us up was nice ... they were crazy busy during this lunch rush, but they were still nice!  I can't emphasize enough how much good service means to me!  It's almost everything... 

I have nothing negative to say about this place.  Go Muracci's!!!
author: Nancy S.

description: Mmmm what can I say, tonkatsu curry definitely hit the spot. The crunchy perfection of the crust meeting the delicious curry sauce with ginger and lettuce on the side = euphoria. Definitely worth coming here, and I have tried my fair share of tonkatsu. They do it well here :)
author: Erelyn A.

description: Japanese Curry?  It reminds me of the homemade Japanese curry that my mom used to make me when she used to 'change it up' from the Korean food and the few American foods she used to make me at home.  They have an excellent combo plate with Chicken katsu.  It is really popular though, and I heard much about it, and it was able to live up to the hype a bit.
author: Min P.

description:
Healthy, fast, and good! Glad to find some comfort-food curry close to my office! Today I tried the fried salmon curry (hot), which was a lot better than I thought it would be. I've tried fried salmon in the past and wasn't a huge fan, but this was fresh and crispy, plus it was made better by adding curry. I didn't think the "hot" was terribly hot, but it did pack at least some punch.

They ran out of tofu & veggie curry by about 12:15, so I suggest getting there early if you want veggie curry.
author: Phil K.

description: I'm a fan. I got to try Maracci's with some friends the other day and it was as good as it's been billed. The curry was extra spicy and came in a rather generous portion. I probably wouldn't do brown rice again because the texture doesn't compliment well with Japanese curry. Make sure you call ahead and order it to go.
author: Cristofer P.

description: This place was decent. The 'medium' was actually really spicy.
author: Grant M.

description:
Muracci!!! YOU out of all places! I dislike curry almost all of my life until I've met you. After having their Chicken Katsu curry I was in a curry rampage for the whole month!

5+ stars for your curry!
-1 star for being slow
-1 star b/c you closed at 6 and don't open on the weekend

How do I even get a bite out of your curry now? It would be nice if people stop going here on the weekdays until they change their hours, but I'm afraid I don't see that happening soon.
author: Justin L.

description:
Japanese curry? Not Indian & Not Thai, you heard it right, Japanese.

We had about 15 people who were interested at work, so we faxed in our order the day before. Two people went and picked up the food, which was ready, when they arrived. They even labeled all of the boxes & plastic containers with our names (we put our names on the list that was faxed in)!

I ordered the chicken curry (Hot) with brown rice. I was not impressed with the chicken that was in the curry, it definitely was not white meat. The curry had a good flavor (had a lot of Cumin in it) and it tasted like my mom's version of "Indian curry", maybe she should re-name it "Japanese Curry"! The brown rice was good. Overall I was satisfied for a fairly cheap take-out ($9) lunch during the work week. I wish I would have split it with someone, it was pretty large.
author: Elaine S.

description:
My experience was a rather odd combination. I went with a colleague around noon. After waiting in line for a good half hour, we finally got our food and took it back to our office. Expecting one katsu curry and one chicken curry, both with spinach, we found the katsu curry was fine, but the chicken was absent from my curry. We thought it was in the stew (which it is supposed to be), but it wasn't. So I went back there after work and asked about it and the owner promptly offered to refund my money. I declined, but the pure fact that the owners want to keep their customers happy was such a refreshing surprise!

Oh, and by the way, the curry sauce straight up over rice, sans chicken, is still AWESOME. Add a little katsu (fried pork) and it tastes even better. The katsu was crispy on the outside, flavorful on its own, and still tender inside. Yum.

The cocoa cake was nothing special but you need to keep your eye on the ball here. The curry is delicious. I'm not a spicy fan so the mild kept me happy. Just remember, don't come during the noon hour or you'll be waiting forever. I think you can order in advance, but I haven't yet done this. After such service and yummy food, I'll definitely be trying it at some point!
author: Aaron F.

description:
Hmmm, where can I eat today?  - that's always the question during the work week.  

I want something healthy, fast and good.  So I walked by Muracci's everyday and finally decided to try their curry.  

So allow me share my experience...

The wait was super long...since they cook each and every dish fresh!  Ok, I can appreciate that...so when I get to the cash register, I found out that you can order ahead of time by going to their website, printing out the order form and faxing it over with a pick up time!  *sweet*

Once I had a chance to settle down and start eating...I can see why this place is so awesome.  The food is fresh, I got the Chicken Curry with brown rice and everything was just NICE. Chicken was well cooked, (juicy) and the curry had a lot of flavors and it wasn't  "fake powdery" tasting so you know they went to great lengths to cook the curry.  

I love that this meal is as healthy as it can get and the folks are authentic and keeping true to making a real Japanese dish.  

Yummy and will come back whenever I can.  Speaking of which...let me just fax over my order right now...Katsu Curry...yummm
author: Alice H.

description: This is fine katsu curry, but nothing special. Probably gets a bump in ratings because of its location. It's good. Not that awesome, though.
author: Brian C.

description: I can't get enough of Muracci's chicken katsu curry, and do a star trek from my Civic Center office to this financial district eatery.  The curry is like gravy!  Long lines and limited seating, but I've never had a problem snagging a counter seat.  This is closed early, so not really a dinner option, but I'll try to recreate the katsu curry tonight with the Golden Curry packets.  My bf is pounding the chicken breasts as I write this and breading with panko bread crumbs...Will be a yummy, if not completely true to Murraci's, but close to it!
author: Lisa C.

description:
Very solid Japanese curry.  Haven't had better Japanese curry in San Francisco so I give it up to Muracci's.  I find it a bit odd that such a good Japanese curry place resides in the financial district vs. being in Japan town.  Although I first thought it was going to be a big fish in a small pond (trying to be the Japanese curry in the middle of a non-curry area because it was too scared to be compared to the other Japan town joints?) it turned out that Muracci's is the real deal.  It is a big fish in a big pond, it just happens to be in the middle of the financial district and far away from any competitors.  It's a very small place that doesn't have any big signs so make sure you don't miss it.

I got the katsu curry (hot) and was very happy with what I got.  I agree with others when they say that the person taking my order was a bit hard to understand but nevertheless, my order came out perfectly. 

I also got a korokke (deep fried croquette style appetizer) and that was amazing to start off the meal.  I didn't end up eating in because there were only 4 stools that were taken up so I just took it back to work and ate it there. 

People were nice and the curry was perfect.  Very very good and they also gave big portions so I was happy about that as well.  Definitely a place to go if you're craving Japanese curry or if you just want to try something different.  

Only downside is this place has the shortest operating hours out there (M-Th 11AM-6PM; F 11AM - 5PM) so I can't have it during the weekends. 


Try it out and you will be pleasantly surprised.
author: Paul C.

description: Good curry, but not the best.  I guess there aren't that many curry houses in SF.  Their tonkatsu is good because the pork is lean and thick.  I like how they have creative dishes and lots of options.  That said, I can make a mean curry!
author: Jessica T.

description:
I finally managed to sneak away from my workplace in South SF and join my boyfriend in SF's financial district to try Muracci's.  We've been looking forward to going since the first couple of yelp reviews were posted.  Now, it looks like Muracci's is quite well known.

1) The place is pretty camouflaged and unassuming.  We spent 20 minutes looking for it!  There isn't a big sign like the other nearby restos (Banana House, Murphy's Irish Pub....for example) For those that are first timers it is located closer to the corner of BUSH and Kearny than pine.  In fact, it is right next door the  Cinta Aveda Institute and has a tan/beige facade.

2) The lines can grow pretty long.

3) If you are in a hurry, order the EXPRESS curry.  The boyfriend and I ordered the Chicken Katsu curry and it took about 15 minutes.

4) For most Asians, HOT translates to eh...spicy.  It will make your nose run.

5) it is pretty cheap.  I think that the boyfriend and I spent under 20 dollars on our two chicken katsu curries.

6) The inside is small and can be stuffy.  They pack your food to go...so find a sunny spot near union square to enjoy your curry.

Overall, I was satisfied.  Yet my minor complaints:  1) the curry was too runny and 2) my mom puts potatoes, carrots and more meat into hers (who doesn't love their MOM's CURRY more??? and she didn't even pay me to type that!) 

Plus, It looks like they use the S&B curry powder (my mom uses the same) and that is what really makes it taste great and easy to churn out.  I think that this is a great deal for those working downtown.  Yet, I spent $ to park and I don't think that it would be someplace to go OUT of your way to try if you aren't already in the area.
author: Hiromi N.

description:
I'm a creature of habit so if I decide to eat out for lunch it's always Mixt Greens or Murracci's. Everything is delicious here, but I'm usually in a rush so I'll get just the chicken curry so that I can be In and Out.

An absolute must! I've been here too many times to count!
author: Cherry P.

description: The curry sauce was well balanced. I like the different options/sides you can choose from, great customization. The only bad is that it's really only available for those thr work around there, limited hours and no weekends.
author: Jack A.

description: This is the best katsu curry I've had so far in the city.  The Katsu was tender and the curry sauce was delicious.  They also let you pick brown rice without extra charge which was awesome as I prefer brown rice.
author: Wei-Lun H.

description:
My worst cold in 10 years. Sinuses swollen, my head feels like someone hit me in the face with a baseball bat. I'm out of town on business, no home remedies to help me and sudafed has simply stopped working.

I check out Yelp - a four star curry place is a block away. A quick search on the net and yep, their menu has ramen, too. I'm sold.

I almost miss the place, small enough for a counter and a table against the wall with bar stools at it. I order a chicken and vegetable curry ramen, spicy, to go. My order is taken promptly by a nice girl with a pleasant smile.

While waiting, I notice the ramen through the counter's glass. Fresh noodles, not dried. Some signs taped to the counter show favorite curry combos. The pictures of food look delicious. A few minutes later and my order is done, I hurry it back to the hotel. I can feel it's piping hot through the bag.

Inside my room I hurriedly unwrap the steaming bag of goodies. They've packaged the noodles separately from the curry in a bowl. I pour the curry over the noodles. Big chunks of chicken pile out with generously cut vegetables and a thick curry soup. I taste it. It's perfect. They haven't pulled the punches with the spiciness either. A few minutes later and my sinuses have cleared and I feel ten times better. Forget sudafed, I've got the cure for what ails me right here.
author: Lesley M.

description: Pretty good, but a pretty small joint as well. Great variety, as we had chicken curry and croquettes. It was, yes, okay. Not the greatest, but a great alternative to anything else around.
author: Jeff K.

description:
Pretty good, but the downer is that there's usually a long wait for lunch and $8 avg for bowl of noodles is a bit on the expensive side.

I wish they had a clear or lighter broth than the curry kind they serve in soup. The udon was fresh and the beef is tender and flavorful.
author: Kitty N.

description:
My co-worker put me on to it and of course the day I go the SF GATE article runs and the wait is like 30 min.  However, It was very good and have been back 3 times since and have a goal to try all the currie dishes (even if Katsu Don screams at me every time I order!).  

Wait is long and their freshly made to order moto is a little out of place for the FD at lunch time but its very comforting Japanese that is perfect for the colder days.
author: Terence D.

description:
Been here twice for lunch and must have missed the lunch rush entirely both times.  You're out the door if there are 5 people ahead of you, but the wait really isn't that long.  This isn't Panda Express-style fast food, boys and girls.

My very first experience eating Japanese curry lies with Muracci's and it was a delicious and satisfying experience.  This isn't your thick, yellow brick of Golden Curry.  It's thinner and darker and very tasty.  I'm not too good at handling spicy foods, but I do enjoy it once in a while.  The medium had me break into a sweat.

I love that they have brown rice without an extra fee, and you can choose to mix white and brown.

The cashier in front is a really nice guy.  Speaks pretty good English and converses to the workers in the teeny tiny kitchen in Japanese.  He hands you your receipt with both hands and bows his head.  That's appreciation of your patronage right there!
author: L Y.

description:
Muracci's is legit. So legit that they sell Japan rail passes here! 

Even though Japanese curry is super easy and cheap to make at home, I will gladly shell out the cash to eat here. I love that they offer brown rice at no additional cost. 

This is not by any means a grab-and-go kinda place. Expect to wait at least 10-15 minutes to receive your food because everything is made to order. My only gripe is that they claim to take phone orders, but everytime I call, no one picks up. And I have never seen them answer the phone when I am inside.

I always get the vegetable and tofu curry. For $8, the portion is generous and they even give you the red pickle thing on the side. When they first opened, the veggie curry came with crunchy fried slices of renkon (lotus root) on the side. Since the first time I came here, the portions have shrunk and the renkon has disappeared, but I guess I can live. 

You can order your curry mild, medium or hot. When I make Vermont Curry at home, I always use the hot package, because Japanese spicy isn't really that spicy. However, Muracci's mild=Vermont hot. Keep that in mind when you're eating Muracci's at work.
author: A K.

description: the first try of this place. not bad the beef curry. a long line during lunch time, but we got our order pretty fast.
author: Shiwen C.

description: holy crap, thanks for the recommendation CL! just walking around, hungry, ducked into this tiny Japanese katsu joint and was wowed. you'd never know from the outside and there's no reason you'd choose to come in here over the other asian joints on the block, but damn if they don't do it right. 4.5
author: Eric L.

description:
5 stars for flavor, flavor flavor, authenticity, and originality. Minus one star for that crazy line!

I was soooo excited try this place out. Any place that has a sign stating their curry is slow cooked for 2 days has my name written all over it. It screams AUTHENTICITY. That being said, I had never tried Japanese curry. Boy was I missing out! Here the curry is thick like a stew, rich, and packed with spicy goodness. The hot is perfect for a fire eater like me, but I suspect even the milder curries are just as tasty. They have different protein and veggie selections to accompany the curry base. I always pick the spinach and tofu and add extra veggies. The portions are HUGE and I've never managed to come close to finishing a plate. The only downside is that loooong slooooow line. The longest it has taken me has been 40 minutes, but even then my meal was worth it. If you're feeling patient and you want a hearty warm lunch, check this place out!
author: chelsea b.

description: Amazing! all I can say is I hate curry and the chicken katsu curry is to die for!
author: Martin A.

description: I don't mean to rain on the parade of the hundreds of yelpers that love this place, but I really think this place is just A-OK. I think for the area this is probably the better Japanese curry places. The serving is generous, the sauce is good but not that flavorful in my opinion, the compostable containers are very cool, the option of brown rice is a plus....but I just wasn't WOW-ed. My all time favorite place for curry is Rokko in Sunnyvale. They have the BEST curry. So incredibly flavorful....unfortunately or fortunately my taste buds have been spoiled by the curry there....BUT I'd say that if I were working in SF nearby Muracci's and needed my curry fix, I probably would get it here.
author: Jessica L.

description:
This place is fantastic!  They make your order only when it is placed so you always have fresh curry, hence the long lines.  Definitely go with the spicy pork katsu curry, and remember to add veggies and also spinich, otherwise you will end up with just rice and meat.  Oh, the pork katsu is far superior than the chicken katsu, which was dry the few times i had it.  

Minus one star for the long lines all the time and the inconvenience of waiting on a work day.  You'll make more money if you get customers in and out faster!!! SIMPLE BUSINESS ACUMEN!
author: Randall L.

description: This place has amazing pork and chicken katsu curry in San Francisco. I usually get the katsu don or the katsu curry with veggies, medium spicy and ahh I'm in heaven. The curry is always made fresh to order and doesn't simmer all day in a large pot like most other places.
author: Kevin C.

description:
I can see why the pork katsu curry was listed on the 100 Things to Eat in San Francisco list!

The pork is thin, juicy and delectable, the panko coating is crispy, not greasy and a perfect texture, the curry is extremely good - rich, flavorful, and has a great kick (I ask for "hot" and I was sweating a little more than I like to in the office... but it is worth it) , and the perfect bed of brown rice with the little pickled things on the side all add up to one of my new favorite meals!

Our whole office ordered from there, and everyone was extremely satisfied with everything - except for the poor soul who's order was missed by the restaurant.  They cheerfully provided a refund, so I cannot hold it against them.

I will point out that if you get a curry, you get a box with your rice (and your katsu if you get katsu), and then a separate container with your curried meat and sauce.  Be sure that you have TWO containers if you are getting it to go, or you're missing something!

The staff was really friendly and efficient - they deserve all of the business they have had recently!  I hope they open another store closer to the FiDi so it is not such a trek to get their scrumptious curries!!!
author: Jim K.

description: It's all about the Hot curry sauce on chicken katsu.  (which honestly is not even that hot).  I've had the medium curry, and it's pretty tame in flavor (in my opinion).  And I prefer the chicken to the pork, but really, with curry sauce like that, you can't go wrong.
author: Melinda C.

description: I had the curry chicken katsu (spicy), and I thought it was great.  The chicken was still juicy, the crust was extra crispy and the curry was a perfect contrast of spice and zest.  It's a small, popular spot, so call ahead or go right before or after the usual lunch hour.  (Also, don't plan on being very productive after this meal.)  I'll be back.
author: D H.

description:
Nucking fawsome. 

Get the katsu currey or the chicken kara-age.
author: Rich C.

description:
Just went there the 2nd time and found out two major changes!!
1. They are no longer open on Saturdays
2. Express curry in mild chicken/beef over white/brown rice. No need to wait the extra 15mins for them to prepare it.

Both times I was impressed, got the tofu curry the first time and it was very flavorful. Could use a little bit more curry sauce since most got soaked by the rice. This time I tried their beef teriyaki and it was surprising to find out they use steak, not shredded beef. 

If you work around there, call ahead to reduce your wait time.

Pros: Very authentic, tasty, inexpensive

Cons: Long wait during lunch hour, almost impossible to sit there (they do have a few chairs)
author: Maggie C.

description:
I had the Ebi Fry Curry, and it was good! Ive been waiting to a Japanese curry restaurant to open in the city (or even around the bay area), and it's finally here! authentic and good, the family owned restaurant has been open for 2 months now.  I was delighted to speak Japanese to the owners, and the food was awesome. The shrimp was HUGE, and i could barely finish all three due to the size.

One thing i wish they had, is that curry is usually booked and simmered with vegtables such as onions, carrots and potatoes. I wish they would put that into the curry too (unless you order veg curry, it doenst come with it).  I will go back to try the other curry's real soon, when im not watching my weight!
author: Chieko H.

description:
I'm so glad this place opened near my work! I'll agree with everyone else that the curry is amazing! It's very fresh, authentic (I'm from Hawaii so I know real Japanese food) and their chicken is all white meat. Love that they have brown rice or white rice and you can pick the level of spiciness. I haven't tried anything else because the katsu curry is so damn good but I bet their items are yummy too.

When they first opened, they were slow but they seem to have spead up in the service. If you don't want to wait, just call it in ahead and pick it up - totally saves time.
author: Melissa C.

description: Muracci's is like that girl/boy you can always rely on but never get with.  It's pretty good, but there is always a better place popping up in your life.  It's just how that stuff works.  But don't miss out on this place, I do recommend it.  They have specials that they only make "15" of.  Uh-huh sure.  Great supply-demand psychology, but comon.  One time I ordered 16 just to test it out, and yes they made it.  Ok, that never happened, but I wish I did.
author: Tony N.

description: This is my place to go if I need a break from my boring turkey sandwich lunch.  Their chicken katsu curry is awesome.  They give you a big portion of chicken breast katsu style and tasty curry to dip or pour on top.  Makes my mouth water just writing about it.  ;-)  I would recommend that you call your order ahead of time.  It can get pretty packed during lunch hours.
author: Jack A.

description: Ramen noodles were tasty but for $10 expected more chicken and veggies and not all noodle. Also they no longer have soba noodles as an option.
author: Julie G.

description: It's a hole in the wall, there's always a long wait, the portions shrank in the past few years, and there's no where to park or eat, but I'm still crazy for the Katsu-Curry. The best Japanese curry I've had so far. You could put that sauce on anything and it would be good. You can to choose how spicy you want it. Plus, there's a brown rice option. Cheap, tasty, fast.
author: Candy C.

description: Ive eaten here about 20 times already and yes it is so worth coming back. Every time i come here i get the katsu curry. Why? They got the food down right. Always juicy on the inside and  crispy on the outside pork or chicken over brown rice topped with Spicy (my choice) curry sauce. Best ive ever had! Yes its a small place and yes they have a long line during lunch time...but that means the place has good food. So worth the wait. If your impatient just call in your order.
author: Walter B.

description: Absolutely delicious, I got the traditional pork Katsu curry and ate the whole thing. Definitely large enough portions but such good spices and quality of meat that its possible to eat the whole thing without realizing. I'll most definitely be back. The whole staff was really helpful and since we had to stand outside to wait for our food during the lunch rush, the owner came out and asked our number so he could let us know when it was ready. Really such a great experience all around.
author: Nicole F.

description:
had to try it b/c i LOVE katsu curry.

for katsu curry in america, i think it's good.  katsu is tender, and well fried.  the curry is of decent consistency.  they also serve brown rice (though for the record, i think white rice is a better mix for katsu curry).

their hot curry is nowhere near as hot as the curry in japan.  perhaps it's catered to american taste buds, but it would be nice to have a "jesus h christ, this is making me cry" hot (again, as found abundantly in japan).

nonetheless, in a city with a dearth of curry houses, this one does it very well.  too bad they're not open for dinner or weekends.  luckily it's one block away from work!
author: Jason J.

description: As a vegan, I'm writing only about the vegetable tofu udon ( the ramen is egg based)... my co-workers rave about the rest of the items.  It's across the street from work so I've eaten there four times and it's been okay.  I love how they cook to order and the taste is good but not amazing.  It's  reliable place for a quick fix.
author: Rob C.

description:
This may sound blasphemous to my fellow Yelpers, but I hate plain rice.  Hate hate hate - which is why I poured my curry over my rice and proceeded to mix the two thoroughly together.  But...umm..apparently there's a wrong way and a right way to eat curry, and this was the ultimate wrong way, or so the bf says.  

The bf has been RAVING about Muracci's for months and months now, and I finally got to try it out a couple weeks ago.  I had the chicken curry (medium - the bf says I'm going to burn a hole in my stomach with all the spicy food I eat, and since he did the ordering (by phone - the place can get packed), I didn't get a say in the matter), and for the price of nearly $8, I was, well, unimpressed.  After mixing my food together, all I tasted was..spicy.  There was no curry flavor whatsoever.  The bf, who was in curry heaven after devouring his food, was in disbelief that I did not enjoy my meal (I barely ate half, and this is saying a lot because for those who know me, I eat..a lot) and was convinced the lack of flavor was a direct result of burned out tastebuds (see, I told you he doesn't like me eating spicy foods).  I persuaded him to take a bite of my curry.  He chewed.  Initially puzzled, he agreed that my food tasted just, really, spicy, and blamed me because I had mixed the rice and curry together.  He said if I had eaten my food correctly, simply pouring the curry over the rice and eating - not mixing - I would have enjoyed my meal as much as he had his.

In any case, 2 stars for now, Muracci's.  Maybe I'll give you another go sometime and eat my curry "correctly," and you can win me over.
author: Mel T.

description: Love this place!!   A friend brought me here and now I'm addicted!!  The best katsu curry I've ever had.  The perfect amount of breading  fried to perfection!   Little delicate pieces of fried chicken katsu followed by japanese curry over rice,  Not to mention the wonderful pickled cabbages on the side make a perfect compliment to the dish!  They also offer brown rice which is huge plus!  Seating is limited which makes it pretty cramped during rush hours!
author: Janelle D.

description:
I ordered the weekly special which was korokke (potato, ground beef and corn croquette) hot curry (you can choose mild, medium or hot) with brown rice (you can choose white too, if you like). I was also craving potato salad, so I ordered that too. The potato salad is mixed with brocolli and corn. 

After waiting in line for an entire hour, I finally got my lunch to go. Each meal is made to order, that's why it takes so long. So I advise people to go there earlier than noon which is when i went, becuase they were sold out of the weekly special and brown rice by the time i got my food.

I tried the potato salad first which was delicious. Excellent, delicate flavor, not too strong like some potato salads. 

Then I tried the korokke sans curry first. It was fried to a crisp, golden brown and was also very delicious. I added the curry and it was awesome. The hot was pretty hot and the flavor was very good. However, the only thing I didn't like about the curry was that it was remniscient of the packaged Japanese curry, "Golden Curry" brand, which is also delicious. Perhaps my tongue isn't trained well enough, but the 2 curries tasted pretty much the same, except "Golden Curry" is $1.95 or something like that, and my weekly special was $8.95.
author: Paweena P.

description:
Nice. Got here at 2:30 pm and it only took six minutes.

Had the chicken katsu curry. Be sure to get it with the vegetables, because they're only fifty cents extra.

Unless you're a little girl, DEFINITELY get the curry hot because the heat is just right. You can get it very hot also.

Come early to get the weekly special before they run out of it.
author: Adam Z.

description: I go here for lunch at least once a week. Especially during these cold winter days, nothing satisfies my hunger quite like the katsu curry at Muracci's. The line is quite long for lunch on most days, so I would recommend calling ahead. I'd also recommend the fried salmon curry, but NOT the regular salmon curry, as your portion of salmon goes down substantially.
author: Richard Z.

description:
mmm CURRY!

my new cute lil spot to grab lunch when im having cravings for some curry chicken! I have the option to choose between brown rice & white? yes. :)

They're really friendly here & it takes a lil bit of time for your order to come out sometimes, but i think its worth the wait. Good for take outs on ur break or to sit in when there's no one there. This place is tiny.
author: Rosalynn D.

description: Think I missed that curry transcendence that I was supposed to feel?  Stopped in for a late lunch, ordered chicken katsu curry on white rice.  Used up the entire container of (bland) curry & it still wasn't saucy enough.  The fried coating of the chicken cutlet was crispy & not greasy, but the chicken it encased was rather dry.  Big portion, big price.  Think I would have been happier with half of each.
author: Talia R.

description: Good god, that katsu. I'm grateful it's so far from my office or I'd be eating deep fried meat on a daily basis.
author: Anonymous F.

description:
This is one of those places that unless you know about it, you'll miss it - and that would be a great shame. The curry here is a great comfort food, especially on colder days, and the portions are surprisingly large. I had a medium katsu curry with vegetables. The wait (I came in at 11:15 or so) was about fifteen minutes, so come prepared for that (and if other reviews are any indication, be prepared for more during the lunch rush).
