Food was great. The katsu was crispy and tender, the curry sauce was just spicy enough to have some kick to it, and the vegetables weren't soggy or anything. You get a generous amount, but unfortunately, you pay for it - my meal cost $9.77, which is a little on the pricey side. Still, as a now-and-then lunchtime meal, it's fantastic.
author: Rob D.

description:
Katsu Curry (Medium spiciness) with Brown rice is my order !!

For a price usually cheaper than any comparable restaurant/ take outs around the area - excluding China Town ones ..... you get yourself a rather hearty, tasty, and maybe - spicy box of curry for lunch. 

I have come to this place too many times when the line was basically almost out the door, but when I needed to get stuff there - I would just line up, ordered up, and my food ready for me in minutes. Needless to say, the people working in Muracci's are ultra efficient in what they do, and they managed to have good service as well. So I brought that food back, and ....

first off, i would never try to eat curry with brown rice in the first place, but my girl made me do that for the first time. Honestly, if everywhere else can make their brown rice so chewy yet still soft enough, I would totally switch my rice choice to brown, but so far, only Muracci's can do it this way. Then the curry had good flavor and spiciness in them for my likings, and the best was, the tonkatsu (pork cutlet), thick, and juicy ...... simply the best tonkatsu I have had so far ...... Though the second time was a little let down with the tonkatsu, but you can't control what they deliver to you , and for around $9 ....... I think it's a very good deal for lunch in a busy san francisco district.
author: David C.

description:
This place reminds me of those Coco Ichiban Curry chain restaurants in Japan that's always jampacked with salarymen (translation: businessmen) during the lunch hour. For the nostalgia alone, I love this place!! 

It's a little pricey to be eating here for lunch on a daily basis but the portions are at least fairly generous. Still, I think they should consider offering half-portion sizes for the ladies. =P

Minus one star because I wish it wasn't so chaotic and cramped (for the claustrophobes).
author: Yuffie G.

description: Super yummy, authentic, and very affordable Japanese curry in the FiDi. If I worked in SF, I'd try to make it out here at least once a week. The owner/chef is super cute and works in tandem with his wife, who mans the register. For about $15/2 people, you get a hearty meal that would probably cost at least twice as much in most other FiDi eateries.
author: Susanna W.

description: The katsu curry was sooooooo good.  The portion size was pretty generous too.  I did carry out and there wasn't a line when I got there a little after 2pm.  My food was ready within just a few minutes.  I went medium with the curry and it wasn't too spicy, a good medium spice.  I also had it with the brown rice, which was good.
author: Crystal Z.

description:
Hi Folks,

I work in the heart of FIDI
For my slang-challenged friends, that's the Financial District in SF.
Good Food isn't impossible to find here but ridiculously priced.
Let's look at Muraccis' for example. 
The prices are little higher than the norm but they have good food. 
I've tried the Chicken Katsu with curry and spinach.
Really good and not overly salty, chicken cutlet was delicious. 
They also have an array of other curry items over noodles (udon, soba, ramen) or white/brown rice. For their food alone I would absolutely give them five stars. However, the wait... Arghh.. the wait for this precious dish is unbelievable. 

I have an hour lunch and by the time I've walked up there (approximately three blocks away), ordered and got my food, I was 15 minutes late. You figure it out!! 
Oh, I'm sure my co-workers really appreciated the smell of curry lingering through the office for the rest of the afternoon. I love the curry but  I just can't justify the horrendous wait for it. Minus 2 Stars
author: H To The W.

description:
Finally, a decent place to eat at if you work in Downtown. :D

Great curry! 

The wait is too long and the place is too small to dine in. maybe later on they can take over that stupid overpriced thai place next door.
author: Catalina C.

description:
We order from Muracci's at least once a week. This place is awesome. Make sure that you preorder on the phone and then go to pick up the food, otherwise the wait can get ridiculous. My favorite is Beef Ramen. I tried the beef curry, chicken curry, ebi curry, and chicken ramen and they were all good. 

I have to try the other stuff on the menu too. Highly recommend this place. The owners are super nice the food is great.
author: Mohammad M.

description:
Muracci's used to be a mainstay of my weekly lunch rotation - I would eat here at least twice a week.

However, the quality of their food has gone downhill on my last few visits, as well as the size of the protein-portions.  

My last meal, chicken karaage, tasted exactly like microwaved chicken nuggets.

I'll probably try it again a couple more times, but given how long it takes to get your order, and price relative to other fantastic options in the area, this place needs to focus on quality or they will be off my list.
author: zeph h.

description: Another great place for curry plates in the city!  The katsu is good but I usually go for the salmon curry.  It's grilled crisp and drenched with the savory curry.  Th rice is done right...glutenous and slightly firm.  It's so good, you can eat it plain.  When the rice is combined with the curry, you can eat endless plates of this stuff!
author: MTBer I.

description: The location is excellent if you work in the FiDi.  The food is good.  However, if you order even one side item, even if it's just extra curry, you're already over $10.  Look to spend 12 bucks for a good meal here. The curry in my Chicken Katsu Curry dish was slightly bland but the quantity of food was good and made up for that!  If meals were within10 bucks I would've given this place 4 or 5 stars!  The seating is horrible as well.  This palce is tiny!  A few more feet between the stools and the checkout counter would've done the trick.  On a side note: it's awesome that they offer brown rice instead of white if you want.
author: AJ B.

description:
I have waited a long, long time to try this place out.  It's hard because it closes at 6 pm and it's not close enough to the area in SoMa where I work.  So, I worked up this big appetite to come eat here and get a katsu curry (pork).  The quiet, shy waitress politely says "we're out of that".  Alright, so I'll have the chicken katsu.  The waitress says we're out of that.  What about beef?  Out of that.  Dammmit.  I've come all this way to have some katsu curry and I can't get any.  Eventually, I settled on the Salmon curry, but I wanted white rice and they were out of that.  You have to get Japanese curry with white rice.  It's a must b/c it soaks up the curry the best.  I did come here a day before the Christmas holiday though and they said they cut down on supplies in lieu of the holidays.  I would've given an extra star had I not wanted katsu curry sooooo much.  
The serving is decent, but not enough for the $9 you spend for it.  The sweet taste of the curry is good, but i'm used to it being sweeter and having a stronger flavor.  The place is really small, so be prepared to wait if you come during rush hours.  It is reminiscent of restaurants I visited when I vacationed in Japan.  I would try this place again hopefully to try some katsu curry next time.
author: Robert K.

description:
went here for lunch with my brother looking to get some authentic jap curry. felt very homey going here and eating here.

located near the financial, this place is small with some counter space for quick eats. the katsu curry is tasty. plus i love how they sell croquettes and fukujinzuke (the red stuff on top of the curry) to take home! it's like being at mitsuwa or nijiya....but not. plus i love it more because the people who work there actually are japanese and speak japanese. plus plus plus.
author: Ely K.

description: Haven't found a good Japanese curry place since being in LA.  Went to this spot today for lunch and awakened those long lost tastebuds.  I ordered the Chicken Katsu Curry over Brown Rice with extra curry sauce.  You can choose between different spice levels and of course I had to do the spiciest.  The Hot was pretty good, not too spicy at all.  The meal came out to be around 10 bucks and it was worth every penny.
author: Bert N.

description:
cute lil family-owned place with warm, hospitable service!

the owner recommended i have a warm curry b/c it's cold outside! =) the curry is brewed for 2 days. it was flavorful and delicious. the katsu was perfectly fried with crispy panko breading and the ginger was arranged into a flower.

i would definitely frequent this place if i lived here.  nice to-go packaging, too!
author: gookgette c.

description:
I was thrilled to find this great Japanese curry place near the financial district.  Their homemade curry is delicious and the portions are generous.  They have specials that change every couple of weeks as well that are often wonderful (the shiroi sakana curry is my favorite).

The only downside to this restaurant is that it can take a while to get your order because they make each order fresh.  This is easily avoidable, however, by calling in your order before you head down.  Orders called in are generally ready in 10-15 minutes, and you don't have to stand in line to pay.
author: Scott Z.

description: The tiny space & incredible kindness of the place is what makes Muracci's feel authentically Japanese to me. Everything, from curry to ramen, is delicious. As a prego woman, I appreciate the healthy options & brown rice.
author: Caricia C.

description: I finally stopped by Muracci's today. As I'm typing this up, I'm stuffing my face full of yummy curry goodness. I ordered the much-talked-about Katsu Curry and I love it. I ordered the mild since I wasn't sure how spicy it was going to be and it's delicious, although next time, I think I'm gonna have to order the medium. Like the other reviews said, it's really small in there so ordering your food to go would be your best bet. And no worries about your katsu getting all soggy by the time you get home! They put the curry in its own container so that the amount of curry you decide to put in is totally up to you.
author: Anna T.

description: The curry chicken was some of the best I have had. The food was portioned just enough, the savor and flavor were on point. I came after the lunch rush which is probably a better experience than during, they took about 10 minutes to make the dish but it was well worth the wait of a few minutes. I suggest going at around 2pm.
author: Joe J.

description:
I love this place! My usual used to be the chicken curry, medium spice...but then I discovered chicken katsu. Just delicious. 

I love that they have an option to order brown rice, instead of white and would also recommend getting there before the 12:00 lunch rush. Seating is very limited, so I almost always ordered to-go.
author: J P.

description: wow japanese curry can never go wrong, and Muracci just brings it to the next level! price is decent, and they prepare ur food after u order, so its very fresh. I often order Chicken Katsu Curry; they separate the curry and the katsu for you so its perfect for to-goer! their katsu is crispy yet juicy! the only down side may be the portion, not big enough for a guy, but that only says how good their curry is. A reminder for ppl who like to order to go, u can call before u go, so u won't have to wait. totally recommend for ppl who work in sf downtown!!!
author: Kevin T.

description:
This place has actually been in my lunch routine since I started working downtown SF; in fact, I keep the corny free swag they give out simply because this place is that good.  

Anyways, recently I called in an order of the Katsu Curry so that I could bring it back to the confines of my office.  I must admit that I was slightly annoyed when I called ahead and placed my order.  The person taking my order said that it wouldn't be ready for another 30 minutes!  C'mon, 30 min. to prepare Katsu Curry at a joint that churns out food to hundreds of people a day??  I got over it ... fairly quickly.  

Like many lunch stops in SF, Muracci's is a small, crowded,  in-and-out food establishment the size of one of my closets at home so seating as you may have guessed is pretty sparce.  My office would at least provide me with a desk to eat on, a door which to shut out the immaculate fumes of the curry from the rest of my floor, and space to assume the food-comotose position ... I was ready; I opened my brown bag and was immediately excited for a few reasons.  First, I got to use chopsticks ... I absolutely love eating with chopsticks and use them as often as possible.  Second, there were sides packaged separately; one for the spicy curry (in a 1/2 lb. container like you see at the deli!!) and a couple others for pickled red and green stuff, and finally my last-second addition, mac salad from L&L's Hawaiian BBQ across the way from Muracci's.  This, as I said, was a last second addition to my meal, one which I debated in my head for all but 15 seconds.  In my opinion, mac salad should accompany any dish with white rice and meat ... it just works.    

The meal itself was amazing.  I have to say a good Katsu Curry depends on the the flakiness of the panko crust, the juiciness of the meat, and of course the flavor of the curry; fortunately, it had all of these.  Plus, throw in refreshing red and green pickles AND my personal touch, the mac salad ... oh, sweet baby Jesus!!  My favorite part of the meal, however, was "dunking" the pieces of Katsu meat into the 1/2 lb. container of spicy curry.  Oftentimes, I judge food by not only how it tastes, where I am, or whom I am with, but rather how my body sits on its seat afterwards.  After Muracci's, my body was slouched backwards, my head faced the ceiling, and my feet extended under my desk.  Overall, this meal was a huge success.
author: Brian S.

description:
Fantastic authentic Japanese curry!  I get lunch here at least once a week.

I usually order chicken curry w/ extra vegetables or tofu with vegetable curry and brown rice.  The chicken is always really tender.  The udon is all right, but that's not what you go here for.  These guys make perfect curry sauce, but I'm sure they don't make their own noodles.
author: Stephanie W.

description:
So after all these glowing reviews, and walking past the place and seeing the lines, a co-worker and I finally decided to give Muracci's a try. 
We got there at 11:40, which most places are usually not too busy yet in the Financial, but there was already a long line, and the phone was ringing off the hook.  My first thoughts are, . . .This place MUST be good for all this.  So after a 5 min wait in line, we get to order.  I had the chicken Teriyak and my friend had the chicken katsu curry.  The gentleman behind the counter, was very friendly.  
We now began the "wait".  A 24 min wait for our food.  I have a hard time with this, because even though they were busy, from what I can see its mostly re-heating.  There were BIG pots of curry on the stove, and all the rice was ready.  As were the miso soup.  So all that needed to be done was the katsu and the chicken.

So after the wait.  I got a DRY, STRINGY almost NO SAUCE Teriyaki, with flavorless brown rice, some veggie thing I cant identify, 5 pieces of lettuce with a drop of dressing and some pre-prepared miso soup.  I wouldn't wait 2 min for food like this, much less 24!  My co-worker's katsu curry was better, but definitely NOT worth waiting for.  I don't know what other curry's people have had before to rate this place so highly. It was ok, just average curry, not great and not worth waiting for.  
I guess if this is the only curry you've ever had, and have nothing to compare it to, then you might think it's good.

I really had a hard time with the rating.  But 2 stars for nice people, ok katsu, and a clean place.  But that's all the good I can say about it.
author: David H.

description:
Re post 08/28/2008:
Since going there for the first time this past Monday (8/25), I've been here 3 times and its only Thursday (8/28).  And I have to restate my rating.  I'm giving this place 5 stars.  The wait can be long but today, it was only few minutes.  The food is so damn good, I gotta give it another star.  This place is the bomb.  Keep in mind, there might be better curry places in NY or LA or Tokyo or at your mom's but unless its in SF, I don't give a hoot.  This place is the shiz nitz and anyone who gives it less than 4 stars is out of his mind and a curry snob.  Only one word for someone like that....  "boooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooo"

Being Asian and having spent a year in Japan, I have to say, this is one of the best quality curry I've tasted in the city.  Its pretty damn authentic.  I just got the Chicken Katsu Curry (hot) and was enjoying every minute of my meal.  I almost licked the to-go container expect my co-workers would have thought I was crazy.  Actually, I didn't want curry stains on my shirt.  I can't wait until I go back and try some of their Udon Curry dishes.  (Disclaimer: When I say hot, I mean Asian hot not American hot.  You know what I'm talking about.  My curry made my nose run a little bit.  Be warned folks.)

The only reason why I didn't give it 5 stars is because the wait is a bit too long.  If you have a full hour for lunch and want some good Japanese food, then try Muracci.  If you are in a time crunch, then this may not be for you, although, I think there is something called "an express meal" where you get prepared curry.  But you still have to wait in line to order.

I think this place will pleasantly surprise you as it is the best Japanese curry in the city.  That's right, I said it, the best Japanese curry in the city.  Prove me wrong.
author: Chad N.

description:
Small!  Very very small the lines are extremely long and the fresh food takes quite a while to prepare.  Call in your order 20minute a head of time and it's an easy walk in and out.  

The food is delicious.  The katsu - fried to perfection.  Light, crispy, delicious.  The curry (which is the only thing you should be getting) is amazing, I enjoy it hot everything else is just to weak on the palate.  Add the vegetables for $0.50, well worth it.
author: Chris S.

description:
This place rocks!!! Awesome Japanese Curry. The place is really small so the lines can be out the door. Its only counter seating and there may be about 10 chairs total.

You get to choose whether you want your curry over white rice, brown rice, or noodles (in a broth type deal). You can also choose how hot you want it; mild, medium, hot. 

If you don't want curry you can also orders the katsu's and meat and fish teriyaki's. They have a small variety of lunch specials

Today we had the veg tofu curry (medium) with brown rice which was soooooooo good. The beef curry is delicious as well. They serve the curry separately so you get to add as much or as little as you want. There is also a small side of pickled cabbage. We also tried the miso soup, which was also very good.
author: Tom L.

description: I would eat here every day if I could, they have without question THE BEST Japanese style Curry I have ever tasted.  I lived in Japan for most of my life and have grown up on Japanese Curry, flavors, and culture.  When I go to Muracci's it's like going home, you can even get a can of UCC coffee and cold Japanese tea in the cooler.  The couple that own Muracci's are warm and inviting.  It's Japanese comfort food you won't find anywhere else in the city.  I wish they were open for dinner is my only complaint but If you love Japanese Curry this is the spot!
author: N E.

description:
Wow, excellent example of katsu curry... the sauce is fantastic, just the right sweetness and spice and the katsu is great golden perfection. All this, with an extra side of egg, and a finishing touch of pickles... one of the most satisfying lunches I've had in a while. In total, along with my cold bottled jasmine tea, lunch was $13. A little bit higher than what I was expecting to pay, especially for the tea which was in itself $3 and I've usually paid for at Mitsuwa for $1.50... and to be honest, although it's a fantastic example of katsu curry, it doesn't go up and beyond to completely wow me, rather it beats most competitors out of the game to show up something as a gold baseline. Much bigger fan of the curry at Ferry Building's Delica rf-1, which isn't a conventional J-curry (and true, they don't serve it a la katsu) but really has more of a flavor impact, all for about the same price or a little less.
I would come back to Muracci's for sure, but it wouldn't be frequent given the cost, and I definitely advise if you do work in the FiDi then take your entree back to your office as the eating space at Muracci's is just too confined and few.
Overall, great curry, okay price, great service.
author: Jessica L.

description: The line was pretty long during lunch and the the chicken curry was only ok...Perhaps I ordered the wrong dish because people before me kept ordering chicken katsu.  Oh well, I'll try it again and get katsu.
author: Laurice G.

description: Katsu was perfect, firm and white with no dark splotches like at most places. And a big serving too, especially for lunch. Even though it was crowded, it only took about 5 minutes for my food to be ready.
author: Brian B.

description: Great lunch spot! I got the katsu curry and it was awesome. Although I ordered the hot curry and didn't think it was that spicy, but still delicious. Will definitely be back here a lot. I hear there is a very long wait, so I called in my order and it was ready when I arrived, and they included utensils. (I'm always surprised how many lunch spots forget that little detail.) It's very small, so I'd plan on take out only here.
author: Beth D.

description:
This is my favorite place to grab lunch and I'll typically drop by 3x a month. I usually call in my order and by the time I get there and wait in line, my order is ready to be picked up.

I usually get the katsu curry, medium and over brown rice. It's the absolute best! And I never order it elsewhere any more cause I know that I'll just end up comparing it to Muracci's. They don't charge extra for brown rice. And the curry is packaged separately so your katsu remains crisp until you have the opportunity to eat it. Occasionally, I'll get the weekly special, but the katsu curry will always remain my favorite.
author: Tammy L.

description:
I am a big fan of their Chicken Katsu.  It always consistent and tastes great. We go here for lunch at least once a week.   

It is best to phone a bigger order in, as the place is small with very little standing room.
author: John C.

description:
you know how sometimes on a cold fall day, all you really want is some pork katsu and curry? if you're nodding YES, then Muracci's Japanese Curry & Grill is totally the place to go if you're in SF on that cold fall day with a craving for curry!

WLB and I headed over, attempting to beat the lunch rush, to no avail...definitely consider calling in your order ahead of time if you're looking to save some serious time.  or you can wait (as WLB and I did) and enjoy the smells of the katsu (pork cutlet), kaki fry (fried oysters), and many other delicious deep fried items waft through the area while you wait among many to get your food...there's also japanese drinks and snacks and sweets to tide you over while you wait and/or as a yummy dessert!

7x7 magazine recommended the katsu pork meal -- my take on it? the medium spicy curry was sufficiently hot for my taste buds, but I have a feeling for many it might be a little weak -- for me though it was perfection...the curry is delicious...and of course it should be since "takes 2 days to prepare [because the] homemade soup stock, along with vegetables, herbs and spices are simmered for 20 hours, resulting in a thick creamy curry base." so with the katsu comes a choice of brown/white rice and house special radish pickles and voila your katsu meal is complete!

I definitely agree with 7x7 magazine in naming this place as one of the 100 places to go in SF...just call ahead for your order next time to avoid the wait!
author: Grace O.

description: Sometimes I crave Coco Ichibanya Curry House from Hawaii.  But it would be a bit irrational, if not fiscally irresponsible, to fly back to Hawaii just for Curry House.  So I felt out of luck until I tried Muracci's, which satisfied my craving.  Although it doesn't have the same variety as Curry House and doesn't taste quite as good, it's still a very solid choice.  I had the chicken katsu curry, hot level of spiciness, with spinach.  It was very tasty and the portions were generous.  I hope in the future they will offer stewed chicken curry, which is my go-to choice.  The place is small and service is a bit slow, but overall it's good taste and good value.  Worth coming back for.
author: Neill T.

description: This place has perfect Japaneses curry and katsu and very good specials too.  Great soul food.
author: J V.

description: Not bad, I had the chicken katsu which is pretty good. Anything deep fried is usually good, katsu is no exception. The flavor of the curry is somewhere around Golden Curry.
author: Wil M.

description: I had the Katsu Curry (Pork) on the recommendation of the 7x7sf, "100 places to eat in San Fransisco before you die" and it was one of the best currys that I have ever eaten.  Muracci's curry sauce is prepared by Tamiko. The sauce takes two days to prepare. The homemade soup stock, along with vegetables, herbs and spices are simmered for 20 hours, resulting in a thick creamy curry base.  Don't miss it.
author: Chase B.

description:
f*cking love this place.

sometimes i wish i was a FIDI tool so i can eat here everyday.  don't take this personally, some of my best friends are FIDI tools!
http://static.px.yelp.com/ephoto/DaL-yhNEX-TdOjmVb55JCw/l

if they offered the tonkatsu with the vegetable curry, this would be the best curry i have ever met!!!

in the southbay, come to minatos ; P
author: omar b.

description:
Curry is cooked to order here and is deliciously fresh and flavorful. I recommend the hot chicken katsu curry.

This place gets really crowded close to lunchtime.
author: R E.

description:
Why did I order the curry knowing I would smell up the office with it? I blame Muracci's! 

I went in knowing they specialize in curry and being a semi-fan of it, I had to give the chicken katsu with medium curry a try. The portion was spot on for me as I have a healthy appetite and the heat of the curry was not to hot or mild for my tastes. 

I would have given them 4 stars except as I was about to order, the cashier opted to push me aside so he could help people who called in. Poor customer service but they can't really be blamed for how small the place it. If anyone remembers, this used to be the place that had Thai take-out. Egos ago...

Warning: I waited over 20 minutes for my food including the time it took to order. Order ahead as you won't be twiddling your thumbs waiting around.
author: S L.

description:
This place is a gem.  Perfectly portioned, fresh, and authentic Japanese lunch fare for pocket change.  The place is known for their Japanese curry, but it's the katsudon, oyakodon, lunch sets, and whimsical weekly specials that keep me coming back.  I find the curries a bit bland, but there's no denying that Muracci's is authentic as you're going to find this side of Osaka.  I've been looking for a place like this for years, and I finally found it.

One caution is that the wait can be dreadfully long at peak lunch hour.  Go after 1pm and you won't have to wait more than 15 minutes for your food.

Itadakimasu!
author: Susuk L.

description:
The boy INSISTED that this was the BEST FOOD HE'S EVER HAD IN HIS LIFE.
So good that we DROVE all the way from the Mission out to the Financial District on a Thursday during lunch hour to get this stuff.
He also insisted that Japanese curry beats out Indian and Thai curries.
What!
!!!
He was sort of right. 
It was damn tasty.  I ordered the exact same thing he did (chicken katsu curry with white rice, hot, with extra sauce.  BELIEVE ME:  Get the EXTRA SAUCE).
Shit was good.  Damn good.
The chicken cutlets were perfectly breaded but kind of dry WHICH IS WHY YOU NEED THE EXTRA SAUCE.
All in all, I like Indian curries better because of the smokiness, but Japanese curry has definitely won a place in my heart.  It's a slow heat, but doesn't really have too much smokiness.  It's not really thick either.  
The space itself is TINY.  I'm all about sit down meals, but there was definitely no room to sit around here. 
If I'm ever down here or have the motivation to drive to the FiDi again, I will definitely go to Muracci's.
HINTS:  CALL AHEAD AND PLACE YOUR ORDER.
HINTS:  GET EXTRA SAUCE!!!!
author: Meh M.

description: Chicken katsu curry was really yummy. The space is small and there's was a 10-minute line during lunch, but solid-on-the-heavier-side lunch option when you're craving japanese soul food. They also carry a selection of Japanese bakery desserts in case you're a sweet tooth!
author: Karen L.

description: It's hard not to clean up your plate whenever I get the chance to dine here. You can taste the care that goes into preparing the delicious curry sauce. Doesn't beat the katsu you can get in Japan, but it sure comes close. Very reasonably priced too.
author: E. L.

description: Huge cuts awesome curry
author: Nick M.

description: Hopped on the train to try this out for lunch today.  It is listed on the 7x7 2010 Big Eat list so I decided to check it out.  I had the katsu curry.  The curry was flavorful and not too spicy (I ordered mild), the rice was perfect and the katsu was fantastic!  Affordable and quick service.  I will definitely be back!
author: Dominique K.

description: I had the grilled salmon lunch box. The miso soup was excellent and the salmon was fresh. The only thing they can improve on is the portion size of the salmon. For 10.25 I got a thin piece of salmon that was TINY. Definitely left hungry and probably will not go back.
author: Bobby D.

description:
Awesome curry! The katsu curry is one of the best and don't forget to have the korokke. I usually call in my order and they are very fast. It's even worth the wait if you forget to call first. 

Not an ideal place to eat-in, but definitely a to-go place.
author: Jason E.

description: Prompted by my niece's quest to hit up all the places on the 100 must try list, I stopped in here for some of their famous katsu curry.  Loved the fact that they offer brown rice as an alternative for the health conscious like me who has no qualms about eating deep fried pork drenched in heavy curry sauce, but need to stay away from processed white rice!!  YUMMY about sums up the experience.  By far the best katsu curry I have ever had.  Choose from mild, medium or spicy.  Go early as the place gets pretty busy by noon.  Take it to go as there is not much room for a dine-in experience.
author: Sharon S.

description: Tonkatsu (fried breaded pork cutlet) + authentic, hot Japanese curry = incredibly delicious, filling lunch for the price. The katsu and curry are made fresh to order, which is obviously a good thing but can make the line at lunch time veeeery long and the tiny shop very crowded. The pork is tender, juicy and fried just right; the curry is actually spicy if you ask for it. There isn't much seating in the store so you might want to either come slightly off hours or drag it back to your desk for a mid-day curry break because this place is worth repeated visits.
author: Kristina A.

description: I'd always been curious about Muracci's having seen the long lines to get into the place, so I checked it out a couple of weeks ago. I had the chicken katsu, medium with brown rice. I ate almost every bite! It was absolutely delicious. It's a safe bet for good, simple and comforting lunch food. While small, the place has pretty comfortable seating and the staff was polite and attentive. To avoid a crazy wait period at noon, order ahead for pick-up.
author: Frances L.

description: My friend discovered this spot a few weeks ago, so we gave it a try.  I've been a repeat customer ever since then.  The curry is very tasty, portion is good and price is decent.  I love the way they pack the curry separately from your entree just so it doesn't get soggy.  My fav pick is the Katsu Curry.  I highly suggest calling in your order as the line continues to grow during peak lunch hour.  Check out their "specials".  It changes about every two weeks on their website - www.muraccis.com.
author: JADE L.

description:
this delectable
curry always finds its way 
running down my chin
author: chester R.

description:
REAL TALK ALERT!

The curry here is nothing short of fantastic: authentically thick, spicy, appropriately Japo-fied, and lovingly prepared to order by a sweet woman who bears a faint resemblance to my Obachan. Can't wait for your lunch? Then call in your order, get a pre-made curry, or go after 1.30 pm. Trying to up your fiber intake? Then get your curry with brown rice. Every bite of the chicken katsu curry reminded me of when Dad would whip up quick dinners by prepping some Japanese S&B curry, veggies, and leftover meat -- when, that is, he wasn't grilling bologna on a makeshift pan made out of tinfoil. So feeling the burn of the"Hot" curry on my palate was like being a kid again, only without the post-dinner belt beatings, verbal abuse, and unreasonable expectations of success that led to various acts of rebellion against paternity, maternity, and tradition including, but not limited to, failing math, reading literature, smoking, drinking, and playing the meat flute in the dressing room of my high school theatre courtesy of G, R, M, K, R, B and W (don't laugh -- I can play the overture to Tannhauser) -- and all for the reasonable price of $8.50! SCORE!

Speaking of authentic, I can't express how wonderful it is to walk into a Japanese curry house and be greeted with a hearty "irrashaimase," and, naturally, I just chalk this reaction up to my inbred Japanese JINGOISM and outright xenophobia which makes no sense because I'm technically a fourth-generation American so I REALLY should look upon non-English greetings with disdain by saying "It's okay, speak English now, YURR IN THE GOOD OLE YOU ESS OF AYYY" right before I dump my tea in the Bay, annex a couple of islands, and YOU CALL THIS A STIMULUS PACKAGE MOTHERFUCKER? THIS'LL ONLY GET ME TWO HOURS WITH A HOOKER but yeah, it's a nice added touch of authenticity to one of my favorite new lunch spots in the FiDi.

***No, I'm kidding. I'm not a jingoist or xenophobe. I hate everyone.
author: d s.

description: First ever trying Japanese curry.  I tried the beef over white rice.  It was ok, I prefer Thai curry, which is lighter with coconut milk.  There are large chucks of beef, which is ususally how I DON'T like my beef.  It comes with a little container of pickled radish and cabbage.  All in all, it was decent.
author: Qui F.

description: What a wonderful curry place near my work this is, and to prove it, I eat there, on average, twice a week. "Chicken Katsu curry with extra vegetables," I tell them when I get to the head of the line. Then I sometimes say "arigatou gozaimasu," and they usually look at me sideways and say, "thank you." The curry ramen is also to die for, but not literally. It would be stupid to die over something like a bowl of soup.
author: Nathaniel L.

description: I first experienced Japanese Curry when I visited Tokyo last year. Since my return, I have had tried the curry in several Japanese restaurants, but somehow they were always lacking. That is until I ate at Muracci's several weeks ago. "Oh my god", the homestyle curry made by the adorable older Japanese family is the smoothest and best tasting I have had in the US. Now, I am a weekly regular and get the #3, Medium curry with pork each time. It is absolutely delicious and would recommend this place to everyone. The crowds may be larger if you come at peak hours, but it is worth every savory bite!!
author: S L.

description: Muracci's is literally a hole in the wall. I would've completely missed it if my cousin hadn't pushed me towards the door. By the time we got there for lunch at 3PM, they were sold out of a lot of their popular items (i.e. the chicken katsu, pork katsu, and their lunch special). My cousin was disappointed since she wanted to try the lunch special: the oyster fry. Initially, we were just gonna get some fried vegetarian curry pockets (not sure what they're called). However, upon further contemplation, she changed her mind and we got the salmon fry curry to share too. It came with four pieces of fried salmon, curry sauce, pickled vegetables, and your choice of white or brown rice. The salmon was crispy and moist, complimenting the curry sauce well. Overall, the food is decent, but I give Muracci's four stars because the cashiers and owner are super nice. I suggest going before the lunch rush if you want to be able to try their more popular items. The inside is really small and has limited seating (probably only enough room for 10 people), so I'd recommend getting it to-go, especially if you're claustrophobic.
author: Audrey T.

description:
nice big, perfectly fried tonkatsu, over brown rice, also cooked just right with a decent japanese style curry on top (though perhaps not enough of the actual curry).
at $10 a pop it's a little pricey, but I think it's worth it.  this is probably the best katsu curry I've had in the city.

I'll be back to try the katsudon, my japanese food staple.  the una-tama don (freshwater eel and eggs, steamed over rice) special was PERFECT.  I know their katsudon has gotta be done right.
author: Fong L.

description:
Muracci's has given me an Obama-like patience for what is an unqualified operational nightmare. Their process needs a major overhaul- they routinely mess up orders, sometimes completely forgetting them. In fact, my longest total wait was over 40 minutes- and that's when I called it in.  
I think getting pissed off at them is almost an initiation ritual. Watching the massive wrecks and tempers flare has become a form of entertainment during the insane waits. When a person's brows furrow and lips twitch after being told that their order isn't ready after 15 minutes but they still stick around, it's kind of a "welcome to the club".
Why put up with it?
Because the one and only thing they manage to do right is the food.   As we know, their curry  is exactly perfect (and katsu too, I hear), vegetables are perky, and even their tofu (something I never order anywhere else) are simultaneously crisp and tender; like pillows for little baby angels. 
After a while, one realizes the futility of getting agitated... when I'm in the mood, I have to do a quick patience-budget check. Surprisingly, I'm willing to suck it up from time to time.
Now I've conditioned my mind to blank out after I order. When I come to, I usually find myself back at my desk eating, with no recollection of the intervening 30 minutes.

Hint: Order, then leave; go for a walk. and always, ALWAYS, re-check your order AT the restaurant. Calling in an order is useless unless you do it before noon.

If patience is a problem, go to sushi bay a few doors down. Not as good (but not bad either), but better than angry, and it can offset some of the japo-curry craving.
author: Edward P.

description: My boyfriend has been raving about a Japanese curry house near his work. When I was in the area, we decided to go there for lunch. The establishment is very small. The shape of an L for customers to sit on bar stools or to stand, waiting for their orders. I had the pork katsu. WOW! The meat was perfect, it didnt have that over fried taste to it where it makes you feel gross or unhealthy afterwards. The meat was just right, not dry as it may be tricky to order pork when going out to eat. The curry is given to you in a small round, plastic container 1/4 filled. You can either pour the curry on top or dip your meat in the sauce. I like to do a combination. I pour the curry onto my rice and dip my meat in the sauce. MMMMMmm. The curry was not to heavy with robust flavors. It was perfect in a sense that you were not sick of it after a few bites. It came came with a small container of pickled cabbage and also some chopped red-colored ginger. Great compliments!
author: Becky Q.

description: Curry was flavourless by US or Japanese standards. And, its weak on the toppings (pickles, etc). A Japanese curry should be thicker and should offer more ingredients. However, this was closer to a kind of "brown spiced water" on rice rather than a curry.
author: David P.

description: I was a little disappointed of this place because I expected more for a $10 lunch box. I order the salmon curry, and it was really only salmon + curry + rice... with a pinch of pickles. The curry sauce was delicious, and the fish was pretty fresh... However, I don't think I would pay $10 for that again. Maybe when I'm really craving for Japanese style curry... but still... maybe I'll order something else next time. Seriously, I rather have a smaller piece of salmon in exchange for some veggies... and speaking of veggies, there is only one vegetarian dish. Everything else got some kind of fish stock in it.
author: Bee T.

description:
I'd been hoping to try Muracci's Japanese Curry and Grill since its opening and have tried hard to make its hours.  Unfortunately, they're never open weekends and they close at 6pm, which makes coming here difficult for me since I don't work in the area.  So when I finally got the chance to try them, I rushed over as fast as I could.

Muracci's has a surprsingly extensive menu, with noodle soups, lunch specials, and of course, the curries.  I intially wanted the katsu curry, but instead opted for the regular chicken curry, which I mistakenly ordered spicy, rather than mild, which would have allowed the order to be filled immediately.  Instead, I waited a good 10 minutes for my spicy chicken curry, which apparently is a much shorter wait than during peak hours (I went at about 1:30 pm).  For less than $8, you get a good amount of steamed white rice, a little portion of tasty pickles and a separately packaged hefty portion of boneless chicken pieces (both dark and white meat) in a somewhat spicy curry sauce.  I loved that the curry wasn't placed all over the rice- it allowed you to control exactly how much curry you put on your rice.  The pickles that came with the dish were wonderful- I just wish that I could have had some more of them.  

Overall, while I was charmed by the owners and how authentic it felt, I wasn't completely blown away by the curry.  I think that the sauce was great- it was definitely vibrant with spices and spicy enough to require drinking some water, but my choice of protein probably wasn't best, as I'm used to eating Japanese-style curry with katsu.  My fault, yes, but I didn't like the chicken curry all that much.  3 stars for a good meal- I'm reserving more stars until I get the chance to try it again, especially the katsu curry.
author: Angela H.

description: Can I just say YUMS!  I love their chicken katsu curry.  The portions are good, the curry is delish (get spicy if you can handle it) and the katsu isn't too oily and just the right amount of crispy.  Once I got the plain chicken curry in an attempt to be *healthy*, and while good, it just wasn't the same.  Go hard or go home.  You will be stuffed.  The place is always busy so I recommend calling in your order in advance if you don't have much time to wait.
author: Sara T.

description: Very good katsu with an almost as good curry.  Definitely worth the trip and short 15-20 minute wait in line that moves fast.  Wish there was more of a seating area but maybe that's the price of good curry.
author: Yahoo S.

description:
#16 On the "Big Eat SF" list  - Katsu Curry

very crowded, not much room to sit...but then again, in this area, most people get to-go. if you're meeting someone, get in line, and better yet, order for them!  a lot of staff crammed into a tiny spot to make your meal. took about 15 min. not that i expected it would be 2 min. it's made FOR you!

pretty good curry. enough of a serving to last you two meals; though hard to transport curry long term.

would have been much better on a cold day...
author: S V.

description:
solid. katsu curry was delicious :9 even though it was packed around noon, i only waited about 15 minutes for my food. mild curry wasn't too spicy. chicken katsu was hot and crispy. i'll definitely come back for the katsudon.

not good for big parties. there is one table that seats 2 and 7-8 bar stools. the owner is really nice.
author: B Y.

description: Bland. Much better offerings elsewhere in the city. I guess it's for the work lunch crowd that's looking for a break from Chipotle, it's ok. However if you're looking for a proper meal, this is not the place to go.
author: Andy L.

description: Love the katsu curry and the ebi fry.  I like the fact that when you order to go, the curry comes in a separate container.  Comes w/ your choice of brown or white rice.  2 thumbs up!
author: Dorothy L.

description:
I'm not going to be particularly elaborate in this review.

However, suffice it to say, I lived in Tokyo for 8 years, so curry snob or not, I think I know good Japanese curry.  And Murraci's has good Japanese curry!

Easily the best Japanese curry I've had in California (northern and southern) and the best Japanese food available in the Financial District.

Minus one star (maybe unfairly) for higher prices than I like to pay for lunch (comes out to about $10-$11 after a beverage and taxes).

I'm a fan and a regular when I'm in the Financial District and am feeling like Japanese food and not in a penny-pinching mood.
author: Chris S.

description:
chicken katsu curry, brown rice, get it spicy hot, add some vegetables = good, filling, reasonable lunch.

order online in advance to avoid the line.
author: Nedra D.

description: Hands down for some real Japanese home made curry!  Love the tofu curry udon soup.  Comes in mild, med or hot.  Line gets long during rush hours so either call in advance or go before noon.
author: Uinii H.

description: I have kind of become addicted to the chicken and vegetable curry ramen. I stick with the drill of calling ahead and I'm not disappointed. The ingredients taste really fresh.
author: Greenballoon X.

description: I have not written a single review since I signed up for Yelp, but felt compelled to write this one.  These guys make excellent Japanese curry.  I had the Tonkatsu curry and it was definitely one of the better take-out lunches I've had in a while.  Also great that they offer brown rice at no extra cost.  Stay away from their bottled drinks though (bottled green tea was $2.75)...
author: Roy N.

description:
this is the best place to get japanese curry dishes this side of van ness street. a really great lunch option if you work in FiDi near kearney street.  the curry is delicious with options from mild to spicy, and there's a lot of variety in the kinds of curry entrees and non-curry japanese dishes. 

i have my usuals - the express chicken curry and the katsu don.  the express chicken curry comes with sides of pickled vegetables that really puts the finishing touch on a curry dish. you can also choose between white or brown rice.  the great thing about the express curry is that you order it and they serve it to you ASAP (they post a "express curry" policy in the restaurant so you'll see what i mean).  

the katsu don... well... i really like this dish but because i've had it so many times, sometimes it doesn't turn out so well.  the egg can be a bit runny occasionally and the pork katsu sometimes looks either overcooked or undercooked.  i still recommend it, but be sure to order it either before or after the lunch rush, because i think they get so busy during the lunch rush they might get a bit careless about the quality of the dish.

the reason i cannot give this place 5 stars is because it gets SO crazy during the lunch hour.  i refuse to go there after 12PM or before 1:30PM.  It's that popular, which means it must be pretty good, but it's SO annoying to have to wait 20 minutes to get your food.  the place is small so don't bother to eat in.  another thing that annoys me is the service.  they're really nice but inefficient in their service.  sometimes i think they have one person taking orders and ringing up the register AND prepping the food.  they need a more organized way of serving... sometimes i think the delay in getting my food is really their inefficiency rather than the crowds.  i HIGHLY RECOMMEND calling in your order.... or just avoid the lunch hour rush.

a big plus for using biodegradable/compostable take-out containers.  a minus for not taking amex.  a plus for having weekly lunch specials so you can try something different that's not on the regular menu.  prices are pretty decent... express curry is about $7 and the average dish is about $8-9.
author: Christy I.

description: If you are craving Japanese curry, you'll love this place. Authentic and Japanese run. I would give it 5 stars but their wait is horrible at peak lunch hours.
author: brandon m.

description: After reading the article in The Chronicle I ventured out to this small but incredible place.  There was no large sign advertising this place, but I found it right away due to the long line of people that had wrapped around the door outside.  I waited for 1 hour.....but IT WAS SO WORTH THE WAIT!  The curry was delicious!  Just like they make it in Japan.  I had my order with brown rice and it came with my favorite pickles as well.  The wait was long (I'm assuming there were many people like me that read the Chronicle article and came out as well today) and the place was very small, but overall they staff (all Japanese) were very friendly and moved the process along as fast as they could.  I will for sure be coming back and bringing my friends/co-workers/boyfriend with me next time!  Thank you Muracci, for a wonderful meal!!!!!
author: Yael G.

description:
Horrible service!  

Knowing this place gets packed around noon, I ran over quickly and arrived at 11:15 am.  There were 4 people ahead of me already in line.  It took them 20 minutes to take those 4 people's order.  After I ordered which was around 11:35 am, I walked over to next store and ordered for a co-worker's of mine.  I got back around 11:45 am and waited till 11:55 am.  I kept trying to ask the cashier if my order was ready, but he wouldn't help me because he was taking other people's orders.  Finally, after 15 minutes of taking other people's orders, he talked to me and i had asked if my order was ready.  He checked on my order number and said that someone already had picked up my order.  Well, how could that be??!!??  I never picked up anything.  As I stood there angry and hungry..., I looked at the clock and realized it was already 12:15 p.m.  They did not offer me any compensation for my time, but just had told me they could make another for me.  I didn't want to stand around for another 30 minutes, so i just requested for my refund and left.  

Never again will I go there.  They need a better system.
author: Helen O.

description: Yum! I was looking for a Japanese restaurant and stumbled upon this place. I had the Katsu Curry, a fav dish of mine. It was delicious! Although, I'm sick and my taste buds are not working at their full potential. Still, I'm sure it would have been all the better if they were. Definitely, worth another trip back.
author: Shar T.

description: Absofrickinlutely fabulous. I have a very high curry standard. I love how this a mom and pop operation . I felt like I was entering their home and their we're gracious enough to cook for me. I was impressed they offered brown rice at no extra cost. I love ogling all the goodies in their case. The curry had just the right amount of spice and kick and the portions were so generous. The lady that prepared our curry was so friendly. I told her this is the best curry I've had in a long time. And I really meant it. I can't wait to have lunch here again.
author: Sophia C.

description:
Can't let my friend (who eagerly recommended this place to me) know i gave only a 3...

The curry sauce - ichiban!  HOWEVER, there is not enough curry.  Com'on for $9, I think i deserve at least enough curry to go with my rice.  Extra curry costs $1.5...  

Ate there twice.  1st time - curry beef - a lot of rice, but not a lot of beef.  The plastic container (for beef + curry) is 2/3 empty!  My friend had the Katsu and was nice enough to offer me a piece.  It was a good 1/2 inch by 1.5 inch piece, but it turned out to be just a big chunk of fat...

2nd time - chicken katsu - chicken tasted very good, but again, I ran out of curry with 1/3 of the rice left.  

Enough complaint about the curry volume.  What can I say, could have been an easy 4 or even 5...
author: E H.

description: Oh My God!!!  I love this place!! It has the most authentic Japanese style curry EVER!  Sure, it takes about half your lunch hour to get your lunch, but it's well worth the wait.  Plus, you can call in your order for pick-up to avoid waiting in their tiny restaurant.  But trust me, the curry makes up for anything bad you or anyone else have to say about Muracci's.
author: Lu G.

description: Good tasty Japanese curry Lunch!! I used to stop by once in a while when I was craving curry rice for lunch when I worked in the neighborhood. I loved that they offer brown rice because not many restaurants downtown give you that option. The curry is also home-made and not from a mix which makes it really yummy. My favorite curry is the tofu curry with extra vegetables and spinach to get healthy veggies at lunch. I need to go back again soon!!
author: Lisa M.

description: Best katsu/curry! Yes, a bit pricey and it can be sloooow BUT it is worth it - especially on a cold day (we have many in SF). Take your food to go - there isn't much room between the counter seating and the lines. I never thought I would like brown rice - but it's pretty good especially when drowned in curry sauce.
author: Joy A.

description: Best katsu curry that I've had outside of Japan (yes, I lived there for two years, so my taste buds are more accurate than other "Japanese aficionados"). Medium spice actually has some kick to it (no white man spiciness level here!). The shop really is a hole in the wall, and if it isn't during the lunch time rush, one could easily miss it. Because it is so small, it's best to go here before 12 or after 1. They get so busy during lunch that they don't even pick-up their phone, so there's no "cutting" the line! Orders take about 10-15 minutes when they're busy.
author: Rod M.

description: Easily the most popular Japanese curry I've had in San Francisco. Great sauce. The wait can be long, but I've found it to be worth it.
author: Angelo F.

description: Average curry that you can make at home with store bought curry roux.  Not that it tastes bad but I was definitely expecting more from this place with such high reviews.  My friend who also ordered curry was highly disappointed.  If you just want to have your Japanese curry fix then this is the place to go but don't expect something special.
author: J D.

description: It's an awkward space to eat in, but they make your curry to order, and it comes out fresh. The tonkatsu is amazingly juicy, and I liked that they had brown rice as an option. I had enough food to take some back to the office for my late afternoon hunger pangs.
author: Angela X.

description: I had been wanting to try here since I've heard many good things from friends, but was very disappointed. I ordered the beef curry and I usually love Japanese curry, and I in face did like the curry sauce, but the beef was sorely lacking. First of all, there were only like 8  small pieces, which seemed like a tiny portion, but much more disappointing was that two of the pieces were completely inedible and were actually 100% fat pieces. Another 3 pieces were some sort of meat that looks like it came from a cow, but definitely was not a piece of regular stew beef. Not sure what it was, but had a very funny texture and psychologically my mind was screaming, "Yuck!"  Only 2-3 pieces were regular stew beef, which is what I was expecting. Basically I ate curry sauce over rice, which was not worth $7.50. Next time I'm definitely going to Delica in the Ferry Building for my Japanese curry.
author: Jeff L.

description: Murracci's is pretty good, particularly the fried curries (e.g., fried ebi and katsu curry). However, they are ridiculously busy and that compromises the quality. I called in a food order for chicken curry at 11:20 am (well before the lunchtime rush) and they somehow forgot to include the chicken. By the time I figured it out at 12 pm, no one was answering the phone and the lunch line was super long to get in. Really disappointing.
author: Ray N.

description: The service here is sooo great. They are incredibly warm and welcoming, it's great. While I was waiting, one of the women was singing and she has a beautiful voice (I hope it also means she is happy and enjoys her job).  I got the katsu curry with spinach and brown rice and tea. The tea smelled so good.  We went during dinner (they close at 6pm since they are busiest at lunch), which was nice to skip the crowd.
author: Nicole D.

description:
best curry in the bay area. 
their curry takes 2 days to make, and you can definitely tell. i hate box curry and instant food, so this is the only curry i will eat.

i have never had a bad experience here.
they close at 6, but i came in once at 5:57 and the man working made all my food and waited for me to finish with a smile on his face.

homemade croquette and curry pan are great, and the girls behind the counter are always kind and chatty. it's cute hearing them speak in japanese too.
i used to work nearby and i took all my food togo. even during the lunch rush, it was always ready in about 10-15 minutes.
author: Lizzie O.

description:
This place is the real deal, better than bukkake, Japanese curry house. I must admit: I was concerned after visiting the first time. It must have taken 45 minutes to get my damn food, but then I ate that stuff and damn it. It reminded me of real Japanese food. I felt better than Godzilla after destroying Tokyo. 

The food ain't some fake shitz served by Chinese people or whatever. To avoid the long wait, I call in my order and each time that I've arrived they've had my order ready. That said, I really hope they are quicker with counter orders now that they've been opened for a month because that's their only flaw. 

These yuppie Fidi people aren't going to tolerate 45 minute waits when they have to get back to the office to bill more hours for The Man.  Then again, it takes them so long to make that shitz cause they make it from scratch. Also, one other problem, once when I tried to call in my order I got a busy tone for like 15 minutes and had to give up. Work on that and you'll be more popular than a white man in Roppongi.
author: Hmmm W.

description: Staff is great. Food is better. Real authentic Japanese style curry. I've only had the pork and chicken katsu because they're so good! Also don't forget to have the UCC coffee and calpico drinks...BOMB.
author: Leo S.

description: A very awesome Japanese curry.  I had the chicken curry ramen (hot).  Hot isn't that hot, really.  It's like a medium (at best!) at a Thai or Korean place.  Anyhow the food is great and the people are friendly, but the service was so, so slow.  Definitely not a good choice for people in a rush.
author: Eric W.

description: Great Curry! You have to wait a bit, while they make it, but if you not in the hurry - it worse waiting for!!!! Perfect in the day time!
author: Vera S.

description:
as far as lunch places go, i'd eat here every day.  upon hearing about muracci's i was intrigued.  i'd never heard of japanese curry before and was eager to try it out.  my first dish there continues to be a favorite of mine, katsu curry.  the katsu is cooked perfectly and is very tasty and to top that off, literally, the curry sauce is just outstanding.  3 different spice levels can be ordered and i prefer hot.  it's just the right mix of flavor and heat.  i've tried the chicken katsu curry a number of times and enjoyed it but not as much as the regular katsu.

since this is becoming a staple lunch joint for me, i can't wait to try all the other types of dishes they have!

a word of advice about eating @ muracci's.  if you're not getting there by 11am, you're not gonna get a place to sit and eat so do what me and my co-workers do.  call your order in and walk straight to the counter and pick up your food.  you may get some glares of death for the insanely long line but it's worth it!
author: Swarup B.

description: Muracci,s is located in a great location for lunch takeout. .  This area of downtown San Francisco offers sit down restaurants that cater to hedge fund managers and  venture capitalists but the office lunch crowd is challenged to find good food for a fair price.  Muracci,s is an option, with most entrees under ten dollars.  I have tried Muracci,s several times. Chicken Ton Katsu curry, chicken curry and beef curry were my orders...all take out and all about ten dollars each.  With the exception of the Ton Katsu I received what I considered a minimal amount of protein and a big pile of rice and curry sauce. Even the Ton Katsu had a minimal amount of meat.  The beef, which was advertised as tender was quite tough....stew meat. Four small pieces. The chicken curry was ok but also meager...5 bites. I consider all of Muracci,s entrees as appetizers with lots of rice and sauce.   If you want heavy carbs this may be the place but I think ten bucks for a few small pieces of meat is poor value.
author: William H.

description: work near them got the Chicken Katsu Curry Medium Hot with brown rice and it's the bomb. Lots of food fast friendly service. Like It. Keep it Up.
author: Dave G.

description: Muracci's has decent curry but it's a bit watery. I'm used to thicker curry but Muracci's isn't bad. The lunch line is pretty long but it moves quickly. There are only a few seats in the place so this is not a good place for groups (actually, unless you're lucky, it's really not a good place to sit and eat at all). The Boyfriend tried the Chicken Katsu Curry and I had the Vegetable and Tofu Curry with brown rice. The rice was a little hard but the curry was tasty. I loved the vegetables - different types of bell peppers with carrots and broccoli. The Chicken Katsu Curry was tasty - I would recommend getting the curry hot (in terms of spiciness) because it gives the otherwise slightly bland / watery curry some flavor.
author: Christine P.

description: Muracci's pork katsu with brown rice and spicy curry may be my favorite thing to order at lunch in the City. Best to go before 11:30 or after 2:00 if you want to grab one of the few stools.
author: Mike L.

description: Came here on a Friday at 12:45 for their famous Katsu Curry. Be prepared to wait AWHILE. It took me about 20 minutes in line just to place my order and another 20 minutes to get my food. The food ended up being pretty good, the katsu was nice and crisp and hot and the curry had a really nice kick to it but was it worth all the wait? I'm going to say no....
author: Cathy T.

description: I was disappointed. The pork cutlet was too thick. Japanese cutlets are always sliced thin and pounded thinner. The curry was more hot pepper hot than curry (whatever that is) hot. They messed up my order and gave me that horror of horrors --brown rice. Anyone who eats brown rice at a Japanese restaurant is a yabanjin.
author: Corwin S.

description: This place is just okay. Definitely not worth the line out the door.
author: Stevonne R.

description: Had the urge for a pie from Kearney St pies and found it replaced by this restaurant.  The first time I went I got a lunch set with Agedashi Tofu. This was a lot of food for one person; soup, salad, entree, and rice.  Not the best Agedashi i've had, but pretty damn good. The second time i went I got a curry dish that wasn't as exciting.  And both times I thought it took a little longer to get my food then it should at a usual take out spot.  But, it's a rare treat to find a Japanese restaurant with so many veggie options.   I'll be back, but I think I'll probably phone my order ahead next time.
author: Rob F.

description:
Definitely one of the best places (if not THE best place) for Japanese curry in the bay area.  Full bodied, lots of flavor, a very zesty curry that comes from simmering in a blend of spices for hours--it's not a surprise that they've become so successful in such a short span of time.

I definitely recommend their specials: recently it's been a Japanese eggplant curry with ground beef, other times it's been something else on a bed of ramen.

Also, heads up to people who don't want to wait: show up 5-10 minutes BEFORE they open at 11am.  A couple of weeks ago I showed up just as they opened the doors and within a few minutes 10+ people showed up.  It was crazy.
author: P B.

description: I was a little hesitant to give this place a try.  I was on my lunch hour and the line was out the door, the restaurant was packed with people standing through the length of the place that was lined with bar stools and t a long table against a mirror so you can people watch while you eat.  My coworker told me it was really good, and so I decided to go for it.  I ordered the weekly special which was advertised as being ready right away with no wait.  It was quite good, the curry was rich and spicy.  It had ground beef, onions, eggplant and tomato in it.  They give you a choice of brown or white rice, a small container of pickled cabbage and a pinch of red ginger? The curry was in a plastic bowl which I think was a good idea so the rice would not soak it up.  As for the rice...they really skimp on the rice and charge you an extra buck plus some cents for more rice.  The dish already cost $10, I think it was a bit on the high side for what you get, but considering the location I'm sure they have to make up for the cost of rent.  After I ate my lunch, I ordered my bf an order of the pork katsu to go, it took 15 minutes for my order...I guess that is good that it probably was cooked to order, but just keep in mind that you will have to wait longer if you cooked something that needs be be fried, verses a curry dish that they just add veggies or tofu to. I also got the fried curry bread.  There were two types vegetable and beef, all the beef was gone and I wondered if the veggie was not as good...it was actually VERY good and pretty filling. They have them out under a heated lamp by the cashier, I noticed a lot of the people who were waiting for their food munched on theirs as an appetizer...good idea!
author: Charla M.

description: Good spot for lunch, tiny, busy, call in ahead of time if you can. Full of techies, beam me up!!!
author: G K.

description: was never a fan of katsu cause restaurants would always serve pork with all the muscles and ligaments...this katsu was great!  curry was great too...i'm gonna have to order extra curry next time and drink it up with a straw!
author: ayyyych m.

description: Four starts only, since the place it small and packed on business hours, lunch time between 1-3 busy busy, no seat and slow service, therefore, try to avoid a visit during those hours. The place is very popular and provide authentic Japanese food and drinks, I had the Japanese Tea and Rail Tickets, Ebi Fry, white rice and more, like the place like the price, good for lunch and dinner.
author: Stephen W.

description:
in a hurry and want some curry?

muracci to the rescue! (is that a japanese name?)

long menu of options to mix in your mild, medium, or spicy curry, including tempura, vegetarian, katsu, and poultry. thank you for offering brown rice and little sweet nothings like lupicia tea, japanese sponge cake, and fruit! wee! my pick of vegetarian medium and green tea cake hit the spot on a hungry friday afternoon.  the curry tastes just as you'd expect. 

maybe when it gets a bit more popular, they'll consider expanding their space so it doesn't feel like a curry ER.  so far, it's not built for eating in. 

at long last, i have been saved by the curry doctor. m.d. (much deliciousness).
author: Diana L.

description: This place is solid. It is the best japanese food in Fidi. The curry tastes just right for japanese curry. I also like how they give you white and brown rice options. The tonkatsu is usually deep-fried to perfection. The only down side is the wait, so call ahead!
author: P L.

description: I was introduced to this place by a couple of friends when we met up for lunch during work, and I'm pretty surprised!  The food was really good and for about $10, I got a very filling katsu curry lunch with a drink.  I've never really had curry with Japanese food but the way they make it fused two different types of foods together into a curiously recommendable meal.  I probably would never have come here if it weren't for my friends because the place doesn't look like a "Eat Here!" atmosphere... unless you're talking about the waiting line that goes way out the door during lunch hour.  Only piece of advice, get a bigger place! Your food is pretty good but you gotta give people a place to sit.
author: James A.

description: I love eating here for lunch. I usually order the Katsu, medium or hot curry, which is fantastic! It reminds me of my time in Okinawa. The food was the best there! My only issue, like many of the places in FiDi, the prices are a bit high for a meal like this. I would say $7 max, but at least the portions are hefty.
author: Stevro L.

description: Great curry.  And great to have a choice between brown rice and white rice.  The only thing is the wait but it is well worth it for some fresh good food.  Definitely reccomended.  I wish they would get a bigger place or open another store because it is obvious there is more than ample demand.
author: Diego C.

description: oh gentle japanese soul behind the counter, why do you torture me with the sweet sweet smell of japanese curry, your kind smile belies the agony of the waiting, you already checked my order: tonkatsu curry with white rice, why am I staring at these enigmatic pastries in the glass case? And then it's over, a white plastic bag is handed to me and I rush back to my office, lock the door, and the next 35 minutes is food porn. next week: tonkatsu!
author: Alex C.

description: This place reminds me of Coco's in Okinawa when I visited my brother in the military. He was always talking about THE curry place and when he took me there, he was right to be always talking about it. It was one-of-a-kind, until my running in to Muracci's. How I never noticed this place that's only 2 blocks down from where I work, I don't know. The food's tasty here, and I love the speedy transaction. Yay! I'm a fan.
author: Ava C.

description: I stopped by and had the chicken curry. Very good. Very cheap. The restaurant is clean. They scored 100 on the inspection report. The location is convienent. The seating is basic and somewhat cramped. Check their hours carefully. I went for an early dinner on a Tuesday. They closed at 6:00PM. Oh yeah, the service Five on a scale of one - five. I will be back.
author: Top Cat S.

description: Great katsu with hot curry! Yum!  The food is always consistent and the protions are fair. If you like Japanese curry, you will need to try this place. I do not think they are open on the weekends though.
author: Marty M.

description: OH  MY GOD!!! most amazing restaurant . you can literally taste the LOVE they put in to make the meals. owned by the most wonderful family that wants to share their love for the japanese cuisine they make. I recommend the Katsu Curry! a must have.
author: Sho M.

description: I had a serious craving for Japanese Curry. Online 7X7 magazine rated this place as the best. The reviewer suggested getting medium because spicy was way too hot. WHAT? I arrived just about half an hour before closing so I didn't get to try everything I wanted: Chicken Katsu, Croquettes, but I did try their Weekly Special which was Seafood Curry and their Vegetarian Curry (minus the lotus root which they were also out of anyway, plus potatoes and spinach). I asked two patrons who were waiting if the curry really was hot because I love hot foods. The first guy said it was his first time as well but his experience is that Japanese curries are generally not very hot. The other guy shook his head - not at all. I ordered both dishes HOT. They were not - with one actually being milder than the other. Overall the food was fine but I didn't love the flavor of the curry. The special wasn't very special but the veggie was good - just NOT hot. :( The pickled red veggie was tasty to me but the pickled cabbage wasn't. The staff/cook were very nice. Not too sure I'd go back. looking for a better place. It was easy to park at 6:45 on a Monday night though!
author: A Z.

description:
the FiDi isn't necessarily known for interesting or varied cuisine; that's why muracci's is such a refreshing place to lunch for the 9-to-5 masses.

and boy, do the masses come out for muracci's. there is usually a line out the door come lunch time, so expect a good 15-minute wait just to get your order (but at least this means that your food is made fresh when you order). people usually take food to-go, so there are usually a few stools open if you wanted to eat in.

the food is all quite competent. the chicken katsu is crunchy. the curry sauce is interesting. the portions are what you should expect for shelling out $9. the curry could have been a bit more flavorful, but i'm probably used to spicier/stronger foods. a solid 3 stars, with an extra star for location.
author: Maveric V.

description: If you're really hugry and the regular curry lunch isn't enough...my advice is to order a regular non-curry lunch set (comes w/ salad and appetizer) (around $8.50)  and extra curry sauce ($1.50).
author: J B.

description: The food is AMAZING but you have to wait about 20 minutes to get your food! definitely call in first and then do a pick-up. the udon is off the hook and I can't wait to try more!
author: Natasha F.

description: Lunchtime lines here are crazy. This place is really small so i would suggest to order prior and pick up. if you do plan on eating here there are only few bar stools but wouldn't recommend eating here. i usually order either chicken, pork, veggies with your choice of curry mild , medium, or hot spicy curry. their curry is simmered with veggies, herbs, and spices, for 2 days resulting in holly goodness. Comes with brown or white rice with pickled cabbages. Come before the noon rush. they only serve a certain amount of servings per day. Their daily special are a real treat. truly a mom and pop joint.
author: maria t.

description: Awesome Japanese Curry House. The place is very small so either get there early or late in the day to sit and eat. Their fried lotus root chips are pretty good. I highly recommend the Chicken Katsu Curry, best I've ever had.
author: Marco M.

description:
YWE (Yelping While Eating)
New to the FiDi, I decided to give Muracci's a try. Before reading on, the spoiler alert is this: the food is very good. Worth the wait...but that's where my only problem was.
I stood in line for a good 10 minutes. Placed order. Waited another 10 minutes. They called number 57 so I knew my order was next. For some reason though they called the next 3 orders by meal (Chicken Katsu, etc.) instead of the number. 3 Yups immediately grabbed them. One was my Chicken Katsu but one of them apparently ordered the same so she assumed it must have been hers. Oh well, rather than get in an argument over whose order it was (so third world!) I decided to "act British" - that would be politely staying the course while waiting. Big mistake. After a few more orders were handed off I finally decided to say something as by now I was sure the Yup had grabbed my lunch. Sure enough, they didn't see my #58 anywhere up on the ticket holder so they had to make my lunch all over gain. I didn't clock it but from but from the time I went in to the time I left (with a To Go order) was at least 30 minutes, possibly more like 40. I can't give it 5 stars for that.
The food though is pretty good. Chicken Katsu with a nice medium spiced curry sauced (simmers for two days apparently). They also give you a choice of brown rice which is really nice. Lots of tasty curries and udons on the menu (and even a few different varieties of rolls, like California, cucumber, etc.). I will definitely go back as the food is worth it, but I will either try to beat the maddening lunch rush or wait until it is over, never going during peak lunch hour again.

Update: True to my word I went this time a little after they opened at 11 (will never go during lunch rush again). Much better this time. Only a few other people in there. Wait time for food was about 10 min. but since it is all cooked to order this is ok. Brought a coworker who liked his meal a lot and said he would definitely go back. This place is a keeper.
author: Matt H.

description: Local cheap eat, nice comfort Asian food. Had the beef and veg udon curry, it was good.  Four stars for being tasty and cheap at the same time, minus 1 star for the open hours...I know its in the heart of the FiDi which explains this, but its a bummer for locals like me.
author: yolanda f.

description: Sure, you may have to wait forever before you can get your curry on during the weekday lunch hours, but remember: this place is open on Saturdays too! That's the day that I had my first encounter with this fine little establishment, with the tastiest katsu curry, dare I say, in the City! Prices are a little steep for what it is, but the quality of the food is worth it. Make sure to get brown rice for a healthy change!
author: Andrey C.

description: I have been here a couple times now and i love the simplicity of the menu and the food.  I thought the pork tonkatsu curry was awesome and i definitely recommend getting some veggies thrown in.
author: Katie M.

description: Katsu curry was really good.  Choice of brown or white rice, a very healthy alternative.  Wait is a bit long.  We waited 15 mins for our order.  NO AC, so be careful.   The curry sauce is really good w/ the rice.  I can never have enough.
author: AhLin C.

description: great jap curry. order over the phone to avoid having to wait half an hour in line. by the time you walk over to pick it up, it'll be sitting there on the side ready to go.
author: Greg H.

description:
The menu is fairly simple: a typical order is rice with meat (or veggies) and a choice of mild, medium, or spicy curry. I personally get mild, but I've heard complaints that the "spicy" level isn't taste-numbing enough. However, the curry sauce is absolute yum -- it's thick and savory like gravy and infused with aromatic curry spices.
