Couple that with deep fried meat (pork, chicken, shrimp, or salmon) and you've got yourself a full, tasty lunch for under $10. A non-curry item worth mentioning is the garlicky karaage (fried boneless chicken) which is served with some horseradish/wasabi dip on the side.

The shop is very tiny with only a few seats so prepare to order to-go. During peak lunch hours the wait might take up to 10-15 minutes. If you're in a rush, you can order from the express menu (beef or chicken with mild curry) and your order gets put at the front of the queue.

The staff are also very friendly and if you catch them during the later hours, you can even practice your Japanese.

Highly recommended and well worth my 4- or 5- block walk.
author: Benny T.

description: Muracci's serves up some great authentic Japanese curry, katsu, and various other tasty comfort foods. Yes, the place is tiny, the wait is long, but the curry is fabulous! Better than Delica rf-1 I'd say, although Delica has excellent rice and views. So If you work in the FiDi, well, I'm sorry, but at least you can get Muracci's takeout!
author: Will A.

description:
yes, the food is delicious. the wait, not as bad as everyone says. i guess it must suck to work hourly. i wouldn't reccomend this place if you have time constraints. the owners & employees are great. they hussle alot of curry within that lunch hour!

the customers consist of a long line of yuppies that are demanding and impatient. they expect perfect service while being indecisive at the front of the line and all for the $0 that they tip. but i won't take any stars off for that.......
author: Linda T.

description: Wow! This place is excellent! I'm glad to have found this little spot that's been open only for a few months. I had the chicken katsu curry. The portion was just enough, the pickled plums and cabbage balance out the spiciness very well. I'll be back tomorrow for their spicy tofu and ground beef special!
author: Alton Y.

description: Yum. Curry. One of my favorite comfort foods. Don't come here too late because they do run out. The regular katsu curry is great (I got the pork because the chicken sold out). The croquette was so-so. I noticed the seafood curry was only 15 servings a day.
author: Maximillian M.

description: Muracci's is like the Blue Bottle (http://www.yelp.com/biz/blue-bottle-coffee-co-san-francisco-7#hrid:hTi6n9MiPPSDmx-ys6C9cw) of Japanese curry, without the attitude--insanely tasty but also insanely slow to serve up the goods.  It's a bit infuriating, but if you have a full hour (or more) to kill for lunch, it is definitely worth the wait.  If you don't, figure out some other trick to get your curry fix--either by going early or calling in your order.  I don't have anything else to add that hasn't already been said--this place rocks (slowly).
author: Sharyn F.

description: I like the fact that Japanese curry is so different from Indian and Thai curry. This place really showcases the uniqueness of curry, and I equally liked it as well. As for the prices, it could be a lot cheaper, but since it's in the financial district, I guess their prices are cheaper compared to others.
author: Alex Y.

description: The curry here is pretty good but the wait is loonngggg....What I liked: they had good variety of options and they even had udon as well. I had the beef and veg udon. I had expected the curry consistency to be thick - just like what they would serve over the rice but it was watery. Maybe this is just their style but the taste was pretty good and the beef portion was pretty generous. BF had tonkatsu and it was a tasty thick fat portion but I think they are a tad stingy on the curry cos I would prefer my rice to be DRENCHED in curry..not just wading in curry! What I did not like was the restaurant was pretty cramped and could only seat about 10 people (mostly counter seating) so when you are eating, you are elbow to elbow with someone else...not very comfortable. Other than that, I think this is a great lil joint in the financial district!
author: Topazskye L.

description:
I went here with my friend last week Wednesday around noon for the first time. I heard about this place from SFGate and how people are raving about it.. So finally, I am writing about this place and came into conclusion that it's not worth coming back. We waited in line for about 7 minutes and still have to wait for another 10-15 minutes while they cook your food. There goes my lunch hour! 

The food is bland, the curry sauce is nothing to brag about and it is not worth the wait.
author: Lileth M.

description:
Serious downhill alert.

Yesterday, I would have rated Muraccis five stars for their Katsu Curry, which always consisted of an exquisitely lean cut of pork fried to a tee with just the right amount of breading to make it crisp and juicy.

Today was the first time I went in about a month.  I was mildly peeved when the counterperson forced me to order brown rice, claiming the white was sold out.  However, then I saw other people after me ordering white rice, so I had to approach the counter again for "permission" to change my order to white rice.

When I got the katsu back to the office, I was extremely peeved that the piece of pork I got was far too thick and riddled throughout with unpleasant fat and grizzle.  Moreover, the breading was very thick and mealy beneath the surface.  The sauce also seemed gummy and gloppy, for some reason.

In the past, I admired Muraccis for doing one dish PERFECTLY every time, even if it was the most expensive takeout lunch in my rotation of lunch spots.  Now, they will have to prove a lot to earn back my business.
author: Andrew S.

description: Check your order (open each container) before leaving the restaurant. We ordered take out and when we got back to our hotel room discovered that my wife's container only had brown rice--not the vegetable curry with tofu that she had ordered and paid for. My chicken katsu was tasty and perfectly crispy.
author: Ken B.

description: I came here this morning to check it off my 7x7 list.  Woohoo 7 out of 100 complete! Slooooowly making my way through it all.  I couldn't find any parking in the area so I stopped out front in the passenger unloading zone (shhhh! =X) and called in my order.  It was done within 10 minute and I weaved my way through the TINY restaurant among the sea of people.  For $9, it was a pretty good meal in the financial district that left me happy.  It's a huge dish with rice, katsu, some cabbage, and a containter of curry to drench the food with.  The curry reminded me of the boxed curry that I had made the previous week and didn't impress me too much.  However, the pork cutlet was incredibly moist and savory as other reviewers had mentioned.  Not at all like the dry katsu I've had elsewhere.  We shared the dish and it was plenty for two.  I'd probably come back only if I were craving this meal but other than that it's a try a least once dish!
author: Nicole G.

description: I cant even begin to describe the delight this place brings me! What an amazing lunch option in the financial district! I couldn't recommend this place more. Katsu Curry Chicken is dreamy! GO GO GO!
author: Dani B.

description:
Definitely a 4.5. I had to take 0.5 off because they only have 15 servings of specials every day...that's harsh! Esp if you are trying to avoid the crowds by eating later in the day. If you get caught in the crowd it can be 30 min wait and half your lunch hour is gone.

I use to go here once a week and the even cooks know me. I am trying to save money so I am not eating out so much. But I love the chicken katsu. They make it when you order it. 

I bring all my out of town guest here because the people are nice and the food is good.
author: Sylvia H.

description: i have only had the curry dishes, and they do not disappoint.  do call in your order if you're short for time.  the curry is so delicious with layers of flavors.  do add the egg with your dishes!  i didn't feel medium spicy was that spicy, but then again i like to burn my mouth to bits.
author: Sheri N.

description: I've been looking for a Japanese place near my office downtown for the last 8 years I've lived in the city that had Katsu Curry and Korokke on their menu. I think my wait is now over. Yes, you have to wait in a line because people think it's yummy also. But patience, grasshopper, will reap you crunchy juicy katsu smothered with their thick curry sauce. I like their Hot curry.  It's not "thai" hot which can render your tastebuds in an inferno, but it's a beautiful sweet spice.
author: Clodel G.

description: The curry here is good, but the wait is a little long.  So as long as you don't mind waiting.  Also I wish they would give you a little more curry.  I ordered the Chicken Curry with vegetables and boiled egg.  I wanted spinach, but they were out.  I would eat here again, but the wait is too long for my lunch hour.
author: Peter W.

description: I ate here recently. Its so good its not even funny.
author: Ish H.

description: So yummy!  In SF for business trip and  found this place near the hotel I was staying.  So sad  there is not a restaurant like this in Houston :(
author: HM H.

description:
Ok, it's been a year since I went here and since it's been getting such stellar reviews I wanted to try it again.

It got worse. I ordered at 12:50, I got my curry at 1:30. I knew there was going to be a wait, but 40 minutes is ridiculous unless they warn me it's going to take so long. I received no such warning when I ordered my meal. I could have waited 20 minutes without one, but 40 minutes is just not the kind of service I'd expect from any restaurant.  

The curry had no vegetables and as for flavor it is pretty meh. Seriously, the food here is what you can get at any super market that sells the tiny bricks of Golden Curry. You're pretty much paying 10 bucks for the equivalent of Kraft macaroni and cheese.  They're giving you a 300% mark up because it's "convenient." 40 minutes of waiting is not convenient. 

This place even sucks compared to Matsuya in Japan. It is no Little Spoon or C&C Curry House. 

Everyone who is giving this place 4 stars+ is an idiot. 

I'll give it +1 star because the chicken katsu wasn't too dry. Otherwise, save your money, don't go to this place, and buy the curry yourself from the super market.
author: Will S.

description: I had been wanting to try this place on my lunch break for a couple of years now, but I never came around to it.  When I finally did, I was a bit underwhelmed.  I guess since I've just grown to love Tani's more home style curry so much, I'm a little biased.  Muracci's was by no means bad, but it just wasn't great.  Plus, they kinda skimped on the portions.  For a little less at Tani's, I was able to get twice as much.  Still though, it's a spot that I will hit up on occasion.
author: Joel J.

description: I love this place! This place is a hole-in-the-wall, but it does not prevent people from being frequent customers. I tried the medium curry beef and everything was perfect: texture of the beef and curry, and the amount of the beef curry in proportion to the rice. In my opinion, Muracci's is the best place in San Francisco for Japanese curry.
author: Gerry L.

description:
Wow that place was crowded! But now I know why.

I got the Katsu Curry and it was deelish! The curry was very nice and they packed it in a separate bowl for the to go order. The pork cutlet was some of the best katsu I've had! Even though I took it back to the office, it was pretty moist and tender but still crispy. I am very full.

My wait was pretty long, this was probably a 45 minute excursion to travel to Muracci, order, wait (had to have been 20 minutes or more) and walk back. But! I was not disappointed when it was time to dig in. Fresh, made to order food is worth the wait. And they spend 2 days making their curry! 20 hours to simmer!!

I'd say order by phone ahead of time, or FAX?? if you're old school. The phone seemed to be ringing the ENTIRE time I was there, which made me wonder if they even were answering it - because that line was never-ending and no one seemed to have a down moment. But a friend assured me she orders by phone and it is ready by the time she arrives.

They accept Visa and Mastercard.
author: Karen J.

description: This place is the bomb.  One recommendation - if you are short on time and want to avoid a potential long line at lunch, call in your order.    Never had a bad meal there and the food is always fresh.
author: Angie L.

description: soup nazi style line, but decent, cheap lunch
author: T L.

description: this place is a little gem in downtown sf.  The price is decent.  they give generous portion.  the karaage is sooo good.  :D   the  cashier was super friendly.
author: con c.

description: Compared to beef curry at On the Bridge, Delica-RF, and Osakaya, Muracci's had the sweetest sauce, driest beef and moderate portions (6 cubes of beef totaling about 6 cubic inches). Vegetables are an additional 50 cents. What I liked about this place was the option of having brown rice with the curry rather than the standard white. Fresh pickled veggies on the side. Seating is approx. 10 stools split amongst 2 counters. Very quick service - if you order mild beef curry - less than 5 minutes to get served on a Wednesday at 4pm.
author: Lum P.

description:
Tried this place twice. Once I ordered the Katsu Don and another time I tried their famous Pork Katsu Curry.  The food was edible, but nothing to write home about.  The curry was similar to the stuff you get from the box, again nothing special.   The Katsu Don was actually quite disgusting;  the egg was not fully cooked and the dish seriously lacked flavor.  

The portions are quite small and was expensive.  $9.51 for the Katsu Curry.  I want to be at least full, when I pay that much for lunch. 

I really wanted to like this place, since there are not many good Japanese spots in the Embarcedero .

I won't be coming back.
author: Gastronaut M.

description: I LOVE Muracci's! This is probably the only Japanese restaurant in SF that I can really say tastes like home. I've had their chicken curry and katsu curry and they have both been super great.
author: Tina B.

description:
Good curry and a nice lunch option to have downtown.

One has the impression of a family who woke up one day and decided that making Japanese curry is easy so why not sell it to Americans?  The serving/preparation process was a bit slow and work behind the counter looked a bit disorganized.  You might say it creates a bit of down home character, and that would be the optimistic description.  The salmon I ordered took so long that it seemed they went all the way to Hakodate to get it.  Still, I will return, but the speed will dictate that putting this down as a regular place to visit would probably be a bit frustrating.

So, could I possibly have the word "bit" any more times in such a short space?
author: Richard P.

description: The best curry and I have never been disappointed. Try this place soon and remember to order extra curry.
author: Ryan K.

description: Get take-out only, this place doesn't really have seating.  The salmon curry is A-MAZ-ING.  I would get my lunch-at-my-desk here every day if I could.
author: Sarah B.

description: I had the day off today and was looking for a place to have lunch and decided to stop by here after reading the reviews on yelp. I've been curious about Japanese curry but haven't had time to explore any of the curry places in the city till today. I'm a curry novice so I guess you should take my review with a grain of salt. I ordered the tofu and vegetable curry noodle soup with udon and a medium spiciness. It was quite tasty-- the curry was spicy enough for me, the tofu cubes were well-fried, the broth very thick and flavorful, and the noodles were nice and chewy. There were also perfectly cooked vegetables-- peppers, broccoli and carrots-- that were tender without being mushy. The place is quite small so I can see why everyone gets their order to go but I went at 230pm so there were only two other people eating there. Overall, my dish was yummers and I would definitely go back.
author: stykkisholmur t.

description:
I was introduced to this almost hole-in-the-wall (I mean size-wise) by a Japanese colleague, and had an extra spicy katsu curry. This stuff is amazing! 

We got three seats by the window, and watching the world go by while eating my katsu kare took me all the way back to my time in Tokyo (I lived there for three years). The staff is Japanese too.
author: Josh L.

description: One of my favorite dishes in Japan is Katsu Curry, if you like breaded fried pork and curry, you're going to love this.  Highly recommend, they make your food to order so expect to wait especially during the lunch time rush.  Japanese owned and made =  delicious and authentic tasting curry.  The curry flavor reminds me of curry in Japan.  Its the flavor of the curry that makes this place a hidden secret.  Plan on taking your food to go as there are only a few places to sit.
author: David S.

description:
Katsu curry! It was my first time there and it was awesome.  It makes me miss Japan.  The katsu was perfect :) nice and crunchy outside and generous portion.  the amount of curry they give u is good too, I had a lot left over and thats amazing for me.  It gets super busy during lunch so I'd suggest ordering before u get there cuz we waited a while for our food.  My friend got the oyako-don and I think she didn't like it as much as the katsu.

I'll definitely be going back for lunch :)  gonna try the ebi fry next time!
author: S T.

description:
this place is good for a fast meal, when you're on-the-go.  the curry was only ok, i actually make a mean curry at home.  the additional charge for adding vegetables in the curry is ridiculous.  why not just add a spoonful of frozen veggies for no charge?  spinach in curry?  weird.
the saba shioyaki was good!  the owners were super-friendly!  i'd give it another try when i'm in the area.
author: Big e.

description: Went here the other day, ordered the chicken katsu with medium curry and was happily filled for lunch! Inari was good as well. Note - the curry isn't all that spicy so if you want any spice, I'd go with spiciest they have. Great place for lunch! Prices reasonable. Good job Yelp!
author: Con L.

description:
A cute, clean, Japanese curry place, but evil.  

Why?  ... Because I watched an Oprah inspired by Prop 2 where she showed conventional narrow cages for breeding pigs forlornly looking out though the bars ...  Then she showed a "free-range" pig farm where happy swine cavorted through a meadow, emitting periodic joyful grunts.  I swore then that I would only eat free-range pork unless absolutely necessary.

Fast forward 12 hours.  I am at Muracci's.  I smell tonkatsu and order the tonkatsu curry, stomach growling.  I eat it all back in my office.  As I lick my curry bowl clean, only then do I remember my vow from the night before.  

I'm pretty sure that wasn't free-range pork.  But I'm not really sorry.  And I choose to blame Muracci's.
author: Gina C.

description: not sure when it opened, but it is in the old shop where the english pasties used to be.  very crowded at lunch time - get here early or wait.  veggie curry is good.  not sure that it is my style, but it was very good for what it was supposed to be.  fairly efficient staff, considering the micro size and the line out the door.
author: Jeremy S.

description: Good stuff, great with brown rice which is offered w/o extra charge.  I had the express beef curry and it WAS express.  Beef is tender like beef stew and the curry was enough for two servings of the rice.  I do wish they put carrots in for some veggie besides the pickled cabbage...definitely a repeat for me...
author: Diana C.

description:
Yeah, it's that good.  It's tasty, it's creamy, it's spicy (if you want it to be) and it comes with something fried!  I really love this place.  It's consistently good.  And the owners are so nice in there.  My favorite is definitely the ebi fry curry - can't really get a good fried shrimp with curry elsewhere in the city.  Their chicken katsu and pork katsu curry are pretty good too.  I have to be honest, haven't tried much else on their menu (i figure it's a curry place, so i get the curry!) but it sounds like other people come back for the other stuff (terriyaki, sushi, udon noodles).

It definitely gets crowded during the lunch hour.  My only gripe is that it's not opened later in the evening and on the weekends.  It's kind of tough on the stomach (and figure) to have curry and fried stuff midday and then sit on your butt the rest of the afternoon at work...  Hey, but it's worth it!  Maybe next time I'll get the brown rice just to be healthier...ha ha!
author: Ming Y.

description: Had lunch there a couple of days ago, had the ebi curry per recommendation from a friend. It's alright, the curry is tasty and the price prices are affordable. Their curry isn't excellent and they use the familiar S&B curry powder used for most wafu curry recipes. Though I can definitely make a similar wafu style curry sauce on my own, this is a good place for lunch. The portions are big, though the place is tiny. It's something different for every once in awhile.
author: Sheena L.

description: If you work downtown and love japanese curry, this is the place to go.  This place is always busy, sometimes there's a line out the door.  That's only a testament to how good the food is here though.  The katsu and ebi-fry are my favorites there.  The spicy curry is also a must.  The food here reminds me of good old home style cooking  They also have weekly specials served in limited quantities daily.  Something like 10 to 15 orders of the specials are available a day.  I would have given Muracci's five stars but sometimes the wait is just too long.  But that's the only bad thing about this place.
author: Shane Y.

description: I love curry. I love curry so much that I make my own. This is the first place that can top mine, and mine comes highly rated. First, the staff is super friendly and efficient. Even though the line was out the door, folks were in and out with in a few minutes. The place is small, about six to ten seats, so take out is highly recommended. The selection is very good, curries with choice of meat (or not), spice level (and there hot is hot! Not overwhelming, but not most places wimpy hot), and white or brown rice (at no extra charge!) There are a few non-curry main dishes, plenty of side dishes and a few desserts. Plus they serve Lupicia Teas, which are by and far some of the yummiest teas I have had. The portions are very generous. For about $11, I got a huge chicken curry with brown rice, two kinds of Japanese pickles, and a side of endemame. I would happily make the hike over to here again and again (and by hike I mean 20 min walk from my office).
author: Jennifer W.

description:
I came here last month with some coworkers and had a good experience. It was pretty crowded so we waited a while both to oder and for our food but it wasn't Too long of a wait. It'd probably be easier to call ahead and just get it to go.

I had the katsu curry which was really good. The katsu was perfectly fried, nice and crispy. And the curry sauce was served on the side so the katsu didn't get soggy.  I got mine mild which was good for me.  My coworkers got medium and said that was spicy enough. We also tried the roll cakes for dessert- chocolate and green tea.  The green tea one was only ok, I think the chocolate was better.

Go again? Yes, definitely. I would definitely go and order the katsu curry again, maybe get it with spinach next time, probably skip the dessert.
author: J L.

description: I shouldn't do it, I shouldn't do it, I know I shouldn't do it!! Once again I decided I would try a Yelper favorite - and once again I am left wondering who you morons are that recommend places like this on Yelp? I keep promising myself I am going to STOP going to places that Yelper's go nuts about - it is almost always a losing proposition. So here I was at Muracci's last week at 11:30 ordering the Yelper favorite - Katsu Curry - and it was good - not terrible - but nothing more than OK curry. As a bonus it is rather pricey for what you end up with and the staff is rather unpleasant. WOW - let's stand in line for this joint huh fellow Yelpers?? Make another trip to this four star curry joint? Not a chance.
author: stephanie d.

description: I don't understand why this place has such good reviews.  They were out of white rice and my lunch was prep'ed with brown rice.  Could this why?  Very small place.  Extremely busy.
author: J S.

description: fantastic. ive been in san francisco a while now, and ive completely forgotten about japanese curry. before muraccis, i would even know where to go to get good japanese curry, and im so happy now ive found this place. the beef curry is excellent - they serve it to you right away. the breaded curry pan is an appetizer i like to start off with too. the katsu is excellent as well. their curry is just the right amount of potent thickness. i am definitely frequenting this place, im going to try the noodles next!
author: Angie K.

description: I finally made the trek up to SF from the Peninsula on a weekday to try out this place.  It was well worth the trip.  Muracci's is a small lunch counter restaurant in the financial district whose curry sauce is as authentic as the ones I've tried in Japan.  The flavor is excellent and beats any other curry I've tried in the states.  The pork tonkatsu in the katsu curry was well done as well, with tender but well fried pork without greasiness.  The side of cabbage salad provides a nice balance and the pickled ginger goes well with the curry and rice.  The only downside is that it isn't open on the weekends, otherwise a true comfort food haven.
author: Peter L.

description: Best katsu curry I've had outside of Asia.
author: Scott S.

description: it's just a race to see what expands first - my waistline or their business.
author: Mooni P.

description: arrived at about 1:45 on a monday afternoon looking for a solid lunch in the financial district. ordered the chicken curry over brown rice (hot) and waited about 10-15 minutes to get my food. it wasn't even rush hour. apparently, i was the last one able to get rice that day as their rice cooker broke? at 6.95 plus tax, i expected a good amount of chicken and curry. i instead received super meager portions of dark chicken meat and curry that could barely be called spicy. if that's their best effort at their spiciest curry, then that was epic failure. the curry itself was tasty, but it was nothing special. it could have been made from curry powder for all i knew. inside the take-out box was a thin layer of rice, a few pickled cabbage slices, and an extra parsimonious sauce container with regular cabbage. what did i pay for here? the service was friendly, but the wait was long, and i ate an elf's lunch that could have easily been cooked at home. the yelping community kind of failed me here.
author: Danny C.

description: okay, so i'm kind of embarrassed because today was my first time having japanese curry.  how is that possible???  i'm not sure but went here for lunch today on a recommendation and was pretty blown away.  i had the chicken katsu and it was sooooooo good.  the curry sauce had so much flavor, it was unbelievable.  and the chicken was breaded and cooked just right.  had a bite of the pork katsu and the beef curry also... also quite amazing.  what an awesome addition to offset the dizzying amounts of bland and boring lunch options in the financial district.  i knew that weird pot pie place wouldn't last... so glad something good took its place!
author: Yvette H.

description: How have I not already reviewed this place?  This place is off the chain - I've had Japanese curry before but never like this.  Seriously, you will be dreaming about this place for the rest of the day after only one trip here.  One con about this place is that it's tiny but as long as they keep cranking out their delicious food, I am happy to get it to go (rather than squeezing myself into one of the like, 6 available stools/chairs) and eat outside.  I've tried their katsu curry as well as their hot noodle curry soup bowls - highly recommend both of them!  You might have to restrain yourself from licking your plate/bowl, it's that good.  They also offer Japanese drinks and sweet treats.  I recommend calling in your order so that you don't have to wait inside the cramped space.  The staff is very fast and nice, if not a bit frenetic - I would be too if I were trying to serve all these people desperate for some Muracci's to brighten up their FiDi week.  A true gem in the FiDi, I wish there was one in every neighborhood!
author: Suzanne V.

description: Really, really good food. A expensive lunch but worth it. Katsu Pork is amazing and the portion size is perfect. What's better than crispy pork in a delicious curry, so many great flavors that you can't stop eating. The karokke is delicious as well, especially when mixed in the curry. Friendly great service!
author: Neil A.

description: The food was quite good.  Before this, I was not much of a Japanese curry fan, but after I heard from a bunch of friends, I gave it a shot.  I had the pork katsu with white rice.  The pork was crispy, but moist.  Overall, I would definitely go back.
author: Andy V.

description: i was staying in chinatown for the weekend and didn't know where to eat. came on yelp and read about muracci's. "this sounds too good to be true," i thought to myself as i read the reviews. i planned out to find this mysterious little place and eat their curry, and when i did i wasn't disappointed! it was pretty awesome. i got the katsu curry (after reading recommendations on here) and it was good. might want to ask for extra curry sauce since i ran out towards the end. the actual place is indeed really small, with only a handful of seats. but i went on a saturday so it was relatively empty. when i went they told me that they wouldn't be open on saturdays anymore, so i felt really lucky.
author: jon c.

description: Okay, I am torn on this.  I give this four stars for authenticity, but in reality I want to only give it three stars.  The main reason for that is that I actually don't like Japanese curry, but I lived there for 5 years, and now it has the nostalgia factor going for it.  Not only was it spot on as Japanese curry, the location itself is like sitting in Tokyo all over again, except with a few too many white people wandering around.  The owners are super nice, and the other food that I do like, such as the potato croquette, was awesome.
author: Daniel M.

description: This place is great.  I always get katsu curry and it is always what I remembered about it...EXCELLENT!  The line gets very long during lunchtime, so allow yourself some extra time.
author: Nick H.

description: All I have to say is this place is good.  Yummy and tasty.
author: Connie J.

description: the BEST Japanese curry in the area...it gets pretty crowded so I usually call in my order and just pick it up...the staff are friendly too.
author: j s.

description: talk about REAL japanese food. you won't hear any mis pronounced "irashaimasei's" in here. curry anything is good. my favorite is probably the curry udon. they sell pre packaged mochi and tsukemonos (pickled stuff). i'd eat here every day if rice didn't make me fat.
author: Al I.

description: Decent place, just seemed slightly overpriced for simple Japanese food.  Will go back again.
author: Weihan W.

description: I love curry!  And I love curry from here, even though I always end up ordering the same thing...Katsu Curry.  It is delish!  The wait can be long during the lunch time rush but hey there's no other place like this, especially in the FiDi.  I also like that is authentic Japanese food made by Japanese people...none of this Chinese-made Japanese stuff...c'mon people! The place is small so you'll be lucky to get a seat.  I'll have to convince myself to try some of their other dishes next time around...
author: Quyen Q.

description: best japanese curry in the city! a great place to eat for lunch and a good price for what you get. the only problem is that it gets a little busy during the lunch hour. i guess that's the mark of a great restaurant. to avoid some of the rush, you can call in your order. they also only have about 8 seats inside the small joint. take it to go and eat at the top of crocker galleria.
author: Katrina S.

description: Our lunch gang went to this place inspired by Yelp ratings. The crowds there seemed to think so too. However service was as quick as they could make it. The food is definitely fresh. It is clean too. However I did think it was lacking in flavor. One of us had the daily special of that day which was vegetarian. I had the tofu and veggies in brown rice. Though we had asked for medium spicy the food was not as tasty as I expected.
author: Chandra I.

description: Curry is quite good, but I've gone there a total of 5 times and they've gotten my order wrong 3 times!  Not cool when you discover this back at the office -- just getting ready to tuck in and your tofu is beef.  This was after they carefully reviewed my order (which was only for one person, for god's sake).  Plus, they recently took soba noodles off the menu, so I won't be going back.
author: Dennis H.

description:
got the katsu curry, and my friend got the salmon curry. both at the "hot" like fire level - think aaliyah like the song .. !!

overall it was good and satiating, however the amount of curry sauce was not enough for "my belly" think austin powers hahah. so i was thinking about getting more but was too bloated to buy it. the katsu of my curry was also very salty, saltier than normal. not sure why, or if its just me or if it was the curry that tricked me into thinking the katsu was salty! :0

i guess i'd come back, since the staff were nice, seems family owned?
author: Porkers T.

description: I love this spot! Fresh ingredients that you can taste and a warm reception every time you visit this small eatery. My favorite dish is not the curry (although yummy), but the chicken katsu lunch set. Everything is cooked to order which makes a huge difference. The wait time can be long, so I suggest calling in your order beforehand. If you call after 12noon, they sometimes won't answer. Great small spot in the Financial District!!!
author: Jamie S.

description: I've been coming here since this place opened and love it. So far I've only stuck to what the place specializes (and the agedashi tofu). I love the curry - and I get it spicy for the dulling of the tasting buds, although it's bearable spicy (at least for me). The line is long - so just call your order in advance. Portions are huge - I generally share with a co-worker (saves money + saves the overbulging stomach of a young woman). So as far as agedashi tofu goes, it's "okay", but not as good as going to a more traditional sit down restaurant. I think the problem lies in the fact that by the time you get to your desk its' a bit soggy and it doesn't have that crisp that agedashi tofu should have. I won't ever reject tofu though - soy lover for life.
author: Jeannette L.

description: It seems like they run out of sushi really quick .. every time I get there ( around 2ish , 3 , or 4 ) , they're always sold out !! They don't have much selection though .. only California roll , avocado roll , and cucumber roll . Very simple & not creative at all . The California roll is only $3.25 and it's okay but it's not all that great . I've tried the salmon curry which was alright . The salmon was very tasty and delicious . The curry was okay .. they asked me if I wanted mild or hot . I asked for hot which turned out to be a little spicy . It tasted like they put a little bit of wasabi in the curry . The salmon curry came with one piece of salmon , one mound of rice , and very very little homemade radish sprinkled on top of the rice . All for what ? 8 ?! It was such a rip off !! I've also tried their green salad which was okay except they didn't provide enough dressing !! The potatoe salad is really good though .
author: Eileen L.

description: My cubie was craving curry and this place had such good reviews that we decided to brave the 15 block journey during lunch rush just to see for ourselves. It was totally worth the trek. The menu includes non-curry options but why would you go to a Japanese curry house and not order curry? I thought it was interesting that one of their add on options is cheese. I didn't try it but my friend who lived in Tokyo for a few years raved about the cheesy curry she had in the curry shops in Japan. I think I'll try that next time. Our food was very tasty but I feel that the spiciness rating was inaccurate. I ordered the Chicken Curry Ramen Soup in Hot and feel like what I got was actually medium. Granted, my taste buds have probably been completely burned off from my vapid consumption of Flaming Hot Cheetos while growing up but it feels like they simmered down the spicy levels to suit a more sensitive palette. There's nothing wrong w/ being consumer friendly though. I wish this place was closer to my office so I could eat here more often but it's probably better that it's far away... My officemates would probably not want me to smell like curry after lunch every day...
author: Queenie C.

description: You know, there's a reason this place is located in the FiDi-it's as bland as all the salary women and men in the FiDi! My boss, who doesn't like things spicy, had to borrow some of my co-worker's spicy curry to put over her mild curry! The mild curry was virtually tasteless. This place is also not as fast as they'll have you believe-I had three orders of curry and a Donburri-it took a good 15, 20 minutes. The taste of the curry was bland and wasn't very hearty-do they really simmer it for two days with veggies and meats? The meats, esp. in my Donburri did not taste particularly fresh. My Donburri was boring-plain and simple. I wonder if they had to tone it down for the folks that can't handle ethnic food-they need to pick it up a notch! The prices are steep for the portion and taste (really, pushing $9 for curry/!!). After Japan, I was hoping for a place that would be decent enough to satisfy my cravings-Muracci's didn't do it for me.
author: Jenny W.

description: I gave Muracci's 3 stars only because the wait was SO long. I even waited til after peak hours (or so I thought) and I still had to wait a good 30 minutes. I even tried to pre order via phone, and I wasn't able to get through on the line, so I just had to suck it up walk over and wait in the line. I get the fact that they make every order fresh, but really, it shouldn't take 30 minutes to get a lunch that's supposedly fast food. Otherwise, it would have easily been 4 stars. I had the hot katsu curry with extra veggies and the curry had a great depth and complexity of flavor. It was spicy, but not too spicy and had clearly been long simmered. The katsu was crisp and had a nice panko crust. Inside the pork was juicy.  Unfortunately, my "extra" vegetables turned out to be a coupl eof pieces of broccoli and a slice of carrot. In any case, I'll be back, but at a really weird hour, just to ensure that I don't die of hunger next time smelling those yummy curry smells waiting in Muracci's doorway.
author: Jennifer C.

description: The food is reasonably priced but lacks flavor. The spicy chicken curry wasn't spicy. The terriyaki salmon lunch meal came with a lot of food but also wasn't very flavorful.
author: Molly B.

description: Good food. Best if there is little line.  Will usually only go here if when walking by there is a small line.  Otherwise it can take a long time to get your food.
author: Brian S.

description: I've been here a few times now and I love this place! I tend to eat later in the day so I've never had a super long wait. I went in around 1:45 today and my lunch was ready in 5 minutes. My review might be a little skewed since I've only ordered one thing: vegetable and tofu curry with brown rice and added spinach. Yum. I've also had the green tea roll cake, which was good, but not great. I had never eaten Japanese curry before so I can't vouch for authenticity, but it sure is delicious.
author: Rekha S.

description: Authentic Japanese Curry, just like they make in Japan, served by people who know how it's done!  Make sure to get there before 11:40 or after 12:45 if you want to avoid a long lunch line.
author: Josh J.

description: Do not get the ramen here.  It's the worst I've ever eaten, including the awful bagged kind I haven't touched since my student days.  The noodles were tasteless and overcooked, it was greasy, there was almost no beef and what meat there was was dry.  The vegetables were underdone and a very weird combination for ramen - large chunks of bell pepper and some wilted brocolli.  I checked it out because it's closer to my office than Katana-ya - it is so, so worth the extra walk to avoid this place.
author: Daed L.

description: I guess you shouldn't order the curry spicy (like I did last time) because it ends up overpowering the taste so I went with medium this time.  Also got my curry with tonkatsu since everyone on here says it's the bomb, boy was it goooood. Midway through making my order they told me there was no more potatoes which really bummed me out so they offered to substitute it with another extra, nothing on the menu interested me but the potatoes but I really didn't want them to go through the trouble of refunding my money since they were really busy so I substituted with a boiled egg; imagine my suprise when I opened my togo container to find not only the boiled egg but the potatoes I had wanted in the first place as well so that definately earns them an extra star. The curry wasn't watery like last time neither so i guess I just went on a bad day last time. I guess it helps when a restaurant gets alot of good reviews on yelp cause I might've never came back here which I'm glad I did. Glad I work nearby now. Only thing that sucks about the place now is that it gets crowded but that's really not their fault..oh wait it is since their curry is the bomb!!!
author: Mike A.

description: Excellent food....veggie and tofu curry is the best!  The 40 minute wait is tough but if you call ahead with your order you can just go to the front of the line and pick it up.  This food is awesome...very fresh and perfectly prepared.
author: Amy T.

description: It's not a huge menu but it's exactly what it claims to be: a curry house, no more, no less.  Every kind of Japanese curry there is in the options of mild, medium or hot.  This place is so freaking good.  My mouth is watering thinking about it.  I love the katsu curry which was astounding by the way... amazingly juicy and tender in an ultra crisp coating-there is actually a distinctive crunching sound when the chef slices the katsu into pieces!  The curry is blow your mind tasty though... that is the real go getter.  I had the mild so I didn't have too much spice barring the taste factor.  It's really good stuff!  The pricing is relatively inexpensive but when you consider the size of their portions, I'd say it is downright cheap... for the katsu at least... my friend had the grilled salmon and that did look quite a bit stingier in size... (less than half of my serving?)  My other friend had the chicken curry though and not only did they get a large serving of chicken that looked like my pork katsu, they also had chicken pieces served in their curry sauce.  I love the house made neon pink super crunchy pickles (I think it's ume plum flavored daikon?) on the side. And I really like that you have the option of white or brown rice.  The seating is extremely limited in this tiny dinky little place but it's easily taken to go and enjoyed elsewhere.  The service is extremely fast which is a big plus for me although the line can also be extremely long because of how many other customers who love this spot.  I also really liked the fried sweet potato croquette.  Very thick, very crisp on the outside, very fresh warm like and fluffy on the inside.  All kinds of yummy. So on my second run, I ordered the special of the month which was the Muracci's Spicy Noodles: Ground Beef, Onion, Green Onion, Hot Chili Pepper, in the house curry sauce over dry ramen noodles.  The noodles had a nice chewy texture without being too firm and the whole dish was a perfect level of saucey without being soggy.  I think they really have their perfect formula down at this place.  It's my ever consistent cheap eats love.
author: Angela W.

description: the family is japanese, so  this is authentic japanese cooking (not korean like some other places in town).  a tiny place with bar/counter seating only. packed and busy at lunch time.  $8.50 for the chicken katsu with curry. comes with rice and japanese pickles.  the chicken breast was a thick piece so it was a bit dry and too much chicken vs. katsu.  but the katsu fried crumb was perfect.  usually katsu is made from pork so i'm sure they have that down.  will definitely go back.  i took mine to the square and ate.
author: Yelper S.
